title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 33

dialogue.speaker: Announcer

dialogue.text: The Adventures of Biggles. Part one - Biggles dictates a letter.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Miss Bladder, take a letter.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: (Nicki Howorth) Yes, Señor Biggles.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Don't call me señor! I'm not a Spanish person. You must call me Mr Biggles, or Group Captain Biggles or Mary Biggles if I'm dressed as my wife, but never señor.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: I've never even been to Spain.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: You went to Ibiza last year.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: That's still not grounds for calling me señor, or Don Beeg-les for that matter. Right, Dear King Haakon...

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Of Norway, is that?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Just put down what I say.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Do I put that down?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Of course you don't put that down.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Well what about that?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Look. Don't put that down. Just put down - wait a mo - wait a mo. Now, when I've got these antlers on - when I've got these antlers on I dictating and when I take them off I am dictating.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: I am not dictating.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: What? Read that back.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Dear King Haakon, I am not dictating what?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: No, no, no, you loopy brothel inmate.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: I've had enough of this. I am not a courtesan.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Oh, oh, 'courtesan', oh aren't we grand. Harlot's not good enough for us eh? Paramour, concubine, fille de joie. That's what we are not. Well listen to me my fine fellow, you are a bit of tail, that's what you are.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: I am not, you demented fictional character.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Algy says you are. He says you're no better than you should be.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: And how would know?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: And just what do you mean by that? Are you calling my old fictional comrade-in-arms a fairy?

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Fairy! Poof's not good enough for Algy, is it? He's got to be a bleedin' fairy. Mincing old RAF queen.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Algy, I have to see you.

dialogue.speaker: Algy
dialogue.text: Right ho. What ho everyone.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Are you gay?

dialogue.speaker: Algy
dialogue.text: I should bally well say so, old fruit.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Ugh! Dear King Haakon ... oh ... Dear King Haakon. Just a line to thank you for the eels. Mary thought they were really scrummy, comma, so did I full stop. I've just heard that Algy was a poof, exclamation mark. What would Captain W. E. Johns have said, question mark. Sorry to mench, but if you've finished with the lawn-edger could you pop it in the post. Love Biggles, Algy deceased and Ginger. Ginger!

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Rhyming slang - ginger beer.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Ginger.

dialogue.speaker: Ginger
dialogue.text: Hello, sweetie.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: I have to see you.

dialogue.speaker: Ginger
dialogue.text: Yes, Biggles?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Are you a poof

dialogue.speaker: Ginger
dialogue.text: I should say not.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Thank God for that. Good lad. Stout fellow, salt of the earth, backbone of England. Funny, he looks like a poof. Dear Princess Margaret.

dialogue.speaker: Margaret
dialogue.text: Hello.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Get back in the cupboard you pantomimetic royal person.

dialogue.speaker: Loony
dialogue.text: Lemon curry?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Dear real Princess Margaret, thank you for the eels, full stop. They were absolutely delicious and unmistakably regal, full stop. Sorry to mench but if you've finished with the hairdryer could you pop it in the post? Yours fictionally Biggles, Oh, PS see you at the Saxe-Coburgs' canasta evening. That should puzzle her.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Si Señor Biggles.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Silence, naughty lady of the night!

dialogue.text: Next week part two - 'Biggles Flies Undone'.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Meanwhile not very far away.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Climbing. The world's loneliest sport, where hardship and philosophy go hand in glove. And here, another British expedition, attempting to be the first man to successfully climb the north face of the Uxbridge Road. This four-man rope has been climbing tremendously. BBC cameras were there to film every inch.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: The major assault on the Uxbridge Road has been going on for about three weeks, really ever since they established base camp here at the junction of Willesden Road, and from there they climbed steadily to establish camp two, outside Lewis's, and it's taken them another three days to establish camp three, here outside the post office. Well they've spent a good night in there last night in preparation for the final assault today. The leader of the expedition is twenty-nine-year-old Bert Tagg - a local headmaster and mother of three.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Bert. How's it going?

dialogue.speaker: Bert
dialogue.text: Well, it's a bit gripping is this, Chris. I've got to try and reach that bus stop in an hour or so and I'm doing it by... damn ... I'm doing it, er, by laying back on this gutter so I'm kind of guttering and laying back at the same time, and philosophizing.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Bert, some people say this is crazy.

dialogue.speaker: Bert
dialogue.text: Aye, well but they said Crippen was crazy didn't they?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Crippen crazy.

dialogue.speaker: Bert
dialogue.text: Oh, well there you are then. John, I'm sending you down this carabiner on white.

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: Lemon curry?

dialogue.speaker: Bert
dialogue.text: Now you see he's putting a peg down there because I'm quite a way up now, and if I come unstuck here I go down quite a long way.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Such quiet courage is typical of the way these brave chaps shrug off danger. Like it or not, you've got to admire the skill that goes into it.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Good evening and welcome to another edition of 'Storage Jars'. On tonight's programme Mikos Antoniarkis, the Greek rebel leader who seized power in Athens this morning, tells us what he keeps in storage jars. From strife-torn Bolivia, Ronald Rodgers reports on storage jars there. And closer to home, the first dramatic pictures of the mass jail-break near the storage jar factory in Maidenhead. All this and more in 'Storage Jars'!

dialogue.speaker: Rodgers
dialogue.text: This is La Paz, Bolivia, behind me you can hear the thud of mortars and the high-pitched whine of rockets, as the battle for control of this volatile republic shakes the foundations of this old city. But whatever their political inclinations these Bolivians are all keen users of storage jars. Here the largest size is used for rice and for mangoes - a big local crop. Unlike most revolutionary South American states they've an intermediary size in between the 2 lb and 5 lb jars. This gives this poor but proud people a useful jar for apricots, plums and stock cubes. The smallest jar - this little 2oz jar, for sweets, chocolates and even little shallots. No longer used in the West it remains here as an unspoken monument to the days when La Paz knew better times. Ronald Rodgers, 'Storage Jars', La Paz.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Tussaud
dialogue.text: Hello, the, er, show so far...well it all started with the organist losing all his clothes as he sat down at the organ, and after this had happened and we had seen the titles of the show, we saw Biggles dictating a letter to his secretary, who thought he was Spanish, and whom he referred to as a harlot and a woman of the night, although she preferred to be called a courtesan. Then we saw some people trying to climb a road in Uxbridge. And then there were some cartoons and then some lifeboatmen came into a woman's sitting room and after a bit the woman went out to buy some cakes on a lifeboat and then a naval officer jumped into the sea. Then we saw a man telling us about storage jars from Bolivia, then there were some more cartoons and a man told us about what happened on the show so far and a great hammer came down and hit him on the head. I don't remember that?

dialogue.speaker: Mousebender
dialogue.text: Good Morning. I was sitting in the public library on Thurmon Street just now, skimming through 'Rogue Herries' by Horace Walpole, when suddenly I came over all peckish.

dialogue.speaker: Wensleydale
dialogue.text: Peckish, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Mousebender
dialogue.text: Esurient.

dialogue.speaker: Wensleydale
dialogue.text: Eh?

dialogue.speaker: Mousebender
dialogue.text: Eee I were all hungry, like!

dialogue.speaker: Wensleydale
dialogue.text: Oh, hungry.

dialogue.speaker: Mousebender
dialogue.text: In a nutshell. So I thought to myself, 'a little fermented curd will do the trick'. So I curtailed my Walpolling activites, sallied forth and infiltrated your place of purveyance to negotiate the vending of some cheesy comestibles.

dialogue.speaker: Wensleydale
dialogue.text: Come again.

dialogue.speaker: Mousebender

dialogue.speaker: Wensleydale

dialogue.speaker: Mousebender

dialogue.speaker: Mousebender
dialogue.text: I like a nice dance - you're forced to.

dialogue.text: Tish tish. No matter. Well, four ounces of Caerphilly, then, if you please, stout yeoman.

dialogue.speaker: Philip Jenkinson
dialogue.text: Horace Walpole's 'Rogue Cheddar', one of the first of the Cheese Westerns to be later followed by 'Gunfight at Gruyère Corral', 'Ilchester 73', and 'The Cheese Who Shot Liberty Valence'. While I'm on the subject of Westerns, I want to take a closer look at one of my favourite film directors, Sam Peckinpah, the expatriate from Fresno, California.

dialogue.speaker: Philip Jenkinson
dialogue.text: In his earliest films, 'Major Dundee',

dialogue.speaker: Philip Jenkinson
dialogue.text: 'The Wild Bunch' and 'Straw Dogs' he showed his predilection for the utterly truthful and very sexually arousing portrayal of violence in its starkest form.

dialogue.speaker: Philip Jenkinson
dialogue.text: In his latest film Peckinpah has moved into the calmer and more lyrical waters of Julian Slade's, 'Salad Days'.

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'SALAD DAYS (1971) DIRECTOR SAM PECKINPAH'

dialogue.speaker: Lionel
dialogue.text: Hello everybody.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Hello Lionel.

dialogue.speaker: Lionel
dialogue.text: I say what a simply super day.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Gosh yes.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: It's so, you know, sunny.

dialogue.speaker: Lionel
dialogue.text: Yes isn't it? I say anyone for tennis?

dialogue.speaker: Julian
dialogue.text: Oh super!

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: What fun.

dialogue.speaker: Julian
dialogue.text: I say, Lionel, catch.

dialogue.speaker: Lionel
dialogue.text: Oh gosh.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Oh crikey.

dialogue.speaker: Philip Jenkinson
dialogue.text: Pretty strong meat there from Sam Peckinpah.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'THE BBC WOULD LIKE TO APOLOGIZE TO EVERYONE IN THE WORLD FOR THE LAST ITEM. IT WAS DISGUSTING AND BAD AND THOROUGHLY DISOBEDIENT AND PLEASE DON'T BOTHER TO PHONE UP BECAUSE WE KNOW IT WAS VERY TASTELESS, BUT THEY DIDN'T REALLY MEAN IT AND THEY DO ALL COME FROM BROKEN HOMES AND HAVE VERY UNHAPPY PERSONAL LIVES, ESPECIALLY ERIC. ANYWAY, THEY'RE REALLY VERY NICE PEOPLE UNDERNEATH AND VERY WARM IN THE TRADITIONAL SHOW BUSINESS WAY AND PLEASE DON'T WRITE IN EITHER BECAUSE THE BBC IS GOING THROUGH AN UNHAPPY PHASE AT THE MOMENT - WHAT WITH ITS FATHER DYING AND THE MORTGAGE AND BBC 2 GOING OUT WITH MEN.'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: : 'THE BBC WOULD LIKE TO DENY THE LAST APOLOGY. IT IS VERY HAPPY AT HOME AND BBC 2 IS BOUND TO GO THROUGH THIS PHASE, SO FROM ALL OF US HERE GOOD NIGHT, SLEEP WELL, AND HAVE AN ABSOLUTELY SUPER DAY TOMORROW, KISS, KISS.'

dialogue.speaker: Richard Baker
dialogue.text: We've just heard that an explosion in the kitchens of the House of Lords has resulted in the breakage of seventeen storage jars. Police ruled out foul play. Lemon curry?

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Um, I'm sorry about the ... the, er, pause, only I'm afraid the show is a couple of minutes short this week. You know, sometimes the shows aren't really quite as er, long as they ought to be. Beautiful, isn't it. Look there's not really a great deal of point in your, sort of hanging on at your end, because I'm afraid there aren't any more jokes or anything.

annotations: A light comes up on an organ in the centre of a concert-hall stage. Applause. The organist with wild hair (Terry J) appears from left. He walks fully clothed across to the organ looking pleased with himself. He sits at the organ and raises his hands...his clothes fly up in the air so that, as per normal, he is naked. He plays the usual chords. Cut on the last note to a naked quartet with identical grins, fright wigs and blacked-out teeth staring maniacally at the camera.
Animated titles.
Cut to stock film of First World War fighter planes in a dog-fight. Heroic war music.
Mix through to Biggles and secretary in an office.
(she types)
(puts on antlers)
(takes them off)
(types)
(she types; puts the antlers on)
(moves round to front of the desk, sits on it and crosses her legs provocatively)
(sits at the desk)
(into the intercom)
(he enters)
(he shoots him)
(takes the antlers off)
(the secretary types)
(puts the antlers on)
(into the intercom)
The door opens, Ginger enters as a terrible poof in camp flying gear, sequins, eye make-up, silver stars on his cheeks.
(camp outrage)
(Ginger exits)
(takes off the antlers)
Pantomime Princess Margaret enters from cupboard.
(she goes)
Quick cut to a loony.
Cut back to Biggles.
(puts the antlers on)
(sexily)
Bring up heroic music and mix through to stock film of fighter planes in dog-fight.
Then a very noisy and violent animation sketch.
Cut to mountain climbers, with all the accoutrements: ropes, carabino's, helmets, pitons, hammers, etc. They are roped together, apparently climbing a mountain.
(Pull out to reveal that they are climbing along a wide pavement; a shopper pushing a pram comes into shot)

Cut to a BBC cameraman clinging to a lamppost, filming. He is wearing climbing gear too. Cut to papier mache model of the Uxbridge Road, with the route all neatly marked out in white, and various little pins for the camps.
(voice over)
(cut to a pup tent being firmly planted on the side of a large post-box; it has a little union jack on it.)
Cut to Bert crawling along the pavement. The interviewer is crouching down beside him.
(heavy breathing interspersed)
(rearranging rope)
(shouts)
(there is a white rope between Bert and John)
Quick cut to Viking.
Cut back to the street.
(leaving him)
By the miracle of stop action, they all fall off the road, back down the pavement. Passers-by, also in stop action, walk by normally, ignoring the fall.
(taking off his sou'wester and shaking the water off it)

The First Lifeboatman puts on his sou'wester, goes over to the back door and opens it, He peers out. Sound of wind and lashing rain. Cut to the back door at the side of a suburban home, the lifeboatman looking out over the lawns, flowers and windless, rainless calm across to similar neat suburban houses. The noise cuts. The liftboatman withdraws his head from the door. Sound of wind and rain again which cease abruptly as he withdraws his head and shuts the door.
The door flies open. More sound of wind and rain. Two other rain-soaked lifeboatmen appear.
The two lifeboatmen look at each other, then turn and open the door. Sound of wind and rain as usual. They peer out. Cut to the back door - the two lifeboatmen are peering out. They shout.

Their voices carry over the following shot or two. Cut to reverse angle of window across the road. A net curtain moves and an eye peers out. We still hear the shouts. Close up on an elderly spinster (Gladys) holding the net curtain discreetly ajar.

We pull out to reveal a sitting room full of high-powered eavesdropping equipment, i.e. an enormous telescope on wheels with a controller's chair attached to it, several subsidiary telescopes pointing out of the window, radar scanners going round and round, two computers with flashing lights, large and complex tape and video recorders, several TV monitors, oscilloscopes, aerials, etc. All these have been squeezed in amongst the furniture of two retired middle-class old ladies. Enid, a dear old lady with a bun, sits at the control seat of an impressive-looking console, pressing buttons. She also has some knitting.
(looking at the array of telescopes)

Gladys leaps over to the tape deck, presses levers and switches. Sound of tape reversing. There is a hum and lights flash on and off. A blurred image of a lady in the street comes up on one of the monitors.
(reading a graph on a computer)

(she dips into the control seat of the huge mobile telescope; we cut to the view through Gladys's telescope - out of focus at first, but then sharper as she zooms in towards the side door of Number 24)
(the curtain is opened a little)
Cut to the interior of Mrs Neves's kitchen once again. It is absolutely full of lifeboatmen. They are all talking happily and drinking cups of tea. We pick up the conversation between two them.

She puts a scarf on, picks up a basket and goes out of the front door. As she opens door, we hear the sound of a storm which carries us into the next shot. Cut to the deck of a lifeboat; rain-lashed, heaving, wind-tossed Mrs Neves struggles against the gale force winds along the deck. She hammers on a hatch in the forward part of the lifeboat.
The hatch opens and a cosy shop-keeping pepperpot sticks her head out.
(sound of a ship's horn; they both look)
(she produces a loudhailer)
Mrs Edwards hurls a box of Kup Kakes off deck.
Mrs Neves struggles back along the deck. Cut to stock film of Ark Royal in a storm.
Sound of a ship's horn.
Doris appears at the hatch, and hands over two cake boxes.
(takes them and throws them both overboard; an officer climbs up the side of the boat)
Money is handed over. The teas emerge on two little trays with delicate crockery, little teapots, milk jugs, etc.
(holding the teas he goes up to edge and jumps overboard)
Cut to very quick series of stills of storage jars.
Urgent documentary music. Mix through to an impressive documentary set. Zoom in to presenter in a swivel chair. He swings around to face the camera.
(quick cut to photo of a guerrilla leader with a gun; sudden dramatic chord; instantly cut back to the presenter)
(still of a Bolivian city and again dramatic chord and instantly back to the presenter)
Cut to a road in front of a heap of smouldering rubble. Dull thuds of mortars. Reporter in short sleeves standing in tight shot. Explosions going off behind him at intervals.
(slowly we pull out during this until we see in front of him a fairly long trestle table set out with range of diffrent-sized storage jar)
(the explosions continue behind him)
television is bad for your eyes.
(and CAPTION:)
Cut to a man sitting at a desk with a script.
(he frowns)
(a big hammer hits him on the head)
Quick cut to 'It's' man.

A montage of photographs. The cutting from photo to photo is pretty fast. Greek music is heard. Starting with: a close up of Mousebender, who is respectable and wears smart casual clothes; various photos of Mousebender walking along the pavement, again very artily shot from show-off angles; Mousebender pausing outside a shop; Mousebender looking up at the shop; Edwardian-style shop with large sign above it reading 'Ye Olde Cheese Emporium'; another sign below the first reading 'Henry Wensleydale, Purveyor of Fine Cheese to the Gentry and the Poverty Stricken Too'; another sign below this reading 'Licensed for Public Dancing'; close up of Mousebender looking pleased; shot of Mousebender entering the shop. Music cuts dead. Cut to interior of the cheese shop. Greek music playing as Mousebender enters. Two men dressed as city gents are Greek dancing in the corner to the music of a bouzouki. The shop itself is large and redolent of the charm and languidity of a bygone age. There is actually no cheese to be seen either on or behind the counter but this is not obvious. Mousebender approaches the counter and rings a small handbell. Wensleydale appears.
(broad Yorkshire)
(normal accent)
(smacks his lips)
(broad nothern accent)
(normal voice)
Quick cut to a Viking.
(broad Northern accent)
Cut back to cheese shop.
(normal voice)
(smiling grimley)
(bends below counter and reappears)
(pause)
(the music stops)
(to dancers)
(shoots him)
Mousebender puts a cowboy hat on his head. Cut to stock shot of man on horse riding into the sunset. Music swells dramatically.
Ordinary simple Philip Jenkinson at a desk set as seen in Monty Python's Flying Circus. Philip Jenkinson sits simpering and pouting like a cross between Truman Capote and a pederast vole.
(sniff)
(sniff)
(sniff)
(sniff)
Lyrical scene of boys in white flannels and girls in pretty dresses frolicking on a lawn to the accompaniment of a piano played by one of the boys.
The boys and girls cease frolicking and singing. Lionel enters holding a tennis racket.
He throws the tennis ball to Lionel. It hits Lionel on the head. Lionel claps one hand to his forehead. He roars in pain as blood seeps through his fingers.

He tosses his racket out of frame and we hear a hideous scream. The camera pans to pick up a pretty girl in summer frock with the handle of the racket embedded in her stomach. Blood is pouring out down her dress.

Spitting blood out of her mouth she collapses onto the floor clutching at Charles's arm. The arm comes off. Buckets of blood burst out of the shoulder drenching the girl and anyone else in the area. He staggers backwards against the piano. The piano lid drops, severing the pianist's hands. The pianist screams. He stands, blood spurting from his hands over piano music. The piano collapses in slow motion, shot from several angles simultaneously as per 'Zabriskie Point'. Intercut terrified faces of girls screaming in slow motion. The piano eventually crushes them to death; an enormous pool of blood immediately swells up from beneath piano where the girls are. We see Julian stagger across the frame with the piano keyboard through his stomach. As he turns the end of the keyboard knocks off the head of a terrified girl who is sitting on the grass nearby. A volcanic quantity of blood geysers upwards. Pull out and upward from this scene as the music starts again. Cut back to Philip Jenkinson.
(sniff)
There is the sound of a burst of machine-gun fire and holes appear in Philip Jenkinson's shirt. Blood spurting from each hole in slow motion. Intercut shots from different angles.
Roll credits over Jenkinson's dying agonies. Fade out.
(and Roller Caption)
(and Roller Caption)
Cut to Richard Baker sitting at the traditional news desk.
(pause)
Fade out. Fade up on film of seashore, waves breaking on beach.
The film goes on for quite a long time. Eventually, the announcer, dressed in medieval Spanish soldier's costume, walks into shot.
(to camera)
(pause, he looks round at the sea)
(he walks out of shot; long pause; he walks back)
He walks out of shot. We stay with the film for quite a long time before we finally fade out.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 32

script.description: The 'Nine O'Clock News' which was to follow has been cancelled tonight so we can bring you the quarter finals of the All Essex Badminton Championship. Your commentator as usual is Edna O'Brien.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: In the modern Britain, united under a great leader, it's the housewives of Britain who are getting things moving. Here a coachload of lovely ladies are on their way to speed up production in a car factory. And here we are boys, it's the no-hurry brigade hanging about for endless overtime. And just watch these gallant girls go into action . .. Not working fast enough? Well, there's an answer for that. Yes, this is certainly the way to speed up production. This is the recipe for increased productivity to meet the threat of those nasty foreigners when Britain takes her natural place at the head of the British Common Market. And how's this for a way to beat strikers. Those spotty continental boys will soon have to look out for Mrs Britain, and talking of windmills, these girls aren't afraid to tilt at the permissive society, Business is booming in the so-called arts, but two can play at that game, chum. . And it's not just the modern so-called plastic arts that get the clean-up treatment.

dialogue.speaker: Othello
dialogue.text: Oh Desdemona, Desdemona.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And those continentals had better watch out for their dirty foreign literature. Jean-Paul Sartre and Jean Genet won't know what's hit them. Never mind the foulness of their language - come '73 they'll all have to write in British. You can keep your fastidious continental bidets Mrs Foreigner - Mrs Britain knows how to keep her feet clean ... but she'll baffle like bingo boys when it comes to keeping the television screen clean...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Better watch out for those nasty continental shows on the sneaky second channel. But apart from attacking that prurient hot-bed of left-wing continentalism at Shepherds Bush, what else do these ordinary mums think? Do they accept Hegelianism?

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No! ..

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Do they prefer Leibnitz to Wittgenstein?

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No! No!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And where do they stand on young people?

dialogue.speaker: Third Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Just here, dear.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And their power is growing daily and when these girls roll their sleeves up its arms all the way. Yes, this is the way to fight the constant war against pornography.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now...

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Monty Python's Flying Circus.

dialogue.speaker: T. F. Gumby
dialogue.text: Doctor! Doctor! DOCTOR! Doctor! Doctor! DOCTOR! DOCTOR! Doctor! Doctor! Where is the Doctor?

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Hello!

dialogue.speaker: T. F. Gumby
dialogue.text: Are you the brain specialist?

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Hello!

dialogue.speaker: T. F. Gumby
dialogue.text: Are you the brain specialist?

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: No, no, I am not the brain specialist. No, no, I am not... Yes. Yes I am.

dialogue.speaker: T. F. Gumby
dialogue.text: My brain hurts!

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Well let's take a look at it, Mr Gumby.

dialogue.speaker: T. F. Gumby
dialogue.text: No, no, no, my brain in my head.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: It will have to come out.

dialogue.speaker: T. F. Gumby
dialogue.text: Out? Of my head?

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Yes! All the bits of it. Nurse! Nurse! NURSE! NURSE! Nurse, take Mr Gumby to a brain surgeon.

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: Yes doctor...

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Where's the 'Lancet'?

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: He's brilliant you know.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Where's the bloody 'Lancet'? My brain hurts too.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: Gloves ... glasses... moustache... handkerchief... I'm going to operate!!

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Let's operate.

dialogue.speaker: T. F. Gumby
dialogue.text: Hello!

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: Ooh! We forgot the anaesthetic!

dialogue.speaker: Operating Gumbys
dialogue.text: The anaesthetic! The anaesthetic!

dialogue.speaker: Gumby Anaesthetist
dialogue.text: I've come to anaesthetize you!!

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Hullo fans. Begorra an' to be sure there's some fine badminton down there in Essex this afternoon. We really...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: George.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Yes, Gladys.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: There's a man at the door with a moustache.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Tell him I've already got one. All right, all right. What's he want then?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: He says do we want a documentary on molluscs.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Molluscs?!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: What's he mean, molluscs?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: MOLLUSCS!! GASTROPODS! LAMELLIBRANCHS! CEPHALOPODS!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Oh molluscs, I thought you said bacon. All right, all right. What's he charge then?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: It's free.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Ooh! Where does he want us to sit?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: He says yes.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Good evening. Tonight molluscs. The mollusc is a soft-bodied, unsegmented invertebrate animal usually protected by a large shell. One of the most numerous groups of invertebrates, it is exceeded in number of species only by the arthropods ... viz.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Not very interesting is it?

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: I was talking to him.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Oh. Anyway, the typical mollusc, viz, a snail consists of a prominent muscular portion... the head-foot... a visceral mass and a shell which is secreted by the free edge of the mantle.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Dreadful isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: I was talking to him.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Oh. Well anyway... in some molluscs, however, viz, slugs, the shell is absent or rudimentary...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Switch him off.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Whereas in others, viz, cephalopods the head-foot is greatly modified and forms tentacles, viz, the squid. What are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Switching you off.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Why, don't you like it?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Oh it's dreadful.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Embarrassing.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Is it?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Yes, it's perfectly awful.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Disgraceful! I don't know how they've got the nerve to put it on.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: It's so boring.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Well ... it's not much of a subject is it... be fair.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: What do you think, George?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Give him another twenty seconds.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Anyway the majority of the molluscs are included in three large groups, the gastropods, the lamellibranchs and the cephalopods...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: We knew that

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: However, what is more interesting, er ... is the molluscs's er ... sex life.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Oh!

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Yes, the mollusc is a randy little fellow whose primitive brain scarcely strays from the subject of the you know what.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Disgusting!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: Ought not to be allowed.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: The randiest of the gastropods is the limpet. This hot-blooded little beast with its tent-like shell is always on the job. Its extra-marital activities are something startling. Frankly I don't know how the female limpet finds the time to adhere to the rock-face. How am I doing?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Disgusting.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: But more interesting.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Oh yes, tch, tch, tch.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Another loose-living gastropod is the periwinkle. This shameless little libertine with its characteristic ventral locomotion ... is the marrying kind: 'Anywhere anytime' is its motto. Up with the shell and they're at it.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: How about the lamellibranchs?

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: I'm coming to them ... the great scallop ... this tatty, scrofulous old rapist, is second in depravity only to the common clam. This latter is a right whore, a harlot, a trollop, a cynical bed-hopping firm-breasted Rabelaisian bit of sea food that makes Fanny Hill look like a dead Pope... and finally among the lamellibranch bivalves, that most depraved of the whole sub-species - the whelk. The whelk is nothing but a homosexual of the worst kind. This gay boy of the gastropods, this queer crustacean, this mincing mollusc, this screaming, prancing, limp-wristed queen of the deep makes me sick.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Have you got one?

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Here!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Let's kill it. Disgusting.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jalin
dialogue.text: That'll teach it. Well thank you for a very interesting programme.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Oh, not at all. Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Yes, that was very nice.

dialogue.speaker: Zorba
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Jalin
dialogue.text: Oh, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: And now a word from the man in the...

dialogue.speaker: Loony
dialogue.text: ...street.

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text: The Minister for not listening to people toured Batley today to investigate allegations of victimization in home-loan improvement grants, made last week by the Shadow Minister for judging people at first sight to be marginally worse than they actually are. At the Home Office, the Minister for inserting himself in between chairs and walls in men's clubs, was at his desk after a short illness. He spent the morning dealing with the Irish situation and later in the day had long discussions with the Minister for running upstairs two at a time, flinging the door open and saying 'Ha, ha! Caught you, Mildred'. In the Commons there was another day of heated debate on the third reading of the Trade Practices Bill. Mr Roland Penrose, the Under-Secretary for making deep growling noises grrr, launched a bitter personal attack on the ex-Minister for delving deep into a black satin bag and producing a tube of Euthymol toothpaste. Later in the debate the Junior Minister for being frightened by any kind of farm machinery, challenged the Under-Secretary of State for hiding from Terence Rattigan to produce the current year's trading figures, as supplied by the Department of stealing packets of bandages from the self-service counter at Timothy Whites and selling them again at a considerable profit. Parliament rose at 11:30, and, crawling along a dark passageway into the old rectory broke down the door to the serving hatch, painted the spare room and next weekend I think they'll be able to make a start on the boy's bedroom, while Amy and Roger, up in London for a few days, go to see the mysterious Mr Grenville.

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text: He in turn has been revealed by D'Arcy as something less than an honest man. Sybil feels once again a resurgence of her old affection and she and Balreau return to her little house in Clermont-Ferrand, the kind of two-up, two-down house that most French workers throughout the European Community are living in today.

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'THE CLASSIC SERIAL HAS NOW BECOME THE TUESDAY DOCUMENTARY'

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: The ease of construction, using on-site prefabrication facilities makes cheap housing a reality. The walls of these houses are lined with prestressed asbestos which keeps the house warm and snuggly and ever so safe from the big bad rabbit, who can scratch and scratch for all he's worth, but he just can't get into Porky's house.

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'THE TUESDAY DOCUMENTARY HAS BECOME "CHILDREN'S STORY" '

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Where is Porky? Here he is. What a funny little chap. But Porky's one of the lucky ones - he survived the urban upheaval of the thirties and forties. For him, Jarrow is still just a memory. The hunger marches, the East End riots, the collapse of the Labour Government in 1931...

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'THE CHILDREN'S STORY HAS GONE BACK INTO THE TUESDAY DOCUMENTARY'

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: ... are dim reminders of the days before a new-found affluence swept the land, making it clean and tidy and making all the shops full of nice things, lovely choo-choo trains ...

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: . .. and toys and shiny cars that go brrm, brrm, brrm, and everybody was happy and singing all the day long and nobody saw the big bad rabbit ever again.

dialogue.speaker: Politician
dialogue.text: But you know it's always very easy to blame the big bad rabbit...

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'NOW IT'S BECOME A PARTY POLITICAL BROADCAST!'

dialogue.speaker: Politician
dialogue.text: ...when by-elections are going against the Government, Do you think we should really be blaming ourselves?

dialogue.speaker: Politician
dialogue.text: Because you know, that's where we really ought to start looking.

script.description: 'WE WOULD LIKE TO APOLOGIZE FOR THE WAY IN WHICH POLITICIANS ARE REPRESENTED IN THIS PROGRAMME. IT WAS NEVER OUR INTENTION TO IMPLY THAT POLITICIANS ARE WEAK-KNEED, POLITICAL TIME-SERVERS WHO ARE CONCERNED MORE WITH THEIR PERSONAL VENDETTAS AND PRIVATE POWER STRUGGLES THAN THE PROBLEMS OF GOVERNMENT, NOR TO SUGGEST AT ANY POINT THAT THEY SACRIFICE THEIR CREDIBILITY BY DENYING FREE DEBATE ON VITAL MATTERS IN THE MISTAKEN IMPRESSION THAT PARTY UNITY COMES BEFORE THE WELL-BEING OF THE PEOPLE THEY SUPPOSEDLY REPRESENT NOR TO IMPLY AT ANY STAGE THAT THEY ARE SQUABBLING LITTLE TOADIES WITHOUT AN OUNCE OF CONCERN FOR THE VITAL SOCIAL PROBLEMS OF TODAY. NOR INDEED DO WE INTEND THAT VIEWERS SHOULD CONSIDER THEM AS CRABBY ULCEROUS LITTLE SELF-SEEKING VERMIN WITH FURRY LEGS AND AN EXCESSIVE ADDICTION TO ALCOHOL AND CERTAIN EXPLICIT SEXUAL PRACTICES WHICH SOME PEOPLE MIGHT FIND OFFENSIVE.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Hello. All the activity you can see in progress here is part of the intricate... aah! preparations for the British Naval Expedition to Lake Pahoe. The leader of the expedition is Sir Jane Russell. Sir Jane, what is the purpose of your expedition?

dialogue.speaker: Sir Jane
dialogue.text: Well this is a completely uncharted lake with like hitherto unclassified marine life man, so the whole scene's wide open for a scientific exploration.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: One can see the immense amount of preparation involved. Have there been many difficulties in setting up this venture?

dialogue.speaker: Sir Jane
dialogue.text: Well the real hang-up was with the bread man but when the top brass pigs came through we got it together in a couple of moons. Commodore Betty Grable, who's a real sub-aqua head, has got it together diving wise and like the whole gig's been a real gas man.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Thank you. Lieutenant Commander Dorothy Lamour.

dialogue.speaker: Parrot
dialogue.text: Pieces of eight.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Dorothy you're in charge of security and liason for this operation.

dialogue.speaker: Dorothy Lamour
dialogue.text: Right on.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: You've kept this all rather hush-hush so far shipmate.

dialogue.speaker: Dorothy Lamour
dialogue.text: Yeah, it's been really heavy man with all these freaks from the fascist press trying to blow the whole scene.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: There's no doubt about it, this expedition does have some rather unusual aspects, Jim lad. For a first, why does the senior personnel all bear the names of Hollywood film stars of the forties ... and female ones at that, shiver me timbers 'tis the black spot, and secondly, I be not afraid of thee Blind Pew ... why do they talk this rather strange stilted, underground jargon, belay the mainbrace Squire Trelawney this be my ship now. Argh! A tranquillizing dart fired by the cowardly BBC health department dogs ... they've done filled me full of chlorpromazine damn!

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: I'm sorry about my colleague's rather unconventional behaviour.

dialogue.speaker: Sir Jane
dialogue.text: The navy's out of sight man come together with the RN it's really something other than else.

dialogue.speaker: Animated Voice
dialogue.text: You dig it, man?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Hello. I'm sorry about my colleague's rather unconventional behaviour just now, but things haven't been too easy for him recently, trouble at home, rather confidential so I can't give you all the details... interesting though they are... three bottles of rum with his Weetabix, and so on, anyway... apparently the girl wasn't even ... anyway the activity you see behind me... it's the mother I feel sorry for. I'll start again. The activity you see behind me is part of the preparations for the new Naval Expedition to Lake Pahoe. The man in charge of this expedition is Vice Admiral Sir John Cunningham. Sir John, hello there.

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Ah, hello. Well first of all I'd like to apologize for the behaviour of certain of my colleagues you may have seen earlier, but they are from broken homes, circus families and so on and they are in no way representative of the new modern improved British Navy. They are a small vociferous minority; and may I take this opportunity of emphasizing that there is no cannibalism in the British Navy. Absolutely none, and when I say none, I mean there is a certain amount, more than we are prepared to admit, but all new ratings are warned that if they wake up in the morning and find any toothmarks at all anywhere on their bodies, they're to tell me immediately so that I can immediately take every measure to hush the whole thing up. And, finally, necrophilia is right out. Now, this expedition is primarily to investigate reports of cannibalism and necrophilia in... this expedition is primarily to investigate reports of unusual marine life in the as yet uncharted Lake Pahoe.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: And where exactly is the lake?

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Er 22A, Runcorn Avenue, I think. Yes, that's right, 22A.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Runcorn Avenue?

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Yes, it's just by Blenheim Crescent... do you know it?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: You mean it's in an ordinary street?

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Of course it's not an ordinary street! It's got a lake in it!

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes but I...

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Look, how many streets do you know that have got lakes in them?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: But you mean... is it very large?

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Of it's not large, you couldn't get a large lake in Runcorn Avenue! You'd have to knock down the tobacconist's! Jenkins ... no!

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: I'm now standing in Runcorn Avenue. Sir John ... where exactly is the lake?

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Er, well let's see, that's 18... that's 20 so this must be the one.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, excuse me...

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Yes, that's the one all right.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: But it's an ordinary house.

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Look, I'm getting pretty irritated with this line of questioning.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: But it doesn't even look like a lake...

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Look, your whole approach since this interview started has been to mock the Navy. When I think that it was for the likes of you that I had both my legs blown off...

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: You haven't had both your legs blown off!

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: I was talking metaphorically you fool. Jenkins - put that down. Right, is the equipment ready?

dialogue.speaker: Rating
dialogue.text: Diving equipment all ready man.

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Right. Now quite simply the approach to Lake Pahoe is up the steps, and then we come to the shores of the lake. Now, I'm going to press the bell just to see if there's anyone in.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Hello?

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Good morning - I'm looking for a Lake Pahoe.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: There's a Mr Padgett.

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: No, no a .

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: There's no lake here, mate. This is Runcorn Avenue. What's the camera doing?

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Camera? What's he want? Oooh, are we on the telly?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: He's looking for a lake.

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Lake Pahoe.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Oh, you want downstairs, 22A the basement.

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Ah! Thank you very much. Good morning. Come on men, downstairs.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Were you successful, Sir John?

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: It's in the basement.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: In the basement?

dialogue.speaker: Parrot
dialogue.text: Pieces of eight.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Eugh!

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Hello.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Ooooh. I think it's someone about the damp.

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Hello.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Tell 'em about the bleeding rats, too.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: I'll go Yes?

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Good morning, is this Lake Pahoe?

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know about that, but it's bleeding damp. Are you from the council?

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: No. We are the official British Naval Expedition to this lake. May we come in?

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Hang on.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Bloody sharks.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Get in.

dialogue.speaker: Sir John
dialogue.text: Well um... that would appear to be the end of the expedition.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: The Magna Carta - was it a document signed at Runnymede in 1215 by King John pledging independence to the English barons, or was it a piece of chewing gum on a bedspread in Dorset? The latter idea is the brainchild of a man new to the field of historical research. Mr Badger, why - why are you on this programme?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Well, I think I can answer this question most successfully in mime.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: But why Dorset?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Well, I have for a long time been suffering from a species of brain injury which I incurred during the rigours of childbirth, and I'd like to conclude by putting my finger up my nose.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Mr Badger, I think you're the silliest person we've ever had on this programme, and so I'm going to ask you to have dinner with me.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: My wife Maureen ran off with a bottle of Bell's whisky during the Aberdeen versus Raith Rovers match which ended in a goalless draw. Robson particularly, in goal, had a magnificent first half, his fine positional sense preventing the build-up of any severe pressure on the suspect Aberdeen defense. McLoughlan missed an easy chance to clinch the game towards the final whistle but Raith must be well satisfied with their point.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Do please go on. This is the least fascinating conversation I've ever had.

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: Would you like to order sir?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, Mr Badger, what would you like to start with?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Er, I'll have a whisky to start with.

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: For first course, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Aye.

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: And for main course, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: I'll have a whisky for main course and I'll follow that with a whisky for pudding.

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: Yes sir, and what would you like with it, sir? A whisky?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: No, a bottle of wine.

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: Fine, sir, he said between clenched teeth knowing full well it was a most unrewarding part.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: This is the silliest sketch I've ever been in.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Shall we stop it?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yeah, all right.

Machine guns chatter. Two pepperpots in a trench firing. Mortar bombs, reloading and firing. Bombs and smoke. At the end of the film we pick up on the nude organist (Terry J), sitting amongst the explosions. He plays his chords.
Animated titles.

Close up on a sign saying 'Harley Street'. Stirring music. Mix through to interior of a smart, plush, ever so expensive Harley Street consulting room. The music swells and fades. Knocking at door, a short pause, then T.F. Gumby enters, backwards.
(he goes up to the antique desk and bangs the bell violently; he smashes the intercom and generally breaks the desk up)
A pause. Then another door opens and another Gumby appears.
Gumby specialist starts to pull up Gumby's sweater.
(specialist thumps him on the head)
(a nurse enters)
She leads Gumby out. In the background the specialist is grunting and shouting.

Ambulance racing. 'Dr Kildare' theme. Cut to operating theatre. The surgeon is not a Gumby.

We now see he is surrounded by Gumbys. T. F. Gumby is on operating table.
They begin to use woodworking implements on T. F. Gumby.
At that moment a Gumby anaesthetist comes crashing through the wall with two gas cylinders.
He raises a gas cylinder and strikes Gumby hard over the head with it. Bong. Blackness. Into the oblivion of animation.

Then cut to an ordinary suburban living room. Mr and Mrs Jalin are sitting on a sofa. The previous item in the show is visible on their TV set. Mrs Jalin is stuffing a chicken. Mr Jalin is reading the telephone directory. The picture changes and we hear voice from TV.

Mr Jalin picks up a jousting ball and chain and smashes the TV set. There is a ring from the doorbell. Mr Jalin sits, Mrs Jalin goes to the door, exits and comes back.

(she hits him again)

Mr Zorba enters carrying plywood flat with portion cut out to represent TV. He stands behind flat and starts.
(he holds up a lobster)

(holds one up)
Mrs Jalin gets up and looks for the switch unsuccessfully.
(looking out)
(she gets up and goes to the set)

(going back to sofa)
(holds one up)

Zorba throws it on the floor and Mr and Mrs Jalin stamp on it.

Cut to a studio presenter at a desk.
Cut to Glencoe vox pop: a loony.
high-suction baby.

Cut to a politican giving a party political broadcast in one of those badly lit sets that they use for broadcasts of that nature.
(he turns and we cut to side camera which reveals a cross behind him as for religious broadcast)
A football comes in, he heads it neatly out of shot.
Cut to stock film of ball flying into net and shot of Wembley crowd roaring. Then cut into short sequence of footballers in slow-motion kissing each other.

The camera pans across a landscape. Roller caption starts to come up, superimposed. The words are quite large and easily readable, but well spaced so that the roller will seem to go on for quite some time. Voice over reads.
(and CAPTION:)
Cut to a similar landscape. Preparations for an expedition are underway: equipment being piled into land-rovers etc. An interviewer walks into shot.
(he steps into a man-trap, but continues bravely)

He falls. A second interviewer comes into shot and catches the microphone.

We see a rather sheepish rating about to sink his teeth into a human leg. Sir John puts his hand in front of the lens. Cut to Runcorn Avenue, an ordinary street with houses now turned into flats. The land-rover arrives with the equipment.
(pointing at perfectly healthy legs)
