dialogue.text: You can keep your Marxist ways For it's only just a phase.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: For its money, money, money, Makes the world go round. Money, money, money, money, money, money!

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Not so fast, Yakomoto. Shut up! Allow me to introduce myself. I am Inspector Leopard of Scotland Yard, Special Fraud Film Director Squad.

dialogue.speaker: Court
dialogue.text: Leopard of the Yard!

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: The same. Only more violent. Right, Slit Eyes Yakomoto, I'm arresting you for the impersonation of Signor Luchino Visconti, famous Italian director of such movie classics as 'Ossessione' 1942, 'La Tetra Trema' 1948, and 'Bellissima' 1951 - a satisfying ironic slice-of-life drama. 1957 brought to the silver screen his 'I Bianche Notre' adapted by Dostoyevsky, a mannered and romantic melancholy of snow and mist and moonlit encounters on canal bridges. 'Boccaccio 70' followed five years later and the following year saw 'The Leopard'! So impressed was I with this motion picture treatment of the Risorgimento that I went along to Somerset House and changed me own name to Leopard, preferring it to me original handle, 'Panther' (Aargh). I digress. 1969 saw 'The Damned', a Götterdämmerung epic of political and industrial shennanigans in good old Nazi Germany, starring Helmut Berger as a stinking transvestite what should have his face sawn off, the curvaceous Charlotte Rampling as a bit of tail, and the impeccable Dirk Bogarde as Von Essen. The association of the latter with Signor Visconti fructified with Dirk's magnificent portrayal of the elderly poof what expires in Venice. And so, Yakomoto... blimey, he gone! Never mind. I'll have you instead.

dialogue.speaker: Akwekwe
dialogue.text: Yes, sir. Yes, we'll try.

dialogue.speaker: The BBC would like to announce that the next scene is not considered suitable for family viewing. It contains scenes of violence, involving people's heads and arms getting chopped off, their ears nailed to trees, and their toenails pulled out in slow motion. There are also scenes of naked women with floppy breasts, and also at one point you can see a pair of buttocks and there's another bit where I'll swear you can see everything, but my friend says it's just the way he's holding the spear.
dialogue.text: Because of the unsuitability of the scene, the BBC will be replacing it with a scene from a repeat of 'Gardening Club' for 1958.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And now back to the story.

dialogue.speaker: Third Explorer
dialogue.text: That was a nasty business back at the restaurant.

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: Yes, I thought most places took Barclaycard nowadays.

dialogue.speaker: Second Explorer
dialogue.text: Where do you think they're taking us, Brian?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Explorer
dialogue.text: God knows!

dialogue.speaker: Third Explorer
dialogue.text: Look!

dialogue.speaker: Second Explorer
dialogue.text: The sacred volcano Andu! Which no man has seen before.

dialogue.speaker: Third Explorer
dialogue.text: No, no, no, next to that.

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: The London Brick Company?

dialogue.speaker: Third Explorer
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no - next to that.

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: The forbidden plateau of Roiurama, the Lost World, thrown up by mighty earth movements thousands of millions of years ago, where strange primeval creatures defying evolution, lurk in the dark, impenetrable forests, cut off forever from the outside world.

dialogue.speaker: Second Explorer
dialogue.text: I still can't see it.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Explorer
dialogue.text: You don't think that's where they're taking us?

dialogue.speaker: Third Explorer
dialogue.text: Yes, and God knows what we'll find there.

dialogue.speaker: Native
dialogue.text: What page please?

dialogue.speaker: Second Explorer
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Native
dialogue.text: What page in the script?

dialogue.speaker: Second Explorer
dialogue.text: Page 7.

dialogue.speaker: Native
dialogue.text: 'Come on, you dogs, we have far to go. We must lose no time'. 'Come on, you dogs, we have far to go. We must lose no time'. 'Come on you dogs'. Come on you dogs, we have time to lose, this has gone too far.

dialogue.stage_direction: Meanwhile back in London ... at the British Explorers' Club in the Mall...

dialogue.speaker: Our Hero
dialogue.text: Any news of Betty Bailey's expedition, Hargreaves?

dialogue.speaker: Hargreaves
dialogue.text: Er ... um ... er...

dialogue.speaker: Our Hero
dialogue.text: Page 9...

dialogue.speaker: Hargreaves
dialogue.text: 'The Lost World of Roiurama'.

dialogue.speaker: Our Hero
dialogue.text: That's my line.

dialogue.speaker: Hargreaves
dialogue.text: Oh, sorry. 'Where were they going, sir'?

dialogue.speaker: Our Hero
dialogue.text: The Lost World of Roiurama.

dialogue.speaker: Hargreaves
dialogue.text: Yes sir, we've got a telegram.

dialogue.speaker: Our Hero
dialogue.text: Oh

dialogue.speaker: Hargreaves
dialogue.text: Reads it. Expedition superb. Weather excellent. Everything wonderful.

dialogue.speaker: Our Hero
dialogue.text: I wonder what's gone wrong.

dialogue.speaker: Hargreaves
dialogue.text: For God's sake be careful...

dialogue.speaker: Our Hero
dialogue.text: Wait a minute... I'm going to go... after them.

dialogue.speaker: Hargreaves
dialogue.text: For God's sake be careful, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Second Explorer
dialogue.text: My God, Betty, we're done for...

dialogue.speaker: Third Explorer
dialogue.text: We'll never get out of here... we're completely lost, lost. Even the natives have gone.

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: Goodbye Betty, Goodbye Farquarson. Goodbye Brian. It's been a great expedition...

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: Great expedition ...

dialogue.speaker: Third Explorer
dialogue.text: All that'll be left of us will be a map, a compass and a few feet of film, recording our last moments...

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: Wait a moment!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Explorer
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: If we're on film, there must be someone filming us.

dialogue.speaker: Second Explorer
dialogue.text: My God, Betty, you're right!

dialogue.speaker: Third Explorer
dialogue.text: Look! Great to see you!

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: What a stroke of luck!

dialogue.speaker: Camera Crew
dialogue.text: Hello! ...

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: Wait a minute!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Explorer
dialogue.text: What is it again?

dialogue.speaker: First Explorer
dialogue.text: If this is the crew who were filming us . .. who's filming us now? Look!

dialogue.speaker: Director
dialogue.text: Cut there man! No! No good! How we going to get feeling of personal alienation of self from society with this load of Bulldog Drummond crap? When I was doing 'La Notte' wi' dat Monica Vitti gal she don't gimme none of this empire building shit, man ...

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Not so fast, Akarumba! Allow me to introduce myself. I'm Inspector Baboon of Scotland Yard's Special Fraud Film Director Squad, Jungle Division.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Explorer
dialogue.text: Baboon of the Yard!

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Shut up! Right, Akarumba! I'm arresting you for impersonating Signor Michelangelo Antonioni, an Italian film director who co-scripts all his own films, largely jettisoning narrative in favour of vague incident and relentless character study . . . ... In his first film: 'Cronaca Di Un Areore' (1950), the couple are brought together by a shared irrational guilt. 'L'Amico' followed in 1955, and 1959 saw the first of Antonioni's world-famous trilogy, 'L'Avventura' - an acute study of boredom, restlessness and the futilities and agonies of purposeless living. In 'L'Eclisse', three years later, this analysis of sentiments is taken up once again. 'We do not have to know each other to love', says the heroine, 'and perhaps we do not have to love...' The 'Eclipse' of the emotions finally casts its shadow when darkness descends on a street corner. ... Signor Antonioni first makes use of colour to underline...

dialogue.speaker: Continuity Voice
dialogue.text: And now on BBC another six minutes of Monty Python's Flying Circus.

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: (Rita Davies) Yes, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I'd like to have an argument please.

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: Certainly, sir. Have you been here before...?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, this is my first time.

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: I see. Do you want to have the full argument, or were you thinking of taking a course?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well, what would be the cost?

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: Yes, it's one pound for a five-minute argument, but only eight pounds for a course of ten.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well, I think it's probably best if I start with the one and see how it goes from there. OK?

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: Fine. I'll see who's free at the moment ... Mr. Du-Bakey's free, but he's a little bit conciliatory ... yes, try Mr. Barnard - Room 12.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Barnard
dialogue.text: What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well I was told outside ...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Barnard
dialogue.text: Don't give me that you snotty-faced heap of parrot droppings!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Barnard
dialogue.text: Shut your festering gob you tit! Your type makes me puke! You vacuous toffee-nosed malodorous pervert!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Look! I came here for an argument.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Barnard
dialogue.text: Oh! I'm sorry, this is abuse.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh I see, that explains it.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Barnard
dialogue.text: No, you want room 12A next door.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I see - sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Barnard
dialogue.text: Not at all. Stupid git.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Come in.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Is this the right room for an argument?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: I've told you once.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No you haven't.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Yes I have.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Just now!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No you didn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Yes I did!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Didn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Did.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Didn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: I'm telling you I did!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You did not!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, is this a five minute argument, or the full half hour?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh ... Just a five-minute one.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Fine thank you. Anyway, I did.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You most certainly did not.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Now, let's get one thing quite clear. I most definitely told you!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You did not.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Yes I did.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Didn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Yes I did.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Didn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Yes I did!!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Look, this isn't an argument.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No it isn't, it's just contradiction.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: It is not.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: It is. You just contradicted me.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No I didn't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Ooh, you did!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You did, just then.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No, nonsense!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, look this is futile.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I came here for a good argument.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No you didn't, you came here for an argument.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well, an argument's not the same as contradiction.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: It can be.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No it can't. An argument is a connected series of statements to establish a definite proposition.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes it is. It isn't just contradiction.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Look, if I argue with you, I must take up a contrary position.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: But it isn't just saying 'No it isn't'.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No it isn't, Argument is an intellectual process ... contradiction is just the automatic gainsaying of anything the other person says.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Not at all.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Now look!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: That's it. Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: But I was just getting interested.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Sorry the five minutes is up.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: That was never five minutes just now!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: I'm afraid it was.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No it wasn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, I'm not allowed to argue any more.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What!?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: If you want me to go on arguing you'll have to pay for another five minutes.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: But that was never five minutes just now ... oh Come on! This is ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: I'm very sorry, but I told you I'm not allowed to argue unless you've paid.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh. all right. There you are.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well?.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Well what?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: That was never five minutes just now.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: I told you I'm not allowed to argue unless you've paid!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I've just paid.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No you didn't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I did! I did! I did!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No you didn't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Look I don't want to argue about that.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Well I'm very sorry but you didn't pay.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Aha! Well if I didn't pay, why are you arguing ... got you!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No you haven't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes I have ... if you're arguing I must have paid.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: Not necessarily. I could be arguing in my spare time.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I've had enough of this.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vibrating
dialogue.text: No you haven't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh shut up! I want to complain.

dialogue.speaker: Man in charge
dialogue.text: You want to complain ... look at these shoes ... I've only had them three weeks and the heels are worn right through.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, I want to complain about ...

dialogue.speaker: Man in charge
dialogue.text: If you complain nothing happens ... you might just as well not bother. My back hurts and ...

dialogue.speaker: I want to complain.
dialogue.text: Ooh!

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: No, no, no, hold your head like this, and then go 'waaagh'! Try it again.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Waaghh!

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: Better. Better. But 'waaaaaghh'! 'Waaaagh'! Hold your hands here ...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: Now.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Waagh!

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: That's it. That's it. Good.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Stop hitting me!

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Stop hitting me.

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: Stop hitting you?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: What did you come in here for then?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I came here to complain.

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: Oh I'm sorry, that's next door. It's being hit on the head lessons in here.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What a stupid concept.

dialogue.speaker: Man and Spreaders
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: Allow me to introduce myself. I'm Inspector Fox of the Light Entertainment Police, Comedy Division, Special Flying Squad.

dialogue.speaker: Man and Spreaders
dialogue.text: Flying Fox of the Yard.

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Ooooh?

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: No, no, no - Waagh!

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: And you.

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: Waagh!

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: He's good! You could learn a thing or two from him. Right now you two me old beauties, you are nicked.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What for?

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: I'm charging you under Section 21 of the Strange Sketch Act.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: The what?

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: You are hereby charged that you did wilfully take part in a strange sketch, that is, a skit, spoof or humorous vignette of an unconventional nature with intent to cause grievous mental confusion to the Great British Public. Evening all.

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: It's a fair cop.

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: And you tosh.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: WAAAGH!

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: That's excellent! Right, come on down the Yard.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Hold it. Hold it. Allow me to introduce myself. I'm Inspector Thompson's Gazelle of the Programme Planning Police, Light Entertainment Division, Special Flying Squad.

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: Flying Thompson's Gazelle of the Yard!

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Fox
dialogue.text: Waaaagh!

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: He's good.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Spreaders
dialogue.text: WAAGH!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Rotten. WAAAGH!

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Good. Now I'm arrestin' this entire show on three counts: one, acts of self-conscious behaviour contrary to the 'Not in front of the children' Act, two, always saying 'It's so and so of the Yard' every time the fuzz arrives and, three, and this is the cruncher, offenses against the 'Getting out of sketches without using a proper punchline' Act, four, namely, simply ending every bleedin' sketch by just having a policeman come in and... wait a minute.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Hold it.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: It's a fair cop.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer's Voice
dialogue.text: And now on BBC 1, one more minute of Monty Python's Flying Circus.

annotations: Opening title sequence and signature tune for 'The Money Programme'. Set with presenter and two guests. Close up on presenter.
(starting to get excited)
(collects himself)
(getting worked up again)
(standing on the desk)
(sings to piano accompaniment)
Five singers (male) in Welsh (women's) national costume come on. A Welsh harpist joins them.
(a shower of paper notes descends)
The 'It's' man
Animated titles.
Exterior of an Elizabethan palace. Elizabethan music. An Elizabethan messenger on a moped, comes up the drive and drives in through the front door.

Cut to a long corridor. The messenger appears mopeding along the corridor very fast. He leaps off the moped and hands it to a guard at a door. The guard places the moped on a rack and the messenger enters the door going past three trumpeters who play a fanfare. He approaches a clerical figure, who stands at yet another door.
The doors open. The messenger leaps on another moped and rides up to the throne on which sits Elizabeth surrounded by her courtiers, all of who are on motorized bicycles.
Enter Japanese director.
(linging his berr for him)
(cheesed off)
(sings)
(sings)
The door opens. lnspector Leopard runs through the door followed by a copper.
(trumpeters play a fanfare)
(fanfare stops)
(he demonstrates this by kneeing the copper in the balls)
(grabs the queen)
sketch about violence.
Cut to a kitchen. A man and woman listening to a radio.
(Switching the radio off)
Enter their son
(goes out)
(coming back)
(shouts)
Enter two policemen with ecclesiastical accoutrements.
(kneels)
Organ music. A huge hand descends and points at the man.
(singing)
(policemen escort the man out)
bouncing Queen Victoria.

A steamy tropical jungle. A native guide leads four explorers in pith helmets and old-fashioned long shorts through the jungle. Cicada sounds and shrieks of predatory jungle birds. Intercut close ups of perspiring foreheads etc. The native guide keeps beckoning them to hurry. The jungle appears to get thicker: they have to push their way through the undergrowth. Finally the guide stops and points, with eyes staring. The four explorers cluster around and look over his shoulder. A neat clearing in the thick of the jungle. Tables set as in a London bistro with check cloths and big wooden pepper mills, candles and menus standing on each table. Sitting at the tables are six other explorers in pith helmets etc., eating and chatting. Clink of coffee cups.
(across the restaurant the head waiter appears, dressed in black tie and tails just a bit too big for him; he beckons them to a table)
(who is dressed as a man and has a moustache)

Suddenly there is a hideous scream. We see a gorilla tear a man from his table at the back of the restaurant, in front of a tree and drag him back into the jungle. Awful shrieks are heard. Akwekwe runs into the jungle shouting, Terrible sounds of the unseen fight. Thrashing about of bushes in the distance. A shot rings out. Then silence also rings out. Akwekwe emerges, dragging the inert body of the customer whom he puts back in his chair. He slumps forward. Akwekwe comes back to the table in the foreground which has remained in the foreground throughout this preceding shot, with cut ins of the four explorers looking through the menu. Akwekwe has a bloodstained claw mark right across his face and chest and his dicky is torn and bloodstained.
He produces a notepad such as waiters always carry.

Cut to close up of pygmy's evil face parting leaves and firing a blow-pipe. Cut to another table where two explorers are having coffee and cigars. One of them stiffens and then slumps firward. Cut to Akwekwe at the main table registering what has happened. We pan with him as he rushes over to the bushes. Sound of pygmies retreating into the bushes. Akwekwe shouts after him. We pan with Akwekwe as he walks over to the table where the customer has slumped forward. He pulls him up, looks at dart sticking out of his chest, tut tuts with annoyance and lets him slump back on to the table again. He returns to the main table.
(sinister sound of jungle drums in distance; close up of look of fear in Akwekwe's eyes)
Jungle drums getting louder. Akwekwe shouts off towards the back of the clearing where we assume the kitchens mast be.
He casts yet another fearful glance in the direction of the ever-increasing drum beats.

The drum beats get louder. Shot of forest, rustling of bushes. Close up of Akwekwe's eyes. Another shot of forest. Drum beats louder. More rustling. Close up of Akwekwe's eyes and sweating forehead. Forest again and more noise. Close up of Akwekwe; he now has blood on his face, his eyes dilate with fear, the drum beats become deafening. Sudden cut to BBC world symbol.
(pulling himself together)

A beautiful well-stocked garden bed. 'Gardening Club' music. After two seconds there are shrieks of licentious and lustful laughter. A nude woman pursues a city gent, both screaming with pleasure, into the middle of the flowerbed and they roll around smashing up the flowers in unbridled erotic orgy. Immediately two nuns run in to join the fun, followed by two Vikings, a gumby, a pantomime goose, etc. The whole of this orgy is speeded up.

Cut to the edge of the jungle. Emerging from the dense undergrowth are two pygmy warriors pulling the four explorers who are roped together. The pygmies carry spears. We lose the pygmies and hold just the explorers in frame, and track with them.
(pointing, eyes wide with amazement)
Cut to a stock shot of a volcano. Thrilling chord. Cut back to explorers.
(filled with awe)
Cut to stock shot of collection of big chimneys in a brickworks. Another thrilling chord. Cut back to explorers.
Cut to stock shot of plateau of Roiurama. Yet another thrilling chord. Cut back to explorers.
A pigmy native rushes up from behind them, holding a script.
(with a trace of irritation)
(whispered)
(he speaks the lines over to himself)
(tries with eyes shut)
(throws away the script, starts to push them roughly)
Stock film of Houses of Parliament from across the Thames.

Cut to the leather-armchaired hallway of a London club. In four of the chairs sit men in polar explorers' kit - furs, iced-over goggles, etc. - reading newspapers. At one chair sits a man in Norfolk jacket and plus fours. Around his neck he wears a sign saying 'Our Hero'. He is reading a newspaper but obviously has something else on his mind. Suddenly he throws the paper down and gets up. He walks over to the porter's desk. As he does this a polar expedition with four huskies, a sled, and two explorers pass him. Our Hero goes up to the desk. A whiskery old porter stands behind it.
(through clenched teeth)
(thumbing over page of script beneath counter)
(reads it)
(irritably)
Cut to film of the lost world. Tropical South American vegetation. Our four explorers from Jungle Restaurant and Ken Russell's Gardening Club sketches limp along exhaustedly.
Music. Cut to engraving of Crystal Palace.
Cut immediately back to jungle.
They all look around, then gradually all notice the camera. They break out in smiles of relief, come towards the camera and greet the camera crew.

Cut to another shot which indudes the first camera crew and yet another camera crew with all their equipment. The director is dressed the same as Yakomoto, the director in 'Erizabeth L', only he is blacked up.
(African accent)
Camera pans slightly to reveal a door in jungle. It opens and an inspector enters.
(shoots her)
(during this harangue the credits start to roll, music very faint beneath his words)
(the credits end; voice and picture start to fade)
Fade to black and then to BBC world symbol
A reception desk in a sort of office building.
The man walks down a corridor. He opens door 12. There is a man at a desk.
(shouting)
(calmly)
(exits)

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 28

script.description: 'THE KON-TIKI' 'RA 1' 'RA 2' 'AND NOW ...' 'MR AND MRS BRIAN NORRIS' FORD POPULAR'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Who, a year ago, had heard of Mr and Mrs Brian Norris of 37, Gledhill Gardens, Parsons Green? And yet their epic journey in EBW 343 has set them alongside Thor Heyerdahl and Sir Edmund Hillary. Starting only with a theory, Mr Norris set out to prove that the inhabitants of Hounslow could have been descendants of the people of Surbiton who had made the great trek north. No newcomer to this field, Mr Norris's 'A Short History of Motor Traffic Between Purley and Esher' had become a best-selling minor classic in the car-swapping belt. But why would the people of Surbiton go to Hounslow? Mr Norris had noticed three things: Firstly, the similarity of the houses. Secondly, the similarity of the costume between Hounslow and Surbiton, and thirdly, the similarity of speech.

dialogue.speaker: Man on Right
dialogue.text: Are you still running the GDBDMDB?

dialogue.speaker: Man on Left
dialogue.text: Yes, but I've had the excess nipples woppled to remove tamping.

dialogue.speaker: Man on Right
dialogue.text: Jolly good.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Were these just coincidences, or were they, as Mr Norris believed, part of an identical cultural background? One further discovery convinced him. The lawnmower. Surely such a sophisticated household gadget could not have been generated independently in two separate areas. Mr Norris was convinced.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Norris's Voice
dialogue.text: I'm convinced.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But how to prove it.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Norris's Voice
dialogue.text: But how to prove it.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: There was only one way to see if the journey between Surbiton and Hounslow was possible, and that was to try and make it. Months of preparation followed whilst Mr Norris continued his research in the Putney Public Library, and Mrs Norris made sandwiches.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Finally, by April, they were ready. On the 23rd, Mr and Mrs Norris set out from 'Abide-A-Wee' to motor the fifteen miles to Surbiton, watched by a crowd of local well-wishers. That evening they dined at Tooting. This would be the last they'd see of civilization. Mr Norris's diary for the 23rd reveals the extraordinary calmness and deep inner peacefulness of his mind.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Norris's Voice
dialogue.text: 7.30 Fed cat. 8.00 Breakfast. 8.30 Yes (successfully). 9.00 Set out on historic journey.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: On the morning of the 24th, early to avoid the traffic, Mr Norris's historic expedition set out from Surbiton - destination Hounslow. Early on they began to perceive encouraging signs. The writing on the sign was almost exactly the same as the writing in the AA book. They were on the right route. During the long hours of the voyage, Mr Norris's wife Betty kept a complete photographic record and made sandwiches. This is some of the unique footage which Mrs Norris got back from the chemists... Mile succeeded mile and the terrific strain was beginning to tell when suddenly, by an amazing stroke of luck, Mr Norris had come across the Kingston by-pass. This was something to tell the Round Table. At this stage, Mr Norris was faced with two major divergent theories concerning his Surbiton ancestors. Did they take the Kingston by-pass, turning left at Barnes, or did they strike west up the A308 via Norbiton to Hampton Wick? Both these theories ran up against one big obstacle - the Thames, lying like a silver turd between Richmond and Isleworth. This was a major setback. How could they possibly cross the river? Several hours of thought produced nothing. There was only one flask of coffee left when suddenly Mr Norris spotted something. Could this have been the method used? Hardly daring to believe, Mr Norris led his expedition on to the 3.47. Forty minutes later, via Clapham, Fulham, Chiswick and Brentford, they approached their goal: Hounslow. Was this, then, the final proof? Something aroused the accountant's instinct buried deep in Mr Norris's make-up. The journey was possible, and yet .... 'Wrong Way' Norris had accidentally stumbled on a piece of anthropological history. It was the inhabitants of Hounslow who had made the great trek south to the sunnier pastures of Surbiton, and not vice versa, as he had originally surmised. This was the secret of Surbiton! Happy and contented Mr Norris returned to the calmer waters of chartered accountancy, for, in his way, 'Wrong Way' Norris was right.

Apparently small investors were attracted by the wide-ranging portfolio and that in the first week the limited offer was oversubscribed eight times.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Tschaikowsky. Was he the tortured soul who poured out his immortal longings into dignified passages of stately music, or was he just an old poof who wrote tunes? Tonight on 'Farming Club' we're going to take an intimate look at Tschaikowsky and an intimate look at his friends. Incidentally, BBC Publications have prepared a special pamphlet to go with this programme called 'Hello Pianist', and it contains material that some people might find offensive but which is really smashing.

dialogue.speaker: Second Presenter
dialogue.text: Peter Ilyich Tschaikowsky was born in 1840 in a Ken Russell film just outside St Petersburg. His father , a free-lance bishop, was married to Verna Plachenka but secretly deeply in love with Margo Farenka and the strangely flatulent Madame Ranevsky . Soon, however, the family moved to the neighbouring industrial village of Omsk where they soon found themselves, sadly, quite unable to cope . In 1863, however, Tschaikowsky was sent to Moscow to study the piano and, when he'd finished that, the living room. Maurice takes up the story.

Robin.

dialogue.text: We are from the SS Mother Goose, we were twelve days out from Port of Spain, and I ...

dialogue.speaker: Second Guard
dialogue.text: I got thirty bob for the trousers!

dialogue.speaker: Captain
dialogue.text: We are from SS Mother Goose. We were twelve days out from Port of Spain, and one night I was doing my usual rounds, when I had occasion to pass the forward storage lockers...

dialogue.speaker: Police Chief
dialogue.text: Go on!

dialogue.speaker: Captain
dialogue.text: Well, I noticed something unusual, the main bilge hatches had been opened... and there, crouching amidst the scuppers was the most ghastly creature I'd ever seen in my life. As soon as it saw me, its horrible face split aside in a ghastly look of terror. His head, which was like ...

dialogue.speaker: Scene Shifter
dialogue.text: Could you sign this please? Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Captain
dialogue.text: A small, small rat was ghastly and horrible and befurred... its little red eyes glinted in the unaccustomed glare of the midday sun and before I could shut the hatch, it sprang upon me with one almighty...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Kelly
dialogue.text: What's this about doing the 'Horse of the Year Show' in here tonight?

dialogue.speaker: Police Chief
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Mrs Kelly. We don't know, I'm afraid - this is drama.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Kelly
dialogue.text: Mr Fox told me, before he went down to the pub, that they were doing 'Horse of the Year Show' in here tonight at 9.10.

dialogue.speaker: Police Chief
dialogue.text: This is BBC 2 .

dialogue.speaker: Captain
dialogue.text: I think BBC 1 are in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Kelly
dialogue.text: Well, I'm not having Harvey Smith jumping over my binette.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Kelly
dialogue.text: No, come on.

dialogue.speaker: Captain
dialogue.text: ... tearing at my throat, ripping my clothes...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Kelly
dialogue.text: And turn the gas off before you leave!

dialogue.speaker: Police Chief
dialogue.text: All right!!

dialogue.speaker: Captain
dialogue.text: I fought it with all my strength, but it was too much for me...

dialogue.speaker: Dorian Williams
dialogue.text: Another clear round for Harvey Smith on 'Orealley'.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: And now it's Mrs David Barker riding 'Atalanta' Number 3.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Kelly
dialogue.text: Right! That's it! Come on now, out! All of you - get out of my kitchen, all of you - come on! Harvey Smith, get out of here!

dialogue.speaker: Paul Fox
dialogue.text: It's one of our most popular programmes.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Kelly
dialogue.text: That's what think, Mr Fox!

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text: Well, that's all from BBC Television for this evening...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Kelly
dialogue.text: Shove off! Go and find yourself another flat! Get out!

dialogue.speaker: Announcer's Voice
dialogue.text: Tonight from London your special guests are Lulu, Ringo Starr and the man you've all been waiting for - your host for tonight...

dialogue.speaker: Lulu
dialogue.text: Love the outfit dear, it's gorgeous...

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: Hello, good evening, welcome. It's...

annotations: and CAPTIONS:
Pull back from a shot of an old little Ford Popular to reveal Mr and Mrs Norris, standing with it outside the front garden of a small suburban semi-detached house.
(shot of Mr Norris gazing into a window, where his book lies; there is a sign saying 'Remaindered')
(split-screen shot of two identical semi-detached houses)
(similarly, dressed suburbanites on other side of the split screen)
Split screen.
(cut to two lawnmowers arranged on a table, as if they were exhibits in a museum, with type-written documentation in front of them for the visitor)
(Mr Norris in a library reading a book titled 'The Lady with the Naked Skin' by Paul Fox Jnr)
Cut to Mr and Mrs Norris leaving their home.
(one tiny child holding a small British flag)
(quick flash of them sitting in the window of a Golden Egg or Wimpy place)
We see the diary.
Cut to Mr Norris's car driving along a suburban road. A sign says 'You are now leaving Surbiton, gateway to Esher'.
(cut to sign saying 'Hounslow 25 miles'; Mr Norris closely examines the sign, as would an archaeologist)
(badly shot pictures of sandwiches, with fingers in the lens, etc.)
(chord; Mr Norris points excitedly, pull back to reveal him standing on a bridge over the Kingston by-pass examining it through field glasses)
(cut to a map, it traces the two routes in red as the voice talks)
(the car at a river bank; Mr and Mrs Norris puzzling; behind them three or four bridges with traffic pouring over)
(cut to a sign saying Metropolitan Railway)
(cut to them getting on the train)
(a sign saying 'Hounslow Central'; Mr Norris sticks a British flag on the platform; he poses for his wife's photos; much hand shaking)
(cut to Mr Norris's eyes and furrowed brow)
(zoom in on railway timetable on wall saying 'Trains to Surbiton every half hour')
Music swells, over book title 'The Story of EBW 343 ' by 'Wrong Way' Norris.
A music crescendo. Cut to nude organist (Terry J) playing a chord.
Animated titles.
Cut to a headmaster's study.
(knock on door; it opens and three schoolboys in short trousers enter)
(silence)
(Tidwell raises hand reluctantly)
(very reluctantly)
(muttering into his shoes)

Cut to a sign saying 'How to do it'. Music. Pull out to reveal a 'Blue Peter' type set. Sitting casually on the edge of a dais are three presenters in sweaters - Noel, Jackie and Alan - plus a large bloodhound.
(picking up a flute)
Children's music. Pull out to reveal that the 'Blue Peter' set is in one corner of a stockbroker-belt sitting room. Two ladies are sitting by the fire looking at a photo album.
The door opens. The son comes in.
(they chuck him under the chin)
(the son smiles a little tight smile)
(gets out a rattle)
(whilst Mrs Nigger-Baiter is talking)
Sound of an explosion out of vision. Cut to reveal Mrs Nigger-Baiter's chair charred and smoking. Mrs Nigger-Baiter is no longer there. The upholstery is smouldering gently.
The doorbell rings. Mrs S goes to the door. A vicar with a suitcase.
The vicar opens his suitcase to reveal it is packed with brushes.
(she shuts the door, as she returns to seat the vicar pops his head round the door again)
(he goes)
Cut to a doctor in a posh consulting room.
(doorbell)
(he opens the door)
(exhibits the collection inside his jacket)
He shuts the door.
(goes to a wall diagram of two skeletons and taps one with a rod)
(clips a face on and moves off the diagram)
(moving through countryside)
(goes past various warning signs)
The sprocket holes at the side of the film come into view.
The skeleton moves past the sprocket holes and falls into blank space.
Artistic-type set. There is a large screen on back. Stock two-chair set-up as for interview.
(pigs appear on the screen, Cobbley gets up, looks about him, wanders off, rather puzzled)
Cue Tschaikowsky's first piano concerto. Stock film of a farmyard with superimposed roller caption.
Cut back to the presenter.
(pull back to show a second presenter in the other chair)
(a picture of Tschaikowsky on the screen)
(a picture of a naked sailor on a tiger-skin rug)
(It comes up on the screen; on its cover there is a picture of a pig)
(Leo McKern)
(Julie Christie)
(Shirley Abicair)
(Norris McWhirter)
(Eldridge Cleaver, Moira Lister and Stan the Bat)
(Eddie Waring)
(Anthony Barber)
Cut to a poofy presenter in really chintzy surroundings.
Cut back to second presenter.
Cut to space-programme-type set. Experts at a desk. An Apollo-type monograph behind them says 'Tchaikowsky XII'. The centre motif is a picture of Tschaikowsky.
He has a model of Tschaikowsky which comes apart.
(he takes the legs off)
(takes it off)
Cut to first expert.
Cut to first presenter.
Cut to second presenter.
Cut to Maurice.
Cut to a piano in a pool of light.

A chained figure in a sack rolls into shot and starts rolling about and playing the piano concerto. After a minute 'Rita' enters and gestures to him. She is in fish-net tights, etc, - the full conjurer's assistant. He wriggles free from the sack, playing the while. The music stops.
Film of an applauding audience in the Royal Albert Hall,
Jolly showbiz music. A curtain goes up, revealing three actors in trim-jeans
(which are heavily padded to make you sweat off weight)
grouped à la advert. They all have slight Australian accents.
Cut to a cathedral interior. There are three priests, four knights and two women, all in trim-jeans. Thomas does not wear one.
Cut back to Gary and the others.
Cut to a man (Terry J) in trim-jeans under a sign saying 'Before'.
(same shot but very skinny John Hughman has replaced Terry J)
(Long John Silver in trim-jeans)
(cut to a photo of two ballet dancers in a 'lift' position, both wearing tights and trim-jeans)
(cut to a photo of Toulouse Lautrec, his feet sticking out of the bottom of the trim-jeans)

Cut to scrubland, barbed wire a la prison camp in the background. After a few seconds a head appears out of a hole in the ground. He looks around then gets out. He is wearing trim-jeans. He looks back. Satisfied he beckons. Others start appearing. Three German guards behind the wire muttering.
A superimposed counter shows the numbers increasing.
A moment's panic. Shooting starts and a siren goes. Men pour out of hole rapidly. Guards pursue them with tracker dogs in trim-jeans. The counter goes berserk.
An animated item ends with a sign saying 'And now, the Fish Slapping Dance.'

Cut to a quayside. John and Michael, dressed in tropical gear and solar topees. John stannds still while Michael dances up and down before him to the jolly music of Edward German. Michael holds up two tiny fish and from time to time in the course of the dance he slaps John lightly across the cheeks with them. The music ends; Michael stops dancing. John produces a great fish and swipes Michael with it. Michael falls off the quay into the water.
underwater. We see an animated Michael sinking. He is swallowed by a fish with a swastika on its side.
The Nazi fish is swallowed by a fish with an RAF emblem.
The British fish is swallowed by a Chinese fish.
The Chinese fish bites the underside of a large ship. Film of big liner sinking in storm. General panic and dramatic music.
(over tannoy)

Cut to the ship's bridge. The captain and two or three officers are seen scrambling into ladies clothing or young children's short trousers and school satchels and caps. The ship pitches and rolls in the gale. The captain is still trying to speak into the PA.
A first officer is revealed in the corner of the bridge putting a head-dress on a Red Indian outfit.
(putting his hand over the PA)
(into the PA)
Cut to another officer in astronaut's kit.
(hand over PA)
Cut to third officer who is putting finishing touches to a medieval outfit.
(into the PA)
(puts his hand over the PA)
(into the PA)
(stock film of long shot of sinking vessel, the voice over fading)
Cut to a police chief's office in an anonymous South American police state. The chief of police at his desk. From outside we hear footsteps approaching the office and voices.

The door opens and two guards roughly push in the captain in drag, another officer half in drag, half in naval uniform, two officers hastily dressed as children, a complete Renaissance Man, a Red Indian and a spaceman. They stand there for a moment. Then one of the guards pushes his way forward and hands the police chief a piece of paper.
(reads)
(the guard nods enthusiasticaly)
(the guard mouths something)
(to camera)
(a third guard suddenly rushes up to the window and flashes through it; scream and breaking glass)
(banging the desk)
Cut to a newsreader in a 'News at Nine' set with a bare light bulb hanging in shot. He wears only an old blanket around his shoulders. He is shivering.
(he is handed a piece of paper)
(he coughs and pulls the blanket tighter round his shoulders)
Knocking on the door.
(banging)
Cut back to the same police chief's office. Noises off of people walking down. The door opens and the same crowd is pushed in. No one has any trouses on.
Enter a pantomime principal boy holding a stuffed cat. All the rest of the group break back in a well-choreographed panto arrowhead and raise their hands toward her.
(kids joining in voice over)
(plus kids)
(plus kids)
(getting up, holding a pistol; he has no trousers; silence)
The door is flung open and the second - trouserless - guard rushes in.

Slightly eerie music has crept in under his words and the screen goes into a ripple. It gets right out of focus and continues to ripple as it pulls back into focus. Ripple stops and they are still in the same set as they were.
(at this point three men in brown coats come in and start taking pictures off the wall, clearing props and chairs from the set, etc.)
(the flats start to be flown up, revealing behind a sitting room - so that we can see the police office has been built in the Kelly's sitting room)
(handing the captain a piece of paper)
By this time the whole office set has been removed revealing the Kelly's boarding house sitting room. Mr and Mrs Kelly come in through door and put their heads round.
(they go)
Mr Kelly puts his head round the door.
Mr Kelly goes.

Cut to Mr and Mrs Kelly coming through the hall. We can hear the captain's voice growing faster. Mr and Mrs Kelly go towards the kitchen door and stop and listen. We have lost the captain's voice by now, but from inside the kitchen we hear 'Horse of the Year Show' sound track.
(voice over)
(voice over on tannoy)
Crash of breaking pottery, falling pots and pans, horse neighing.
(they throw door open and march into the kitchen; a horse plus Pat Hornsby Smith and the commentator and the wreckage of a jump)
She chases them out and down the hall.
(emerging from another door)
She shooshes them all out down the passage and out of the front door. The newsreader with a blanket over him joins them and tries to read off a piece of paper.
(slamming door on him)

As she slams the door, a piece of paper (obviously a tax return form) is shoved through the door. It has the credits scribbled hurriedly on it; the camera pans into it. After the credits Mrs Kelly stamps on the paper.
Fade out.
Showbix music, cut to a sign saying 'It's'. Pull out to reveal glossy, spangly, opulent showbiz set. Two extraordinarily famous guests sitting on sofas.
More music. The 'It's' man, tattered and ragged as usual, emerges onto set.

The signature tune and opening animated titles start. The 'It's' man, still visible through the titles, tries in vain to stop them. The guests walk off in disgust. The 'It's' man tries to drag them back. Failing, he sits down as the music ends. Fade out.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 27: Whicker's World

dialogue.speaker: Icelandic Gent
dialogue.text: I Eric ... um

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now ...

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's ...

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Monty Python's Flying Circus!

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Michael Norman Randall, you have been found guilty of the murder of Arthur Reginald Webster, Charles Patrick Trumpington, Marcel Agnes Bernstein, Lewis Anona Rudd, John Malcolm Kerr, Nigel Sinclair Robinson, Norman Arthur Potter, Felicity Jayne Stone, Jean-Paul Reynard, Rachel Shirley Donaldson, Stephen Jay Greenblatt, Karl-Heinz Mullet, Belinda Anne Ventham, Juan-Carlos Fernandez, Thor Olaf Stensgaard, Lord Kimberley of Pretoria, Lady Kimberley of Pretoria, The Right Honourable Nigel Warmsly Kimberley, Robert Henry Noonan and Felix James Bennett, on or about the morning of the 19th December 1972. Have you anything to say before I pass sentence?

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Yes, sir. I'm very sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Very sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Yes, sir. It was a very very bad thing to have done and I'm really very ashamed of myself. I can only say it won't happen again. To have murdered so many people in such a short space of time is really awful, and I really am very, very, very sorry that I did it, and also that I've taken up so much of the court's valuable time listening to the sordid details of these senseless killings of mine. I would particularly like to say, a very personal and sincere 'sorry' to you, m'lud, for my appalling behaviour throughout this trial. I'd also like to say sorry to the police, for putting them to so much trouble for the literally hours of work they've had to put in, collecting evidence and identifying corpses and so forth. You know I think sometimes we ought to realize the difficult and often dangerous work involved in tracking down violent criminals like myself and I'd just like them to know that their fine work is at least appreciated by me.

dialogue.speaker: First Policeman
dialogue.text: No, no, we were only doing our job.

dialogue.speaker: Second Policeman
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: It's very good of you to say that, but I know what you've been through.

dialogue.speaker: First Policeman
dialogue.text: No, no, we've had worse.

dialogue.speaker: Third Policeman
dialogue.text: It was plain sailing apart from the arrest.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: I know and I'm grateful. I'd like to apologize too to the prosecuting counsel for dragging him in here morning after morning in such lovely weather.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Well, I would have had to come in anyway.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Ah good, but what a presentation of a case!

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Oh thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: No, no, it's a privilege to watch you in action. I never had a chance.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Oh yes you did.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Not after that summing up. Great.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Oh thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: And now I must come to the jury. What can I say. I've dragged you in here, day after day, keeping you away from your homes, your jobs, your loved ones, just to hear the private details of my petty atrocities.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: No, no, it was very interesting.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: But you could have had a much nicer case.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: No, no, murder's much more fun.

dialogue.speaker: First Juryman
dialogue.text: Yes and so many of them.

dialogue.speaker: Second Juryman
dialogue.text: Excellent.

dialogue.speaker: Third Juryman
dialogue.text: We've had a terrific time.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, I'm very moved. And so, m'lud, it only remains for you to pass the most savage sentence on me that the law can provide.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Well er... not necessarily.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: No, m'lud, the full penalty of the law is hardly sufficient. I insist I must be made an example of.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Well yes and no. I mean society at large...

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Oh no, m'lud. Not with mass murder.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: But in this case, don't you think?

dialogue.speaker: Court
dialogue.text: Yes, yes!

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Oh, come on, m'lud, you've got to give me life.

dialogue.speaker: Court
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Well, ten years at least.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Ten years!

dialogue.speaker: Court
dialogue.text: Shame. Shame!

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Well five then. Be fair.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: No, no. I'm giving you three months.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Oh no, that's so embarrassing. I won't hear of it. Give me six...please.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Well, all right. Six months.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Thank you, m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: But suspended.

dialogue.speaker: Randall
dialogue.text: Oh no.

dialogue.speaker: Court
dialogue.text: Hooray.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: Three cheers for the defendant. Hip. Hip.

dialogue.speaker: Court
dialogue.text: Hooray.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: Hip. Hip.

dialogue.speaker: Court
dialogue.text: Hooray.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: Hip. Hip.

dialogue.speaker: Court
dialogue.text: Hooray.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: For he's a jolly good fellow, For he's a jolly good fellow, For he's a jolly good fellow...

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Which nobody can deny.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: This little-known Icelandic saga, written by an unknown hand in the late thirteenth century, has remained undiscovered until today. Now it comes to your screens for the first time. Fresh from the leaves of Iceland's history. The terrible 'Njorl's Saga'.

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: It's not that terrible.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: No, I meant terribly violent.

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, yeah.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Erik Njorl, son of Frothgar, leaves his home to seek Hangar the Elder at the home of Thorvald Nlodvisson, the son of Gudleif, half brother of Thorgier, the priest of Ljosa water, who took to wife Thurunn, the mother of Thorkel Braggart, the slayer of Cudround the powerful, who knew Howal, son of Geernon, son of Erik from Valdalesc, son of Arval Gristlebeard, son of Harken, who killed Bjortguaard in Sochnadale in Norway over Cudreed, daughter of Thorkel Long, the son of Kettle-Trout, the half son of Harviyoun Half-troll, father of Ingbare the Brave, who with Isenbert of Gottenberg the daughter of Hangbard the Fierce ...

dialogue.speaker: Another Voice Over
dialogue.text: I must apologize for an error in the saga. Evidently Thorgier, the Priest of Ljosa water who took to wife Thurunn, the mother of Thorkel Braggart, the slayer of Gudmund the powerful, who knew Howal, son of Geernon, son of Erik from Vadalesc ...

dialogue.speaker: Original Voice Over
dialogue.text: Well I'm afraid we're having a little trouble getting this very exciting Icelandic saga started. If any of you at home have any ideas about how to get this exciting saga started again here's the address to write to:

dialogue.speaker: Third Voice Over
dialogue.text: Help the Exciting Icelandic Saga, 18b MacNorten Buildings, Oban.

script.description: CAPTION: 'HELP THE EXCITING ICELANDIC SAGA C/O MATCH OF THE DAY BBC TV THE LARCHES 26 WESTBROOK AVENUE FAVERSHAM KENT'

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Hello, well I was the third voice you heard just now. I'm sorry about that terrible mess.

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: Well it wasn't all that terrible.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: No, no, I meant terrible in the sense of unfortunate.

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Anyway, our plea for assistance has been answered by the North Malden Icelandic Saga Society who've given us some very useful information about the saga and so we carry on now with 'Njorl's Saga' with our thanks going, once again, to the North Maiden Icelandic Saga Society.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Erik Njorl, son of Frothgar rode off into the desolate plain. Day and night he rode, looking neither to right nor left. Stopping neither for food nor rest. Twelve days and nights he rode. Through rain and storm. Through wind and snow beyond the enchanted waterfall, through the elfin glades until he reached his goal. He had found the rich and pleasant land beyond the mountains, the land where golden streams sang their way through fresh green meadows. Where there were halls and palaces, an excellent swimming pool and one of the most attractive bonus incentive schemes for industrial development in the city. Only fifteen miles from excellent Thames-side docking facilities and within easy reach of the proposed M25. Here it was that Erik Njorl, son of Frothgar, met the mayor. Mr Arthur Huddinut, a local solicitor.

dialogue.speaker: Mayor
dialogue.text: Welcome to North Malden. Yes, everyone is welcome to North Malden, none more so than the businessmen and investors who shape our society of the future. Here at North Malden...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And we apologize to viewers of 'Njorl's Saga' who may be confused by some of the references to North Malden. After a frank exchange of views we have agreed to carry on showing this version supplied to us by the North Malden Icelandic Saga Society on the undertaking that future scenes will adhere more closely to the spirit of twelfth-century Iceland.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: With moist eyes, Erik leaves this happy land to return to the harsh uneconomic realities of life in the land of Ljosa waters. On his way Erik rested a while in the land of Bjornsstrand - the land of dark forces, where Gildor was King. These were the dukes of the land of Bjornsstrand. Proud warriors who bore on their chests the letters of their dread name.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer's Voice
dialogue.text: Hello? Is that the North Malden Icelandic Society?

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Yes, that's right.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: About this saga.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Oh yes, the Icelandic saga.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Good, isn't it.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Well er, I don't know, but you promised us that you would stick to the spirit of the original text.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Yes, that's right.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Well I mean a lot of these things that are happening, well they just don't quite ring true.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Well, it's a new interpretation really.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Well we don't want a new...

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: ... I mean we wanted the proper thing... I mean just look what's happening now.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Banners were a very important part of Icelandic lore, Mr Mills.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: No, no, I'm sorry I, I can't accept that, it's gone too far, I'm very sorry but we'll have to terminate the agreement. You're just trying to cash in on the BBC's exciting Icelandic saga.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: That's business, Mr Mills.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Well, that's as maybe but it's not the way the BBC works.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Well I'm sorry you feel that way but er, you know, if you ever want to come to Malden...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: 8 o'clock is a peak viewing hour so naturally we tend to stick to our comedy output - unless of course there's sport - because of course we know this is popular, and popularity is what television is about. Quite frankly I'm sick and tired of people accusing us of being ratings conscious.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Ratings conscious?

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Transmitting bland garbage, m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Now I'm really cheesed off. I mean it's not your high-brow bleeding plays that pull in the viewers, you know.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I mean Joe Public doesn't want to sit down and watch three hours of documentaries every evening.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: He wants to sit down and he wants to be entertained, he doesn't want a load... No really - I'm absolutely fed up with this. I really am.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Case dismissed.

dialogue.speaker: Prosecuting Counsel
dialogue.text: Case dismissed, m'lud?

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Oh all right, five years.

dialogue.speaker: Prosecuting Counsel
dialogue.text: Thank you, m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Call the next case please.

dialogue.speaker: Prosecuting Counsel
dialogue.text: Call Erik Njorl, son of Frothgar, brother of Hangnor... .

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Call Erik Njorl ... ,

dialogue.speaker: Voices
dialogue.text: Call Erik Njorl .. , .

dialogue.speaker: Usher
dialogue.text: You are Erik Njorl, son of Frothgar...

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Get on with it!

dialogue.speaker: Usher
dialogue.text: Will you raise your right hand.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: He obviously can't raise his right hand, you silly usher person... can you raise your right leg Mr Njorl?

dialogue.speaker: Usher
dialogue.text: Can you raise any part of your body, Mr Njorl?

dialogue.speaker: Usher
dialogue.text: I see... well, we'll skip that... well, just take the book in your right hand Mr Njorl without raising any part of your body... Oh ....

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: What is it now, you persistently silly usher?

dialogue.speaker: Usher
dialogue.text: He can't hold the Bible m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Well screw the Bible! Let's get on with this bleeding trial, I've got a Gay Lib meeting at 6 o'clock. Superintendent Lufthansa will you please read the charge.

dialogue.speaker: Superintendent
dialogue.text: Is a charge strictly necessary, m'lud?

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: The press is here.

dialogue.speaker: Superintendent
dialogue.text: Oh sorry! Right, here we go. You are hereby charged. One, that you did, on or about 1126, conspire to publicize a London Borough in the course of a BBC saga; two, that you were wilfully and persistently a foreigner; three, that you conspired to do things not normally considered illegal; four, that you were caught in possession of an offensive weapon, viz, the big brown table down at the police station.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: The big brown table down at the police station?

dialogue.speaker: Superintendent
dialogue.text: It's the best we could find, m'lud ... and five... all together now...

dialogue.speaker: Court
dialogue.text: Assaulting a police officer!

dialogue.speaker: Prosecuting Counsel
dialogue.text: Call Police Constable Pan-Am. Into the witness box, constable ... there'll be plenty of time for that later on. Now, you are Police Constable Pan-Am?

dialogue.speaker: Constable
dialogue.text: No, I shall deny that to the last breath in my body. Oh. Sorry, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Prosecuting Counsel
dialogue.text: Police constable, do you recognize the defendant?

dialogue.speaker: Constable
dialogue.text: No. Never seen him before in my life. Oh , yes, yes he's the one. He done it. I'd recognize him anywhere, sorry, super.

dialogue.speaker: Prosecuting Counsel
dialogue.text: Constable, will you please tell the court in your own words what happened?

dialogue.speaker: Constable
dialogue.text: Oh yes! I was proceeding in a northerly direction up Alitalia Street when I saw the deceased standing at an upstairs window, baring her bosom at the general public. She then took off her ... wait a tick. Wrong story. Ho yes! There were three nuns in a railway compartment and the ticket inspector says to one of them. No, anyway I clearly saw the deceased...

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Defendant.

dialogue.speaker: Constable
dialogue.text: Defendant! Sorry. Sorry, super. I clearly saw the defendant ... doing whatever he's accused of...Red-handed. When kicked... he said: 'It's a fair ... cop, I done it all ... Right... no doubt about... that'. Then, bound as he was to the chair, he assaulted myself and three other constables while bouncing around the cell. The end.

dialogue.speaker: Constable
dialogue.text: Thank you, thank you... and for my next piece of evidence...

dialogue.speaker: Superintendent
dialogue.text: I think you'd better leave it there, constable.

dialogue.speaker: Prosecuting Counsel
dialogue.text: Excellent evidence, constable ... Thank you very much. Now then Mr Njorl, will you tell the court please where were you on the night of 1126? Move any part of your body if you were north of a line from the Humbet to the Mersey.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Is he in there, d'you think? . .. Hello... Hello! Defendant, are you there ... coo-ee! De-fend-ant... I think you'd better go and have a look, Maurice.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Don't call me Maurice in court!

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And now the Stock Market Report by Exchange Telegraph.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Trading was crisp at the start of the day with some brisk business on the floor. Rubber hardened and string remained confident. Little bits of tin consolidated although biscuits sank after an early gain and stools remained anonymous. Armpits rallied well after a poor start. Nipples rose dramatically during the morning but had declined by mid-afternoon, while teeth clenched and buttocks remained firm. Small dark furry things increased severely on the floor, whilst rude jellies wobbled up and down, and bounced against rising thighs which had spread to all parts of the country by mid-afternoon. After lunch naughty things dipped sharply forcing giblets upwards with the nicky nacky noo. Ting tang tong rankled dithely, little tipples pooped and poppy things went pong! Gibble gabble gobble went the rickety rackety roo and ...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Hello, Mrs Premise.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Hello, Mrs Conclusion.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Busy day?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Busy! I've just spent four hours burying the cat.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Four hours to bury a cat?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Yes! It wouldn't keep still, wriggling about howling its head off.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Oh - it wasn't dead then?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Well, no, no, but it's not at all a well cat so as we were going away for a fortnight's holiday, I thought I'd better bury it just to be on the safe side.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Quite right. You don't want to come back from Sorento to a dead cat. It'd be so anticlimactic. Yes, kill it now, that's what I say.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: We're going to have our budgie put down.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Really? Is it very old?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: No. We just don't like it. We're going to take it to the vet tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Tell me, how do they put budgies down then?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Well it's funny you should ask that, but I've just been reading a great big book about how to put your budgie down, and apparently you can either hit them with the book, or, you can shoot them just there, just above the beak.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Just there!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Well well well. 'Course, Mrs Essence flushed hers down the loo.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Ooh! No! You shouldn't do that - no that's dangerous. Yes, they breed in the sewers, and eventually you get evil-smelling flocks of huge soiled budgies flying out of people's lavatories infringing their personal freedom. Good morning Mrs Cut-out.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: It's a funny thing freedom. I mean how can any of us be really free when we still have personal possessions.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: You can't. You can't. I mean, how can I go off and join Frelimo when I've got nine more installments to pay on the fridge.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: No, you can't. You can't. Well this is the whole crux of Jean-Paul Sartre's 'Roads to Freedom'.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: No, it bloody isn't. The nub of that is, his characters stand for all of us in their desire to avoid action. Mind you, the man at the off-licence says it's an everyday story of French country folk.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: What does he know?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Sixty new pence for a bottle of Maltese Claret. Well I personally think Jean-Paul's masterwork is an allegory of man's search for commitment.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: 'Tis.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: All right. We can soon settle this. We'll ask him.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Do you know him?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Yes, we met on holiday last year.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: In Ibeezer?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Yes. He was staying there with his wife and Mr and Mr Genet. Oh, I did get on well with Madam S. We were like that.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: What was Jean-Paul like?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Well, you know, a bit moody. Yes, he didn't join in the fun much. Just sat there thinking. Still, Mr Rotter caught him a few times with the whoopee cushion. Le Capitalisme et La Bourgeoisie ils sont la même chose... Oooh we did laugh.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Well, we'll give him a tinkle then.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Yes, all right. She said they were in the book. Where's the Paris telephone directory?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Inference
dialogue.text: It's on the drier.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: No, no, that's Budapest. Oh here we are Sartre ... Sartre.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Oh, thank you, Mrs Varley. Hallo. Paris 621036 please and make it snappy, buster... Hallo? Hello Mrs Sartre. It's Beulagh Premise here. Oh, pardon, c'est Beulagh Premise ici, oui, oui, dans Ibeezer. Oui, we met... nous nous recontrons au Hotel Miramar. Oui, à la barbeque, c'est vrai. Madame S. - est-ce que Jean est chez vous? Oh merde. When will he be free? Oh pardon. Quand sera-t-il libre? Oooooh. Ha ha ha ha She says he's spent the last sixty years trying to work that one out. Très amusant, Madam S. Oui absolument... à bientôt. Well he's out distributing pamphlets to the masses but he'll be in at six.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Oh well, I'll ring BEA then.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Oh look, Paris!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: That's not Paris. Jean-Paul wouldn't live here. It's a right old dump.

dialogue.speaker: Whicker
dialogue.text: But this is where they were wrong. For this was no old dump, but a town with a future, an urban El Dorado where the businessmen of today can enjoy the facilities of tomorrow in the comfort of yesterday. Provided by a go-getting, go-ahead council who know just how loud money can talk. Interest rates are so low...

dialogue.speaker: Head of Drama
dialogue.text: Well it's none of my business but we had the same trouble with one of our Icelandic sagas. These people are terribly keen but they do rather tend to take over. I think I'd stick to Caribbean Islands if I were you. Fine... and now back to the saga.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Here - this is not Paris, this is Iceland.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Oh, well, Paris must be over there then.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Oh, here we are, Number 25 .... Flat 1, Duke and Duchess of Windsor, Flat 2, Yves Montand, Flat 3, Jacques Cousteau, Flat 4, Jean Genet and Friend, Flat 5, Maurice Laroux...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Who's he?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Never heard of him. Flat 6, Marcel Marceau, 'Walking Against the Wind' Ltd. Flat 7, Indira Gandhi?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: She gets about a bit, doesn't she?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Yes, Flat 8, Jean-Paul and Betty-Muriel Sartre.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Oui.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: C'est nous, Betty-Muriel, excusez que nous sorerues en retard.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Entrez.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Oui, merci.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Sartre
dialogue.text: Oh, rubbish. Bonjour.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Parlez vous Anglais?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Sartre
dialogue.text: Oh yes. Good day. Hello, love!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Hello! Oh this is Mrs Conclusion from No. 46.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Sartre
dialogue.text: Nice to meet you, dear.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Hello.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: How's the old man, then?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Sartre
dialogue.text: Oh, don't ask. He's in one of his bleeding moods. 'The bourgeoisie this is the bourgeoisie that' - he's like a little child sometimes. I was only telling the Rainiers the other day - course he's always rude to them, only classy friends we've got - I was saying solidarity with the masses I said... pie in the sky! Oooh! You're not a Marxist are you Mrs Conclusion?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: No, I'm a Revisionist.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Sartre
dialogue.text: Oh good. I mean, look at this place! I'm at my wits end. Revolutionary leaflets everywhere. One of these days I'll revolutionary leaflets him. If it wasn't for the goat you couldn't get in here for propaganda.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Oh very well. Can we pop in and have a word with him?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Sartre
dialogue.text: Yes come along.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Sartre
dialogue.text: But be careful. He's had a few. Mind you he's as good as gold in the morning, I've got to hand it to him, but come lunchtime it's a bottle of vin ordinaire - six glasses and he's ready to agitate.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Coo-ee! Jean-Paul? Jean-Paul! It's only us. Oh pardon ... c'est même nous...

dialogue.speaker: Jean-Paul
dialogue.text: Oui.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: Jean-Paul. Your famous trilogy 'Rues à Liberté, is it an allegory of man's search for commitment?

dialogue.speaker: Jean-Paul
dialogue.text: Oui.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Premise
dialogue.text: I told you so.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Conclusion
dialogue.text: Oh coitus.

dialogue.speaker: First Whicker
dialogue.text: Today we look at a vanishing race. A problem people who are fast disappearing off the face of the earth.

dialogue.speaker: Second Whicker
dialogue.text: A race who one might say are losing a winning battle.

dialogue.speaker: Third Whicker
dialogue.text: They live in a sunshine paradise, a Caribbean dream, where only reality is missing.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Whicker
dialogue.text: For this is Whicker Island.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Whicker
dialogue.text: An island inhabited entirely by ex-international interviewers in pursuit of the impossible dream.

dialogue.speaker: First Whicker
dialogue.text: The whole problem of Whicker Island is here in a nutshell.

dialogue.speaker: Second Whicker
dialogue.text: There are just too many Whickers.

dialogue.speaker: Third Whicker
dialogue.text: The light-weight suits.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Whicker
dialogue.text: The old school tie.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Whicker
dialogue.text: The practised voice of the seasoned campaigner.

dialogue.speaker: First Whicker
dialogue.text: Cannot hide the basic tragedy here.

dialogue.speaker: Second Whicker
dialogue.text: There just aren't enough rich people left to interview.

dialogue.speaker: Third Whicker
dialogue.text: You can't teach an old dog new tricks and so you find them...

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Whicker
dialogue.text: Sitting beside elegant swimming pools...

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Whicker
dialogue.text: ... sipping Martinis...

dialogue.speaker: First Whicker
dialogue.text: .. and waiting for the inevitable interview.

dialogue.speaker: Second Whicker
dialogue.text: I talked to the island's only white man, Father Pierre.

dialogue.speaker: Third Whicker
dialogue.text: Father Pierre, why did you stay on in this colonial Campari-land where the clink of glasses mingles with the murmur of a million mosquitoes, where waterfalls of whisky wash away the worries of a world-weary Whicker, where gin and tonic jingle in a gyroscopic jubilee of something beginning with J - Father Pierre, why did you stay on here?

dialogue.speaker: Father Pierre
dialogue.text: Well mainly for the interviews.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Whicker
dialogue.text: Well there you have it, a crumbling...

dialogue.speaker: First Whicker
dialogue.text: ... empire in the sun-drenched...

dialogue.speaker: Second Whicker
dialogue.text: Caribbean, where the clichés sparkle on the waters...
