dialogue.speaker: Third Whicker
dialogue.text: ... like the music of repeat fees...

dialogue.speaker: First Whicker
dialogue.text: And so...

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Whicker
dialogue.text: ... from Whicker Island...

dialogue.speaker: Second Whicker
dialogue.text: ... fare...

dialogue.speaker: Third Whicker
dialogue.text: ... well and...

dialogue.speaker: First Whicker
dialogue.text: ... age.

annotations: The camera pans across Glencoe. The wind is whistling and climaxes with a great chord, which introduces...
The caption fades. Continue the pan until we pick up Icelandic gentleman. He unravels a scroll and starts to read.

The camera pans away from him and picks up a man (Terry J) seated at the organ, his back to the camera. He is naked, and he looks identical to the way he did in that deceased classic of our time 'And now for something completely trivial'. He grins at the camera and plays a few chords. Quick cut to the announcer at his desk.
Quick cut to close up of 'It's' man.
Cut to a courtroom. Severe atmosphere.
(shot of three heavily bandaged exhausted-looking policemen behind him)
The policemen look embarrassed.
(very chuffed)
(the jury applauds)
(blows his nose, does a Dickie Attenborough)
(to court)
(to court at large)
(they applaud)
(off )
Pan across a bleak landscape.
Cut to Viking.
Cut to landscape. The announcer appears in the corner of the shot.
Cut to Viking.
A Viking hut. A Viking comes out and has great difficulty mounting his horse.
(fades and continues under:)
(fades under next speech)
The Viking has still failed to mount his horse. Both he and the horse look a bit exasperated.
Cut to an office: the announcer at a desk. At another desk a secretary, applies a deodorant spray to her bust.
(to camera)
Cut to the Viking at wheel of car.
Cut back to the office.
Cut to the Viking.
Cut back to the office.
Cut to the Viking standing by his home. He is asleep.
(the Viking manages to mount the horse; he rides off)
(shots of Erik riding through a bleak landscape)
(Erik rides past a Waterfall)
(shot of a modern road sign: 'North Malden - please drive carefully')
(shots of Erik riding gently through a modern suburban shopping street)
Erik rides up to the town hall and is met by the mayor.
(to camera)
His voice fades under the following.
Film leader countdown (5, 4, 3. . .) then shot of Erik riding away into bleak landscape.
(Erik comes to a river in a wood; he drinks)
(sudden shot of six armoured knights standing in a row)
The knights move their shields to reveal on their breastplates the letters M.A.L.D.E.N. Shots of Erik battling with the knights. A telephone rings and the following conversation is heard.
One of the knights is carrying a sign: 'Malden, Gateway to Industry'.
Another carries a sign, 'ICI thanks Malden'.
More signs: 'Invest in Malden', 'Malden - 45% Interest Free Loans '.
The knights are carrying more and more advertising banners and signs.
Film leader countdown (5, 4, 3...).
Usual dramatic music. Fade music as we come up on a courtroom. A man, Mr Birchenhall, is giving evidence.
(to the clerk of the court)
(bored)
(getting more and more angry)
(he is helped out of court by two policemen, still protesting violently)
(banging gavel)
The prosecuting counsel rises anxiously.
(he sits)
(etc.)
(etc.)
(off)
(etc.)
(all calling at once)
Erik comes into the dock. He is bandaged almost totally, like a cocoon, including his head. He wears a Viking fur hat, The usher approaches him with the card and Bible.
Njorl shakes his head.
Njorl leans over and whispers in the usher's ear.
(heavy aside)
The whole court shout together.
(Pan-Am runs into court and starts beating Njorl with a truncheon)
(the policeman gets into box hitting at anyone within range; his colleagues restrain him)
(superintendent nods)
(superintendent nods)
(the superintendent looks embarrassed)
(refers to his notebook)
(points at Njorl)
(refers to his notebook)
(the superintendent shakes his head)
Spontaneous applause from the court. Shouts of 'more! more!'. Pan-am raises his hands and the clapping and shouting dies down.
(the constable is removed, flailing his truncheon the while)
(silence from the bandages)
(silence)
(to the clerk of the court)

The clerk and prosecuting counsel and two policemen look inside Njorl, who is now in fact a framework of bandages with no one inside. From this oh-so zany situation only Terry 'Marty Feldman's Comedy Machine' Gilliam can save us ...
(a bucketful of water descends on him)
ends with an animated woman going into a laundromat. Cut to the interior of a laundromat. Various shabby folk sitting around. Mrs Conclusion approaches Mrs Premise and sits down.
(life-size cut-out of woman at end of last animation goes by)
(she demonstrates)
(shouts)
(dials)
(as they wait they sing 'The Girl from Ipanema')
(to Mrs Conclusion)
(to Madame Sartre)
(puts the phone down)
Cut to them sitting on a raft in mid-ocean.
Cut to shot of a notice board on the seashore, it reads 'North Malden Welcomes Careful Coastal Craft'.
'Alan Whicker', complete with microphone, walks in front of sign.
(a phone off-screen starts to ring)
Cut to head of drama's office; he is on the phone.
(rings off)
Thundering music. Cut to an Icelandic seashore. Dark and impressive. After a pause the pepperpots walk into shot.
(points out to the sea; they walk back to the raft)

Stock shot of Eiffel Tower. French accordion music. Mix through to French street thronged by old Frenchmen with berets and loaves. Mrs Conclusion and Mrs Premise appear and walk up to the front door of an apartment block. On the front door is a list of the inhabitants of the block. They read it out loud.
(reads)
She rings the bell. A voice comes from the intercom.
Buzzer sounds.

Interior the Sartres flat. It is littered with books and papers. We hear Jean-Paul coughing. Mrs Sartre goes to the door. She is a ratbag with a fag in her mouth and a duster over her head. A French song is heard on the radio. She switches it off.
(opens the door)
(entering)
(Mrs Premise comes in)
Shot of a goat eating leaflets in corner of room.
Mrs Premise and Mrs Conclusion knock on the door of Jean-Paul's room.
They enter. We do not see Jean-Paul although we hear his voice.
Stock shot of a plane taking off

A stock shot of a jet landing which they always use to introduce 'Whicker's World'. This leads us into Whicker Island - a tropical island paradise where all the inhabitants have Alan Whicker suits, glasses and microphones.
Various Whickers pace past the camera.
Cut to a different location.
(turning to a swimming pool with lots of Whickers around it, wandering with stick mikes and muttering)
(seated by swimming pool)
(seated at drinks table, with sun umbrella)
(standing by the pool)
(standing fully clothed in the pool)
Cut to a different location. Feeling of heat. The third Whicker stands beside a priest in a white robe.
(putting on a pair of Whicker-style glasses)
Cut to film of Whicker plane taking off. Roll credits, which read:

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 26

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text:
Ladies and gentlemen, I am not simply going
to say 'and now for something completely different' this week, as I do
not think it fit. This is a particularly auspicious occasion for us
this evening, as we have been told that Her Majesty the Queen will be
watching part of the show tonight. We don't know exactly when Her
Majesty will be tuning in. We understand that at the moment she is
watching 'The Virginian', but we have been promised that we will be
informed the moment that she changes channel. Her majesty would like
everyone to behave quite normally but her equerry has asked me to
request all of you at home to stand when the great moment arrives,
although we here in the studio will be carrying on with our humorous
vignettes and spoofs in the ordinary way. Thank you. And now without
any more ado and completely as normal, here are the opening titles.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
The coal miners of Wales have long been famed
for their tough rugged life hewing the black gold from the
uncompromising hell of one mile under. This is the story of such men, battling
gallantly against floods, roof falls, the English criminal law, the
hidden killer carbon monoxide and the ever-present threat of
pneumoconiosis which is... a disease miners get.

dialogue.speaker: First Miner
dialogue.text:
Don't you talk to me like that, you lying
bastard.

dialogue.speaker: Second Miner
dialogue.text:
You bleeding pig. You're not fit to be down
a mine.

dialogue.speaker: First Miner
dialogue.text:
Typical bleeding Rhondda, isn't it. You
think you're so bloody clever.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text:
You bloody fighting again. Break it up or
I'll put this pick through your head. Now what's it all about?

dialogue.speaker: First Miner
dialogue.text: He started it.

dialogue.speaker: Second Miner
dialogue.text: Oh, you bleeding pig, you started it.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text:
I don't care who bloody started it. What's it
about?

dialogue.speaker: Second Miner
dialogue.text:
Well ... he said the bloody Treaty of
Utrecht was 1713.

dialogue.speaker: First Miner
dialogue.text: So it bloody is.

dialogue.speaker: Second Miner
dialogue.text:
No it bloody isn't. It wasn't ratified 'til
February 1714.

dialogue.speaker: First Miner
dialogue.text:
He's bluffing. You're mind's gone, Jenkins.
You're rubbish.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text:
He's right, Jenkins. It was ratified
September 1713. The whole bloody pit knows that. Look in Trevelyan,
page 468.

dialogue.speaker: Third Miner
dialogue.text:
He's thinking of the Treaty of bloody
Westphalia.

dialogue.speaker: Second Miner
dialogue.text:
Are you saying I don't know the difference
between the War of the bloody Spanish Succession and the Thirty bloody
Years War?

dialogue.speaker: Third Miner
dialogue.text:
You don't know the difference between the
Battle of Borodino and a tiger's bum.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text:
Break it up, break it up. I'm sick of all this bloody fighting. If it's not
the bloody Treaty of Utrecht it's the bloody binomial theorem. This
isn't the senior common room at All Souls, it's the bloody coal face.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Miner
dialogue.text:
(Ian Davidson) Hey, gaffer, can you settle something? Morgan here says you
find the abacus between the triglyphs in the frieze section of the
entablature of classical Greek Doric temples.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text:
You bloody fool, Morgan, that's the metope.
The abacus is between the architrave and the aechinus in the capital.

dialogue.speaker: Morgan
dialogue.text: You stinking liar.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text:
Oh, most magnificent and merciful majesty,
master of the universe, protector of the meek, whose nose we are not
worthy to pick and whose very feces are an untrammelled delight, and
whose peacocks keep us awake all hours of the night with their noisy
lovemaking, we beseech thee, tell thy humble servants the name of the
section between the triglyphs in the frieze section of a classical
Doric entablature.

dialogue.speaker: Management Man
dialogue.text: No idea. Sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: Right. Everybody out.

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text:
Still no settlement in the coal mine
dispute at Llanddarog. Miners refused to return to work until the
management define a metope. Meanwhile, at Dagenham the unofficial
strike committee at Fords have increased their demands to thirteen
reasons why Henry III was a bad king. And finally, in the disgusting
objects international at Wembley tonight, England beat Spain by a plate
of braised pus to a putrid heron. And now, the Toad Elevating Moment.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Good evening. Well, we have in the studio
tonight a man who says things in a very roundabout way. Isn't that so,
Mr Pudifoot.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Pudifoot
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Have you always said things in a very
roundabout way?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Pudifoot
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Well, I can't help noticing that, for
someone who claims to say things in a very roundabout way, your last
two answers have very little of the discursive quality about them.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Pudifoot
dialogue.text:
Oh, well, I'm not very talkative today.
It's a form of defensive response to intensive interrogative stimuli. I
used to get it badly when I was a boy ... well, I say very badly, in
fact, do you remember when there was that fashion for, you know, little
poodles with small coats...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Ah, now you're beginning to talk in a
roundabout way.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Pudifoot
dialogue.text: Oh, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
No, no, no, no. Please do carry on ...
because that is in fact why we wanted you on the show.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Pudifoot
dialogue.text:
I thought it was because you were
interested in me as a human being.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Well... lets move on to our
guest who not only
lives in Essex but also speaks only the ends of words. Mr Ohn Ith. Mr
Ith, good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Ith
dialogue.text: ... ood ... ing.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Nice to have you on the show.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Mr Ith, don't you find it very difficult to
make yourself understood?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Ith
dialogue.text: Yes, it is extremely difficult.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Just a minute, you're a fraud

dialogue.speaker: Mr Ith
dialogue.text:
Oh no. I can speak the third and fourth
sentences perfectly normally.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Oh I see. So your next sentence will be
only the ends of words again?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Ith
dialogue.text: T's... ight.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Well, let's move on to our
next guest who
speaks only the beginnings of words, Mr J ... Sm... Mr Sm... good
evening.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well, have you two met before?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Well, this is really a
fascinating occasion
because we have in the studio Mr ... oh ... I ... who speaks only the
middles of words. Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Um, where do you come from?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Dunfermline in Scotland. Well let me
introduce you, Mr Ohn Ith...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Ith
dialogue.text: ... ood ... ing.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Sm
dialogue.text: G... Eve...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Yes, well, ha, ha, just a moment. Perhaps
you would all like to say good evening together.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Sm
dialogue.text: Eve...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Ith
dialogue.text: ... ing.

dialogue.speaker: Adman
dialogue.text:
This table has been treated with ordinary
soap powder, but these have been treated with new Fibro-Val. We put both of them through our washing machine, and just
look at the difference. The
table is broken and smashed, but the sheets, with Fibro-Val, are
sparkling clean and white.

dialogue.speaker: Man's Voice
dialogue.text:
I love the surgical garment. Enjoy the
delights of the Victor Mature abdominal corset. Sail down the Nile on
the Bleed-it Kosher Truss. And don't forget the Hercules Hold-'em-in, the all.purpose concrete
truss for the man with the family hernia.

dialogue.speaker: Adman
dialogue.text:
Well last week on Fish Club we learnt how to
sex a pike ... and this week we're going to learn how to feed a
goldfish. Now contrary to what most people think the goldfish has a
ravenous appetite. If it doesn't get enough protein it gets very thin
and its bones begin to stick out and its fins start to fall off. So
once a week give your goldfish a really good meal. Here's one specially
recommended by the board of Irresponsible People. First, some cold
consommé or a gazpacho , then some sausages
with spring greens, sautée potatoes and bread and gravy.

dialogue.speaker: RSPCA Man
dialogue.text: All right, come on, that's enough, that's enough.

dialogue.speaker: Adman
dialogue.text: ... treacle tart ... chocolate cake and ...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
'THE RSPCA WISH IT TO
BE KNOWN THAT THAT MAN WAS NOT A BONA FIDE ANIMAL LOVER, AND ALSO THAT
GOLDFISH DO NOT EAT SAUSAGES. SHUT UP!
... THEY ARE QUITE HAPPY WITH BREADCRUMBS, ANT'S EGGS AND THE
OCCASIONAL PHEASANT ...'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Who wrote that?

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text:
I hope you're
enjoying the show.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
Herbert Mental collects birdwatchers' eggs.
At his home in Surrey he has a collection of over four hundred of them.

dialogue.speaker: Herbert
dialogue.text:
'Ere now. This is a very interesting one.
This is from a Mr P. F. Bradshaw. He is usually found in Surrey
hedgerows, but I found this one in the gents at St Pancras, uneaten. Mr
Mental, why did you start collecting birdwatchers' eggs? Oh, well, I did it to get on 'Man Alive'. 'Man Alive'? That's right, yes. But then that
got all serious, so I carried on in the hope of a quick appearance as
an eccentric on the regional section of 'Nationwide'. Mr Mental, I believe a couple of years ago you started to collect
butterfly hunters. Butterfly hunters? Yes. Oh, that's right. Here's a couple of them
over here. Nice little chaps. But
the hobby I enjoyed most was racing pigeon fanciers.

dialogue.speaker: Spiny Norman
dialogue.text: Dinsdale! Dinsdale!

script.description:
EXTREMELY ANIMATED CAPTION: 'MONTY PYTHON PROUDLY PRESENTS
THE INSURANCE SKETCH'

dialogue.speaker: Martin
dialogue.text:
Good morning. I've been in touch with you
about the, er, life insurance...

dialogue.speaker: Feldman
dialogue.text:
Ah yes, did you bring the um ... the specimen
of your um ... and so on, and so on?

dialogue.speaker: Martin
dialogue.text:
Yes I did. It's in the car. There's rather a
lot.

dialogue.speaker: Feldman
dialogue.text: Good, good.

dialogue.speaker: Martin
dialogue.text: Do you really need twelve gallons?

dialogue.speaker: Feldman
dialogue.text: No, no, not really.

dialogue.speaker: Martin
dialogue.text: Do you test it?

dialogue.speaker: Feldman
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Martin
dialogue.text: Well, why do you want it?

dialogue.speaker: Feldman
dialogue.text:
Well, we do it to make sure that you're
serious about wanting insurance, I mean, if you're not, you won't spend
a couple of months filling up that enormous churn with mmm, so on and
so on...

dialogue.speaker: Martin
dialogue.text: Shall I bring it in?

dialogue.speaker: Feldman
dialogue.text: Good Lord no. Throw it away.

dialogue.speaker: Martin
dialogue.text:
Throw it away? I was months filling that
thing up.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
And we've just heard that Her Majesty the
Queen has just tuned into this programme and so she is now watching
this royal sketch here in this royal set. The actor on the left is
wearing the great grey suit of the BBC wardrobe department and the
other actor is ... about to deliver the first great royal joke here
this royal evening. Over to the fight you can see the royal cameraman, and behind... Oh,
we've just heard she's switched over. She's watching the 'News at Ten'.

dialogue.speaker: First Doctor
dialogue.text:
Get on parade! Come on! We haven't got all
day, have we? Come on, come on, come on. Hurry up ... right! Now, I know some
hospitals where you get the patients lying around in bed. Sleeping,
resting, recuperating, convalescing. Well, that's not the way we do
things here, right! No, you won't be loafing about in bed wasting the
doctors' time. You - you horrible little cripple. What's the matter
with you?

dialogue.speaker: Patient
dialogue.text: Fractured tibia, sergeant.

dialogue.speaker: First Doctor
dialogue.text:
'Fractured tibia, sergeant'? 'Fractured
tibia, sergeant'? Ooh. Proper little mummy's boy, aren't we? Well, I'll
tell you something, my fine friend, if you fracture a tibia here you
keep quiet about it! Look at him! He's
broken both his arms and he don't go shouting about it, do he? No! 'Cos
he's a man - he's a woman, you see, so don't come that broken tibia
talk with me. Get on at the double. One, two, three, pick that crutch
up, pick that crutch right up.

dialogue.speaker: Patient
dialogue.text: Aaargh!

dialogue.speaker: First Doctor
dialogue.text:
Right, squad, 'shun! Squad, right turn.
Squad, by the left, quick limp! Come on, pick 'em up. Get some air in
those wounds.

dialogue.speaker: Second Doctor
dialogue.text:
Here at St Pooves, we
believe in ART - Active Recuperation Techniques. We try to help the
patient understand that however ill he may be, he can still fulfill a
useful role in society. Sun lounge please, Mr Griffiths.

dialogue.speaker: Patient
dialogue.text:
I've got a triple fracture of the right
leg, dislocated collar bone and multiple head injuries, so I do most of
the heavy work, like helping the surgeon.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer's Voice
dialogue.text: What does that involve?

dialogue.speaker: Patient
dialogue.text:
Well, at the moment we're building him a
holiday home.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer's Voice
dialogue.text: What about the nurses?

dialogue.speaker: Patient
dialogue.text:
Well, I don't know about them. They're not
allowed to mix with the patients.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer's Voice
dialogue.text: Do all the patients work?

dialogue.speaker: Patient
dialogue.text:
No, no, the ones that are really ill do
sport.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
Yes, one thing patients here dread are the
runs.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer's Voice
dialogue.text: How are you feeling?

dialogue.speaker: Patient
dialogue.text: Much better.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
But patients are allowed visiting. And
this week they're visiting an iron foundry at Swindon, which is crying
out for unskilled labour. But this
isn't the only hospital where doctors' conditions are improving.

dialogue.speaker: Third Doctor
dialogue.text:
Er, very little shortage of doctors here.
We have over forty doctors per bed - er, patient. Oh, be honest. Bed.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Doctor
dialogue.text:
We've every facility here for dealing with
people who are rich. We can deal with a blocked purse, we can drain
private accounts and in the worst cases we can perform a total
cashectomy, which is total removal of all moneys from the patient.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Doctor
dialogue.text:
Well, here we try to help people who have to
link sketches together. We try to stop them saying 'Have you ever
wondered what it would be like if' and instead say something like um...
er... 'And now the mountaineering sketch'.

dialogue.speaker: Mountaineer
dialogue.text: I haven't written a mountaineering sketch.

dialogue.speaker: Mountaineer
dialogue.text:
But now over to the
exploding version of the
'Blue Danube'.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
And now a dormitory in a
girls' public school.

dialogue.speaker: First Butch Voice
dialogue.text:
Hello, Agnes... Agnes are you awake?
Agnes....

dialogue.speaker: First Butch Voice
dialogue.text: Agnes...

dialogue.speaker: Second Butch Voice
dialogue.text: Who is it ... is that you, Charlie?

dialogue.speaker: First Butch Voice
dialogue.text: Yeah... Agnes, where's Jane?

dialogue.speaker: Third Butch Voice
dialogue.text: I'm over here, Charlie.

dialogue.speaker: First Butch Voice
dialogue.text:
Jane, we're going down to raid the tuck
shop.

dialogue.speaker: Second Butch Voice
dialogue.text: Oh good oh ... count me in, girls.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Butch Voice
dialogue.text: Can I come, too, Agnes?

dialogue.speaker: First Butch Voice
dialogue.text: Yeah, Joyce.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Butch Voice
dialogue.text: And me and Avril...

dialogue.speaker: Third Butch Voice
dialogue.text: Yeah, rather... and Suki.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Butch Voice
dialogue.text: Oh, whacko the diddle-oh.

dialogue.speaker: First Butch Voice
dialogue.text: Cave girls... Here comes Miss Rodgers...

dialogue.speaker: Miss Rodgers
dialogue.text:
All right girls, now stop this tomfoolery
and get back to bed, remember it's the big match at St Bridget's
tomorrow.

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'THE NAUGHTIEST GIRL IN THE SCHOOL'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
Yes, on your screen tomorrow: 'The Naughtiest
Girl in the School' starring the men of the 14th Marine Commandos. And now it's documentary time, when we look at the
momentous last years of the Second World War, and tonight the invasion
of Normandy performed by the girls of Oakdene High School, Upper Fifth
Science.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oh, it's still raining.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: I'm going down the shops.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text:
Oh, be a dear and get me some rats' bane
for the budgie's boil. Otherwise I'll put your eyes out.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Aye, aye, captain.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Coo-ee. Torpedo bay.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Yoo-hoo. Torpedo bay.

dialogue.speaker: Third Pepperpot
dialogue.text: She said torpedo bay.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Yes, she did, she did.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Pepperpot
dialogue.text:
Yes, she said torpedo bay. She did, she
did.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text:
Mrs Lieutenant Edale here. Mrs Midshipman
Nesbitt's got one of her headaches again, so I put her in the torpedo
tube.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text:
Roger, Mrs Edale. Stand by to fire Mrs
Nesbitt.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Stand by to fire Mrs Nesbitt.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Red alert, put the kettle on.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Kettle on.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Engine room, stand by to feed the cat.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Standing by to feed the cat.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Fire Mrs Nesbitt.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Nesbitt
dialogue.text: Oh, that's much better.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
As an admiral who came up through the ranks
more times than you've had hot dinners, I wish to join my husband
Admiral O.W.A Giveaway in condemning this shoddy misrepresentation of
our modern navy. The British Navy is one of the finest and most
attractive and butchest fighting forces in the world. I love those
white flared trousers and the feel of rough blue serge on those pert
little buttocks!

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text:
I'm afraid we are unable to show you any
more of that letter. We continue with a man with a stoat through his
head.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: And now ...

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Still no sign of land ... How long is it?

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: That's a rather personal question, sir.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text:
You stupid git. I meant how long we've
been in the lifeboat. You've spoilt the atmosphere now.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text:
Shut up! We'll have to start again ...
Still no sign of land ... how long is it?

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: Thirty-three days, sir.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Thirty-three days?

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text:
I don't think we can hold out much longer.
I don't think I did spoil the atmosphere.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, I don't think I did.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Of course you did.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text:
Do you think I
spoilt the atmosphere?

dialogue.speaker: Third Sailor
dialogue.text: Well, I think you ...

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text:
Look, shut up! SHUT UP! ... Still no sign
of land ... how long is it?

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: Thirty-three days.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Sailor
dialogue.text: Have we started again? Wagh!

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Still no sign of land ... how long is it?

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: Thirty-three days, sir.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Thirty-three days?

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text:
Yes. We can't go hold out much longer, sir.
We haven't had any food since the fifth day.

dialogue.speaker: Third Sailor
dialogue.text: We're done for, we're done for!

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text:
Shut up, Maudling. We've just got to keep
hoping someone will find us.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Sailor
dialogue.text: How are you feeling, captain?

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Sailor
dialogue.text: Not too good ... I ... feel ... so weak.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: We can't hold out much longer.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Sailor
dialogue.text:
Listen ... chaps ... there's one last chance.
I'm done for, I've got a gammy leg, I'm going fast, I'll never get
through ... but ... some of you might ... so you'd better eat me.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Eat you, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Sailor
dialogue.text: Yes. Eat me.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: Uuuuggghhh! With a gammy leg?

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Sailor
dialogue.text:
You don't have to eat the leg, Thompson,
there's still plenty of good meat ... look at that arm.

dialogue.speaker: Third Sailor
dialogue.text: It's not just the leg, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Sailor
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Third Sailor
dialogue.text: Well, sir ... it's just that ...

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Sailor
dialogue.text: Why don't you want to eat me?

dialogue.speaker: Third Sailor
dialogue.text: I'd rather eat Johnson, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: Oh, so would I, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Sailor
dialogue.text: I see.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Sailor
dialogue.text:
Well, that's settled then. Everyone eats
me.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Well ... I ... er ...

dialogue.speaker: Third Sailor
dialogue.text: What, sir?

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: No, no, you go ahead, I won't ...

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Sailor
dialogue.text:
Nonsense, nonsense, sir, you're starving.
Tuck in!

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: No, no, it's not just that ...

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: What's the matter with Johnson, sir?

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Well, he's not kosher.

dialogue.speaker: Third Sailor
dialogue.text: That depends how we kill him, sir.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text:
Yes, yes, I see that ... well to be quite
frank, I like my meat a little more lean. I'd rather eat Hodges.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text: Oh well ... all right.

dialogue.speaker: Third Sailor
dialogue.text: No, I'd still prefer Johnson.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Sailor
dialogue.text: I wish you'd all stop bickering and eat me.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogue.text:
Look! I'll tell you what. Why don't those
of us who want to, eat Johnson, then you, sir, can eat my leg and then
we'll make a stock of the Captain and then after that we can eat the
rest of Johnson cold for supper.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Good thinking, Hodges.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Sailor
dialogue.text: And we'll finnish off with the peaches.

dialogue.speaker: Third Sailor
dialogue.text: And we can start off with the advocados.

dialogue.speaker: First Sailor
dialogue.text: Waitress! We've decided now, we're going to have leg of Hodges ...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
Dear Sir, I am glad to hear that your studio
audience disapproves of the last skit as strongly as I. As a naval
officer I abhor the implication that the Royal Navy is a haven for
cannibalism. It is well known that we have the problem relatively under
control, and that it is the RAF who now suffer the largest casualties
in this area. And what do you think the Argylls ate in Aden. Arabs?
Yours etc. Captain B.J. Smethwick in a white wine sauce with shallots,
mushrooms and garlic.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Stop it, stop it. Stop this cannibalism.
Let's have a sketch about clean, decent human beings.

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: Morning.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Good Morning.

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: What can I do for you, squire?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Um, well, I wonder if you can help me. You
see, my mother has just died.

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text:
Ah well, we can help you. We deal with
stiffs.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text:
Well, there's three things we can do with
your mum. We can bury her, burn her, or dump her.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Dump her?

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: Dump her in the Thames.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: Oh, did you like her?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes!

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text:
Oh well, we won't dump her, then. Well,
what do you think? We can bury her or burn her.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well, which do you recommend?

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text:
Well, they're both nasty. If we burn her,
she gets stuffed in the flames, crackle, crackle, crackle, which is a
bit of a shock if she's not quite dead, but quick. and then we give you handful of ashes, which you can
pretend are hers.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text:
Or, if we bury her she gets eaten up lots
of weevils, and nasty maggots, which as
I said before is a bit of a shock if she's not quite dead.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I see. Well, she's definitely dead.

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: Where is she?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: She's in this sack.

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: Can I have a look? She looks quite young.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, she was.

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: Fred!

dialogue.speaker: Fred's voice
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: I think we've got an eater.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Fred
dialogue.text: Right, I'll get the oven on.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Er, excuse me, um, are you suggesting eating
my mother?

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: Er ... Yeah. Not raw. Cooked.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text:
Yes, roasted with a few french fries,
broccoli, horseradish sauce ...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well, I do feel a bit peckish.

dialogue.speaker: Voice From Audience
dialogue.text: Disgraceful! Boo!

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: Great!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Can we have some parsnips?

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text: Fred - get some parsnips.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I really don't think I should.

dialogue.speaker: Undertaker
dialogue.text:
Look, tell you what, we'll eat her, if you
feel a bit guilty about it after, we can dig a grave and you can throw
up in it.

annotations: Announcer standing in front of his desk.
(bows)
Very regal animated opening titles.

A nice photograph of a typical pit head. Music over this:
'All Through the Night' being sung in Welsh.

(at this moment
across the bottom of the screen comes the following message in urgent
teleprinter style, moving right to left, superimposed 'HM THE QUEEN
STILL WATCHING 'THE VIRGINIAN')

Cut to coal face below ground where some miners are
engaged at their work. They hew away for a bit, grunting and talking
amongst themselves. Suddenly two of them square up to one another.
He hits the second miner and a fight starts.

They writhe around on the floor pummelling each other. The
foreman comes in.
They start to fight.

(he hits them
with his pickaxe)
A fourth miner runs up.

Another fight breaks out. A management man arrives carried
in sedan chair by two black flunkies. He wears a colonial governor's
helmet and a large sign reading 'frightfully important'. All the miners
prostrate themselves on the floor.

They all walk off throwing down tools. Cut to a
newsreader's desk.

Pompous music. Mix to spinning globe and
then to two men in a
studio.
(gets up and leaves)

Enter from back of set as per Eamonn Andrews show Mr Ohn
Ith. He sits at the desk
Enter Mr Sm.
Enter Scot.

a sketch advertising Crelm
Toothpaste. Cut to a soap
powder commercial. Slick adman against neutral background. On his left
is an ordinary kitchen table. On his right is a pile of sheets on a
stand.

(cut
to top shot of interior of washing machine with water spinning round as
per ads)

(cut back to the original set-up; the
sheets are obviously painted white; the table is smashed up)

Traditional expanding square links to next commercial.
Animated countryside with flowers, butterflies and Babycham animal. A
boy and a girl (real, superimposed) wander through hand in hand.

(the adman comes into view over the
background; he holds a tailor's dummy - pelvis only - with a truss)

He throws away the truss. The background
changes to blow-up of
a fish tank. The adman is sitting at a desk. He pulls a goldfish bowl
over.
(pours it in)

He tips all this into the bowl. An RSPCA man rushes in,
grabs the man and hauls him off.
(and CAPTION:)
(the man still shouting)
The last four words are crossed out in the caption.

Mix to a lyrical shot of wild flowers in
beautiful English
countryside. Gentle pastoral music. The camera begins to pan away from
the flowers, moving slowly across this idyllic scene. Mix in the sound
of lovers - the indistinct deep voice, followed by a playful giggle
from the girl. At first very distant, but as we continue to pan it
increases in volume, until we come to rest on the source of the noise -
a tape recorder in front of a bush. After a short paase, the camera
tracks round behind this bush where are a couple sitting reading a book
each. Pan away from them across afield. In the middle of the pan we
come across a smooth, moustachioed little Italian head waiter, in tails
etc. We do not stop on him.
(bowing to camera)

The camera pans to the end of the field where we pick up a
man in a long mac crawling on all fours through the undergrowth. We
follow him as he occasionaly dodges behind a bush or a tree. He is
stealthily tracking something. After a few moments he comes up behind a
birdwatcher
(in deerstalker and tweeds)

who lies at the top of
a small rise, with his binoculars trained. With infinite caution the
man in the long mac slides up behind the birdwatcher, then he stretches
out a hand and opens the flap of the birdwatcher's knapsack. He pulls
out a small white paper bag. Holding his breath, he feels inside the
bag and produces a small pie, then a tomato and finally two hard-boiled
eggs. He pockets the hard-boiled eggs, puts the rest back and creeps
away.

Cut to mantle in a study lined with shelves full of
hard-boiled eggs. They all have little labels on the front of them. He
goes up and selects one from a long line of identical hard-boiled eggs.

(he
provides the next question himself in bad ventriloquist style)

(normal
voice)
(ventriloquially)
(normal voice)
(ventriloquially)
(normal voice)
(ventriloquially)
(normal voice)

(he moves to his left; on the wall behind him are the
splayed-out figures of two butterfly hunters, with pins through their
backs and their names on cards underneath)

An open field. A large hamper, with an attendant in a
brown coat standing behind it. The attendant opens the hamper and three
pigeon fanciers,
(in very fast motion)

leap out and run off
across the field, wheeling in a curve as birds do. Cut to a series of
speeded-up close ups of baskets being opened and pigeon fanciers
leaping out. After four or five of these fast close ups cut to long
shot of the mass of pigeon fanciers wheeling accross the field like a
flock of pigeons. Cut to film of Trafalgar Square. The pigeon fanciers
are now running around in the square, wheeling in groups. Cut to
Gilliam picture of Trafalgar Square. The chicken man from the opening
credits flies past towing a banner which says 'This Space Available,
tel 498 5116'. The head of a huge hedgehog - Spiny Norman - appears
above St Martin's-in-the-Fields.
Animated sequence then leads to:

Interior smooth-looking office. Mr Feldman behind a desk,
Mr Martin in front of it. Both point to a sign on the desk: 'Life
Insurance Ltd'.

The sound of the National Anthem starts. They stand to
attention. Martin and Feldman mutter to each other, and we hear a
reverential voice over.

(the camera pans, Martin following it part way,
to show the camera crew and the audience, all standing to attention)

Cries of disappointment. Cut to Reggie Bosanquet (the real
one) at the 'News at Ten' set. He is reading.

(the National Anthem starts to play in the background and
Reggie stands, continuing to read)

A hospital: a sign above door says 'Intensive Care Unit'.
A group of heavily bandaged patients with crutches, legs and arms in
plaster, etc., struggle out and onto a courtyard.

(the patients painfully
get themselves into line)
(looks more closely)
The patient hobbles off at the double and falls over.
Cut to second doctor. He is smoking a cigar.
(to camera)

Pull back to show doctor sitting in a wheelchair. A
bandaged patient wheels him off.
Cut to bandaged patients on a cross-country run.

The patients climb over a fence with much difficulty. One
falls.
Shots of patients doing sporting acivities.

('Dr Kildare' theme music; shot - doctors
being manicured having shoes cleaned etc. by patients)

Sign on wall: 'St Nathan's Hospital For Young, Attractive
Girls Who Aren't Particularly Ill'. Pan down to a doctor.

Sign: 'St Gandalf's Hospital For Very Rich People Who Like
Giving Doctors Lots Of Money'. Pull back to show another doctor.

Sign: 'St Michael's Hospital For Linkmen'. Pan down to
doctor.

Cut to a mountaineer hanging on ropes on
steep mountain face.

Cut to an orchestra in a field playing the 'Blue Danube'.
On each musical phrase, a member of the orchestra explodes. Fade to
pitch darkness.

Noise of female snores. Sound of a window sash being
lifted and scrabbling sounds. Padding feet across the dorm.
Sound of waking up. More padding feet.

Light goes on to reveal a girls' dorm. In the middle of
the floor between the beds are two panto geese which run off
immediately the light goes on. There is one man in a string vest and
short dibley haircut, chest wig, schoolgirl's skirt, white socks and
schoolgirl's shoes. Hanging from the middle of the ceiling is a goat
with light bulbs hanging from each foot. In the beds are other batch
blokes in string vests... and short hair. At the door stands a
commando-type Miss Rodgers.

Cut to still of one of us in the uniform as described
above.

(cut
to a picture made up of inch-square photos of various topical subjects
e.g. Stalin, Churchill, Eden, White Home, atom bomb, map of Western
Europe, Gandhi)

Stock film of amphibious craft brought up
on a beach. The
front of the craft crashes down and fifty soldiers rush out. We hear
schoolgirl voices. Cut to traditional shot thorugh periscope of ocean,
cross-sights scanning the hoizon. Submarine-type dramatic noise -
motors and asdic. Cut to interior of submarine. A pepperpot looks
thorugh the periscope, then looks round at her colleagues.
Her four companions continue to knit.
(goes out)

Attention noise from the communication tube. A red light
flashes by it.

a pepperpot is fired from a torpedo tube
through the water, until she travels head first into a battleship with
a load clang.

Cut to a letter as in the last series, plus voice reading
it.
Cut to a man at a desk.

Cut to man with a stoat through his head. He bows. Cut to
film of Women's Institute applauding.

Cut to a lifeboat somewhere at sea miles from any land. In
the lifeboat are five bedraggled sailors, at the end of their tether.
(to third Sailor)

(he is kicked on
the leg by the first sailor)

(he points
at fourth sailor)
(cheerfully)

(picks
up a tin of peaches)

(picks
up a two advocados)
(a waitress walks in)
Boos off-screen. Cut to a letter

various nasty cannibalistic scenes from Terry
Gilliam.
Cut to man.
Cut to an undertaker's shop

(the audience
starts booing)
(the booing increases)
Increasing protests from audience
(calling)
Another undertaker pokes his head round the door
(goes off)
(etc.)
(calling)

A section of the audience rises up in revolt and invades
the set, remonstrating with the performers and banging the counter,
etc., breaking up the sketch. Zoom away from them and into caption
machine; roll credits. The National Anthem starts. The shouting stops.
Mix through credits to show audience and everyone on set standing to
attention. As the credits end, fade out.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 25

script.description: ROLLER CAPTION: 'IN 1742 THE SPANISH EMPIRE LAY IN RUINS. TORN BY INTERNAL DISSENT, AND WRACKED BY NUMEROUS WARS, ITS RICH TRADE ROUTES FELL EASY PREY TO BRITISH PRIVATEERS...AND THE TREASURE OF THE SPANISH MAIN WAS BROUGHT HOME TO THE SHORES OF ENGLAND'

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different...

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Fireman
dialogue.text: Thank you very much for the change, Mr Tobacconist. Was that all right?

dialogue.speaker: Everybody
dialogue.text: SSSh!

script.description: ROLLER CAPTION: IN 1970, THE BRITISH EMPIRE LAY IN RUINS, FOREIGN NATIONALS FREQUENTED THE STREETS - MANY OF THEM HUNGARIANS (NOT THE STREETS - THE FOREIGN NATIONALS). ANYWAY, MANY OF THESE HUNGARIANS WENT INTO TOBACCONIST'S SHOPS TO BUY CIGARETTES...

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: I will not buy this record, it is scratched.

dialogue.speaker: Tobacconist
dialogue.text: Sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: I will not buy this record, it is scratched.

dialogue.speaker: Tobacconist
dialogue.text: No, no, no.This ... tobacconist's.

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: Ah! I will not buy this tobacconist's, it is scratched.

dialogue.speaker: Tobacconist
dialogue.text: No, no, no ...tobacco...er, cigarettes?

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: Yes, cigarettes. My hovercraft is full of eels.

dialogue.speaker: Tobacconist
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: My hovercraft is full of eels.

dialogue.speaker: Tobacconist
dialogue.text: Matches, matches?

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: Yah, yah. Er, do you want ... do you want to come back to my place, bouncy bouncy?

dialogue.speaker: Tobacconist
dialogue.text: I don't think you're using that right.

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: You great pouf.

dialogue.speaker: Tobacconist
dialogue.text: That'll be six and six, please.

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: If I said you had a beautiful body, would you hold it against me? I am no longer infected.

dialogue.speaker: Tobacconist
dialogue.text: It costs six and six ... Costs six and six ... Here we are ... Yandelvayasna grldenwi stravenka.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: What's going on here then?

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: You have beautiful thighs.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Tobacconist
dialogue.text: He hit me.

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: Drop your panties, Sir William, I cannot wait till lunchtime.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Right!

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: My nipples explode with delight.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Call Alexander Yahlt

dialogue.speaker: Voices
dialogue.text: Call Alexander Yahlt. Call Alexander Yahlt. Call Alexander Yahlt.

dialogue.speaker: Magistrate
dialogue.text: Oh, shut up.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: You are Alexander Yahlt?

dialogue.speaker: Yahlt
dialogue.text: Oh I am.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Skip the impersonations. You are Alexander Yahlt?

dialogue.speaker: Yahlt
dialogue.text: I am.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: You are hereby charged that on the 28th day of May 1970, you did wilfully, unlawfully, and with malice aforethought publish an alleged English-Hungarian phrasebook with intent to cause a breach of the peace. How do you plead?

dialogue.speaker: Yahlt
dialogue.text: Not guilty.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: You live at 46, Horton Terrace?

dialogue.speaker: Yahlt
dialogue.text: I do live at 46, Horton Terrace.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: You are the director of a publishing company?

dialogue.speaker: Yahlt
dialogue.text: I am the director of a publishing company.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Your company publishes phrasebooks?

dialogue.speaker: Yahlt
dialogue.text: My company does publish phrasebooks.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: You did say 46, Horton Terrace, didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: Yahlt
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Ha, ha, ha, I got him.

dialogue.speaker: Magistrate
dialogue.text: Get on with it! Get on with it!

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Yes, m'lud, on the 28th of May, you published this phrasebook.

dialogue.speaker: Yahlt
dialogue.text: I did.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: I quote an example. The Hungarian phrase meaning 'Can you direct me to the station?' is translated by the English phrase, 'Please fondle my bum'.

dialogue.speaker: Yahlt
dialogue.text: I wish to plead incompetence.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Please may I ask for an adjournment, m'lud?

dialogue.speaker: Magistrate
dialogue.text: An adjournment? Certainly not. Why on earth didn't you say why you wanted an adjourment?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: I didn't know an acceptable legal phrase, m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Magistrate
dialogue.text: If there's any more stock film of women applauding, I'll clear the court.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Call Abigail Tesler

dialogue.speaker: Defence
dialogue.text: M'lud - this is Abigail Tesler.

dialogue.speaker: Magistrate
dialogue.text: Is it?

dialogue.speaker: Defence
dialogue.text: Yes, m'lud. Twenty-three-year-old Abigail hails from down under, where they're upside down about her. Those Aussies certainly know a thing or two when it comes to beach belles. Bet some life-saver wouldn't mind giving her the kiss of life. So watch out for sharks, Abigail!

dialogue.speaker: Journalist
dialogue.text: Is this strictly releveant? Quizzed learned lovely, Justice Maltravers. Seventy-eight-year-old Justice hails from Esther, and he's been making a big name for himself at the recent Assizes at Exeter.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: All will be revealed soon m'lud, quipped tall forty-two-year-old Nelson Bedowes. Cutie QC Nelson's keen on negligence and grievous bodily harm at Gray's Inn. And with cases like he's won we bet Gray's in when Nelson's around.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Well get on with it, admitted seventy-eight-year-old genial jurisprude Maltravers seen here at London airport, on his way to judge for Britain at the famous International Court in the Hague ...

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Get off!

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Good evening. Tonight is indeed a unique occasion in the history of television. We are very privileged, and deeply honoured to have with us in the studio, Karl Marx, founder of modern socialism, and author of the 'Communist Manifesto'. Vladimir Ilich Ulyanov, better known to the world as Lenin, leader of the Russian Revolution, writer, statesman, and father of modern communism. Che Guevara, the Cuban guerrilla leader. And Mao Tse-tung, leader of the Chinese Communist Party since 1949. And the first question is for you, Karl Marx. The Hammers - The Hammers is the nickname of what English football team? 'The Hammers? No? Well bad luck there, Karl. So we'll go onto you Che. Che Guevara - Coventry City last won the FA Cup in what year? No? I'll throw it open. Coventry City last won the FA Cup in what year? No? Well, I'm not surprised you didn't get that. It was in fact a trick question. Coventry City have never won the FA Cup. So with the scores all equal now we go onto our second round, and Lenin it's your starter for ten. Teddy Johnson and Pearl Carr won the Eurovision Song Contest in 1959. What was the name of the song? ... Teddy Johnson and Pearl Carr's song in the 1959 Eurovision Song Contest? Anybody? Yes, Mao Tse-tung?

dialogue.speaker: Mao Tse-tung
dialogue.text: 'Sing Little Birdie'?

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Yes it was indeed. Well challenged. Well now we come on to our special gift section. The contestant is Karl Marx and the prize this week is a beautiful lounge suite. Now Karl has elected to answer questions on the workers control of factories so here we go with question number one. Are you nervous? The development of the industrial proletariat is conditioned by what other development?

dialogue.speaker: Karl
dialogue.text: The development of the industrial bourgeoisie.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, it is indeed. You're on your way to the lounge suite, Karl. Question number two. The struggle of class against class is a what struggle? A what struggle?

dialogue.speaker: Karl
dialogue.text: A political struggle.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Yes, yes! One final question Karl and the beautiful lounge suite will be yours... Are you going to have a go? You're a brave man. Karl Marx, your final question, who won the Cup Final in 1949?

dialogue.speaker: Karl
dialogue.text: The workers' control of the means of production? The struggle of the urban proletariat?

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: No. It was in fact, Wolverhampton Wanderers who beat Leicester 3-1.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'IN WORLD FORUM TODAY: KARL MARX, CHE GUEVARA, LENIN AND MAO TSE-TUNG. NEXT WEEK, FOUR LEADING HEADS OF STATE OF THE AFRO-ASIAN NATIONS AGAINST BRISTOL ROVERS AT MOLINEUX'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'IN 1914, THE BALANCE OF POWER LAY IN RUINS. EUROPE WAS PLUNGED INTO BLOODY CONFLICT. NATION FOUGHT NATION. BUT NO NATION FOUGHT NATION MORELY THAN THE ENGLISH HIP HIP HOORARY! NICE, NICE YAH BOO. PHILLIPS IS A GERMAN AND HE HAVE MY PEN'

dialogue.speaker: Different Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'START AGAIN'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'IN 1914, THE BALANCE OF POWER LAY IN RUINS...'

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Jenkins?

dialogue.speaker: Jenkins
dialogue.text: Yes, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: What are you going to do when you get back to Blighty?

dialogue.speaker: Jenkins
dialogue.text: I dunno, sarge... I expect I'll be looking after me mum. She'll be getting on a bit now.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Got a family of your own 'ave you?

dialogue.speaker: Jenkins
dialogue.text: No, she's ... she's all I got left now. My wife, Doreen ... she ... I got a letter.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: You don't have to tell me, son.

dialogue.speaker: Jenkins
dialogue.text: No, sarge, I'd like to tell you, see this place....

dialogue.speaker: Floor Manager
dialogue.text: Hold it. Hold it. Look, loves ... can anyone not involved in this scene, please leave the set. Now! Come on please. Anyone not concerned in this scene, the canteen's open upstairs. Now come on please. Sorry loves. Sorry. We'll have to take it again, from the top. All fight. OK... Cue!

dialogue.speaker: Floor Manager
dialogue.text: Hold it. Hold it. Now, who changed the caption? Can whoever changed the caption put the right one back immediately please.

dialogue.speaker: Floor Manager
dialogue.text: Right. All right, we'll take it again from the top. Cue. Hold it. Hold it. Come on. Come on, out of there. You're not in this ... you're only holding the whole thing up. Come on please. It's no good, loves. It's no good. We'll have to leave it for now. Come back when everyone's settled down a bit. So-that means we go over to the Art Room, all right. So cue camera three! Sorry, camera four.

dialogue.speaker: First Critic
dialogue.text: Aren't they marvelous? The strength and boldness... life and power in those colours.

dialogue.speaker: Second Critic
dialogue.text: This must be Titian's masterpiece.

dialogue.speaker: First Critic
dialogue.text: Oh indeed - if only for the composition alone. The strength of those foreground figures ... the firmness of the line...

dialogue.speaker: Second Critic
dialogue.text: Yes, the confidence of the master at the height of his powers.

dialogue.speaker: Cherub
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: Bumpkin
dialogue.text: Hello sonny, your dad in?

dialogue.speaker: Cherub
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Bumpkin
dialogue.text: Could I speak to him please? It's the man from 'The Hay Wain'.

dialogue.speaker: Cherub
dialogue.text: Who?

dialogue.speaker: Bumpkin
dialogue.text: The man from 'The Hay Wain' by Constable.

dialogue.speaker: Cherub
dialogue.text: Dad... it's the man from 'The Hay Wain' by Constable to see you.

dialogue.speaker: Solomon
dialogue.text: Coming.

dialogue.speaker: Solomon
dialogue.text: Hello? How are you? Come on in.

dialogue.speaker: Bumpkin
dialogue.text: No, no can't stop, just passing by, actually.

dialogue.speaker: Solomon
dialogue.text: Oh, where are you now?

dialogue.speaker: Bumpkin
dialogue.text: Well may you ask. We just been moved in next to a room full of Brueghels ... terrible bloody din. Skating all hours of the night. Anyway, I just dropped in to tell you there's been a walk-out in the Impressionists.

dialogue.speaker: Solomon
dialogue.text: Walk-out, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Bumpkin
dialogue.text: Yeah. It started with the 'Déjeuner Sur L'Herbe' lot, evidently they were moved away from above the radiator or something. Anyway, the Impressionists are all out. Gainsborough's Blue Boy's brought out the eighteenth-century English portraits, the Flemish School's solid, and the German woodcuts are at a meeting now.

dialogue.speaker: Solomon
dialogue.text: Right. Then I'll get the Renaissance School out.

dialogue.speaker: Bumpkin
dialogue.text: OK, meeting 4.30 - 'Bridge at Arles'.

dialogue.speaker: Solomon
dialogue.text: OK, cheerio - good luck, son.

dialogue.speaker: Bumpkin
dialogue.text: OK.

dialogue.speaker: Solomon
dialogue.text: Right - everybody out.

dialogue.speaker: Voices
dialogue.text: I'm off. I'm off. I'm off, dear.

dialogue.speaker: Radio
dialogue.text: Here is the News... by an almost unanimous vote, paintings in the National Gallery voted to continue the strike that has emptied frames for the last week. The man from Constable's 'Hay Wain' said last night that there was no chance of a return to the pictures before the weekend. Sir Kenneth Clarke has said he will talk to any painting if it can help bring a speedy end to the strike At Sotheby's, prices dropped dramatically as leading figures left their paintings.

dialogue.speaker: Auctioneer
dialogue.text: What am I bid for Vermeer's 'Lady Who Used to be at a Window'? Do I hear two bob?

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Two bob!

dialogue.speaker: Auctioneer
dialogue.text: Gone. Now what am I bid for another great bargain? Edward Landseer's 'Nothing at Bay'.

dialogue.speaker: Venus
dialogue.text: All we bloody want is a little bit of bloody consultation.

dialogue.speaker: Radio
dialogue.text: At a mass meeting at Brentford Football Ground, other works of art voted to come out in support of the paintings. The vote was unanimous. with one abstention. Meanwhile, at Television Centre work began again on a sketch about Ypres. A spokesman for the sketch said: he fully expected it to be more sensible this time.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Jenkins.

dialogue.speaker: Jenkins
dialogue.text: Yes, sarge?

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: What are you going to do when you get back to Blighty?

dialogue.speaker: Jenkins
dialogue.text: I dunno, sarge. I expect I'll look after my mum. She'll be getting on a bit now.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Got a family of your own, have you?

dialogue.speaker: Jenkins
dialogue.text: No - she's all I got left now. My wife, Doreen ... she... I got a letter.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: You don't have to tell me, son.

dialogue.speaker: Jenkins
dialogue.text: No, sarge, I'd like to tell you. You see, this bloke from up the street...

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: OK, chaps, at ease. I've just been up the line...

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Can we get through, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: No, I'm afraid we'll have to make a break for it at nightfall.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Right, sir. We're all with yer.

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: Yes I know, that's just the problem, sergeant. How many are there of us?

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Well there's you, me, Jenkins, Padre, Kipper, there's five, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: And only rations for...

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Four, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: Precisely. I'm afraid one of us will have to take the 'other' way out.

dialogue.speaker: Padre
dialogue.text: I'm a gonner, major. Leave me, I'm ... I'm not a complete man anymore.

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: You've lost both your arms as well.

dialogue.speaker: Padre
dialogue.text: Yes. Damn silly really.

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: No, no, we'll draw for it. That's the way we do things in the army. Sergeant, the straws!

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: Right now, the man who gets the shortest straw knows what to do

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Looks like you, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: Is it? What did we say, the longest straw was it?

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: No, shortest, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: Well we'd better do it again, there's obviously been a bit of a muddle. Oh dear. Best of three? Right, well I've got the shortest straw. So I decide what means we use to decide who's going to do... to... to... to er .... to do the thing ... to do the right thing. Now rank doesn't enter into this, but obviously if I should get through the lines, I will be in a very good position to recommend anyone, very highly, for a posthumous VC. No? Good. Fine. Fine. Fine. Fine. Right. Dip, dip, dip, my little ship sails on the ocean, you are ... no wait, wait a minute, no I, I must have missed out a dip. I'll start again. Dip, dip, dip, dip, my little ship, sails on the ocean, you are ... No, this is not working out. It's not working out. What shall we do?

dialogue.speaker: Jenkins
dialogue.text: How about one potato, two potato, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: Don't be childish, Jenkins. No, I think, I think fisties would be best. OK, so hands behind backs. After three, OK, one, two, three. Now what's this... stone, stone, stone, and scissors. Now. Scissors cut everything, don't they?

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Not stone, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: They're very good scissors Padre hasn't been!

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: No arms, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Major
dialogue.text: Oh, I'm terribly sorry, I'm afraid I didn't... tell you what. All those people who don't want to stay here and shoot themselves raise their arms.

dialogue.speaker: Padre
dialogue.text: Stop it! Stop it! Stop this ... this hideous façade.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Easy, padre!

dialogue.speaker: Padre
dialogue.text: No, no, I must speak. When I, when I came to this war, I had two arms, two good arms, but when the time came to... to lose one, I .. I gave it gladly, I smiled as they cut if off, because I knew there was a future for mankind. I ... I knew there was hope... so long as men were prepared to give their limbs And when the time came for me to give my other arm I... I gave it gladly. I... I sang as they sawed it off. Because I believed... Oh you may laugh, but I believed with every fibre of my body, with every drop of rain that falls, a... a flower grows. And that flower, that small fragile, delicate flower... ... shall burst forth and give a new life. New strength! ... freedom. Freedom from fear and freedom from oppression. Freedom from tyranny. A world where men and women of all races and creeds can live together in communion and then in the twilight of this life, our children, and our children's children and . ..

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: All our patients here are suffering from severe over-acting. When they're brought in they're all really over the top. And it's our job to try and treat the condition of over-acting ... rather serious. This is the Richard III Ward.

dialogue.speaker: Richard III
dialogue.text: A horse. A horse. My kingdom for a horse.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Most of these cases are pretty unpleasant. Nurse... But the treatment does work with some people. This chap came to us straight from the Chichester Festival; we operated just in time, and now he's almost normal.

dialogue.speaker: Second Richard
dialogue.text: A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: But in here we have some very nasty cases indeed.

dialogue.speaker: Hamlets
dialogue.text: To be or not to be. That is the question. To be...

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'INTRODUCED BY D. P. GUMBY'

dialogue.speaker: Gumby
dialogue.text: Good evening. First take a bunch of flowers. Pretty begonias, irises, freesias and cry-manthesums...then arrange them nicely in a vase. Get in! Get in! Get in!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Bun
dialogue.text: Morning

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Morning

dialogue.speaker: Mr Bun
dialogue.text: What have you got, then?

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Well, there's egg and bacon; egg sausage and bacon; egg and spam; egg, bacon and spam; egg, bacon, sausage and spam; spam, bacon, sausage and spam; spam, egg, spam, spam, bacon and spam; spam, spam, spam, egg and spam; spam, spam, spam, spam, spam, spam, baked beans, spam, spam, spam and spam; or Lobster thermidor aux crevettes with a mornay sauce garnished with truffle pâté, brandy and with a fried egg on top and spam.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Bun
dialogue.text: Have you got anything without spam in it?

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Well, there's spam egg sausage and spam, that's not got much spam in it.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Bun
dialogue.text: I don't want ANY spam!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Bun
dialogue.text: Why can't she have egg, bacon, spam and sausage?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Bun
dialogue.text: That's got spam in it!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Bun
dialogue.text: Not as much as spam, egg, sausage and spam.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Bun
dialogue.text: Look, could I have egg, bacon, spam and sausage without the spam.

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Uuuuuuggggh!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Bun
dialogue.text: What d'you mean uuugggh! I don't like spam

dialogue.speaker: Vikings
dialogue.text: Spam, spam, spam, spam, spam ... spam, spam, spam, spam ... lovely spam, wonderful spam ...

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Shut up. Shut up! Shut up! You can't have egg, bacon, spam and sausage without the spam.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Bun
dialogue.text: Why not!

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: No, it wouldn't be egg, bacon, spam and sausage, would it.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Bun
dialogue.text: I don't like spam!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Bun
dialogue.text: Don't make a fuss, dear. I'll have your spam. I love it. I'm having spam, spam, spam, spam, spam ...

dialogue.speaker: Vikings
dialogue.text: Spam, spam, spam, spam ...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Bun
dialogue.text: ... baked beans, spam, spam and spam.

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Baked beans are off.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Bun
dialogue.text: Well can I have spam instead?

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: You mean spam, spam, spam, spam, spam, spam, spam, spam, spam, spam?

dialogue.speaker: Vikings
dialogue.text: Spam, spam, spam, spam ...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Bun
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Arrggh!

dialogue.speaker: Vikings
dialogue.text: .. . lovely spam, wonderful, spam.

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Shut up! Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: Great boobies, honeybun, my lower intestine is full of spam, egg, spam, bacon, spam, tomato, spam ...

dialogue.speaker: Vikings
dialogue.text: Spam, spam, spam, spam ...

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Shut up

dialogue.speaker: Hungarian
dialogue.text: My nipples explode...

dialogue.speaker: Historian
dialogue.text: Another great Viking victory was at the Green Midget cafe at Bromley. Once again the Viking strategy was the same. They sailed from these fiords here, assembled at Trondheim and waited for the strong north-easterly winds to blow their oaken galleys to England whence they sailed on May 23rd. Once in Bromley they assembled in the Green Midget cafe and spam selecting a spam particular spam item from the spam menu would spam, spam, spam, spam, spam ...

dialogue.speaker: Vikings
dialogue.text: Spam, spam, spam, spam, spam, lovely spam, wonderful spam. Lovely spam wonderful spam ...

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'IN 1970 MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS LAY IN RUINS, AND THEN THE WORDS ON THE SCREEN SAID:'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Haagbard Etheldronga and his Viking hordes are currently appearing in 'Grin and Pillage it' at the Jodrell Theatre, Colwyn Bay. 'The Dirty Hungarian Phrase Book' is available from Her Majesty's Stationery Office, price - a kiss on the bum.

annotations: Close up of a flag bearing a black eagle on a red background fluttering in the wind. Blue sky behind and scudding clouds. Adventure music as for buccaneer film.
Captions:

Mix through from flag to sea at night. Sound of water lapping. Soft sound of muffled oars drawing nearer. We can see a rowing boat making slowly and silently towards the shore where the camera is. The stirring music continues.

By the time roller captions have finished the rowing boat has approached much nearer. It stops and they ship their oars. Cut in to close ups of pirate's face peering into the darkness. Shot from the boat of a deserted cliff top. A light flashes twice. Then there is a pause. Cut back to the boat; the men look uneasy as they wait for the third flash. Cut back to the cliff...at last the third flash. Cut back to the boat; they start to again. Cut to them beaching the boat on the shore. They start to unload sacks and chests. Putting them onto their shoulders they start to walk along the shore line. We pan with them for quite some way...and suddenly between the camera and the pirates we come across the announcer at a desk. He wears a dinner jacket and shuffles some papers in front of him.
Animated titles. Cut to a small tobacconist's shop. The tobacconist is handing change to a fireman.
(he exits; then out of vision, very loud)
Stirring adventure music of buccaneer film as at the beginning and the roller caption in the same typeface.
Enter Hungarian gentleman with phrase book. He is looking for the right phrase.
(miming matches)
(showing some)
(he takes cigarettes and matches and pulls out loose change; he consults his book)
(miming that he wants to see the book; he takes the book)
(mumbling as he searches)

Hungarian hits him between the eyes. Policeman walking along the street suddenly stops and puts his hand to his ear. He starts running down the street, round corner and down another street, round yet another corner and down another street into the shop
(opening book and pointing at tobacconist)
(grabs him and drags him out)
Cut to a courtroom.
(They do this three times finishing with harmony)
(Derek Nimmo's voice (dubbed on))
(normal voice)
He claps his hand to his mouth; gong sounds - general applause.
The policeman stands up
(the policeman sits down; there is a loud raspberry; the policeman goes bright red)
Cut to stock film of Women's Institute applauding. Cut back to the magistrate.

Two policemen carry a large photo blow-up the size of a door. It is a photo from a newspaper like the 'Mirror', with a girl in a bikini and the headline across the top: 'Sunshine Sizzler'. Underneath is some small print which is later read out (see below). They prop her up in the witness box.
Cut back to the judge's desk. The judge has turned into a similar photo blow-up of himself, the size of a door. The headline at the top is 'Legal Sizzler'.
(voice over)
(cut back to defence counsel, who has turned into a large photo blow-up of himslef headed 'Defence Counsel Sizzler')
Starting with newspaper photo of judge in dark glasses and full wig with a starlet beside him, walking down London airport departure corridor carrying cases.
An important-looking current affairs set. On the back wall behind the presenter huge letters say: 'World Forum'
(Karl Marx is sitting at a desk; he nods)
(shot of Lenin also at desk; he nods)
(shot of Guevara)
(shot of Mao; the presenter picks up a card)
(shot of Karl Marx furrowing his brow- obviously he hasn't a clue)
(cut to Che looking equally dumbfounded)
(they all look blank)
(buzzer goes as in 'University Challenge'.' zoom in on Mao Tse-tung)
(applause)
(curtains behind the presenter sweep open to reveal a beautiful lounge suite; terrific audience applause; Karl comes out and stands in front of this display)
(Karl nods his head; the presenter reads from a card)
(applause)
Tumultuous applause
(Karl nods)
Cut to stock film of goal bring scored in a big football match. Roar from crowd. Stock footage of football crowds cheering.
(and CAPTION:)
Sketch leading to stock drawing of First World War trench scene - barbed wire against the sky with a helmet stuck on a bayonet.
(and CAPTION:)
(and CAPTION:)
(and CAPTION:)
Mix through to close up of a harmonica bring played by a British Tommy.

The camera pulls slowly out, with the plaintive harmonica still playing, to reveal the interior of a bunker in the trenches. Sitting around on old ammunition boxes etc. are the harmonica player, Private Jenkins, Sergeant Jackson, a padre with no arms, a sheikh, a Viking warrior, a male mermaid, a nun, a milkman and a Greek Orthodox priest. Sounds of warfare throughout, shells thudding, explosions etc.
(looking round rather uncomfortably at the strange collection)
(equally uncomfortable about playing such a tender scene in front of sheiks etc.)
Cut to long shot of bunker. Floor manager strides on to set.
(he starts to herd out anyone not in First War costume)
(sheikh, male mermaid etc. troop off)
(to soldiers)
Back to identical shot of harmonica-playing tommy; he plays a few bars.
Cut to long shot. The floor manager rushes on again. The caption remains superimposed.
(back to identical shot of harmonica-playing tommy with caption superimposed; slow pull out as before, then floor manager rushes on again)
(he goes behind some sandbags looking extremely irritated)
(he hauls a spaceman and hustles him off the set)
(turning to studio as a whole)
(cut to Che Guevara caught in a hot embrace with Karl Marx)

Cut to Art Gallery. A large sign says: 'Italian Masters of the Renaissance'. Two art critics wandering through. They stop in front of a large Titian canvas. The canvas is about ten foot high by six foot wide.

At this point a man in a country smock and straw hat and a straw in his mouth comes up to the painting and with a very businesslike manner presses the nipple of a nude in the painting. Ding dong sound of a front doorbell. He stands tapping his feet and whistling soundlessly beside the painting. He nods at the critics. Cut to the top of the painting to see that one of the figures has disappeared leaving a blank. The camera pans down the painting as we hear footsteps; as if coming down a lot of stone steps. Eventualy the camera comes to rest beside where the country bumpkin is standing and a door opens in the painting. We do, not see who has opened it, but can assume it is the cherub.
Sound of footsteps. Cut to another close up on the painting and we see the main figure disappearing. This figure suddenly puts his head round the door.
The door shuts and we hear Solomon's voice over.
We see various famous paintings whose characters suddenly disappear.
(etc.)
Mix through to front room of a suburban house. A man is sawing his wife in two in the classic long box.

(the man pauses for a moment and looks at radio, then resumes sawing; we zoom in to close up on the radio. There is a window behind it; as the radio talks, a group of paintings with picket signs pass by)
(a ghastly scream out of vision; the sawing stops abruptly)
(Cut to Sotheby's)

Pull out to reveal man standing beside auctioneer with the painting (the stag is missing). Cut to a group of famous characters from famous paintings who are clustered round the camera. Botticelli's Venus is in the centre jabbing her fingers at camera.
Fade sound of them all shouting and jostling etc. Bring up sound of radio out of vision.
(still in animation cut to Brentford football ground with famous statues in the stands)
(they all put their hands up)
(cut to close up of 'Venus De Milo'; cut to TV Centre and slow zoom in)
Cut to usual opening shot of close up of harmonica being played by tommy.
Slow zoom out to reveal set-up as before with no extraneous characters.
Enter a young major.
Crash zoom into revolver which the major has brought out. Jarring chord. Close up of faces looking tense from one to the other. Tense music.
The sergeant gives him the straws. The major arranges them and hands them round.
They all take the long straws. Including the padre who takes one in his teeth. The major is left with a tiny straw. A pause.
(they do it again and the same thing happens)
(they go through it again and he gets left with it again)
(he looks round to see if there are any takers)
(counting out)
(comes back to himself)
(it's back on him again)
(everyone except the padre who has no arms puts out clenched fist)
(looks down at his hand)
(then he suddenly sees the padre)
(music under: 'There'll Always Be An England)
(emotionally)
(hysterically)
(two modern-day ambulance attendants come in with a trolley which they put the padre onto and wheel him away; he is still going on)

(cut to a present-day ambulance racing out of TV Centre in speeded-up motion; it man through the streets, and arrives at the casualty entrance of a hospital; the doors swing open and the padre is rushed out on stretcher (still in fast motion) totally under a blanket; we hear his voice)
(the camera picks up on sign which reads: 'Royal Hospital for Over-acting)
