(by this time he has disappeared in through the doors of the hospital)
Cut to the interior of hospital and see specialist as he walks down a corridor.
(a nurse goes past leading a Long John Silver who keeps going 'Aha! Jim Lad')
(he passes a whole group of Long John Silvers)
(he passes a group of King Rats, and indicates the worst case)
(he walks on through a door)
Pull out to reveal a crowd of Richard III's. The specialist indicates one who is really over the top.
(a nurse comes in and sedates Richard III)
He walks over to a very ordinary Richard III, who smiles disarmingly and says quite chatlily
Shaking his head sadly, the specialist leaves the ward and opens a door to another one.
involving grotesque Hamlets.
Animation leads to close up of flowers.
Pull back to show Gumby in studio with piles of flowers on a table.
(he grabs flowers from the table)
(he thrusts the flowers head downwards into the vase and stuffs them in wildly; he even bangs them with a mallet in an attempt to get them all in)
Cut to a cafe. All the customers are Vikings. Mr and Mrs Bun enter - downwards (on wires)
(singing)
Brief stock shot of a Viking ship.
(singing)
(still singing)
(etc.)
The Vikings shut up momentarily. Enter the hungarian.
(starting up again)
A policeman rushes in and bundles the Hungarian out.
Cut to a historian.
(indicating a map with arrows on it)
The backdrop behind him rises to reveal the cafe again, The Vikings start singing again and the historian conducts them
(singing)
Mr and Mrs Bun rise slowly in the air
Fade out and roll credits, which read:
Fade out. Fade in in Karl Marx and Che Guevara lying post-coitally in bed. Karl switches off the light.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 24

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Come in. Ah, Frog.

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: S. Frog, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Shut up, I want to have a word with you, Frog.

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: S. Frog, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Shut up. It's about your advertising campaign for Conquistador Coffee. Now, I've had the managing director of Conquistador to see me this morning and he's very unhappy with your campaign. Very unhappy. In fact, he's shot himself.

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: Badly, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: No, extremely well. Well, before he went he left a note with the company secretary , the effect of which was how disappointed he was with your work and, in particular, why you had changed the name from Conquistador Instant Coffee to Conquistador Instant Leprosy. Why, Frog?

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: S. Frog, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Shut up. Why did you do it?

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: It was a joke.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: A joke?

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: No, no not a joke, a sales campaign.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: I see, Frog.

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: S. Frog, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Shut up. Now, let's have a look at the sales chart. When you took over this account, Frog, Conquistador was a brand leader. Here you introduced your first campaign, 'Conquistador Coffee brings a new meaning to the word vomit'. Here you made your special introductory offer of a free dead dog with every jar, and this followed your second campaign 'the tingling fresh coffee which brings you exciting new cholera, mange, dropsy, the clap, hard pad and athlete's head. From the House of Conquistador'.

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: It was a soft-sell, sir

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Why, Frog?

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: S. Frog, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Shut up! Well?

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: Well, people know the name, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: They certainly do know the name - they burnt the factory down. The owner is hiding in my bathroom - the owner was hiding in my bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: You're not going to fire me, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Fire you? Three men dead, the factory burnt down, the account lost and our firm completely bankrupt, what... what... what ... can you possibly say? What excuse can you possibly make?

dialogue.speaker: Frog
dialogue.text: Sorry, father.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Oh, yes. Oh, incidentally your film's won a prize.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Sorry about that. And now for something completely diff... something completely diff... completely diff... completely diff... completely diff... completely different.

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 1929. Stanley Baldwin's Conservative Government is defeated and Ramsay MacDonald becomes, for the second time, Prime Minister of England.

dialogue.speaker: Ramsay MacDonald
dialogue.text: My, it's hot in here.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Hello, come in. Ah, hello, hello, how much do you want for that briefcase?

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: Well, I...

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: All right then, the briefcase and the umbrella. A fiver down, must be my final offer.

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: Well, I don't want to sell them. I've come for a job.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Oh, take a seat, take a seat.

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: I see you chose the canvas chair with the aluminium frame. I'll throw that in and a fiver, for the briefcase and the umbrella ... no, make it fair, the briefcase and the umbrella and the two pens in your breast pocket and the chair's yours and a fiver and a pair of ex-German U-boat commander's binoculars.

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: Really, they are not for sale.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Not for sale, what does that mean?

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: I came about the advertisement for the job of assistant editor.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, right. Ah, OK, ah. How much experience in journalism?

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: Five years.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Right, typing speed?

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: Fifty.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: O Levels?

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: Eight.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: A Levels?

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: Two.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Right... Well, I'll give you the job, and the chair, and an all-wool ex-army sleeping bag ... for the briefcase, umbrella, the pens in your breast pocket and your string vest.

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: When do I start?

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Monday.

dialogue.speaker: Bee
dialogue.text: That's marvellous.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: If you throw in the shoes as well. Hello, er ... Miss Johnson? Could we have two coffees and biscuits please?

dialogue.speaker: Miss Johnson
dialogue.text: One coffee and one biscuit for the two ex-army greatcoats and the alarm clock on the mantelpiece.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Two ex-army greatcoats and the alarm clock and a table lamp, for two coffees and biscuits.

dialogue.speaker: Miss Johnson
dialogue.text: Two greatcoats and two table lamps.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Two greatcoats, one table lamp and a desert boat.

dialogue.speaker: Miss Johnson
dialogue.text: For two coffees and biscuits? Office.

dialogue.speaker: Glans
dialogue.text: Done.

dialogue.speaker: Miss Johnson
dialogue.text: Done.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: So Miss Johnson returned to her typing and dreamed her little dreamy dreams, unaware as she was of the cruel trick fate had in store for her. For Miss Johnson was about to fall victim of the dreaded international Chinese Communist Conspiracy. Yes, these fanatical thieves under the leadership of the so-called Mao Tse-tung had caught Miss Johnson off guard for one brief but fatal moment and destroyed her. Just as they are ready to do anytime free men anywhere waver in their defence of democracy.

dialogue.speaker: Uncle Sam
dialogue.text: Yes, once again American defence proves its effectiveness against international communism. Using this diagram of a tooth to represent any small country, we can see how international communism works by eroding away form the inside When one country or tooth falls victim to international communism, its neighbours soon follow. In dentistry, this is known as Domino Theory. but with american defence the decay is stopped before it starts and that's why nine out of ten small countries choose American defense ...

dialogue.speaker: Different Voice Over
dialogue.text: ... Or Crelm toothpaste with the miracle ingredient, Fraudulin! The white car represents Crelm toothpaste with the miracle ingredient, Fraudulin. The non-white car represents another toothpaste. Both toothpastes provide 30% protection. At 60% protection both toothpastes are doing well. And now at 90% protection the ... wait! The non-white car is out, and the Crelm toothpaste goes on to win with 100% protection! Yes, do like all smart motorists. Choose Crelm toothpaste.

dialogue.speaker: 'Shrill' Man
dialogue.text: Or Shrill Petrol with the new addititve GLC 9424075. After 6 p.m., 9424047. Using this white card to represent Shrill's new additive GLC 9424075 - after 6 p.m., 9424047 - we can see how the engine deposits are pushed off the face of the earth by the superior forces available to Shrill. Aaaagh!

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: Anyway, John, you can catch the 11.30 from Hornchurch and be in Basingstoke by one o'clock, oh, and there's a buffet car and... Oh! Daddy!

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: My hat! Sir Horace!

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: Has he been...

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Yes - after breakfast. But that doesn't matter now... he's dead.

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: Oh! Poor daddy...

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Looks like I shan't be catching the 11.30 now.

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: Oh no, John, you mustn't miss your train.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: How could I think of catching a train when I should be here helping you?

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: Oh, John, thank you... anyway you could always catch the 9.30 tomorrow - it goes via Caterham and Chipstead.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Or the 9.45's even better.

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: Oh, but you'd have to change at Lambs Green.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Yes, but there's only a seven-minute wait now.

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: Oh, yes, of course, I'd forgotten it was Friday. Oh, who could have done this?

dialogue.speaker: Lady Partridge
dialogue.text: Oh, do hurry Sir Horace, your train leaves in twenty-eight minutes, and if you miss the 10.15 you won't catch the 3.45 which means ... oh!

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: I'm afraid Sir Horace won't be catching the 10.15, Lady Partridge.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Partridge
dialogue.text: Has he been... ?

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: Yes - after breakfast.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Lady Partridge, I'm afraid you can cancel his seat reservation.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Partridge
dialogue.text: Oh, and it was back to the engine - fourth coach along so that he could see the gradient signs outside Swanborough.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Not any more Lady Partridge... the line's been closed.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Partridge
dialogue.text: Closed! Not Swanborough!

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: I'm afraid so.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: All right, nobody move. I'm Inspector Davis of Scotland Yard.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: My word, you were here quickly, inspector.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Yeah, I got the 8.55 Pullman Express from King's Cross and missed that bit around Hornchurch.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Partridge
dialogue.text: It's a very good train.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Excellent, very good, delightful.

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Hello everyone.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Tony!

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Where's daddy? Oh golly! Has he been... ?

dialogue.speaker: John and Jasmina
dialogue.text: Yes, after breakfast.

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Then ... he won't be needing his reservation on the 10.15.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Exactly.

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: And I suppose as his eldest son it must go to me.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Just a minute, Tony. There's a small matter of... murder.

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Oh, but surely he simply shot himself and then hid the gun.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Partridge
dialogue.text: How could anyone shoot himself and then hide the gun without first cancelling his reservation.

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Ha, ha! Well, I must dash or I'll be late for the 10.15.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: I suggest you murdered your father for his seat reservation.

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: I may have had the motive, inspector, but I could not have done it, for I have only just arrived from Gillingham on the 8.13 and here's my restaurant car ticket to prove it.

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: The 8.13 from Gillingham doesn't have a restaurant car.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: It's a standing buffet only.

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Oh, er... did I say the 8.13, I meant the 7.58 stopping train.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Partridge
dialogue.text: But the 7.58 stopping train arrived at Swindon at 8.19 owing to annual point maintenance at Wisborough Junction.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: So how did you make the connection with the 8.13 which left six minutes earlier?

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Oh, er, simple! I caught the 7.16 Football Special arriving at Swindon at 8.09.

dialogue.speaker: Jasmina
dialogue.text: But the 7.16 Football Special only stops at Swindon on alternate Saturdays.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Partridge
dialogue.text: Yes, surely you mean the Holidaymaker Special.

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Oh, yes! How daft of me. Of course, I came on the Holidaymaker Special calling at Bedford, Colmworth, Fen Dinon, Sutton, Wallington and Gillingham.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: That's Sundays only!

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Damn. All right, I confess I did it. I killed him for his reservation, but you won't take me alive! I'm going to throw myself under the 10.12 from Reading.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Don't be a fool, Tony, don't do it, the 10.12 has the new narrow traction bogies, you wouldn't stand a chance.

dialogue.speaker: Tony
dialogue.text: Exactly.

dialogue.speaker: Shunt
dialogue.text: Chuff, chuff, chuffwoooooch, woooooch! Sssssssss, sssssssss! Diddledum, diddledum, diddlealum. Toot, toot. The train now standing at platform eight, tch, tch, tch, diddledum, diddledum. Chuffff chuffffiTff eeeeeeeeeaaaaaaaaa Vooooommmmm.

dialogue.speaker: Art Critic
dialogue.text: Some people have made the mistake of seeing Shunt's work as a load of rubbish about railway timetables, but clever people like me, who talk loudly in restaurants, see this as a deliberate ambiguity, a plea for understanding in a mechanized world. The points are frozen, the beast is dead. What is the difference? What indeed is the point? The point is frozen, the beast is late out of Paddington. The point is taken. If La Fontaine's elk would spurn Tom Jones the engine must be our head, the dining car our oesophagus, the guard's van our left lung, the cattle truck our shins, the first-class compartment the piece of skin at the nape of the neck and the level crossing an electric elk called Simon. The clarity is devastating. But where is the ambiguity? It's over there in a box. Shunt is saying the 8.15 from Gillingham when in reality he means the 8.13 from Gillingham. The train is the same only the time is altered. Ecce homo, ergo elk. La Fontaine knew his sister and knew her bloody well. The point is taken, the beast is moulting, the fluff gets up your nose. The illusion is complete; it is reality, the reality is illusion and the ambiguity is the only truth. But is the truth, as Hitchcock observes, in the box? No there isn't room, the ambiguity has put on weight. The point is taken, the elk is dead, the beast stops at Swindon, Chabrol stops at nothing, I'm having treatment and La Fontaine can get knotted.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Gavin Millar...

dialogue.speaker: Another Man
dialogue.text: ...rrrrrrr...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: ... was not talking to Neville Shunt. From the world of the theatre we turn to the world of dental hygiene. No, no, no, no. From the world of the theatre we move to the silver screen. We honour one of the silver screen's outstanding writer-dentists... writer-directors, Martin Curry who is visiting London to have a tooth out, for the pre-molar, er... premiere of his filling, film next Toothday... Tuesday, at the Dental Theatre... Film Theatre. Martin Curry talking to Matthew Palate... Padget.

dialogue.speaker: Padget
dialogue.text: Martin Curry, welcome. One of the big teeth... big points that the American critics made about your latest film, 'The Twelve Caesars', was that it was on so all-embracing a topic. What made you undertake so enormous a tusk... task?

dialogue.speaker: Curry
dialogue.text: Well I've always been interested in Imperial Rome from Julius Caesar right through to Vethpathian.

dialogue.speaker: Padget
dialogue.text: Who?

dialogue.speaker: Curry
dialogue.text: Vethpathian.

dialogue.speaker: Padget
dialogue.text: Ah! Vespasian.

dialogue.speaker: Curry
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Padget
dialogue.text: When I saw your film it did seem to me that you had taken a rather, umm, subjective approach to it.

dialogue.speaker: Curry
dialogue.text: I'm sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Padget
dialogue.text: Well, I mean all your main characters had these enormous ... well not enormous, these very big ... well let's have a look at a clip in which Julius Incisor .... Caesar talks to his generals during the battle against Caractacus.

dialogue.speaker: Curry
dialogue.text: I don't see that at all.

dialogue.speaker: Labienus
dialogue.text: Shall I order the cavalry that they may hide themselves in the wood, O Caesar?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Thus O Caesar.

dialogue.speaker: Julius
dialogue.text: Today is about to be a triumph for our native country.

dialogue.speaker: Padget
dialogue.text: Martin Curry, why do all your characters have these very big er ... very big um ... teeth?

dialogue.speaker: Curry
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Padget
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, er... and even in your biblical epic, 'The Son of Man', John the Baptist had the most enormous ... dental appendages ... and of course ... himself had the most monumental ivories.

dialogue.speaker: Curry
dialogue.text: No, I'm afraid I don't see that at all. Could I have a straw?

dialogue.speaker: Padget
dialogue.text: Oh, a straw, yes, yes. Well while we're doing that perhaps we could take another look at an earlier film, 'Trafalgar'.

dialogue.speaker: Nelson
dialogue.text: Cover my coat, Mr Bush, the men must not know of this till victory is ours.

dialogue.speaker: Toad
dialogue.text: The surgeon's coming, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Nelson
dialogue.text: No, tell the surgeon to attend the men that can be saved. He can do little for me, I fear.

dialogue.speaker: Toad
dialogue.text: Aye, aye, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Nelson
dialogue.text: Hardy! Hardy!

dialogue.speaker: Hardy
dialogue.text: Sir?

dialogue.speaker: Nelson
dialogue.text: Hardy...kiss... er ... put your hand on my thigh.

dialogue.speaker: Padget
dialogue.text: Martin Curry, thank you. Well. We asked the first-night audience what they thought of that film.

dialogue.speaker: Man With Enormous Ears
dialogue.text: It wasn't true to life.

dialogue.speaker: Man With Enormous Teeth
dialogue.text: Yes it was.

dialogue.speaker: Man With Enormous Nose
dialogue.text: No it wasn't.

dialogue.speaker: Madly Dressed Man
dialogue.text: I thought it was totally bizarre.

dialogue.speaker: First City Gent
dialogue.text: Well I've been in the city for over forty years and I think the importance of looking after poor people cannot be understressed.

dialogue.speaker: Second City Gent
dialogue.text: Well I've been in the city for twenty years and I must admit - I'm lost.

dialogue.speaker: An Old Gramophone
dialogue.text: Well, I've been in the city all my life and I'm as alert and active as I've ever been.

dialogue.speaker: Third City Gent
dialogue.text: Well I've been in the city since I was two and I certainly wouldn't say that I was stuck in a rut... stuck in a rut ... stuck in a rut... stuck in a rut...

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Oh dear, Mr Bulstrode's stuck again.

dialogue.speaker: Third City Gent
dialogue.text: I certainly wouldn't say that I was stuck in a rut.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth City Gent
dialogue.text: Well l've been in the city for thirty years and I've never once regretted being a nasty, greedy, cold hearted, avaricious, money-grubber ... Conservative.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth City Gent
dialogue.text: Well I've been in the city for twenty-seven years and I would like to see the reintroduction of flogging. Every Thursday, round at my place.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well I've been in the sea for thirty-three years and I've never regretted it.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I think it must be a naturalist outing.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: I think it must be one of them crackpot religions.

dialogue.speaker: Crackpot
dialogue.text: This is an example of the sort of abuse we get all the time from ignorant people. I inherited this religion from my father, an ex-used-car salesman and part-time window-box, and I am very proud to be in charge of the first religion with free gifts. You get this luxury tea-trolley with every new enrollment. In addition to this you can win a three-piece lounge suite, this luxury caravan, a weekend for two with Peter Bonetti and tonights star prize, the entire Norwich City Council.

dialogue.speaker: Crackpot
dialogue.text: And remember with only eight scoring draws you can win a bishopric in a see of your own choice. You see we have a much more modern approach to religion.

dialogue.speaker: Crackpot
dialogue.text: Blessed is Arthur Crackpot and all his subsidiaries Ltd. You see, in our Church we have a lot more fun.

dialogue.speaker: Priest
dialogue.text: Oh, Mrs Collins, you did say you were nervous, didn't you? You have eyes on the coffee machine?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Collins
dialogue.text: I don't mind, I don't mind - it's just nice to be here, Reverend.

dialogue.speaker: Priest
dialogue.text: Archdeacon! You asked for the coffee machine ... so lets see what you've won. You chose Hymn no. 437. Oh, Mrs Collins, you had eyes on the coffee machine. Well you have won tonight's star prize: the entire Norwich City Council.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Collins
dialogue.text: I've got one already.

dialogue.speaker: Crackpot
dialogue.text: A lot of religions - no names no pack drill - do go for the poorer type of person - face it, there's more of 'em - poor people, thieves, villains, poor people without no money at all - well we don't have none of that. Rich people and crumpet over sixteen can enter free: upper middle class quite welcome; lower middle class not under five grand a year. Lower class - I can't touch it. There's no return on it, you see.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Do you have any difficulty converting people?

dialogue.speaker: Crackpot
dialogue.text: Oh no, well we have ways of making them join.

dialogue.speaker: Crackpot's Voice
dialogue.text: Norman there does a lot of converting: a lot of protection, that sort of thing. And there's his mate, Bruce Beer.

dialogue.speaker: Crackpot's Voice
dialogue.text: Brucie has personally converted ninety-two people twenty-five inside the distance. Then again we're not afraid to use more modern methods.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Sarah, today's diocesan lovely is enough to make any chap go down on his knees. This twenty-three-year-old bishop hails appropriately enough from Bishop's Stortford and lists her hobbies as swimming, riding, and film producers. What a gas! Bet she's no novice when it comes to converting all in her See.

dialogue.speaker: Gumby
dialogue.text: Basically, I believe in peace and bashing two bricks together.

dialogue.speaker: Lennon
dialogue.text: I'm starting a war for peace.

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: Cor blimey. I'm raising polecats for peace.

dialogue.speaker: Nudge
dialogue.text: Peace? I like a peace. Know what I mean? Know what I mean? Say no more. Nudge, nudge.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Our religion is the first Church to cater for the naughty type of person. If you'd like a bit of 'love-your-neighbour' - and who doesn't now and again - then see Vera and Ciceley during the hymns.

dialogue.speaker: Bill
dialogue.text: In our Church we try to help people to help themselves - to cars, washing machines, lead piping, no questions asked. We are the only Church, apart from the Baptists, to do respray jobs.

dialogue.speaker: Ali Byan
dialogue.text: We at the Church of the Divine Loony believe in the power of prayer to turn the head purple ha, ha, ha.

dialogue.speaker: Priest
dialogue.text: I would like to come in here for a moment if I may, and disassociate our Church from these frivolous and offensive religions. We are primarily concerned with what is best... Hello. Oh, well how about Allied Breweries? All right, but keep the Rio Tinto ... for the human soul.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: In our Church we believe first and foremost in you. We want you to think of us as your friend.

dialogue.stage_direction: In this picture there are forty people. None of them can be seen. In this film we hope to show how not to be seen.

script.description: CAPTION: 'HM GOVERNMENT, PUBLIC SERVICE FILM NO. 42 PARA 6. 'HOW NOT TO BE SEEN''

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: This is Mr E. R. Bradshaw, of Napier Court, Black Lion Road, SE5. He cannot be seen. Now I'm going to ask him to stand up. Mr Bradshaw will you stand up please?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: This demonstrates the value of not being seen.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: In this picture we canot see Mrs. B.J. Smegma of 13, The Cresent, Belmont. Mrs Smegma will you stand up please.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: This is Mr Nesbitt of Harlow New Town. Mr Nesbit would you stand up please. Mr Nesbitt has learnt the first lesson of not being seen. However he has chosen a very obvious piece of cover. Mr. E.V. Lambert of 'Homeleigh', The Burrows, Oswestry, has presented us with a poser. We do not know which bush he is behind, but we can soon find out. Yes it was the middle one.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Mr Ken Andrews, of Leighton Road, Slough, has concealed himself extremely well. He could be almost anywhere. He could be behind the wall, inside the water barrel, beneath a pile of leaves, up in the tree, squatting down behind the car, concealed in a hollow, or crouched behind any one of a hundred bushes. However we happen to know he's in the water barrel.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Mr. and Mrs. Watson of 'Ivy Cottage', Worplesdon Road, Hull, chose a very cunning way of not being seen. When we called at their house, we found that they had gone away on two weeks holiday. They had not left any forwading address, and they had bolted and barred the house to prevent us getting in. However a neighbour told us where there were.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And here is the neighbour who told us where they were Nobody likes a clever dick. Here is where he lived And this is where Lord Langdon lived who refused to speak to us . So did the gentleman who lived here.... ... and here ... and of course here..... and Manchester and the West Midlands, Spain, China ...

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Ah, well I'm afraid we have to stop the film there, as some of the scenes which followed were of a violent nature which might have proved distressing to some of our viewers. Though not to me, I can tell you. In Nova Scotia today, Mr Roy Bent of North Walsham in Norfolk became the first man to cross the Atlantic on a tricycle. His tricycle, specially adapted for the crossing, was ninety feet long, with a protective steel hull, three funnels, seventeen first-class cabins and a radar scanner. Mr Bent is in our Durham studios, which is rather unfortunate as we're all down here in London. And in London I have with me Mr Ludovic Grayson, the man who scored all six goals in Arsenal's 1-0 victory over the Turkish Champions FC Botty. Ludovic... first of all, congratulations on the victory.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Grayson
dialogue.text: Thank you, David.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: It should send you back to Botty with a big lead.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Grayson
dialogue.text: Oh yes, well we're fairly confident, David.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Well at the moment, Ludovic, you're crouching down inside a filing cabinet.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Grayson
dialogue.text: Yes that's right, David, I'm trying not to be seen.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: I see. Is this through fear?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Grayson
dialogue.text: Oh no, no, it's common sense really. If they can't see you, they can't get you.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Ha, ha, ha, but of course they can still hear you. Ludovic Grayson, thank you very much for coming on the program tonight. And we end the show with music. And here with their very latest recording 'Yummy, Yummy, Yummy, I've got love in my tummy' Jackie Charlton and the Tonettes.

dialogue.stage_direction: For those of you who may have just missed 'Monty Python's Flying Circus', here it is again.

There is a pause. Almost on the edge of the frame in the distance a pepperpot stands up, proudly. Immediately a shot rings out and she leaps in the air and dies. Cut to a bush some distance awy on open land
(nothing happens)
(the bush explodes; cut to a shot of three bushes)
(the left-hand bush explodes, then the right-hand bush explodes, finally the middle bush explodes; there is a muffled scream; the smoke subsides)
Cut to a shot of farmland. There is a waterbutt, a low wall, a big pile of leaves, a parked car and lots of bushes and trees in the distance
The water barrel just blows up in the biggest explosion yet. Cut to a panning shot from beach huts accross to beach and sea
The camera has come to rest on a very obvious isolated beach hut; it blows up. Cut to a building site in a suburban housing estate. There is a Gumby standing there.
(he blows up)
(cut to stock film of a small house)
(it blows up)
(it blows up)
(shot of house: it blows up)
(ditto)
(a series of quick cuts of various atom bombs and hydrogen bomb at moment of impact)
(mad laugh)
Cut to a presentation desk. The film is on a screen behind. We see it stop behind him as the presenter speaks.
(cut to another camera; the presenter turns to face it,)
(A head and shoulders picture of Roy Bent comes up on the screen behind him)
(he turns)
(pull out to reveal that he is talking to a five-foot-high filing cabinet)
(from inside filing cabinet)
(the filing cabinet explodes)

Cut to a trendy pop-music set with coloured lights, etc. On the main podium is a large packing crate with a microphone in front of it. The backing vocal is by three more packing crates with microphones. The instrumental group are also in crates. We hear the aforementioned pop song. Roll credits over; Fade out. Cut to BBC 1 caption.
Entire show is recapped in a series of flash clips lasting about twenty seconds.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 23

dialogue.speaker: Phil
dialogue.text: Brian Distel and Brianette Zatapathique there in an improvised scene from Jean Kenneth Longueur's new movie 'Le Fromage Grand'. Brian and Brianette symbolize the breakdown in communication in our modern society in this exciting new film and Longueur is saying to us, his audience, 'go on, protest, do something about it, assault the manager, demand your money back'. Later on in the film, in a brilliantly conceived montage, Longueur mercilessly exposes the violence underlying our society when Brian and Brianerte again meet on yet another rubbish dump.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Je t'aime.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Je t'aime.

dialogue.speaker: Phil
dialogue.text: Pretty strong meat there from Longueur who is saying, of course, that ultimately materialism, in this case the Webb's Wonder lettuce, must destroy us all. That was for O. Simon, K. Simon, P. Simon and R. Sparrow of Leicester. Later on, we're going to take a look at John Wayne's latest movie, 'Buckets of Blood Pouring Out of People's Heads' but now we look ahead. On Tuesday Chris Conger took a BBC film unit to the location where 20th Century Vole are shooting their latest epic 'Scott of the Antarctic'.

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: Sea, sand and sunshine make Paignton the queen of the English Riviera. But for the next six months this sleepy Devonshire resort will be transformed into the blizzard-swept wastes of the South Pole. For today shooting starts on the epic 'Scott of the Antarctic', produced by Gerry Schlick.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Hello.

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: Gerry, you chose Paignton as the location for Scott.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Right, right.

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: Isn't it a bit of a drawback that there's no snow here?

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Well, we have 28,000 cubic feet of Wintrex, which is a new white foam rubber which actually on screen looks more like snow than snow...

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: ... and 1,600 cubic US furlongs of white paint, with a special snow finish.

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: And I believe Kirk Vilb is playing the title role.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: That is correct. We were very thrilled and honoured when Kirk agreed to play the part of Lieutenant Scott because a star of his magnitude can pick and choose, but he read the title and just flipped. And directing we have a very fine young British director, James McRettin, who's been collaborating on the screenplay, of course Jimmy...

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Oh, there you are. Hello. Hello. No problem. Have a drink. Have a drink. Great. Hello. Marvellous. Marvellous. Hello. Rewrite. Oh this is really great. I mean, it's really saying something, don't you think?

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: Have you started shooting yet?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. Great. Perfect. No, no, we haven't started yet. No. But great - great.

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: What is the first scene that you shoot this morning?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great. Terrific. Oh it's great. No problem. We'll sort it out on the floor. Sort it out on the floor. No problem. This film is basically pro-humanity and anti-bad things and it rips aside the hypocritical facade of our society's gin and tonic and leaves a lot of sacred cows rolling around in agony, have a drink, have a drink.

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: But which are we shooting first, Jimmy?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Yes, great. Oh, marvellous. Which scene are we shooting first? What? It's scene one. Scene one. It's in the middle of the movie. Well, it is now. I rewrote it. I thought we cut that? Didn't we cut that?

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: No, we didn't.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: We didn't. Oh great. That's even better. I'll put it back in. Rewrite. Scene one's back in everyone. Scene one's back in. Great. Great. This is the scene - outside the tent - it's all bloody marvelous. It makes you want to throw up.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Now in this scene Lieutenant Scott returns to camp in the early morning after walking the huskies to have brunch with the rest of his team. Oates, played by your very own lovely Terence Lemming, who is an English cockney officer seconded to the US Navy, and Bowers played by Seymour Fortescue, the Olympic pole vaulter.

dialogue.speaker: Oates
dialogue.text: Hi, Lieutenant.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: Hi, Oatesy. Sure is a beautiful day already.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great, great.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: What? What are you saying?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: I was just saying great, great. Cue Evans.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: And this is Vanilla Hoare as Miss Evans.

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: Miss Evans?

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: Good morning, Miss Evans.

dialogue.speaker: Evans
dialogue.text: Oh, I've forgotten my line.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: What's her line? What's her line?

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: It's 'Good morning, Captain Scott'.

dialogue.speaker: Evans
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah. 'Good morning, Captain Sc'..; oh, I'm just not really very happy with that line. Could I just say 'Hi Scottie'?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great. Great. Rewrite. Cue.

dialogue.speaker: Evans
dialogue.text: Hi Scarrie! Oh, sorry. Hi Stocky! Oh - I'm sorry again. Oh, Jim. I'm just unhappy with this line. Hey, can I do it all sort of kooky, like this? Hi Scottie!

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great! We'll shoot it.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: Are you sure that's right?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Oh, it's great.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Jim.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Jim! Jim! Oh, me!

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Jim, I feel we may be running into some problems here in the area of height.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great! Where are they?

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Where are who?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: I don't know. I was getting confused.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Jim, I feel here, that Scott may be too tall in the area of height with reference to Vanilla who is too near the ground in the area of being too short at this time.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great ... Oh, I know. I'm going to dig a pit for Scott and put a box in Vanilla's trench.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: Say, why don't I take the boxes off and Vanilla get up out of the trench?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work... It's even better! Great. Rewrite!

dialogue.speaker: Evans
dialogue.text: What was that?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Oh, it's easy. I've worked it out. Scott takes his boxes off and you don't stand in the trench.

dialogue.speaker: Evans
dialogue.text: I say my lines out of the trench?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Even better. Great.

dialogue.speaker: Evans
dialogue.text: But I've never acted out of a trench. I might fall over. It's dangerous.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Oh well, could you just try it?

dialogue.speaker: Evans
dialogue.text: Look, you crumb bum, I'm a star. Star, star, star. I don't get a million dollars to act out of a trench. I played Miss St John the Baptist in a trench, and I played Miss Napoleon Bonaparte in a trench, and I played Miss Alexander Fleming in a furrow so if you want this scene played out of a trench, well you just get yourself a goddamn stuntman. I played Miss Galileo in a groove and I played Mrs Jesus Christ in a geological syncline, so don't...

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great. Great everyone. Lunch now. Lunch. It's all in the can. Good morning's work.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: But you haven't done a shot.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Just keeping morale up.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Now this afternoon we're going to shoot the scene where Scott gets off the boat on to the ice floe and he sees the lion and he fights it and kills it and the blood goes pssssssssshhh in slow motion.

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: But there aren't any lions in the Antarctic.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: There aren't any lions in the Antarctic.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: You're right. There are no lions in the Antarctic. That's ridiculous! Whoever heard of a lion in the Antarctic? Right. Lose the lion.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Got to keep the lion. It's great!

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Lose the lion.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great. We're losing the lion. Rewrite. Lose the lion everyone. That's fantastic.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: What's this about our losing the lion?

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Well, Kirk, we thought perhaps we might lose the fight with the lion a little bit, Kirk, angel.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Well, Kirkie, doll, there are no lions in the Antarctic, baby.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: I get to fight the lion.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: It'd be silly.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: Listen, I gotta fight the lion. That's what that guy Scott's all about. I know. I've studied him already.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: But why couldn't you fight a penguin?

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great!

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: Fight a rotten penguin?

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: It needn't be a little penguin. It can be the biggest penguin you've ever seen. An electric penguin, twenty feet high, with long green tentacles that sting people, and you can stab it in the wings and the blood can go spurting psssssshhhh in slow motion.

dialogue.speaker: Scott
dialogue.text: The lion is in the contract.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: He fights the lion.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Even better. Great. Have a drink. Lose the penguin. Stand by to shoot.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: Where do they have lions?

dialogue.speaker: Conger
dialogue.text: Africa.

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: That's it. Scott's in Africa. As many lions as we need.

dialogue.speaker: McRettin
dialogue.text: Great!

dialogue.speaker: Schlick
dialogue.text: He's looking for a pole no one else knows about. That ties in with the sand. Right. Paint the sand yellow again. Okay, let's get this show on the road. 'Scott of the Sahara.'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Booming out of the pages of history comes a story of three men and one woman whose courage shocked a generation.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: From the same team that brought you ... 'Lawrence of Glareorgan' ... 'Bridge Over the River Trent' ... 'The Mad Woman of Biggleswade' ... and 'Krakatoa, East of Leamington' ... comes the story of three people and a woman united by fate who set out in search of the fabled Pole of the Sahara and found ... themselves. See ... Lieutenant Scott's death struggle with a crazed desert lion.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: See Ensign Oates' frank adult death struggle with the spine-chilling giant electric penguin...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: ... See Miss Evans pursued by the man-eating roll-top writing desk.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different.

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Post Office Worker
dialogue.text: Five pence please.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Excuse me, I would like to buy a fish license, please. The man's sign must be wrong. I have in the past noticed a marked discrepancy between these post office signs and the activities carried on beneath. But soft, let us see how Dame Fortune smiles upon my next postal adventure! Hello, I would like to buy a fish licence, please.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: A what?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: A license for my pet fish, Eric.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: How did you know my name was Eric?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: No no no, my name is Eric, Eric the fish. 'E's an 'alibut.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: A what?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: He is an halibut.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You've got a pet halibut?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Yes. I chose him out of thousands. I didn't like the others, they were all too flat.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You must be a loony.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: I am not a looney! Why should I be tied with the epithet looney merely because I have a pet halibut? I've heard tell that Sir Gerald Nabardo has a pet prawn called Simon and you wouldn't call him a looney; furthermore, Dawn Pailthorpe, the lady show-jumper, had a clam, called Stafford, after the late Chancellor, Allan Bullock has two pikes, both called Chris, and Marcel Proust had an haddock! So, if you're calling the author of 'A la recherche du temps perdu' a looney, I shall have to ask you to step outside!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: All right, all right, all right. You want a licence.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: For a fish.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You a loony.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Look, it's a bleeding pet, isn't it? I've got a license for me pet dog Eric, and I've got a license for me pet cat Eric...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You don't need a license for a cat.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: I bleeding well do and I got one. Ho, ho, you're not catching me out there.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: There's no such thing as a bloody cat license.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Yes there is!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No there isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Is!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Is!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Is!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Is!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Is!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Is!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: What's that then?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: This is a dog license with the word 'dog' crossed out and the word 'cat' written in in crayon.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: The man didn't have the proper form.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What man?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: The man from the cat detector van.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Loony detector van, you mean.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: It's people like you what cause unrest.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: All right, what cat detector van?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: The cat detector van from the Ministry of Housinge.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Housinge?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: It was spelt like that on the van. I'm very observant!. I never seen so many bleeding aerials. The man said that their equipment could pinpoint a purr at four hundred yards...and Eric, being such a happy cat, was a piece of cake.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: How much did you pay for this?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Sixty quid, and eight guineas for the fruit bat.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What fruit bat?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Eric the fruit-bat.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Are all your pets called Eric?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: There's nothing so odd about that: Kemal Ataturk had an entire menagerie, all called Abdul!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No he didn't!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: He did, he did, he did, he did and did. There you are. 'Kemal Ataturk, the Man' by E. W. Swanton with a foreword by Paul Anka, page 91, please.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I owe you an apology, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Spoken like a gentleman, sir. Now, are you going to give me a fish license?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I promise you that there is no such thing. You don't need one.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Then I would like a statement to that effect signed by the Lord Mayor.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You're in luck.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And now, there is the Mayor. Surely the third tallest mayor in Derby's history. And there are the Aldermen magnificently resplendent in their Aldermanic hose and just look at the power in those thighs. The New Zealanders are going to find it pretty tough going in the set pieces in the second half... So Dawn Palethorpe with one clear round on Sir Gerald... and now the Mayor has reached the Great Customer Mr Eric Praline. And now the Mayoral human being takes the Mayoral Pen in the Mayoral hand and watched by the Lady Mayoress, who of course scored that magnificent try in the first half, signs the fishy exemption and the Great Customer, Mr Eric Praline, who is understandably awed by the magnificence and even the absurdity of this great occasion here at Cardiff Arms Park, has finally gone spare and there is the going sparal look on the front of his head. And now the Aldermen are finishing their oranges and leaving the post office for the start of the second half.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: And here come the Derby Council XV following the All Blacks out on to the pitch. There, in the centre of the picture you can see Dawn Palethorpe on Sir Gerald - one of the fastest wingers we must have seen in England this season. On the left hand side of the picture the Lord Mayor has been running such wonderful possession for Derby Council in the lines out and it's the All Blacks to kick off. Wilson to kick off. Oh, I can see there the Chairman of the By-ways and Highways Committee who's obviously recovered from that very nasty blow he got in that loose ball in the first half. And Wilson kicks off and it's the Town Clerk's taken the ball beautifully there, the All Blacks are up on it very fast and the whistle has gone. I'm not quite sure what happened there, I couldn't see, but there's a scrum-down. I think it's an All Blacks' ball. They were upon them very fast. Obviously they're going to try very hard in this half to wipe out this five-point deficit. Derby Council eight points to three up and Derby Council have got the ball against the head. There is the Borough Surveyor, the scrum-half is out of the ... er, the Chairman of the Highway and By-way Committee who's kicked for touch. The line out - and it's into the line out and the Mayor has got the ball again. To the Borough Surveyor who's left out the Medical Officer of Health. Straight along the line to the Lady Mayoress and the Lady Mayoress has got to go through. Number two has missed her - he's taken to the full back - only the full back to beat and she has scored! The Lady Mayoress has scored, it's eleven points to three.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Cliff, this must have been a very disappointing result for the All Blacks.

dialogue.speaker: Cliff
dialogue.text: Well, they've had very bad luck on the tour so far. They missed four very easy kicks against the Exeter Amateur Operatic Society, which must have cost them the match and then of course there was that crippling defeat at the hands of the Derry and Toms Soft Toy Department, so I don't think they can be really fancying their chances against the London Pooves on Saturday.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: And what about China?

dialogue.speaker: Cliff
dialogue.text: Well, whether Mao Tse Tung is alive or not, Lin Piao has a stranglehold on the central committee which Lin Shao Chi can't break, so it remains to be seen whether Chou En Lai can really get his finger out and get going in the second half.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Well, thank you Cliff. Tonight's other outstanding match was the semi-final between the Bournemouth Gynaecologists and the Watford Long John Silver Impersonators. We bring you edited highlights of the match.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Well, that's about it for tonight ladies and gentlemen, but remember if you've enjoyed watching the show just half as much as we've enjoyed doing it, then we've enjoyed it twice as much as you. Ha, ha, ha.

annotations: Exterior large rubbish dump. Hand-held camera tracks to girl in simple white dress with red hair fourteen foot long, who is sitting on a chair holding a cabbage in her hands. After a time Stig, in white jeans, shirt and scarf enters shot and stands around uneasily.
Pause. Stig looks uneasy, glancing at camera.
Pause.
Stig starts to laugh falsely, and then the girl joins in. It is a miserable attempt to capture joy and togetherness. The girl stops laughing before Stig does.
Stig wanders out of shot but is very obviously pushed back into the picture.
Cut to pimply youth in studio.
Different part of same dump, but not very different. Girl is still on chair but this time with a head of lettuce. Then Stig enters shot.
Intercut quick shot from war film: machine-gunner in plane.
Shot of Paris riots and clubbing.
Shot of Michael being struck on head with a club by John.
Shot of collapsing building, then a man at a piano (Graham); the lid slams on his hands.
Shot of aeroplanes bombing. Shot of chef receiving arrow in chest. Shot of girl kicking tall man on shin. Shot of rockets being fired from plane.
Shot of hydrogen bomb.
Shot of ack ack gun. Shot of man receiving a punch in the head from a boxing glove. Shot of nun kicking a policeman in the crutch.
Shot of Spitfire. Shot of Korean soldier; then man being beheaded.

Shot of Paris riots. Shot of man having his foot stamped on. Shot of blazing building. Shot of man being poked in the eye with an umbrella. Shot of battleship firing broadside. Shot of man in underpants having a bucket of water thrown over him. Shot of soccer violence. Shot of man bring knifed by a Greek Orthodox priest.

They smile at each other happily for a moment. Then they hear something ticking. They listen carefully for a moment and then both start to look fearfully at the cos lettuce. After a moment of terror the cos lettuce explodes, in slow motion, blowing them apart. As tatters and pieces of cos lettuce float through the air in slow motion, the camera pans down to some autumn leaves. Freeze frame.
Cut back to Phil.
Chris Conger standing with back to pier and a few holidaymakers behind him.
(walks over to Schlick)
(American)
Cut to shot of people nailing and sticking white foam rubber over things. It looks terrible. Others are painting the sand with white paint.
(cut to Kirk Vilb who is wearing fur open at the chest; he is having a chest wig stuck on and icing sugar squeezed on to his nose and eyebrows)
(cut back to Gerry Schlick and Chris Conger)
McRettin rushes into foreground. He is in no way like J. McGrath.
(calls out)
(to Conger)
(calls.)
(calling)
(to Conger)
Cut to Schlick and Conger on the beach.
(cut to shot of tent with Bowers, who is black, and Oates, sitting outside)
Film: Scott comes up to them. He has two large boxes strapped to his feet to make him look tall.
(rushing in)
Sexy girl with long blond hair comes into shot with short pink fur coat. She walks up to Scott who towers four feet above her as she is walking in a trench.
Miss Evans is now beneath Scott at knee height.
Girl runs in with script.
(goes beserk waving hands)
Gerry Schlick walks into the shot.
(she walks along in the trench and we see that she has two boxes strapped to her feet)
(walks off)
(tries to take a drink from his view finder)
The same afternoon.
(loudly)
(shouts)
(falls over)
(falls over)
Cut instantly to sky.
Blinding sun. Pan down to Paignton beach. Scott, Evans, Oates and Bowers wearing furs crossing sand on snow shoes. With sledge pulled by motley selection of mongrel dogs, badly disguised as huskies.
(the names come out superimposed)

The four are walking along. Suddenly they stop, stare, and react in horror. Scott steps to the front to defend the others. Intercut, non-matching stock shot of lion running out of jungle and leaping at camera. Scott waits poised and is then struck by completely rigid stuffed lion. Montage of shots of him wrestling, firstly with the stuffed lion, then with an actor in a tatty lion suit. The lion picks up a chair, fends Scott off, smashes it over his head. Finally Scott kicks the lion on the shin. The lion leaps around on one leg and picks up a knife. Scott points, the lion looks, Scott kicks the knife out of the lion's paw. He advances on the lion, and socks him on the jaw. The lion collapses in slow motion. After a pause, phoney blood spurts out.

Oates looks up in horror, a shadow crosses him. Reverse shot of model penguin (quite small, about a foot) which lights up and looks electric. The penguin is close to the camera in the foreground and appears huge. Oates looks around desperately then starts to undress. Shot of penguin throwing tentacle. Half-nude Oates struggles with it. Intercut a lot of phoney reverses. Oates by now clad only in posing briefs sees a stone. He picks up the stone, then camera zooms into above-naval shot; he removes his briefs, puts the stone in the briefs, twirls it like a sling, and releases stone. The penguin is hit on beak, and falls over backwards.

Miss Evans is running along screaming. Shot of desk chasing her (phoney desk with man inside). The roll top goes up and down, emitting roars, and displaying fearsome white teeth inside. As Evans runs, her clothing gets torn on each of the three cactuses. These are well spaced apart so that there is a lot of trouble to get near them. When she is practically nude, she runs out of shot revealing the announcer.
dancing teeth. Then animation of a letter being resealed and posted - all backwards - ending in a real post office.
A post office worker removes the stamp from the letter and hands it to man.
The man walks out backwards, pasing Mr Praline as he enters. He looks at the man, puzzled, and then goes up to first of two grils which has a sign saying 'stamps and licences'.
(the man behind the counter points to next grille; to camera)
(he goes to next grille)
(takes book from pocket)
(referring to page 91)
Fanfare of trumpets. Mayor gorgeously dressed with dignitaries enters flanked by trumpeters.
In long shot now. The Mayor, who is nine foot high, and dignitaries approach a startled Praline. Organ music below a reverent voice over:
(the mayor takes a piece of Paper from the post office man)
(the mayor signs it and hands it to Praline)
(Praline looks very confused)

They all exit out of door, eating oranges, and Praline looks after them. Cut to a rugby field. Crowd roaring as the aldermen, mayor, mayoress, town clerk, Dawn Palethorpe (on a horse) and the borough surveyor run onto the pitch and take up their positions.
(opposite them the All Blacks kick off)
Cut to linkman and Cliff Morgan.
(Welsh)

Rapid montage of goals scored by competent gynaecologists wearing surgical gowns and caps, against totally incompetent and immobile LJSI team who simply stand round going 'aaah! Jim lad' as the goals rain in. The ball is tucked off-screen. Sudden cut to studio. A presenter is standing in front of curtain; he catches the ball thrown from off. He smiles.
The sixteen-ton weight falls on him. Cut to montage of scenes of destruction, buildings falling down, bombs etc. Roll credits over.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 22

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different.

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: How to recognize different parts of the body.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number one. The foot.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number two. The shoulder.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And number three. The other foot.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number four. The bridge of the nose.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number five. The naughty bits.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number six. Just above the elbow.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number seven. Two inches to the right of a very naughty bit indeed.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number eight. The kneecap.

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: Goodday, Bruce!

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: Oh, Hello Bruce!

dialogue.speaker: Third Bruce
dialogue.text: How are yer Bruce?

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: Bit crook, Bruce.

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: Where's Bruce?

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: He's not here, Bruce.

dialogue.speaker: Third Bruce
dialogue.text: Blimey, s'hot in here, Bruce.

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: S'hot enough to boil a monkey's bum!

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: That's a strange expression, Bruce.

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: Well Bruce, I heard the Prime Minister use it. S'hot enough to boil a monkey's bum in 'ere, your Majesty,' he said and she smiled quietly to herself.

dialogue.speaker: Third Bruce
dialogue.text: She's a good Sheila, Bruce and not at all stuck up.

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: Ah, here comes the Bossfella now! - how are you, Bruce?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: Goodday, Bruce, Hello Bruce, how are you, Bruce? Gentlemen, I'd like to introduce a chap from pommie land... who'll be joining us this year here in the Philosophy Department of the University of Woolamaloo.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Goodday.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: Michael Baldwin - this is Bruce. Michael Baldwin - this is Bruce. Michael Baldwin - this is Bruce.

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: Is your name not Bruce, then?

dialogue.speaker: Michael
dialogue.text: No, it's Michael.

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: That's going to cause a little confusion.

dialogue.speaker: Third Bruce
dialogue.text: Mind if we call you 'Bruce' to keep it clear?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: Well, Gentlemen, I think we'd better start the meeting. Before we start, though, I'll ask the padre for a prayer.

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: Oh Lord, we beseech thee, have mercy on our faculty, Amen!!

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Amen!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: Crack the tubes, right! Er, Bruce, I now call upon you to welcome Mr. Baldwin to the Philosophy Department.

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: I'd like to welcome the pommy bastard to God's own earth, and I'd like to remind him that we don't like stuck-up sticky-beaks here.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Hear, hear! Well spoken, Bruce!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: Now, Bruce teaches classical philosophy, Bruce teaches Haegelian philosophy, and Bruce here teaches logical positivism, and is also in charge of the sheepdip.

dialogue.speaker: Third Bruce
dialogue.text: What's does new Bruce teach?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: New Bruce will be teaching political science - Machiavelli, Bentham, Locke, Hobbes, Sutcliffe, Bradman, Lindwall, Miller, Hassett, and Benet.

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: Those are cricketers, Bruce!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: Oh, spit!

dialogue.speaker: Third Bruce
dialogue.text: Howls of derisive laughter, Bruce!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: In addition, as he's going to be teaching politics, I've told him he's welcome to teach any of the great socialist thinkers, provided he makes it clear that they were .

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Australia, Australia, Australia, Australia, we love you. Amen!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: Any questions?

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: New Bruce - are you a pooftah?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: Are you a pooftah?

dialogue.speaker: Michael
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: No right, well gentlemen, I'll just remind you of the faculty rules: Rule one - no pooftahs. Rule two, no member of the faculty is to maltreat the Abbos in any way whatsoever - if there's anybody watching. Rule three - no pooftahs. Rule four - I don't want to catch anyone not drinking in their room after lights out. Rule five - no pooftahs. Rule six - there is rule six! Rule seven - no pooftahs. That concludes the reading of the rules, Bruce.

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: This here's the wattle - the emblem of our land. You can stick it in a bottle or you can hold it in your hand.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Amen!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: Gentlemen, at six o'clock I want every man-Bruce of you in the Sydney Harbour Bridge room to take a glass of sherry with the flying philosopher, Bruce, and I call upon you, padre, to close the meeting with a prayer.

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: Oh Lord, we beseech thee etc. etc. etc., Amen.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Amen!

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: Right, let's get some Sheilas.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Bruce
dialogue.text: OK.

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: Ah, elevenses.

dialogue.speaker: Third Bruce
dialogue.text: This should tide us over 'til lunchtime.

dialogue.speaker: Second Bruce
dialogue.text: Reckon so, Bruce.

dialogue.speaker: First Bruce
dialogue.text: Sydney Nolan! What's that!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number nine. The ear.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number ten. The big toe.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number eleven. More naughty bits.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twelve. The naughty bits of a lady,

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number thirteen. The naughty bits of a horse,

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number fourteen. The naughty bits of an ant.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number fifteen. The naughty bits of Reginald Maudling.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number sixteen. The hand.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Good evening. I have with me in the studio tonight Mr Norman St. John Polevaulter, who for the last few years has been contradicting people...Mr Polevaulter, why do you contradict people?

dialogue.speaker: Polevaulter
dialogue.text: I don't!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: You told me that you did.

dialogue.speaker: Polevaulter
dialogue.text: I most certainly did not!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Oh. I see. I'll start again.

dialogue.speaker: Polevaulter
dialogue.text: No you won't!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Ssh! Mr Polevaulter I understand you don't contradict people.

dialogue.speaker: Polevaulter
dialogue.text: Yes I do!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And when you start contradicting people?

dialogue.speaker: Polevaulter
dialogue.text: Well I did, in 1952.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Twenty-three years ago.

dialogue.speaker: Polevaulter
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And so on and so on and so on. And now...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number seventeen. The top of the head.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number eighteen...the feather, rare.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number nineteen. The nose.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Come in.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Ah! Mr Luxury Yacht. Do sit down, please.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: Ah, no, no. My name is 'Luxury Yacht' but it's pronounced 'Throatwobbler Mangrove'.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Well, do sit down then Mr Throatwobbler Mangrove.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Now, what seems to be the trouble?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: Um, I'd like you to perform some plastic surgery on me.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: I see. And which particular feature of your anatomy is causing you distress?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: Well, well for a long time now, in fact, even when I was a child ... I ... you know, whenever I left home to ... catch a bus, or... to catch a train... and even my tennis has suffered actually...

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Yes. To be absolutely blunt you're worried about your enormous hooter.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: No?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Yes, and you want me to hack a bit off.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: Please.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Fine. It is a startler, isn't it? Er, do you mind if I... er.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Oh, no nothing, then, well, I'll just examine your nose. Mr Luxury Yacht, this nose of yours is false. It's made of polystyrene and your own hooter's a beaut. No pruning necessary.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: I'd still like the operation.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Well, you've had the operation, you strange person.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: Please do an operation.

dialogue.speaker: Specialist
dialogue.text: Well, all right, all right, but only ... if you come on a camping holiday with me.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Luxury Yacht
dialogue.text: He asked me! He asked me!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Next week we'll be showing you how to pick up an architect, how to pull a prime minister, and how to have fun with a wholesale poulterer. But now the men of the Derbyshire Light Infantry entertain us with a precision display of bad temper.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Attention

dialogue.speaker: Soldiers
dialogue.text: My goodness me, I am in a bad temper today all right, two, three, damn, damn, two, three, I am vexed and ratty. Two, three, and hopping mad.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And next the men of the Second Armoured Division regale us with their famous close order swanning about.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Squad. Camp it ... up!

dialogue.speaker: Soldiers
dialogue.text: Oooh get her! Whoops! I've got your number ducky. You couldn't afford me, dear. Two three. I'd scratch your eyes out. Don't come the brigadier bit with us, dear, we all know where you've been, you military fairy. Whoops, don't look now girls the major's just minced in with that dolly colour sergeant, two, three, ooh-ho!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And finally...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Morning sir, can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Er, yes, we've booked on your flight for America.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, we don't fly to America ... Oh, the American flight... Er, on the plane ... oh yes, oh we do that, all right. Safe as houses, no need for panic.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Is it really 37/6d?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Thirty bob. I'm robbing myself.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Thirty bob!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Twenty-five. Two quid the pair of yer. Er, that's without insurance.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Well, how much is it with insurance?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Hundred and two quid. That's including the flight.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Do we really need insurance?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No. Yes, essential.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Well, we'll have it with insurance please.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Right - do you want it with the body and one relative flown back, or you can have both bodies flown back and no relatives, or four relatives, no bodies, and the ashes sent by parcel post.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: How long will it take?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Er, let me put it this way - no idea.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Six hours.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Six?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Five, ten for the pair of you.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Oh, is it a jet?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well, no ... It's not so much of a jet, it's more your, er, Triumph Herald engine with wings.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: When are you taking off?.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: 3300 hours.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: 2600 hours for the pair of you.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Irrelevant
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Have the injections, you won't care.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Irrelevant
dialogue.text: What injections?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Barley sugar injections. Calm you down. They're compulsory - Board of Trade. Promise.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Oh, I don't like the sound of injections.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Brrp, brrp. Hello, yes right. You've got to make your mind up straight away if you're coming or not.

dialogue.speaker: Mr and Mrs Irrelevant
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Right, you can't change your mind. I'll ring the departure lounge. Hello? Two more on their way, Mrs Turpin.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Turpin
dialogue.text: Now, the duty-free trolley is over there ... there's some lovely drop scones and there's duty-free broccoli and there's fresh eccles cakes. You're allowed two hundred each on the plane. The Verrifast Plane Company announce the departure of flight one to over the hills and far away. Will passengers for flight one, please assemble at gate one. Passengers are advised that there is still plenty of time to buy eccles cakes.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Nearly ready.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Turpin
dialogue.text: All passengers please get ready for their barley sugar injections.

dialogue.speaker: Kamikaze
dialogue.text: Today we all take vow. Today we smash the enemy fleet... we smash, smash.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Turpin
dialogue.text: That's Mr Kamikaze, the pilot, he's very nice really, but make sure he stays clear of battleships.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: There have been many stirring tales told of the sea and also some fairly uninteresting ones only marginally connected with it, like this one. Sorry, this isn't a very good announcement. Sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And here is the result of the 'Where to put Edward Heath's statue Competition. The winner was a Mr Ivy North who wins ten guineas and a visit to the Sailors Quarters.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: That was last year's re-enactment of the Battle of Pearl Harbor performed by the Batley Townswomen's Guild. It was written, directed and produced by Mrs Rita Fairbanks.

dialogue.speaker: Rita
dialogue.text: Hello again.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And what are your ladies going to do for us this year?

dialogue.speaker: Rita
dialogue.text: Well, this year we decided to re-enact something with a more modern flavour. We had considered a version of Michael Stewart's speech on Nigeria and there were several votes on the Committee for a staging of Herr Willi Brandt's visit to East Germany, but we've settled instead for a dramatization of the first heart transplant. Incidentally my sister Madge will be playing the plucky little springbok pioneer Christian Barnard.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Well off we go, then with the Barley Townswomen's Guild re-enactment of the first heart transplant.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: The first heart transplant. But this is not the only open-air production here that has used the sea. Theatrical managers in this area have not been slow to appreciate the sea's tremendous dramatic value. And somewhere, out in this bay, is the first underwater production of 'Measure for Measure'.

dialogue.speaker: Character
dialogue.text: Servant ho!

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: The underwater version of 'Measure for Measure', and further out to sea 'Hello Dolly' is also doing good business.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: ... and over there on the oyster beds Formula 2 car racing.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty. The armpits.

dialogue.stage_direction: Cut to picture of a person. Superimposed white arrow on the neck.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty-one. The bottom two-thirds of the nape of the neck.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty-two. The nipple.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer's Voice
dialogue.text: ...and that concludes the week's episode of 'How to Recognize Different Parts of the Body', adapted for radio by Ann Haydon-Jones and her husband, Pip. And now we present the first episode of a new radio drama series, 'The Death of Mary, Queen of Scots.' Part One: The Beginning.

dialogue.speaker: Man's Voice
dialogue.text: You are Mary, Queen of Scots?

dialogue.speaker: Woman's voice
dialogue.text: I am!

dialogue.speaker: Radio Announcer
dialogue.text: Episode two of 'The Death of Mary, Queen of Scots', can be heard on Radio 4 almost immediately.

dialogue.speaker: Man's Voice
dialogue.text: I think she's dead.

dialogue.speaker: Woman's voice
dialogue.text: No I'm not!

dialogue.speaker: Announcer's Voice
dialogue.text: That was episode two of 'The Death of Mary, Queen of Scots', adapted for radio by Bernard Hollowood and Brian London. And now, Radio Four will explode.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: We'll have to watch the telly then.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Yes

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: What's that on the tellevision then?

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Looks like a penguin.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No, no, no, I didn't mean what's on the television set, I meant what programme.
