dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: It's funny that penguin being there innit? What's it doing there?

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Standing.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: I can see that!

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: If it lays an egg, it will fall down the back of the television set.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: We'll have to watch that. Unless it's a male.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Ooh, I never thought of that.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Yes, looks fairly butch.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Per'aps it's from next door.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Penguins don't come from next door, they come from the Antarctic.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Burma.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Why did say Burma?

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: I panicked.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oh. Perhaps it's from the zoo.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Which zoo?

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: How should I know which zoo? I'm not Doctor bloody Bernowski.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: How does Doctor Bernowski know which zoo it came from?

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: He knows everything.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oooh, I wouldn't like that, that'd take all the mystery out of life. Anyway, if it came from the zoo, it would have 'property of the zoo' stamped on it.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No it wouldn't. They don't stamp animals 'property of the zoo'. You can't stamp a huge lion.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: They stamp them when they're small.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: What happens when they moult?

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Lions don't moult.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No, but penguins do. There, I've run rings around you logically.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oh, intercourse the penguin.

dialogue.speaker: TV Announcer
dialogue.text: It's just gone 8 o'clock and time for the penguin on top of your television set to explode.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: How did he know that was going to happen?!

dialogue.speaker: TV Announcer
dialogue.text: It was an inspired guess. And now...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty-three. The shin.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty-four. Reginald's Maulding's shin

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty-five. The brain.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty-six. Magaret Thatcher's brain.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty-seven. More naughty bits.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty-eight. The naughty bits of the cabinet.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number twenty-nine. The interior of a country house.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: That's not a part of the body.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: No, it's a link though.

dialogue.speaker: Son
dialogue.text: I didn't think it was very good.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: No, it's the end of the series, they must be running out of ideas.

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: All right, don't anybody move, there's been a murder.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: A murder?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: No... no ... not a murder... no what's like a murder but begins with B?

dialogue.speaker: Son
dialogue.text: Birmingham.

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: No ... no ... no ... no ... no...

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Burnley?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Burnley - that's right! Burnley in Lancashire. There's been a Burnley.

dialogue.speaker: Son
dialogue.text: Burglary.

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Burglary. Yes, good man. Burglary - that's it, of course. There's been a burglary.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Where?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: In the back, just below the rib.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: No - that's murder.

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Oh... er no... in the band... In the bat... Barclays bat.

dialogue.speaker: Son
dialogue.text: Barclays Bank?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Yes. Nasty business - got away with £23,000.

dialogue.speaker: Son
dialogue.text: Any clues?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Any what?

dialogue.speaker: Son
dialogue.text: Any evidence as to who did it?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Any clues, eh? Oh, we don't half talk posh, don't we? I suppose you say 'ehnvelope' and 'larngerie' and 'sarndwiches on the settee'! Well this is a murder investigation, young man, and murder is a very serious business.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: I thought you said it was a burglary.

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Burglary is almost as serious a business as murder. Some burglaries are more serious than murder. A burglary in which someone gets stabbled is murder! So don't come these petty distinctions with me. You're as bad as a judge. Right, now! The first thing to do in the event of a breach of the peace of any kind, is to... go... and ... oh, sorry, sorry, I was miles away.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Ring the police?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Ring the police. Yes, that's a good idea. Get them over here fast ... no, on second thoughts, get them over here slowly, so they don't drop anything.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Shall I make us all a cup of tea?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Make what you like, Boskovitch - it won't help you in court.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: I your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, sorry. That's the trouble with being on two cases at once. I keep thinking I've got Boskovitch cornered and in fact I'm investigating a Burnley.

dialogue.speaker: Son
dialogue.text: Burglary.

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Burglary! Yes - good man.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Who's Boskovitch?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Hah! Boskovitch is a Russian scientist who is passing information to the Russians.

dialogue.speaker: Son
dialogue.text: Classified information?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Oh, there he goes again! 'Classified information'! Oh, sitting on the 'settee' with our 'scones' and our 'classified information'!

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Ah! Hello, Duckie.

dialogue.speaker: Duckie
dialogue.text: Hello, sir. How are you?

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: I'm fine thanks. How are you?

dialogue.speaker: Duckie
dialogue.text: Well, sir, I'm a little bit moody today, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: Why's that, Duckie?

dialogue.speaker: Duckie
dialogue.text: Because...

dialogue.speaker: Duckie
dialogue.text: I'm a little bit sad and lonely Now my baby's gone away... I'm feeling kinda blue Don't know just what to do I feel a little sad today.

dialogue.speaker: Chorus of PCs
dialogue.text: He's a little bit sad and lonely Now his baby's gone away He's feeling kinda blue He don't know just what to do He's not feeling so good today.

dialogue.speaker: Duckie
dialogue.text: When I smile The sun comes flooding in But when I'm sad It goes behind the clouds again.

dialogue.speaker: Chorus
dialogue.text: He's a little bit sad and lonely Now his baby's gone away He's feeling kinda etcetera, etcetera.

dialogue.speaker: Muffin
dialogue.text: A lovely song, Duckie.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: And that's the final entry. La dernière entrée. Das final entry. And now, guten abend. Das scores. The scores. Les scores. Dei scores. Oh! Scores. Ha! Scores! Yes, Monaco is the winner - hall Monaco is the linner- oh yes, man, Monaco's won de big prize, bwana ... and now, here is Chief Inspector Jean-Paul Zatapathique with the winning song once again.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And so, Inspector Zatapathique, the forensic expert from the Monaco Murder Squad sings his song 'Bing Tiddle Tiddle Bong'.

dialogue.speaker: Zatapathique
dialogue.text: Quoi? Quoi? Tout le monde, quoi? ... mais, le monde ... d'habitude ... mais ... je pense ...

dialogue.speaker: Zatapathique
dialogue.text: and Singers Bing tiddle tiddle bang Bing tiddle fiddle bing Bing fiddle fiddle tiddle tiddle Bing fiddle tiddle tiddle BONG!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Number thirty-one. The end.

annotations: The camera tracks past five gorgeous lovelies in bikini, all in send-up provocative pin-up poses. The sixth in the pan is the announcer at his desk also posing in a bikini (with bikini top).
Cut to 'It's' man, also in bikini.
Cut to credit titles as normal, except that the last shot is the little chicken man who drags across a banner reading 'How to recognize different parts of the body'.
Hold long enough to read this new title before the foot comes down, stays in shot long enough for voice over to say:
A little arrow points to the foot simultaneously. Cut to picture of Venus de Milo (top half). Superimposed little white arrow pointing to shoulder.
Cut to picture of a foot cut off at the ankle. Cigarettes are parked in the top Superimposed arrow.
Cut to profile picture of strange person (provided by Terry Gilliam) Superimposed arrow pointing to bridge of nose.
Cut to picture, full length, of man wearing polka-dotted Bermuda shorts. Arrow superimposed points to shorts.
Cut to picture of crooked elbow. Superimposed arrow pointing just above the elbow.
Cut to closer picture of different person in identical Bermuda shorts. Superimposed arrow pointing to top of groin.
Cut to close-up of a real knee. Arrow superimposed painting to knee.

Pull back to reveal the knee belongs to First Bruce, an Australian in full Australian outback gear. We briefly hear a record of 'Waltzing Mathilda'. He is sitting in a very hot, slightly dusty room with low wicker chairs, a table in the middle, big centre fan, and old fridge.
Enter fourth Bruce with English person, Michael
First Bruce snaps a plastic dog-collar round his neck. They all lower their heads.
(Third Bruce starts opening beer cans)
They all stand up.
They sit down.
An Aborigine servant bursts in with an enormous tray full of enormous steaks.
(points)
Cut to dramatic close-up of Fourth Bruce's ear. Hold close-up. The superimposed arrow pointing to the ear.
Cut to picture of big toe. Superimposed arrow.
Cut to picture of another man in Bermuda shorts. Superimposed arrow pointing at shorts.
Cut to full length shot of lady in Bermuda shorts and Bermuda bra. Superimposed arrow on each side of her body. One points to the bra, one to the Bermuda shorts.
Cut to picture of a horse wearing Bermuda shorts. Superimposed arrow.
Cut to picture of an ant. In the very corner of a blank area. It is very tiny. Superimposed enormous arrow.
Cut to picture of Reginald Maudling with Bermuda shorts, put on by Terry Gilliam, over his dark suit. Superimposed arrow pointing to shorts.
Cut to close-up of false hand sticking out of a sleeve. Superimposed arrow.

Pull back to reveal that the hand appears to belong to a standard interviewer in two shot. Chair set up with standard interviewee. The interviewer suddenly pulls the hand off, revealing that he has a hook. He throws the hand away and starts the interview.
Cut to announcer at desk in farmyard. He is fondly holding a small pig.
Cut to picture of the Pope. Slight pause, so we think it might be something to do with the Pope. An arrow suddenly comes in above him pointing down at his head.
Cut to picture of an indeterminate bit of flesh with a feather sticking out. Superimposed arrow pointing to feather.
Cut to profile of Raymond Luxury Yacht from next sketch who has an enormous false polystyrene nose. Superimposed arrow pointing at nose.

A man sitting behind a desk in a Harley Street consulting room. Close-up of the name plate on desk in front of him. Although the camera does not reveal this for a moment, this name plate, about two inches high, continues all along the desk, off the side of it at the same height and halfway round the room. We start to track along this name plate on which is written: 'Professor Sir Adrian Furrows F.R.S. F.R.C.S. F.R.C.P. M.D.M.S. (Oxon), Mall Ph.D., M. Se. (Cantab), Ph.D. (Syd), ER.G.S., F.R.C.O.G., F. FM.R.C.S., M.S. (Birm), M.S. (Liv), M.S. (Guadalahara), M.S. (Karach), M.S. (Edin), B.A. (Chic), B. Litt. (Phil), D. Litt (Phil), D. Litt (Arthur and Lucy), D. Litt (Ottawa), D. Litt (All other places in Canada except Medicine Hat, B. Sc. 9 Brussels, Liege, Antwerp, Asse, (and Grower) '. There is a knock on the door.)

The door opens and Raymond Luxury Yacht enters. He cannot walk straight to the desk as his passage is barred by the strip of wood carrying the degrees, but he discovers the special hinged part of it that opens like a door. Mr Luxury Yacht has his enormous polystyrene nose. It is a foot long.
(he does so; as he examines it the nose comes off in his hand)
Cut to lyrical film of Luxury Yacht and specialist, frolicking in countryside in slow motion.
Cut to interviewer (the one with the hook) at desk.
Eight soldiers in two ranks of four. They halt, and start to chant with precision.
(shake fists)
(stamp feet)
Cut to interviewer.
Cut to sergeant with eight soldiers.
(mincing in unison)
Cut to interviewer.
dancing generals, then the story of the killer cars.
(vicar nudges him)
(vicar nudges him)
(he holds up his crossed fingers)
(making a ringing sound)
(picks up phone)
(puts phone down)
(picks up phone)
Cut to Mrs Turpin sitting in a suburban lounge. A big sign saying 'Intercontinental Arrivals', in airport writing, hangs from the ceiling. Mr and Mrs Irrelevant arrive and sit down.
(she picks up teacup and speaks into it)
Man and vicar enter carrying a large wing.
They take the wing through. Hammering is heard.
(speaking into cup)
Japanese pilot comes in.
Man and vicar grab him and take him back.
Cut to stock film of battleships, steaming on the seas. Stirring music plays over.
Cut from sea to announcer by his desk at the seaside.
Cut to quick clip of the Battle of Pearl Harbor from show eleven, first series. Beginning with Eric blowing the whistle and the two sides rushing at each other. Cut back to announcer.
Cut to Rita Fairbanks on the beach.
Rita Fairbanks blows her whistle. The two groups of ladies rush at each other. They end up in the sea, rolling about splashing, and thumping each other with handbags.
(his desk now surrounded by sea)

Expanse of sea water. Dubbed over this is muffled, watery Shakespearian blank verse. We zoom in. Two Shakespearian actors (Terry J and Michael) leap up. They take a deep breath and go under again. The dialogue carries on muted. Pull out to see a rowboat. Shakespearian characters are sitting there waiting for their cue. One of the two characters leaps up and shouts:
He then goes underwater again. The servant in the boat steps into the water and goes under. Cut to announcer, now up to his waist in sea.
We see a buoy, on the top of which is a stiff piece of card which reads 'Hello Dolly, Tonight 7.30'. There is a muffled watery snatch of Hello Dolly. Swing round to a patch of open sea.
(underwater noises of Formula 2 cars)
a racing car moves over a naked lady, going past a sign saying 'Pit Stop'. Close up of armpits. Superimposed little white arrow.
Cut to radio.
Arrow indicates the tuning dial. Pull back. Two women are listening to the set. The announcer continues from the radio set.
Theme music. 'Coronation Scot' as used in 'Paul Temple' for years.

There now follows a series of noises indicating that Mary is getting the shit knocked out of her. Thumps, bangs, slaps, pneumatic drilling, sawing, flogging, shooting, all interlaced with Mary's screams. The two women listen calmly. After a few seconds: fade as the signature tune 'Coronation Scot' is brought up loudly to denote ending of episode.

One of the women goes over to the set and switches it over. As she goes back to her seat from the radio we hear the theme music again, fading out as the sounds of violence and screaming start again and continue unabated in vigour.
After a time, sounds of violence and screaming start again rapidly fading under the tune of 'Coronation Scot'.
(the radio explodes)
The pepperpots swivel round to look at the TV set in the corner of the room.
On the TV set there is indeed a penguin. It sits contendedly looking at them in a stuffed sort of way. There is nothing on the screen.
The second pepperpot goes to the TV, switches it on and returns to her chair. The set takes a long time to warm up and produce a picture. During this pause the following conversation takes place:
On the TV screen there now appears an announcer.
The penguin on top of the set now explodes.
Cut to picture of a shin.
Cut to Reginald Maulding.
Cut to Gilliam-type open-head picture, with arrow superimposed.
Cut to picture of Magaret Thatcher. Arrow points to her knee.
Cut to a fairly wide still picture of cricket match in progress. Batsman, bowler, ring of fielders all have polka-dotted Bermuda shorts. Little arrows point to each pair of Bermuda shorts.
Cut to picture of the cabinet at a table. Arrows point down below the table to their naughty bits.
Cut to studio shot of the next set. Interior of country house. Superimposed arrow.
Cut to room, with doctor, mother, and son.
Inspector Muffin the Mule bursts through the door.
(sarcastically)
(pause)
Sound of police siren and sound of cars drawing up outside.
The door opens and a plainclothes detective plus ten PCs (the Fred Tomlinson Singers) enter.
Rhythm combo starts up out of vision and Dective Duckie sings.
(solo)
(they stop abruptly and say):
(applause)
Eurovision girl comes in.
(cut to scoreboard in Chinese)
The accompaniment starts as the singers hum the intro. Cut to flashy Eurovision set. Zatapathique steps onto podium.
(hushed tone)
(spoken)
Credits over. Zatapathique finishes and bends over exhausted. An arrow indicates his rear.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 21

script.description: And now an appeal for sanity from the Reverend Arthur Belling.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Here is a preview of some of the programmes you'll be able to see coming shortly on BBC Television. To kick off with there's variety ... Peter West and Brian Johnston star in 'Rain Stopped Play', a whacky new comedy series about the gay exploits of two television cricket commentators with E. W. Swanton as Aggie the kooky Scots maid. For those of you who don't like variety, there's variety, with Brian Close at the Talk of the Town. And of course there'll be sport. The Classics series return to BBC 2 with twenty-six episodes of John Galsworthy's 'Snooker My Way' with Nyree Dawn Porter repeating her triumph as Joe Davis. And of course there'll be sport. Comedy is not forgotten with Jim Laker in 'Thirteen Weeks of Off-spin Bowling'. Jim plays the zany bachelor bowler in a new series of 'Owzat', with Anneley Brummond-Haye on Mr Softee as his wife. And of course there'll be sport. 'Panorama' will be returning, introduced as usual by Tony Jacklin, and Lulu will be tackling the Old Man of Hoy . And for those of you who prefer drama - there's sport. On 'Show of the Week' Kenneth Wostenholme sings. And for those of you who don't like television there's David Coleman. And of course there'll be sport. But now for something completely different - sport.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Hello. On 'Archaeology Today' tonight I have with me Professor Lucien Kastner of Oslo University.

dialogue.speaker: Kastner
dialogue.text: Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: How tall are you, professor?

dialogue.speaker: Kastner
dialogue.text: ... I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: How tall are you?

dialogue.speaker: Kastner
dialogue.text: I'm about five foot ten.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: ... and an expert in Egyptian tomb paintings. Sir Robert... are you really five foot ten?

dialogue.speaker: Kastner
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Funny, you look much shorter than that to me. Are you slumped forward in your chair at all?

dialogue.speaker: Kastner
dialogue.text: No, er I...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Extraordinary. Sir Robert Eversley, who's just returned from the excavations in El Ara, and you must be well over six foot. Isn't that right, Sir Robert?

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: In fact, I think you're six foot five aren't you?

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Oh, that's marvelous. I mean you're a totally different kind of specimen to Professor Kastner. Straight in your seat, erect, firm.

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Yes. I thought we were here to discuss archaeology.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, of course we are, yes, absolutely, you're absolutely right! That's positive thinking for you. You wouldn't have said a thing like that, would you? You five-foot-ten weed. Sir Robert Eversley, who's very interesting, what have you discovered in the excavations at El Ara?

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Well basically we have found a complex of tombs...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Very good speaking voice.

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: ... which present dramatic evidence of Polynesian influence in Egypt in the third dynasty which is quite remarkable.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: How tall were the Polynesians?

dialogue.speaker: Kastner
dialogue.text: They were...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Sh!

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Well, they were rather small, seafaring...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Short men, were they... eh? All squat and bent up?

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Well, I really don't know about that...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Who were the tall people?

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: I'm afraid I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Who's that very tall tribe in Africa?

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Well, this is hardly archaeology.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: The Watutsi! That's it - the Watutsi! Oh, that's the tribe, some of them were eight foot tall. Can you imagine that. Eight foot of Watutsi. Not one on another's shoulders, oh no - eight foot of solid Watutsi. That's what I call tall.

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Yes, but it's nothing to do with archaeology.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Oh to hell with archaeology!

dialogue.speaker: Kastner
dialogue.text: Can I please speak! I came all the way from Oslo to do this program! I'm a professor of archaeology. I'm an expert in ancient civilizations. All right, I'm only five foot ten. All right my posture is bad, all right I slump in my chair. But I've had more women than either of you two! I've had half bloody Norway, that's what I've had! So you can keep your Robert Eversley! And you can keep your bloody Watutsi! I'd rather have my little body... my little five-foot-ten-inch body...

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Bloody fool. Look what you've done to him.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Don't bloody fool me.

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: I'll do what I like, because I'm six foot five and I eat punks like you for breakfast.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: I'll get you for that, Eversley! I'll get you if I have to travel to the four corners of the earth!

dialogue.speaker: Danielle
dialogue.text: The dig was going well that year, We had discovered some Hittite baking dishes from the fifth dynasty, and Sir Robert was happier than I had ever seen him.

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Today I hear the robin sing Today the thrush is on the wing Today who knows what life will bring Today...

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Why, a Sumerian drinking vessel of the fourth dynasty. Today!!!! Catalogue this pot, Danielle, it's fourth dynasty.

dialogue.speaker: Danielle
dialogue.text: Oh, is it... ?

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Yes, it's... Sumerian.

dialogue.speaker: Danielle
dialogue.text: Oh, how wonderful! Oh, I am so happy for you.

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: I'm happy too, now at last we know there was a Sumerian influence here in Abu Simnel in the early pre-dynastic period, two thousand years before the reign of Tutankhamun, Today I hear the robin sing Today the thrush is on the wing Today who knows what life will bring.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: All right Eversley, get up out of that trench.

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Don't forget... I'm six foot five.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: That doesn't worry me... Kastner.

dialogue.speaker: Kastner
dialogue.text: Here Lord.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Up!

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Eleven foot three!

dialogue.speaker: Kastner
dialogue.text: I'm so tall! I am so tall!

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Danielle!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Eleven foot six - damn you! Abdul

dialogue.speaker: Sir Robert
dialogue.text: Fifteen foot four! Mustapha!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Nineteen foot three... damn you!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And there we end this edition of 'Archaeology Today'. Next week, the Silbury Dig by Cole Porter with Pearl Bailey and Arthur Negus.

dialogue.speaker: Reverend Belling
dialogue.text: You know, there are many people in the country today who, through no fault of their own, are sane. Some of them were born sane. Some of them became sane later in their lives. It is up to people like you and me who are out of our tiny little minds to try and help these people overcome their sanity. You can start in small ways with ping-pong ball eyes and a funny voice and then you can paint half of your body red and the other half green and then you can jump up and down in a bowl of treacle going 'squawk, squawk, squawk...' And then you can go 'Neurhhh! Neurhh!' and then you can roll around on the floor going 'pting pting pting' ...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The Reverend Arthur Belling is Vicar of St Loony Up The Cream Bun and Jam. And now an appeal on behalf of the National Trust.

dialogue.speaker: Good evening. My name is Leapy Lee. No, sorry. That's the name of me favourite singer. My name is Mrs Fred Stone. No, no, Mrs Fred Stone is the wife of me favourite tennis player. My name is Bananas. No, no, that's me favourite fruit. I'm Mrs Nice- evening- out- at- the- pictures- then- perhaps- a- dance- at- a- club- and- back- to- his- place- for- a- quick- cup- of- coffee- and- little- bit- of - no! No, sorry, that's me favourite way of spending a night out. Perhaps I am Leapy Lee? Yes! I must be Leapy Lee! Hello fans! Leapy Lee here!
dialogue.text: Little arrows that will... Hello? ... Evidently I'm not Leapy Lee. I thought I probably wouldn't be. Thank you, I'll tell them. Hello. Hello, Denis Compton here. No no... I should have written it down. Now where's that number? I'm Mao Tse Tung... I'm P. P. Arnold... I'm Margaret Thatcher ... I'm Sir Gerald Nabarro ... Hello? Sir Len Hutton here. Could you tell me, please ... oh, am I? Oh, thank you. Good evening. I'm Mrs What-number-are-you-dialing-please?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Are you the registrar?

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: I have that function.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I was here on Saturday, getting married to a blond girl, and I'd like to change please. I'd like to have this one instead please.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Er, well, the other one wasn't any good, so I'd like to swap it for this one, please. Er, I have paid. I paid on Saturday. Here's the ticket.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: Ah, oh, no. That was when you were married.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Er, yes. That was when I was married to the wrong one. I didn't like the colour. This is the one I want to have, so if you could just change the forms round I can take this one back with me now.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: I can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Look, make it simpler, I'll pay again.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: No, you can't that.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Look, all I want you to do is change the wife, say the words, blah, blab, blah, back to my place, no questions asked.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: I'm sorry sir, but we're not allowed to change.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You can at Harrods.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: You can't.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You can. I changed my record player and there wasn't a grumble.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: It's different.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: And I changed my pet snake, and I changed my Robin Day tie.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: Well, you can't change a bloody wife!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, all right! Well, can I borrow one for the weekend.

dialogue.speaker: Registrar
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, blimey, I only wanted a jolly good...

dialogue.speaker: Referee
dialogue.text: All right, break it up. What's your number, then? All right. Name?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Cook.

dialogue.speaker: Watson
dialogue.text: Er, Watson.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Mr Watson.

dialogue.speaker: Watson
dialogue.text: Ah, no, Doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Ah, Mr Doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Watson
dialogue.text: No, not Mr, Doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Oh, Doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Watson
dialogue.text: No, Doctor .

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Oh, Doctor Doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Watson
dialogue.text: Oh, just call me darling.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Hello, Mr Darling.

dialogue.speaker: Watson
dialogue.text: No, Doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Hello Doctor Darling.

dialogue.speaker: Host
dialogue.text: Ah, John. Allow me to introduce my next-door neighbour. John Stokes, this is A Snivelling Little Rat-Faced Git. Ah!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: Hello, I noticed a slight look of anxiety cross your face for a moment just then, but you needn't worry - I'm used to it. That's the trouble of having a surname like Git.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Oh ... yes, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: We did think once of having it changed by deed-poll, you know - to Watson or something like that. But A Snivelling Little Rat-Faced Watson's just as bad eh?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, I suppose so.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: Oh, that's my wife. Darling! Come and meet Mr... what was it?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Stokes - John Stokes.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: Oh yes. John Stokes, this is my wife, Dreary Fat Boring Old.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Oh, er, how do you do.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Git
dialogue.text: How do do.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Stokes
dialogue.text: Darling, there you are!

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, here I am, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: Oh, is this your wife?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, yes, this is the wife. Yes. Um darling, these, these are the Gits.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Stokes
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: The Gits.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: Oh, heaven's sakes we are being formal. Does it have to be surnames?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Oh, no, no. Not at all. No. Um, no, this... this... this is my wife Norah, er, Norah Jane, Norah Jane Stokes. This is Snivelling Little Rat-Faced Git. And this is his wife Dreary Fat Boring Old Git.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: I was just telling your husband what an awful bore it is having a surname like Git.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Stokes
dialogue.text: OH Oh well, it's not that bad.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: Oh, you've no idea how the kids get taunted. Why, only last week Dirty Lying Little Two-Faced came running home from school, sobbing his eyes out, and our youngest, Ghastly Spotty Horrible Vicious Little is just at the age when taunts like 'she's a git' really hurt. Yes.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Do ... do you live round here?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: Yes, we live up the road, number 49 - you can't miss it. We've just had the outside painted with warm pus.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: Yes. It's very nice actually. It goes nicely with the vomit and catarrh we've got smeared all over the front door.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Stokes
dialogue.text: I think we ought to be going. We have two children to collect.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: Oh, well, bring them round for tea tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Stokes
dialogue.text: Well...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Git
dialogue.text: It's Ghastly Spotty Cross-Eyed's birthday and she's having a disembowelling party for a few friends. The Nauseas will be there, and Doug and Janice Mucus, and the Rectums from Swanage.

dialogue.speaker: Host
dialogue.text: John! Allow me to introduce our next-door neighhour. John, this is Mr Watson.

dialogue.speaker: Watson
dialogue.text: Hello. I noticed a slight look of anxiety cross your face just then but you needn't worry.

dialogue.speaker: Nun
dialogue.text: I preferred the dirty version.

dialogue.speaker: Hank
dialogue.text: Well, I've been a hunter all my life. I love animals. That's why I like to kill 'em. I wouldn't kill an animal I didn't like. Goodday Roy.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Hank and Roy Spim are tough, fearless backwoodsmen who have chosen to live in a violent, unrelenting world of nature's creatures, where only the fittest survive. Today they are off to hunt mosquitoes.

dialogue.speaker: Roy
dialogue.text: The mosquito's a clever little bastard. You can track him for days and days until you really get to know him like a friend. He knows you're there, and you know he's there. It's a game of wits. You hate him, then you respect him, then you kill him.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Suddenly Hank spots the mosquito they're after.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Now more than ever, they must rely on the skills they have learnt from a lifetime's hunting. Hank gauges the wind. Roy examines the mosquito's spoor. Then ... It's a success. The mosquito now is dead. But Roy must make sure.

dialogue.speaker: Roy
dialogue.text: There's nothing more dangerous than a wounded mosquito.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But the hunt is not over. With well practised skill Hank skins the mosquito. The wings of a fully grown male mosquito can in fact fetch anything up to point eight of a penny on the open market. The long day is over and it's back to base camp for a night's rest. Here, surrounded by their trophies Roy and Hank prepare for a much tougher ordeal - a moth hunt.

dialogue.speaker: Hank
dialogue.text: Well, I follow the moth in the helicopter to lure it away from the flowers, and then Roy comes along in the Lockheed Starfighter and attacks it with air-to-air missiles.

dialogue.speaker: Roy
dialogue.text: A lot of people have asked us why we don't use fly spray. Well, where's the sport in that?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: For Roy, sport is everything. Ever since he lost his left arm battling with an ant, Roy has risked his life in the pursuit of tiny creatures. But it's not all work and for relaxation they like nothing more than a day's fishing. Wherever there is a challenge, Hank and Roy Spim will be there ready to carry on this primordial struggle between man and inoffensive, tiny insects.

dialogue.stage_direction: Oh, I've had such a morning in the High Court. I could stamp my little feet the way those QC's carry on.

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Don't I know it, love.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Objection here, objection there! And that nice policeman giving his evidence so well - beautiful speaking voice ... well after a bit all I could do was bang my little gavel.

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: You what, love?

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: I banged me gavel. I did me 'silence in court' bit. Ooh! If looks could kill that prosecuting counsel would be in for thirty years. How did your summing up go?

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Well, I was quite pleased actually. I was trying to do my butch voice, you know, 'what the jury must understand', and they loved it, you know. I could see that foreman eyeing me.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Yes, cheeky devil.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Was he that tall man with that very big... ?

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: No, just a minute - I must finish you know. Anyway, I finished up with 'the actions of these vicious men is a violent stain on the community and the full penalty of the law is scarcely sufficient to deal with their ghastly crimes', and I waggled my wig! Just ever so slightly, but it was a stunning effect.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Oh, I bet it was... like that super time I wore that striped robe in the Magistrates Court.

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Oh, aye.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Hello, Mrs Thing.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Hello, Mrs Entity.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: How are you then?

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oh, I have had a morning.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Busy?

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Busy - huh! I got up at five o'dock, I made myself a cup of tea, I looked out of the window. Well, by then I was so worn out I had to come and have a sit-down. I've been here for seven hours.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: You must be exhausted.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Mm. Oh, have you been shopping?

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No, I've been shopping.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Funny.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: I'm worn out. I've been shopping for six hours.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: What have you bought, then?

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Nothing. Nothing at all. A complete waste of time.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Wicked, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Wicked. It'll be worse when we join the Common Market.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: That nice Mr Heath would never allow that.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: It's funny he never married.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: He's a bachelor.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oooh! That would explain it, Oh dear me, this chatting away wears me out.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Yes. I bet Mrs Reginald Maudling doesn't have to put up with all this drudgery, getting up at five in the morning, making a cup of tea, looking out of the window, chatting away.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No! It'd all be done for her.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Yes, she'd have the whole day free for playing snooker.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: She probably wouldn't go through all the drudgery of playing snooker, day in, day out.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No, it would all be done for her. She wouldn't even have to lift the cue.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: She probably doesn't even know where the billlard room is.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No, still, it's not as bad as the old days. Mrs Stanley Baldwin used to have to get up at five o'clock in the morning and go out and catch partridges with her bare hands.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Yes... and Mrs William Pitt the Elder used to have to get up at three o'clock and go burrowing for truffles with the bridge of her nose.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Mrs Beethoven used to have to get up at midnight to spur on the mynah bird.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Lazy creatures, mynah birds,..

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Yes. When Beethoven went deaf the mynah bird just used to mime.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Ooh! What's happening?

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: It's all right. It's only a flashback.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: You don't fool me, you stupid mynah bird. I'm not deaf yet.

dialogue.speaker: Mynah
dialogue.text: Just you wait... ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! Oh! Bugger...

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Mynah
dialogue.text: Right in the wing.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: Shut your beak. Gott in Himmel... I never get any peace here.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: Ludwig!

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: Have you seen the sugar bowl?

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: No, I haven't seen the bloody sugar bowl.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: You know ... the bowl.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: Sod the sugar bowl... I'm trying to finish this stinking tune! It's driving me spare ... so shut up! No, no, no, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: Ludwig, have you seen the jam spoon?

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: Stuff the jam spoon!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: It was in the sugar bowl.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: Look, get out you old rat-bag. Buzz off and shut up.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: I don't know what you see in that piano.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: Leave me alone!! ... ... Ha! ha! ha! I've done it, I've done it!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: Do you want peanut butter or sandwich spread for your tea?

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: What!!!!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: PEANUT BUTTER...

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: I've forgotten it. I had it! I had it!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: Do you want peanut butter or sandwich spread?

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: I don't care!!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: Ooooh! I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: I it. I it you old bag. Mein lieber Gott. What are you doing? What's that! What's that!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: It's the plumber!

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: Gott in Himmel, I'm going out.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: Well, if you're going out don't forget we've got the Mendelssohns coming for tea so don't forget to order some pikelets.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: Pikelets, pikelets. Shakespeare never had this trouble.

dialogue.speaker: Shakespeare
dialogue.text: You wanna bet? Incidentally, its da-da-da-dum, da-da-da-dum.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: You're right. Oh, incidentally, why not call him Hamlet?

dialogue.speaker: Shakespeare
dialogue.text: Hamlet I like much better than David. Michelangelo! You use David. I won't sue

dialogue.speaker: Michelangelo
dialogue.text: Thanks, but I've had a better idea.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Michelangelo!

dialogue.speaker: Michelangelo
dialogue.text: Yes, dear!

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: I've had another son.

dialogue.speaker: Michelangelo
dialogue.text: Oh, my life.

dialogue.speaker: Mozart
dialogue.text: Composer? Huh! I wouldn't wish it on my son. He's a sensitive boy, already. I'd rather he was a sewage attendant or a ratcatcher.

dialogue.speaker: Colin Mozart
dialogue.text: Aha! Rats at 42a Kartoffelnstrasse. Hey Mitzi! I gotta go to Potato Street.

dialogue.speaker: Mitzi
dialogue.text: Put your galoshes on.

dialogue.speaker: Colin Mozart
dialogue.text: Depressed by rats? Do mice get you down? Then why not visit Colin Mozart's Rodent Extermination Boutique. Rats extirpated, mice punished, voles torn apart by Colin Mozart, Munich's leading furry animal liquidator.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: Colin Mozart
dialogue.text: Colin Mozart.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Beethoven
dialogue.text: Oh, thank goodness you've come. We're having a terrible time with them bleeding rats. I think they live in his stupid piano already.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven's Voice
dialogue.text: Get out the bloody piano you stupid furry bucktoothed gits! Get out! Gott in Himmel. Get your stinking tail out of my face.

dialogue.speaker: Beethoven
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: So anyway, Beethoven was rather glad when he went deaf.

dialogue.stage_direction: Well, I was ever so glad they abolished hanging, you know, because that black cap just didn't suit me.

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Yes. Do you remember the Glasgow treason trial?

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Oh yes, I wore a body stocking all through it.

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: No, hen, with the party afterwards.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Oh, that's right. You were walking out with that very butch Clerk of the Court.

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: That's right. Ooh, he made me want to turn Queen's evidence.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Oh, me too. One summing up and I'm anybody's.

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Anyway, Bailie Anderson.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Ooh, her?

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Yes. She's so strict. She was on at me for giving dolly sentences, you know, specially in that arson case.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: What was the verdict?

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: They preferred the brown wig.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Mm. I love the Scottish Assizes. I know what they mean by a really well-hung jury.

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Ooh! Get back in the witness box, you're too sharp to live!

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: I'll smack your little botty!

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Ooh! and again.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Have you tried that new body rub JP's use?

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: I had a magistrate in Bradford yesterday.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: Funnily enough I felt like one in a lunchtime recess today. But the ones I really like are those voice over announcers on the BBC after the programs are over.

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: Oh, aye, of course, they're as bent as safety pins.

dialogue.speaker: First Judge
dialogue.text: I know, but they've got beautiful speaking voices, haven't they? 'And now a choice of viewing on BBC Television.'

dialogue.speaker: Second Judge
dialogue.text: 'Here are tonight's football results.'

dialogue.speaker: First and Second Judges
dialogue.text: Mmm.

(still of him, superimposed over Flick Colby Dancers, Pans People, Ono)
(picture of him smiling)
'Grandstand' signature tune starts and then abruptly cuts into the usual animated credit titles.
a sketch about an archaeological find leads to:
Interview set for archaeology program. Chairman and two guests sit in chair in front of a blow-up of an old cracked pot.
(turning to Kastner)
(puzzled)
Applause from off. Sir Robert looks up in amazement.
(to Kastner)
(he turns his back very ostentatiously on Kastner)
(picking up a beautiful ancient vase)
(knocking Sir Robert's vase to the floor)
(he breaks down sobbing)
Sir Robert floors the interviewer with a mighty punch. Interviewer looks up rubbing his jaw.
Crash of music. Music goes into theme and film titles as for a Western.
Cut to stock film of the pyramids (circa 1920).
An archaeological dig in a flat sandy landscape. All the characters are in twenties' clothes. Pan across the complex of passages and trenches.)
(voice over)
Camera comes to rest on Sir Robert Eversley digging away. We close in on him as he sings to Hammond organ accompaniment.
He stops and picks up an object, blows the dust off it and looks at it wondrously.
(sings!)
(speaks)
(he breaks into song again)
(singing)
(Danielle joins in)
They are just about to embrace, when there is a jarring chord and long crash. The interviewer, in the clothes he wore before, is standing on the edge of the dig.
He snaps his fingers. From behind him Professor Kastner appears, fawningly.
He snaps his fingers and Kastner leaps onto his shoulders.
Danielle leaps on his shoulders.
A servant appears on Kastner's shoulders.
A servant appears on Danielle's shoulders.

The six of them charge each other. They fight in amongst the trestle tables with rare pots on them breaking and smashing them. When the fight ends everyone lies dead in a pile of broken pottery. The interviewer crawls up to camera and produces a microphone from his pocket. He is covered in blood and in his final death throes.
(he dies)
Cut to studio. A vicar sitting facing camera. He has an axe in his head.
(he rolls around on the floor)
Cut to a smartly dressed woman.
(sings)
(phone rings, she answers)
(puts phone down)
(as she looks in her bag she talks to herself)
(she dials)
(puts phone down)

A boxer (Terry G) rushes in and fells her with one blow. After Women's Institute applauding cut to:
a man coming through a door with a neat little bride in a bridal dress. The man walks up to the registrar who is sitting at his desk with a sign saying 'Registrar of Marriages '.
(gives him the marriage licence.)
A whistle blows. A referee runs on, takes his book out and proceeds to take the name of the man in the registry office, amidst protests.

Cut to the two in the next sketch waiting. Cut back to referee, who finishes booking the man and blows his whistle. The show continues. Cut to the two waiting. On the sound of the whistle they start acting.
(writing it down)
Sound of whistle; instant cut to:
Animation sketch leads us into a cocktail party in Dulwich. Quiet party-type music. Constant chatter.
Mrs Git approaches.
Mrs Stokes appears.
(slightly shocked)
(understanding at last)
Mrs Git gobs colourfully into her handbag.
(with increasing embarrassment)
(and CAPTION:)
Cut to exactly the same set-up as before.
Cut to nun.
She is knocked out by the boxer.
Cut to Women's Institute applause film.

Pull back to reveal he is walking with his brother in fairly rough country location. They pull a small trailer with 'high explosives' written in large letters on the side. The trailer has bombs in it. Hank takes a bazooka from the trailer.
Big close-up Roy Spim. He is obviously searching for something.
(voice over)
Cut to Hank Spim who stands peering toward the horizon. Suddenly he points.
Dramatic music. Crash zoom along Hank's eyeline to as big a close-up as we can get of a patch in a perfectly ordinary field. Cut back to Hank and Roy starting to crawl towards some bushes.
(tense music, as they worm their way forward)
(shot of Hank doing complicated wind gauging biz.)
(shot of Roy examining the ground intently)
(Roy fires a bazooka. Hank fires off a machine gun; a series of almighty explosions in the small patch of field; the gunfire stops and the smoke begins to clear)
(Hank and Roy approach the scorched and blackened patch in the field)
(Roy points machine gun at head of mosquito and fires off another few rounds)
(Hank produces an enormous curved knife and begins to start skinning the tiny mosquito)
(shot of them walking, carrying weapons)
(inside villa; Hank is cleaning bazooka)
Shot of them driving in Land Rover heavily loaded with weapons.
(a peaceful river bank; Roy and Hank are fishing)
(Hank presses a button and there is a tremendous explosion in the water)
Pull out to reveal the brothers standing on a tank. Heroic music reaches a climax.
Apropos of nothing cut to oak-panelled robing chamber in the Old Bailey. Two Judges in full wigs and red robes enter.
(very camp)
(just as camp)
Fade out. Fade into a bench in a public park, garden or square. A pepperpot is sitting on the bench. Another pepperpot comes by pushing a shopping trolley.
The picture begins to wobble as in flashback; appropriate dreamy music effect.
(looking at camera)
Cut to Beethoven's living room. A model mynah bird is opening and shutting its beak. Beethoven is sitting at the piano.
(Beethoven pulls a revolver and shoots the bird which falls to the ground)
He plays the first few notes of the fifth symphony, trying vainly to get the last note. Mrs Beethoven enters.
(she leaves; he goes into opening bars of 'Washington Post March )
Mrs Beethoven comes back in.
(she goes)
(gets the first eight notes right at last)
Mrs Beethoven comes in again.
(plays a few wrong notes)
(she goes out)
(at the same moment as he gets it right again, the door flies open and Mrs Beethoven charges in with a very load vacuum)
(a terrible clanking and banging comes from the wall)
(still vacuuming loudly)
A jarring ring of the doorbell adds to the din.
Shakespeare washing up at a sink present day.
Cut back to Beethoven.
Cut back to Shakespeare
(he shouts through open window next to sink)
Cut to Michelangelo's studio. Michelangelo is in middle of feeding and looking after at least six screaming little babies. His statue of David is in the foreground.
Camera pans down to show engraved on plinth beneath statue the words 'Michelangelo's Fifth Symphony'.
(off-screen)
Cut to Mozart. He is scrubbing the floor.
(Jewish accent)

Cut to street with old-fashioned shops. Exterior. Camera tracks in to a shopfront with a large sign outside: 'Rodent Exterminating Boutique - Colin "Chopper" Mozart (Son Of Composer) Ratcatcher To The Nobility And Ordinary People, Too - Ici On Parle Portugaise'. At the door of shop stands Colin Mozart. A kid runs up to him bearing a long cleft stick, Mozart takes the note from the cleavage and reads it.
(off-screen)
Mozart leaps on to a bike carrying two shrimp-nets, and rides off.
(shouting)
Colin Mozart cycles up to Beethoven's house. Outside is a noticeboard saying:
Beethoven's front door is opened by Mrs Beethoven.
They go into the house. We hear the first two bars of Beethoven's Fifth counterpointed by loud squeaking.

Mrs Beethoven opens the door and we see for the first time a strange sight. Rats are flying across the room (thrown from out of vision) others scuttle across floor (pulled by strings) others up wall. One sits on Beethoven's head. The squealing is deafening. Beethoven plays on relentlessly. Mozart and Mrs Beethoven run into room and start trying to catch the rats with the shrimp-nets.
Colin Mozart is sitting on the piano. He rakes the rat-infested room with machine-gunfire.
The picture starts to wobble and mixes back to the two pepperpots.

Mix to Beethoven pushing the keys of the keyboard which is all that remains of his piano. He listens vainly. The mynah bird opens and shuts its beak. In the corner an old horn gramophone plays. We hear Jimmy Durante singing the end of 'I'm the guy that found the lost chord'. Cut back to judges' robing room.
Superimposed credits. Theme tune heard quietly as judges continue.
(credits end)
Fade out.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 20

dialogue.speaker: First Voice Over
dialogue.text: In the fifth century, as the once-mighty Roman Empire crumbled, the soft underbelly of Western Europe lay invitingly exposed to the barbarian hordes to the East. Alaric the Visigoth, Galseric the Vandal and Theodoric the Ostrogoth in turn swept westward in a reign of terror. But none surpassed in power and cruelty the mighty Attila the Hun.

dialogue.speaker: Second Voice Over
dialogue.text: Ladies and gentlemen, it's the 'The Attila the Hun Show'.

dialogue.speaker: First Voice Over
dialogue.text: In the second quarter of the fifth century, the Huns became a byword for merciless savagery. Their Khan was the mighty warrior Attila. With his devastating armies he swept across Central Europe.

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Oh darling, I'm home.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Attila
dialogue.text: Hello darling. Had a busy day at the office?

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Not at all bad. Another merciless sweep across Central Europe.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Attila
dialogue.text: I won't say I'm glad to see you, but boy, am I glad to see you.

dialogue.speaker: Jenny
dialogue.text: Hi, daddy.

dialogue.speaker: Robin
dialogue.text: Hi, daddy.

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Hi, Jenny, hi, Robby. Hey, I've got a present for you two kids in that bag. I want you kids to get a-head.

dialogue.speaker: Uncle Tom
dialogue.text: Hear you are, Mr Hun!

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Hi, Uncle Tom.

dialogue.speaker: Uncle Tom
dialogue.text: There's a whole horde of them marauding Visigoths to see y'all.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different.

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's ...

dialogue.speaker: First Voice Over
dialogue.text: Yes, it's Attila the Nun.

dialogue.speaker: Second Voice Over
dialogue.text: A simple country girl who took a vow of eternal brutality.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Nurse!

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Hello, Miss Norris. How are you?

dialogue.speaker: Miss Norris
dialogue.text: Not too bad, thank you, doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Yes, well I think I'd better examine you.

dialogue.speaker: Miss Norris
dialogue.text: What are they doing here?

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: It's all right, they're students. Um... lights please, nurse. Oh... and... er... music, too. Breathe in ... out ... in ... out...

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Thank you, thank you. Charles Crompton, the Stripping Doctor. And next, gentlemen and ladies, here at the Peephole Club for the very first time - a very big welcome please for the Secretary of State for Commonwealth Affairs.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Good evening. Tonight I'd like to restate our position on agricultural subsidies, and their effect on our Commonwealth relationships. Now although we believe, theoretically, in ending guaranteed farm prices, we also believe in the need for a corresponding import levy to maintain consumer prices at a realistic level. But this would have the effect of consolidating our gains of the previous fiscal year, prior to the entry. But I pledge that should we join the Common Market - even maintaining the present position on subsidies - we will never jeopardize, we will never compromise our unique relationship with the Commonwealth countries. A prices structure related to any import charges will be systematically adjusted to the particular requirements of our Commonwealth partners - so that together we will maintain a positive, and mutually beneficial alliance in world trade and for world peace. Thank you and goodnight.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Wasn't he marvellous? The Secretary of State for Commonwealth Affairs! And now gentlemen and ladies, a very big welcome please for the Minister of Pensions and Social Security!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Yes, today in Britain there is a new wave of interest in politics and politicians.

dialogue.speaker: First Girl
dialogue.text: Well, we're just in it for the lobbying, you know. We just love lobbying.

dialogue.speaker: Second Girl
dialogue.text: And the debates - you know a good debate ... is just... fabulous.

dialogue.speaker: Third Girl
dialogue.text: Well, I've been going with ministers for five years now and, you know... I think they're wonderful.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Girl
dialogue.text: Oh yes, I like civil servants.

dialogue.speaker: Third Girl
dialogue.text: Oh yes, they're nice.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Girl
dialogue.text: I like the Speaker.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Girl
dialogue.text: Oh yes.

dialogue.speaker: Second Girl
dialogue.text: I like Black Rod.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: What do their parents think?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Concrete
dialogue.text: Well she's broken our hearts, the little bastard. She's been nothing but trouble and if she comes round here again I'll kick her teeth in.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Have you been talking to television again, dear?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Concrete
dialogue.text: Yes, I bloody told 'em.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: What about?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Concrete
dialogue.text: I dunno.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Was it Reginald Bosanquet?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Concrete
dialogue.text: No, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Did he have his head all bandaged?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Concrete
dialogue.text: No, it wasn't like that. They had lots of lights and cameras and tape recorders and all that sort of thing.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Oh, that'll be Ray Baxter and the boys and girls from 'Tomorrow's World'. Oh, I prefer Reginald Bosanquet, there's not so many of them. Oh - that'll be the ratcatcher.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Hello - Mr and Mrs Concrete?

dialogue.speaker: Both
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Well, well, well, well, well, well, well, well, well, well, well, how very nice. Allow me to introduce myself. I am Leslie Ames, the Chairman of the Test Selection Committee, and I'm very pleased to be able to tell you that your flat has been chosen as the venue for the third test against the West Indies.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: No, it was just a little joke. Actually, I am the Council Ratcatcher.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Oh yes, we've been expecting you.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Oh, I gather you've got a little rodental problem.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Oh, blimey. You'd think he was awake all the night, scrabbling down by the wainscotting.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Um, that's an interesting word, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Wainscotting ... Wainscotting ... Wainscotting ... sounds like a little Dorset village, doesn't it? Wainscotting.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: We've been mentioned on telly!

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Now, where is it worst?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Well, down here. You can usually hear them.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Sssssh

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Baa ... baa ... baa ... baa ... baa ... baa...

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: No, that's sheep you've got there.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Baa ... baa.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: No, that's definitely sheep. A bit of a puzzle, really.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Is it?

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Yeah, well, I mean it's (a) not going to respond to a nice piece of cheese and (b) it isn't going to fit into a trap.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Oh - what are you going to do?

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Well, we'll have to look for the hole.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Oh yeah. There's one here.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: No, no, that's mice.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Ah, this is what we're after.

dialogue.speaker: Cricketer
dialogue.text: Excuse me, is the third test in here?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Concrete
dialogue.text: No - that was a joke - a joke!

dialogue.speaker: Cricketer
dialogue.text: Oh blimey,

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Right. Well, I'm going in the wainscotting.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: They said it again.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: I'm going to lay down some sheep poison.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Baa, baa, baa.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Aagh. Ooh! It's got a gun!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Concrete
dialogue.text: Blimey.

dialogue.speaker: Ratcatcher
dialogue.text: Now, normally a sheep is a placid, timid creature, but you've got a killer.

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: It's an entirely new strain of sheep, a killer sheep that can not only hold a rifle but is also a first-class shot.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: But where are they coming from, professor?

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: That I don't know. I just don't know. I really just don't know. I'm afraid I really just don't know. I'm afraid even I really just don't know. I have to tell you I'm afraid even I really just don't know. I'm afraid I have to tell you... ... thank you ... ... I don't know. Our only clue is this portion of wolf's clothing which the killer sheep ...

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: ... was wearing...

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: ... in yesterday's raid on Selfridges.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: I'll carry out tests on it straight away, professor.

dialogue.speaker: Cricketer
dialogue.text: Hello, is the third test in here, please?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Professor, there are some cricketers in the laboratory.

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: This may be even more serious than even I had at first been imagining. What a strange... strange line. There's no time to waste. Get me the Chief Commissioner of Police.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Yes, sir!

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: No, no, on the phone.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh...

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: Look of fear! Another strange line. Look out, Miss Garter Oil!

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Professor! What is it? What have you seen?

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: Look - there, in the doorway.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Urghhh! Arthur X! Leader of the Pennine Gang!

dialogue.speaker: Narrator
dialogue.text: But soon the killer sheep began to infect other animals with its startling intelligence. Pussy cats began to arrange mortgages, cocker spaniels began to design supermarkets...

dialogue.speaker: Narrator
dialogue.text: Good evening. Here is the news for Parrots. No parrots were involved in an accident on the M1 today when a lorry carrying high-octane fuel was in collison with a bollard. That's a and not a . A spokesman for parrots said he was glad no parrots were involved. The Minister of Technology today met the three Russian leaders to discuss a £4 million airliner deal... None of them went in the cage, or swung on the little wooden trapeze or ate any of the nice millet seed yum, yum. That's the end of the news, now our program for parrots continues with part three of 'A Tale of Two Cities', specially adapted for parrots by Joey Boy. The story so far, Dr. Manette is in England after eighteen years in the Bastille. His daughter Lucy awaits her lover Charles Darney, who we have just learned is in fact the nephew of the Marquis de St Evremond, whose cruelty had placed Manette in the Bastille. Darney arrives to find Lucy tending her aged father.

dialogue.speaker: Darnay
dialogue.text: 'Allo, 'allo.

dialogue.speaker: Lucy
dialogue.text: 'Allo, 'allo, 'allo.

dialogue.speaker: Old Man
dialogue.text: 'Allo, 'allo, 'allo.

dialogue.speaker: Darnay
dialogue.text: Who's a pretty boy, then?

dialogue.speaker: Lucy
dialogue.text: 'Allo, 'allo, 'allo.

dialogue.speaker: And more of the same.
dialogue.text: Cut back to the narrator.

dialogue.speaker: Narrator
dialogue.text: And while that's going on, here is the news for gibbons. No gibbons were involved in...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And while that's going on, here from Westminster is a parliamentary report for Humans.

dialogue.speaker: Cyril
dialogue.text: In the debate, a spokesman accused the goverment of being silly and doing not at all good things. The member accepted this in the spirit of healthy criticism, but denied that he had ever been naughty with a choir boy. Angry shouts of 'What about the Watermelon then?' were ordered then by the speaker to be stricken from the record and put into a brown paper bag in the lavvy. Any further interruptions would be cut up and distributed amongst the poor. For the Government, a front-bench spokesman said the Agricultural Tariff have to be raised, and he fancied a bit. Futhermore, he argued, this would give a large boost to farmers, him, his friends, and Miss Moist of Knightsbridge. From the back benches there were opposition shouts of 'Postcards for sale' and a healthy cry of 'Who likes a sailor then?' from the minister without portfolio. Replying, the Shadow Minister said he could no longer deny the rumors, but he and the Dachshund were very happy. And in any case he argued Rhubarb was cheap, and what was the harm in a sauna bath?

dialogue.speaker: Narrator
dialogue.text: ...were not involved. The Minister of Technology met the three Russian leaders today to discuss a £4 million airliner deal....none of them were indigenous to Australia, carried their young in pouches, or ate any of those yummy Eucalyptus leaves.Yum Yum. Thats the news for wombats, and now Attila the Bun!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Well that's all for Attila the Bun, and now - idiots!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Arthur Figgis is an idiot. A village idiot. Tonight we look at the idiot in society.

dialogue.speaker: Figgis
dialogue.text: Well I feel very keenly that the idiot is a part of the old village system, and as such has a vital role to play in a modern rural society, because you see ... ooh ar ooh ar before the crops go gey are in the medley crun and the birds slides nightly on the oor ar ... Ooh ar thankee, Vicar ... There is this very real need in society for someone whom almost anyone can look down on and ridicule. And this is the role that ... ooh ar naggy gamly rangle tandie oogly noogle Goblie oog ... Thank you, Mrs Thompson... this is the role that I and members of my family have fulfilled in this village for the past four hundred years... Good morning, Mr Jenkins, ICI have increased their half-yearly dividend, I see.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Jenkins
dialogue.text: Yes, splendid.

dialogue.speaker: Figgis
dialogue.text: That's Mr Jenkins - he's another idiot. And so you see the idiot does provide a vital psycho-social service for this community. Oh, excuse me, a coach party has just arrived. I shall have to fall off the wall, I'm afraid.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Arthur takes idiotting seriously. He is up at six o'clock every morning working on special training equipment designed to keep him silly. And of course he takes great pride in his appearance.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Like the doctor, the blacksmith, the carpenter, Mr Figgis is an important figure in this village and - like them - he uses the local bank.

dialogue.speaker: Bank Manager
dialogue.text: Yes, we have quite a number of idiots banking here.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: What kind of money is there in idioting?

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: Well nowadays a really blithering idiot can make anything up to ten thousand pounds a year - if he's the head of some big industrial combine. But of course, the more old-fashioned idiot still refuses to take money.

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: He takes bits of string, wood, dead budgerigars, sparrows, anything, but it does make the cashier's job very difficult; but of course they're fools to themselves because the rate of interest over ten years on a piece of moss or a dead vole is almost negligible.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Mr Brando.

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Hollywood on the phone.

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: I'll take it in the office.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But Mr Figgis is no ordinary idiot. He is a lecturer in idiocy at the University of East Anglia. Here he is taking a class of third-year students.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: After three years of study these apprentice idiots receive a diploma of idiocy, a handful of mud and a kick on the head.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But some of the older idiots resent the graduate idiot.

dialogue.speaker: Old Idiot
dialogue.text: I'm a completely self-taught idiot. I mean, ooh arh, nob arhh, nob arhh .... nobody does that anymore. Anybody who did that round here would be laughed off the street. No, nowadays people want something wittier.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Kevin O'Nassis works largely with walls.

dialogue.speaker: Kevin
dialogue.text: You've got to know what you're doing. I mean, some people think I'm mad. The villagers say I'm mad, the tourists say I'm mad, well I am mad, but I'm naturally mad. I don't use any chemicals.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But what of the idiot's private life? How about his relationship with women?

dialogue.speaker: Idiot
dialogue.text: Well I may be an idiot but I'm no fool.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But the village idiot's dirty smock and wall-falling are a far cry from the modern world of the urban idiot. What kinds of backgrounds do these city idiots come from?

dialogue.speaker: First City Idiot
dialogue.text: Eton, Sandhurst and the Guards, ha, ha, ha, ha.

dialogue.speaker: Second City Idiot
dialogue.text: I can't remember but I've got it written down some where.

dialogue.speaker: Third City Idiot
dialogue.text: Daddy's a banker. He needed a wastepaper basket.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth City Idiot
dialogue.text: Father was Home Secretary and mother won the Derby.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: The headquarters of these urban idiots is here in St John's Wood. Inside they can enjoy the company of other idiots and watch special performances of ritual idioting.

dialogue.speaker: First Idiot
dialogue.text: Well left.

dialogue.speaker: Second Idiot
dialogue.text: Well played.

dialogue.speaker: Third Idiot
dialogue.text: Well well.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Idiot
dialogue.text: Well bred.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Idiot
dialogue.text: Ah!

dialogue.speaker: Jim
dialogue.text: Good afternoon and welcome to Lords on the second day of the first test. So far today we've had five hours batting from England and already they're nought for nought. Cowdrey is not out nought. Naughton is not in. Knott is in and is nought for not out. Naughton of Northants got a nasty knock on the nut in the nets last night but it's nothing of note. Next in is Nat Newton of Notts. Not Nutring - Nutting's at nine, er, Nutring knocked neatie nighty knock knock... ... anyway England have played extremely well for nothing, not a sausage, in reply to Iceland's first innings total of 722 for 2 declared, scored yesterday disappointingly fast in only twenty-one overs with lots of wild slogging and boundaries and all sorts of rubbishy things. But the main thing is that England have made an absolutely outstanding start so far, Peter?

dialogue.speaker: Peter
dialogue.text: Splendid. Just listen to those thighs. And now it's the North East's turn with the Samba. Brian.

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: Rather. I'm reminded of the story of Gubby Allen in '32. ..

dialogue.speaker: Jim
dialogue.text: Oh, shut up or we'll close the bar. And now Bo Wildeburg is running up to bowl to Cowdrey, he runs up, he bowls to Cowdrey...

dialogue.speaker: Jim
dialogue.text: ... and no shot at all. Extremely well not played there.

dialogue.speaker: Peter
dialogue.text: Yes, beautifully not done anything about.

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: A superb shot of no kind whatsoever. I well remember Plum Warner leaving a very similar ball alone in 1732.

dialogue.speaker: Jim
dialogue.text: Oh shut up, long nose. And now it's Bo Wildeburg running in again to bowl to Cowdrey, he runs in. He bowls to Cowdrey - and no shot at all, a superb display of inertia there... And that's the end of the over, and drinks.

dialogue.speaker: Peter
dialogue.text: Gin and tonic please.

dialogue.speaker: Jim
dialogue.text: No, no the players are having drinks. And now, what's happening? I think Cowdrey's being taken off. Yes, Cowdrey is being carried off. Well I never. Now who's in next, it should be number three, Natt Newton of Notts... get your hand off my thigh, West... no I don't think it is... I think it's er, it's the sofa ... no it's the Chesterfield! The green Chesterfield is coming in at number three to take guard now.

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: I well remember a similar divan being brought on at Headingley in 9 BC against the darkies.

dialogue.speaker: Jim
dialogue.text: Oh, shut up, elephant snout. And now the green Chesterfield has taken guard and Iceland are putting on their spin dryer to bowl.

dialogue.speaker: Jim
dialogue.text: The spin dryer moves back to his mark, it runs out to the wicket, bowls to the table... a little bit short but it's coming in a bit there and it's hit him on the pad... and the table is out, leg before wicket. That is England nought for one.

dialogue.speaker: Different Voice Over
dialogue.text: And now we leave Lords and go over to Epsom for the three o'clock.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Well here at Epsom we take up the running with fifty yards of this mile and a half race to go and it's the wash basin in the lead from WC Pedestal. Tucked in nicely there is the sofa going very well with Joanna Southcott's box making a good run from hat stand on the rails, and the standard lamp is failing fast but it's wash basin definitely taking up the running now being strongly pressed by ... At the post it's the wash basin from WC then sofa, hat stand, standard lamp and lastly Joanna Southcott's box.

dialogue.speaker: Bishops
dialogue.text: Open the box! Open the box! Open the box! Open the box! Open the box!

dialogue.speaker: Michael Miles
