dialogue.text: Apparently there were these three nuns...

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Shut up. Come the year 1991, given the present rate of increase in the world's population, the Chinese will be three deep. Another thing...

dialogue.speaker: Floor Manager
dialogue.text: Sorry, loves, sorry, the show is too long this week and this scene's been cut.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Lord Hill's at the bottom of this.

dialogue.speaker: Floor Manager
dialogue.text: But if you can find a piano stool you can appear later on in the show on film.

dialogue.speaker: Brooky
dialogue.text: 'Ow much?

dialogue.speaker: Floor Manager
dialogue.text: Oh, about ten bob each?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: I wouldn't wipe me nose on it.

dialogue.speaker: Brooky
dialogue.text: 'Ave you 'eard the one about these three nuns...

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Shh. I can hear something. 'Ang about, we may still get in this show as a link.

dialogue.speaker: Brooky
dialogue.text: That's clever. How do they do that?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Colour separation, you cotton head.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Well, they seem to be in another tight spot... Could you...could you, could you keep it down a little, please. Thank you so much. Could you keep it down please...Thank you. Well and now we move on to our, to our main course. Prawn salad...Prawn salad?

dialogue.speaker: Butler
dialogue.text: Well, if you'll just wait in here, sir, I'm sure Mr Thompson won't keep you waiting long.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Fine. Thanks very much.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: The mirror fell off the wall.

dialogue.speaker: Butler
dialogue.text: Sir?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: The mirror fell off... off the wall... it fell.

dialogue.speaker: Butler
dialogue.text: I see. You'd better wait here. I'll get a cloth.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Ah, it ... it came off the wall.

dialogue.speaker: Butler
dialogue.text: Yes, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: It just came right off the wall.

dialogue.speaker: Butler
dialogue.text: Really, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, I ... I didn't touch it.

dialogue.speaker: Butler
dialogue.text: Of course not. It just fell off the wall.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes. It just fell off the wall.

dialogue.speaker: Butler
dialogue.text: Don't move. I'll get help.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes - er, fell off the wall.

dialogue.speaker: Maid
dialogue.text: Oh my God, what a mess. 'Ere, did you do this?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, no. I didn't do all this. It... it did it all.

dialogue.speaker: Maid
dialogue.text: Oh? Well... 'ere, hold this. I'll get started.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, it's jolly nice. What is it?

dialogue.speaker: Maid
dialogue.text: It's a Brazilian dagger. Ooops.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Er, she just fell on ... on to the dagger.

dialogue.speaker: Green
dialogue.text: Yes, of course she did, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, just gave me the dagger and tripped, and went, 'Oops'.

dialogue.speaker: Green
dialogue.text: Yes sir, I understand.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I mean, I didn't er...

dialogue.speaker: Green
dialogue.text: Oh no, no, of course not, sir, I understand.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I mean she ... she just, er...

dialogue.speaker: Green
dialogue.text: Fell?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Fell.

dialogue.speaker: Green
dialogue.text: Arrghh!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I'm terribly sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Butler
dialogue.text: That's him.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Right, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Hello, officer. There seems to have been an accident. Well, several accidents actually.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: That's right, sir. Would you come this way, please. Ahh! It's me ... me heart, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Butler
dialogue.text: You swine. I'll get you for that.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Er, I won't wait. I'll phone.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Members
dialogue.text: I think we're really out this time. Yes. Jolly good. Now where's the school hall. I think it's over there. Come on. Sorry. Jolly good.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Oh, Mr Belpit. Your legs are so swollen.

dialogue.speaker: Sir William
dialogue.text: Excuse me, is that the school hall?

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Um, I'm sorry, I don't know. I'm not in this one - I'm in next week's, I think.

dialogue.speaker: Sir William
dialogue.text: Oh, come on.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Oh, Mr Belpit!...

dialogue.speaker: Sir William
dialogue.text: Oh, here we are.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Ah well, they seem to have linked that themselves, so there's no need for me to interrupt at all. So, ah, back to the school hall.

dialogue.speaker: Schoolmaster
dialogue.text: 'Seven Brides for Seven Brothers'.

dialogue.speaker: Headmaster
dialogue.text: 'Tis time the seven Smith brothers had brides. Fetch me Smith Major.

dialogue.speaker: First Smith
dialogue.text: Sir.

dialogue.speaker: Headmaster
dialogue.text: 'Tis time you and your six brothers were married.

dialogue.speaker: First Smith
dialogue.text: Thank you, Headmaster.

dialogue.speaker: Headmaster
dialogue.text: Fetch me your six brothers, that the seven brothers may be together.

dialogue.speaker: Boys
dialogue.text: Behold, the seven brothers.

dialogue.speaker: Headmaster
dialogue.text: Right, I'll see Watson, Wilkins, and Spratt in my study afterwards.

dialogue.speaker: First Smith
dialogue.text: But where shall we find seven brides for seven brothers?

dialogue.speaker: Second Smith
dialogue.text: The Sabine School for Girls.

dialogue.speaker: Third Smith
dialogue.text: Yes, and it's the Annual Dance.

dialogue.speaker: Headmaster
dialogue.text: Fetch hither the seven brides for seven brothers.

dialogue.speaker: Two Girls
dialogue.text: Behold the seven brides.

dialogue.speaker: Headmaster
dialogue.text: Fetch hither the padre that the seven brides may marry the seven brothers. Fetch hither the master on duty that the seven brides may marry the seven brothers.

dialogue.speaker: Padre
dialogue.text: Sorry, I'm late, Headmaster - I've been wrestling with Plato.

dialogue.speaker: Headmaster
dialogue.text: What you do in your own time, Padre, is written on the wall in the vestry.

dialogue.speaker: Padre
dialogue.text: Right, do you four boys take these two girls to be your seven brides?

dialogue.speaker: Boys
dialogue.text: Yes, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Padre
dialogue.text: Right, go and do your prep.

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: Good morning, I'd care to purchase a chicken, please.

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: Don't come here with that posh talk you nasty, stuck-up twit.

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: A chicken, sir. Certainly.

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: Thank you. And how much does that work out to per pound, my good fellow?

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: Per pound, you slimy trollop, what kind of a ponce are you?

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: I'm sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: 4/6 a pound, sir, nice and ready for roasting.

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: I see, and I'd care to purchase some stuffing in addition, please.

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: Use your own, you great poofy poonagger!

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: Ah, certainly sir, some stuffing.

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: Oh, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: 'Oh, thank you' says the great queen like a la-di-dah poofta.

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: That's all right, sir, call again.

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: Excuse me.

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: What is it now, you great pillock?

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: Well, I can't help noticing that you insult me and then you're polite to me alternately.

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: I'm terribly sorry to hear that, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Gent
dialogue.text: That's all right. It doesn't really matter.

dialogue.speaker: Butcher
dialogue.text: Tough titty if it did, you nasty spotted prancer.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Sorry, I asked for tea. Thank you very much. Well we've had the dessert and then, and so the first item, the item on our menu of fun is the coffee. Now I did ask for tea.

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: But you just said coffee.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: No, no, that was just my announcement, just a metaphor.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: We come...look would you mind keeping it down, please...we come as - as I said just now, to the coffee.

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Here, he said it again!

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: This is Ken Clean-Air Systems, the great white hope of the British boxing world. After three fights - and only two convictions - his manager believes that Ken is now ready to face the giant American, Satellite Five.

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: The great thing about Ken is that he's almost totally stupid.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Every morning, he jogs the forty-seven miles from his two-bedroomed, eight-bathroom, six-up-two-down, three-to-go-house in Reigate, to the Government's Pesticide Research Centre at Shoreham. Nobody knows why.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs CAS
dialogue.text: Basically Ken is a very gentle, home-loving person. I remember when one of his stick insects had a knee infection. He stayed up all night rubbing it with germoline and banging its head on the table.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Oh he was such a pretty baby, always so kind and gentle. He was really considerate to his mother, and not at all the kind of person you'd expect to pulverize their opponent into a bloody mass of flesh and raw bone, spitting teeth and fragments of gum into a ring which had become one man's hell and Ken's glory.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Every morning at his little three-room semi near Reading, Ken gets up at three o'dock and goes back to bed again because it's far too early.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: At seven o'clock Ken gets up, he has a quick shower, a rub-down, gets into his track-suit, and goes back to bed again. At 7.50 every morning Ken's trainer runs the 13,000 miles from his two-room lean-to in Bangkok and gets him up.

dialogue.speaker: Trainer
dialogue.text: I used to wake Ken up with a crowbar on the back of the head. But I recently found that this was too far from his brain and I wasn't getting through to him anymore. So I now wake him up with a steel peg driven into his skull with a mallet.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: For breakfast every day, Ken places a plate of liver and bacon under his chair, and locks himself in the cupboard.

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: Well, he's having a lot of mental difficulties with his breakfasts, but this is temperament, caused by a small particle of brain in his skull, and once we've removed that he'll be perfectly all right.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: At 8.30 the real training begins. Ken goes back to bed and his trainer gets him up. At 10.30 every morning Ken arrives at what he thinks is the gym. Sometimes it's a sweetshop, sometimes it's a private house. Today its a hospital.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Urn, straight down there. Straight down there.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: For lunch Ken crouches down in the road and rubs gravel into his hair. But lunch doesn't take long. Ken's soon up on his feet and back to bed. And his trainer has to run the 49,000 miles from his two-bedroom, six-living-room tree-house in Kyoto to wake him up.

dialogue.speaker: Trainer
dialogue.text: Hello. When Ken is in a really deep sleep like this one, the only way to wake him up is to saw his head off.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: What is he like in the ring, this human dynamo, this eighteen-stone bantam weight battering-ram? We asked his sparring partner and one-time childhood sweetheart, Maureen Spencer.

dialogue.speaker: Maureen
dialogue.text: Well, I think that if Ken keeps his right up, gets in with the left jab and takes the fight to his man - well, he should go for a cut eye in the third and put Wilcox on the canvas by six.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Ken's opponent in Tuesday's fight is Petula Wilcox, the Birmingham girl who was a shorthand typist before turning pro in 1968. She's keen on knitting and likes Cliff Richard records. How does she rate her chances against Ken?

dialogue.speaker: Petula
dialogue.text: (Connie Booth) Well, I'm a southpaw and I think this will confuse him, particularly with his brain problem.

dialogue.speaker: Master of Ceremonies
dialogue.text: My lords, ladies and gedderbong... On my right, from the town of Reigate in the county of Kent, the heavyweight... Mr Ken Clean-Air Systems!... and on my left! Miss Petula Wilcox.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Type
dialogue.text: I think boxing's a splendid sport - teaches you self-defense.

dialogue.speaker: Critic
dialogue.text: Obviously boxing must have its limits, but providing they're both perfectly fit I can see nothing wrong with one healthy man beating the living daylights out of a little schoolgirl.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: It's quick and it's fun.

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: Oh, no, he's gone. But he left a message. Jack! Where's that note that fellow left?

dialogue.speaker: Jack
dialogue.text: Oh, here you are.

dialogue.speaker: Waitress
dialogue.text: It says sorry, had to catch the last bus. Am on the 49b to Babbacombe.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Oh, er, there you are. Hello. You got the note, jolly good. Well, um, that's all the items that we have for you this week and er, what a jolly nice lot of items too, eh? Um...well, the same team will be back with you again next week with another menu full of items. Um...I don't know if I shall be introducing the show next week as I understand my bits in this show have not been recieved quite as well as they might but er, never mind, the damage is done - no use in crying over spilt milk. I've had my chance and I've muffed it. Anyway, there we are. I'm not really awfully good with words. You see, I'm more of a visual performer. I have a very funny - though I say so myself - very funny funny walk. I wish I'd been in that show. I'd have done rather well. But anyway, there we are - the show's over. And...we'll all be - all be back with you again next week... Sorry. I do beg your pardon. I don't like these...displays of emotion...I wish it would say the end.

annotations: BBC world symbol
Interior of a nasty snack bar. Customers around, preferably real people. Linkman sitting at one of the plastic tables.
Animated titles.
Back to the snack bar.
(with rather forced bonhomie)

Cut to the word 'Blackmail' in letters four feet high, picked out in lightbulbs which flash on and off. Big showbiz music crashes in. Camera pulls back to reveal glittery showbiz set. A presenter in glittery showbiz jacket sits behind a glittery desk, with a telephone on it.
Cut to a slightly blurred black and white photo of a housewife with her face blotted out by a black oblong.
Cut back to presenter. He picks up a letter and reads it.
(which flashes on and off quickly)
Cut to a nude man (except for a collar and a tie) at organ. He plays a few stirring chords. Cut back to presenter.
(as he speaks he holds up the various items)
(which flashes on and off)
Cut back to nude man at organ with chords again. Cut to still of two pairs of naked feet and lower legs. Organ music over this. Cut back to presenter.

The following film is shot in murky 8mm. As the film progresses we have a £ sign with numerals in one corner which increase. Shot of a residental street in Thames Ditton (sic). Another section of a street with a figure in a Robin Hood hat and raincoat - in the distance on the far side of the road, so we can't really make him out. Cut to slightly closer shot of him about to cross the road. Cut to suburban house. The man is standing at the door pressing the bell and looking round rather furtively. Again shot from some distance and over a hedge. Cut back to studio. The presenter looking at a monitor and then at a phone. Back to the film: a woman opens the door. She wears a dressing gown over lingerie. A shaky zoom in to reveal her clothing. Wide shot of the house with door shut. Jump cut to shot obviously taken from a window in the house. Shaky zoom in on window. We can see in the window...both the man and woman enter the bedroom. He goes out of shot, taking his coat off. Cut back to studio.

Cut back to the film: even closer perhaps of window. A series of short jump cuts. She is undressing. She throws off her dressing gown. A jump and she's taking off her negligee. Underneath she wears black corsets. She produces a whip and seems to be beckoning to the man. Phone rings. Cut back to the studio. The presenter picks up the phone.
(and CAPTION:)
(he puts the phone down)

Cut to a hallway in which a middle-aged man in dinner dress is putting down the telephone rather furtively. He leaves the booth and goes through a door into a large room where a banquet is in progress. There are tables on three sides of a square and he joins the head table which faces as it were downstage. He sits beside other middle-aged and rather elderly men all of whom are the city of London ex-public school type. As he sits, the toastmaster standing behind speaks.
There is much upperclass applause and banging on the table as Sir William rises to his feet.
(hear, hear)
(shame!)
(applause)
(shame!)
As Sir William sits a meek man rises at one of the side tables.
Cries of outrage. Chairman leaps to feet.
(he pauses and thinks)
(hear, hear)

He gets right up and walks away from the table to approving noises and applause. He walks to a door at the side of the studio set and goes through it. Exterior shot: a door opens and Sir William appears out of it into the fresh air. He suddenly halts.
He turns round and disappears into the building again. He reappears through door, crosses set and goes out through another door. He appears from the door into the fresh air and then stops.
He turns and disappears through the door again. Cut to him inside the building. He crosses to a window and looks out, then turns and says...

Several members run to window and look out. Cut to film of them looking out of mindow. Cut to studio: the members run to a door and open it. Cut to film: of them appearing at the door hesitating and then closing door. Cut to studio: with increasing panic they run to the second door. Cut to film: they appear, hesitate, and go back inside. Cut to studio: they run to Sir William in the centre of the room.
Barnes and others carry a vaulting horse into shot. The members start vaulting over it. Two Gestapo officers walk by.
(donning tin helmet)
(sing)
The Gestapo officers leave. Mr Cutler runs up to Sir William.
(he stops them with a finger gesture)

A bleak landscape. A large foot with a Victorian lady on top of it comes hopping past. A door in a building opens and the society members (real people superimposed) run out, along the cartoon, and disappear, falling into nothingness. Cut to section of an oesophagus. The members (now animated cut-outs) fall down it into a stomach where they are joined by various large vegetables. Pull back to show that this is a cutaway view of an Edwardian gentleman. He belches.
He moves through a door marked 'gents'. We hear a lavatory flushing. Cut to café: linkman at table as before.
Cut to a simple set with two chairs in it. Close up of Mr Praline.
Pull back to show Brooky.
Floor manager comes in.

Praline kneels and puts his ear to the floor. In the bottom section of the shot we see beneath the floor an animation of the unfortunate members of the Society for Putting Things on Top of Other Things being flushed along a pipe.
various adventures of the Society members.
Cut back to linkman. There is a loud argument going on in the café behind him.
(to the argument)
(to camera)

Oak-panelled door with notice on it saying 'Prawn Salad Ltd'. The butler pushes it open and shows man into living room. The room is fairly large, containing at one end opposite the door a big window, making the room look quite high up - although it should be stately rather than modern. In the middle of the room's back wall there is a large ornate mirror, over a mantelpiece filled with objects. To the right of this wall there is a large bookshelf filled with books, and in front of it there is a drinks trolley.
He picks up a magazine. The mirror behind him without warning falls off the wall and smashes to the ground. The butler returns, and looks at the man enquiringly.
(disbelieving but polite)
The butler just closes the door behind him and the bookcase detaches itself from the wall and comes sweeping down, bringing with it the drinks trolley. The butler opens the door.
(politely ironic)
He goes.
A maid enters.
She hands him a dagger.

She trips, falls lethally on to the dagger he is holding. She collapses at his feet. There is blood on the dagger and his hand. He is looking down at her, when he becomes aware of a man in a green baize apron at the door, who is looking at him in horror.
(soothingly)
Green starts backing round the room away from him, but humouring him.
(backs off too far and falls backwards through the window)
(to window)
A policeman and the butler appear at the door.
(goes towards him)
(clutches chest)
(collapses)
He is about to move forward when a large portion of the ceiling collapses on him. He goes down, too.

He moves off through door. Large crashing sounds. He comes downstairs into a stretch of hall leading to an outside door. As he comes suits of armour collapse, bookcase glass smashes, a grandfather clock tips over and smashes, pictures fall off walls. All this quite quickly in sequence as he passes in horror. He gets to the main door. We see his relief. He closes the main door behind him, slamming it: it's a country-house-type entrance. Cut to stock film of country house being blown up. Cut back to man looking in horror, with dust and rubble swirling around. He is holding the remains of the door.
Pull wide. He is in a patch of rubble. The Society for Putting Things on Top of Other Things members walk by in their evening dress.
They go past the bishop in the field.
(singing)
They come to a school hall. A sign says 'Seven Brides for Seven Brothers, presented by the staff and pupils of the Dibley School for Boys'.
(they go in)
Cut to linkman in cafeteria.
A school hall with a stage. Mr Praline and Brooky enter. Praline sits at piano and plays something very badly; Brooky turns the pages for him. Music ends. Unseen schoolmaster announcer:
(slight applause)
The curtain pans. Enter headmaster in mortar board and gown.
Enter Smith Major in short pants.
Smith Major rings handbell. Three boys enter and stand next to him.
(has to be prompted, then declaims badly)
Enter two schoolgirls.
(nothing happens)
(entering)
The curtain comes across quickly.
Cut to the Grillomat in Paignton. The announcer is just handing back a cup and saucer to a waitress.
(she takes it grudgingly)
(to camera)
(waitress hands him back his cup)
She shrugs and begins to move off. At the table just behind him we hear her complaining noisily in the background.
Film of a boxer (John) in training, running along a country road. All this is shot in 'Man Alive' style: plenty of hand-held documentary work. Sound of boxer's feet on the leaves and heavy breathing.
Cut to manager being driven in Rolls.
Cut back to Ken jogging, the early morning sun filtering through the trees.
Cut to Ken's wife (a young married with her head in a scarf and curlers), hanging out the washing in a council estate.
Cut to Ken's mother - an old lady in a wheelchair. Hand-held big close-up against the sky.
The wheelchair moves away and we see that it is on top of a car. Cut to exterior of a semi-detached house. Night.
(light goes on)
Light goes out. Close-up alarm clock at 7.05. General shot of room, Ken coming out of bathroom pulling his track-suit on.
(shot of trainer running)
General shot of room to show his trainer standing over the sleeping Ken. He holds a large mallet and a steel peg.

Cut to the empty kitchen, shot from ground level. The camera pans across to show plate of food under an upright chair, and then pans across the room to the kitchen cupboard; Mrs Clean-Air Systems at the sink.
Cut to gym. Manager standing beside ropes of the ring. Again a hand-held 'Man Alive' type interview, with camera noise and all.
Close-up alarm clock. Hands at 8.30.
(General shot of room. Ken asleep in bed)

(The door bursts open but we don't stay to see what happens. We cut immediately to outside of the house. His trainer pushes Ken out. Trainer goes back into the house (obviously to Ken's wife). Cut to Ken jogging through town. Hand held. Ken finds his way blocked by a parked car. He stops and looks very puzzled, then instead of going round it turns and runs back the way he has come.)
Ken turns into the gates of a hospital. There is a slight pause, and a white-coated doctor arrives at the door and points right up the street.

Ken follows his finger and looks very hard in that direction. When he is satisfied that Ken has understood where he is pointing, the doctor retires back inside. Ken turns and watches him as he does this, then turns and sets off in the opposite direction. Cut to a shot of a roadside diner.
(Pan down to roadside to reveal Ken just finishing rubbing gravel into his hair; he stands up and hops over a railing to a riverside where a bed stands)
(Ken hops into the bed)
(Trainer runs into shot, pauses by bedside and turns to camera. He has large plumber's bag.)
Cut to stock close-up of punchbag and glove smashing into it. Continual hitting and impact-bang-bang-bang-bang throughout.
Cut to medium close-up of Maureen, very busty in boxing gear and sparring helmet.
She goes back to sparring and we see it is she who is hitting the punchbag. Remaining on her we hear the voice over.
(Cut to typical teenage girl's bedside. Pin-ups of popstars on the walls. Teddy bears on the bed and gonks. Petula Wilcox is sitting up on the bed knitting.)

Cut to the ring. Floodlight. The night of the big fight. Murmur of a huge crowd. Excitement, cigar smoke rising in front of the camera. Bustle of activity all around. In medium close-up the master of ceremonies walks out into the middle of the ring, and takes the microphone.
(unintelligible)
(applause, cut to Ken's corner; Ken raises his arms above his head)

For the first time we see Petula dance out into the middle of the ring, frail and lovely in a white muslin dress, with a bow in her hair and boxing gloves. The referee bring them together, cautions them and then they separate. The bell goes. As speeded-up as we can manage and with the same stupendous sound effects as for all-in cricket, Ken belts the hell out of Petula. While this goes on, we hear a few voice overs.

Boxing match is still in full swing as we cut away to the Grillomat snack bar. A dim light; the announcer has gone. There is only the waitress setting chairs on the tables, and cleaning. She looks up as the camera comes on her.
Cut to the top of an open-top bus driving along.
(start to roll credits over this)
(miserably)
(starting to cry)
It says 'The End'.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 45

script.description: CAPTION: 'A PARTY POLITICAL BROADCAST ON BEHALF OF THE LIBERAL PARTY'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: There now follows a Party Political Broadcast on behalf of the Liberal Party...

dialogue.speaker: Radio Voice

For a thirty-nine.year-old you wouldn't expect such speed. Normally considered slow, he's incredibly fast as he wanders aimlessly around, sweeping up and taking the defence to the cleaners. Who would have thought, though many expected it, that this remarkable forty-five-year-old, 9' 4" dwarf of a man, who is still only seventeen in some parts of the world, would ever really be ... dialogue.text: Well, harsh words there for the Garibaldi family of Droitwich in Worcestershire, at present holders of the East Midlands Most Awful Family Award - Lower Middle-Class Section but unable today to score more than fifteen on our disgustometer. Well with the scores all in from the judges, the Garibaldis are number three ... and a surprise number two ... the Fanshaw-Chumleighs of Berkshire...

dialogue.text: Well, some of the wonderful behaviour that made the Fanshaw-Chumleighs the second Most Awful Family in Britain 1974. But the winners, by a clear ten point margin, are once again the awful Jodrell family of Durham. Unfortunately, we're not allowed to show you some of the performance that won them an award, but I assure you it was of the very highest standard, was it not, Lady Organs?

dialogue.speaker: Lady Organs

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Well, thank you very much, Lady Organs ... and from all of us all, well done to the Jodrells ... and to all of you, not forgetting those of you who may be halfway in between, without whom, of course, and not forgetting who made it all possible, when, and we'll be back, until then and so it's goodnight from me and here's wishing you a safe journey home, thank you for watching this show, don't forget it was all great fun, I've enjoyed it, and I hope you watching at home have enjoyed it too.

Administrative errors are bound to occur in enormous quantities. Look at this - it's all a mistake. It's a real pain in the sphincter! Icelandic Honey Week? My Life!

And I shall inform all your relatives and friends and anyone else I bump into. OK... cash, wasn't it? Thank you very much. Get out. Dirty little man. Hmm.,. hmm ... dialogue.text: Ahhh ... couldn't ... I ... do ... it ... later, doctor!

dialogue.text: Yes, it's a hell of a nuisance all this damn paperwork, really it is... it's a real nightmare, this damned paperwork. It really is a hell of a nuisance. Something ought to be done about it.

dialogue.text: Do I have to answer all the questions, doctor?

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: No, no, no, just fill in as many as you can - no need to go into too much detail. I don't know why we bother with it all, really, it's such a nuisance. Well let's see how you've done, then... Oh dear oh dear... that's not very good, is it. Look, surely you knew number four!

dialogue.text: No ... I didn't...

dialogue.text: Oh don't worry about that! Look at this - number six - the Treaty of Versailles, Didn't you know that? Oh, my God.

dialogue.text: I'm sorry about the carpet, doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Mr Williams, I'm afraid I can't give you any marks, so I won't be able to recommend you for hospital. Tell you what - I'll stop the bleeding - but strictly speaking I shouldn't even do that on marks like these...

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: There are no more patients now, doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Oh well, let's go and have lunch, then.

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: What about... er...

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Ah yes - look, Mr Williams we're just popping out for a bite of lunch while we've got a spare moment, you know. Look, have another bash at the form... and if at least you can answer the question on history right, then we may be able to give you some morphine or something like that, OK?

dialogue.speaker: Williams
dialogue.text: Thank you, doctor, thank you.

dialogue.text: Well to be quite frank, Brigadier ... one can't walk so closely with a chap like you for... for so long without... feeling something deep down inside, even if it isn't anything... anything ... very much.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'THERE NOW FOLLOWS AN APPEAL ON BEHALF OF EXTREMELY RICH PEOPLE WHO HAVE ABSOLUTELY NOTHING WRONG WITH THEM'

dialogue.speaker: Sir Pratt
dialogue.text: Hello. I'd like to talk to you tonight about a minority group of people who have no mental or physical handicaps and, who, through no fault of their own, have never been deprived, and consequently are forced to live in conditions of extreme luxury. This often ignored minority, is very rarely brought to the attention of the general public. The average man in the street scarcely gives a second thought to these extremely well-off people. He, quite simply, fails to appreciate the pressures vast quantities of money just do not bring. Have you at home, ever had to cope with this problem... or this... or even this... I know it's only human to say, 'Oh this will never happen to me', and of course, it won't. I'm asking you, please, please, send no contributions, however large, to me.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: This is Stonehenge ... and it's from here we go to Africa.

dialogue.speaker: Attenborough
dialogue.text: Well here it is at last ... the goal of our quest. After six months and three days we've caught up with the legendary walking tree of Dahomey, Quercus Nicholas Parsonus, resting here for a moment, on its long journey south. It's almost incredible isn't it, to think that this huge tree has walked over two thousand miles across this inhospitable terrain to stop here, maybe just to take in water before the two thousand miles on to Cape Town, where it lives. It's almost unimaginable, I find - the thought of this mighty tree strolling through Nigeria, perhaps swaggering a little as it crosses the border into Zaire, hopping through the tropical rain forests, trying to find a quiet grove where it could jump around on its own, sprinting up to Zambia for the afternoon, then nipping back ... Oh, super ... well, I've just been told that this is not in fact the legendary walking tree of Dahomey, this is one of Africa's many stationary trees, Arborus Barnbet Gaseoignus. In fact we've just missed the walking tree... it left here at eight o'clock this morning... was heading off in that direction... so we'll see if we can go and catch it up. Come on boys.

dialogue.speaker: Attenborough
dialogue.text: Well, we're still keeping up with it, but it's setting a furious pace. Early this morning we thought we'd spotted it, but it turned out to be an Angolan sauntering tree, Amazellus Robin Ray, out walking with a Gambian Sidling Bush... So on we go ... it's going to be difficult - the walking tree can achieve speeds of up to fifty miles an hour, especially when it's in a hurry. Super! Well, Rupert has spotted something ... this could be it... a walking tree on the move ... But, what Rupert had in fact discovered was something very different...

dialogue.speaker: Attenborough
dialogue.text: The Turkish Little Rude Plant. This remarkably smutty piece of flora was used by the Turks to ram up each other's ... Ah no! In fact it was something even more interesting... Yes, there it was, over the other side of the clearing, the legendary Puking Tree of Mozambique...

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: No, what they had come across was a tribe lost to man since time immemorial... the legendary Batsmen of the Kalahari...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Primitive customs still survive here as if the march of time had passed them by. But for all the mumbo-jumbo and superstition, the Batsmen of the Kalahari are formidable fighters, as we can see on this rare footage of them in action against Warwickshire.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Warwickshire had dismissed the Kalahari Batsmen for 140, and then it was their turn to face this extraordinary Kalahari attack. Pratt was the first to go, but Pratt and Pratt put on a second wicket stand of nought, which was broken by Odinga in his most hostile mood.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Thats B. Pratt, hit wicket - 0. But Pratt and Z. Pratt dug in and took the score to a half... before Z. Pratt ran away. But out came M.J.K. Pratt... to play a real captain's innings. He'd taken his own score up to nought when he mistimed a shot of Bowanga and was lbw.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Typical of Umbonga's hostile opening spell was his dismissal of V.E. Pratt, who offered no resistance to this delivery... ... and he was caught behind.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: But by lunch the situation had changed dramatically.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'C.U. PRATT KILLED OUTRIGHT, BOWLED ODINGA - 0. P.B.T.R. PRATT LEGS OFF BEFORE WICKET, BOWLED ODINGA - 0. B.B.C.T.V. PRATT ASSEGAI UP JACKSEY, BOWLED UNBOKO - 0. Z. PRATT MACHETE BEFORE WICKET, 'BOWLED UMBONGA - 0. M.J.K. PRATT STUMP THROUGH HEAD, BOWLED UMBONGA - 0. V.E. PRATT RAN AWAY - 0. P.D.A. PRATT RETIRED HURT - 0. W.G. PRATT RETIRED VERY HURT - 0. PRATT DIED OF FRIGHT, BOWLED ODINGA - 0. Y.E.T.A.N.O.T.H.E.R. PRATT NOT OUT BUT DREADFULLY HURT- 139.'

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: And so with the tension colossal as we come up to the last ball ... that's all from us.

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text: Good evening. Over 400,000 million pounds were wiped off the value of shares this afternoon, when someone in the Stock Exchange coughed. Sport: capital punishment is to be re-introduced in the first and second division. Any player found tackling from behind or controlling the ball with the lower part of the arm will be hanged. But the electric chair remains the standard punishment for threatening the goalie. Referee's chairman, Len Goebbels said 'at last the referee has been given teeth'. Finally, politics: the latest opinion poll published today shows Labour ahead with 40%, the AA second with 38% and not surprisingly Kentucky Fried Chicken running the Liberals a very close third. And now back to me. Hello. And now it's time to go over to Hugh Delaney in Paignton.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Hello and welcome to Paignton, because it's from Paignton that we take you straight back to the studio.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Hello. And it's from here we go over there.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Well we're already here so let's go over there.

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text: Welcome back. And now it's time for part eight of our series about the life and work of Ursula Hifier, the Surrey housewife who revolutionized British beekeeping in the nineteen-thirties.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'THAT WAS A PARTY POLITICAL BROADCAST ON BEHALF OF THE LIBERAL PARTY'

annotations: Cut to a kitchen. Mr Garibaldi is eating a packet of 'Ano-Weet'. On the back of the packet in big letters it reads 'Free Inside - The Pope + Demonstration Record'. Kevin Garibaldi is stretched out the whole length of the sofa, eating a huge plate of baked beans. His father occasionally flaps the copy of the paper he is reading at him to clear the air. The paper is called 'The Scun' and has a pin-up on the front page with big headline 'What a Scorcher! Phew! Can Resist this Miss'; at the bottom of the page in small print 'China Declares War'. The banner across top reads 'In the Scun Today "Tits and Inflation"'. Ralph Garibaldi is sitting at the table eating. At one point he stretches across the table, and his arm sticks in the butter. He tries to clean it off and knocks the sugar over. There is a large photo of Ian Smith on the wall; built around it is a plaster shrine, with flowers in front of it. Mrs Garibaldi is ironing. She irons some underclothes, then she irons a transistor radio. Dotted about the room are a flat telephone, a flat standard lamp, and a flat cat. Valerie Garibaldi is wearing a shiny red miniskirt. She has bright yellow 'beehive' hair so stiffly lacquered that it is quite a hazard to various ornaments on the mantelpiece. She is continuously making herself up in the mantelpiece mirror which is shaped like a lavatory. The other member of the family is a very fat old dog. As we see all this, the football commentary is droning throughout on the radio.
(crackle)
By now mother has succeeded in flattening the radio with the iron. She folds it neatly and puts it on the pile.
Ralph Garibaldi knocks a bowl onto the floor. It smashes.
Kevin opens another can of beans and pours them on to his plate, throwing the tin on the floor. The radio drones on.
(he knocks the cereal box off the table)
(turning from the mirror in mid make-up)
Mother is now ironing the telephone and the cat. She irons them flat and pins them on the line.
The doorbell rings.
(she goes out)
A middle-aged man appears from the broom cupboard.
(he gets back into the cupboard again)
(he knocks the teapot on to the floor, it smashes)
Cut to the doorway in the hall. A man in a dark suit, very smart and well-dressed, is doing strange kung-fu antics.
She shuts the door on him. As she does so Mr Garibaldi shouts out to her.
(coming in again)
(he is standing beside the sink which has just split in two)
(Kevin opens another can of beans; dad notices in disgust and flaps his paper again)
(she has finally finished her startling make-up)
(coming out of the cupboard)
(he goes back in again)
Ralph knock a leg off the table. It collapses entirely.
(too fat and flatulent to get up)
The phone rings. Mrs Garibaldi answers it.
(on the phone)
(desperate but unable to move)
(The bell rings.)
(shouting to Ralph)

Ralph gets up. As he goes he knocks the leg off the old-fashioned gas cooker. It falls to one side bringing down shelves next to it, plates, crockery and a section of the wall revealing the hallway the other side.
(roaring)
A man in a Tarzan outfit, except with a postman's hat and a little mailbag, swings in on a liana shouting a jungle yell.
A gong sounds. They all stop acting.
Cut to stock film of ladies applauding.

Pull out from this stock film to see that it is on a screen in a presentation studio. A glittery compère is also applauding sycophantically at his desk, about which is the glittery slogan 'Most Awful Family in Britain, 1974. Sponsored by Heart Attacko Margarine'.
Pull out further to pick up a panel of three distinguished rather academic looking people.
Two other members of the panel nod vigorous agreement.
(he turns to the screen)

A very elegant breakfast table in beautifully tasteful surroundings. Four upper-class folk - two woman (Michael and Graham) and two men (Eric and Terry J) - are talking most incredibly loudly at each other, with quite appalling accents. An appalling din altogether. They talk just about at the same time as each other.
(etc.)
Cut back to the panel nodding thoughfully.
(hurriedly)
(during this speech we cut to the same image on a TV screen)

He is switched off, and fades into a dot. Pull back to reveal that the TV which has just been switched off is in a dirty old sitting room in which all the characters are really unpleaant pepperpots. They are dressed more or less identically, except that son has a school cap and a blazer over his pepperpot gear. He has a satchel and National Health glasses. The father has moustache and glasses and a Fair-Isle jersey.
A cat set into the wall, i.e. a glove puppet, screeches as if someone had pulled its tail outside.
(to the cat)
(she slaps it; it expires)
She takes a couple of milk bottles out. Standing on the doorstep is a man with a Nordic accent in female national costume. He has a tray labeled 'Icelandic Honey Week'
They slam the door on him. Someone rather like Jeremy Thorpe looks round the door and waves as they do so.
Animated titles. Then cut to a drawing of Indians attacking a fort. Music: 'The Big Country' theme.
(and superimposed roller caption:)
Cut to a doctor's surgery. It has a wall shrine with a photo of Christiaan Barnard with flowers and candles in front of it. The doctor is talking to an embarrassed-looking man.
(he hands him card three feet long which reads 'For Special Treatment')
(the man hands him over wad of fivers)
(the man gets up to go)
(he picks up big text book entitled 'Medical Practice' and flicks through the pages)
An out-of-vision scream. A man staggers in clutching his bleeding stomach. Lots of blood pours out of him throughout the scene.
(obviously fatally wounded)
(he hands him a form)
With great effort he releases one of his hands from his bleeding stomach.
(he gets up and strolls around fairly unconcerned)
(Williams half collapses)
(bleeding profusely)
(gives Williams a look)
The nurse enters with a smoking revolver.
She exits, taking a sword from the wall. Through the next bit of the scene we hear screams off.
The nurse enters covered in blood.
(she points to Williams who is lying on the floor gurgling by this time)

Cut to a large country house sitting more, dominated by large grinning portrait of Jeremy Thorpe. A bishop is sitting at a desk, typing. A brigadier in full military uniform just to below the chest, then a patch of bare midriff, with belly button showing, then a lavender tutu, incredibly hairy leg, thick army socks and high heels, is dictating.
Cut to an animation sketch.
(and CAPTION:)
(at a large leather-topped desk with an elaborate table lamp)
(cut to a rich young yachting type surrounded by girls in bikinis)
(cut to a rich woman loading her chauffeur with all kinds of expensive parcels)
(cut to a still of Centre Point)

We see the last bit on a TV in Mrs What- a- long- name- this- is- hardly- worth- typing- but- never- mind- it- doesn't- come- up- again's living- room. Ding-dong of doorbell. A cupboard door opens, and the middle-aged man we saw in first scene comes out. He has no iguana on his shoulder.

She turns it off. The TV set just folds up as if empty and collapses on to the floor. Dust rises. She goes into the hallway to the front door (singing 'Anything Goes' by the other Cole Porter to herself) and opens it. A man with a briefcase stands there.
(comes in)
(they go through into the sitting room)
(he sits)
(with self-wonder)
(hesitantly)
(with growing confidence)
(faster)
(completely confident now)
Mrs Long Name leaves. Mr Vernon shuts the door. A girl's voice comes from sitting room.

Cut to exterior of Mrs Long Name's house. She comes out and sets off purposefully up the road, passing four pepperpot nannies digging up the road. They are wearing the usual slippers, paisley dresses and knotted handkerchief. One wears a helmet. One works a pneumatic drill. She is stripped to the waist wearing a big pink bra. Behind, heroic shots of Mrs Long Name walking out of town, through suburbs, into neat country, then into wilder country. She finally stops in close up, and looks up with inspiration in her eyes.
Cut to a linkman standing before Stonehenge.
Jeremy Thorpe appears at the edge of shot and waves.

Cut to an as overgrown, jungleoid location as Torquay can provide. A very big thick tree in the foreground. David Attenborough pushes through jungle towards camera. He has damp sweat patches under his arms which grow perceptibly during the scene. He has two African guides in the background both with saxophones round their neck.
(slapping the side of a tree)
(a native whispers in his ear)

They move off. At this point we notice that there are two other saxophone-wearing natives, a trumpeter, a trombonist, a double bassist, a guitarist, and finally a man with a drum kit tied to his back. Mix through to them on the move in another pan of the jungle. Sweat is now spraying out from under Attenborough's armpits as if from a watering can.
(Jeremy Thorpe leans in the background and waves to camera)
(Rupert the bearer points excitedly)
(they move off, by this time waterspray is gushing out from all over his chest)

He stops him, they kneel down. Cut to their eyeline. In the distance, amongst low bushes and thick undergrowth, six Africans dressed immaculately in cricket gear having a game of cricket. Cut to Attenborough, Rupert and one other bearer watching. Attenborough is looking down at something he is holding. The other two are gazing wide-eyed at the cricketers.
(he holds up, carefully and wondrously, a plant which has green outer leaves splayed back to reveal a small, accurately sculpted bum)
(Rupert nudges him and points excitedly at the batsmen)
(Attenborough points, apparently at the batsmen, but he has clearly got it wrong again)
(Rupert nudges him again)
Cut to an animated professor.
(cut to a shot of natives playing cricket)
Cut to a big county ground pavilion in mid-shot. We zoom in on the commentator on a balcony.

A compilation of the day's play. Natives in normal cricket gear. Pratt at crease as per usual cricket coverage. Cut to a low shot of the bowler thundering up towards the wicket. Cut away to the batsman preparing to take the shot. Cut back to the bowler. As he reaches the crease he produces a spear and raises it to shoulder height and hurls it. Cut to batsman who is hit full in the stomach. His bat dislodges the bails. There is a 'howzat' from all the native fielders. He makes an annoyed gesture as if he were Colin Cowdrey caught clean bowled, and sinks to the ground.
(cut to the new batting partnership; B. Pratt's body is still on the ground)
(Z. Pratt reaching the pavilion, running with a hail of spears and arrows coming after him)
(cut to M.J.K. Pratt coming out pulling on gloves etc.)
(he reaches the crease and takes guard, the bowler bowls)
(a huge spear sticks right through the lower part of his leg; they appeal and he turns and limps manfully off)
(cut to native bowler bowling a machete; it hits the ground and does a leg spin up, slicing off the batsman's head as he waves his bat)
The batsman's severed head lands in the wicket keeper's gloves. He throws it in the air with a flourish.
Jeremy Thorpe appears and waves.
Cut to the presenter from 'World' s Most Awful Family 1974'.
(and CAPTION:)
Cut back to the presenter. Behind him the 'Worlds Most Awful Family' sign is crossed out and replaced with 'Sport'.
Roll credits on black background. The first part of the signature tune is played very hesitantly on guitar.
Nine O'clock News intro in the newsroom behind. Behind the newsreader several men including Jeremy Thorpe are drinking and celebrating. A woman is dancing on the table.
Cut to the linkman on the pier at Paignton. A smallish crowd is gathered behind him including Jerermy Thorpe who waves at the camera from the back.
Cut to a man in swimming trunks and a snorkel pushed back on his head standing in the studio holding a stuffed polecat on a pole.
Cut to the 'Most Awful Family' presenter.
Cut back to the newsreader.
(and CAPTION:)
His voice breaks up with giggles. Fade to blackout. The end.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 44

dialogue.speaker: Scrap Man
dialogue.text: Let's bring 'em out! Any old iron! Any old iron!

dialogue.speaker: Scrap Man
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: GPO Official
dialogue.text: We are here today to witness the opening of a new to replace the which used to stand at the corner of Ulverston Road and Sandwood Crescent. Owing to the road-widening programme carried out by the Borough Council, the Ulverston Road was removed, leaving the wall in Esher Road as the only for the Ulverston Road area. This new will enable the people of the Ulverston Road area to post letters, post-cards and small packages without recourse to the Esher Road or to the outside the post office at Turner's Parade which many people used to use, but which has now been discontinued owing to the opening of this and also the re-organization of distribution throughout the whole area, which comes into force with the opening of new at the Wyatt Road Post Office in July. Nous sommes ici ce matin pour loire témoin à l'ouvermre de la nouvelle pour remplacer la qui autrefois était placée au coin d'Ulverston Road et Sandwood Crescent. Parce que du projet pour l'élargissement de la rue qui fait par le Borough Council, la dans Ulverston Road est remplacée, et la de mur dans Esher Road, est la seule pour le région d'Ulverston Road. Cette nouvelle rendra capables les hommes d'Ulverston Road de mettre dans les poste les lettres, les carte-postales, et des petits paquets sans avant besoin de la de mur dans Esher Road, ou les de la Turner's Parade bureau de poste, qui beaucoup des hommes ont fait usage mais qui est maintenant disconfinuée parce que l'ouverture de cette ici, et le réorganisation régionale que commence avec l'ouverture des boîtes au bureau de poste en Wyatt Road le juillet. Wir kommen hier heute Morgen für die Einfang auf dem neue Kabinett für die Poste.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: A perfectly ordinary morning in a perfectly ordinary English suburb. Life goes on as it has done for years.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But soon this quiet pattern of life was to change irrevocably. The commonplace routine of a typical Monday morning would never be the same again, for into this quiet little community came ... Mr Neutron!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Mr Neutron! The most dangerous and terrifying man in the world! The man with the strength of an army! The wisdom of all the scholars in history! The man who had the power to destroy the world. Mr Neutron. No one knows what strange and distant planet he came from, or where he was going to!... Wherever he went, terror and destruction were sure to follow.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Mr Neutron! The man whose incredible power has made him the most feared man of all time... waits for his moment to destroy this little world utterly!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Entrail
dialogue.text: Then there's Stanley ... he's our eldest ... he's a biochemist in Sutton. He's married to Shirley...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: Shirley who used to be the hairdresser?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Entrail
dialogue.text: Yes, that's right, I think she's a lovely person. My husband doesn't ... he thinks she's a bit flash.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Entrail
dialogue.text: I hate 'er! I hate 'er guts.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Entrail
dialogue.text: And they, of course, they come down most weekends, so you'll be able to meet them then.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: l'd ... love ... to. Hairdressing is very interesting.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Entrail
dialogue.text: And very important, too. If you don't care for your scalp, you get rabies. Then there's Kenneth, he's our youngest. Mind you, he's a bit of a problem... at least my husband thinks he is, anyway.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Entrail
dialogue.text: Nasty little piece of work, he is, I hate him!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Entrail
dialogue.text: Mind you, the one we hear so much about nowadays is Karen. She married a Canadian - he's a dentist - they live in Alberta - two lovely children, Gary who's three, Leslie who's six. They look like the spitting image of Karen. D'you want to see a photo ... ?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: Oh, yes please.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Entrail
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Entrail
dialogue.text: They're a couple of little bastards. I hate 'em. They've got eyes like little pigs, just like their mother. She's a disaster ... a really horrible-looking person, she is. I thought that one would stay on the shelf, but along comes this stupid dentist git. He's a real creepy little bastard, he is. I hate 'im.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: This is a nice area.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Entrail
dialogue.text: It's like a bloody graveyard. I hate it.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: It's handy for the shops and convenient for the West End.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Entrail
dialogue.text: If you like going to the West End. I think it's a stinking dump.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Meanwhile in Washington, at the headquarters of 'FEAR' - the Federal Egg Answering Room - in reality a front name for 'FEEBLE' - the Free World Extra-Earthly Bodies Location and Extermination Centre... all was not well.

dialogue.speaker: Captain Carpenter
dialogue.text: Good God! Get me the Supreme Commander Land, Sea and Air Forces, immediately!

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Hello?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: This is Captain Carpenter sir, from FEAR.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: You mean FEEBLE?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yes, sir ...

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Mr Neutron is missing, sir!

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Mr Neutron! Oh my God! OK - Surround the entire city! Send in four waves of armed paratroopers with full ground-to-air missile support! Alert all air bases! Destroy all roads! We'll bomb the town flat if we have to!

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Sir! Sir! He's not in Washington, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: OK! Hold everything! Hold everything! Hold it! Lay off! Lay off... Where is he?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: We don't know, sir ... all we know is he checked out of his hotel and took a bus to the airport.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: All right! I want a full-scale Red Alert throughout the world! Surround everyone with everything we've got! Mobilize every fighting unit and every weapon we can lay our hands on! I want... I want three full-scale global nuclear alerts with every army, navy and air force unit on eternal standby!

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Right, sir!

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: And introduce conscription!

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yes, sir!

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Right!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: So the world was in the grip of FEAR! A huge and terrifying crisis generated by one man! ... easily the most dangerous man the world has ever seen, honestly. Though still biding his time, he could strike at any moment. Could he be stopped in time?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Smailes
dialogue.text: You've got a bit of work to do there, then.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: Yes, it is a problem.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Smailes
dialogue.text: Mrs Ottershaw never used to bother ... then of course she was very old... she was 206! Well, must be going... if you need any help I'll send Frank round. He could do with a bit of'exercise, ha! ha! ha! ha! ... Fat old bastard...

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Captain Carpenter here, sir. We've been on red alert now for three days, sir, and still no sign of Mr Neutron.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Have we bombed anywhere? Have we shown 'em we got ?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Oh yes, sir. We've bombed a lot of places flat, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Good. Good. We don't want anyone to think we're chicken.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Oh no! They don't think that, sir. Everyone's really scared of us, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Of us?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yes, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Of our power?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Oh yes, sir! They're really scared when they see those big planes come over.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Wow! I bet they are. I bet they are. I bet they're really scared.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Oh they are, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Do we have any figures on how scared they are?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: No ... no figures, sir. But they sure were scared.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Ah! But it's not working?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: No, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: OK. We'll try another tactic. We'll try and out-smart this Neutron guy. Yes, there's one man who could nail him.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: One guy? That won't frighten anyone, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: He's the most brilliant man I ever met. We were in the CIA together. He's retired now. He breeds rabbits up in the Yukon... '

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: What's his name, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: His name is Teddy Salad.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Salad as in... ?

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Lettuces, cucumber, radishes. Yeah, yeah, yeah.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Where do I find him, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: The Yukon. Oh, and Carpenter ...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yes, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: Make sure you get a decent disguise.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Oh, hello. My name's Carpenter. I'm from the US Government.

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: Are you from the army?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Er... no... I'm... er... I'm... I'm from the ballet. The US Government Ballet.

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: The ballet! The ballet's coming here?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Well maybe...

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: Oh, that's great! We love the ballet. Last year some of us from Yellow River got a party to go see the ballet in Montreal.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Look, I was wondering...

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: Oh, we had a time. It was Margot Fonteyn dancing 'Les Sylphides'... oh, it was so beautiful...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Do you know...

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: Do you know how old she is?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Who?

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: Margot Fonteyn.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: She's 206!

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Look, I hear there's a US organizer round these parts by the name of Teddy Salad.

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: You mean the special agent?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Well...

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: He's an ex-CIA man. He's not a ballet dancer.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Well, I just want to see him on some ballet business...

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: Well, you could try the store...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Oh, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Lumberjack
dialogue.text: Hey! Can you get us Lionel Blair's autograph?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: While precious time was being lost in Canada, the seconds were ticking away for the free world...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Already Neutron - who, you will remember, is infinitely the most dangerous man in the world, he is - was gathering allies together.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: Try having an omelette for your evening meal... perhaps with yogurt and grapefruit.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Smailes
dialogue.text: Oh, I've tried that ... I once got down to fifty-six stone. But I couldn't stay like that. I used to take potatoes wherever I went. I used to go to the cinema with three hundredweight of King Edwards, I'd eat 'em all before I got out of the toilet. I had to go on to bread.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: What about salad?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Smailes
dialogue.text: Teddy Salad?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: No, no, no - salad - as in lettuces, radishes, cucumber...

dialogue.speaker: Italian
dialogue.text: You don't like it?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: No, I didn't want to a salad. I wanted to find out about a man called Salad.

dialogue.speaker: Italian
dialogue.text: You're the first person to order a salad for two years. All the Eskimos eat here is fish, fish ...

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: We're Eskimos.

dialogue.speaker: Second Eskimo
dialogue.text: Where's our fish. We've finished our fish.

dialogue.speaker: Italian
dialogue.text: What fish you want today, uh?

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: Bream please.

dialogue.speaker: Italian
dialogue.text: Bream! Where do I get a bream this time of year? You bloody choosy Eskimo pests.

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: We are Eskimos!

dialogue.speaker: Italian
dialogue.text: Why don't you like a nice plate of canelloni?

dialogue.speaker: Eskimos
dialogue.text: Eurrrrghhh!

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: That's not fish.

dialogue.speaker: Italian
dialogue.text: I've had my lot of the Arctic Circle. I wish I was back in Oldham ...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Do any of you Eskimos ... speak ... English?

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: We're not Eskimos!

dialogue.speaker: Third Eskimo
dialogue.text: I am.

dialogue.speaker: Others
dialogue.text: Sh!

dialogue.speaker: Italian
dialogue.text: Haddock!

dialogue.speaker: Eskimos
dialogue.text: Where?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Do any of... you ... know... a man ... called ... Salad?

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: What, Salad as in...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Lettuce, cucumbers, tomatoes ... yes.

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: Like you have on your plate?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yes. That's right.

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: No, I'm afraid not.

dialogue.speaker: Second Eskimo
dialogue.text: Where's our fish?

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: What does this Teddy Salad do?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: He's a... er... hen-teaser.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Che cosa è la stucciacatori di polli?

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: No, the only Teddy Salad we know is a CIA man.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Oh, he might know.

dialogue.speaker: Eskimos
dialogue.text: Gunga gunga, where's our fish?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Where will I find him?

dialogue.speaker: Second Eskimo
dialogue.text: Oh, he lives up at Kipper Sound.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Thanks a lot.

dialogue.speaker: Eskimos
dialogue.text: Fishy fishy iyoooiyooo.

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: Are you in international spying, too?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: No... no... I'm with the... US Ballet... force... who are you with?

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: MI6. But not a word to the Eskimos.

dialogue.speaker: Eskimos
dialogue.text: Fishy fishy igooo.

dialogue.speaker: Italian
dialogue.text: Here's your bloody fish.

dialogue.speaker: First Eskimo
dialogue.text: Thank you, Anouk.

dialogue.speaker: Italian
dialogue.text: I'm not an Eskimo!

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Hey! Hey!

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Hi! I'm Carpenter of the US Ballet.

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: Hey, great to have you around. The last decent ballet we got around here was Ballet Ramben..On Thursday they did 'Petrouchka', then on Saturday they did 'Fille Mal Gardée'. I thought it was a bit slow...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: It sure is nice to see you, Mr Salad.

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: I ain't Salad.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: You want Teddy Salad?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yeah ... I don't see anyone.

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: The one on the end, on the right. That's Salad.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: That's a dog!

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: No only of it.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: Listen, Teddy Salad is the most brilliant agent the CIA ever had, right?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: That's how he made his name - disguise!

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: That's incredible!

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: He had to slim down to one and a half pounds to get into that costume. He cut eighteen inches off each arm and over three feet off each leg. The most brilliant surgeon in Europe stuck that tail on.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: What about the head?

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: All of the head was removed apart from the eyes and the brain in order to fit into the costume.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: That's incredible!

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: D'you want to talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: OK, let's move over to those trees over there... anyone might be watching.

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: Mr Salad? ... There's Mr Carpenter to see you.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: What does he say?

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: Do you have a bone? It's all part of the disguise OK, Teddy... here's the bone. All right, you've got his trust, now, you can talk to him.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Sir ... sir ... Mr Salad ... sir, I've come direct from the Commander of Land, Sea and Air Forces ... There's a pretty dangerous situation, sir. Mr Neutron... is missing. The General says you're the only one who'll know where to find him ... What's he say?

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: He wants to go walkies.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Walkies?

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: Yeah, he's right into it today - d'you mind taking him for walkies?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: While Carpenter took the most brilliant agent the CIA ever had for walkies, events in the world's capitals were moving fast!

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: The Secretary of State to see you, Prime Minister.

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: Very well, show him in.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: Prime Minister.

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: Do take a seat.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: Prime Minister, we've just had the Supreme Commander US Forces on the phone. Apparently they want a full-scale Red Alert!

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: They what?

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: They want a full-scale Red Alert - every troop movement...

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: It's all right - don't worry about Giuseppe... He's English really.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: Well apparently the whole structure of world peace may be threatened unless we immediately...

dialogue.speaker: Giuseppe
dialogue.text: Your anniversary, signore?

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: No, no, Giuseppe - not now.

dialogue.speaker: Giuseppe
dialogue.text: You mean zis isn't ze lady?

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Giuseppe
dialogue.text: Oh, signora ... my mistake! I play for you 'My Mistake'. 'My mistake, I have made my mistake! What a dreadful mistake! Is this mistake that I make!' 'Oh my mistake...'

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: Giuseppe, do you mind playing over there.

dialogue.speaker: Giuseppe
dialogue.text: Very well, signor. But I play only for you... and your beautiful companion.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: Well anyway, this Mr Neutron, is located somewhere in the London area. We must find and exterminate him. The Americans say if we don't, they will.

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: The Americans say if we won't will!

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: That he doesn't know ?

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: They'll bomb the entire London area.

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: We'd better get out of here!...

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: They won't bomb .

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: Are you sure?

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: Sure.

dialogue.speaker: Prime Minister
dialogue.text: Right. When are they going to start?

dialogue.speaker: Secretary of State
dialogue.text: Well apparently they haven't got Neutron yet... but when they do...

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: Well. Did he tell you anything?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: No ... we chased sticks ... we chased a few reindeer...

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: You been chasing reindeer, have you? You're a naughty boy... yes... ain't you a naughty boy...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Look, we haven't got much time ... He hasn't given me any information yet...

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: OK. Tell you what, let's eat. You give him one of your meatballs, he'll tell you anything... OK?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: OK.

dialogue.speaker: Trapper
dialogue.text: Wait a minute - he's trying to tell us something.

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: Carpenter ... er ... ugh ... ah...Carpenter...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yes, Mr Salad? Can you hear me?

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: Yes... yes... it's just it's so goddam painful in here... what's the problem?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: It's Mr Neutron, sir ... he's gone missing. The Supreme Commander wants you to take charge.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yes, Mr Salad?

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: I gotta go walkies again.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Still no sign of Captain Carpenter, sir... or Mr Neutron.

dialogue.speaker: Commander
dialogue.text: OK. We'll bomb Neutron out. Get me Moscow! Peking! and Shanklin, Isle of Wight!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And so the Great Powers and the people of Shanklin, Isle of Wight, drew their net in ever-tightening circles around the most dangerous threat to peace the world has ever faced. They bombed Cairo, Bangkok, Cape Town, Buenos Aires, Harrow, Hammersmith, Stepney, Wandsworth and Enfield... But always it was the wrong place.

dialogue.speaker: Loudspeaker
dialogue.text: Sorry Enfield!... We apologize for any inconvenience caused by our bombing... sorry...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But what of Mr Neutron, the most fearfully dangerous man in the world! The man who could destroy entire galaxies with his wrist, the man who could tear fruit machines apart with his eyeballs... He had not been idle!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: In fact he had fallen in love... with the lady who 'does' for Mrs Entrail...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh 'ello Mr N, terrible about Enfield, innit? It's all gone. So's Staines ... lovely shops they used to have in Staines... and Stunmore, where the AA offices used to be. I don't know where we'll pay our AA subscriptions to now. Do you know where we'll have to pay our AA. subscriptions to now, Mr N?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: I didn't know you were a member of the AA Mrs S.C.U.M.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh yes. Ever since the Corsair broke down in Leyonstone ... they towed it all the way to Deauville FOC. Free of Charge. Well my husband Ken, K.E.N., he said...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: Oh, forget about your husband, Mrs S.C.U.M. - or may I call you Mrs S?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: You can call me Linda, if you like.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: No, I'd rather call you Mrs S.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: And you can call me Mr N.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Well... that's what I was calling you.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: Mrs S, there is something I have to tell you...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Yes, Mr N?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: I have just won a Kellogg's Corn Flake Competition.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh Mr N! That's wonderful!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: I got the ball in exactly the right place. The prize is £5,000 in cash, or as much ice cream as you can eat.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: I was thinking of taking the ice cream.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh no!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: It's been so hot recently.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: You couldn't eat that much ice cream Mr N.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: Mrs S, I can eat enormous quantifies of ice cream without being sick.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh no! Take the £5,000! Please take the £5,000.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: I was thinking. If we got married...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh yes!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: We could use the £5,000 to buy a spoon...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh! We could buy a lot more than that!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: And then fill up with ice cream.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: No! Forget about the ice cream. We need the money.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: We need nothing. For there is something I have not told you Mrs S.C.U.M.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh please call me Mrs S.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: No I would rather go back to calling you Mrs S.C.U.M., Mrs S.C.U.M. I am the most powerful man in the universe. There is nothing I cannot do.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh Mr N.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: I want you to be my helpmate. As Tarzan had his Jane, as Napoleon had his Josephine, as Frankie Laine had whoever he had, I want you to help me in my plan to dominate the world!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Scum
dialogue.text: Oh Mr N. That I should be so lucky!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Neutron
dialogue.text: You're not Jewish are you?

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: Another time when I was in Cairo, I was disguised as a water hydrant. The whole top part of my head had been removed and...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Please, Mr Salad .... you must tell us where Neutron is.

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: And I functioned! D'you hear? I really worked. I could put out a fire.

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Please, Mr Salad...

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: Mind you, it hurt a bit...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Please, Mr Salad - there isn't much time. Where will we find Neutron?

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: OK. Give me another meatball and I'll tell you.

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: OK listen carefully... I won't repeat this. You understand?

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: Yes yes - quick.

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: I know where Neutron is right now. I know the exact address and the exact house and the exact road...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: OK where is he?

dialogue.speaker: Dog
dialogue.text: He's not in America...

dialogue.speaker: Carpenter
dialogue.text: No?

dialogue.speaker: Dog
