dialogue.speaker: Wingco
dialogue.text: Yes!

dialogue.speaker: Bovril
dialogue.text: Bend an ear to the Squadron Leader's banter for a sec, would you?

dialogue.speaker: Wingco
dialogue.text: Can do.

dialogue.speaker: Bovril
dialogue.text: Jolly good.

dialogue.speaker: Wingco
dialogue.text: Fire away.

dialogue.speaker: Squadron Leader
dialogue.text: Bally Jerry...pranged his kite...right in how's yer father...hairy blighter...dicky-birdied...feathered back on his Sammy...took a waspy...flipped over on his Betty Harper's and caught his in the ...

dialogue.speaker: Wingco
dialogue.text: ...No, don't understand that banter at all.

dialogue.speaker: Squadron Leader
dialogue.text: Something up with my banter, chaps?

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: Bunch of monkeys on the ceiling, sir! Grab your egg and fours and let's get the bacon delivered!

dialogue.speaker: Wingco
dialogue.text: Do you understand that?

dialogue.speaker: Squadron Leader
dialogue.text: No, didn't get a word of it.

dialogue.speaker: Wingco
dialogue.text: Sorry old man, we don't understand your banter.

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: You know...bally ten-penny ones dropping in the custard... un...Charlie Choppers chucking a handful...

dialogue.speaker: Wingco
dialogue.text: No, no...sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Bovril
dialogue.text: Say it a bit slower, old chap.

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: Slower , sir?

dialogue.speaker: Wingco
dialogue.text: Ra-ther!

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: Um...sausage squad up the blue end?

dialogue.speaker: Squadron Leader
dialogue.text: No, still don't get it.

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: Um...cabbage crates coming over the briny?

dialogue.speaker: Squadron Leader
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Others
dialogue.text: No, no....

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But by then it was too late. The first cabbage crates hit London on July the 7th. That was just the beginning.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Five shillings a dozen? That's ordinary cabbages, is it? And what about the bombs?... Good Lord, they expensive.

dialogue.speaker: Corporal
dialogue.text: Sir!

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Yes, what is it?

dialogue.speaker: Corporal
dialogue.text: News from the Western Front, sir.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Yes ... ?

dialogue.speaker: Corporal
dialogue.text: Big enemy attack at dawn, sir ...

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Yes ... ?

dialogue.speaker: Corporal
dialogue.text: Well, the enemy were all wearing little silver halos, sir ... and ... they had fairy wands with big stars on the end ... and ...

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: They what ... ?

dialogue.speaker: Corporal
dialogue.text: .. and ... they had spiders in matchboxes, sir.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Good God! How did our chaps react?

dialogue.speaker: Corporal
dialogue.text: Well, they were jolly interested, sir. Some of them ... I think it was the 4th Armoured Brigade, sir, they ... well, they went and had a look at the spiders, sir.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Oh my God! All right, thank you, Shirley.

dialogue.speaker: Corporal
dialogue.text: Sir!

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Get me the Prime Minister. Not that quickly! Gentlemen, it's now quite apparent that the enemy are not only fighting this war on the cheap, but they're also not taking it seriously.

dialogue.speaker: Ageing General
dialogue.text: Bastards ...

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: First they drop cabbages instead of decent bombs ...

dialogue.speaker: Corporal
dialogue.text: The crates were probably quite expensive, sir.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Quiet, critic! And now they're doing very silly things in one of the most vital areas of the war!

dialogue.speaker: Ageing General
dialogue.text: What are we going to do, Shirley?

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Well, we've got to act fast before it saps morale. We're going to show these Chinese ...

dialogue.speaker: Captain
dialogue.text: Germans, sir.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: These Germans ... we're going to show them that no British soldier will descend to their level. Anyone found trivialising this war will face the supreme penalty that military law can provide. That was all right, I think?

dialogue.speaker: Captain
dialogue.text: Seemed to go quite well.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Sapper Walters, you stand before this court accused of carrying on the war by other than warlike means - to wit, that you did on April 16th, 1942, dress up as a bag of dainties, flick wet towels at the enemy during an important offensive ...

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: Well, sir ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Shut up! Colonel Fawcett for the prosecution ...

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Sir, we all know ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: I'm sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Carry on.

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Sir, we all know the facts of this case; that Sapper Walters, being in possession of expensive military equipment, to wit one Lee Enfield .303 rifle and 72 rounds of ammunition, valued at a hundred and forty pounds three shillings and sixpence, chose instead to use wet towels to take an enemy command post in the area of Basingstoke ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Basingstoke? Basingstoke in Hampshire?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: No, no, no, sir, no.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: I see, carry on.

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: The result of his action was that the enemy ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Basingstoke ?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Basingstoke in Westphalia, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Oh I see. Carry on.

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: The result of Sapper Walters's action was that the enemy received wet patches upon their trousers and in some cases small red strawberry marks upon their thighs ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: I didn't know there a Basingstoke in Westphalia.

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: It's on the map, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: What map?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: The map of Westphalia as used by the army, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Well, I've certainly never heard of Basingstoke in Westphalia.

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: It's a municipal borough sir, twenty-seven miles north-north east of Southhampton. Its chief manufactures ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: What ... Southhampton in Westphalia?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Yes sir ... bricks ... clothing. Nearby are remains of Basing House, burned down by Cromwell's cavalry in 1645 ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Who compiled this map?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Cole Porter, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Cole Porter ... who wrote `Kiss Me Kate'?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: No, alas not, sir ... this was Cole Porter who wrote `Anything Goes'. Sir, I shall seek to prove that the man before this court ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: That's the same one! `In olden days a glimpse of stocking ...'

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: I your pardon, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: `In olden days a glimpse of stocking, was looked on as something shocking, now heaven knows, anything goes ...'

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: No, this one's different, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: How does it go?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: What, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: How does `Anything Goes' go?

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: Can I go home now?

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Shut up! Come on!

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Sir, really, this is rather ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Come on, how does your `Anything Goes' go?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Anything goes in. Anything goes out! Fish, bananas, old pyjamas, Mutton! Beef! and Trout! Anything goes in ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: No, that's not it ... carry on.

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: With respect sir, I shall seek to prove that the man before you in the dock being in the possession of the following: one pair of army boots, value three pounds seven and six, one pair of serge trousers, value two pounds three and six, one pair of gaiters value sixty-eight pounds ten shillings, one ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Sixty-eight pounds ten shillings for a pair of ?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: They were special gaiters, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: gaiters?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Yes, sir, they were made in France. One beret costing fourteen shillings, one pair of ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: What was special about them?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Oh ... they were made of a special fabric, sir. The buckles were made of empire silver instead of brass. The total value of the uniform was there ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Why was the accused wearing special gaiters?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: They were a presentation pair sir, from the regiment. The total value of the uniform ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Why did they present him with a special pair of gaiters?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Sir, it seems to me totally irrelevant to the case whether the gaiters were presented to him or not, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: I think the court will be able to judge that for themselves. I want to know why the regiment presented the accused with a special pair of gaiters.

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: He ... used to do things for them. The total value ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: What things?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: He .. he used to oblige them, sir. The total value ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: them?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Yes, sir. The total value of the uniform ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: How did he oblige them?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: What sir?

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: How did he them?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: He ... um ... used to make them happy in little ways, sir. The total value of the uniform could therefore not have been less than ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Did he touch them at all?

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Sir! I submit that this is totally irrelevant.

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: I want to know how he made them happy.

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: He used to ram things up their ...

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: All right! All right! No need to spell it out! What er ... what has the accused to say?

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: What, me?

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Yes. What have you got to say?

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: What can say? I mean, how can I encapsulate in mere words my scorn for any military solution? The fultility of modern warfare? And the hypocrisy by which contemporary government applies one standard to violence within the community and another to violence perpetrated by one community upon another?

dialogue.speaker: Defense Counsel
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, but my client has become pretentious. I will say in his defense that he has suffered ...

dialogue.speaker: Fawcett
dialogue.text: Sir! We haven't finished the prosecution!

dialogue.speaker: Presiding General
dialogue.text: Shut up! I'm in charge of this court. Stand up! Sit down! Go moo! See? Right, now, on with the pixie hats! And order in the skating vicar.

dialogue.speaker: Everyone
dialogue.text: Anything goes in. Anything goes out! Fish, bananas, old pyjamas, Mutton! Beef! and Trout! Anything goes in. Anything goes out.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Yes! Coming to this cinema soon! The tender compassionate story of one man's love for another man in drag. THRILL! to the excitement of a night emission over Germany.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: When the pilot, Jennifer has to choose between his secret love for Louis, the hot-bloodedly bi-sexual navigator and Andy, the rear gunner, who, though quite assertive with girls, tends to take the submissive role in his relationships with men. And sensational Mexican starlet, Rosetta Nixon, plays the head of bomber command, whose passion for sea-birds ends in tragedy. With Ginger, as the half-man, half-woman, parrot whose unnatural instincts brought forbidden love in the aviary. And Roger as Pip, the half-parrot, half-man, half-woman, three-quarter badger, ex-bigamist negro preacher, for whom banjo-playing was very difficult, and he never mastered it although he took several courses and went to banjo college ... er ... and everything ... don't miss it!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Elizabeth III
dialogue.text: Yes, repeats or war films. It really makes you want to micturate.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: People on television treat the general public like idiots.

dialogue.text: Well we idiots.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: Oh no we are !

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Elizabeth III
dialogue.text: Well am.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: How do you know you're an idiot?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Elizabeth III
dialogue.text: Oh, I can show you!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: How?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Elizabeth III
dialogue.text: Look!

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: You see the public idiots ... Yes ... you might just as well show them the last five miles of the M2 ... they'd watch it, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: At last they done been put on something interesting.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Elizabeth III
dialogue.text: Oh, most interesting.

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: ... and our figures show that the motorways are extremely popular. I mean, last time we showed a repeat of the Leicester bypass our ratings gave us 97,300,912, and ITV nought. So I do feel we ought to give B roads their own series.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: I'm sorry ... we just can't give you a bigger budget.

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: Budgie?

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: No, he's left I think. Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: We're not the only slice of the cake, you know.

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: Wouldn't mind a slice of cake. Nice chocolate cake ... delicious ...

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: I had a budgie once you know, amusing little chap, used to stick his head in a bell ... what was his name, now ... Joey? ... Xerxes? ...

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: We could repeat them ...

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: Re-heat them?

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: No, repeat them ...

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: You don't re-heat cakes. Not chocolate cakes.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: What, repeat the cakes?

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: Mr Heath, that was the name of the budgie.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: Good Lord, the bar's open! Oh no it isn't, I was looking at the little hand that goes round very fast ...

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Damn. Blast.

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: I've got it. We can retitle the repeats.

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: What ... give them different names?

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: Wouldn't that mean retitling them?

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: Brilliant!

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: Right - all we need is new titles. And they must be damned new!

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: How about `Dad's Navy'?

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: Mm, good, good.

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: `Up Your Mother Next Door.'

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: Even better ...

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: 'Doctor At Bee'!

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: Someone's knocking at the door.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: Quite like it - bit long, though, I think.

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: Far too long.

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: `I Married Lucy.'

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: Hasn't that been done?

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: Oh, yes, a long time ago, though, they'd never remember it.

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: `Doctor at Three'!

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: I think someone's knocking at the door.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: That's even longer!

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: `I Married A Tree.'

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: `And Mother Makes Tree.'

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: `Doctor At Cake'!

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: Look! I'm not absolutely certain, but, well I do rather get the impression that there is someone actually knocking on the door at this very moment.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: That's ridiculous. Half the programme gone. Stop lengthening it!

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: `I Married A Cake'?

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: `I Married Three Rabbit Jelly Moulds'!

dialogue.speaker: Third Planner
dialogue.text: Prefer a cake ... specially chocky cake ...

dialogue.speaker: Security Man
dialogue.text: Open the sodding door!

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: No, no. You can't say `sodding' on the television.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Executive
dialogue.text: You're supposed to knock!

dialogue.speaker: Security Man
dialogue.text: Sorry, sir, but there's trouble at studio five!

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: You're in security, aren't you?

dialogue.speaker: Security Man
dialogue.text: Yes, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Second Planner
dialogue.text: Well, you're not allowed to suggest programme titles.

dialogue.speaker: Security Man
dialogue.text: Sir! It's the World War series in studio five - they're not taking it seriously any more.

dialogue.speaker: First Planner
dialogue.text: You're not allowed to suggest programme titles!

dialogue.speaker: Security Man
dialogue.text: Look!

dialogue.speaker: Security Man
dialogue.text: Ow! Mind me war wound!

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: That's it! Very good title!

dialogue.speaker: Everyone
dialogue.text: Anything goes in. Anything goes out! Fish, bananas, old pyjamas, Mutton, beef and trout! Anything goes in. Anything goes out! etc.

dialogue.speaker: ANIMATION:
dialogue.text: CAPTION: '1942 ENGLAND'

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: I say...

dialogue.speaker: Daughter
dialogue.text: Yes, Daddy?

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Croquet hoops look damn pretty this afternoon.

dialogue.speaker: Daughter
dialogue.text: Frightfully damn pretty.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: They're coming along awfully well this year.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Yes, better than your Aunt Lavinia's croquet hoops.

dialogue.speaker: Daughter
dialogue.text: Ugh! - dreadful tin things.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: I did tell her to stick to wood.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Yes, you can't beat wood...Gorn!

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: What's gorn dear?

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Nothing, nothing, I just like the word, it gives me confidence. Gorn...gorn.It's got a sort of woody quality about it. Gorn. Gorn. Much better than 'newspaper' or 'litterbin'.

dialogue.speaker: Daughter
dialogue.text: Frightful words!

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Perfectly dreadful!

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Ugh! Newspaper!...litterbin...dreadful tinny sort of words. Tin, tin, tin.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Oh, dear, don't say 'tin' to Rebecca, you know how it upsets her.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Sorry, old horse.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Sausage!

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Sausage...there's a good woody sort of word, 'sausage'...gorn.

dialogue.speaker: Daughter
dialogue.text: Antelope!

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Where? On the lawn?

dialogue.speaker: Daughter
dialogue.text: No, no, daddy...just the word.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Don't want an antelope nibbling the hoops.

dialogue.speaker: Daughter
dialogue.text: No, antelope...sort of nice and woody type of thing.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Don't think so, Becky old chap.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: No, no 'antelope', 'antelope' - tinny sort of word. Oh, sorry old man.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Really, Mansfield.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Well, she's got to come to terms with these things... seemly... prodding... vacuum... leap...

dialogue.speaker: Daughter
dialogue.text: Hate 'leap'.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Perfectly dreadful.

dialogue.speaker: Daughter
dialogue.text: Sort of PVC-y sort of word, don't you know.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Lower-middle.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Bound!

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Now you're talking!

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Bound...Vole...Recidivist.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Bit tinny. Oh! Sorry, Becky old beast.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Oh dear, I suppose she'll be gorn for a few days now.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Caribou!

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Splendid word.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: No, dear...nibbling the hoops.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Caribou gorn.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Intercourse.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Later, dear.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: No, no, the word, 'intercourse' - good and woody...Inter...course... pert...pert thighs...botty, botty botty... ...erogenous...zone...concubine...erogenous zone! Loose woman...erogenous zone... Oh, thank you, dear...you know, it's a funny thing, dear...all the naughty words sound woody.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Really, dear?...how about tit?

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Oh dear, I hadn't thought about that. Tit. Tit. Oh, that's very tinny, isn't it? Ugh! Tinny, tinny... Oh dear...ocelot...wasp....yowling...Oh dear, I'm bored...I'd better go and have a bath, I suppose.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Oh really, must you, dear? You've had nine today.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: All right, I'll sack one of the servants...Simpkins!...nasty tinny sort of name. Simpkins!

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: I say, mater, cabbage crates coming over the briny.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Sorry dear, don't understand.

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: Er...cow-catchers creeping up on the conning towers...

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: No...sorry...old sport.

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: Caribou nibbling at the croquet hoops.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Yes, Mansfield shot one in the antlers.

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: Oh, jolly good show. Is 'Becca about?

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: No, she's gorn off.

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: What a super woody sort of phrase. `Gorn orff'.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Yes, she's gorn orff because Mansfield said tin to her.

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: Oh, what rotten luck ... oh well ... whole afternoon to kill ... better have a bath I suppose.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Oh, Gervaise do sing me a song ...

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: Oh, OK.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Something woody.

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: For ... she's going to marry Yum Yum ... oh crikey. The old song finished her orff.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: What's urp?

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: I'm afraid Mrs Vermin Jones appears to have passed orn.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Dead, is she?

dialogue.speaker: Pilot
dialogue.text: 'Fraid so.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: What a blow for her.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: What I want to know Mrs Elizabeth III, is why they give us crap like that, when there's bits of the Leicester by-pass what have never been shown. Biskwit?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Elizabeth III
dialogue.text: Oh, thank yew ...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Appearing on the M2 were 4,281 Vauxhall Vivas, 2,117 Vauxhall Vivas de luxe, 153 Vauxhall Vivas with ...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: Bloody repeats.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: Bloody repeats.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Elizabeth III
dialogue.text: Yes, repeats or war films ... makes you want to ...

dialogue.speaker: Dorian
dialogue.text: Hello and welcome to Show-Jumping from White City ...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: Oh, moto-cross!

dialogue.speaker: Dorian
dialogue.text: ... and it's Anneli Drummond-Hay on Mr Softee just about to go into jump-off against the clock. The short pause is for the stewards who are repairing the Sound of Music. ... Captain Phillips on 'Streuth' just caught one of the nuns at the very start of what would have been a fine clear round. It's a formidable obstacle this Sound of Music - eight nuns high but they're ready now, and singing. And there's the bell. She's got 1.07 seconds to beat, but she needs a clear round to win. As she comes towards the Sound of Music and ...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Elizabeth III
dialogue.text: Quite exciting.

dialogue.speaker: Dorian
dialogue.text: ... beautifully taken, and now she needs to pick up speed for Oklahoma, but not too much. This is where Alan Jones knocked down poor Judd, but ... And ... she's taken it superbly!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: You notice how we never actually see the horses jump.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: Wait for it ...

dialogue.speaker: Dorian
dialogue.text: And! She's taken it ... She's over the Minstrels. She just flicked Leslie Crowther with her tail, but the time's good, and now she turns before coming into the final jump ... this is a tough one ... It's Ben-Hur - forty-six chariots ... 6,000 spectators ... 400 slaves, lion-handlers, the Emperor Nero and the entire Coliseum. 198 feet high. 400 years across!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Mock Tudor
dialogue.text: I bet we don't see this one.

dialogue.speaker: Airman
dialogue.text: (Neil Innes) When does a dream begin? Does it start with a goodnight kiss? Is it conceived or simply achieved When does a dream begin? Is it born in a moment of bliss? Or is it begun when two hearts are one When does a dream exist? The vision of you appears somehow Impossible to resist But I'm not imagining seeing you For who could have dreamed of this? When does a dream begin? When reality is dismissed? Or does it commence when we lose all pretence When does a dream begin?

annotations: A high street. Musical theme played on a banjo a la 'Steptoe and Son' opening. Cut to a tracking shot of two tramps walking jauntily along. They are very arch, over-the-top jolly fellows. They nod at the occasional passer-by and do mock bows to a city gent.

They come to a litter bin, root in it, and one of them produces a newspaper. He hands it to the other, looks in again and brings out a pork pie. He looks in again, his eyes light up, and he produces a bottle of champagne. He passes it to his mate. He looks in again and finds two highly polished glasses. Meanwhile over all this and as they set off down the road together we hear:

(by this time the tramps have walked out of shot; cut to a shot of a sports car up on the pavement with the legs of the two tramps sticking out from underneath; the music turns more urgent and transatlantic)
(appropriate music; a James Bond character climbs out of the car and looks down at the dead tramps)
(shot of him rushing into a film premiere past photographers with flashing bulbs)
(cut to him on yacht)
(still of him with Henry Kissenger; cut to him striding down a street)
(we see him go into a doorway; cut to a low angle close up of Dr Koning donning gloves prior to the operation; the music changes to the Kildare theme)
(cut to a doorbell and pan down)
(pan down to find the doorbell and name)
(the door opens and the rear-admiral comes striding out; naval music; he walks up the road)
(cut to a still of a young inspired and devoted nurse; the music instantly changes to the heroic)
(mix to impressive college grounds)
(zoom in across lawns towards the college building)

(the camera suddenly veers off away from college and homes in on a solitary bush from which appears a seedy fellow in a terrible lightweight suit of several years ago that has got all stained and creased around the crutch)
Cut to a high-powered Italian businessman at a desk in a very modern casa-type Italian office.
The phone rings. He answers it dynamically and we zoom in on his tense, alert, executive face.
(mix through to stock film of a big car-producing plant)
(as each of these things is mentioned we see a momentary flash of a still of each)
(at this point the freeze frame starts moving as the chaplain lifts himself out of the cockpit and jumps down beside his Spitfire)
(smiling cheerfully he crosses off another emblem of a vicar in a German helmet on the side of the plane. Beside this is written '"Here we come Kraut" Luke 17, verse 3')
(a squadron leader, just off a mission, runs past, and dashes into a Nissen hut)
The squadron leader enters an RAF officers' mess and takes off his helmet.
(shouts)
(draws a deep breath and looks slightly uncertain, then starts even more deliberately than before)
A siren goes. The door bursts open and an out-of-breath young pilot rushes in in his flying gear.
General incomprehension. They look at each other.
(searching for words)
Stock film of a German bombing raid.
Cut to a Whitehall war office conference room. A general is on the phone. Four other generals sit there.
A corporal rushes in.
(in disbelief)
A girl emerges from under the table. She is a blonde WAAF.
(to a sergeant)
(the sergeant opens the door, Churchill stands outside)
(the sergeant shuts the door)
(he holds a heroic pose; there is a pause during which we expect to cut; we don't; suddenly he breaks out of the pose into informality)
(getting out drinks)

Cut to a courtroom in the 1940s. A courtmartial is in progress. An elderly general presides, with two others on either side of him. There is a defense counsel, a prosecutor, a clerk of court, and two men guarding the prisoner.
(slightly irritated)
(more irritably)
(patiently)
(incredulously)
(he sings)
(singing)
(to Fawcett)
(clearing his throat and going into an extraordinary tuneless and very loud song)
(dismissively)
(as if he can hardly be bothered to reply)
(irritably)
(stifling his impatience)
(exasperated)
(more and more irritated)
(losing his temper)
(quickly)
(taken off guard)
(to the court)
(everyone stands up)
(everyone sits down)
(everyone goes moo; the presiding general turns to Fawcett)
(everyone puts on pixie hats with large pointed ears)
(a skating vicar and everyone bursts into song)
(etc.)
Cut to the coast of Norway. Night. Tense music. Shots of big coastal guns, cliff-top fortifications.

Build up for abut ten seconds. Cut to a cliff top looking out to sea. A grappling hook comes over and sticks in, then another, and another. Whispered voices, music, the tension rises as the rope is tightened. Then over the top comes a German, head blackened and camouflaged. Then others climb over; they are wearing haloes, pink tutus, jackboots, wands. They charge over. Stock film of guns blazing.
(cut to stock film of a destroyer in the midst of a pitched sea-battle; victory-at-sea music)
(cut to a sailor on a ship in rough sea; he calls to the captain who is in an evening gown)
Cut to stock shots of bombers on a night raid. Cut to interior of a bomber. Various shots of pilot and navigator. There is flak outside and explosions occasionally light up the cabin.
(shot of the pilot)
(shot of the navigator)
(shot of the rear gunner)
(cut to close up of gritty pipe-smoking RAF top brass)
(insert of WAAF)
(cut to montage of war footage, explosions, guns firing, etc.)
During this last lot are superimposed in quick succession the following captions:
(cut to an Indian restaurant)
Cut to the nude organist (Terry J) and `It's' man.
Opening titles
At the end of the title cut to tramps exactly as at the beginning of the show.
She presses the switch. The arab boy flinches with pain and turns and switches of the TV set.

Cut to Mrs Elizabeth III coming out of the front door in a fairly well-to-do mock Tudor detached house in its own grounds. She runs headlong into a tree opposite the front door. Repeat a few times. Then she rushes into a field, digs a hole three feet deep and stands in it. Cut to her standing beside a letter box. She straps on a long false nose and pokes it through the letter box. She drinks a delicate cup of tea at a posh café and eats the whole cup. Cut to her nailing something to a lorry. The lorry starts off to reveal that she had been nailing herself to the lorry. She is dragged away. Cut to TV planners at a window, watching Mrs Elizabeth III doing silly things in a car park below them. She has a cream bun hanging from a long stick which comes out of her hat. She walks along strangely.
(he has a conference tag on his lapel which reads `Chief TV Planner'; he turns from the window to a conference table, piled with drinks)
Cut to Mrs Mock Tudor and Mrs Elizabeth III watching TV. There is a film of the motorway on it, filmed from the bank beside a bridge.
Cut back to the programme planners conference.
(reading figures)
(to the second planner)
(to the senior executive)
(looking at his watch)
(they all scramble madly to their feet)
They sit down again reluctantly. There is a short pause.
There is a knock at the door.
There is a knock at the door.
Continuous knocking on the door.
(desperate)
(over excited)
There is by now a constant hammering.
(yells from outside door)
All shake their heads. The door is broken in. Enter a neo-fascist-looking security man in a wheelchair with an oriental sword through his head.
(triumphantly)
(he smiles victoriously at others)
(switching on a TV set)
They rush to the monitor. One of them brushes the oriental sword which is through his head.
On the screen we see the court martial in progress as we saw it earlier in the show, with the whole court singing.
'What a lovely day'.
The caption fades and we cut to an upper-clas drawing room. Father, mother and daughter having tea. Four motionless servants stand behind them.
The daughter bursts into tears.
(to the daughter)
(he picks up a rifle)
(the daughter bursts into tears)
(miserably)
(the daughter howls)
(the daughter runs out crying)
(he fires a shot)
(laughs politely)
(the mother leaves the room)
(the mother returns and throws a bucket of water over him)
(the daughter returns)
(the daughter runs out crying)
(he exits)
A pilot from the RAF banter scene enters.
(frowns and shakes her head)
The pilot launches into a quite enormously loud rendering of `She's going to marry Yum Yum'. The impact of this on the mother causes her to have a heart attack. She dies and the song ends.
(entering)
Cut to the scene on a TV screen and pull out from the TV to Mrs Mock Tudor and Mrs Elizabeth III in their sitting room watching it.
(takes biskwit from plate)

Mrs Mock Tudor switches her TV switch. The Arab boy winces in great pain and moves over to the set. He changes channels. Up comes a picture of the motorway again. Roller caption superimposed over the motorway. Appropriate 'Crossroads' type theme music.
(reading the roller caption)

Mrs Elizabeth III throws the switch and the Arab boy winces with real pain and turns the knob of the television set which changes channels. On the TV set we see the same two ladies watching their set as before with the tramps on it. They continue watching until the two ladies on the set speak.
(on the TV set)
(not on the TV set)
As before she switches switch. The Arab boy winces in pain and changes channels.
(on the TV set)
She throws the switch. The Arab boy winces in pain and turns over. The White City as for show-jumping. Close up of a mounted female rider waiting to start. Voice over of Dorian Williams.
(cut to shot of stewards who are organizing eight nuns, Von Trapp in Tyrolean gear, Julie Andrews, and the six Von Trapp children into a group forming a fence; cut back to Anneli)
(the group start singing 'The Hills are Alive'; the bell goes for the start of the round and the lady rider sets of towards the group)
Cut away to the two ladies watching their TV. Shot from an angle so we can't see the screen.

Cut back to White City to see the lady rider has just cleared the obstacle. A cheer from the crowd. The music changes to 'Oklahoma'. Follow her round to see a similar group dressed as for 'Oklahoma'. Ten hayseeds and six wenches with a hay wagon. Most have primitive pitch forks and are sucking on straws.
Cheer from TV. Cut back to White City. The horse is coming away from Oklahoma. Cut to run up to Black and White Minstrels.
Cut back to White City.
(cheer; we actually see the lady jumper jump over the chorus of mistrels)
The lady jumper is now coming right towards the camera. Cut back to the ladies watching.
Cut back to horse actually jumping towards the camera. Cut to newsreader Peter Woods in a news studio.

Music comes in underneath: 'When Does a Dream Begin'. Mix to a young airman on an airfield gazing into a WAAF's eyes. Black and white, soft focus and scratched film to look like a not very good print of a 40's film. Airman sings.
Mix sound to end of signiture tune. Halfway through the song the credits roll, superimposed. They read:

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 41

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Yes this looks the sort of thing. May I just try it?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Certainly, madam.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Oh! Sorry! sorry! Yes that's fine.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Is that on account, madam?

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Hello? Hello?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, I'm terribly sorry... I thought you were someone else.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh I see, yes.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: I'm sorry sir, can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, as a matter of fact you can, actually I was interested in the possibility... of purchasing one of your ... can I ask who you thought I was?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Who did you think I was... just then... when you thought I was somebody.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, it's no one you'd know, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well I might know them.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: It's possible, obviously, but I think it's really unlikely.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, I know quite a lot...

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: I mean he's hardly likely to move in your circles, sir...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Why, is he very ?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, no, I didn't mean that, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Is he a lord or something?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, no, not at all.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well look, this is very easy to settle. What is his name?.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What is his name?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Well... er...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Michael Ellis.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Who?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Michael Ellis.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I see.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Do you know him, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Er ... Michael Ellis. Michael Ellis...

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: You don't

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, I don't remember the name.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: I think you would remember him, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Why do you say that?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Well, would you remember a man six foot nine inches high, fortyish, and he's got a long scar from here to here and absolutely no nose?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: ... oh, I think I do remember somebody like that...

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Well, that's not Michael Ellis.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: He's a small man about this high with a high-pitched voice.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Right, I'm not going to buy an ant from you now.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, no, please.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No. You've not been properly trained. I demand another assistant.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, no, come on... please...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No, I want .

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: All right! I'll get another assistant.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Hello sir, can I help you, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No, I want a assistant.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: I sir, I'm Mr Abanazar, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Don't be silly.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh no, please please please let me help you...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No! I want another assistant.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, no, come on, please...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: If you don't give me another assistant...

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: No, no, I'll be very good, sir, really. Good morning, sir... how are you, sir... bit parky outside today... isn't it, sir... ? A very nice suit you've got there, sir... you had a very close shave this morning, sir...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Right I'm going!

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: No, no, please... I'll get another assistant...

dialogue.speaker: Second Assistant
dialogue.text: Woooooo ....ooooooo...

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: It's not him!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I don't want !

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh please, give him a chance!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Second Assistant
dialogue.text: Yes, sir, can I be of any assistance?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh no, come on, don't try that!

dialogue.speaker: Second Assistant
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, sir... try what?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: You know perfectly well what I mean.

dialogue.speaker: Second Assistant
dialogue.text: I'm afraid I don't, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: You were down behind there with a silly mask on going wooo-ooo...

dialogue.speaker: Second Assistant
dialogue.text: I don't think I was, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: All right, get the manager.

dialogue.speaker: Second Assistant
dialogue.text: There seems to have been some sort of misunderstanding, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Manager!

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: This is the manager, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Second Assistant
dialogue.text: Yes, I'm the manager.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Manager!

dialogue.speaker: Second Assistant
dialogue.text: It's a smashing store this, I can't recommend it too highly, well-lit, rat-free. It's a joy to manage. Oh yes, the freshest haddock in London, second floor, third floor Ribena, ants here, television and flame throwers over there, behind them our dinner-wagon exhibition closes at six...

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Quick!

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: Yes, sir? Can I help you, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Yes, I want to complain about the assistants on this counter.

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: I'm sorry to hear that, sir, which ones?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, they're hiding now.

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: Sir?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: They're hiding, down there behind the counter.

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: I see, sir. ... well... there's nobody down here, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: They must have crawled through here, and made their escape through 'Soft Toys'.

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: Yes, of course.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: They were wearing masks and making silly noises and one of them pretended to be the manager. He spoke like this..

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: Ah! I think I've got it, sir, I think I've got it! It's rag week.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Ragweek?

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: Yes, you know, for charity, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh! I see. Some local college or university?

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: No, no it's the rag week.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: The rag week?

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: Yes. The senior staff don't join in much - it's for the trainees really...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: It's not very good for business is it?

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: Oh, It's for charity, sir. People are awfully good about it, you know.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, of course.

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: Right, sir, I'll get you a senior assistant - ants, was it?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Yes, please.

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: Mr Snetterton? Could you look after this gentleman, Mr Snetterton?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I don't want him!

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh Give me a chance!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Real Manager
dialogue.text: All right - Mr Hartford!

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Yes - good morning, sir - can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Yes, please, I'm interested in buying an ant.

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Ah yes - and what price were you thinking of paying, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh, well, I hadn't actually got as far as that.

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Well sir, they start about half a p. but they can go as high as three p. or even three and a half p. for a champion - inflation I'm afraid...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, I should think one about one and a half p., please.

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Ah yes, well you should get a very serviceable little animal for that, sir. Quite frankly the half pence ones are a bit on the mangy side ... What length was sir thinking of?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh ... medium?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Medium. Medium. Here we are, sir. That one there is an Ayrshire, and that one there is a King George bitch I think ... and that one killing the little flitbat is an Afghan.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: That's a nice one.

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Let's see how you get on with him, eh? Ah yes, he likes you. He's taken to you.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What do you feed them on?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Blancmange.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Blancmange?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: I'm sorry. I don't know why I said that. No, you don't feed them at all.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, what do they live on?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: They don't. They die.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: They die?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Well of course they do, if you don't feed them.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I don't understand.

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: You let them die, then you buy another one. It's much cheaper than feeding them and that way you have a constant variety of little companions.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh, I see.

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: That's the advantage of owning an ant.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Right, well I'll take this one. Oh dear, I've dropped it...

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Never mind. Here's another one.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Is there anything else I'll need?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Yes, sir - you'll need an ant house. This is the model we recommend, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Won't it get out of there?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well what's the point of having the cage?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Well, none at all really. And then some pieces of cage furniture which will keep him entertained. Here's an ant-wheel, ant-swing, and a very nice one here, a little ladder - he can run up there and ring the bell at the top, that's a little trick he can learn.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Will he live long enough?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Not really, no, but it's best to have one just in case, and here's a two-way radio he can play with... and of course you'll need the book.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: The book?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Yes, the book on ants.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Yes...

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: So, sir, that is, if I may say so, one hundred and eighty-four pounds one and a half p., sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Will you take a cheque?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Yes, sir, if you don't mind leaving a blood-sample, and a piece of skin off the back of the scalp just here, sir ... sorry ... it's just for identification .-. you can't be too careful.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh, well I think I'll put it on account.

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: I should, sir... much less painful. Anyway sir, you know what they say about an ant. A friend for life, eh? Well, a friend for its life anyway... His name is Marcus. If the little chap should go to an early grave, sir, give us a ring and we'll stick a few in an envelope, all right?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Thanks very much indeed.

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Not at all, thank , Mr Ellis.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Sssssshh!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What did you say?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: I said thank you, Mr Ellis...

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: It's not him.

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Oh!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Why did you say I was Mr Ellis?

dialogue.speaker: Hartford
dialogue.text: Who?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: No, he didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Yes he did. I heard him say 'Thank you, Mr Ellis'.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, no, no - he said 'I'm jealous'.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: I'm jealous of your ant. Goodbye. Goodbye.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I don't care who Michael Ellis is!

dialogue.speaker: PA System
dialogue.text: Will Mr Michael Ellis please go straight to the manager's office... I'll repeat that... Will Mr Nigel Mellish please go straight to the manager's office.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: What have you got now?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I bought an ant, mother.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: What d'you want one of them for! I'm not going to clean it out. You said you'd clean the tiger out, but do you? No, I suppose you've lost interest in it now. Now it'll be ant ant ant for a couple of days, then all of a sudden, 'oh, mum, I've bought a sloth' or some other odd-toed ungulate like a tapir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: It's really different this time, mum. I'm really going to look after this ant.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: That's what you said about the sperm whale... now your papa's having to use it as a garage.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, you didn't feed it properly.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Where are we going to get forty-four tons of plankton from every morning? Your papa was dead vexed about that. They thought he was mad in the deli.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well at least he's got a free garage.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: That's no good to him... his Hillman smells all fishy. Oh blimey, that's the tiger. He'll want his mandies.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Are you giving that tiger drugs?

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: ' I'm giving it drugs!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: It's illegal.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: You try telling that to the tiger.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I think it's dangerous.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Listen ... before he started fixing, he used to get through four Jehovah's witnesses a day. And he used to eat all of them, except the pamphlets.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well he's not dim.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: All right!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, I'm going to watch one of the televisions... come on Marcus.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Michael's been on the phone all day for you.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Michael?

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: You know, Michael... . Michael . He's been on the phone all day ... he came round twice.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What did he look like?

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Oh, I didn't see him. The orange-rumped agouti answered the door. Only useful animal you ever bought, that.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Where is he now?

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: He's upstairs forging prescriptions for the sodding tiger!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No, no, where is Michael Ellis now?

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Oh, I don't know... he said it wasn't important, anyway... all right, here I come.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Hello and welcome to the University of the Air. And first this afternoon, part seventeen in our series of lectures on animal communications. This afternoon we look at recent discoveries in the field of intraspecific signalling codes in the family formicidea.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: That's a stroke of luck, Marcus...

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Turn that bloody thing off!

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: We interrupt this programme to bring you the latest news of the extraordinary Michael Ellis saga. Apparently Michael Ellis...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Hey! I was watching that...

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Bloody thing. It's upsetting the tiger. Oh Christ!

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: ... nd of the announcement. And now back to 'University of the Air', and our series for advanced medical students, 'Elements of Surgical Homeopathic Practice'. Part 68 - 'Ants'.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Ah! We're in luck again, Marcus.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: Hello formicidophiles! Before the blood and guts that you're waiting to see, let's have a look at the anatomy of the little ant.

dialogue.speaker: Ant Expert's Voice
dialogue.text: The body of the ant is divided into three sections. The head, the thorax and the abdomen. They are enclosed in a hard amour-like covering called the exoskeleton, which provides some protection from other nasty little insects but unfortunately not from the dissector's scalpel. See, nothing to it, he's not such a toughy. And his legs ... they help him carry hundreds of times his own weight, but look at this ... you're not so strong compared with me, four, five, six ... Ha!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I didn't know ants had legs, Marcus!

dialogue.speaker: Ant Expert
dialogue.text: Well I can assure you they do, Mr Ellis.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Hey! You've got two legs missing! And that's a false feeler Marcus! Blimey!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I'm taking this ant back, mother - he's got two legs missing.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Hey! Mrs McWong's been on the phone! The polar bear's been in her garden again.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well I'll get it on the way back from the store.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Well mind you do - his droppings are enormous. Oh, and by the way, while you're out get us another couple of tellies would you, here's 180 quid.

dialogue.speaker: Lift Woman
dialogue.text: Second floor ... stationery, leather goods, tribal head injuries, cricket bats, film stars, dolphinariums.

dialogue.speaker: Lift Woman
dialogue.text: Third floor ... cosmetics, books, Irish massage, tribal head-gear, ants.. but not about ants!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh, where do I go to complain?

dialogue.speaker: Lift Woman
dialogue.text: Straight on, then left, then right past the thing, then, up the little stairs, then right by where it's gone all soft, then down the wobbly bit, left past the nail, past the brown stain on the wall to your right and it's the door marked exit straight ahead of you on the left.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Lift Woman
dialogue.text: Fourth floor... kiddies' vasectomies...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I don't want you.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, something wrong with your little ant friend?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No! I'm not going to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: First Assistant
dialogue.text: Something missing in the leg department?

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: Can I help you, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No! No! No! No!

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: Oh, it's all right, sir, it's for the sack race later on.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No, no, no, I want to speak to the General Manager, I want to complain.

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: Oh, well you want the Toupee Hall in that case, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: The what?

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: The Toupee Hall, Mr Ellis.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Excuse me - could you tell me the way to the Toupee Hall, please?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: The Toupee Hall.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: The what?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: The Toupee Hall.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, the Gladys, where are toupees now?

dialogue.speaker: Gladys
dialogue.text: Toupees?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: This gentleman wants one.

dialogue.speaker: Gladys
dialogue.text: A toupee?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, no, actually...

dialogue.speaker: Gladys
dialogue.text: I think they're in surgical appliances now.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: That's right, yes, you go left at artificial limbs and hearing aids, right at dentures and it's on your left just by glass eyes. It doesn't say toupees to avoid embarrassing people, but you can smell 'em.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: You can see the join.

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, it's so nice to see such a large turnout this afternoon. And I'd like to start off by welcoming our guest speakers for this afternoon, Mr Wadsworth...

dialogue.speaker: Wordsworth
dialogue.text: Wordsworth!

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Sorry, Wordsworth... Mr John Koots, and Percy Bysshe.

dialogue.speaker: Shelley
dialogue.text: Shelley!

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Just a little one, medium dry, and Alfred Lorde.

dialogue.speaker: Tennyson
dialogue.text: Tennyson.

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Tennis ball.

dialogue.speaker: Tennyson
dialogue.text: Son, son.

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Sorry - Alfred Lord, who is evidently Lord Tennisball's son. And to start off I'm going to ask Mr Wadsworth to recite his latest offering, a little pram entitled 'I wandered lonely as a crab' and it's all about ants.

dialogue.speaker: Wordsworth
dialogue.text: I wandered lonely as a That floats on high over vales and hills When all at once I saw a crowd A host of golden worker ants.

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Thank you, thank you, Mr Bradlaugh. Now, Mr Bysshe.

dialogue.speaker: Shelley
dialogue.text: Shelley.

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Oh... ... is going to read one of his latest psalms, entitled 'Ode to a crab'.

dialogue.speaker: Shelley
dialogue.text: Well, it's not about crabs actually, it's called 'Ozymandias'. It's not an ode. I met a traveller in an antique land Who said 'Six vast and trunkless legs of stone Stand in the desert And on the pedestal these words appear My name is Ozymandias, King of Ants Look on my feelers, termites, and despair I am the biggest ant you'll ever see The ants of old weren't half as bold and big And fierce as me'.

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Thank you Mr Amontillado. I'd like to ask one or two of you at the back not to soil the carpet, there is a restroom upstairs if you find the poems too exciting Good afternoon, next, Mr Dennis Keat will recite his latest problem 'Ode to a glass of sherry'.

dialogue.speaker: Keats
dialogue.text: My heart aches and a drowsy numbness pains My senses, as though an anteater I'd seen A nasty long-nosed brute With furry legs and sticky darting tongue I seem to feel its cruel jaws Crunch crunch there go my legs Snap snap my thorax too My head's in a twain, there goes my brain Swallow, swallow, swallow, slurp

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Mr Keats, Mr Keats, please leave immediately.

dialogue.speaker: Keats
dialogue.text: It's true. Don't you see. It's true. It happens.

dialogue.speaker: Old Lady
dialogue.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I do apologize for that last... well I hesitate to call it a pram ... but I had no idea ... and talking of filth... I have asked you once about the carpet ... Now, I do appreciate that last poem was very frightening... but please! Now before we move on to tea and pramwiches, I would like to ask Arthur Lord Tenniscourt to give us his latest little plum entitled 'The Charge of the Ant Brigade'.

dialogue.speaker: Tennyson
dialogue.text: Half an inch, half an inch...

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: The Queen, the Queen.

dialogue.speaker: Queen Victoria
dialogue.text: My loyal subjects, we are here today on a matter of national import. My late husband and we are increasingly disturbed by recent developments in literary style that have taken place here in Germany ... er England. There seems to be an increasing tendency for ze ent... the ent... the ant... to become the dominant ... was is der deutsches Entwicklungsbund...

dialogue.speaker: Attendant
dialogue.text: Theme.

dialogue.speaker: Queen Victoria
dialogue.text: Theme ... of modern poetry here in Germany. We are not ... amusiert? Entertained. From now on, ants is verboten. Instead it's skylarks, daffodils, nightingales, light brigades and ... was ist das schreckliche Gepong ... es schmecke wie ein Scheisshaus... und so weiter. Well, we must away now or we shall be late for the races. God bless you alles.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Psst! Electric kettles over here, Sir.

dialogue.speaker: Toupee Manager
dialogue.text: Don't worry, sir, you're among friends now, sir. Mr Bradford, Mr Crawley. These are our fitters, sir. We've had a lot of experience in this field and we do pride ourselves we offer the best and most discreet service available. I don't know whether you'll believe this sir, but one of us is actually wearing a toupee at this moment...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, you all are, aren't you?

dialogue.speaker: Bradford
dialogue.text: Have you got one?

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: Yes, but I didn't know...

dialogue.speaker: Toupee Manager
dialogue.text: I didn't realize that you two... I thought it was me,

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: Yes, I thought it was me.

dialogue.speaker: Bradford
dialogue.text: So did I. That is good.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Actually, I only came in here to ask where the manager's office was.

dialogue.speaker: Toupee Manager
dialogue.text: Just a minute - someone told you we all had toupees?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: Oh yeah?

dialogue.speaker: Bradford
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well ... it's pretty obvious, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: What do you mean obvious! His is undetectable.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Well, it's a different colour, for a start.

dialogue.speaker: Bradford
dialogue.text: Is it?

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: Course it isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: And it doesn't fit in with the rest of his hair... it sort of sticks up in the middle.

dialogue.speaker: Bradford
dialogue.text: It's better than yours.

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I'm not wearing one.

dialogue.speaker: Toupee Manager
dialogue.text: Oh, I see, you haven't got one.

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: Why did you come in here then?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: They told me to find the manager's office here.

dialogue.speaker: Bradford
dialogue.text: Oh no, not again.

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: That's a bit lame, isn't it...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: It's the truth!

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Manager's office.

dialogue.speaker: Bradford
dialogue.text: Yeah, look at it. Where did you get that, Mac Fisheries?

dialogue.speaker: Toupee Manager
dialogue.text: Dreadful, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: Nylon?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: It's not, it's real look.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, anyone can do that.

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: Come on, get if off.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Get away.

dialogue.speaker: Toupee Manager
dialogue.text: Look, do you want a proper one?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No, I don't need one.

dialogue.speaker: Bradford
dialogue.text: There's no need to be ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: We've all owned up.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I'm not wearing one.

dialogue.speaker: Toupee Manager
dialogue.text: Don't you see... this is something you've got to come to terms with.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: I am not wearing a toupee! They just told me to come in here to find the manager's office, to complain about my ant!

dialogue.speaker: Crawley
dialogue.text: Pathetic, isn't it.

dialogue.speaker: Bradford
dialogue.text: Complain about an ant?

dialogue.speaker: Toupee Manager
dialogue.text: This is for your own good.

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: All right. Take a seat.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: You see! There ought to be a safety catch on it, I mean ... ohhhh! I mean, what if this fell into the wrong hands?

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: Yes, madam. I'll speak to the makers personally, all right?

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Would you? It would put my mind at ease.

dialogue.speaker: Lady's Voice
dialogue.text: Sorry...

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: Next?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Zyndersky
dialogue.text: He's still molesting her.

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, I'll see to you in a moment, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Ewing
dialogue.text: I've got a complaint to make.

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: Do take a seat. I'm sorry it's on fire.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Ewing
dialogue.text: Oh, not at all. I got used to this out east.

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: Where were you out east?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Ewing
dialogue.text: Oh, Norway ... Sweden ... places like that... oh I'm terribly sorry, my suit seems to keep catching fire.

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: Extinguisher?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Ewing
dialogue.text: Oh no, thank you, I think we'd better let it run its course. I was just thinking... Norway is not very east, is it? I should have said when I was out north.

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: Are there many fires in Norway?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Ewing
dialogue.text: Good Lord yes. The place is a constant blaze. Wooden buildings, d'you know. I lost my wife in Norway.

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: I am sorry to hear that.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Ewing
dialogue.text: Why, did you know her?

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: No, I meant...

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Ewing
dialogue.text: Oh I see. No, she wasn't a favourite of mine. We were out strolling across a fiord one day when one of the local matadors came out of his tree house and flung a load of old scimitars and guillotines out that he'd got cluttering up his wine cellar and apparently rather a large proportion of them landed on my wife causing her to snuff it without much more ado.

dialogue.speaker: Complaints Manager
dialogue.text: Yes, yes - well look...

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Here is an important announcement about Michael Ellis. It is now the end of 'Michael Ellis' week. From now on it is 'Chris Quinn' week.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What a rotten ending.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Well it is one of our cheapest, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What else have you got?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Well, there's the long slow pull-out, sir, you know, the camera tracks back and back and mixes...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: No, have you got anything more exciting?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: How about a chase?

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: There he is!

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh, no, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Walking into the sunset?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: What's that one?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: You know ... two lone figures silhouetted against the dying rays of the setting sun. The music swells, you've got a lump in your throat and a tear in your eye...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Oh no.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, pity, I rather like that one...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: They're all a bit off the point, you see.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Well there is one that ties up the whole Michael Ellis thing, but....

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: But what... ?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Oh, no, nothing, nothing...

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Look, who is this Michael Ellis?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: How about a happy ending, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Oh Chris! Thank God you're safe.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: No, you wouldn't want that, would you.

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Why wouldn't I want that?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: What about summing up from the panel? That's cheap. You know - the big match experts.

dialogue.speaker: Malcolm Allison
dialogue.text: Yes. It was quite a good show. I think that the Michael Ellis character was a little overdone.

dialogue.speaker: Brian Clough
dialogue.text: Well, I don't agree with that, Malcolm, quite frankly the only bit I liked was this bit with me in it now.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: No? Slow fade?

dialogue.speaker: Chris
dialogue.text: Nnnn... no.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Well, how about a sudden ending?

annotations: Animated titles.
Roll credits.

Quinn, knowing that there are doors, goes forward more cautiously and enters. The banging of noses on glass doors is a constant background theme. Cut to the gift department. A large lady is standing by counter holding a large cylinder with a rose attachment.
The lady presses button and a sheet of flame shoots out across the hall.
(she is happy though)

Chris walks by, watching with interest but not much concern, passing a customer whose back is on fire but who has not noticed. He approaches a counter with a sign saying 'Ant Counter'. He stands by the apparently empty counter for one moment, then rings a bell.
A strange rubber-masked head appears from below the other side of the counter and gesticulates at him making a strange noise. This soon stops.
(he takes off the mask to reveal a straight forward assistant)
(distressed)
(he disappears behind a curtain)
The same assistant reappears with a long mandarin-style Chinese moustache.
(high-pitched voice)
(normal voice)
(he becomes exaggeratedly polite)
(he takes off his moustache)
(he rings the bell on the counter.)

After a pause, very slowly indeed an identical mask to the first appears over the top of the counter right next to the first assistant, making the same noise very quietly. The first assistant sees him, starts and nudges him hard.
The second assistant makes a disappointed noise and disappears below.
(pointing over the counter at the disappeared assistant)
(appearing from below counter without a mask, looking immaculate)
(in a silly voice)
(he keeps calling)
(nudging him)
They both disappear under the counter. The real manager arrives and presents himself to Chris.
(noticing the 'manager' badge on his lapel)
(he goes round counter, looks, but obviously can't see them; Chris goes round to join in the search)
(he points)
(he does an impression)
(he rattles a collecting tin)
(he puts a coin in)
(calling)
(Mr Snetterton approaches immediately; he is clearly the first assistant with very bad short crew-cut wig on)
(he tips some ants - which we can't see - out into a special ring on counter)
(he puts it on Chris's hand)
(he produces a birdcage)
(he produces microscopic things)
(he produces an expensive-looking book, thoughtlessly slams it down where the ants were, then hurriedly brushes them away)
(looking unsure)
(indicates a point behind his ear)
(he hands him a little knife and some cotton wool)
(Hartford loads the large cage, furniture, two-way radio and the book on ants into a huge box; with some difficulty he finds the ant; he picks it up carefully)
(he drops him in the big box and pushes it across the counter; the box has on one side, in large letters 'live ant: handle with care'; it has breathing holes in it)
Chris turns sharply. The first assistant comes quickly up to Hartford.
(innocently)
(waves pointedly)
(leaving the counter)

Chris passes a shop area labelled 'The Paisley Counter' where two customers are talking to mirrors in thick Irish accents. Chris moves on to lift. A little old lady passes, oblivious to the fact that her shopping trolley is smouldering. The lady passes and Chris is about to enter.
(Chris wheels round and listens)

Chris narrows his eyes suspiciously and gets into the lift cautiously. Cut to the kitchen in Chris Quinn's home. His mother is putting chopped meat into a line af at least half a dozen feeding bowls with various animal names on them. 'Babboon', 'Dromedary', 'Gorilla', 'Trout', and 'Pangolin'. There is a tiger in a cage in the middle of the kitchen, with a bowl marked 'Tiger' in front of him. A large cobra is hanging from the clothes drier and a wolf is in a cage below the sink. A monkey is on top of one of the cupboards. Chris enters with the box.
(growl from the tiger)
(we hear a roar)
A very loud roar and rattling of cage.
She loads a syringe and starts to leave.
He puts Marcus in cage and is just about to take it through to the next room.

She goes to the tiger. Chris looks confused, then shrugs and goes into the sitting room with Marcus. In the room there are about twenty old televisions on shelves. Chris selects one of the televisions, puts it on the table, switches it on and settles down to watch it with Marcus.
(on the TV)
(on the TV)

Cut to a restaurant. A waiter (Graham) stands at one side. Our hero (Terry J) enters, the waiter approaches him and they go through an elaborate signalling or greeting ceremony, stamping and so forth. The waiter does strange series of movements.
Hero stamps a lot and clasps the waiters bottom.
Waiter routine.
Hero routine.
Waiter routine.
Hero routine.
Waiter routine.
Hero routine.
Mother enters. She is rather torn and tattered and her face is bloodstained.
(mother switches it off)
(there is a roar and a crash of breaking crockery from the kitchen)
She dashes across to the door and goes into the kitchen. Chris quickly switches the TV on.
(waits for noises to stop)
A surgeon appears on television. He makes a few ant gestures.
Cut to a drawing of an ant.
(arrow indicates)
(an animated hand with a knife slices bits off the ant)
(a hand pulls the legs off)

He leaps up, switches the TV off and hurls it into the corner onto a pile of used TVs, and hurries out. The tiger is quiet now. Mother, bloody and torn, is emptying a tin of 'Kit-E-Cobra' into a box marked 'Cobra'.
(Chris goes through the door, mother shouts after him)
(she tosses a wad out to him)
