dialogue.text: Down below Sir Philip, their first boats are landing even now.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Right, you stay here, I'll go and get them.

dialogue.speaker: Elizabethan Gent
dialogue.text: Sir Philip! Not alone!

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Allo allo! What's going on here?

dialogue.speaker: Spaniard
dialogue.text: Ees nothing, Señor, ees just some literature.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: I know what literature is, you dago dustbin. I also know what porn is. What's this then eh?

dialogue.speaker: Spaniard
dialogue.text: It is one of Lope De Vega's latest play, Señor.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: 'Toledo Tit Parade'? What sort of play's that?

dialogue.speaker: Spaniard
dialogue.text: It's very visual, Señor.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Right. I'm taking this lot in the name of Her Gracious Majesty Queen Elizabeth.

dialogue.speaker: Spaniard
dialogue.text: Oh, but Señor.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Don't give me any trouble. Just pile up these baskets of filth and come with me.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The battle raged long and hard, but as night fell Sidney overcame the Spaniards. 6,000 copies of 'Tits and Bums' and 4,000 copies of 'Shower Sheila' were seized that day. The tide of Spanish porn was stemmed. Sir Philip Sidney returned to London in triumph.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Covered in glory, Sir Philip rode home to Pensburst to see his beloved wife... but all was not well.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Good evening all, my love. I have returned safe from the Low Countries. What are thou reading, fair one?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh, 'tis nothing, husband.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: I can see 'tis .

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: 'Tis one of Shakespeare's latest works.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Oh ...'Gay Boys in Bondage' What, is't - tragedy? Comedy?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: 'Tis a... er... 'tis a story of a man's great love for his... fellow men.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: How fortunate we are indeed to have such a poet on these shores.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Indeed. How was the war, my lord?

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: The Spaniards were defeated thrice. Six dozen chests of hardcore captured.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Hast brought home any spoils of war?

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Yes, good my wife, this fair coat trimmed with ermine.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh, lovely, nowt else?

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: No, no fair lady. The rest was too smutty.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Now, my good wife. Whilst I rest, read to me a while from Shakespeare's 'Gay Boys in Bondage'.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Yes... my lord ... 'Gay Boys in Bondage' ... Ken, 25, is a mounted policeman with a difference... and what a difference. Even Roger is surprised and he's... he's used to real men ...

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: 'Tis like 'Hamlet' ... what a genius!

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: 'But who's going to do the cooking tonight? Roddy's got a mouthful...'

dialogue.speaker: Maddox
dialogue.text: All right, this is a raid.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh! We are disgraced!

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: There you are, Maddox!

dialogue.speaker: Maddox
dialogue.text: Cut the chat... and get in the van.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Maddox! You recognize me...

dialogue.speaker: Maddox
dialogue.text: Indeed I do, Sir Philip Sidney, and sad I am to see you caught up in this morass of filth, ooh - that's a long one.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh oh... the glorious name of Sidney is besmirched ... all is lost ... oh alas the day.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Shut up! I know this man - this is my old mate Sergeant Maddox...

dialogue.speaker: Maddox
dialogue.text: You'll do time for this.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: Oh Maddox - it's me - Gaskell ... 'F' division down at Acton ... Inspector Arthur Frodwell.

dialogue.speaker: Maddox
dialogue.text: Come on Sidney. And you, miss.

dialogue.speaker: Gaskell
dialogue.text: I'm not Sir Philip bleedin' Sidney .... and where were you? We could have mopped up that Tudor shop...

dialogue.speaker: Maddox
dialogue.text: Ooh! That's a good one!

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: It's nice here, darling, isn't it.

dialogue.speaker: He
dialogue.text: It's beautiful, it's Paris all over again.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Excuse me, do you mind if I join you?

dialogue.speaker: He
dialogue.text: Er, no... no... no... not at all.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Are you you don't mind?

dialogue.speaker: He
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, absolutely.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: You're sure I won't be disturbing you?

dialogue.speaker: He
dialogue.text: No, no.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: You're absolutely sure I won't be disturbing you?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: No, no really.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Good. Because I don't want to disturb you. Specially as you're being so kind about me not disturbing you.

dialogue.speaker: He
dialogue.text: Oh, no, no, we don't mind, do we, darling?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh no, darling.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Good, so I can go ahead and join you then? Can I?

dialogue.speaker: Both
dialogue.text: Yes ... yes...

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Won't be disturbing?

dialogue.speaker: Both
dialogue.text: No. No.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Good, good. You're very kind. A lot of people are far less understanding than you are. A lot of people take offense even when I talk to them. Let alone when I specifically tell them about my being disturbing.

dialogue.speaker: He
dialogue.text: ... Well, it's not disturbing.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: No, absolutely, absolutely, that's what I always say. But you'd be amazed at the number of people who really don't want me - I mean, even doing this gets people looking at me in the most extraordinary way.

dialogue.speaker: He
dialogue.text: We must be getting on.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: I knew I'd disturb you ... I knew I'd disturb you ... It always happens ... whenever I've found someone I really think I'm going to be able to get on with...

dialogue.speaker: He
dialogue.text: No, the only thing is, you see, we're going to be a little bit late.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Let's stay.

dialogue.speaker: He
dialogue.text: Well, just a little bit... I mean, we will be late if we don't...

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Oh, thank you. You're very kind.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: As it turned out our chance meeting with Reverend Arthur Belling was to change our whole way of life, and every Sunday we'd hurry along to St Loony up the Cream Bun and Jam.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now...

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'THE FREE REPETITION OF DOUBTFUL WORDS - SKIT, SPOOF, JAPE OR VIGNETTE, BY A VERY UNDER-RATED WRITER'

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: I've come for some free repetition of doubtful words on an inland telegram.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Have you got the telegram in question?

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: I have the very thing here.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Well, slip it to me my good chap and let me eye the contents.

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: At once Mr Telegram Enquiry Man.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Thank you Mr Customer Man. Aha. 'Parling I glove you. Clease clome at bronce, your troving swife, Pat.' Which was the word you wanted checking?

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: Pat.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Pat?

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: My wife's name is not Pat at all.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: No?

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: It's Bat. With a B.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: And therefore I will take a quick look in the book.

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: Ripping.

script.description: CAPTION: 'ONE QUICK LOOK IN THE BOOK LATER'

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: You're quite right, old cock. There been a mistake.

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: I thought as much. What really does it say?

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: It say 'Go away you silly little bleeder. I am having another man. Love Bat'. Quite some error.

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: Yes. She wouldn't call herself Pat, it's silly.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Daft, I call it.

dialogue.speaker: Peepee
dialogue.text: Well it has been a pleasure working with you.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: For me also it has been a pleasure. And that concludes our little skit.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'THE FREE REPETITION OF DOUBTFUL WORDS THING, BY A JUSTLY UNDERRATED WRITER - THE END'

dialogue.speaker: Roger Last
dialogue.text: Good evening. Tonight on 'Is There' we examine the question, 'Is there a life after death?'. And here to discuss it are three dead people... The late Sir Brian Hardacre, former curator of the Imperial War Museum ... the late Professor Thynne, until recently an academic, critic, and broadcaster ... and putting the view of the Church of England, the very late Prebendary Reverend Ross. Gentlemen, is there a life after death or not? Sir Brian? Professor? ... Prebendary?.... Well there we have it, three say no. On 'Is There' next week we'll be discussing the question 'Is there enough of it about?', and until then, goodnight.

dialogue.speaker: SUPERIMPOSED CREDITS:
dialogue.text: 'IS THERE' INTRODUCED BY ROGER LAST RESEARCH: J. LOSEY L. ANDERSON S. KUBRICK P. P. PASOLINI O. WELLES THE LATE B. FORBES PRODUCED BY: GILLIAN (AGED 3 l/2)

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: Good doctor morning! Nice year for the time of day!

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Come in.

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: Can I down sit?

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Certainly. Well, then?

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: Well, now, not going to bush the doctor about the beat too long. I'm going to come to point the straight immediately.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Good, good.

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: My particular prob, or buglem bear, I've had ages. For years, I've had it for donkeys.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: I'm up to here with it, I'm sick to death. I can't take you any longer so I've come to see it.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Ah, now this is your problem with words.

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: This is my problem with words. Oh, that seems to have cleared it. 'Oh I come from Alabama with my banjo on my knee'. Yes, that seems to be all right. Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: I see. But recently you have been having this problem with your word order.

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: Well, absolutely, and what makes it worse, sometimes at the end of a sentence I'll come out with the wrong fusebox.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Fusebox?

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: And the thing about saying the wrong word is a) I don't notice it, and b) sometimes orange water given bucket of plaster.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Yes, tell me more about your problem.

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: Well as I say, you'd just be talking and out'll pudenda the wrong word and ashtray's your uncle. So I'm really strawberry about it.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Upset?

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: It's so embarrassing when my wife and I go to an orgy.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: A party?

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: No, an orgy. We live in Esher.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Quite.

dialogue.speaker: Burrows
dialogue.text: That's what I said. Such a bloody whack the diddle fa di la, fo di la, lo do di ... do di do, rum fum.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Mr Burrows, this is no common problem. You are suffering from a disease so rare that it hasn't got a name. Not yet. But it will have. Oh yes. This is the opportunity I've been waiting for. The chance of a lifetime! I'll show them at the Royal College of Surgeons! I'll make them sit up and take notice! Thripshaw's disease! Discovered by E. Henry Thripshaw MD! I'll be invited on 'Call My Bluff' and the merchandizing, there'll be E. Henry Thripshaw t-shirts ... I'll turn it into a game ... I'll sell the film rights.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: That clip... comes from the new David O. Seltzer... film. The author... of that film clip ... is with me ... now. Doctor E. Henry ... Thripshaw.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Well, I feel that they have missed the whole point of my disease.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: This is .... always the problem ... with directors of film... clips.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Yes, well you see, they've dragged in all this irrelevant mush...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: What... are you doing ... now?

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Well at the moment I am working on a new disease, which I hope to turn into a musical, but, primarily we are working on a re-make of my first disease and this time we're hoping to do it properly.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well ... let's just ... take a ... look at this new film...clip.

dialogue.speaker: Thripshaw
dialogue.text: Well now, what seems to be the matter?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: The next sketch starts after some silly noises.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Come in.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: I wondered if I could have a word with you for a moment.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: By all means ... by all means, sir. Do sit down. Ah, sit on the desk here.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Now then, a glass of sherry?

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: No... no thank you...

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Are you sure? I'm going to have some.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Well, if you're having some, yes then, perhaps, vicar.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Oh... well there's only just enough for me.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Well in that case I won't, don't worry.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: You see, if I split what's left, there'd be hardly any left for me at all.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Well, I'm not a great sherry drinker.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Good! So, I can have it all ... now then what's the problem?

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Well, just recently I've begun to worry about...

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Ah! I've found another bottle! You can have some now if you want to.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Well... yes, perhaps a little...

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Oh you don't have to. I can drink the whole bottle.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Well in that case, no...

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Good! That's another bottle for me. Do go on.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: I've begun to worry recently that...

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Come in!

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Ah, Mr Husband ... this is Mr Kirkham, one of my parishioners, this is Mr Husband of the British Sherry Corporation...

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Look, look, perhaps I'd better come back later...

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: No, no ... no do stay here. Have a sherry... you won't be long will you, Husband?

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Oh no, vicar... it's just a question of signing a few forms.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: There we are... there we are, Mr Husband. Now, how about you, Mr Kirkham?

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Well only if there's enough.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Oh well, there's not much now.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Oh, in that case... no... I won't bother.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Good. Right... now, then, what is the problem, Husband?

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Well, vicar, I've made enquiries with our shippers and the most sherry they can ship in any one load is 12,000 gallons.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: And how many glasses is that?

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: That's roughly 540,000 glasses, Vicar.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: That's excellent, Husband, excellent.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Yes... it means you can still keep your main sherry supply on the roof, but you can have an emergency supply underneath the vestry of 5,000 gallons.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Yes... and I could have dry sherry on the roof and Amontillado in the underground tank!

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Absolutely.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Excellent work, Husband, excellent work.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Not at all, vicar, you're one of our best customers... you and the United States. Well goodbye.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Terrific. Now then, Mr Kirkham I am so sorry... do go on.

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: Well, it's just that recently I've begun to worry about...

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Well, look...

dialogue.speaker: Kirkham
dialogue.text: I sometimes ask myself - does the Bible intend...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What did you want?

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Dirty books, please.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: E. Henry Thripshaw t-shirts are now available from BBC Enterprises. The price hasn't finally been decided, and the address to write to...they haven't yet quite worked out.

annotations: Outside a shop. A sign reads 'Tuder Job Agency - Jobs a Speciality'. A man enters the shop. Inside it is decorated in Tudor style. The assistant is in Tudor dress.
(he gets out a book and looks through it)
(produces selection of mags from under counter)
(off)
(off)

The wall of the Tudor shop slides back to reveal the interior of a Soho dirty bookshop in the back room - a bare room with a counter and magazines in racks on the walls at eye-level. Three drably dressed men are thumbing through books. One of them is a vicar, one of them is gathering a huge pile. Behind the counter is a Soho toughie in Tudor gear showing books to Mr Nid - a tweedy, rather academic, respectable-looking man of senior years. The customer goes through, and the wall slides back.
(voice over)
(voice over)
He presses a button below counter and the wall slides back. The man with the big pile of books comes up to counter.
Enter Gaskell in Tudor gear. The wall closes up behind him.
They all look at him blankly. He looks to Maddox for support and realizes he isn't there.
Everybody resumes their book-buying and ignores him. At the counter the assistant is still totting up the huge pile of books.
(takes top one)
(addressing everyone in shop; they ignore him)
(no reaction)
(people start to leave through the rear door of the shop; Gaskell blocks it)
(looks for his notebook but it's not in his Tudor clothing)
(the customer leaves; other customers start to leave)
(the vicar comes up to counter)
(the vicar leaves guiltily)
He goes out carrying a pile of magazines. Then the vicar goes, followed by the Tudor man.
(the door slams; Gaskell turns and looks round the empty shop; pause)
He rushes up to the sliding wall and beats on it. Then he turns and makes for the little back door and goes through.

He stops and gapes. We cut to his eye-line to see he is standing in a beautiful, green, Tudor garden. In the distance a Tudor house. A girl is sitting on a stone bench, sobbing. Gaskell walks towards her, bewildered.
The girl looks up at him with beseeching eyes. She is young and beautiful.
An Elizabethan gentleman appears through the trees.
(he bows extravagantly to Gaskell)
(turning to Caskell with bated breath)
They walk off together arm in arm into the idyllic country garden. The girl looks after them with hope in her eyes. Bring up Elizabethan music.

Mix through to a Tudor dining room. At the table a group of Tudor gentry are sitting listening to Gaskell. Evidence of a banquet, and two minstrels in attendance. Gaskell has obviously just finished a story. Applause and laughter.

Applause. They are all very impressed. Cut to exterior. A messenger on a horse rides full pelt straight towards the camera. It is dusk. He stops outside the Elizabethan house, leaps off and dashes into the house. Cut to interior again. They are still all laughing from his last story. The messenger bursts into room.
Cut to exterior. Gaskell is seated on the back of the messenger's horse and they gallop off. The dinner crowd are standing waving on the doorstep.

Cut to a British standard fluttering in the breeze against the blue sky. Fanfare. Two Elizabethan gentlemen, and four men dressed as Elizabethan soldiers are standing on a cliff top. Gaskell strides up to them, and takes up position on topmost point of the knoll.
Shot of a sailing-galley seen from above.
Cut to the beach. Suspense music. Gaskell strides up to the camera, until he is towering over it. The music reaches crescendo.
Cut to beached rowing boat piled high with bundles of dirty magazines. Two Spaniards are unloading it.
(pulls out a loose magazine and brandishes it)

The second Spaniard leaps out of the boat with a drawn sword and they both engage Gaskell in a fight. Then we start to draw away from them, leaving them tiny dots in the distance fighting. Fight music over all this and voice over.
Cut to stock film of Elizabethan London street during celebrations.
Cut to side on close up of Gaskell riding hard through woodland.

Gaskell runs up outside another Tudor house and strides in. Cut to interior of an Elizabethan room - panelled walls, log fire, latticed windows, etc. Sir Philip's wife is sitting reading. Gaskell enters.
(she hurriedly hides the book she is reading under some knitting and starts whistling)
Gaskell picks up the book and reads the title.
(trying to look innocent)
(without enthusiasm)
He settles himself down in front of his lady's feet and the fire.
The wife looks a trifle taken aback but reluctantly opens the book and starts to read with a resigned air.
(she looks slightly, sick with guilt)
Enter Maddox - a modern-day plain-clothed policeman.
The wife screams, Gaskell leaps to his feet.
(he picks up the book)
(he bundles them both out)
They are bundled out. Maddox pauses only to pick a book from the bookcase near the door.

Cut to outside a modern theatre stage-door. Gaskell, still protesting, and Mrs Sidney are bundled out and into a police van. As it drives off, it reveals on the side of the theatre a poster saying
'The Aldwych Theatre, The Royal Shakespeare Company Presents 'Gay Boys In Bondage' By William Shakespeare'.
Enter a vicar, dressed normally but has bald wig with fright hair at sides. He carries a suitcase.
(he sits down)
(he makes strange gestures with his hands)
(he produces plates from his case and smashes them on the table)
(he produces a rubber crab suspended from a ping-pong paddle and a rubber baby doll and bobs them up and down, making loud silly noises as he does so)
(he breaks more plates and squirts shaving cream over his head; he and she get up to leave)
(miserably)
(sitting down and comforting vicar)
(he sits down reluctantly)
More silly behaviour from the vicar. He and she look embarrassed. Dissolve to them sitting at home smashing plates, making silly noises and covering themselves with shaving cream.
(voice over)
(film of them running into a church)
Hold shot of the church. Sound of a congregation standing. We hear the silly noises. Cut to nude organist (Terry J). He plays a fanfare.
Animated titles.
Straight into animated sketch, ending with:
(and CAPTION)
A post office counter window, with 'Telegram Enquiries' over the top. We see this through an ornate vignette. The clerk is behind the counter. Enter Mr Peepee. They speak very stiltedly.
(reads)
String quartet music starts to play, as at the beginning, only this time we widen to reveal a string quartet sitting in the set, playing. The clerk and Peepee adopt slightly frozen position. Mix to:
(and CAPTION:)
Animation link to a late-night religious-type discussion. A chairman and three guests are slumped motionless in their seats.
(superimposed captions identify them)
(silence)
Under these credits, we see the stiffs being carried off by people.
(Burrows sits)
(zoom in to close up on him as lighting changes to dramatic spotlight)
Cut to front of a booklet, entitled 'A Dissertation on Thripshaw's Disease Presented to the Royal College of Surgeons by Dr f. Henry Thripshaw'. Captions zoom forward over it:

A page of the book turns to reveal the title 'David O. Seltzer Presents'. The page turns again to reveal 'Rip Glint in:'. The page turns again to reveal a title in stone lettering a la Ben-Hur, with searchlights behind a la 20th-Century Fox: 'Dr E. Henry Thripshaw's Disease'.
Cut to stock film of marauding knights.
The knights sack a village, looting, pillaging, burning and murdering. Cut to a studio set with interviewer and Thripshaw.
(speaking with frequent pauses, as of one reading from a slow autocue)
Film clip exactly as before. Cut to Thripshaw at a desk evidently in a castle. A knight in armor rushes up to him.
Cut to a corner of the set where a man emerges from a barrel.

Black screen and a collection of really silly noises. Then fade up on a country church. Cut to interior, a vestry. A sign reads 'No Papists'. The door opens and the vicar enters as if from the end of a service. He takes off his cassock and is hanging it up. At one side of the set is a sculpture on a plinth. It is the vicar's head, but with an enormously long nose. Mr Kirkham has followed the vicar in. He is an earnest, quiet, self-effacing soul, with a tortured conscience.
(they look round for a chair)
(getting a bottle from the cupboard)
(slightly taken aback)
The vicar has been looking through his desk. He produces a bottle of sherry in triumph.
The vicar opens the bottle and pours himself a glass. As soon as he has drunk it he replenishes it again.
There is a knock on the door.
A smooth man, Mr Husband, enters carrying a smart little briefcase.
The vicar pours Husband a sherry.
(pouring himself one)
The vicar signs a form that Husband hands to him.
(he leaves)
(pouring himself anothter sherry)

A group of Spanish singers in full national costumes with guitars bursts into the Vestry, noisily singing a song praising Amontillado. A man in an extravagant Spanish costume rushes in. His hat has a sign on it saying: 'Sherry, the drink of champions'. Two girls come in bearing maracas and Carmen Miranda style hats. Mr Kirkham looks fed up. The Spaniards finish their song, noisily.
As they carry out their transactions, noisily, we cut to the credits, rolled over a shot of the dirty postcards scetion of the Tudor dirty bookshop. The credits read:
Fade out. Fade up on the BBC world symbol.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 35

dialogue.speaker: First Pilot
dialogue.text: This is Captain MacPherson welcoming you aboard East Scottish Airways. You'll have had your tea. Our destination is Glasgow. There is no need to panic.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: There's a bomb on board this plane, and I'll tell you where it is for a thousand pounds.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: I don't believe you.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: If you don't tell me where the bomb is... if I don't give you the money... Unless you give me the bomb...

dialogue.speaker: Stewardess
dialogue.text: The money.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: The money, thank you, pretty lady... the bomb will explode killing everybody.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Including you.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: I'll tell you where it is for a pound.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Here's a pound.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: I don't want Scottish money. They've got the numbers. It can be traced.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: One English pound. Now where's the bomb?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: I can't remember.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: You've forgotten.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Aye, you'd better have your pound back. Oh... fingerprints.

dialogue.speaker: First Pilot
dialogue.text: Now where's the bomb?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Ah, wait a tic, wait a tic. Er, my first is in Glasgow but not in Spain, my second is in steamer but not in train, my whole is in the luggage compartment on the plane... I'll tell you where the bomb is for a pound.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: It's in the luggage compartment.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Right. Here's your pound..

dialogue.speaker: Headphones
dialogue.text: Is this character giving you any trouble?

dialogue.speaker: First Pilot
dialogue.text: He's just ruined this sketch.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Yes, absolutely.

dialogue.speaker: Headphones
dialogue.text: Let's go on to the next one.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Wait a tic, wait a tic. No. I won't ruin your sketch for a pound.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: No, no.

dialogue.speaker: Headphones
dialogue.text: Next item.

dialogue.speaker: Nude Man
dialogue.text: Well I see my role in it as, er, how can I put it best - the nude man - as sort of symbolizing the two separate strands of existence, the essential nudity of man...

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: It's an interesting question. Personally I rather adhere to the Bergsonian idea of laughter as a social sanction against inflexible behaviour but... excuse me a moment... And now...

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'AND NOW THE TEN SECONDS OF SEX'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'ALL RIGHT, YOU CAN STOP NOW'

dialogue.speaker: Man in Tails
dialogue.text: Well, we'll be continuing with 'Monty Python's Flying Circus' in just a moment fr...o...m nnnnnnnnnnnn...now.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: This new housing development in Bristol is one of the most interesting in the country. It's using a variety of new techniques: shock-proof curtain-walling, a central high voltage, self-generated electricity source, and extruded acrylic fiberglass fitments. It's also the first major housing project in Britain to be built entirely by characters from nineteenth-century English literature.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Here Little Nell, from Dickens's 'Old Curiosity Shop' fits new nylon syphons into the asbestos-lined ceilings ... But it's the electrical system which has attracted the most attention. Arthur Huntingdon, who Helen Graham married as a young girl, and whose shameless conduct eventually drove her back to her brother Lawrence, in Anne Brontë's 'The Tenant of Wildfell Hall' describes why it's unique.

dialogue.speaker: Huntingdon
dialogue.text: Because sir, it is self-generating. Because we have harnessed here in this box the very forces of life itself. The very forces that will send Helen running back to beg forgiveness!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The on-site building techniques involve the construction of twelve-foot walling blocks by a crowd of farmhands from 'Tess of the D'Urbervilles' supervised by the genial landlady, Mrs Jupp, from Samuel Butler's 'Way of All Flesh'.

dialogue.speaker: Narrator
dialogue.text: In contrast to the site in Bristol, it's progress here on Britain's first eighteen-level motorway interchange being built by characters from Milton's 'Paradise Lost'...

dialogue.speaker: Narrator
dialogue.text: What went wrong here?

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: Well, no one really got on. Satan didn't get on with Eve ... er... Archangel Gabriel didn't get on with Satan... nobody got on with the Serpent, so now they have to work a rota: forces of good from ten till three, forces of evil three to six.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But even more modern building techniques are being used on an expanding new town site near Peterborough; here the Amazing Mystico and Janet can put up a block of flats by hypnosis in under a minute.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The local Council here have over fifty hypnosis-induced twenty-five story blocks, put up by El Mystico and Janet. I asked Mr Ken Verybigliar the advantages of hypnosis compared to other building methods.

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'MR K. V. B. LIAR'

dialogue.speaker: Mr Verybigliar
dialogue.text: Well there is a considerable financial advantage in using the services of El Mystico. A block, like Mystico Point here, would normally cost in the region of one-and-a-half million pounds. This was put up for five pounds and thirty bob for Janet.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But the obvious question is are they safe?

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'MR CLEMENT ONAN, ARCHITECT TO THE COUNCIL'

dialogue.speaker: Architect
dialogue.text: Of course they're safe. There's absolutely no doubt about that. They are as strong, solid and as safe as any other building method in this country provided of course people believe in them.

dialogue.speaker: Tenant
dialogue.text: Yes, we received a note from the Council saying that if we ceased to believe in this building it would fall down.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: You don't mind living in a figment of another man's imagination?

dialogue.speaker: Tenant
dialogue.text: No, it's much better than where we used to live.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Where did you used to live?

dialogue.speaker: Tenant
dialogue.text: We had an eighteen-roomed villa overlooking Nice.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Really, that sounds much better.

dialogue.speaker: Tenant
dialogue.text: Oh yes - yes you're right.

dialogue.speaker: Tenant
dialogue.text: No, no, no, of course not.

dialogue.speaker: Tenant
dialogue.text: Phew, that was close.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But the construction of these vast new housing developments, providing homes for many thousands of people, is not the only project to which he has applied his many talents. He also has an Infallible Pools Method, a School of Spanish Dancing and a Car Hire Service. What is the driving force behind a man of such restless energies, and boundless vision? Here as with so many great men of history, the answer lies in a woman... As Antony has his Cleopatra... as Napoleon has his Josephine... So Mystico has his Janet.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Yes. Janet ... a quiet, shy girl. An honours graduate from Harvard University, American junior sprint record holder, ex-world skating champion, Nobel Prize winner, architect, novelist and surgeon. The girl who helped crack the Oppenheimer spy ring in 1947. She gave vital evidence to the Senate Narcotics Commission in 1958. She also helped to convict the woman at the chemist's in 1961, and a year later she gave police information which led to the arrest of her postman. In October of that same year she secured the conviction of her gardener for bigamy and three months later personally led the police swoop on the couple next door. In 1967 she became suspicious of the man at the garage and it was her dogged perseverance and relentless enquiries that two years later finally secured his conviction for not having a licence for his car radio. He was hanged at Leeds a year later despite the abolition of capital punishment and the public outcry. Also in Leeds that year, a local butcher was hanged for defaulting on mortgage repayments, and a Mr Jarvis was electrocuted for shouting in the corridor.

dialogue.speaker: Swalk
dialogue.text: We admit that there have been outbreaks of hanging recently, but the police are trying to keep the situatuon under control. You must remember the courts are very busy at the moment and the odd death sentence is bound to slip through. Electrocutions are another big worry. But we hope that guillotining has been eradicated from the urban areas. and garrotting is confined almost entirely to Luton. So if you have a friend in prison or under the sentence of death, be sure to let us know at this address.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'THE POLICE FORCE, "SUNNYVIEW", YEOVIL, SOMERSET'

dialogue.speaker: First Radio Voice
dialogue.text: ... and Premier Chou En Lai, who called it 'a major breakthrough'. Twelve men were accidentally hanged at Whitby Assizes this afternoon whilst considering their verdict. This is one of the worst miscarriages of justice in Britain since Tuesday.

dialogue.speaker: DJ Voice
dialogue.text: Well it's thirteen minutes to the hour of nine-nine-nine, here on wonderful Radio One-One-One! So if you're still lying in your big big bed, now is the time to get up out of it! We've got another thirteen hours of tip-top sounds here on Wonderful Radio One! Sorry about that ... So unless you have brain cells, or have completed the process of evolution, there's a wonderful day ahead!

dialogue.speaker: Battersby
dialogue.text: It must be on Radio Four. Radio Two. ... Three ...

dialogue.speaker: Second Radio Voice
dialogue.text: It's 9 o'clock and time for 'Mortuary Hour'. An hour of talks, tunes and downright tomfoolery for all those who work in mortuaries, introduced as usual by Shirley Bassey. .

dialogue.speaker: Shirley
dialogue.text: Well, we're going to kick straight off this week with our Mortuary Quiz, so have your pens and pencils ready.

dialogue.speaker: Wang
dialogue.text: Turn that radio off and look lively!

dialogue.speaker: Battersby
dialogue.text: Oh, it's 'Mortuary Quiz', Mr Wang...

dialogue.speaker: Wang
dialogue.text: Don't argue, Battersby.

dialogue.speaker: Mayor
dialogue.text: ... This is our mortuary in here, Your Grace ...

dialogue.speaker: Peer
dialogue.text: I see, I see, I ... er ... I ... er ... I ... er ... I ... I can't think of anything to say about it.

dialogue.speaker: Mayor
dialogue.text: Well, we're very proud of it here, sir. It's one of the most up to date in the country.

dialogue.speaker: Peer
dialogue.text: I see... yes... yes ... now... um... what... what... ah... ah... what is it? .... is it a power station?

dialogue.speaker: Mayor
dialogue.text: No, Your Grace, it's a mortuary.

dialogue.speaker: Peer
dialogue.text: I see ... I see ... good ... good ... good, good, good...

dialogue.speaker: Mayor
dialogue.text: But it has one of the most advanced thermostat control systems in the country, and it has computer-controlled storage facilities.

dialogue.speaker: Peer
dialogue.text: I see, I see ... I ... er... er... er... er ... I ... er ... I'm a good little doggie.

dialogue.speaker: Mayor
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Your Grace?

dialogue.speaker: Peer
dialogue.text: I'm a good little dog.

dialogue.speaker: Attendant
dialogue.text: Oh dear...

dialogue.speaker: Mayor
dialogue.text: Perhaps we should postpone the visit?

dialogue.speaker: Attendant
dialogue.text: No, no, no - you see it's just that his brain is so tiny that the slightest movement can dislodge it Your Grace ... Oh dear... it's rather like one of those games you play where you have to get the ball into the hole ... That's it.

dialogue.speaker: Peer
dialogue.text: Ah! Now then, excellent, excellent, excellent, excellent. Now then ... ah ... what happens when the steel is poured into the ingots?

dialogue.speaker: Mayor
dialogue.text: Perhaps we should go and have a look at the new showers?

dialogue.speaker: Peer
dialogue.text: Yes... yes ... yes ... yes... yes rather jolly good... jolly good .. jolly good ... jolly good ... no fear...

dialogue.speaker: Radio Voice
dialogue.text: Well the answers were as follows: 1) the left hand, 2) no, 3) normal, 4) yes it has, in 1963 when a bird got caught in the mechanism. How did you get on?

dialogue.speaker: Wang
dialogue.text: Turn that thing off!

dialogue.speaker: Battersby
dialogue.text: Oh! It's 'Mortuary Dance Time', Mr Wang!

dialogue.speaker: Wang
dialogue.text: Never mind that, Battersby, this is the big one. I've just had Whitby Police on the phone with twelve hangees...

dialogue.speaker: Battersby
dialogue.text: Oh yes, I just heard about that on the radios ...

dialogue.speaker: Wang
dialogue.text: No, these are twelve different ones ... so shtoom.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: I'll not interrupt this sketch for a pound.

dialogue.speaker: Wang
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: For one pound I'll leave this sketch totally uninterrupted.

dialogue.speaker: Wang
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Fifty pence ... I'm prepared to negotiate a forty-pence deal. For 35p I won't interrupt any of the next three items.

dialogue.speaker: Wang
dialogue.text: No, no, it's no good...

dialogue.speaker: Wang
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: 10p and a kiss.

dialogue.speaker: Terry Gilliam
dialogue.text: You see, it's very simple - I just take these cut-out figures and by putting them together... oh, you mean we're on?... Sorry.

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'FINAL OF THE HIDE-AND-SEEK SECOND LEG'

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Hello, good afternoon and welcome to the second leg of the Olympic final of the men's Hide-and-Seek here in the heart of Britain's London. We'll be starting in just a couple of moments from now, and there you can see the two competitors Francisco Huron the Paraguayan, who in this leg is the seeker and there's the man he'll be looking for ... our own Don Roberts from Hinckley in Leicestershire who, his trainer tells me, is at the height of his self-secreting form. And now in the first leg, which ended on Wednesday, Don succeeded in finding the Paraguayan in the new world record time of 11 years, 2 months, 26 days, 9 hours, 3 minutes, 27.4 seconds, in a sweetshop in Kilmarnock. And now they're under starter's orders.

dialogue.speaker: Starter
dialogue.text: On your marks... get set...

dialogue.speaker: Francisco
dialogue.text: Uno, dos, tres, quattro, cinque, seis, siete, ocho, nueve, diez ...

dialogue.speaker: Francisco
dialogue.text: ... trientay dos, trientay tres, trientay quattro...

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Well Don's off to a really great start there. Remember the Paraguayan has got 11 years, 2 months, 26 days, 9 hours... 3 minutes, 27.4 seconds to beat.

dialogue.speaker: Francisco
dialogue.text: Neuvecian no nuevetay ocho, nuevecientas nuevente ye nueve, mil. Coming!

dialogue.speaker: Frank Bough
dialogue.text: Well, we'll be taking you back there as soon as there are any developments.

dialogue.speaker: Frank Bough
dialogue.text: We've just heard that something is happening in the Hide-and-Seek final, so let's go straight over there.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Hello again, and welcome to Madagascar, where Francisco Huron is seeking Don Roberts. And I've just been told that he has been told that he has been unofficially described as 'cold'. Ah, wait a minute. I've just been told that Huron has requested a plane ticket for Budapest! So he's definitely getting warmer. So we'll be back again in just a few years.

dialogue.speaker: Frank Bough
dialogue.text: Really beginning to hot up now.

script.description: CAPTION: 'FIVE YEARS, TWO MONTBS AND TWENTY-SIX DAYS LATER'

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: So here we are on the very last day of this fantastic final. Huron now has less than twelve hours left to find British ace Don Roberts. Early this morning he finished combing the outskirts of Lisbon and now he seems to have staked everything on one final desperate seek here in the Tagus valley. But Roberts is over fifteen hundred miles away, and it's beginning to look all over, bar the shouting. The sands of time are running out for this delving dago, this savior of seek, perspicacious Paraguayan. He's still desperately cold and it's beginning to look like another gold for Britain.

dialogue.speaker: Official
dialogue.text: The official result of the World Hide-and-Seek, Mr Don Roberts from Hinckley, Leicestershire, 11 years, 2 months, 26 days, 9 hours, 3 minutes, 27 seconds. Mr Francisco Huron, Paraguay, 11 years, a months, 26 days, 9 hours, 3 minutes, 27 seconds. The result - a tie.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: A tie! Well what a fantastic result. Well the replay will start tomorrow at 7.30 a.m.

dialogue.speaker: Redcoat
dialogue.text: Well hello again .... nice to be back ... glad to see the series has been doing well. Well now, sorry about Mon-trerx.

dialogue.speaker: Redcoat
dialogue.text: That was a little item entitled Hide-and-Seek - very anarchic, very effective, not quite my cup of tea, but very nice for the younger people. Well, the next item the boys have put together takes place in a sitting room. Sorry it's just a sitting room, but the bank account's a bit low after the appallingly expensive production of 'Clochmerle'...

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: This is a totally free interruption and no money has exchanged hands whatever.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Robinson
dialogue.text: Sorry about that, darling...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Robinson
dialogue.text: Gravy?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Robinson
dialogue.text: Yes please, dear.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Robinson
dialogue.text: Oh dear, that'll be the Cheap-Laughs from next door.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Robinson
dialogue.text: Come in.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Cheap-Laugh
dialogue.text: No! Just breathing heavily!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Cheap-Laugh
dialogue.text: Oh we just dropped in.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Robinson
dialogue.text: Would you like to come through...

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'ONE EVENING WITH THE CHEAP-LAUGHS LATER'

dialogue.speaker: Mr Cheap-Laugh
dialogue.text: Well goodnight and give us a kiss.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Cheap-Laugh
dialogue.text: Oh thank you very much for a very nice evening.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Cheap-Laugh
dialogue.text: After you, dear.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Robinson
dialogue.text: Oh honestly dear, why do we always have to buy everything just because the Cheap-Laughs have one?

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: This is not an interruption at all.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Robinson
dialogue.text: It's just neighbourliness dear, that's all...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Robinson
dialogue.text: I think we should try and lead our own lives from now on.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Robinson
dialogue.text: Can't you be serious for one moment?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Robinson
dialogue.text: I'm sorry I was cross earlier.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Robinson
dialogue.text: Oh that's all right, dear. It's just that I get so sick of always having to be like the Cheap-Laughs.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Robinson
dialogue.text: Well yes, from now on we'll be like ourselves.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Robinson
dialogue.text: Oh Roger...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Robinson
dialogue.text: Oh Beatrice.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Many people in this country are becoming increasingly worried about bull-fighting. They say it's not only cruel, vicious and immoral, but also blatantly unfair. The bull is heavy, violent, abusive and aggressive with four legs and great sharp teeth, whereas the bull-fighter is only a small, greasy Spaniard. Given this basic inequality what can be done to make bull-fighting safer? We asked Brigadier Arthur Farquar-Smith, Chairman of the British Well-Basically Club.

dialogue.speaker: Brigadier
dialogue.text: Well, basically it's quite apparent that these little dago chappies have got it all wrong. They prance round the bull like a lot of bally night club dancers looking like the Younger Generation or a less smooth version of the Lionel Blair Troupe, with much of the staccato rhythms of the Irving Davies Dancers at the height of their success. In recent years Pan's People have often recaptured a lyricism ... and what we must do now is to use devices like radar to locate the bull and SAM missiles fired from underground silos, to knock the bull over. Then I would send in Scottish boys with air cover to provide a diversion for the bull, whilst the navy came in round the back and finished him off. That to me would be bull-fighting and not this pansy kind of lyrical, evocative movement which George Balanchine and Martha Graham in the States and our very own Sadler's Wells ... Troops could also be used in an auxiliary role in international chess, where... What? ... oh...

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: I'll put the lights on again for a pound.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: This is the planet Algon, fifth world in the system of Aldebaran, the Red Giant in the constellation of Sagittarius. Here an ordinary cup of drinking chocolate costs four million pounds, an immersion heater for the hot-water tank costs over six billion pounds, and a pair of split-crotch panties would be almost unobtainable. A simple rear window de-misting device for an 1100 costs eight thousand million billion pounds and a new element for an electric kettle like this would cost as much as the entire gross national product of the United States of America from 1770 to the year 2000, and even then they wouldn't be able to afford the small fixing ring which attaches it to the kettle.

dialogue.speaker: M'Burke
dialogue.text: Well, our computers have been working all day to analyse the dramatic information that's come in from this first ever intergalactic probe, Algon I ... ... and we're just getting an interesting development now, which is that attachments for rotary mowers - that is mowers that have a central circular blade - are... relatively inexpensive! Still in the region of nine to ten million pounds, but it does seem to indicate that Algon might be a very good planet for those with larger gardens ... or perhaps even an orchard that's been left for two years, needs some heavy work, some weeding... But we're now getting some live pictures through from Algon! Harry - Perhaps you could talk us through them.

dialogue.speaker: Harry
dialogue.text: Very little evidence of shopping facilities here .. there don't seem to be any large supermarkets. There may be some on-the-corner grocery stores behind those rocks, but it's difficult to tell from this angle. It does seem to suggest that most of the shopping here is by direct mail.

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED TELEPRINTER CAPTION: 'DIGESTIVE BISCUITS; £8,OOO,OOO PER PACKET'

dialogue.speaker: M'Burke
dialogue.text: Of course the big question that everyone's asking here is, what about those split-crotch parities? Are they going to be unobtainable throughout the Universe or merely on Algon itself? Professor?

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'PROFESSOR HERMAN KHAN, DIRECTOR OF THE INSTITUTE OF SPLIT-CROTCH PANTIES'

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: We must remember that Algon is over 75,000 miles wide. The probes come down to this area here and we're really only getting signals from a radius of only thirty or forty miles around the probe. Split-crotch panties, or indeed any items of what we scientists call, 'Sexy Underwear' or 'Erotic Lingerie' may be much more plentiful on other parts of the planet.

dialogue.speaker: M'Burke
dialogue.text: Professor, you were responsible for finding Scanty-Panties and Golden Goddess High-Lift Bras on planets which were never thought able to sustain life, and now that man has discovered a new galaxy do you think we're going to see underwear become even naughtier?

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: Oh naughtier and naughtier.

script.description: SUPERIMPOSED TELEPRINTER CAPTION: 'NO BANANAS ON ALGON'

dialogue.speaker: M'Burke
dialogue.text: Well so much for that ... But of course, the probe itself has excited a great deal of interest... for it contains uranium-based dual transmission cells entirely re-charged by solar radiation, which can take off a bra and panties in less than fifteen seconds. It is, of course, the first piece of space hardware to be specially designed to undress ladies, and so there are bound to be some teething troubles ... such as how to cope with the combination of elastic-sided boots and tights.

dialogue.speaker: M'Burke
dialogue.text: But I think we're getting some pictures now from Algon itself, and it looks as though ... yes! The satellite has found a bird! The probe has struck crumpet and she looks pretty good too! Professor?

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: Ja - she's a real honey!

dialogue.speaker: M'Burke
dialogue.text: Well the pictures are a bit sporadic... I think probably... the solar radiation during the long journey to Algon... Hoy! Look! Oh dear, I'm sorry we've lost contact. We'll try and re-establish contact with Algon...

dialogue.speaker: Badger
dialogue.text: Hello... The BBC have offered me the sum of forty pence to read the credits of this show. Personally I thought they should have held out for the full seventy-five, but the BBC have explained to me about their financial difficulties and ... er ... I decided to accept the reduced offer... so ... the show was conceived, written and performed by... the usual lot... Also appearing were Carol Cleveland, Marie Anderson, Mrs Idle, Make-up - Madelaine Gaffney, Costume - Hazel Pethig, Animations by Terry Gilliam, Visual Effects Designer - Bernard Wilkie, Graphics - Bob Blagden, Film Cameraman - Alan Featherstone, Film Editor - Ray Millichope, Sound - Richard Chubb, Lighting - Bill Bailey, Designer - Bob Berk, Produced by Ian MacNaughton for 92p and a bottle of Bells whisky ... it was a BBC colour production. That's just it. I'd like to say if there are any BBC producers looking in who need people to read the credits for them, I would personally...

annotations: Fade up on two pilots in the cockpit of an aeroplane. A stewardess is there too. After a moment or two the first pilot makes an announcement.
The door of the cockpit opens and Mr Badger comes in.
(rubs it)
(closes eyes and thinks)
(opens eyes)
Enter a man with headphones.
(they start to leave)

The nude organist is seated at his organ in the open air, with a lovely scarlet dressing-gown draped round his shoulders. It says on it 'Noel Coward' which is crossed out and 'Nude Organist' written underneath. He is holding forth to a journalist with a notepad who is nodding and interviewing him. Someone else holds a small tape recorder. Make-up ladies are adding the finishing touches. They bring him a mirror while he talks. Someone is taking photos of him, perhaps with flashbulbs.

They realize that they are on camera. They remove the man's robe and clear the set. He grins at the camera and plays his chords. Cut to the announcer. He is sitting at his desk in the middle of a field but he is talking earnestly to a trendy girl reporter.
Animated titles.
(and CAPTION:)
Black screen and the sound of a ticking clock for ten seconds.
(and CAPTION:)
Cut to a little palm court set. A man seated.
(consults his watch)
Cut to a building site. The camera pans over it.

By, this time the pan has come to rest on a section of the site where various nineteenth-century literary figures are at work round a cement mixer: two ladies in crinolines, Bob Cratchett on his father's back, Heathcliff and Catherine throwing bricks to each other with smouldering passion, Nelson, Mr Beadle as foreman. Cut to the interior of a half-finished concrete shell. A little girl is working on top of a ladder.
(shot of complicated electrical wiring in some impressive electrical installation)
(cut to Arthur Huntingdon studying a plan; he has a builder's safety helmet on)

Cut to a close up of big pre-fabricated concrete slabs being hoisted into the air by a crane and start to pull out, as the commentator speaks, to reveal a crowd of nineteenth-centuty farmhands working on them.

Pan to reveal Mrs Jupp with a clipboard. Cut to voice over narrator in vision with a stick-mike, in front of an impressive piece of motorway interchange building. Behind him and working on the site are six angels, three devils, and Adam and Eve.
He turns and we zoom past him into the angels etc.
(voice over)
Cut to a foreman in a donkey jacket and helmet.
The camera tracks through a high-rise development area.

Mystico removes his cloak, gloves and top hat and hands them to Janet, who curtsies. He then makes several passes. Cut to stock film of flats falling down reversed so that they leap up. Cut back to Mystico and Janet. She hands him back his things as they make their way to their car, a little Austin 30.
Cut to a man in a drab suit.
(indicating a high-rise block behind him)
Cut to an architect's office. The architect at his desk. Behind him on the wall are framed photos of various collapsed buildings. He is a well-dressed authoritative person.
Cut to a council flat. On the wall there is a picture of Mystico.
Cut to stock shot of block falling down in slow motion. Cut back to tenant and wife inside. Camera shaking and on the tilt.
Cut to stock film again. The building rights itself. Cut back to interior again. Camera slightly on tilt. They are holding bits of crockery etc.
Cut to tracking shot from back of camera car again. This time El Mystico striding through the towering blocks, his cloak swirling behind him.
(cut to Mystico at wheel of his little Austin 30, his amazing eyes riveted on the road ahead; Janet occasiona1ly tactfully guides the steering wheel)
(the camera pans over on to Janet and starts to zoom in on her as she watches the road ahead; cut to a nineteenth-century engraving of Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra)
(cut to picture of Napoleon and Josephine)
(cut to Janet lying on a bed in a negligie in a rather seedy hotel)

Mystico leaps from top of the wardrobe on to the bed with a lusty yell. Cut to montage of black and white photos of Janet in various stage poses: three poses against black drapes; one against a building; one posed outside a terrace house with notice reading 'School of Spanish Dancing - Dentures Repaired'.
(cut to Janet shaking hands with a police commissioner)
(cut to photo of Janet with a judge and a policeman standing on either side of her smiling at the camera)
(cut to Janet in a street with goggles of policemen clustering round her grinning at the camera and two people obviously naked with blankets thrown over them)
(cut to a photo of a petrol attendant filling a car)
(another rather fuzzy photo of the man at the garage peering through the window of cash kiosk)
(final photo of five police, Janet and the man from the garage in handcuffs all posing for the camera)
(cut to Janet posing outside a prison)
(cut to a blurred family snap of a butcher in an apron with a knife)
(photo)
Cut to Superintendent Harry 'Boot-in' Swalk'
(his personal two-way radio is making rather a noise)
(claps his hand over the radio to little avail)
(and CAPTION:)

Cut to a mortuary. Various trolleys lie about with corpses covered by sheets. Two workers are sitting at a low make-shift table with cups of tea and a transistor radio, shelling eggs and dropping them in a pickling jar.
(music)
(brief funny noises)
(switching the radio off)
(he gets another radio out from underneath the table)
(he gets another radio out)
(he opens the top of the third radio and gets out a fourth; he switches it on)
(sinister chords)
A door at the back of the mortuary opens and Mr Wang, an official of the Department of Stiffs, enters. He wears an undertaker's suit and top hat plus a long blond wig.
We hear voices off. Officials at the door spring to attention. Enter a mayor with a chain round his neck, and an elderly peer of the realm who is standing on a small platform, pushed by an attendant.
(starts to slap the duke's head from side to side gently but firmly)
(ushering everyone out)
They leave. Battersby turns the radio on again.
Two men behind him push in a trolley with sheet-covered corpses on it.
Battersby and friend gather round the body. Wang joins them. They start to work away busily and eficiently on the corpse. We suddenly become aware that Badger is standing with them around the body.
(an eye peers out from under the sheet on the corpse they are working on)

The corpse is now sitting up waiting to see what happens. Another corpse sits up as they continue arguing. The sheet is pushed back on another trolley revealing a boy and girl on the same stretcher. They light cigarettes.
with Gilliam's hands in shot.
(voice over)
(Gilliam's head appears briefly)
The animated sketch starts. Then cut to Trafalgar Square. The Olympic symbol is superimposed briefly.
Zoom in on commentator and the two finalists, forty-year-old men limbering up in shorts and singlets.
(we see Francisco Huron darting about, looking behind things)
(we see Don Roberts practising hiding)
We see Don Roberts and Francisco Huron standing side by side, poised, looking nervous.
(voice over)
The starter fires his pistol. Francisco Huron immediately puts his hands over eyes and starts counting.
Meanwhile Don Roberts hails a cab. He gets in and it drives off.
(cut to taxi on the way to London airport)
Cut back to Francisco still counting.
(Francisco takes his hands from his eyes and shouts)

He starts looking around the immediate locality suspiciously. We see a plane landing. There is a sign saying 'Benvenuto a Sardinia'. Cut to Don on a bicycle. Then running up a hill. Then going into castle. Running along corridors and eventualy pausing, looking around agitatedly, and then hiding behind a pillar. Occasionally he looks out nervously. Then cut to Francisco looking in shops in the Tottenham Court Road. Cut to studio 'Sportsview' desk with a Frank Bough man at it.
Cut back to desk. Frank Bough looks older.
Cut to film of Francisco Huron. He is wandering around looking for Don Roberts in a beach setting. The commentator is some way from him. He speaks quietly into a microphone.
(in the distance Francisco Huron consults with an official; the commentator moves out of shot briefly, then returns)
Cut to Frank Bough looking older. He is covered with cobwebs.
Cut to a Portuguese-looking setting. Francisco Huron looking round desperately and glancing at his watch.

The camera shows Huron creeping up on a dustbin. He pauses, snatches off the lid and looks inside. He turns away disappointed then does double take and looks back into the bin. He pulls out a sardine tin with the word 'Sardines' very obvious. Shot of Huron's reaction as he suddenly gets a tremendous idea. He snaps his fingers and hails a taxi and gets in. Cut to plane landing. Same sign as before 'Benvenuto a Sardinia'. Francisco cycles past. Cut to him discarding the bike and running up the hill straight into the castle. He runs along corridors into the right room, up to the pillar and finds Don Roberts skulking behind. They both look very tense as they await the official result, then react in fury and frustration when it is announced by a blazered offical.
As they stand there the camera pans off them to a window and then zooms through the window to reveal a beach where there is a Redcoat.
At this point two men run past in the background carrying a donkey. A third runs behind carrying a sign saying 'Donkey Rides' and winking and pointing at the donkey, they run out of picture.
He is hit by Mr Robinson with a chicken. Robinson walks away and we follow him as he passes Badger in the foreground.

The camera doesn't pause at all on Badger and we continue panning with Robinson until he reaches the knight in amour. He hands the chicken to the knight. He walks away from knight and into the distance. Mix through to a modern sitting room. Mrs Robinson is eating alone at the table looking at the clock.
(he sits)
She serves him some vegetables. He unfolds his napkin.
They sit and eat in silence. Suddenly the doorbell rings.

Various different doorbell sounds and chimes. Mr Robinson goes to the front door, and opens it. Standing outside are Mr and Mrs Cheap-Laugh. He is wearing a big floppy comedian's suit and a big bow tie and fright wig. She is a Mrs Equator sort of lady, with an enormous hairstyle, and dressed in very bad taste.
He and his wife roar with laughter. As he comes in he slips and falls on the mat. His wife puts a custard pie in his face. More roars of laughter.
We mix through to the exterior of a house at night. Shrieks of laughter, crushes of crockery. The two men with the donkey run past in road, the third man behind pointing to the sign.
The light comes on in hall. Cut to them in the hall at the front door.
(kisses Mrs Robinson)

He trips her up and she falls out into the darkness. We hear her shriek with laughter. Mr Cheap-Laugh drops his trousers, makes lavatory chain pulling sign and noise and hurls himself out after wife and disappears into the darkness. More laughter. The host shuts the door. They heave a sigh of relief and go back into the sitting room. The crockery on the table is all smashed in a heap on the floor with the table cloth. The standard lamp is broken in half. There are large splodges of food and wine splashes on the walls. Some glasses and a moustache are drawn on the Tretchikoff picture of the Chinese girl. Mrs Robinson flops down on the sofa. There is a farting cushion. She removes it, irritated.
He goes over to the wall cupboard for drinks. A bucket of whitewash is balanced on the half-open door. He opens the cupboard and the bucket of whitewash falls on him. Cut briefly to Mr Badger.
Cut back to Mr Robinson. He pours himself a drink, without reacting to the whitewash.
She opens a sewing box and a boxing glove on a spring comes out and hits her on the chin.
He sits on the pouffe. The sixteen-ton weight falls on him. Cut to the exterior of the house. The lights go off downstairs and upstairs. The two men run past carrying a pantomime goose.
Cut to a darkened bedroom. Mr and Mrs Robinson are in a double bed, talking.

The bed springs up and folds into the back wall of the bedroom. On the underneath of the bed is a presenter on a chair. The underneath of the bed also consists of a flat as for current affairs-type programme, with 'Probe' written above narrator.
Cut to a brigadier.
(getting rather camp)
(a huge hammer strikes him on the head; he becomes butch again)
(getting camp)
(the hammer strikes him on the head again)
(the lights go off)
(voice over)
Cut to an animated sketch, and then to a strange moonlike landscape. Eerie science-fiction music plays in the background.
(cut to a budget-day-type graphic, with a picture of the product and the price alongside)
(picture of electric kettle)
(graphic of American GNP)
(graphic of an electric kettle showing all the separate pieces detatched from each other, arrow points to the fixing ring)

Cut to James M'Burke sitting at a desk. 'Algon I' motifs everywhere. Another expert stands by a model of the planet, and there is a panel of experts at a long desk who are all obviously dummies. Everyone has one of those single earphones.
(suddenly very excited as he hears something over his earphone)
(very, indistinct pictures start to come through on the screen behind him)
Cut into pictures from Algon.
Very fuzzy pictures of the Algon landscape. Panning and tracking shots hand held.
(voice over)
Cut to James M'Burke.
Cut to a professor sitting beside a contour model of an area of Algon. It has a little model of the probe marking where it has landed.
Camera pans to include M'Burke.
He produces the bottom half of a tailor's dummy wearing boots and tights with panties over the tights halfway down. On the screen behind, more dim indecipherable TV pictures from Algon.
All we see on the screen is a blurred female figure.
(the screen goes blank)
Cut to presenter's-type chair. Mr Badger appears at side of screen.
(sits)
(the signature tune is heard)
The camera pulls out to reveal the sixteen-ton weight poised above him. As the picture fades the weight falls on him.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 34

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: August 18th. Fell off near Bovey Tracey. The pump caught in my trouser leg.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: The pump caught in my trouser leg, and my sandwiches were badly crushed.

dialogue.speaker: Proprietor
dialogue.text: 35p please.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: These sandwiches, however, were an excellent substitute.

dialogue.speaker: Driver
dialogue.text: Give us ten woods, Barney.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Hello! It's funny how one can go through life, as I have, disliking bananas and being indifferent to cheese, and then be able to eat, and enjoy, a banana and cheese sandwich like this.

dialogue.speaker: Proprietor
dialogue.text: 35p please.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Ah! I have only a fifty. Do you have change?

dialogue.speaker: Proprietor
dialogue.text: Well I'll have a look, but I may have to go to the bank.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I'm most awfully sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, what a stroke of luck. Well, all the very best. And thank you again for the excellent banana and cheese delicacy.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: August 23rd. Fell off near Budleigh Salterton.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: ...and the pump caught in my trouser leg... ...and that's how they were damaged... ...the eggs...you remember...the hard-boiled eggs I was telling you about...they were in a tupperware container, reputedly self-sealing, which fell open upon contact with the tarmacadam surface of the road.... ...the B489...the Dawlish road... That shouldn't really happen to a self-sealing container, should it? What do you keep your hard-boiled eggs in?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I think in future I shall lash them to the handlebars with adhesive tape...this should obviate a recurrence of the same problem...well I can't stop here all day...I'm on a cycling tour of North Cornwall. Must be off.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: August 26th. Fell off near Ottery St Mary. The pump caught in my trouser leg. Decided to wear short trousers from now on.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Fell off near Tiverton. Perhaps a shorter pump is the answer.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Excuse me, madam, I wonder if you could tell me of a good bicycle shop in this village, where I could find either a means of adapting my present pump, or failing that, purchase a replacement?

dialogue.speaker: Old lady
dialogue.text: There's only one shop here.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: What a stroke of luck. Now perhaps cycling will become less precarious.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Yes? (a nurse puts her head round the door)

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: A Mr Pither to see you, doctor. His bicycle pump got caught in his sock.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Oh, thank you nurse, show him in please.

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: This way, please.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Morning.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, a very good morning to you too, Doctor

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Ah, I understand you had an accident?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Yes, my pump got...

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: ...caught in your sock.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Absolutely. Yes. My fruit cake was damaged on one side.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Well...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: It's got grit all over it.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Well now, are you in pain?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, heavens no.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Ah well, where were you hurt?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, fortunately, I escaped without injury.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Well what is the trouble?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Please, could you tell me the way to Iddesleigh?

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: I'm a doctor, you know.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh yes, absolutely. Normally I would have asked a policeman or a minister of the Church, but finding no one available, I thought it better to consult a man with some professional qualifications, rather than rely on the possibly confused testimony of a passer-by.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Oh alright. Take this to a chemist.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: September 2nd. Did not fall off outside Iddesley.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Fell off in Tavistock.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: My foot caught in my trouser leg and that's how the bottle broke.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Tell her today, you could ring her.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I can't. I can't.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I said you'd never guess.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Sixteen years we've been together. I can't just ring her up.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Well, if you can't do it now, you never will.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Do you like Tizer?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What? No. No.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Do you want me or not, James? It's your decision.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I suppose it is still available in this area, is it?

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Do you want me or not, James?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Tizer.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Yes or no.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Is it still available in this area?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: I see, in that case it's goodbye for ever, James.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No! I mean yes!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh it is, is it?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Oh! You never could make up your mind.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I can.... I have....

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Goodbye James.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No wait, Lucille!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Does your lovely daughter like Tizer? Eh?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Lucille!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Wouldn't mind buying her a bottle of Tizer.... if it's available in this area, that is.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Would you like me to show you the door?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, that's extremely kind of you, but I saw it on the way in.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You stupid, interfering little rat.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh! The very words of the garage mechanic in Bude!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I had just fallen off my bicycle, this is most kind of you, and my lemon curd tartlet had...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Damn your lemon curd tartlet!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Just had a chat with your dad.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: My rubber instep caught on the rear mudguard stanchion and...

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Really? And what happened to the corned beef rolls?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: The corned beef rolls squashed out of all...here, how did you know about the corned beef rolls?

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: I noticed them - or what remained of them - in the road. I noticed also that the lemon curd tart had sustained some superficial damage.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: That's right. The curd had become...

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Detached from the pastry base.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Absolutely right, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Otherwise the contents of the sandwich box were relatively unharmed, although I detected small particles of bitumen in the chocolate kup kakes.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: But they were wrapped in foil!

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Not the hard chocolate top, I'm afraid.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, that's the bit I like.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: The sausage roll, the crisps and ginger bisquit were unscathed.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: How do you know so much about cycling?

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Well, I'm making a special study of accidents involving food.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Yes, do you know that in our laboratories, we have developed a cheese sandwich that can withstand an impact of 4,000 pounds per square inch?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Good heavens!

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Amazing, isn't it? We have also developed a tomato which can eject itself when an accident is imminent.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Even if it's inside an egg and tomato roll?

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Anywhere! Even if it's in your stomach, and it senses an accident it will come up your throat and out of the window. Do you realise what this means?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Safer food?

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Exactly! No longer will food be squashed, crushed and damaged, by the ignorance and stupidity of the driver! Whole picnics will be built to withstand the most enormous forces! Snacks will be safer than ever! An simple pot of salad dressing, treated in our laboratories, has been subjected to the impact of a 4,000 pound steam hammer every day for the last sixteen years and has it broken?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Er....well...

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Yes, of course it has...but there are other ideas - the safety straps for sardines for instance.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Here, that tomato just ejected itself.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Really? It works! It works!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: What a strange turn this cycling tour has taken. Mr Gulliver appears to have lost his memory and far from being interested in safer food is now convinced that he is Clodagh Rogers, the young girl singer. I am taking him for medical attention.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Is this the Casualty Department?

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: Yes, that's right.

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: And what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I am at present on a cycling tour of the North Cornwall area taking in Bude and...

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: Could I have your name please?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Ah, my name is Pither.

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
