dialogue.text: P-I-T-H-E-R ...as in Brotherhood, but with PI instead of the BRO and no HOOD.

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: I see...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I had just visited Taunton...

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: Sh!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: ...and was cycling north towards...

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: Yes, where were you injured?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Just where the A397 Ilfracombe road meets the...

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: On your ...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Ah no... it's not I who was injured, it's my friend.

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: Tut... Name?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Pither.

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no. Your friend's name.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, Clodagh Rogers...

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: Clodagh Rogers!?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Well only since about 4:30....

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: Yes. I think you'd better talk to Doctor Wu... Doctor!

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: What? Damn!

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: Aaaaaagh!

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Now, what's the trouble?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I am on a cycling tour of...

dialogue.speaker: Nurse
dialogue.text: He he's had an accident.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I have friend who, as a result of his injuries thinks he is Clodagh Rogers.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: He what?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Well, what happened was...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: September 4th. Well I never. We are now in the Alpes Maritimes region of Southern France. Clodagh seems more intent on reaching Moscow than on rehearsing her new BBC2 series with Buddy Rich and the Younger Generation... Oh hello!

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: We cannot stay here. We must leave immediately. There is a ship in Marseilles.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I did enjoy your song for Europe, Clodagh.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: I have seen an agent in the town. My life is in danger.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Danger, Clodagh?

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Stalin has always hated me.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: No one hates you, Clodagh.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: I will not let myself fall into the hands of these scum.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I think you should go and have a little lie down, my dear. There is a busy day tomorrow of concerts and promotional tours.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: I. One of the founders of the greatest nation on earth. I! Whom Lenin has called his greatest friend.

dialogue.speaker: M. Brun
dialogue.text: Taisez-vous. Taisez-vous.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh dear.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: I! Who have worked all my life that my people should live.

dialogue.speaker: M. Brun
dialogue.text: Taisez-vous. Qu'est-ce que le bruit? C'est impossible!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Er... my name is Pither.

dialogue.speaker: M. Brun
dialogue.text: Oh... you are English?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Er yes, that's right. I'm on a cycling tour of North Cornwall, taking in Bude...

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: I will not be defeated. I will return to my country to fight against this new tyranny!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: This is Clodagh Rogers, the Irish-born girl singer.

dialogue.speaker: Mme. Brun
dialogue.text: Mais oui - c'est Clodagh Rogers - 'Jack-in-a-box'! I'm just a jack in a box, I know whenever love knocks... Genevieve! Gerard! C'est Clodagh Rogers la fameuse chanteuse Anglaise.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: I will never surrender! I will never surrender!...

dialogue.speaker: Genevieve
dialogue.text: Excusez-moi Madame Clodagh. Ecrivez-vous votre nom dans mon livre des hommes célèbrites, s'il vous plait. Là, au-dessous de Denis Compton. Maman! Ce n'est pas la belle Clodagh.

dialogue.speaker: Mme. Brun
dialogue.text: Quoi?

dialogue.speaker: Genevieve
dialogue.text: C'est Trotsky le révolutionaire.

dialogue.speaker: M. Brun
dialogue.text: Trotsky!

dialogue.speaker: Mme. Brun
dialogue.text: Mais Trotsky ne chante pas.

dialogue.speaker: M. Brun
dialogue.text: Il chante un peu.

dialogue.speaker: Mme. Brun
dialogue.text: Mais pas professionalement. Qu'il pense de Lenin.

dialogue.speaker: M. Brun
dialogue.text: Ah! Lenin!! Quel chanteur: 'If I ruled the world'.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Lenin. My friend. I come.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh excuse her, she's not very well recently, pressure of work, laryngitis, you know...

dialogue.speaker: M. Brun
dialogue.text: Et aussi Monsieur Kerensky avec le 'Little White Bull', eh?

dialogue.speaker: Mme. Brun
dialogue.text: Formidable.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Lenin! I come! Lenin!

dialogue.speaker: Frenchman
dialogue.text: Je t'aime.

dialogue.speaker: French Girl
dialogue.text: Maurice! Regardez! C'est la chanteuse anglaise Clodagh Rogers.

dialogue.speaker: Frenchman
dialogue.text: Ah mais oui! Jacques dans la boîte

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: After several days I succeeded in tracking down my friend Mr Gulliver on the outskirts of Smolensk.

dialogue.speaker: Military Man
dialogue.text: Smolensk. 200 miles east of Minsk. 200 north of Kursk. 1500 miles west of Omsk.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Anyway, as we were so far from home, and as Mr Gulliver, still believing himself to be Trotsky, was very tired from haranguing the masses all the way from Monte Carlo,

dialogue.speaker: Military Man
dialogue.text: Monte Carlo. 100 miles south of Turin. 100 east of Pisa. 500 miles west of Bilbao.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Thank you. I decided to check...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I decided to check...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: No, sorry you go on.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I decided to check him into a hotel while I visited the British Embassy to ask for help in returning to Cornwall.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: And so we registered at the Smolensk Young Men's Anti-Christian Association.

dialogue.speaker: Military Man
dialogue.text: YMACA. Corner of Anti-Semitic Street and Pogrom Square.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Go away. No, not you. A single room for my friend please.

dialogue.speaker: Desk Clerk
dialogue.text: Yes, sir. Bugged or unbugged?

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: I think I'd be happier with a bugged one.

dialogue.speaker: Desk Clerk
dialogue.text: Right, one bugged with bath.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Well, just have a nice lie down, and I'll go to the Embassy.

dialogue.speaker: Desk Clerk
dialogue.text: Trotsky! My lack of God, it's Trotsky!

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Comrades. Socialism is not a...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Excuse me. Is this the British Consulate?

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Yes yes... si si...that is correctment. Yes... Piccadilly Circus, mini-skirt and Joe Lyons.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: I wish to see the consul, please.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, speakee speakee... me Blitish consul.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh! You are Rear Admiral Sir Dudley Compton?

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: No. He died. He have heart attack and fell out of window onto exploding bomb, and was killed in a shooting accident. I...I his how you say...succ...sussor.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, successor.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: I'm his successor, Mr Atkinson.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Would you like drinkee? Or game bingo?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Well.... A drink would be very nice.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Mr. Livingstone. Go and get sake.

dialogue.speaker: Livingstone
dialogue.text: Yes, Boss.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: How is Tonblidge Wells? How I long to see again walls of famous Shakespeare-style theatre in Stlatford-on-Avon.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh well, I'm a West Country man myself, Mr. Atkinson.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Oh Texas - Arizona - Kit Carson Super Scout.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: No. No. West of England... Cornwall.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Coron... worll...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Cornwall.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Coronworl...oh yes know Coronworl very well. Went to school there, mother and father live there, ah yes. Go many weekend parties and polo playing cards in blidge club. Belong many clubs in Coronworld.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Ah, Mr Livingstone thank you, sake and bakewells tart. Well, chaps, buttocks up!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Rather.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Now then er... er...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Ah, Pither.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Ah Mr Pither. We Blitish here in Smolensk velly intellested in cliket.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, cricket?

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: No, no...you not speak English velly wells. Not clicket - clicket...clicketty click...clicket...housey housey...er, bingo.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Bingo...

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Oh bingo...bingo...bingo.

dialogue.speaker: Livingstone
dialogue.text: Bingo! Bingo!

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Hsai! Solly. Our boys got velly excited.

dialogue.speaker: Livingstone
dialogue.text: Bingo.

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Shut face! Mr Pither, perhaps you could put in a good word for so we could join a very smart bingo club in Coronworl.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Well, it's not really my line...

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: We all velly quiet at back, not say anything except shout 'Housey! Housey!'

dialogue.speaker: Livingstone
dialogue.text: Housey! Housey!

dialogue.speaker: Maoists
dialogue.text: Housey! Housey!

dialogue.speaker: Chinese Hordes
dialogue.text: Housey! Housey! Housey housey!

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Hi skwwati niyhi, keo t'sin feh t'sdung, hih watai bingo cards!

dialogue.speaker: Livingstone
dialogue.text: Nihi watai bingo cards?

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Nihi watai!

dialogue.speaker: Livingstone
dialogue.text: Ah so...

dialogue.speaker: Chinaman
dialogue.text: Now then, Mr Pither, tell me which better - Hackney Star Bingo or St. Albans Top Rank Suite?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Well, I was hoping that you could help me and my friend to get back to England as...you see we're on a cycling tour of North Cornwall...

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Bingo, bingo, bingo...

dialogue.speaker: Chinese Hordes
dialogue.text: Bingo! Bingo! Bingo! Bingo!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Is Mr Trotsky in his room, please?

dialogue.speaker: Desk Clerk
dialogue.text: No. He has gone to Moscow.

dialogue.speaker: Military Man
dialogue.text: Moscow. 1500 miles south of...

dialogue.speaker: Desk Clerk
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Moscow!

dialogue.speaker: Grip
dialogue.text: Come with us, please.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, who are you?

dialogue.speaker: Bag
dialogue.text: Well we're not secret police anyway.

dialogue.speaker: Wallet
dialogue.text: That's for sure.

dialogue.speaker: Grip
dialogue.text: If anything we are ordinary Soviet systems with no particular interest in politics.

dialogue.speaker: Bag
dialogue.text: None at all. Come with us.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, where are you taking me?

dialogue.speaker: Wallet
dialogue.text: What do we tell him?

dialogue.speaker: Grip
dialogue.text: Don't tell him any secrets.

dialogue.speaker: Bag
dialogue.text: Agreed.

dialogue.speaker: Grip
dialogue.text: Tell him anything except that we are taking him to Moscow where Trotsky is reunited with the Central Committee.

dialogue.speaker: Wallet
dialogue.text: We're taking you to a clambake.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh a clambake! I've never been to one of those.

dialogue.speaker: Grip
dialogue.text: Right, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: Bag
dialogue.text: Who's giving the orders round here?

dialogue.speaker: Grip
dialogue.text: I am. I'm senior to you.

dialogue.speaker: Bag
dialogue.text: No, you're not. You're a greengrocer, I'm an insurance salesman.

dialogue.speaker: Grip
dialogue.text: Greengrocers are senior to insurance salesmen.

dialogue.speaker: Wallet
dialogue.text: Cool it. I'm an ice-cream salesmen and I am senior to both of you.

dialogue.speaker: Bag
dialogue.text: You're an ice-cream salesman? I thought you were a vetenarian.

dialogue.speaker: Wallet
dialogue.text: I got promoted. Let's go.

dialogue.speaker: Bag
dialogue.text: Taxi!

dialogue.speaker: Taxi
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Bag
dialogue.text: Drive us to Moscow.

dialogue.speaker: Taxi
dialogue.text: I have no a cab.

dialogue.speaker: Wallet
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Taxi
dialogue.text: I'm in the Secret Police.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: ...Dostoievye useye tovarich trotsky borodina SUBTITLE: 'THIS IS THE MAN WHO BROUGHT OUR BELOVED TROTSKY BACK TO US' General Beluntanks dretsky mihai ovna isky Mr Reg Pither. SUBTITLE: 'FIRST MAY I PRESENT MR PITHER FROM WEST OF ENGLAND' General Shi muska di scensand dravenka oblomov Engleska Solzhenitzhin. SUBTITLE: 'FORGIVE ME IF I CONTINUE IN ENGLISH IN ORDER TO SAVE TIME' General And now, Comrades, the greatest moment of the day, the moment when I ask you to welcome the return of one of Russia's greatest heroes, creator of the Red Army, Lenin's greatest friend, Lev Davidovich Trotsky! Gulliver Comrades. Bolsheviks. Friends of the Revolution. I have returned. The bloodstained shadow of Stalinist repression is past. I bring you new light of Permanent Revolution . Comrades, I may once have been ousted from power, I may have been expelled from the party in 1927, I may have been deported in 1929 but I'm just an old-fashioned girl, with an old-fashioned mind. Comrades, I don't want to destroy in order to build, I don't want a state founded on hate and division I want an old-fashioned house with an old-fashioned fence, and an old-fashioned millionaire. Pither Our friend Mr Gulliver was clearly undergoing another change of personality. General So! You have duped us. You shall pay for this. Guards, seize him. General Shall I seize him too? Senior General No, I think we'll have to keep him, he's going down well. General He's more fun than he used to be. Senior General He's loosened up a lot. This is an old Lenin number. Pither April 26th. Thrown into Russian cell. Severely damaged my Mars bar. Shall I ever see Bude Bus station again? Oh excuse me... Pither What a pleasant exercise yard. How friendly they were all being. Officer Cigarettes? Pither Oh, no thank you I don't smoke. Pither After a few minutes I perceived a line of gentlemen with rifles. They were looking in my direction... I looked around but could not see the target. Officer Blindfold? Pither No thank you, no. Officer Slowotny! Grydenka... Verschnitzen. Messenger Nyet! Nyet! Nyet! Officer A telegram? From the Kremlin! The Central Committee! It says...'Carry on with the execution'. Verschnitzen... Pither Now I was really for it. Officer How could you miss? Soldier He moved. Officer Shut up! Go and practise. I'm so sorry. Do you mind waiting in your cell? Pither What a stroke of luck. My Crunchie was totally intact. I settled down to a quick intermeal snack... Officer Next time. Definitely! Now then, how many of them have been injured? Oh God... Pither As I lay dwon to the sound of the Russian gentlemen practising their shooting, I realised I was in a bit of a pickle. My heart sank as I realised I should never see the Okehampton by-pass again... Mother Come on, dear. Wake up dear. Pither Mother! Mother Come on dear. Pither So, it was all a dream. Mother No dear, is the dream, you're still in the cell. Officer OK, we're going to have another try. I think we've got it now. My boys have been looking down the wrong bit, you see. Pither Oh no, look, you've got to look down the bit there. Officer Oh I thought you had to look down that bit. Pither No, no, you've got to look down that bit, or you won't hit anything. Officer Alright, we'll give it a whirl. Guards, seize him. Officer Listen. You've got to look down this bit. Compère Osledi Osledi. Compère Eartha Kitt! Heath's Voice Trade Union leaders - I would say this - we've done our part. Now, on behalf of the community, we have a right to expect you, the Trade Union leaders, to do yours. Gulliver That turnip's certainly not safe. Oh no! Mr Pither! Mr Pither! Gulliver Mr Pither! Mr Pither! Gulliver Mr Pither! Pither's Voice Here! Pither Gulliver. Gulliver Pither! What a stroke of luck. Pither Well yes and no. CAPTION: 'SCENE MISSING' Pither Phew, what an amazing escape. Well goodbye, Reginald. Gulliver Goodbye, Mr Pither, and good luck with the tour! Hey, I think he's finally gone! Second Monster Ooh yes! First Monster Ready, Maurice? Second Monster Right-ho, Kevin. Let's go. First Monster All right, maestro, hit it!

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: ...Dostoievye useye tovarich trotsky borodina

script.description: SUBTITLE: 'THIS IS THE MAN WHO BROUGHT OUR BELOVED TROTSKY BACK TO US'

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Beluntanks dretsky mihai ovna isky Mr Reg Pither.

script.description: SUBTITLE: 'FIRST MAY I PRESENT MR PITHER FROM WEST OF ENGLAND'

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Shi muska di scensand dravenka oblomov Engleska Solzhenitzhin.

script.description: SUBTITLE: 'FORGIVE ME IF I CONTINUE IN ENGLISH IN ORDER TO SAVE TIME'

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: And now, Comrades, the greatest moment of the day, the moment when I ask you to welcome the return of one of Russia's greatest heroes, creator of the Red Army, Lenin's greatest friend, Lev Davidovich Trotsky!

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Comrades. Bolsheviks. Friends of the Revolution. I have returned. The bloodstained shadow of Stalinist repression is past. I bring you new light of Permanent Revolution . Comrades, I may once have been ousted from power, I may have been expelled from the party in 1927, I may have been deported in 1929 but I'm just an old-fashioned girl, with an old-fashioned mind. Comrades, I don't want to destroy in order to build, I don't want a state founded on hate and division I want an old-fashioned house with an old-fashioned fence, and an old-fashioned millionaire.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Our friend Mr Gulliver was clearly undergoing another change of personality.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: So! You have duped us. You shall pay for this. Guards, seize him.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Shall I seize him too?

dialogue.speaker: Senior General
dialogue.text: No, I think we'll have to keep him, he's going down well.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: He's more fun than he used to be.

dialogue.speaker: Senior General
dialogue.text: He's loosened up a lot. This is an old Lenin number.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: April 26th. Thrown into Russian cell. Severely damaged my Mars bar. Shall I ever see Bude Bus station again? Oh excuse me...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: What a pleasant exercise yard. How friendly they were all being.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Cigarettes?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh, no thank you I don't smoke.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: After a few minutes I perceived a line of gentlemen with rifles. They were looking in my direction... I looked around but could not see the target.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Blindfold?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: No thank you, no.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Slowotny! Grydenka... Verschnitzen.

dialogue.speaker: Messenger
dialogue.text: Nyet! Nyet! Nyet!

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: A telegram? From the Kremlin! The Central Committee! It says...'Carry on with the execution'. Verschnitzen...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Now I was really for it.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: How could you miss?

dialogue.speaker: Soldier
dialogue.text: He moved.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Shut up! Go and practise. I'm so sorry. Do you mind waiting in your cell?

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: What a stroke of luck. My Crunchie was totally intact. I settled down to a quick intermeal snack...

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Next time. Definitely! Now then, how many of them have been injured? Oh God...

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: As I lay dwon to the sound of the Russian gentlemen practising their shooting, I realised I was in a bit of a pickle. My heart sank as I realised I should never see the Okehampton by-pass again...

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Come on, dear. Wake up dear.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Mother!

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: Come on dear.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: So, it was all a dream.

dialogue.speaker: Mother
dialogue.text: No dear, is the dream, you're still in the cell.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: OK, we're going to have another try. I think we've got it now. My boys have been looking down the wrong bit, you see.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Oh no, look, you've got to look down the bit there.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Oh I thought you had to look down that bit.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: No, no, you've got to look down that bit, or you won't hit anything.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Alright, we'll give it a whirl. Guards, seize him.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Listen. You've got to look down this bit.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Osledi Osledi.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Eartha Kitt!

dialogue.speaker: Heath's Voice
dialogue.text: Trade Union leaders - I would say this - we've done our part. Now, on behalf of the community, we have a right to expect you, the Trade Union leaders, to do yours.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: That turnip's certainly not safe. Oh no! Mr Pither! Mr Pither!

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Mr Pither! Mr Pither!

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Mr Pither!

dialogue.speaker: Pither's Voice
dialogue.text: Here!

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Gulliver.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Pither! What a stroke of luck.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Well yes and no.

dialogue.speaker: Pither
dialogue.text: Phew, what an amazing escape. Well goodbye, Reginald.

dialogue.speaker: Gulliver
dialogue.text: Goodbye, Mr Pither, and good luck with the tour!

dialogue.stage_direction: Hey, I think he's finally gone!

dialogue.speaker: Second Monster
dialogue.text: Ooh yes!

dialogue.speaker: First Monster
dialogue.text: Ready, Maurice?

dialogue.speaker: Second Monster
dialogue.text: Right-ho, Kevin. Let's go.

dialogue.speaker: First Monster
dialogue.text: All right, maestro, hit it!

annotations: The green lush Devon countryside. Theme music. The camera is tracking along a hedgerow beside the road. We see a head whizzing along, sometimes just above the hedgerow and sometimes bobbing out of sight, accasionally for long periods.

Mr. Pither, the cyclist, bobs up and down a few more times, then disappears from sight. There is a crash and clang of a bicycle in collision, mixed with the scream of a frightened hen, and stifled shout of alarm. We are still in long shot and see nothing. The music stops abruptly on the crash.
(voice over)

Cut to interior of a transport cafe. A rather surly proprietor with fag in mouth is operating an Espresso coffee machine. Pither, a fussy bespectacled little man, in sweater, trousers, is leaning over the counter, talking chattily.
He goes back to working the machine.
Enormous lorry driver comes up to counter.
(the lorry driver looks at him without interest)
(the driver goes off with his cigarettes)
(with heavy sarcasm)
(handing him change)
(Pither proffers his hand, the proprietor ignores it)

He exits busily. The proprietor looks after him. Cut to hedgerows. Theme music. Pither's head bobbing up and down. At the same point in the music it disappears and there is a crash mingled with grunting of pig.
(voice over)
A brief shot of an unindentifiable animated Gilliam monster looking over the top of a hedge. Cut to a woman gardening. Behind her we see Pither's head peering over the hedge.
(she carries on digging trying to ignore him)
(no reaction)
(she goes on digging)
(again no reaction)
The lady gardener goes back into house. Pither waits for a few moments.
(shouting)
Cut to hedgerows again. Pither's head bowling along. Theme music. He dips out of sight. Crash and a cow moos.
(voice over)
Another brief shot of the animated monster peeking over a hedgerow. Cut to another hedgerow. Pither's head bowling along. Short burst of music. Crash.
(voice over)

Another monster peeps briefly. Cut to a tiny village high street, deserted save for an old lady. Pither cycles into shot. He is in shorts, but still has his bicycle clips on. He approaches the old lady.

She points with a shaking finger. Camera pans very slightly to one side to reveal a shop with a huge four-foot-high sign: 'Bicycle Pump Centre - Specialists In Shorter Bicycle Pumps'. Another sign: 'Short Pumps Available Here'. Another sign: 'We Shorten Pumps While-U-Wait'. The camera shows the shop only for a couple of seconds and pans back to the old lady and Pither.
Cut to interior of doctor's surgery. There is a knock on the door.
The nurse exits, Pither enters in shorts and sweater.
(he scribbles something on a piece of paper and hands it to Pither)

Cut to exterior of a chemist's shop. A chemist comes out holding the paper and points up the street. Pither thanks him and mounts his bike. Cut to the hedgerows again. Pither's head. Theme music reaches the point where Pither normally falls off, his head disappears, the music cuts off. There is no crash. Suddenly Pither's head reappears further on and the music starts up again.
(voice over)
Cut to a small market town. A line of cars. Pither's head just above roofs of cars. Theme music. He suddenly disappears, the music stops and there is a crash.
(voice over)

Cut to a discreet corner of a Watney's pub. Soft music. A middle-aged businessman and a sexy secretary who obviously want to be alone are sitting huddled over a table. At the next table is Pither, with half-pint in front of him.
(tapping the man on the leg)
(to Pither)
(to Pither)
(to Pither)
(taking off ring)
She runs out sobbing.
(turning on Pither)
The man picks Pither up by the scruff of the neck and the seat of his pants. He carries him bodily towards the door.
Pither is thrown out. He picks himself up and sees girl outside sobbing.

Girl bursts into further tears. Whistling cheerfully, Pither gets on his bicycle and, happier than he has been for a long time, he cycles off down the road and round a corner. Sounds of car-tyre screech and crash of Pither going straight into a car. Cut to interior of car speeding along highway. Pither is sitting in the back seat with his bicycle. The driver, Mr Gulliver, talks with a professional precision.
(with some surprise)
(becoming slightly messianic)
A tomato leaps up out of the glove compartment and hovers, then it ejects itself out of the car window
(embracing Pither excitedly)
(the car crashes)

Fade out. Fade up on country road. Pither is cycling along with Gulliver on the back of the bicycle. Gulliver has his head bandaged and his arm in a sling. Occasionally strains of Clodagh Rogers hit 'Jack in a box' float towards us as Gulliver moves rhythmically.
(voice over)
Cut to Pither and Gulliver cycling into hospital. A sign says 'North Cornwall District Hospital'. Cut to nurse receptionist at a counter with a glass window which lifts up and down. Pither appears.

Noise of splintering wood and crash out of vision. Pither and the nurse look up. A bench has collapsed in the middle and three patients sitting on it have slid into a heap in the middle. A nurse is on her way to assist. Cut back to Pither and nurse.
The window comes down on her fingers, she winces sharply in pain. She pushes it up again.
Terrific crash. Cut to trolley on its side, and a bandaged patient under a mound of hospital instruments and a nurse standing looking down.
Nurse scowls, crumples up paper, and throws it away. The piece of paper hits a smallish cabinet of glass which topples forward and smashes.
Cut to a doctor unloading a crate balanced on top of a medicine. He whips round knocking off the crate.
Cut to patient in a wheelchair being pushed. The wheelchair completely collapses and the nurse is left holding the handles. Quick cut to the nurse as window comes down on her fingers again.
Doctor comes across to pither, limping slightly, in some pain.

A nurse carrying a tray walks past the doctor, making for the entrance doors. As she reaches them they swing open to admit Gulliver, with his head bandaged and his arm in a sling. He collides with the nurse; she drops her tray. He graps Pither and they exit rapidly, stepping on the doctor's foot in the process. The doctor yells, grabs his foot, and as he does so the reception window slamms down, trapping his hand. He howls in pain. Cut to a camp fire at midnight in a forest clearing. By the light of the fire, Pither is writing up his diary.
(voice over)
(Gulliver enters the scene; his head is still bandaged)
From the darkness we hear French voices.
A pair of middle class French people in pyjamas appear.
(sings)
(calls)
Two teenagers in pyjamas and carrying autograph books appear and rush towards Gulliver.
(Gulliver signs and hands the book back.)
A brief film clip of Lenin, apparently singing the next line of the song.
He dashes off into the forest possessed.
He gets on his bike and pedals off hurriedly after Gulliver into the forest.
(still reminiscing)
Cut to a few quick shots of Gulliver dashing through the trees and then of Pither making much slower progress due to his bike. Cut to a shot of a French couple snogging in car.
(seeing Gulliver)
(sings)
(he switches on car radio and the song is heard throughout the forest)
Cut to Russian street. Pither cycles along with Gulliver looking like Trotsky on the back.
(voice over)
Cut to military man. He has a large map of Europe and Russia and a stick with which he raps at the places.
Cut back to Pither and Gulliver.
They've stopped by a signpost that says 'Smolensk town centre 1/2, Tavistock 1612 miles'.
(voice over)
Cut to military man who thumps the map again.
Cut back to Pither.
(voice over)
(voice over)
They leave the bicycle on the kerb and enter a door with the sign 'YMACA.' over it.
(voice over)
Cut to military man.
(by now standing at the reception desk with Gulliver)
(to departing desk clerk)
(as Trotsky)
He goes. Gulliver signs hotel register.
(looking at the book)
A couple of people race in excitedly.

Mix through to the British Consulate. Pither cycles up, parks his bike and goes in. Imperial music. Mix through to interior. A picture of the queen is dimly visible on the back wall. A Chinaman approaches. He is dressed in traditional Mandarin's robe and cap.
(he examines his diary.)
The Chinaman claps his hands and another runs in and bows obsequiously.
(goes)
(with difficulty)
Livingstone reappears, with drink and plate of pastries. He puts them down.
(hands a glass of sake to Pither)
(they drink)
Several Mao-suited Chinese people rush in waving the Red Book and shouting 'bingo'. The Chinaman remonstrates with Livingstone and eventually stops them.
(the Maoists exit)
(to Livingstone)
(to Pither)
(rushing back in)
Cut to stock film of large Chinese crowds.
Cut back to Consulate. The Chinaman is shouting out of window.
(comes back into room)
The Chinaman ushers Pither out. Brief film of rioting Chinese.
Cut to hotel lobby.
Cut to military man.
Cut bach to lobby.
He is surrounded by three secret policemen dressed in identical suits, dark glasses and pork pie hats.
The secret police all move away to confer.
They return to Pither.
A girl enters dressed as a New York cabbie.
(they all snap into salute)

Cut to stock film of train wheels in the night. The siren sounds. Superimposed names zoom into camera, as in a musical: Petrograd, Ottograd, Lewgrad, Lesliegrad, Etceteragrad, Dukhovskoknabilebskohatsk, Moscva. Cut to the stage of a big Russian hall. A banner across the top of the stage reads 'Russian 42nd International Clambake'. At the back of the stage sits Pither with his bicycle. At one side of the stage, at an impressive table on a dais, are some very important Russian persons including generals. One of the generals addresses the audience.
(etc.)
Pandemonium lasting for about ten seconds.
Gulliver appears looking as much like Trotsky as possible. He wears a uniform and has a beard and glasses. Pandemonium breaks out. He eventually quietens them by raising his hands for silence.
(renewed cheering)
(his movements are becoming a little camp and slinky)
(sings)
(a certain amount of confusion is spreading among the audience and particulary the general on the podium)
(sings)
From now on Gulliver continues exactly as Eartha Kitt. He has aquired a fur stole which he manipulates slinkily. The confusion is complete on the stage.
(voice over)
A senior general appears beside Pither with two guards.
The guards seize the startled Pither and drag him away. The senior general strides back across the stage avoiding Gulliver, towards the general who addressed the audience.
Cut to Pither sitting in a cell.
(voice over)
(two Russian guards throw the cell door open)
(they grab him and march him out of cell)
Cut to exterior of a door leading out into prison yard. The door is thrown open and Pither is marched over and stood against a blank wall. There are lots of small holes in the wall.
(voice over)
Pither facing a line of uniformed men with guns, obviously a firing squad.
(voice over)
(cut to Pither against the wall looking behind him)
(very cheerful)
(stepping clear)
(the firing squad snaps to attention)
(they raise their rifles)
Drum roll. The firing squad takes aim. A messenger runs frantically up.
(he hands the officer a paper)
(examines it)
(The squad raise their rifles)
(voice over)

Cut to shot of officer with his hand raised. The same as before, only without Pither in shot. Drum rolls again. He brings his sword down. Volley of shots from the firing squad. The officer is looking in Pither's direction. Long pause.
(to soldiers)
(to Pither)
Pither is flung back in his cell by the guards, and the door slammed.
(voice over)
But he is bundled out again. Pause. Shots. He si bundled in. The officer appears at door.
(to aide)
(voice over)

Mix to Pither's sleeping face, waking up, shaking himself in disbelief at finding himself in a beautiful garden, with the sun shining, the birds singing. He is in a deckchair, and his mother, having poured him a jug of iced fruit juice, is gently nudging Pither to wake him.
Mix to Pither waking up in the cell. The officer enters carrying a rifle.
(they take him out)
(as he leaves)

As they leave, we can see on the wall of the cell a poster, saying: 'Saturday Night at the Moscow Praesidium, starring Eartha Kitt, with Burgess and Maclean. "A Song a Dance and a Piece of Treachery". Marshal Bulganin and "Charlie", Peter Cook, Dudley Moore, Leningrad has never laughed so much.'

Mix through to stock film of the Kremlin. Dubber over laughter and applause. A cheerful band sing. Mix through to stage where someone dressed as Marshall Bulganin, is standing with a little real ventriloquist's dummy. He gets up, takes his bow and walks off as the curtain swings down. Lots of applause and atmosphere. Terrible Russian compère comes on smiling and applauding.

He tells a quick joke in Russian, and roars with laughter. Laughter from audience. He holds up his hands and then becomes very sincere, saying obviously deeply moving, wonderful things about the next guest, whom he finally introduces.
Gulliver comes on-stage in the full Eartha Kitt rig - white fur stole, slit skirt and jewellery. He mimes to the voice of Edward Heath.
(etc.)

Unrest in the audience as they recognize him. They start shouting 'sing "Old-Fashioned Girl"' and throwing vegetables. Slow motion shot of a tomato hitting Gulliver. He is seen to be holding a turnip.
(looking round and seeing where he is)

He runs off-stage, pursued by the guards. Cut to the stage-door of the hall. A sign on the door says 'Next week Clodagh Rogers'. Gulliver out, and then through the streets, hotly pursued by soldiers and secret service men, firing after him.
(calling)
He is seen running through a dockyard. Finally he stops by a high stone wall.
Gulliver looks round and then rapidly climbs up and over the wall. He drops down to find Pither standing on the other side.
He indicates with his head. Cut to show that both of them are standing in front of a firing squad. The officer is heard as before. The squard runs towards them with fixed bayonets.
Cut to Cornish country lane. A road sign says 'Tavistock 12 miles'. Pither stands beneath with Gulliver and his bicycle.

They shake hands. Gulliver strides off. Pither mounts his bike and rides off into the sunset. Music swells. Roll credits. Cut to a field with hedgerow behind. The first animated monster peeks over the hedge.
Second monster appears.
They hop over the fence into the field.
We hear Clodagh Rogers singing 'Jack in a Box'. The two monsters jump up and down enthusiastically if not gracefully. Fade out.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 17

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different.

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: 'THE BBC WOULD LIKE TO APOLOGIZE FOR THE NEXT ANNOUNCEMENT'

dialogue.speaker: Mr Tid
dialogue.text: Gentlemen, we have two basic suggestions for the design of this... ... Gentlemen, we have two basic suggestions for the design of this... Shut up! Gentlemen, we have two basic suggestions... Gentlemen, we have two basic suggestions for the design of this for the design of this residential block, and I thought it best that the architects themselves came in to explain the advantages of both designs. That must be the first architect noow. Ah, yes - it's Mr Wiggin of Ironside and Malone.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: Good morning, gentlemen. This is a twelwe-storey block combining classical neo-Georgian features with the efficiency of modern techniques. The tenants arrive in the entrance hall here, and are carried along the corridor on a conveyor belt in extreme comfort and past murals depicting Mediterranean scenes, towards the rotating knives. The last twenty feet of the corridor are heavily soundproofed. The blood pours down these chutes and the mangled flesh slurps into these...

dialogue.speaker: First City Gent
dialogue.text: Excuse me....

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: Hm?

dialogue.speaker: First City Gent
dialogue.text: Did you say knives?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: Rotating knives, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Second City Gent
dialogue.text: Are you proposing to slaughter our tenants?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: Does that not fit in with your plans?

dialogue.speaker: First City Gent
dialogue.text: No, it does not. We asked for a simple block of flats.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: Oh, I see. I hadn't correctly divined your attitude towards your tenants. You see I mainly design slaughter houses. Yes, pity. Mind you, this is a real beaut. I mean, none of your blood caked on the walls and flesh flying out of the windows, inconveniencing the passers-by with this one. I mean, my life has been building up to this.

dialogue.speaker: Second City Gent
dialogue.text: Yes, and well done, but we want a block of flats.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: May I ask you to reconsider. I mean, you wouldn't regret it. Think of the tourist trade.

dialogue.speaker: First City Gent
dialogue.text: No, no, it's just that we wanted a block of flats, not an abattoir.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: Yes, well, of course, this is just the sort blinkered philistine pig ignorance I've come to expect from you non-creative garbage. You sit there on your loathsome, spotty behinds squeezing blackheads, not caring a tinker's cuss about the struggling artist. You excrement! You lousy hypocritical whining toadies with your lousy colour TV sets and your Tony Jacklin golf clubs and your bleeding masonic handshakes! You wouldn't let me join, would you, you blackballing bastards. Well I wouldn't become a freemason now if you went down on your lousy, stinking, purulent knees and begged me.

dialogue.speaker: Second City Gent
dialogue.text: Well, we're sorry you feel like that but we, er, did want a block of flats. Nice though the abattoir is.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: Oh the abattoir, that's not important. But if any of you could put in a word for me I'd love to be a freemason. Freemasonry opens doors. I mean, I was...I was a bit on edge just now, but if I were a mason I'd sit at the back and not get in anyone's way.

dialogue.speaker: First City Gent
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: I've got a second-hand apron.

dialogue.speaker: Second City Gent
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: I nearly got in at Hendon.

dialogue.speaker: First City Gent
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Tid
dialogue.text: I'm sorry about that, gentlemen. The second architect is Mr Leavey of Wymis and Dibble.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Leavey
dialogue.text: Good morning gentlemen. This is a scale model of the block. There are twenty-eight storeys, with two hundred and eighty modern apartments. There are three main lifts and two service lifts. Access would be from Dibbingley Road. The structure is built on a central pillar system with cantilevered floors in pre-stressed steel and concrete. The dividing walls on each floor section are fixed by recessed magnalium flanged grooves. By avoiding wood and timber derivatives and all other flammables we have almost totally removed the risk of...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Leavey
dialogue.text: Quite frankly, I think the central pillar system may need strengthening a bit.

dialogue.speaker: Second City Gent
dialogue.text: Isn't that going to put the cost up?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Leavey
dialogue.text: It might.

dialogue.speaker: Second City Gent
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know whether I'd worry about strengthening much. After all, they're not meant to be luxury flats.

dialogue.speaker: First City Gent
dialogue.text: I quite agree. I mean, providing the tenants are of light build and relatively sedentary and er, given a spot of good weather, I think we're on to a winner here.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Leavey
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Second City Gent
dialogue.text: Quite agree. Quite agree.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Leavey
dialogue.text: Thank you very much. Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Wiggin
dialogue.text: It opens doors, I'm telling you.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Let's have a look at that handshake again in slow motion.

dialogue.speaker: First Voice Over
dialogue.text: What other ways are there of recognizing a mason?

dialogue.speaker: Second Voice Over
dialogue.text: Having once identified a mason immediate steps must be taken to isolate him from the general public. Having accomplished that it is now possible to cure him of these unfortunate masonic tendencies through the use of behavioural psychotherapy. In this treatment the patient is rewarded for the correct response and punished for the wrong one. Let us begin. Would you like to give up being a mason? Think carefully. Think. Think.

dialogue.speaker: Cartoon City Gent
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: No? That's wrong! Wrong! Wrong! Wrong! No! No! No! Bad! Bad!

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: The BBC would like to apologize for the following announcement.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well I've come about your special fully comprehensive motor insurance policy offer...

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: What was that?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Fully comprehensive motor insurance for one-and-eightpence.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Oh, oh, yes...yeah well, unfortunately, guv, that offer's no longer valid. You see, it turned out not to be commercially viable, so we now have a totally new offer...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What's that?

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: A nude lady.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: A nude lady?

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Yes. You get a nude lady with a fully comprehensive motor insurance. If you just want third party she has to keep her bra on, and if it's just theft...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, no, I don't really want that, Mr er...Mr...

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Devious.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Mr Devious. I just want to know what it would cost me to have a fully comprehensive inurance on a 1970 Aston Martin.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Aston Martin?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Five hundred quid.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Five hundred quid?

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Forty quid.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Forty quid?

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Forty quid and a nude lady.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, no, I'm not interested in a nude lady.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Dirty books?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, no, look, I'm not interested in any af that. I just want to know what it would cost me to have a fully comprehensive insurance on a 1970 Aston Martin. Can you please qoute me your price.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Knock knock.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Who's there

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: The Reverend...

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: The Reverend who?

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: The reverend Morrison.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Oh, come in.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Now then, vic. What's the trouble?

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Well, it's about this letter you sent me.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Excuse me, do I have any more lines?

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: I don't know, mush, I'll have to look in the script... Where are we? Show 8. Are you 'man?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: No...no, you're finished.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well, I'll be off then.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: 'The vicar sits'.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: It's about this letter you sent me regarding my insurance claim.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah, yeah - well, you see, it's just that we're not...as yet... satisfied with the grounds of your claim.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: But it says something about filling my mouth in with cement.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Oh well, that's just insurance jargon, you know.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: But my car was hit by a lorry while standing in the garage and you refuse to pay my claim.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Oh well, reverend Morrison...in your policy...in your policy... ...here we are. It states quite clearly that no claim you make will be paid.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Oh dear.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: You see, you unfortunately plumped for our 'Neverpay' policy, which, you know, if you never claim is very worthwhile...but you had to claim, and, well, there it is.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Oh dear, oh dear.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Still, never mind - could be worse. How's the nude lady?

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Oh, she's fine.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: Look...Rev...I hate to see a man cry, so shove off out the office, there's a good chap.

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: The bishop!

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: I take as my text for today...

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: The text, vic! Don't say the text!

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Leviticus 3-14. . .

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: We was too late. The Reverend Grundy bit the ceiling.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Hello? ... What?... We'll be right over!

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: And it is for this reason that the Christian Church lays upon you, the godparents, the obligation of seeing this child is brought up in the Christian faith. Therefore, I name this child...

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Don't say the kid's name, vic!

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Francesco Luigi...

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: We was too late... The Rev. Neuk saw the light.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: The ring, vic Don't touch the ring! Hey vic!

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: ... dust to dust, ashes to ashes.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Help ... help... help... help... help... help...

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: OK, Devious, don't move!

dialogue.speaker: Devious
dialogue.text: The bishop!

dialogue.stage_direction: This is where we came in.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Potter
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Potter
dialogue.text: Oh, it's nice to be home.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Potter
dialogue.text: Builders haven't been then.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Potter
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: These two old people are typical of the housing problem facing Britain's aged.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Potter
dialogue.text: Here! Don't you start doing a documentary on us, young man.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Oh please ...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Potter
dialogue.text: No, you leave us alone!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Oh, just a little one about the appalling conditions under which you live.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Potter
dialogue.text: No! Get out of our house! Go on!

dialogue.speaker: Cameraman
dialogue.text: Oh all right. Come on, George, pick it up.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Potter
dialogue.text: Why don't you do a documentary about the drug problem round in Walton Street?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Potter
dialogue.text: Oh, I'll go and have a bath.

dialogue.speaker: Tennyson
dialogue.text: The splendour fans on castle walls And snowy summits old in story...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Potter
dialogue.text: 'Ere, there's Alfred Lord Tennyson in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Potter
dialogue.text: Well, at least the poet's been installed, then.

dialogue.speaker: Sales Manager
dialogue.text: Yes, a poet is essential for complete home comfort, and all-year round reliability at low cost. We in the East Midlands Poet Board hope to have a poet in every home by the end of next year.

dialogue.speaker: Voices
dialogue.text: Poets are both clean and warm And most are far above the norm Whether here, or on the roam Have a poet in every home.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: I wandered lonely as a cloud That floats on high...

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Morning, madam, I've come to read your poet.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh yes, he's in the cupboard under the stairs.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: What is it, a Swinburne? Shelley?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: No, it's a Wordsworth.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Oh, bloody daffodils.

dialogue.speaker: Wordsworth
dialogue.text: A host of golden daffodils Beside the lake, beneath the trees Fluttering and dancing in the breeze

dialogue.speaker: Wordsworth
dialogue.text: Continuous as the stars that shine And twinkle in the Milky Way They stretch in...

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Right. Thank you, madam.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh, not at all. Thank ... It's a nice day, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, the weather situation is generally favourable. There's a ridge of high pressure centred over Ireland which is moving steadily eastward bringing cloudy weather to parts of the West Country, Wales and areas west of the Pennines. On tomorrow's chart ... the picture is much the same. With this occluded front bringing drier, warmer weather. Temperatures about average for the time of year. That's three degrees centigrade, forty-four degrees fahrenheit, so don't forget to wrap up well. That's all from me. Goodnight.

dialogue.speaker: Continuity Voice
dialogue.text: Now on BBC television a choice of viewing. On BBC 2 - a discussion on censorship between Derek Hart, The Bishop of Woolwich and a nude man. And on BBC 1 - me telling you this. And now...

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: We don't want that, do we. Do you really want that cherry in your tea? Do you like doing this job?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Well, it's a living, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: I mean, don't you get bored reading people's poets all day?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Well, you know, sometimes ... yeah. Anyway, I think I'd better be going.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: You've got a nice torch, haven't you?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Er, yeah, yeah, it er... it er ... it goes on and off.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: How many volts is it?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Er ... um... well, I'll have a look at the batteries.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh yes, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: It's four and a half volts.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Mmmm. That's wonderful. Do you want another look at the poet?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: No, no, I must be off, really.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: I've got Thomas Hardy in the bedroom. I'd like you to look at him.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Ah well, I can't touch him. He's a novelist.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh, he keeps mumbling all night.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Oh well, novelists do, you see.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh forget him! What's your name, deary?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Harness.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: No, no! Your first name, silly!

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Wombat.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh, Wombat. Wombat Harness! Take me to the place where eternity knows no bounds, where the garden of love encloses us round. Oh Harness!

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: All right, I'll have a quick look at yer Thomas Hardy.

dialogue.speaker: Derek
dialogue.text: Nude man, what did you make of that?

dialogue.speaker: Nude Man
dialogue.text: Well, don't you see, that was exactly the kind of explicit sexual reference I'm objecting to. It's titillation for the sake of it. A deliberate attempt at cheap sensationalism. I don't care what the so-called avant-garde, left-wing, intellectual namby-pambies say... It is !

dialogue.speaker: Derek
dialogue.text: Bishop.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Okay, don't anybody move!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The BBC would like to apologize for the constant repetition in this show.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The BBC would like to apologize for the constant repetition in this show.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Right. I've got some of your prescriptions here. Er, who's got the pox? ... Come on, who's got the pox ... come on... . .. there you go. Who's got a boil on the bum... boil on the botty. Who's got the chest rash? Have to get a bigger bottle. Who's got wind? Catch.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The BBC would like to apologize for the poor quality of the writing in that sketch. It is not BBC policy to get easy laughs with words like bum, knickers, botty or wee-wees. Ssssh!

dialogue.speaker: BBC Man
dialogue.text: These are the words that are not to be used again on this programme.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Semprini!?

dialogue.speaker: BBC Man
dialogue.text: Out!

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Right, who's got a boil on his Semprini, then?

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Good morning, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Good morning. I'd like some aftershave, please.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Ah, certainly. Walk this way, please.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: If I could walk that way I wouldn't need aftershave.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes. I'd like some aftershave.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Ah. A toilet requisite-t-t-t-t-t... Would you like to try this, sir. It's our very very latest, it's called Sea Mist.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I quite like it.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: How about something a little more musky? This one's called Mimmo.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Not really, no. Have you anything a little more fishier?

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Fishier?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Fishier.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Fish, fish, fish. A fishy requisite-t-t-t-t-t...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Like halibut or sea bass.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Or bream?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: No, we haven't got any of that... ah, I've got mackerel... or cod... or hake...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You haven't got anything a little more halibutish?

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Er... parrot? What's that doing there? Or skate with just a hint of prawn? Or crab, tiger and almonds, very unusual.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I really had my heart set on halibut.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Well, sir, we had a fishy consignment in this morning, so I could nip down to the basement and see if I can come up trumps on this particular requisite-t-t-t-t-t. So it was halibut... or... ?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Sea bass.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Sea bass. Won't be a moment.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Sorry about this... pom pom pom... Normally we try to avoid these little ... pauses ... longeurs... only dramatically he's gone down to the basement, you see. 'Course, there isn't really a basement but he just goes off and we pretend... Actually what happens is he goes off there, off camera, and just waits there so it as though he's gone down ... to the basement. Actually I think he's rather overdoing it. Ah!

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Well, sorry, sir. Lot of steps. Well, I'm afraid it didn't come in this morning, sir. But we have got some down at our Kensington branch. I'll just nip down there and get it for you.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: How long will that be?

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Twenty minutes.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Twenty minutes!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh... I wonder what other people use for aftershave lotion?

dialogue.speaker: First Gumby
dialogue.text: I use a body rub called Halitosis to make my breath seem sweet.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gumby
dialogue.text: I use an aftershave called Semprini.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, sorry - can't stop now, I've got to get to Kensington.

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal Ximinez
dialogue.text: I use two kinds of aftershave lotions - Frankincense, Myrrh - kinds of aftershave lotions, Frankincense, Myrrh, Sandalwood - kinds of aftershave lotion. Frankincense, ....

dialogue.speaker: Another Man
dialogue.text: I have a cold shower every morning just before I go mad, and then I go mad, 1. Mad, 2. Mad, 3. Mad, 4...

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: I use Rancid Polecat number two. It keeps my skin nice and scaly.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Sorry again. Can't stop - got to get back.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Well I'm afraid they don't have any at our Kensington branch. But we have some down at the depot.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Where's that?

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Aberdeen.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Aberdeen?

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: It's all right. Wait here ... I've got a car.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, no, no. I'll take the other, the crab, tiger and...

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Almond requisite... t... t... ?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I'll take it.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Right. Right! RIGHT! Now then! Now then! Your turn.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Aren't you going to say 'What's all this then?'?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Oh! Right, what's all this, then?

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: This man has been shoplifting, officer.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Oh, he has? Yus?

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Are you trying to tell me my job?

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: No, but he's been shoplifting.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Look! I must warn you that anything you may say will be ignored and furthermore, given half a chance I'll put my fist through your teeth. F'tang. F'tang.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: But officer, this man here...

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: I've had enough of you. You're under arrest.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Officer, it wasn't him. He's the shoplifter.

dialogue.speaker: Shoplifter
dialogue.text: No I'm not.

dialogue.speaker: Shoplifter's Mate
dialogue.text: He's not ... I'm a witnes.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: One more peep out of you and I'll do you for heresy.

dialogue.speaker: Chemist
dialogue.text: Heresy. Blimey. I didn't expect the Spanish Inquisition.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Shut up! F'tang. F'tang. Oh, that's nice. Right. I'm taking you along to the station.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What for?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: I'm charging you with illegal possession of whatever we happen to have down there. Right. Lunar module calling Buzz Aldrin. Come in. Raindrops keep falling on my head... but that doesn't mean that my...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The BBC would like to apologize to the police about the character of Police Constable Pan Am. He was not meant to represent the average police officer. Similarly, the reference to Buzz Aldrin, the astronaut, was the product of a disordered mind and should not be construed as having any other significance.

dialogue.speaker: Gumbys
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different. Oh that was fun. And now...

dialogue.speaker: Gumbys
dialogue.text: The end. The end! The end! The end!

annotations: Opens with animated item (the Butterfly). The announcer at a desk with propellors rise into view.
(and CAPTION:)
Cut to a group of Gumbys, all with rolled-up trousers and knotted handkerchiefs on their heads, attempting to shout in unison and failing miserably.
(ad the sketch fails to start they point up at a nearby building)
The camera pans to a window in the building. Cut to the office inside, where a board meeting is taking place. The Chairman is Mr Tid.
(he is distracted by the two Gumbys still shouting)
(shouts out of window at the gumbys)
(but the gumbys is still shouting 'Architects Sketch'; he throws a bucket of water over them; they subside, damply)
(knock at door)
(Mr Wiggin comes in)
Wiggin walks to the table on which his model stand.
(shouting)
(blows raspberry)
(going to door but stopping)
Mr Wiggin leaves and the familiar figure of Mr Tid comes forward.
Mr Leavey comes in and goes to his model.
(the model falls over, and he quickly puts it upright)
(the model falls over again)
(he puts model upright and holds onto it)
(the model partly collapses, the bottom ten floors giving way)
(the model is smoking and flames are seen)
The model explodes.
(he shakes hands with them in an extraordinary way)
(at door)
They do the handshake again, only slowly.

Shot from camera concealed in a car so we get reactions of passers-by. A busy city street - i.e. Threadneedle Street. In amongst the throng four city gents are leaping along with their trousers round their ankles. They are wearing bowler hats and pinstripes. Another city street or another part of the same street. Two city gents, with trousers rolled up to the knee, approach each other and go into the most extraordinary handshake which involves rolling on the floor etc.
(we see a cartoon city gent locked into a cell)
A large hammer attacks the city gent.

Pull out from caption to reveal that it is not a caption after all but a huge twenty-foot-square poster on a hoarding on the side of the road. After we pull out we hear the shuffling of many feet and grunting. A group of Gumbys shuffle into extreme left edge of frame. They do not move any futher into the picture. After a bit of humming and harring:
Cut to Mr Devious's insurance office. Devious and a man are sitting there.
(quickly)
(superimposed 'STRAIGHT MAN' caption again)
Cut to outside the door of the office. A vicar stands there.
Cut to inside office.
Cut to outside.
Cut to inside.
Cut to inside.
The vicar enters.
(he gets script out of drawer)
(he leaves)
(reading script)
The vicar sits.
(rising and crossing to a filing cabinet)

(he open the drawer of the filing cabinet and takes out a shabby old sports jacket; he feels in the pocket and pulls out a crumbled dog-eared piece of paper then puts the coat back and shuts the filing cabinet)
(he begins to sob)

The vicar goes out sobbing. Cut to outside. Vicar collects a nude lady sitting in a supermarket shopping trolley...and wheels her disconsolately away. Cut back to inside of office. Close-up of Devious. He gets out some files and starts writing. Suddenly a bishop's crook slams down on the desk in front of Devious. He looks up - his eyes register terror. Cut to reverse angle shot from below. The bishop in full mitre and robes.
Animated crime-series-type titles, with suitable music:

Exterior beautiful English church. Birds singing, a hymn being sung. Suddenly, sound of a high-powered car roaring towards the church. Screech of tires as a huge open-top American car screeches to a halt outside the church. The bishop leaps out. Behind him (as throughout the film) are his four henchmen... vicars with dark glasses. They wear clerical suits and dog collars. They leap out of their car and race up the drive towards the church. As they do so the hymn is heard to come to an end. Sound of people sitting down.
Cut to interior of church. Vicar climbing up into pulpit. Cut back to exterior. The bishop and his vicars racing through the doors. Interior of church. Shot of vicar in pulpit.
Cut to bishop and vicars at doorway.
Cut back to vicar.

The pulpit explodes. Vicar disappears in smoke, flying up into the air. Cut to close-up of the bishop. Behind him there is smoke and people rushing about. Sound of people scrambling over pews in panic etc.
The end of the bishop's crook suddenly starts flashing. He lifts the flashing end off and it stops. Using it like a telephone receiver, he speaks into the staff.

Still of another church exterior. Crash zoom in on door. Cut to interior. A baptism party round the font. An innocent vicar is just testing the water. Pan across to the parents - a couple of shifty crooks - and two godmothers, obviously all-in wrestlers in drag (cauliflower ears etc.). As the vicar takes the baby it starts to tick loudly.
Cut to door of church. The bishop and vicars rush in.
Cut back to vicar.
Explosion. Cut to close-up of bishop. Smoke and panic as before.
Whip pan to interior of yet another church. A wedding. Bride and groom standing in front of a vicar. Cut to door of church. The bishop and vicars burst in.
Cut to vicar taking the ring out of the bible. The ring is attached to a piece of string. A sixteen-ton weight falls on top of them with a mighty crunch - the camera shakes as it hits the floor.
Cut to two bell ringers. One pulls his rope, and the other rises off the floor, hanged by the neck. The bishop arrives, just too late.
Cut to another vicar at graveside.

He sprinkles dust on the grave. A huge prop cannon rises up out of the grave until its mighty barrel (twelve inches wide) is pointing right in the vicar's face. He does not notice. Sound of car screeching to a halt. We pan away from grave to reveal the bishop leaping out of the car. Sound of an almighty blast from the cannon. The bishop gets back into the car immediately and turns it round.

Cut to a street. Outside a cigarette shop the four clerics lounge against a wall. The bishop walks out rolling his own. Suddenly he stops. Close-up. He looks up as he hears a faint cry. Camera swings round and up - enormous zoom to high window in huge, drab city office block, where a vicar is looking out.

Cut back to the bishop breaking into a run, throwing his cigarette into the gutter. Peter Gunn music. Hand-held shots of the bishop and the four vicars running through crowded streets. He reaches the office block, rushes in. Interior: a stair well. Right at the bottom we see the bishop and the vicars. Close-up hand-held shot of bishop running up stairs. Shadows running up the stair well. The bishop arrives on the top landing. Door of office. The bishop tries the door. It won't open. One vicar goes rigid. The other three take hold of him and use him as a battering ram and go straight through the balsa wood door first time.
'The Bishop' titles again.

Cut to interior of cinema. A couple holding hands. Bishop film titles start up again exactly as before. After a couple of seconds of titles we cut to an old couple sitting in the back row of the cinema facing camera. The sound of the bishop's titles continues. The light from the projector is streaming out above their heads.

Cut immediately to the front of the cinema. A working-class lounge is arranged on the pavement. There are no walls, just the furnishings: settee, two armchairs, sideboard, table, standard lamp, a tiled fireplace with ornaments on it. There is also a free-standing inside door. Mr and Mrs Potter come out of the cinema and go straight to their chairs and sit down. Passers-by have to skirt the living-room furniture.
(settling into her chair)
(looking round)
A trendy interviewer with hand mike comes into shot.
Interviewer turns, motions to his cameraman and soundman and they all trail off miserably.
Cut to the camera crew. They stop, turn and mutter 'a drug problem!' and they dash off.
She goes to the free-standing door and opens it. Beyond it we see the furnishings of a bathroom. In the bath is Alfred Lord Tennyson, fully clad. As she opens the door we hear him reciting:
She slams the door.
Cut to an officious-looking man in Gas Board type uniform and peaked cap.
an advertisement.
(singing)

Cut to middle-class hall. The front doorbell rings. Housewife opens door to Gas Board type inspector with bicycle clips, rubber mac and cap and notebook. In the background we can hear muffled Wordsworth.
He opens the door of the cupboard under the stairs. Inside is Wordsworth crouching and reciting.
All this while the inspector is shining his torch over him and noting things on his clip board.
The inspector shuts the door in the middle of this and we hear Wordsworth reading on, though muffled, throughout the remainder of the sketch.
He makes as if to go, but she seems anxious to detain him and bars his way.
(he reaches up and pulls down a big weather chart from the wall)
Cut to BBC world symbol.

Sound of TV set bring switched off. The picture reduces to a spot and we pull out to see that it was actually on a TV set which has just been switched off by the housewife. She and the gas man are now sitting in her living room. He is perched awkwardly on the edge of the sofa. He holds a cup of tea with a cherry on a stick in it.
As he gets up she comes quickly to his side.
(seductively)
(looking at it rather baffled)
He demonstrates.
(drawing closer becoming breathy)
(he starts unscrewing the end)
(rubbing up against him)
(dragging him onto the sofa)
Cut to studio discussion.
Cut to crook hitting desk in Devious's office.
Titles for 'The Bishop' start and then stop abruptly.
the 'five frog curse'.
Cut to the five Gumbys standing in a tight group.
A number of men and women are sitting around in an area by the counter where there is a large sign saying 'Dispensing Department'. A cheerful chemist appears at the counter.
(JOHN)
(nobody reacts)
(a man timidly puts his hand up)
(throws bottle to the man with his hand up)
(throws bottle to the only man standing up)
(a woman with a large bosom puts up hand)
(throws bottle to a man sitting on his own)
(laughs off camera)
Cut to a man standing by a screen with a clicker.
He clicks the clicker. On screen appear the following slides:
A girl comes into shot.
(pointing)
Cut back to the chemist's shop. The chemist appears again.
A policeman appears and bundles him off.
Cut to another chemist's shop with a different chemist standing at the counter.
A man walks in.
The policeman runs into the shop and hauls the man off. Cut to shop again.
Another chemist is standing with a large sign reading 'A Not At All Naughty Chemist'. Pull back to reveal sign above stock reads 'Not At All Naughty Chemists Ltd'. A man enters.
(puts down sign)
(sniffs it)
The man waits for a few seconds, starts becoming uncomfortable, looks at watch, hums.
(to camera)
Long shot of the chemist with carton waiting off camera. Floor manager cues him and he walks to counter.
(out of breath)
(man winks at camera)
As he stands getting embarrassed, a girl hastily dressed as an assistant approaches him and hands him a message on a long stick.
Cut to vox pops film.
He is hauled off by policeman.
(hurrying past)
(hurrying Past)
Cut back to chemist's where the man is at a clock on wall pushing minute hand round twenty minutes.
He looks at the camera guiltily and returns to right side of counter. The chemist enters.

The chemist turns his back. A shoplifter enters. There is two men inside a large mac. He has false arms behind his back a la Duke of Edinburgh. The man watches him. He strolls to the counter and then two arms come out of coat and grab things from counter taking them inside the coat. Then these two arms are joined by a third arm which is black. All these arms steal stuff. The man taps the chemist and points at shoplifter. Chemist watches and then blows whistle. They wait for a tick. Then the policeman runs into the shop.
He makes noises of plane flying and firing.
(indicates shoplifter)
(sticking his head out of mac)
(to chemist)
(he takes an object off the counter and pockets it)
(makes plane noise again)
Photo of Buzz Aldrin.
Cut to Gumbys as at start of show.
(jump cut to female Gumbys; then back to original shot)

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 16

script.description: Excuse me, I saw your advertisement for flying lessons and I'd like to make an application.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: My, isn't it hot in here.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something more completely different...

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: 'Oh Mr Belpit your legs are so swollen' ... .. 'Oh Mr Belpit - oh Mr Belpit your legs are so swollen'. 'Oh Mr Belpit., .'

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Excuse me, excuse me. I saw your advertisement for flying lessons and I'd like to make an application.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Nothing to do with me. I'm not in this show.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Oh I see. D'you ... d'you., . do you know about the flying lessons?

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Nothing to do with me. I'm not in this show. This is show five - I'm not in until show eight.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Oh I see.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: I'm just learning my lines, you know. 'Oh Mr Belpit, your legs...'

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Bit awkward, I'm a bit stuck.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Yes, well. Try over there.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Oh yes, thanks. Thanks a lot.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: 'Oh Mr Belpit' - not at all - 'your legs are so swollen'.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Appointment?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Yes, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Certainly. Would you come this way, please.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Morning, Mr Jones, Mr Barnes.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Morning Mrs Wills.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Wills
dialogue.text: Morning, luv.

dialogue.speaker: Executive
dialogue.text: Take this to Marketing, would you.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary's Voice
dialogue.text: Just follow me.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger's Voice
dialogue.text: Oh thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary's Voice
dialogue.text: Oh, be careful.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger's Voice
dialogue.text: Yes, nearly tripped.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary's Voice
dialogue.text: Be there soon.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger's Voice
dialogue.text: Good. It's a long way, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Secretary's Voice
dialogue.text: Oh, get hold of that - watch it.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Morning.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary's Voice
dialogue.text: Morning. Upstairs. Be careful, it's very steep. Almost there.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Morning.

dialogue.speaker: Secretary
dialogue.text: Morning. Will you come this way, please. In here, please.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Thank you. Hello, I saw your advertisement for flying lessons and I'd like to make an appointment.

dialogue.speaker: Second Secretary
dialogue.text: Well, Mr Anemone's on the phone at the moment, but I'm sure he won't mind if you go on in. Through here.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
