dialogue.text: Ah, won't be a moment. Make yourself at home. No, no, well look, you can ask Mr Maudling but I'm sure he'll never agree. Not for fifty shillings ... no... no. Bye-bye Gordon. Bye-bye. Oh dear. Bye-bye. Missed. Now Mr er...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Chigger.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Mr Chigger. So, you want to learn to fly?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Right, well, up on the table, arms out, fingers together, knees bent...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: No, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Up on the table! Arms out, fingers together, knees bent, now, head well forward. Now, flap your arms. Go on, flap, faster... faster... faster... faster, faster, faster, faster - now jump! Rotten. Rotten. You're no bloody use at all. You're an utter bloody wash-out. You make me sick, you weed!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Now look here...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: All right, all right. I'll give you one more chance, get on the table...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Look, I came here to learn how to fly an aeroplane.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: A what?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: I came here to learn how to fly an aeroplane.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Oh, 'an aeroplane'. Oh, I say, we are grand, aren't we? 'Oh, oh, no more buttered scones for me, mater. I'm off to play the grand piano'. 'Pardon me while I fly my aeroplane.' Now get on the table!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Look. No one in the history of the world has ever been able to fly like that.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Oh, I suppose mater told you that while you were out riding. Well, if people can't fly what am I doing up here?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: You're on a wire.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Oh, a wire. I'm on a wire, am I?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Of course you're on a bloody wire.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: I am on a wire. I am flying.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: You're on a wire.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: I am flying.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: You're on a wire.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: I'll show you whether I'm on a wire or not. Give me the 'oop.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Oh, I don't suppose we know what an 'oop is. I suppose pater thought they were a bit common, except on the bleedin' croquet lawn.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Oh, a .

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: 'Oh an .' Thank you, your bleeding Highness. Now. Look.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Go on, right the way along.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: All right, all right, all right. . Now, where's the bleeding wire, then?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: That hoop's got a hole in.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Oh Eton and Madgalene. The hoop has an hole in. Of course it's got a hole in, it wouldn't be a hoop otherwise, would it, mush!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: No, there's a gap in the middle, there.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Oh, a gahp. A gahp in one's hhhhhoop. Pardon me, but I'm off to play the grand piano.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Look, I can see you're on a wire - look, there it is.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Look, I told you, you bastard, I'm not on a wire.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: You are. There is.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: There isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Is.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Is!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Is!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Isn't!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Is!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Anemone
dialogue.text: Isn't!!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Is!!!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Anyway, this rather pointless bickering went on for some time until...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Gosh, I am glad I'm a fully qualified arline pilot.

dialogue.speaker: BALPA Man
dialogue.text: The British Airline Pilots Association would like to point out that it takes a chap six years to become a fully qualified airline pilot, and not two.

dialogue.speaker: BALPA Man
dialogue.text: Thank you. I didn't want to seem a bit of an old fusspot just now you know, but it's just as easy to get these things right as they are easily found in the BALPA handbook. Oh, one other thing, in the Sherlock Holmes last week Tommy Cooper told a joke about a charter flight, omitting to point out that one must be a member of any organization that charters a plane for at least six months beforehand, before being able to take advantage of it. Did rather spoil the joke for me, I'm afraid. Yes, ah yes - yes. My wife just reminded me that on a recent 'High Chapparal' Kathy Kirby was singing glibly about 'Fly me to the Stars' when of course there are no scheduled flights of this kind, or even chartered, available to the general public at the present moment, although of course, when they are BALPA will be in the vanguard. Or the Trident. Little joke for the chaps up at BALPA House. And one other small point. Why is it that these new lurex dancing tights go baggy at the knees after only a couple of evenings' fun? Bring back the old canvas ones I say. It is incredible, isn't it, that in these days when man can walk on the moon and work out the most complicated hire purchase agreements, I still get these terrible headaches. Well . .. I seem to have wandered a bit, but still, no harm done. Jolly good luck.

dialogue.speaker: Zanie
dialogue.text: Are you going to be in there all day? Other people want to go you know! The door's jammed, if you ask me. Ah. Oh my God. Oh, I'm terribly sorry. I thought this was the bally toilet.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: This is the control cabin.

dialogue.speaker: Zanie
dialogue.text: Oh I know that. I'm a flying man, you know... oh yes... Bally stupid mistake...

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Cloud's heavy ... What's the reading?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: 4.8... Steady.

dialogue.speaker: Zanie
dialogue.text: If they had all those dials in the toilet... there wouldn't be room for anything else, would there.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Hello, Geneva this is Roger Five-O ... What is your cloud reading? Hello, Geneva...

dialogue.speaker: Zanie
dialogue.text: I wouldn't fancy flying one of those sitting on the toilet... I mean it'd take the glamour out of being a pilot, wouldn't it, ha ha, flying around the world sitting on a toilet.

dialogue.speaker: Radio Voice
dialogue.text: Geneva here. 4.9 ... Heavy... Over.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Chigger
dialogue.text: Serious?

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: No, not if it keeps at that level, no.

dialogue.speaker: Zanie
dialogue.text: Mind you, if you did fly it from the toilet it would leave a lot more space up here, wouldn't it. Well, I'd better get back to the cabin, then. Sorry about the silly intrusion. Bally stupid. Door's jammed. Aaaaaaaaaarrrggghhhhhh!

dialogue.speaker: Zanie
dialogue.text: Bally piece of luck...

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Oh hello. Everything all right at the back?

dialogue.speaker: Hostess
dialogue.text: Yes, they're as quiet as dormice.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Dormice?

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: All right, don't anybody move ... except to control the aeroplane ... you can move a little to do that.

dialogue.speaker: Hostess
dialogue.text: Can I move?

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, yes. You can move a little bit. Yes. Sorry, I didn't mean to be so dogmatic when I came in. Obviously you can all move a little within reason. There are certain involuntary muscular movements which no amount of self-control can prevent. And obviously any assertion of authority on my part, I've got to take that into account.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Right. I mean one couldn't for example, stop one's insides from moving.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: No, no. Good point, good point.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: And the very fact that the plane is continuously vibrating means that we're all moving to a certain extent.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: And we're all moving our lips, aren't we?

dialogue.speaker: Pilots
dialogue.text: Yes, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Absolutely.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: No, the gist of my meaning was that sudden... er...

dialogue.speaker: Hostess
dialogue.text: Exaggerated movements ...

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Exaggerated movements... are... are out.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Well, that's the great thing about these modern airliners. I mean, I can keep this plane flying with only the smallest movement and Pancho here doesn't have to move at all.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Oh, that's marvellous.

dialogue.speaker: Hostess
dialogue.text: And I don't really need to move either ... unless I get an itch or something...

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Well that's wonderful ... 60% success, eh? Anyway, bearing all that in mind, will you fly this plane to Luton, please?

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Well, this is a scheduled flight to Cuba.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: I know, I know, that's rather why I came in here with that point about nobody moving.

dialogue.speaker: First Pilot
dialogue.text: Within reason.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Within reason - yes. I... er ... er... you know, I want you to fly this plane to Luton ... please.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Right, well I'd better turn the plane round then. Stand by emergency systems.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Look I don't want to cause any trouble.,

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: No, no, we'll manage, we'll manage.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: I mean, near Luton will do, you know. Harpenden, do you go near Harpenden?

dialogue.speaker: First Pilot
dialogue.text: It's on the flight path.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Okay, well, drop me off there. I'll get a bus to Luton. It's only twenty-five minutes.

dialogue.speaker: Hostess
dialogue.text: You can be in Luton by lunchtime.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Oh, well that's smashing.

dialogue.speaker: First Pilot
dialogue.text: Hang on! There's no airport at Harpenden.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Oh well, look, forget it. Forget it. I'll come to Cuba, and get a flight back to Luton from there.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pilot
dialogue.text: Well, we could lend you a parachute.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no. I wouldn't dream of it... wouldn't dream of it... dirtying a nice, clean parachute.

dialogue.speaker: First Pilot
dialogue.text: I know - I know. There's a bale of hay outside Basingstoke. We could throw you out.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Well, if it's all right.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Sure, yeah.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Not any trouble?

dialogue.speaker: Pilots
dialogue.text: None at all.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: That's marvellous. Thank you very much. Sorry to come barging in.

dialogue.speaker: Hostess
dialogue.text: Bye-bye.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Thank you. Bye.

dialogue.speaker: Pilots
dialogue.text: Bye.

dialogue.speaker: Gunman
dialogue.text: Thank you!

dialogue.speaker: Hijacker
dialogue.text: Take this bus to Cuba.

dialogue.speaker: From these glens and scars, the sound of the coot and the moorhen is seldom absent. Nature sits in stern mastery over these rocks and crags. The rush of the mountain stream, the bleat of the sheep, and the broad, clear Highland skies, reflected in turn and loch ...
dialogue.text: ... form the breathtaking backdrop against which Ewan McTeagle writes such poems as 'Lend us a quid till the end of the week'.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But it was with more simple, homespun verses that McTeagle's unique style first flowered.

dialogue.speaker: McTeagle
dialogue.text: If you could see your way to lending me sixpence. I could at least buy a newspaper. That's not much to ask anyone.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: One woman who remembers McTeagle as a young friend - Lassie O'Shen.

dialogue.speaker: Lassie
dialogue.text: Mr MeTeagle wrote me two poems, between the months of January and April 1969...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Could you read us one?

dialogue.speaker: Lassie
dialogue.text: Och, I dinna like to... they were kinda personal... but I will. 'To Ma Own beloved Lassie. A poem on her 17th Birthday. Lend us a couple of bob till Thursday. I'm absolutely skint. But I'm expecting a postal order and I can pay you back as soon as it comes. Love Ewan.'

dialogue.speaker: Sound Man
dialogue.text: Beautiful.

dialogue.speaker: Limbo
dialogue.text: Since then, McTeagle has developed and widened his literary scope. Three years ago he concerned himself with quite small sums - quick bits of ready cash: sixpences, shillings, but more recently he has turned his extraordinary literary perception to much larger sums - fifteen shillings, £4.12.6 ... even nine guineas ... But there is still nothing to match the huge sweep ... the majestic power of what is surely his greatest work: 'Can I have fifty pounds to mend the shed?'.

dialogue.speaker: Ian
dialogue.text: Can I have fifty pounds to mend the shed? I'm right on my uppers. I can pay you back When this postal order comes from Australia. Honestly. Hope the bladder trouble's getting better. Love, Ewan.

dialogue.speaker: Limbo
dialogue.text: There seems to be no end to McTeagle's poetic invention. 'My new cheque book hasn't arrived' was followed up by the brilliantly allegorical 'What's twenty quid to the bloody Midland Bank?' and more recently his prizewinning poem to the Arts Council: 'Can you lend me one thousand quid?'

dialogue.speaker: David
dialogue.text: I think what McTeagle's pottery... er... poetry is doing is all the traditional cliches of modern pottery. No longer do we have to be content with Keats's 'Seasons of mists and mellow fruitfulness', Wordsworth's 'I wandered lonely as a cloud' and Milton's 'Can you lend us two bob till Tuesday'...

dialogue.speaker: McTeagle
dialogue.text: Oh give to me a shillin' for some fags and I'll pay yet back on Thursday, but if you can wait till Saturday I'm expecting a divvy from the Harpenden Building Society...

dialogue.speaker: Highlander
dialogue.text: As a Highlander I would like to complain about some inaccuracies in the preceding film about the poet Ewan McTeagle. Although his name was quite clearly given as McTeagle, he was throughout wearing the Cameron tartan. Also I would like to point out that the BALPA spokesman who complained about aeronautical inaccuracies was himself wearing a captain's hat, whereas he only had lieutenant's stripes on the sleeves of his jacket. Also, in the Inverness pantomime last Christmas, the part of Puss in Boots was played by a native of New Guinea with a plate in her lip, so that every time Dick Whittington gave her a French kiss, he got the back of his throat scraped.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Look, would you mind going away, I'm trying to examine this man. It's - er - it's all right - I a doctor. Actually, I'm a gynaecologist... but this is my lunchhour.

dialogue.speaker: Animation Voice
dialogue.text: I've a nasty feeling I somebody's lunchhour.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Pat-a-cake, pat-a-cake baker's man. Good morning, madam, I'm a psychiatrist.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: You look like a milkman to me.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Good. I am in fact as a milkman... you spotted that - well done.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Go away.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Now then, madam. I'm going to show you three numbers, and I want you to tell me if you see any similarity between them.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: They're all number three.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: No. Try again.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: They're number three?

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: No. They're number three. Right. Now. I'm going to say a word, and I want you to say the first thing that comes into your head. How many pints do you want?

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Er, three?

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Yogurt?

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Er... no.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Cream?

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Eggs?

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Right. Well, you're quite clearly suffering from a repressive libido complex, probably the product of an unhappy childhood, coupled with acute insecurity in adolescence, which has resulted in an attenuation of the libido complex.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: You a bloody milkman.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Don't you shout at me, madam, don't come that tone. Now then, I must ask you to accompany me down to the dairy and do some aptitude tests.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: I've got better things to do than come down to the dairy!

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Mrs Ratbag, if you don't mind me saying so, you are badly in need of an expensive course of psychiatric treatment. Now I'm not going to say a trip to our dairy will cure you, but it will give hundreds of lower-paid workers a good laugh.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: All right... but how am I going to get home?

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: I'll run you there and back on my psychiatrist's float.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: What are those?

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: They're case histories. Yes, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Ah, good morning. I'm afraid our regular psychiatrist hasn't come round this morning ... and I've got an ego block which is in turn making my wife over-assertive and getting us both into a state of depressive neurosis.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Oh, I see, sir. Who's your regular, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Jersey Cream Psychiatrists.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Oh yes, I know them. Right, well, er, what's your job, then?

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: I'm a doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: ... Didn't I see you just now under a Scotsman?

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Yes, but I a doctor. Actually, I'm a gynaecologist but that was my lunchhour.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: What does remind you of?.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Two pints of cream.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Right... well I should definitely say you're suffering from a severe personality disorder, sir, sublimating itself in a lactic obsession which could get worse depending on how much money you've got.

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, I see. And a pot of yogurt, please.

dialogue.speaker: Dr Cream
dialogue.text: I would like to take this opportunity of complaining about the way in which these shows are continually portraying psychiatrists who make pat diagnoses of patients' problems without first obtaining their full medical history.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Mind you, that's just a pat diagnosis made without first obtaining your full medical history.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I feel the time has come to complain about people who make rash complaints without first making sure that those complaints are justified.

dialogue.speaker: Dr Cream
dialogue.text: Are you referring to me?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Not necessarily, however, I would like to point out that the BALPA spokesman was wearing the British Psychiatric Association Dinner Dance Club cuff-links.

dialogue.speaker: Dr Cream
dialogue.text: Oh yes, I noticed that too.

dialogue.speaker: BALPA Man
dialogue.text: These are not British Psychiatric Association Dinner Dance Club cuff-links.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Sorry.

dialogue.speaker: BALPA Man
dialogue.text: They are in fact British Sugar Corporation Gilbert-and-Sullivan Society cuff-links. It is in fact a sort of in-joke with us lads here at BALPA. I think the last speaker should have checked his facts before making his own rash complaint.

dialogue.speaker: Dr Cream
dialogue.text: Yes, that'll teach him.

dialogue.speaker: BALPA Man
dialogue.text: However, I would just like to add a complaint about shows that have too many complaints in them as they get very tedious for the average viewer.

dialogue.speaker: Another Man
dialogue.text: I'd like to complain about people who hold things up by complaining about people complaining. It's about time something was done about it.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Nurse! Would you take Mrs Pim to see Dr Cream, please.

dialogue.speaker: Milkmaid
dialogue.text: Certainly, doctor. Walk this way, please.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Oh, if I could walk that way I...

dialogue.speaker: Milkman and Milkmaid
dialogue.text: Sssssh!

dialogue.speaker: Milkmaid
dialogue.text: Mrs Pim to see you, Dr Cream.

dialogue.speaker: Dr Cream
dialogue.text: Ah yes. I just want another five minutes with Audrey. Could you show Mrs Pim into the waiting room, please.

dialogue.speaker: Milkmaid
dialogue.text: Yes, doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Dr Cream
dialogue.text: Right, Audrey. When did you first start thinking you were a cow?

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: 'Jeez, Mr Belpit your legs is all swollen'...

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: 'Oi, Mr Belpit - your great legs is all swollen!'...

dialogue.speaker: Boniface
dialogue.text: Good evening. Tonight on 'It's the Mind', we examine the phenomenon of déjà vu. That strange feeling we sometimes get that we've lived through something before, that what is happening now has already happened. Tonight on 'It's the Mind' we examine the phenomenon of déjà vu, that strange feeling we sometimes get that we've ... Anyway, tonight on 'It's the Mind' we examine the phenomenon of déjà vu, that strange...

dialogue.speaker: Boniface
dialogue.text: Good evening. Tonight on 'It's the Mind' we examine the phenomenon of déjà vu, that strange feeling we someti... mes get ... that ... we've lived through something...

dialogue.speaker: Boniface
dialogue.text: Good ... good evening. Tonight on 'It's the Mind' we examine the phenomenon of dddddddddddéjà vvvvvvvvuu, that extraordinary feeling... quite extraordinary... No, fine thanks, fine. Oh, thank you. That strange feeling we sometimes get that we've lived through something before. No, fine thank you. Fine. ... Thank you. That strange feeling ... No. Fine, thank you. Fine. thank you. Look, something's happening to me. I - I - um, I think I'd better go and see someone. Goodnight.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Oi, haven't I seen you somewhere before?

dialogue.speaker: Boniface
dialogue.text: No, doctor, no. Something very funny's happening to me.

dialogue.speaker: Milkman
dialogue.text: Oi, haven't I seen you somewhere before?

dialogue.speaker: Boniface
dialogue.text: No, doctor, no. Something very funny's happening to me.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: 'Oh, Mr Belpit, your legs are so swollen.'

dialogue.speaker: Dr Cream
dialogue.text: Ah, come in. Now what seems to be the matter?

dialogue.speaker: Boniface
dialogue.text: I have this terrible feeling of déjà vu.

dialogue.speaker: Dr Cream
dialogue.text: Ah, come in. Now what seems to be the matter?

dialogue.speaker: Boniface
dialogue.text: I have this terrible feeling of déjà vu..

dialogue.speaker: Dr Cream
dialogue.text: Ah, come in. Now what seems to be the matter?

dialogue.speaker: Boniface
dialogue.text: I have this terrible feeling of déjà vu..

annotations: Wide shot of enormous high block of flats. The camera seems to be searching. Suddenly it zooms in on one window. It is a bedroom...a busty girl is looking out the window. She stretches langourously and mouths.
(dubbed on very badly)

She starts to undress. She gets down to bra and panties, unhitches her bra and is about to slip it off her shoulders exposing her heavy bosoms when...the announcer rises up in front of the window on window cleaner's hoist.

Cut to an orchard or a woodland clearing, in which are a group of stuffed animals; a lion, a tiger, a cow, an elk, a leopard, two small ferrets and an owl on an overhanging branch. Sound of birdsong. The elk explodes.
Cut back to John still in front of the window. We can just see Carol behind him in the bedroom casting her panties to one side - that is we just see her arm.
Cut to 'It's' man
Animated titles.
(tries a different voice)
Bishop points to a secretary some yards away sitting at a desk typing. She wears glasses and is very typically a secretary.
(He continues rehearsing as Mr Chigger moves over to the secretary)

She gets up, clutching a file and trips off in a typical efficient secretary's walk. Mr Chigger follows. Cut to a river. She goes straight in without looking to right or left, as if she does this routine as a matter of course. Mr Chigger follows. Halfway across the river they pass a couple of business executives hurrying in the opposite direction.
Cut to a forest. They come past towards camera, passing a tea trolley on the way with a tea lady and a couple of men around it.

Arty shot. Skyline of a short sharp hill, as in Bergman's 'Seventh Seal'. They come in frame right and up and over, passing two men and exchanging 'Good mornings'. Cut to seashore. Tripping along, they pass another executive.
They disappear into a cave. We hear footsteps and a heavy door opening.
Cut to a shopping street. Camera pans in close-up across road surface.
Camera reaches a GPO tent in middle of road.
(they emerge from the tent)
(cut to interior office, another identical secretary at the desk)
(he enters and first secretary trips off he approaches the second secretary)
He goes through door. Mr Anemone is suspended by a wire about nine feet off the ground. He is on the telephone.
(into phone)
(he throws receiver at telephone but misses)
(very loudly)
(Mr Chigger gets on the table)
(Mr Chigger jumps and lands on the floor)
(sarcasticaly)
(imitation posh accent)
(taking hoop)
(he waves hoop over head and feet)
(he moves hoop all the way along himself allowing the wire to pass through obvious gap in hoop's circumference)
Interior cockpit of airliner. Mr Chigger (pilot) and a second pilot sitting at controls.
Cut to BALPA spokesman sitting at a desk. He is in Captain's uniform and has a name plate in front of him on the desk saying 'BALPA Spokesman'.
Interior cockpit. For three seconds. Then cut back to BALPA spokesman.
(phone ring)
(puts phone down)
Back in the cockpit of the airliner. The two pilots sit there. Atmospheric noise of a big airliner in flight. Suddenly there is a banging on the door at the back of the cockpit.
(off-screen)
(the two pilots exchange a puzzled look, then shrug and go back to flying; suddenly another series of bangs on door)
(they exchange another look; pause; a heavier bang on the door)
(a crash as he attempts to force it; another crash and the door flies open; Mr Zanie enters)
(suddenly realizing where he is)
A pause. Zanie remains standing at the back of cockpit. The pilots go on as if he is not there.
(another nervous laugh; not the slightest reaction from the pilots)
(into intercom)
(finally he realizes his attempt at small talk is not working)
(he pushes lever down on the door which opens directly out of the plane)
(he gives it a shoulder charge and flies straight out of the plane)
Plane noise overhead. Continue scream. Outside of a gent's lavatory, there is a big pile of straw. Pause, then Zanie drops onto the straw. He looks up at gent's sign.
He brushes himself down and goes into gents. Cut back to cockpit. A hostess enters from the passenger cabin.
Door opens and a man in a neat suit enters. From beneath his jacket he produces a revolver with silencer attachment. He points it at the pilots.
The ensuing conversation is perfectly calm and friendly.
(joining in the general spirit of bonhomie)
They all laugh.
(they laugh again)
They open the door and throw him out.
(as he falls)
Cut to haystack in a field
(not the same bale of hay that was landed on before)

. Aeroplane noise overhead. The gunman suddenly falls into the haystack. He gets up, brushes himself down, hops over a fence, and reaches a road. He puts his hand out and a bus stops. It has 'Straight to Luton' written on it. He gets in. Conductor is just about to take his fare, when an evil-looking man with a gun jumps up and points gun at conductor.

Bus moving away from camera. The destination board changes to 'Straight to Cuba'. The bus does a speedy u-turn, and goes out of frame. Camera pans away revealing a rather rocky highland landscape. As camera pans across country we hear inspiring Scottish music.
(at this moment we pick up a highland gentleman in kilt and tam o'shanter clutching a knobkerry in one hand and a letter in the other)
Cut to crofter's cottage. McTeagle sits at the window writing. We zoom in very slowly on him us he writes.
(voice over)
Cut to Lassie O'Shen - a young sweet innocent Scots girl - she is valiantly trying to fend off the sexual advances of the sound man. Two other members of the crew pull him out of shot.
(she has immediately a piece of paper in her hand from which she reads)
There is a pause. She looks up.
(voice over)
Another pause. The soundman leaps on her and pulls her to the ground. Cut to abstract trendy arts poetry programme set. Intense critic sits on enormous inflatable see-through pouffe.
(intensely)

Pan across studio to a stark poetry-reading set. A single light falls on an Ian McKellan figure in black leotard standing gazing dramatically into space. Camera crabs across studio until it is right underneath him. He speaks the lines with great intensity.

Cut to remote Scottish landscape, craggy and windtorn and desolate. In stark chiaroscuro against the sky we see McTeagle standing beside a lonely pillar box, writing postcards. The sun setting behind him.
(voice over)
Cut to David Mercer figure in his study at a desk.
Cut to long shot of McTeagle walking through countryside.
(voice over)
(continues muttering indistinctly)
He walks out of shot past a glen containing several stuffed animals, one of which explodes. A highland spokesman stands up into shot.
A doctor's head appears out from under the kilt.
(he goes back under the kilt; a slight pause; he re-emerges)
Animation leads to a living room. Doorbell rings. Lady opens the door, a milkman stands there.
(ticks form on his clipboard)
(holds up a card saying '3' three times)
(he ticks his board again)
(narrowing her eyes, suspecting a trap)
(does some adding up and whistling)
The milkman and lady walk down her garden path. As they go out of the garden gate there's a cat on the garden wall.

The cat explodes. The milkman motions her towards the milk float with a large signboard which reads: 'Psychiatrist's Dairy Ltd'. Just as they are getting in, she points to all the files in the back in milk crates.
(drives off; the van speaker announces: 'Psychiatrists! Psychiatrists!' The doctor from the Scots sketch hails him)
(puts down crate and gets out note pad)
(taking a card out of crate and showing it to the doctor)
Cut to a psychiatrist called Dr Cream in his office.
Cut back to milkman with doctor.
(handing over yogurt)
Cut to man at desk.
Cut to Dr Cream.
Cut back to man.
Cut to Dr Cream.
Cut to BALPA man.
Cut to man.
Cut to BALPA man.
Cut to Dr Cream.
Cut to BALPA man.
Cut to another man.
(the sixteen-ton weight falls on him)
Cut to a street with milkman and lady riding on milk float. It comes to a halt. They get out, milkman hails a milkmaid with yoke and two pails.
The milkmaid leads Mrs Pim into a building, and into a psychiatrist's office. Dr Cream is in a chair.
As milkmaid and Mrs Pim leave the room we see that there is a cow on the couch.

Milkmaid and Mrs Pim emerge from building through a herd of cows and we then have a montage of shots of them walking through countryside as in opening sequence of flying lesson sketch at beginning of show. They pass a tea trolley woman, the bishop learning his script...
(Australian accent)

...the secretary at her desk, past the stuffed animals which explodes, then past the tea lady again, and then past the bishop again and then past the secretary again, still going in the same direction.
(Scots accent)
(then again with japanese accent)
Cut to montage of photographs of sections of brain, a man with an egg in his head, a man looking through microscope, diagrams of brain, music over this and:
Cut to a man sitting at usual desk. He is Mr Boniface.
(looks puzzled for a moment)
Cut to opening title sequence with montage of psychiatric photos and the two captions and music over. Cut back to Mr Boniface at desk, shaken.
Cut to opening titles again. Back then to Boniface, now very shaken.
(he tails off, goes quiet, the phone rings, he picks it up)
(he rings off, a man comes in on the right and hands him glass of water and leaves)
(phone rings again; he picks it up)
(he rings off; a man comes in from right and hands him a glass of water; he jumps)
(phone rings; he answers)
(ring off; a man enters and gives him glass of water)
(he screams with fear)
Phone rings again. He leaps from desk and runs out of shot. He runs out of building into street and chases after passing milk float and leaps aboard.

Cut to montage of photographs again with captions and music. Cut to Boniface at desk. Boniface screams and runs out of shot. Cut to same piece of film as just previously, when he chases float, leaps on and the milkman says:
The milk float goes past in the background with the milkman and Boniface on it. We see the float go along the country lane past the clearing, past the bishop...
(camp)
.. and the secretary at her desk, past a sign saying 'to the zoo' where explosions are heard, and stops outside Dr Cream's building... Boniface runs into building and enters Dr Cream's office.
Repeat same clip from Boniface entering.
Repeat clip again.
Clip starts to repeat again as the programme ends.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 15

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different.

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Lady Mountback
dialogue.text: Come in.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: Trouble at mill.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Mountback
dialogue.text: Oh no. What sort of trouble?

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: One on't cross beams gone owt askew on treddle.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Mountback
dialogue.text: Pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: One on't cross beams gone owt askew on treddle.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Mountback
dialogue.text: I don't understand what you're saying.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: One of the cross beams has gone out askew on the treddle.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Mountback
dialogue.text: Well what on earth does that mean?

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: don't know. Mr Wentworth just told me to come in here and say that there was trouble at the mill, that's all - I didn't expect a kind of Spanish Inquisition.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition! Our chief weapon is surprise...surprise and fear...fear and surprise.... our two weapons are fear and surprise...and ruthless efficiency.... Our weapons are fear, surprise, and ruthless efficiency...and an almost fanatical devotion to the Pope.... Our ...no... our weapons.... amongst our weaponry...are such elements as fear, surprise.... I'll come in again.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: I didn't expect a kind of Spanish Inquisition.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition! Amongst our weaponry are such diverse elements as fear, surprise, ruthless efficiency, and an almost fanatical devotion to the Pope, and nice red uniforms - oh damn! I can't say it, you'll have to say it.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: You'll have to say the bit about 'Our chief weapons are ...'

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: I couldn't do that...

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: I didn't expect a kind of Spanish Inquisition.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Er.... Nobody...um....

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Expects.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Expects... Nobody expects the...um...the Spanish...um...

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Inquisition.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: I know...I know! Nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition. In fact, those who do expect...

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Our chief weapons are...

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Our chief weapons are...um...er...

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Surprise.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Surprise and...

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Stop. Stop there! Stop there. Whew! Our chief weapon is surprise, blah, blah, blah, blah. Cardinal, read the charges.

dialogue.speaker: Fang
dialogue.text: You are hereby charged that you did on diverse dates commit heresy against the Holy Church. My old man said follow the...

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: That's enough. Now, how do you plead?

dialogue.speaker: Lady Mountback
dialogue.text: We're innocent.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha!

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: We'll soon change your mind about that!

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Fear, surprise, and a most ruthless... ooooh! Now, Cardinal, the rack!

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: You....Right! Tie her down. Right! How do you plead?

dialogue.speaker: Lady Mountback
dialogue.text: Innocent.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Ha! Right! Cardinal, give the rack give the rack a turn.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: I . I know you can't. I didn't want to say anything. I just wanted to try and ignore your crass mistake.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: It makes it all seem so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Shall I, um...?

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Oh, go on, just pretend for God's sake.

dialogue.stage_direction: Ah, hello, you don't know me, but I'm from the BBC. We were wondering if you'd come and answer the door in a sketch over there, in that sort of direction... You wouldn't have to do anything - just open the door and that's it.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: Oh, well all right, yes.

dialogue.speaker: BBC Man
dialogue.text: Jolly good. Come this way.

dialogue.speaker: BBC Man
dialogue.text: Yes, we're on film at the moment you see.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: It's a link, is it?

dialogue.speaker: BBC Man
dialogue.text: Yes that's right, that sort of thing, yes, a link. It's all a bit zany - you know a bit madcap funster... frankly I don't fully understand it myself, the kids seem to like it. I much prefer Des O'Connor ... Rolf Harris ... Tom Jones, you know...

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: You do a lot of this sort of thing, do you?

dialogue.speaker: BBC Man
dialogue.text: Quite a lot yes, quite a lot. I'm mainly in comedy. I'd like to be in Programming Planning actually, but unfortunately I've got a degree.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Joke, sir? Guaranteed amusing. As used by the crowned heads of Europe. Has brought tears to the eyes of Royalty. 'Denmark has never laughed so much' - 'The Stage'. Nice little novelty number - 'a naughty Humphrey' - breaks the ice at parties. Put it on the table. Press the button. It vomits. Absolutely guaranteed. With refills. 'Black soap' - leave it in the bathroom, they wash their hands, real fungus grows on the fingers. Can't get it off for hours. Guaranteed to break the ice at parties. Frighten the elderly - real snakes. Comedy hernia kit. Plastic flesh wounds - just keep your friends in stitches. Guaranteed to break the ice at parties. Hours of fun with 'honeymoon delight' - empty it into their beds - real skunk juice. They won't forget wedding night. Sticks to the skin, absolutely waterproof, guaranteed to break the ice at parties. Amuse your friends - CS gas canisters - smells, tastes and acts just like the real thing - can blind, maim or kill. Or for drinks, why not buy a 'wicked willy' with a life-size winkle - serves warm beer. Makes real cocktails. Hours of amusement. Or get the new Pooh-Pooh machine. Embarrass your guests - completely authentic sound. Or why not try a new 'naughty nightie' - put it on and it melts - just watch their faces. Guaranteed to break the ice at naughty parties. Go on, go on.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Do the punchline.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: What punchline?

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: The punchline for this bit.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: I don't know it. They didn't say anything about a punchline.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Oh! Oh well in that case I'll be saying goodbye then, sir... Goodbye then, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: What's the punchline?

dialogue.speaker: BBC Man
dialogue.text: Punchline? I don't think there's a punchline scheduled, is there? Where are we? A week 39.4 no, it's Friday, isn't it - 39.7. Oh ... here we are. Oh! Ha, ha, ha, very good. Ha, ha, ha, very good. What a good punchline. Pity we missed that. Still, never mind, we can always do it again. Make a series out of it. Now if you'll just sign there, I'll put this through to our contracts department and you should be hearing from them in a year or two.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: Can you give me a lift back?

dialogue.speaker: BBC Man
dialogue.text: Ah - can do. But won't. We were wondering if we could possibly borrow your head for a piece of animation.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: BBC Man
dialogue.text: Oh jolly good. Thanks very much. You will get expenses.

dialogue.stage_direction: Gentlemen, our MP saw the PM this AM and the PM wants more LSD from the PIB by tomorrow AM or PM at the latest. I told the PM's PPS that AM was NBG so tomorrow PM it is for the PM nem. con. Give us a fag or I'll go spare. Now, the fiscal deficit with regard to the monetary balance, the current financial year excluding invisible exports, but adjusted of course for seasonal variations and the incremental statistics of the fiscal and revenue arrangements for the forthcoming annual budgetary period terminating in April.

dialogue.speaker: First Official
dialogue.text: I think he's talking about taxation.

dialogue.speaker: Politician
dialogue.text: Bravo, Madge. Well done. Taxation is indeed the very nub of my gist. Gentlemen, we have to find something new to tax.

dialogue.speaker: Second Official
dialogue.text: I understood that.

dialogue.speaker: Third Official
dialogue.text: If I might put my head on the chopping block so you can kick it around a bit, sir...

dialogue.speaker: Politician
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: Third Official
dialogue.text: Well most things we do for pleasure nowadays are taxed, except one.

dialogue.speaker: Politician
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Third Official
dialogue.text: Well, er, smoking's been taxed, drinking's been taxed but not ... thingy.

dialogue.speaker: Politician
dialogue.text: Good Lord, you're not suggesting we should tax... thingy?

dialogue.speaker: First Official
dialogue.text: Poo poo's?

dialogue.speaker: Third Official
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: First Official
dialogue.text: Thank God for that. Excuse me for a moment.

dialogue.speaker: Third Official
dialogue.text: No, no, no - thingy.

dialogue.speaker: Second Official
dialogue.text: Number ones?

dialogue.speaker: Third Official
dialogue.text: No, thingy.

dialogue.speaker: Politician
dialogue.text: Thingy!

dialogue.speaker: Second Official
dialogue.text: Ah, thingy. Well it'll certainly make chartered accountancy a much more interesting job.

dialogue.speaker: Gumby
dialogue.text: I would put a tax on all people who stand in water ... ... Oh!

dialogue.speaker: Man In Bowler Hat
dialogue.text: To boost the British economy I'd tax all foreigners living abroad.

dialogue.speaker: Man In Suit
dialogue.text: I would tax the nude in my bed. No - not tax. What is the word? Oh - 'welcome'.

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: I would tax Racquel Welch. I've a feeling she'd tax me.

dialogue.speaker: First Business Man
dialogue.text: Bring back hanging and go into rope.

dialogue.speaker: Second Business Man
dialogue.text: I would cut off the more disreputable parts of the body and use the space for playing fields.

dialogue.speaker: Man In Cap
dialogue.text: I would tax holiday snaps.

dialogue.speaker: Dear Old Lady
dialogue.text: (Marjorie Wilde) This is Uncle Ted in front of the house. This is Uncle Ted at the back of the house. And this is Uncle Ted at the side of the house. This is Uncle Ted back in front of the house, but you can see the side of the house. And this is Uncle Ted even nearer the side of the house, but you can still see the front. This is the back of the house, with Uncle Ted coming round the side to the front. And the is the Spanish Inquisition hiding behind the coal shed.

dialogue.speaker: Young Lady
dialogue.text: Oh! I didn't expect a Spanish Inquisition.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'IN THE EARLY YEARS OF THE SIXTEENTH CENTURY, TO COMBAT THE RISING TIDE OF RELIGIOUS UNORTHODOXY, THE POPE GAVE CARDINAL XIMINEZ OF SPAIN LEAVE TO MOVE WITHOUT LET OR HINDRANCE THROUGHOUT THE LAND, IN A REIGN OF VIOLENCE, TERROR AND TORTURE THAT MAKES A SMASHING FILM. THIS WAS THE SPANISH INQUISITION...'

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Now, old woman! You are accused of heresy on three counts. Heresy by thought, heresy by word, heresy by deed, and heresy by action. counts. Do you confess?

dialogue.speaker: Dear Old Lady
dialogue.text: I don't understand what I'm accused of.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Ha! Then we shall you understand...Biggles! Fetch...the cushions!

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Here they are, lord.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Now, old lady, you have one last chance. Confess the heinous sin of heresy, reject the works of the ungodly - last chances. And you shall be free... last chances. You have three last chances, the nature of which I have divulged in my previous utterance.

dialogue.speaker: Dear Old Lady
dialogue.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Right! If that's the way you want it - Cardinal! Poke her with the soft cushions! Confess! Confess! Confess!

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: It doesn't seem to be hurting her, my lord.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Have you got all the stuffing up one end?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Yes, lord.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Hm! She is made of harder stuff! Cardinal Fang - fetch...the comfy chair!

dialogue.speaker: Fang
dialogue.text: The comfy chair?

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: So you think you are strong because you can survive the soft cushions. Well, we shall see. Biggles! Put her in the Comfy Chair! Now. You will stay in the Comfy Chair until lunch time, with only a cup of coffee at eleven... Is that really all it is?

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Why, yes lord.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: I see. I suppose we make it worse by shouting a lot, do we? Confess, woman. Confess! Confess!

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: I confess!

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Not you!

dialogue.speaker: Animation Voice
dialogue.text: I confess.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Who was that?

dialogue.stage_direction: And now for the very first time on the silver screen comes the film from two books which once shocked a generation. From Emily Brontë's 'Wuthering Heights' and from the 'International Guide to Semaphore Code'. Twentieth Century Vole presents 'The Semaphore Version of Wuthering Heights'.

script.description: SUBTITLE: 'YES! YES! I'VE BEEN SEEING HEATHCLIFFE, AND WHY NOT? HE'S THE ONLY MAN I EVER LOVED. HE'S FINE. HE'S STRONG. HE'S ALL THE THINGS YOU'LL NEVER BE, AND WHAT'S MORE . . .'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: From the pulsating pages of history, from the dark and furious days of Imperial Rome we bring you a story that shattered the world! A tale so gripping that they said it could not he filmed. A unique event in cinema history! Julius Caesar on an Aldis lamp!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: From the makers of 'Gunfight at the OK Corral in Morse Code'.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And the smoke-signal version of 'Gentlemen Prefer Blondes'.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, have you reached a verdict?

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: We have m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: And how do you find the defendant? Two words. First word. Rope? String?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Point?

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Belt?

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Tie?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Cravat? Silk square?

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Knot?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Knot!

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Second word. Two syllables. First syllable. Bird?

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Swimmer?

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Breast stroke.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Brian Phelps.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: No, no, no, he was a diver.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Esther Williams then.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: No, no, don't be silly. How can you find someone 'Not Esther Williams'.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Fish. Fish wheeze. Fish wheeze?

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Fish breathe.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Fish breathe, throat.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Fish breathe, throat? GILL! Not gill. Second syllable. Not gill.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Drink.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Sip? Imbibe?

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Not gill ... cup? Not gillcup! You have been found not gillcup of the charges brought against you and may leave this court a free man. Right. My turn.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Four words.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: First word shout?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Bellow?

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Call?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Call!

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Second word is very small.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: A?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: An?

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Up?

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: The?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: The!

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Call the, third word:

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Gill?

dialogue.speaker: Member of Jury
dialogue.text: Fish?

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Adam's apple. Neck. Sounds like neck?

dialogue.speaker: Second Counsel
dialogue.text: Next.

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: Call the ... next!

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Fourth word, three syllables. First syllable ... ear?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Hear. Can't hear.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Deaf!! Call the next def-.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Bottom.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Seat? Trouser? Cheek?

dialogue.speaker: Foreman
dialogue.text: End! Call the next defend-.

dialogue.speaker: Whole Court
dialogue.text: Ant!

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Call the next defendant! Call the next defendant. The Honourable Mr Justice Kilbraken. If I may charge you m'lud, you are charged m'lud that on the fourteenth day of June 1970, at the Central Criminal Court, you did commit acts likely to cause a breach of the peace. How plead you m'lud, guilty or not guilty?

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: Not guilty. Case not proven. Court adjourned.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no, no, no. No, you're in the dock, m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: I'm a judge, m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: So am I, m'lud, so watch it.

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: Hah! Call this a court.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Call this a court. Call this a court..Call this a court.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Shut up. Right now get on with the spiel.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: M'lud, and my other lud, the prosecution will endeavour to show m'lud, that m'lud - ah, not you m'lud, that m'lud, m'lud, while passing sentence at the Central Criminal Court blotted his copy book. Call exhibit Q.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Q?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Sorry did I say Q? I meant A. Sorry, call exhibit A.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk
dialogue.text: Call exhibit A.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Exhibit A m'lud, Miss Rita Thang, an artist's model, Swedish accordion teacher and cane-chair sales lady, was found guilty under the Rude Behaviour Act in the accused's court. The accused, m'lud, sentenced her to be taken from this place and brought round to his place.

dialogue.speaker: Second Counsel
dialogue.text: Objection, m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: Objection sustained.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: You shut up! Objection overruled.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: The accused then commented on Miss Thang's bodily structure, made several not-at-all legal remarks on the subject of fun and then placed his robes over his head and began to emit low moans.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Have you anything to say in your defense?

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: I haven't had any for weeks.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Oh no? What about that little number you've got tucked away in Belsize Park?

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: Oh, I never!

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Oh no. Ho! Ho! Ho!

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: All right then what about 8a Woodford Square?

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: You say anything about that and I'll do you for treason.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: M'lud if we could continue ...

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: He's got a Chinese bit there.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: No, that's contempt of court.

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: It was only a joke.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Contempt of court. However, I'm not going to punish you, because we're so short of judges at the moment, what with all of them emigrating to South Africa. I'm going tomorrow; I've got my ticket. Get out there and get some decent sentencing done. Ooh, England makes you sick. Best I can manage here is life imprisonment. It's hardly worth coming in in the morning. Now, South Africa? You've got your cat of nine tails, you've got four death sentences a week, you've got cheap drinks, slave labour and a booming stock market. I'm off, I tell you. Yes, I'm up to here with probation and bleeding psychiatric reports. That's it, I'm off. That's it. Right. But I'm going to have one final fling before I leave, so I sentence you to be burnt at the stake.

dialogue.speaker: Judge Kilbraken
dialogue.text: Blimey! I didn't expect the Spanish Inquisition.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Two, er, three to the Old Bailey please.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Look they've started the credits.

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Hurry. Hurry. Hurry.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Come on hurry. Hurry!

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: There's the lighting credit, only five left. Hell, it's the producer - quick!

dialogue.speaker: Ximinez
dialogue.text: Nobody expects the Spa... Oh bugger!

annotations: A field. A man with large mechanical wings, pulleys and gears contraption, running along trying to fly. Cut to him going faster. Cut to him going even faster. Cut to him even faster and suddenly he appears to take off, jumping off a dune or a hillock. Cut to him flying in slow motion so that it looks like he is gliding. He hits what seems to be a cliff. Camera twists round so that it is the right way up, showing that the flyer has fallen down a cliff onto a beach. It pans across from the wreck of the flyer. As it pans across the sand, various other would-be fliers can be seen, heads in the sand, legs kicking up in the air, amidst the broken debris of their planes. Camera continues to pan until it comes across an announcer in DJ sitting at his desk:
Animated titles. Music: Black Dyke Mills Band playing a slow dirge.
Stock shot of mill town at the turn of the century - at night.
Mix through to mill-owner's opulent sitting room at the turn of the century. Lady Mountback sits with her crochet. There is a knock on the door.
(slightly irritatedly and with exaggeratedly clear accent)
Jarring chord. The door flies open and Cardinal Ximinez of Spain enters, flanked by two junior cardinals. Cardinal Biggles has goggles pushed over his forehead. Cardinal Fang is just Cardinal Fang.
(exit and exeunt)
Jarring chord. They burst in.
(to Biggles)
Ximinez bundles the cardinals outside.
They all enter.
(to Lady Mountback)
(controls himself with a supreme effort)
Biggles produces a plastic-coated dish-drying rack. Ximinez looks at it and clenches his teeth in an effort not to lose control. He hums heavily to cover his anger.
(Fang and Biggles make a pathetic attempt to tie her on to the drying rack)
(oh dear)
Cardinal Biggles stands their awkwardly and shrugs.
(gritting his teeth)

Biggles turns an imaginary handle on the side of the rack. The doorbell rings. Reg detaches himself from the scene and answers it. Outside there is a dapper BBC man with a suit and a beard, slightly arty.
Cut to film of them coming out of the front door of the house and walking to BBC van. Conversation is heard throughout (slightly faintly).
They get into the van. It drives off. They pass an AA sign saying 'To the Sketch'. Panning shot of them, in which we see them convening and hear...

They arrive outside a suburban house, where the novelty salesman, Mr Johnson, is already waiting outside the front door. BBC man points and gives Reg direction. Reg goes to the door saying: 'Excuse me' and goes in, closing the front door. The novelty man rings bell. Reg opens the door.
He turns and walks away. Reg looks around desperately. And then runs out of the door. He runs to BBC van as Johnson walks out of picture. Cut to cabin of BBC van with the BBC man sitting there.
(laughs)
BBC staff set on Reg and saw his head off.
Reg's head starts off by being thrown into picture.
Animation leads to an oak panelled, Civil Service committee room. A politician is addressing three officals.
(leaves)
Cut to vox pops.
(standing in water)
(looks round him)

Freeze frame. Cut to snapshot of same stil which is being held by a dear old lady. Pull out to reveal she is sitting with a large photo album on her knees, lovingly extracting photos from the piles on top of the album and passing them to her friend sitting on the same settee. Her friend is a young lady, who tears up the photos as they are handed to her. The dear old lady is in a world of her own and does not notice.
(she hand over the photo and the young lady tears it up)
(she hand over the photo and the young lady tears it up)
(she hand over the photo and the young lady tears it up)
(she hand over the photo and the young lady tears it up)
(she hand over the photo and the young lady tears it up)
(she hand over the photo and the young lady tears it up)
Friend takes it with the first sign of real interest.
Jarring chord. The door flies open and Ximinez, Biggles and Fang enter.
Cut to film: moving over Breugel drawing of tortures; epic film music.
(and CAPTION:)

Torchlit dungeon. We hear clanging footsteps. Shadows on the Grille. The footsteps stop and keys jangle. The great door creaks open and Ximinez walks in and looks round approvingly. Fang and Biggles enter behind pushing in the dear old lady. They chain her to the wall.
Jarring chord. Biggles holds out two ordinary modern household cushions.
(Biggles carries out this rather pathetic torture)
(angrily hurling away the cushions)
Another loud jarring chord. Zoom in on Fang's horrified face.
Fang pushes in a comfy chair - a really plush one.
(Biggles roughly push her into the comfy chair)
(to Biggles)
'I confess'

Film: appropriate film music throughout. Heathcliffe (Terry J) in close-up profile, his hair is blowing in the wind, he looks intense. Cut to close-up Catherine (Carol) also in profile, with hair streaming in wind. As if they are looking into each other's eyes. Pull out to reveal, on very long zoom, that they are each on the top of separate small hills, in rolling countryside. Heathcliffe produces two semaphore flags from behind him, and waves them.
Pan across to Catherine who also produces two flags and waves.
Heathcliffe waves flags again.
With each cut they are further and further away from each other.
Catherine waves flags again.
Cut to her husband at front door of early Victorian manor house, looking stem. He waves two flags.
Cut back to Catherine on hilltop.
Cut to husband with two enormous flags.
Cut to intertor of the early Victorian manor house. Close-up of a cradle. Suddenly two little semaphore flags pop up from inside the cradle and wave.
Pull back to reveal a nurse who walks over to cradle and waves flag briefly.
The nurse points across the room. Cut to shot of old man asleep in chair with head slumped forward on his chest. He has two flags which he waves.
Cut to front door again. Exterior. Husband is waiting. Catherine comes up the path towards him. As she approaches he flags.
Catherine waves frantically.
Stock film of a Roman chariot race.
Close-up of Caesar walking in Roman street. Soothsayer pushes his way up to him wild eyed and produces Aldis lamp and starts flashing:
Some steps at the foot of a statue. Caesar is stabbed. As he falls he brings out a really big Aldis lamp and flashes to the assassins around him.
A Western street. Two cowboys facing each other with morse buzzers.
They buzz a bit.
Cut to a Red Indian making smoke signals.
Cut to a court room.
(the foreman puts his hand out with two fingers extended)
(the foreman nods and holds up one finger)
(the foreman mimes taking a piece of string and tying it in knot)
The foreman shakes his head and points to the knot.
The foreman nods and points to the knot.
The foreman nods enthusiasticaly.
The foreman gives a thumbs up and points to his second finger.
(foreman indicates two syllables)
(the foreman points to his first finger)
(the foreman starts to mime a fish while pointing at his throat)
(the foreman nods and points at throat)
(the foreman gives a thumbs up and the court applauds excitedly)
(the foreman mimes the second syllable)
Foreman mimes drinking a cup of tea.
The foreman points to the mimed cup itself.
(the foreman looks disappointed)
(the defendant leaves.)
The judge holds up four fingers.
The judge mimes shouting for the first word.
The judge gives a thumbs up and indicates that the second word is very small.
The judge gives a thumbs up.
The judge points to his neck.
(the judge shakes his head)
(the judge mime 'sounds like')
The judge gives a thumbs up and indicates that the fourth word is three Syllables. First syllable: he mimes deafness.
The judge leaps onto the desk and points at his own bottom.
The judge leaps down, disappears under the desk and appears with an enormous model of an ant about four feet long.
(the court applauds the judge who bows and sits; the whole mood changes)
(a very elderly judge in full robes comes into the dock)
He hits the dock. Everyone gets up and starts walking out talking to each other.
(they all stop, go back and sit down again)
Two court ushers carry in a thing with a sheet over it. They pull off the sheet to reveal a very sexy girl in a provocative pose.
Court reacts expectantly. Cut to suburban house. The three members of the Spanish Inquisition suddenly belt out of the door and down the path. Dick Barton music. Cut to them leaping onto a bus.
Credits start superimposed.
We see shots of them coming through London.
(more shots of the bus going through London; the credits reach the producer)
They leap off the bus into the Old Bailey. Cut to court room. They burst in.
('The End' appears)

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 14

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different.

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Hello. Tonight on 'Face the Press' we're going to examine two different views of contemporary things. On my left is the Minister for Home Affairs who is wearing a striking organza dress in pink tulle, with matching pearls and a diamante collar necklace. The shoes are in brushed pigskin with gold clasps, by Maxwell of Bond Street. The hair is by Roger, and the whole ensemble is crowned by a spectacular display of Christmas orchids. And on my right - putting the case against the Government - is a small patch of brown liquid ... which could be creosote or some extract used in industrial varnishing. Good evening. Minister, may I put the first question to you? In your plan, 'A Better Britain For Us', you claimed that you would build 88,000 million, billion houses a year in the Greater London area alone. In fact, you've built only three in the last fifteen years. Are you a bit disappointed with this result?

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: No, no. I'd like to answer this question if I may in two ways. Firstly in my normal voice and then in a kind of silly high-pitched whine... You see housing is a problem really...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well, while the minister is answering this question I'd just like to point out the minister's dress has been made entirely by hand from over three hundred pieces of Arabian shot silk especially created for the minister by Vargar's of Paris. The low slim-line has been cut off-the-shoulder to heighten the effect of the minister's fine bone structure. Well I think the minister is coming to the end of his answer now so let's go back over and join the discussion. Thank you very much minister. Today saw the appointment of a new head of...

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Don't I say any more?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: No fear! Today saw the appointment of a new head of Allied Bomber Command - Air Chief Marshal Sir Vincent 'Kill the Japs' Forster. He's in our Birmingham studio...

dialogue.speaker: Sir Vincent
dialogue.text: Hello Sailors! Listen, guess what. The Minister of Aviation has made me head of the RAF Ola Pola.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Hello. Mrs Rogers?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: No. Ooh I must be in the wrong house,

dialogue.speaker: Sir Vincent
dialogue.text: So from now on we're going to do things my way. For a start David Hockney is going to design the bombs. And I've seen the plans...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: That must be the new gas cooker.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Morning. Mrs G. Crump?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: No - Mrs G. Pinnet.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: This is 46 Egernon Crescent?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: No - Road. Egernon Road.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Road, yes, says here. Yeah. Right, could I speak to Mrs G. Crump please?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Oh there's nobody here of that name. It's Mrs G. Pinnet. 46 Egernon Road.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Well it says 'Crump' here. Don't it, Harry?

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Yeah - it's on the invoice.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Yeah, definitely Crump.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Well there must have been a mistake, because the address is right, and that's definitely the cooker I ordered - a blue and white CookEasi.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Well you can't have this. This is Crump.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Oh dear, what are we going to do?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Well I don't know. What we can do for you is take it back to the Depot, get a transfer slip from Crump to Pinnet, and put it on a special delivery.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Yeah - that's best. We'll special it for you, we'll get it down there today and you'll get it back in ten weeks.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Ten weeks! Blimey, can't you just leave this one?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: What this? What leave it here?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Well I dunno. I suppose we could.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Oh, but she'd have to fill out a temporary despatch note.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Yeah we could leave it on a temporary despatch note.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Well that's sorted out then. What a mess, isn't it.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: I know, it's ridiculous really, but there you are. Glad we could be of such a help. Right, would you sign it down there please, Mrs Crump?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Pinnet.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Pinnet. Listen, just for the books make it a bit easier, could you sign it Crump-Pinnet.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Right. Thank you very much, dear. The cooker's yours. Right. Thank you very much, dear. Right. Sorry about the bother... but there you are ... you know ... cheerio!

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Cheerio, Mrs Crump!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Heh, excuse me! Cooey! Er, can you put it in the kitchen?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: You what?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Well I can't cook on it unless it's connected up.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Oh we didn't realize you had an installation invoice.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: An MI.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: No, we can't touch it without an MI, you see.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Or an R16.

dialogue.speaker: Third Gas Man
dialogue.text: If it's a special.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Nah - it's not special ... the special's back at the Depot.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: No, the special's the same as installation invoice.

dialogue.speaker: Third Gas Man
dialogue.text: So it's an R16.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: What's an installation invoice?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: A pink form from Reading.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Oh - we wondered what that was. Now these are the forms.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: That's the one, love. Yeah, this should be all I need. Hang on. This is for Pinnet. Mrs G. Pinnet.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: That's right. I'm Mrs G. Pinnet.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Well we've got Crump-Pinnet on the invoice.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Well shall I sign it Crump-Pinnet then?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: No, no, no - not an MI - no.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: No - that's from Area Service at Reading.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Gas Man
dialogue.text: No, Cheltenham isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: No, not this side of the street.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Look I just want it connected up.

dialogue.speaker: Third Gas Man
dialogue.text: What about London Office?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Well they haven't got the machinery.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Not now.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Gas Man
dialogue.text: What! The Hounslow Depot?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Gas Man
dialogue.text: No - they're still on standard pressure.

dialogue.speaker: Sixth Gas Man
dialogue.text: Same with Twickenham.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: But surely they can connect up a gas cooker?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, we could connect it up, love, but not unless it's an emergency.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: But this an emergency.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: No it's not. An emergency is 290... 'where there is actual or apparent loss of combustible gaseous substances'.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Yeah, it's like a leak.

dialogue.speaker: Seventh Gas Man
dialogue.text: Yeah, or a 478.

dialogue.speaker: Third Gas Man
dialogue.text: No - that's valve adjustment.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: But there can't be a leak unless you've connected it up.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: No, quite. We'd have to turn it on.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Well can't you turn it on connect it up?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: No. But what we can do, and this is between you and me, I shouldn't really be telling you this, we'll turn your gas on, make a hole in your pipe, you ring Hounslow emergency, they'll be around here in a couple of days.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: What, a house full of gas! I'll be dead by then

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Oh well, in that case you'd have the South East Area Manager round here like a shot.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Ah yes. 'One or more persons overcome by fumes', you'd have Head Office, Holbom, round here.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Yes. That's murder you see.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Or suicide.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Gas Man
dialogue.text: No. That's S42.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Eighth Gas Man
dialogue.text: Still? I thought it was Hainault.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Gas Man
dialogue.text: No - Central area and Southall Marketing Division, they're both on the S42 now.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: And they'd be able to connect it up?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Oh - they'd do the lot for you, love.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: And they'd come round this afternoon?

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: ... Well what is it now... 11:30... murder... they'll be round here by two.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: Oh well that's wonderful.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Oh well, right love, if you'd like to lie down here.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Pinnet
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Okay Harry.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gas Man
dialogue.text: Okay. Gas on.

dialogue.speaker: First Gas Man
dialogue.text: Right, deep breaths love. Ring Head Office would you Norman...

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Gas Man
dialogue.text: Shall I go through maintenance?

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Gas Man
dialogue.text: No, you'd better go through Deptford maintenance.

dialogue.speaker: Sixth Gas Man
dialogue.text: Peckham's on a 207 .... .

dialogue.speaker: Voices
dialogue.text: ... that's LeWisham. What about Tottenham? No that would be a 5.4.. what about Lewisham? It's central isn't it? Or Ruislip...

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Help me? Yeah, I'll say you can help me.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Yes, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: I come about your advert - 'Small white pussy cat for sale. Excellent condition'.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Ah. You wish to buy it?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: That's right. Just for the hour. Only I aint gonna pay more'n a fiver cos it aint worth it.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Well it's come from a very good home - it's house trained.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Chest of drawers? Chest. Drawers. I'd like some chest of drawers please.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Yes, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Does it go?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Er, it's over there in the corner.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Oh. Pram for sale. Any offers. I'd like a bit of pram please.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Ah yes, sir. That's in good condition.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Oh good, I like them in good condition, eh? Eh?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Yes, here it is you see.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Babysitter. No, it's a babysitter. Babysitter?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Babysitter.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Babysitter - I don't want a babysitter. Be a blood donor - that's it. I'd like to give some blood please, argh! Oh spit. Which one is it? Blond prostitute will indulge in any sexual activity for four quid a week. What does that mean?

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: 'Times' please.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Oh yes sir, here you are.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Cheers.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Good morning. I'm sorry to have kept you waiting, but I'm afraid my walk has become rather sillier recently, and so it takes me rather longer to get to work. Now then, what was it again?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well sir, I have a silly walk and I'd like to obtain a Government grant to help me develop it.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
