dialogue.text: I see. May I see your silly walk?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, certainly, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: That's it, is it?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, that's it, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: It's not particularly silly, is it? I mean, the right leg isn't silly at all and the left leg merely does a forward aerial half turn every alternate step.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, but I think that with Government backing I could make it very silly.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Mr Pudey, the very real problem is one of money. I'm afraid that the Ministry of Silly Walks is no longer getting the kind of support it needs. You see there's Defense, Social Security, Health, Housing, Education, Silly Walks ... they're all supposed to get the same. But last year, the Government spent less on the Ministry of Silly Walks than it did on National Defence. Now we get £348,000,000 a year, which is supposed to be spent on all our available products. Coffee?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes please.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Now Mrs Two-Lumps, would you bring us in two coffees please?

dialogue.speaker: Intercom Voice
dialogue.text: Yes, Mr Teabag.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: ... Out of her mind. Now the Japanese have a man who can bend his leg back over his head and back again with every single step. While the Israelis... ah, here's the coffee.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Thank you - lovely. You're really interested in silly walks, aren't you?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh rather. Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Well take a look at this, then.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Now Mr Pudey. I'm not going to mince words with you. I'm going to offer you a Research Fellowship on the Anglo-French silly walk.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: La Marche Futile?

dialogue.speaker: First Frenchman
dialogue.text: Bonjour ... et maintenant ... comme d'habitude, au sujet du Le Marché Commun. Et maintenant, je vous presente, encore une fois, mon ami, le pouf célèbre, Jean-Brian Zatapathique.

dialogue.speaker: Second Frenchman
dialogue.text: Merci, mon petit chou-chou Brian Trubshawe. Et maintenant avec les pieds à droite, et les pieds au gauche, et maintenant l'Anglais-Française Marche Futile, et voilà

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And now a choice of viewing on BBC Television. Just started on BBC2, the semi final of Episode 3 of 'Kierkegaard's Journals', staring Richard Chamberlain, Peggy Mount and Billy Bremner, and on BBC1, 'Ethel the Frog'

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Good evening. On 'Ethel the Frog' tonight we look at violence. The violence of British Gangland. Last Tuesday a reign of terror was ended when the notorious Piranha brothers, Doug and Dinsdale , after one of the most extraordinary trials in British legal history, were sentenced to four hundred years imprisonment for crimes of violence. Tonight Ethell the Frog examinesthe rise to power of the Piranhas, the methods they used to subjugate rival gangs and their subsequent tracking down and capture by the brilliant Superintendent Harry 'Snapper' Organs of Q Division. Doug and Dinsdale Pirenha were born, on probation, in this small house in Kipling Road, Southwark, the eldest sons in a family of sixteen. Their father Arthur Piranha, a scrap-metal dealer and TV quizmaster, was well known to the police, and a devout Catholic. In January 1928 he had married Kitty Malone, an up-and-coming Eastend boxer. Doug was bornin February 1929 and Dinsdale two weeks later; and again a week after that. Their next door neighbour was Mrs April Simnel.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Simmel
dialogue.text: Kipling Road was a typical sort of Eastend street, people were in and out of each other's houses with each other's property all day. They were a cheery lot.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Was it a terribly violent area?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Simmel
dialogue.text: Oh ho......yes. Cheerful and violent. I remember Doug was very keen on boxing, until he learned to walk, then he took up putting the boot in the groin. Oh he was very interested in that. His mother had such trouble getting him to come in for his tea. He'd be out there putting his little boot in, you know, bless him. You know kids were very different then. They didn't have their heads filled with all this Cartesian dualism.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: At the age of fifteen Doug and Dinsdale started attending the Ernest Pythagoras Primary School in Clerkenwell.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Anthony Viney. You taught the Piranha brothers English. What do you remember most about them?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: ...Anthoney Viney.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: When the Piranhas left school they were called up but were found by an Army Board to be too unstable even for National Service. Denied the opportunity to use their talents in the service of their country, they began to operate what they called 'The Operation'. They would select a victim and then threaten to beat him up if he paid the so-called protection money. Four months later they started another operation which the called 'The Other Operation'. In this racket they selected another victim and threatened to beat him up if he pay them. One month later they hit upon 'The Other Other Operation'. In this the victim was threatened that if he didn't pay them, they would beat him up. This for the Piranha brothers was the turning point.

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: Doug and Dinsdale Piranha now formed a gang, which the called 'The Gang' and used terror to take over night clubs, billiard halls, gaming casinos and race tracks. When they tried to take over the MCC they were for the only time in their lives, slit up a treat. As their empire spread however, we in Q Division were keeping tabs on their every move by reading the colour supplements.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: A small-time operator who fell foul of Dinsdale Piranha was Vince Snetterton-Lewis.

dialogue.speaker: Vince
dialogue.text: Well one day I was sitting at home threatening the kids, and I looked out of the hole in the wall and sees this tank drive up and one of Dinsdale's boys gets out and he comes up, all nice and friendly like, and says Dinsdale wants to have a talk with me. So he chains me to the back of the tank and takes me for a scrape round to Dinsdale's. And Dinsdale's there in the conversation pit with Doug and Charles Paisley, the baby crusher, and a couple of film producers and a man they called 'Kierkegaard', who just sat there biting the heads of whippets and Dinsdale sayd 'I hear you've been a naughty boy Clement' and he splits me nostrils open and saws me leg off and pulls me liver out, and I said my name's not Clement and then he loses his temper and nails my head to the floor.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: He nailed your head to the floor?

dialogue.speaker: Vince
dialogue.text: At first, yeah

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Another man who had his head nailed to the floor was Stig O' Tracey.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Stig, I've been told Dinsdale Piranha nailed your head to the floor.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: No, no. Never, never. He was a smashing bloke. He used to give his mother flowers and that. He was like a brother to me.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: But the police have film of Dinsdale actually nailing your head to the floor.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, well - he did that, yeah.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Well he had to, didn't he? I mean, be fair, there was nothing else he could do. I mean, I had transgressed the unwritten law.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: What had you done?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Er... Well he never told me that. But he gave me his word that it was the case, and that's good enough for me with old Dinsy. I mean, he didn't want to nail my head to the floor. I had to insist. He wanted to let me off. There's nothing Dinsdale wouldn't do for you.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And you don't bear him any grudge?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: A grudge! Old Dinsy? He was a real darling.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: I understand he also nailed your wife's head to a coffee table. Isn't that right Mrs O' Tracey?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs O' Tracey
dialogue.text: Oh, no. No. No.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Yeah, well, he did do that. Yeah, yeah. He was a cruel man, but fair

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Vince, after he nailed your head to the floor, did you ever see him again

dialogue.speaker: Vince
dialogue.text: Yeah.....after that I used to go round his flat every Sunday lunchtime to apologize and we'd shake hands and then he'd nail my head to the floor

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Every Sunday?

dialogue.speaker: Vince
dialogue.text: Yeah but he was very reasonable about it. I mean one Sunday when my parents were coming round for tea, I asked him if he'd mind very much not nailing my head to the floor that week and he agreed and just screwed my pelvis to a cake stand.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: He was the only friend I ever had.

dialogue.speaker: Block
dialogue.text: I wouldn't head a word against him.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Lovely fella.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Clearly Dinsdale inspired tremendous loyalty and terror amongst his business associates, but what was he really like?

dialogue.speaker: Gloria
dialogue.text: I walked out with Dinsdale on many occasions and found him a most charming and erudite companion. He was wont to introduce one to eminent persons, celebrated American singers, members of the aristocracy and other gang leaders.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: How had he met them?

dialogue.speaker: Gloria
dialogue.text: Through his work for charity. He took a warm interest in Boys' Clubs, Sailors' Homes, Choristers' Associations, Scouting Jamborees and of course the Household Cavalry.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Was there anything unusual about him?

dialogue.speaker: Gloria
dialogue.text: I should say not. Dinsdale was a perfectly normal person in every way. Except is as much as he was convinced that he was being watched by a giant hedgehog whom he referred to as Spiny Norman.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: How big was Norman supposed to be?

dialogue.speaker: Gloria
dialogue.text: Normally he was wont to be about twelve feet from nose to tail, but when Dinsdale was depressed Norman could be anything up to eight hundred yards long. When Norman was about, Dinsdale would go very quiet and his nose would swell up and his teeth would start moving about and he'd become very violent and claim that he'd laid Stanley Baldwin. Dinsdale was a gentleman. And what's more he knew how to treat a female impersonator.

dialogue.speaker: Criminologist
dialogue.text: It is easy for us to judge Dinsdale Piranha too harshly. After all he only did what many of us simply dream of doing... I'm sorry. After all a murderer is only an extroverted suicide. Dinsdale was a looney, but he was a happy looney. Lucky bastard.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Most of the strange tales concern Dinsdale, but what about Doug? One man who met him was Luigi Vercotti.

dialogue.speaker: Vercotti
dialogue.text: Well, I had been running a successful escort agency - high class, no really, high class girls - we didn't have any of that. That was right out. And I decided. Excuse me Hello......no, not now......shtoom...shtoom....right......yes, we'll have the ready for you at midnight.......the watch.....the ....yes, right-oh, bye-bye mother Anyway I decided then to open a high-class night club for the gentry at Biggleswade with International cuisine, cooking, top-line acts, and not a cheap clip joint for picking up tarts, that was right out, I deny that completely, and one night Dinsdale walked in with a couple of big lads, one of whom was carrying a tactical nuclear missile. They said I'd bought one of their fruit machines and would I pay for it.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: How much did they want?

dialogue.speaker: Vercotti
dialogue.text: Three quarters of a million pounds. Then they went out.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Why didn't you call the police?

dialogue.speaker: Vercotti
dialogue.text: Well I had noticed that the lad with the thermo-nuclear device was the Chief Constable for the area. Anyway a week later they came back, said that the cheque had bounced and that I had to see Doug.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Doug?

dialogue.speaker: Vercotti
dialogue.text: Doug I was terrified of him. Everyone was terrified of Doug. I've seen grown men pull their own heads off rather than see Doug. Even Dinsdale was frightened of Doug.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: What did he do?

dialogue.speaker: Vercotti
dialogue.text: He used sarcasm. He knew all the tricks, dramatic irony, metaphor, bathos, puns, parody, litotes and satire.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: By a combination of violence and sarcasm, the Piranha brothers by February 1966 controlled London and the South East. In February, though, Dinsdale made a big mistake.

dialogue.speaker: Gloria
dialogue.text: Latterly Dinsdale had become increasingly worried about Spiny Norman. He had come to the conclusion that Norman slept in an aeroplane hangar at Luton Airport.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: And so on February 22nd 1966, at Luton airport... Even the police began to sit up and take notice.

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: The Piranhas realized they had gone too far and that the hunt was on. They went into hiding and I decided on a subtle approach, viz some form of disguise, as the old helmet and boots are a bit of a giveaway. Luckily my years with Bristol Rep. stood me in good stead, as I assumed a bewildering variety of disguises. I tracked them to Cardiff, posing as the Reverend Smiler Egret. Hearing they'd gone back to London, I assumed the identity of a pork butcher, Brian Stoats. On my arrival in London, I discovered they had returned to Cardiff, I followed as Gloucester from 'King Lear'. Acting on a hunch I spent several months in Buenos Aires as Blind Pew, returning through the Panama Canal as Ratty, in 'Toad of Toad Hall'. Back in Cardiff, I relived my triumph as Sancho Panza in 'Man of la Mancha' which the 'Bristol Evening Post' described as 'a glittering performance of rare perception', although the 'Bath Chronicle' was less than enthusiastic. In fact it gave me a right panning. I quote...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'As for the performance of Superintendent Harry "Snapper" Organs as Sancho Panza, the audience were bemused by his high-pitched Welsh accent and intimidated by his abusive ad-libs.'

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: 'The 'Western Daily News' said......

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'Sancho Panza (Mr Organs) spoilt an otherwise impeccably choreographed rape scene by his unscheduled appearance and persistent cries of "What's all this then?".'

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Never mind, Snapper, love, you can't win 'em all

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: True constable. Could I have my eye-liner please?

dialogue.speaker: Second Policeman
dialogue.text: Telegram for you, love.

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: Good-oh. Bet it's from Binkie.

dialogue.speaker: Second Policeman
dialogue.text: Those flowers are for Sergant Lauderdale - from the gentleman waiting outside

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: Oh good

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Thirty seconds, superintendent.

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: Oh blimey, I'm on. Is me hat straight, constable?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Oh it's fine

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: Right here we go then, Hawkins.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Oh, merde, superintendent.

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: Good luck, then.

dialogue.speaker: Newspaper Seller
dialogue.text: Read all about it. Piranha brothers escape.

dialogue.speaker: Hedgehog
dialogue.text: Dinsdale? Dinsdale? Dinsdale?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.text: Well, that's all for now and so until next week...

annotations: A man in evening dress, sitting in a cage at the zoo.
Pan to show 'It's' man in next cage.
Animated titles.
(cut to minister completely in drag and a moustache)
(soft fashion-parade music starts to play in background)
(cut to patch of liquid on seat of chair)
(cut back to interviewer)
Cut back to the interviewer. The minister is heard droning on in the background. The soft fashion-parade music starts again.
(at this point we can hear the minister's high-pitched whine beneath the fashion music)
Cut to close-up on what appears to be a monitor with Sir Vincent on it in outrageous drag, heavy lipstick, big bust etc. - Draped on a chaise-longue. A small black boy is fanning him.

As he talks we zoom out quickly from the set to reveal it is not a monitor in the studio but a TV set in a G-plan type sitting room. A housewife (Mrs Pinnet) sits watching, wearing an apron and a scarf and with her hair in curlers. The doorbell sounds. She switches the TV off and answers the door which opens straight into the living room. There in the street stands a truly, amazing figure of fun. A man in a bowler hat with an axe sticking out of it, big red joke nose, illuminated bow tie that revolves, joke broad shoulders, clown's check jacket, long johns with sock suspenders, heavy army boots and leading a goat with a hat. Close-up.

She shuts the door on him and we follow her as she crosses the room. She climbs out of the window. Back yard of terraced house. She scrambles over a quite high dividing wall into next door and starts to scramble into next-door window.
Interior of a more cluttered working-dass sitting-room. There is a TV in there with Sir Vincent still camping it up.
The doorbell rings.
She switches the TV off. Immediate thunderous epic music.
(in stone lettering, as for Ben Hur)
Both caption and music switch off suddenly as she opens the door. Outside the door are two gas men with a new cooker.
(looks at a bit of paper)
(they seem thunderstruck)
(she signs)
(they push it just inside the door and move off)
(coming back)
(who is suddenly revealed behind the two of them)
(she produces a large wad of papers, sorts through and products a pink form which she hands to them)
(suddenly revealed)
Much doubtfulness.
(suddenly, revealed)
(suddenly revealed)
Seventh gas man is revealed.
Eighth gas man is revealed.
(she does so)
(holding a gas pipe to her mouth)

The camera pans along line of gas men all turning to each other and muttering incomprehensible technicalities, the line stretches across to front door. Line continues outside in street and goes into animation sequences which eventually brings us to a close-up on a small ad, which is one of many on the door of a small newsagent's shop. A shabby man is running an evil eye down the adverts, puzzling, looking for something. He walks up to the counter. He has a reflex wink.
(long think, goes to door, looks at ads again)
(indicates a wooden chest of drawers)
(goes to door, runs his finger down the list of adverts)
(picks up pram)
(looks, pauses, goes back to the door, runs finger again)
(shopkeeper shakes head)
(shopkeeper slips him a card from out of his pocket)
A city gent comes into shop. He has a silly walk and keeps doing little jumps and then three long paces without moving the top of his body. He buys a paper, then we follow him as he leaves the shop.

The city gent leaves the shop, from which we see a line of gas men stretching back up the road to Mrs Pinnet's house, and walks off in an indescribably silly manner. Cut to him proceeding along Whitehall, and into a building labelled 'Ministry of Silly Walks '. Inside the building he passes three other men, each walking in their own eccentric way. Cut to an office; a man is sitting waiting. The city gent enters eccentrically.
(sits at desk)
He gets up and does a few steps, lifting the bottom part of his left leg sharply at every alternate pace. He stops.
(rising)
(he walks about behind the desk in a very silly fashion)
(he sits down)
(pressing intercorn)

Enter secretary with tray with two cups on it. She has a particularly jerky silly walk which means that by the time she reaches the minister there is no coffee left in the cups. The minister has a quick look in the cups, and smiles understandingly.
(she exits still carrying tray and cups)

He products a projector from beneath his desk already spooled up and plugged in. He flicks a switch and it beams onto the opposite wall. The film shows a sequence of six old-fashioned silly walkers. The film is old silent-movie type, scratchy, jerky and 8mm quality. All the participants wear 1900's type costume. One has huge shoes with soles a foot thick, one is a woman, one has. very long 'Little Tich' shoes. Cut back to office. The minister hurls the projector away. Along with papers and everything else on his desk. He leans foward.
Cut to two Frenchmen, wearing striped jerseys and berets, standing in a field with a third man who is entirely covered by a sheet.
(he removes his moustache and sticks it onto the other Frenchman)

They unveil the third man and walk off. He is facing to camera left and appears to be dressed as a city gent; then he turns about face and we see on his right half he is dressed au style francais. He moves off into the distance in eccentric speeded-up motion.
(cut to BBC world symbol)
Stirring music - 'This Week' type.
Cut to Presenter at desk in usual grey suit and floral tie.
(photo of same)
(photo of Eastend grotty house)
(old wedding photo)
Exterior in street; interviewer and Mrs Simnel. Line of gas men behind.
(laughs deprecatingly)
Cut to scool playground.
Pan to show Anthony Viney and interviewer with stick mike.

He fails to point stick mike at Viney (graham) who answers. However, when the interviewer poses the next question he points the stick mike to Viney as he does so. This continues, with the mike always pointing to the one who is not talking while Viney relates a fascinating tale complete with large riveting gestures.
Cut to presenter.
Cut to Superintendent Organs
Cut to Vince in a chair in a nasty flat.
(off-screen)
Cut to presenter.
Cut to another younger more cheerful man on sofa.
Camera pans to show woman with coffee table nailed to head.
Cut back to Vince.
Cut to man affixed to a coffee table and a standard lamp.
Cut to block of concrete with a man upside down with his head buried in it.
Cut to a gravestone, which says: 'R.I.P. and Good Luck, Dinsdale'.
Cut to presenter.
Cut to a bar.
(off screen)
Cut to dark-suited loony in armchair.
(tic...controls himself)
Cut to tatty office with desk and phone. Vercotti at deak.
(phone rings on desk)
(he answers it)
(he replaces reciever)
(takes a drink)
Cut to map.
(voice over)
Cut back to bar and Gloria
(stock film of H-Bomb exploding)
Cut to 'Snapper' Organs.
(photo of Organs disguised as a butcher)
(photo of Organs as Gloucester)
(photo of Ratty)
(photo)
Cut to press cutting, shich reads:
Cut to letterhead of newspaper - 'The Western Daily News'.
(off screen)
Cut to back-stage-type dressing-room, with make-up mirrors.
Knock, knock. Head comes round the door.
Cut to exterior of Police Station. They come down the stairs and walk off along pavement. The city gent passes them doing his silly walk. Cut to a little newspaper seller
Cut to suburban street: it completely clears very fast. Freeze frame on empty street. An enormous hedgehog higher that the houses comes into shot saying 'Dinsdale?'
Roll credits, behind which we see the enormous hedgehog appearing in various well-known London locations.
Cut to John in cage as in opening shot.
(roars)
Pan to next cage to show skeleton of 'It's' Man. Fade out.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: Well I deal mainly with mortgage protection policies, but I also do certain types of life assurance.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Now if you and your pal had one big wish, Trevor, what would you like to see on television?

dialogue.speaker: Trevor
dialogue.text: I'd like to see more fairy stories about the police.

dialogue.speaker: Fairy
dialogue.text: And so you shall.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Yes, we in Special Crime Squad have been using wands for almost a year now. You find it's easy to make yourself invisible. You can defy time and space, and you can turn violent criminals into frogs. Something which you could never do with the old truncheons.

dialogue.speaker: First Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, tonight 'Probe Around' takes a look at crime...

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: I'm sorry about that, but I always introduce this programme, not him. Yes, tonight 'Probe Around' takes a look at Crime. Is it true that the police are using dachshunds to combat the crime wave? And can the head of the Vice Squad turn himself into an albatross whenever he wants to? Just what are the police up to?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Oh, I'm up to page 39, where Peter Pan first manifests himself.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: With me now is Inspector Harry H 'Snapper' Organs of 'H' Division.

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, Inspector, I believe you are encouraging magic in the Police Force?

dialogue.speaker: Organs
dialogue.text: That is correct. The criminal mind is a strange and contorted one. Good evening. The mind is subject to severe mental stresses. Good evening. Guilt fears abound, good evening. In the subconscious in this state, one of our lads, with a fair training in the black arts can scare the fertilizer out of them.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Just how are the police combating the increase with the use of the occult? Ex-King Zog of Albania reports ... Well we seem to have lost ex-King Zog there, but who cares. Just what kinds of magic are the police introducing into their crime prevention techniques?

dialogue.speaker: Policemen
dialogue.text: U-P Y-O-U-R-S.

dialogue.speaker: Second Policeman
dialogue.text: Up yours? What a rude Ouija board!

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Now this is the kind of thing that gives the police a bad name, sergeant.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: I know, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Yes, Beryl?

dialogue.speaker: Beryl
dialogue.text: Attila the Hun to see you, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Who?

dialogue.speaker: Beryl
dialogue.text: Attila the Hun, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Oh botherkins! Er, constable, go and see to him will you?

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: What! In this dress?

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Oh all right, I'll go.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Oh, I have got a little green pinny I could wear...

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: No, no, no, I'll go. You stay here.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Oh goody! I can get on with the ironing.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Right where is he?

dialogue.speaker: Beryl
dialogue.text: Over there, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Right, er, all right sergeant leave this to me. Er, now then sir, you are Attila the Hun.

dialogue.speaker: Attila the Hun
dialogue.text: That's right, yes. A. T. Hun. My parents were Mr and Mrs Norman Hun, but they had a little joke when I was born.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Yes well, Mr Hun ...

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Oh! Call me 'The', for heaven's sake!

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Oh well, The... what do you want to see us about?

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: I've come to give myself up.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: What for?

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Looting, pillaging and sacking a major city.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Looting, pillaging, sacking a major city, and I'd like nine thousand other charges to be taken into consideration, please.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: I say, excuse me, Mr Hun. Have you any objection to taking a breath test?

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Oh, no. No, no, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Right, er, sergeant will you bring the Hunalyser, please?

dialogue.speaker: Beryl
dialogue.text: Here we are, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Er, how's it work?

dialogue.speaker: Beryl
dialogue.text: Well he breathes into it, sir, and the white crystals turn lime green. Then he is Attila the Hun, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: I see. Right. Would you mind breathing into this Mr Hun?

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: What if nothing happens, sergeant?

dialogue.speaker: Beryl
dialogue.text: He's Alexander the Great!

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Ha, ha! Caught you, Mr A. T. Great!

dialogue.speaker: Attila
dialogue.text: Oh curses! Curses! I thought I was safe, disguised as Attila the Hun.

dialogue.speaker: Chief Constable
dialogue.text: Oh perhaps so, but you made one fatal mistake... you see, this wasn't a Hunalyser... it was an Alexander the Greatalyser Take him away, Beryl!

dialogue.speaker: First Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, I object very strongly to that last scene, and to the next letter.

dialogue.speaker: Second Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, I object to being objected to by the last letter, before my drift has become apparent. I spent many years in India during the last war and am now a part-time notice board in a prominent public school. Yours etc., Brigadier Zoe La Rue (deceased). PS Aghhh!

dialogue.speaker: Third Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, When I was at school, I was beaten regularly every thirty minutes, and it never did me any harm - except for psychological maladjusunent and blurred vision. Yours truly, Flight Lieutenant Ken Frankenstein (Mrs).

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: Dr Larch ... there's a Mr Phelps to see you.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Er, nurse!

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Er, you don't think you should make it clear that I'm a psychiatrist?

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Well, I could be any type of doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: Well I can't come in and say 'Psychiatrist Larch' or 'Dr Larch who is a psychiatrist'. Oh, anyway look, it's written on the door.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: That's outside.

dialogue.speaker: Receptionist
dialogue.text: Well, I don't care, you'll just have to do it yourself.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Hello. Er, no, wrong number I'm afraid, this is a psychiatrist speaking. Next please. Er, come in.

dialogue.speaker: Phelps
dialogue.text: Bow, wow, wow.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Ah Mr Phelps. Come on in, take a seat. Now what seems to be the matter?

dialogue.speaker: Phelps
dialogue.text: No, no, no. No. No.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: I'm sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Phelps
dialogue.text: Oh can't you do better than that? I mean it's so predictable I've seen it a million times. Knock, knock, knock come in, ah Mr Phelps take a seat. I've seen it and seen it.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Well look will you please sit down and do your first line.

dialogue.speaker: Phelps
dialogue.text: No. No. I've had enough. I've had enough.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: I can't even get it started.

dialogue.speaker: Phelps
dialogue.text: Albatross!

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Shut up! Oh it drives me mad.

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: A mad psychiatrist, that'd be new.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Next please.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Cross the threshold, arrive, ingress, gain admittance, infiltrate. Ah Mr Notlob, ah park your hips, on the sitting device.

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: It is a mad psychiatrist.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: I'm not. I'm not. Come on in. Take a seat. What's, what's the matter?

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Now what's the matter?

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: Well I keep hearing guitars playing and people singing when there's no one around.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Yes, well this is not at all uncommon. In certain mental states we find that auditory hallucinations occur which are of a most ... Is that 'We're all going to the zoo tomorrow'?

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: Yes. Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Is it always that?

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Well that's something.

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: But it's mainly folk songs.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Oh my God.

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: Last night I had 'I'll never fall in love again' for six hours.

dialogue.speaker: Psychiatrist
dialogue.text: Well look, I think I'd better have a second opinion on this. I want you to see a colleague of mine, a specialist in these sort of things, who has an office very much like this one as a matter of fact.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: Brr brr No, no wrong number I'm a colleague of his, a surgeon, who specializes in these kind of things. Yes thank you very much. Next please. Come in. Ah come in, please take a seat. My colleague who has a similar office has explained your case to me Mr Notlob, as you know I am a leading Harley Street surgeon as seen on television. I'm afraid I'm going to have to operate. It's nothing to worry about although it is extremely dangerous. I shall be juggling with your life, I shall be playing ducks and drakes with your very existence, I shall be running me mitts over the pith of your marrow. Yes! These hands, these fingers, these sophisticated organs of touch, these bunches of five, these maulers, these German bands that have pulled many a moribund unfortunate back from the very brink of Lazarus's box. No, it was Pandora's box wasn't it? Well anyway these mitts have earned yours truly a lot of bread. So if you'll just step through here I'll slit you up a treat.

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: Mr Notlob, there's nothing wrong with you that an expensive operation can't prolong.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: Right, I'm ready to make the incision. Knife please, sister What's that supposed to be. Give me a big one.. . . . oh I do enjoy this. Right. Oh what a great slit. Now, gentlemen, I am going to open the slit.

dialogue.speaker: Squatter
dialogue.text: Too much man, groovy, great scene. Great light show, baby.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: What are you doing in there?

dialogue.speaker: Squatter
dialogue.text: We're doing our own thing, man.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: Have you got Mr Nottob's permission to be in there?

dialogue.speaker: Squatter
dialogue.text: We're squatters, baby.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: What? Nurse, wake him up.

dialogue.speaker: Squatter
dialogue.text: Don't get uptight, man. Join the scene and other phrases. Money isn't real.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: It is where I'm standing and it blows my mind, young lad. Good Lord! Is that a nude woman?

dialogue.speaker: Squatter
dialogue.text: She's doing an article on us for 'Nova', man.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Hi everyone. Are you part of the scene?

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: Are you rolling your own jelly babies in there?

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: What's going on? Who are they?

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: That's what we are trying to find out.

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: What are they doing in my stomach?

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: We don't know. Are they paying you any rent?

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: Of course they're not paying me rent!

dialogue.speaker: Squatter
dialogue.text: You're not furnished, you fascist.

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: Get them out!

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: I can't.

dialogue.speaker: Notlob
dialogue.text: Get them out.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: No I can't. Not, not without a court order.

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: Shut up. You're keeping us awake.

dialogue.speaker: First Policeman
dialogue.text: You are hereby ordered to vacate Mr Notlob forthwith. And or.

dialogue.speaker: Squatter
dialogue.text: Push off, fuzz.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Right, that's it, we're going in. Release the vicious dogs.

dialogue.speaker: Animated Character
dialogue.text: What a terrible way to end a series. Why couldn't it end with something like this? Now there's an ending for you. Romance. Laughter.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: When this series returns it will be put out on Monday mornings as a test card and will be described by 'Radio Times' as a history of Irish agriculture.

annotations: Four undertakers carrying a coffin. The lid opens and the 'It's' man looks out.
Cut to large animated sign saying: 'Intermission'.
After this seven seconds of slightly speeded up Mantovani. Two animated cars race in and crash.
Cut to animated opening credits.
Cut to the same sign saying: 'Intermission'
(Same music, same speed, slightly longer.)
Short animation, then cut to restaurant vestibule. He and she are already there, entering. She is nattering. The waiter is waiting.
(the waiter grimaces)
He exits. Shot off-screen and scream.
The head waiter comes in.
(long pause)
(small tic developing, getting carried away)
(reaction)
(they both look at her; pause)
(thinking)
Enter headmaster.
(exits)
Enter prologue, long white Greek robes, long white beard, holding a large staff.
(he exits)
A waiter enters pushing a large serving dish with a semi-naked Hopkins sitting unconcernedly in it.
(makes to shake hands)
(skittishly)
(examining him)
(lowering voice)
(cut to vicar sitting thin and unhappy in a pot)
Cut to animated sign saying 'Intermission '.
Intermission changes to adverts. Animated title: 'Pearls For Swine Presents'. Shots of various cars with young ladies posing on them.
(a card saying 'Soho Motors 2nd floor' an a board with advertisement cards for 'Rita' etc.; cut to a restaurant)
(as Vercotti poses for the camera policemen bundle his staff and several half-dressed girls through and out of the restaurant)
(the police remove a chef carrying a 8mm projector and film)
(the police remove Mr Vercotti)
'Pearls for Swine' closing title.
Cut to corner of cinema. A man in an ice-cream girl's uniform is standing in a spotlight with an ice-cream tray with an albatross on it.
A cutomer approaches him.
The camera zooms past back onto the screen. On screen appears another 'Intermission' sign.
The intermission sign explodes.
And CAPTION:
Cut to the Queen on horseback; first few bars of National Anthem.
Cut to Person sitting in cinema seat clutching albatross.
Cut to a policeman standing in a street man comes up to him.
Women's Institute applauding.
Cut to a man on a bench in casualty ward set.
Doctor and sister enter and go up to him.
Nurse enters.
(to sister)
(to man)
(to nurse)
(knight walks in quickly and hits him over the head with a chicken)
Women's Institute applaud.
Cut to film of Gumbys (vox pop)
Cut to historical impersonation sketch. Big zoom in to linkman. Glittery linkman set, showbizzy music and applause.
Fade applause and music.
Cut to Cardinal Richelieu, he mimes to the phrase from the record.
Vast applause.
Cut to Caesar; cloud effects behind.
(in Waring voice)
Cut back to Wiggin.

Florence Nightingale (Graham) stands there with a lamp, simpering femininely. A boxing bell goes, slight pause, then she is hit on the side of the cheek with a boxing glove, and fallls straight on her back.
Cut back to Wiggin.

In a shoe department. Three people are sitting in chain, only the middle one is a dummy. Ivan the Terrible comes in and splits the man in the middle in half with an immense two-handed sword: the model splits in two.

Cut to a sky backgrouned Napoleon comes into frame horizontally, moving along a wire very slowly. In each hand he has a small propeller. A sign hangs below his belly saying R101. Marseillaise plays. As he passes out of shot there is an explosion.
Cut to Gumby.
A head on a platter is pulled by a string across the floor. We hear brm, brm, brm, noises. The head of John the Baptist has a Graham Hill moustache, obviously stuck on.
Women's Institute applaud.
Marcel Marceau (Graham) walks against the wind.
Cut to him starting the mime. He doesn't get very far as a sixteen-ton weight is dropped on his head.
Cut to Wembley crowd cheering.
(gently)
Brief stock shot of theatre audience applauding.
Applause stock shot. Cut to interviewer and two city gents (on their knees).
Applause stock shot.
(to other city gent)
Fairy godmother trips lightly into shot.

Cut to open country. A policeman cycles up and parks his bike. From the saddlebag he takes a burglar's outfit - striped jersey, cap, and trousers. He lays them out on the ground, and inflates them with a bicycle pump. The inflated burglar runs away in speeded-up motion. The policeman blows his whistle. Three more policemen appear out of nowhere. He points forward and the four of them move off in a pixilated motion after the burglar. The burglar runs across moorland; the policemen follow him. Dick Barton theme music. The burglar lures the policemen into a large packing crate, slams the door on them and nails on it a label: 'Do not open until Christmas'. In the background a policeman with a fairy tutu appears suddenly out of thin air. He waves his wand at the burglar, who disappears. Cut to policeman, with wand, standing in a street.
'Panorama' music and still photos of policemen in tutus.
Cut to interviewer at desk of 'Panorama' type set-up.
A shot rings out and he slumps backward. A second interviewer runs into shot from behind camera with smoking gun.
(he pushes the first interviewer off his chair with his foot and takes his place)
Cut to close-up of a constable reading big book. He is very, very, very stupid.
Cut back to interviewer.
Cut to another part of the 'Panorama' set. Detective Inspector Organs is sitting next to a Viking.
Cut back to interviewer and hereafter cross cut between them.
(as he speaks we notice he is sticking pins into a model of a burglar)
(phone rings)
Cut to four chief constables huddled round an Ouija board. The have their fingers on a tumbler which moves slowly from one letter to the next.

Cut to more film: policeman with wand. By pointing the wand at illegally parked cars he makes them disappear. Another policeman on the pavement helping an old lady across road. He looks to see if the road is clear, waves his wand and she jumps across to other side. Another street: a police siren is heard then five policemen on broom sticks appear from round corner and disappear across frame.
Cut to police dancing round Stonehenge. A burglar is bound to a stone altar. Mix to picture of same thing in newspaper which is being read by a chief constable in his office.
Pull out further to reveal police sergeant in long shimmering slim-fitting ladies evening gown, diamante handbag and helmet.
Intercom buzzer goes on desk.
(depressing knob)
(male voce)
The chief constable walks through the door into the reception area of the police station. There is a policeman behind the counter and a little insignificant man is standing waiting.
(to policeman)
(he takes his hat off, removes his moustache, puts it in the hat and puts the hat back on)
The constable produces a breathalyser.
Hands it to the chief constable.
(blows into bag)
(who is now Alexander the Great)
Cut to letter (as used for 'Xmas night with the stars' after pet shop. I'm sorry...as not used in 'Xmas night with the stars').
Cut to second letter.
Cut to third letter.
Animation link runs into a psychiatrist's consulting room. The psychiatrist at his desk. The door opens and a receptionist looks in.
(whispering)
(still whispering)
(she leaves)
(goes 'brr brr', then picks up phone)
(knock at the door)
Phelps comes in dressed as Napoleon, with a parrot on his head, and a leash with nothing on it.
(he exits)
(off)
Cut to a man in limbo: Mr Notlob.
Cut back to the psychiatrist.
Knocking at door. Psychiatrist is about to call when he picks up a thesaurus and thumbs through it.
(Notlob enters in an ordinary suit)
(to camera)
Cut to Napoleon in limbo; he blows a raspberry.
(he steps suddenly and listens; the sound of 'We're all going to the zoo tomorrow' is heard)
(concerned)
Jump cut off same office now occupied by a surgeon. Start on portrait which has moustache and beard and glasses being added by surgeon.
(picks up phone)
(replaces phone)
(knock at door)
(Notlob enters; 'Going to the zoo' is faintly heard)
(cut to terribly quick shot of Napoleon, then back)
(he is rising from seat)
(he puts needle down on ancient gramophone; Dr Kildare theme begins playing)

Cut to operating theatre. The conversation and the guitar can still be heard. Notlob is on the table. His head is real but the rest of the body is false. Table is covered with green cloth for reality. Surgeon is swabbing. 'Going to the zoo' is still audible.
(takes knife)
(takes big knife and strops it on steel sharpener)
(he stabs the body and makes a slit four feet long)
He pulls it apart. The song gets louder. The head of a squatter pops out.
(to nurse about Notlob)
(she slaps his face)
(looks inside Notlob)
(her head also appearing through slit)
(waking up)
(also appearing)
Some policemen walk in.
(into slit)
(dives into slit)
(a short piece of confusing animation later)
Cut to film of 'It's' man being pursued by undertaker; roll credits over.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 12

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: I know you're down there.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Hey, did you see that?

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Uhm?

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Did you see somebody go past the window?

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Somebody just went past the window. That way.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Oh. Oh.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Another one.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Huh?

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Another one just went past downwards.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Two people have just fallen out of that window to their almost certain death.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Fine, fine. Fine.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Look! Two people three people have just fallen past that window.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Must be a board meeting.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Oh yeah. Hey. That was Wilkins of finance.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Oh, no, that was Robertson.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Wilkins.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Robertson.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Wilkins.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Robertson.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: That was Wilkins.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: That was Wilkins. He was a good, good, er, golfer, Wilkins.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Very good golfer. Very good golfer. Rotten at finance. It'll be Parkinson next.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Bet you it won't.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: How much.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: How much do you bet it won't? Fiver?

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Done.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: You're on.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Fine. Come on Parky.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Don't do it Parky.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Come on Parky. Jump Parky. Jump.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Come on now be sensible Parky.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, I am writing to complain about that sketch about people failing out of a high building. I have worked all my life in such a building and have never once.... arrgghhh

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Parkinson!

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Johnson!

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Good evening. Tonight 'Spectrum' looks at one of the major problems in the world today - that old vexed question of what is going on. Is there still time to confront it, let alone solve it, or is it too late? What are the figures, what are the facts, what do people mean when they talk about things? Alexander Hardacre of the Economic Affairs Bureau.

dialogue.speaker: Hardacre
dialogue.text: In this graph, this column represents 23% of the population. This column represents 28% of the population, and this column represents 43% of the population.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Telling figures indeed, but what do they mean to you, what do they mean to me, what do they mean to the average man in the street? With me now is Professor Tiddles of Leeds University...

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: ... Professor, you've spent many years researching into things, what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: I think it's too early to tell.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: 'Too early to tell' ... too early to say... it means the same thing. The word 'say' is the same as the word 'tell'. They're not spelt the same, but they mean the same. It's an identical situation, we have with 'ship' and 'boat' but not the same as we have with 'bow' and 'bough' , they're spelt differently, mean different things but sound the same. But the real question remains. What is the solution, if any, to this problem? What can we do? What am I saying? Why am I sitting in this chair? Why am I on this programme? And what am I going to say next? Here to answer this is a professional cricketer.

dialogue.speaker: Cricketer
dialogue.text: I can say nothing at this point.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Well, you were wrong... Professor?

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: Hello.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Hello. So... where do we stand? Where do we stand? Where do we sit? Where do we come? Where do we go? What do we do? What do we say? What do we eat? What do we drink? What do we think? What do we do?

dialogue.speaker: Signalman
dialogue.text: Sorry!

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Hello, Mr and Mrs Johnson?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Johnson
dialogue.text: That's right. Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Well come on in, excuse me not shaking hands, I've just been putting a bit of lard on the cat's boil.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Very nice.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Well you must be tired, it's a long way from Coventry, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Well, we usually reckon on five and a half hours and it took us six hours and fifty-three minutes, with the twenty-five minute stop at Frampton Cottrell to stretch our legs, only we had to wait half an hour to get onto the M5 at Droitwich.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Then there was a three mile queue just before Bridgewater on the A38. We usually come round on the B3339 just before Bridgewater, you see...

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Ye, but this time we decided to risk it because they're always saying they're going to widen it there.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Are they?

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Yes well just by the intersection, there where the A372 joins up, there's plenty of room to widen it there, there's only grass verges. They could get another six feet...knock down that hospital... Then we took the coast road through Williton and got all the Taunton traffic on the A358 from Crowcombe and Stogumber...

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Well you must be dying for a cup of tea.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Well, wouldn't say no, not if it's warm and wet.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Well come on in the lounge, I'm just going to serve afternoon tea.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Very nice.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Come on in, Mr and Mrs Johnson, oh this is Mr and Mrs Phillips.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Phillips
dialogue.text: Good afternoon.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: It's their third time here with us, we can't keep you away can we? Ha, ha, and over here is Mr Hilter.

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: Ach. Good time...good afternoon.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Ooh planning a little excursion are we Mr Hilter?

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: Ja, ja. We haff a little... Was ist rückweise bewegen?

dialogue.speaker: Von Ribbentrop
dialogue.text: Hike.

dialogue.speaker: Himmler
dialogue.text: Hiking.

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: Ah yes, ve make a little hike for, for Bideford.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Oh well, you'll want the A39 then...no, no, you've got the wrong map there, this is Stalingrad, you want the Ilfracombe and Barnstaple section.

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: Ah! Hein...Reginald you have the wrong map here you silly old leg-before-wicket English person.

dialogue.speaker: Himmler
dialogue.text: I'm sorry mein Fuhrer. I did not... Mein Dickie old chum.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Lucky Mr Johnson pointed that out, eh? You wouldn't have had much fun in Stalingrad, would you... I said, you wouldn't have had much fun in Stalingrad, would you, ha, ha, ha?

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: Not much fun in Stalingrad, no.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Oh I'm sorry I didn't introduce you. This is Ron...Ron Vibbentrop.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Oh, not Von Ribbentrop, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Von Ribbentrop
dialogue.text: Nein! Nein! Nein! Oh!! Ha, ha, ha.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: And this is the quiet one, Mr Bimmler - Heimlich Bimmler.

dialogue.speaker: Himmler
dialogue.text: How do you do there squire, also I am not Minehead lad but I in Peterborough, Lincolnshire was given birth to, but stay in Peterborough Lincolnshire house all during war, owing to nasty running sores, and was unable to go in the streets play football or go to Nürnberg. I am retired vindow cleaner and pacifist, without doing war crimes tch tch tch, and am glad England win World Cup - Bobby Charlton, Martin Peters - and eating lots of chips and fish and hole in the toads, and Dundee cakes on Piccadilly line. Don't you know old chap I was head of Gestapo for ten years. Five years! No, no, nein, I was not head of Gestapo at all...I make joke.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Oooh, Mr Bimmler, you do have us on. Oh excuse me I must go and answer that.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: How long are you down here for, Mr Hilter. Just the fortnight?

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: Why do you ask that? Are you a spy or something? Get over there against the wall Britischer pig, you're going to die!

dialogue.speaker: Himmler
dialogue.text: Take it easy Dickie old chum.

dialogue.speaker: Von Ribbentrop
dialogue.text: I'm sorry Mr. Johnson, he's a bit on edge. He hasn't slept since 1945.

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: Shut your cake hole you Nazi.

dialogue.speaker: Von Ribbentrop
dialogue.text: Cool it Führer cat!

dialogue.speaker: Himmler
dialogue.text: Ha, ha, ha. The fun we have.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Haven't I seen him on the television?

dialogue.speaker: Von Ribbentrop and Himmler
dialogue.text: Nicht. Nein. Nein, oh no.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Television Doctor?

dialogue.speaker: Von Ribbentrop
dialogue.text: No!!! No!

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Telephone, Mr Hilter, it's that nice Mr McGoering from the Bell and Compasses. He says he's found a place where you can hire bombers by the hour.

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: If he opens his big mouth again...it's lampshade time!

dialogue.speaker: Von Ribbentrop
dialogue.text: Shut up! Hire bombers by the hour, ha ha, what a laugh he is, that Scottish person. Good old Norman.

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: He's on the phone the whole time nowadays.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: In business is he?

dialogue.speaker: Himmler
dialogue.text: Soon baby!

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Of course it's his big day Thursday. Oh, they've been planning it for months.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: What's happens then?

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Well it's the North Minehead bye-election. Mr Hilter's standing as the National Bocialist candidate. He's got wonderful plans for Minehead.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Like what?

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Well, for a start he wants to annex Poland.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Oh, North Minehead's Conservative, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Well, they get a lot of people at their rallies.

dialogue.speaker: Johnson
dialogue.text: Rallies?

dialogue.speaker: Landlady
dialogue.text: Well, their Bocalist meetings, down at the Axis Café in Rosedale Road.

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: I am not a racialist, but, und this is a big but, we in the National Bocialist Party believe das Überleben muss gestammen sein mit der schneaky Armstrong-Jones. Historische Taunton ist Volkermeinig von Meinhead.

dialogue.speaker: Himmler
dialogue.text: Mr Hitler, , he says that historically Taunton is a part of Minehead already.

dialogue.speaker: Von Ribbentrop
dialogue.text: He's right, do you know that?

dialogue.speaker: Hitler
dialogue.text: Und Bridgwater ist die letzte Fühlung das wir haben in Somerset!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: What do you think of Mr Hilter's politics.

dialogue.speaker: Yokel
dialogue.text: I don't like the sound of these 'ere boncentration bamps.

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Well, I gave him my baby to kiss and he bit it on the head.

dialogue.speaker: Stockbroker
dialogue.text: Well, I think he'd do a lot of good to the Stock Exchange.

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: No...no...

dialogue.speaker: Himmler
dialogue.text: Oh yes Britischer pals he is wunderbar...ful. So.

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: I think he's right about the coons, but then I'm a bit mental.

dialogue.speaker: Gumby
dialogue.text: I think he's got beautiful legs!

dialogue.speaker: Madd
dialogue.text: Well speaking as Conservative candidate I just drone on and on and on...never letting anyone else get a word in edgeways, until I start foaming at the mouth and fall over backwards.

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: Foam at the mouth and fall over backwards. Is he foaming at the mouth to fall over backwards or falling over backwards to foam at the mouth. Tonight 'Spectrum' examines the whole question of frothing and falling, coughing and calling, screaming and bawling, walling and stalling, galling and mauling, palling and hauling, trawling and squalling and zalling. Zalling? Is there a word zalling? If there is what does it mean...if there isn't what does it mean? Perhaps both. Maybe neither. What do I mean by the word mean? What do I mean by the word word, what do I mean by what do I mean, what do I mean by do, and what do I do by mean? What do I do by do by do and what do I do by wasting your time like this? Goodnight.

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: Goodnight.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Good evening, I wish to report a burglary.

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: Speak up please, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I wish to report a burglary.

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: I can't hear you, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I wish to report a burglary!

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: That's a little bit too loud. Can you say it just a little less loud than that?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I wish to report a burglary.

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: No... I'm still not getting anything... Er, could you try it in a higher register?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What do you mean in a higher register?

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I wish to report a burglary.

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: Ahl That's it, hang on a moment. Now a little bit louder.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I wish to report a burglary.

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: Report a what?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Burglary!

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: That's the exact frequency... now keep it there.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sergeant
dialogue.text: Hello, sarge!

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: Evening Charlie.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I was sitting at home with a friend of mine from Camber Sands, when we heard a noise in the bedroom. We went to investigate and found £5,000 stolen.

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: Well, I'm afraid I'm going off duty now sir. Er, could you tell First Sergeant Foster?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I was sitting at home with a friend of mine.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sergeant
dialogue.text: Excuse me sir, but, er, why the funny voice?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, terribly sorry. I'd just got used to talking like that to the other sergeant.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sergeant
dialogue.text: I'm terribly sorry... I can't hear you, sir, could you try speaking in a lower register?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What! Oh I wish to report the loss of £5,000.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sergeant
dialogue.text: £5,000? That's serious, you'd better speak to the detective inspector.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: What's the trouble, sergeant?

dialogue.speaker: Second Sergeant
dialogue.text: Well- this- gentleman- sir- has- just- come- in- to- report- that- he- was- sitting- at- home- with- a- friend- when- he- heard- a- noise- in- the- backroom- went- round- to- investigate- and- found- that-£5,000- in- savings- had- been- stolen.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: I see. Where do you live sir?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: 121, Halliwell Road, Dulwich, SE21

dialogue.speaker: Second Sergeant
dialogue.text: 121- Halliwell- Road- Dulwich- SE21

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Another Halliwell Road job eh, sergeant?

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: Yes- I- can't- believe- it- I- thought- the- bloke- who'd- done- that- was- put- inside- last- year.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sergeant
dialogue.text: Yes, in Parkhurst.

dialogue.speaker: First Sergeant
dialogue.text: Well it must have been somebody else.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Thank you, sergeant. We'll get things moving right away, sir. You take over here, sergeant Alert all squad cars in the area. Ha-allo Dar-ling, I'm afra-ID I sh-A-ll BE L-ate H-O-me this evening.

dialogue.speaker: Second Sergeant
dialogue.text: Calling all squad cars in the area...

dialogue.speaker: Lovely Girl
dialogue.text: I think that's in very bad taste.

dialogue.speaker: Upperclass Twit
dialogue.text: Some people do talk in the most extraordinary way.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Good afternoon and welcome to Hurlingham Park. You join us just as the competitors are running out onto the field on this lovely winter's afternoon here, with the going firm underfoot and very little sign of rain. Well it certainly looks as though we're in for a splendid afternoon's sport in this the 127th Upperclass Twit of the Year Show. Well the competitors will be off in a moment so let me just identify for you. Vivian Smith-Smythe-Smith has an O-level in chemo-hygiene. Simon-Zinc-Trumpet-Harris, married to a very attractive table lamp. Nigel Incubator-Jones, his best friend is a tree, and in his spare time he's a stockbroker. Gervaise Brook-Hampster is in the Guards, and his father uses him as a wastepaper basket. And finally Oliver St John-Mollusc, Harrow and the Guards, thought by many to be this year's outstanding twit. Now they're moving up to the starting line, there's a jolly good crowd here today. Now they're under starter's orders ... and they're off! Ah no, they're not. No they didn't realize they were supposed to start. Never mind, we'll soon sort that out, the judge is explaining it to them now. I think Nigel and Gervaise have got the idea. All set to go. Oh, and they're off and it's a fast start this year. Oliver St John-Mollusc running a bit wide there and now they're coming into their first test, the straight line. They've got to walk along this straight line without failing over and Oliver's over at the back there, er, Simon's coming through quite fast on the outside, I think Simon and Nigel, both of them coming through very fast. There's Nigel there. No. Three, I'm sorry, and on the outside there's Gervaise coming through just out of shot and now, the position... Simon and Vivian at the front coming to the matchbox jump.. three layers of matchboxes to clear... and Simon's over and Vivian's over beautifully, oh and the jump of a lifetime - if only his father could understand. Here's Nigel ... and now Gervaise is over he's, er, Nigel is over, and it's Gervaise, Gervaise is going to jump it, is it, no he's jumped the wrong way, there he goes, Nigel's over, beautifully. Now it's only Oliver. Oliver ... and Gervaise... oh bad luck. And now it's Kicking the Beggar. Simon's there and he's putting the boot in, and not terribly hard, but he's going down and Simon can move on. Now Vivian's there. Vivian is there and waiting for a chance. Here he comes, oh a piledriver, a real piledriver, and now Simon's on No. l, Vivian 2, Nigel 3, Gervaise on 4 and Oliver bringing up the rear. Ah there's Oliver , there's Oliver now, he's at the back. I think he's having a little trouble with his old brain injury, he's going to have a go, no, no, bad luck, he's up, he doesn't know when he's beaten, this boy, he doesn't know when he's winning either. He doesn't have any sort of sensory apparatus. Oh there's Gervaise and he's putting the boot in there and he's got the beggar down and the steward's giving him a little bit of advice, yes, he can move on now, he can move on to the Hunt Photograph. He's off, Gervaise is there and Oliver's still at the back having trouble with the matchboxes. Now here's the Hunt Ball Photograph and the first here's Simon, he's going to enjoy a joke with Lady Arabella Plunkett. She hopes to go into films, and Vivian's through there and, er, Nigel's there enjoying a joke with Lady Sarah Pencil Farthing Vivian Streamroller Adams Pie Biscuit Aftershave Gore Stringbottom Smith. And there's, there's Simon now in the sports car, he's reversed into the old woman, he's caught her absolutely beautifully. Now he's going to accelerate forward there to wake up the neighbour. There's Vivian I think, no Vivian's lost his keys, no there's Vivian, he's got the old woman, slowly but surely right in the midriff, and here he is. Here he is to wake up the neighbour now. Simon right in the lead, comfortably in the lead, but he can't get this neighbour woken up. He's slamming away there as best he can. He's getting absolutely no reaction at all. There, he's woken him up and Simon's through. Here comes Vivian, Vivian to slam the door, and there we are back at the Hunt Ball, I think that's Gervaise there, that's Gervaise going through there, and here, here comes Oliver, brave Oliver. Is he going to make it to the table, no I don't think he is, yes he is, he did it, ohh. And the crowd are rising to him there,and there I can see, who is that there, yes that's Nigel, Nigel has woken the neighbour - my God this is exciting. Nigel's got very excited and he's going through and here comes Gervaise. Gervaise, oh no this is, er, out in the front there is Simon who is supposed to insult the waiter and he's forgotten. And Oliver has run himself over, what a great twit! And now here comes Vivian, Vivian to insult the waiter, and he is heaping abuse on him, and he is humiliating him, there and he's gone into the lead. Simon's not with him, no Vivian's in front of him at the bar. Simon's got to get under this bar and this is extremely difficult as it requires absolutely expert co-ordination between mind and body. No Vivian isn't there. Here we go again and Simon's fallen backwards. Here's Nigel, he's tripped, Nigel has tripped, and he's under and Simon fails again, er, here is Gervaise, and Simon is through by accident. Here's Gervaise to be the last one over, there we are, here's Nigel right at the head of the field, and now he's going to shoot the rabbit, and these rabbits have been tied to the ground, and they're going to be a bit frisky, and this is only a one-day event. And they're blazing away there. They're not getting quite the results that they might, Gervaise is in there trying to bash it to death with the butt of his rifle, and I think Nigel's in there with his bare hands, but they're not getting the results that they might, but it is a little bit misty today and they must be shooting from a range of at least one foot. But they've had a couple of hits there I think, yes, they've had a couple of hits, and the whole field is up again and here they are. They're coming up to the debs, Gervaise first, Vivian second, Simon third. And now they've got to take the bras off from the front, this is really difficult, this is really the most, the most difficult part of the entire competition, and they're having a bit of trouble in there I think, they're really trying now and the crowd is getting excited, and I think some of the twits are getting rather excited too. Vivian is there, Vivian is coming through, Simon's in second place, and, no there's Oliver, he's not necessarily out of it. There goes Nigel, no he's lost something, and Gervaise running through to this final obstacle. Now all they have to do here to win the title is to shoot themselves. Simon has a shot. Bad luck, he misses. Nigel misses. Now there's Gervaise, and Gervaise has shot himself - Gervaise is Upperclass Twit of the Year. There's Nigel, he's shot Simon by mistake, Simon is back up and there's Nigel, Nigel's shot himself: Nigel is third in this fine and most exciting Upperclass Twit of the Year Show I've ever seen. Nigel's clubbed himself into fourth place. And so the final result: The Upperclass Twit of the Year - Gervaise Brook-Hampster of Kensington and Weybridge; runner up - Vivian Smith-Smythe-Smith of Kensington; and third - Nigel Incubator-Jones of Henley. Well there'll certainly be some car door slamming in the streets of Kensington tonight.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, how splendid it is to see the flower of British manhood wiping itself out with such pluck and tenacity. Britain need have no fear with leaders of this calibre. If only a few of the so-called working class would destroy themselves so sportingly. Yours etc., Brigadier Mainwaring Smith Smith Smith etc. Deceased etc. PS etc. Come on other ranks, show your stuff.

dialogue.speaker: Soldier
dialogue.text: Yes Sir, I'll do my best, sir!

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: No, not good enough.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: No, still not good enough.

dialogue.speaker: First Voice
dialogue.text: Yes, that's better.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Now I understand that you want to marry my daughter?

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: That's right ... yeah... yeah...

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Yes, you realize of course that Rosamund is still rather young?

dialogue.speaker: Rosamund
dialogue.text: (Connie Booth) Daddy you make me feel like a child.

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: Oh yeah ... you know... get 'em when they're young eh... eh! OOOOH! Know what I mean eh, oooh!

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Well I'm sure you know what I mean, Mr ... er... Mr... er .. er?

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: Shabby... Ken Shabby...

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Mr Shabby... I just want to make sure that you'll be able to look after daughter...

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, yeah. I'll be able to look after 'er all right sport, eh, know what I mean, eh emggh!

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: And, er, what job do you do?

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: I clean out public lavatories.

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Is there promotion involved?

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, yeah. After five years they give me a brush... eurggha eurgh ... I'm sorry squire, I've gobbed on your carpet...

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: And, ah, where are you going to live?

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: Well round at my gran's... she trains polecats, but most of them have suffocated so there should be a bit of spare room in the attic, eh. Know what I mean. Oooh!

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: And when do you expect to get married?

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: Oh, right away sport. Right away... you know... I haven't had it for weeks...

dialogue.speaker: Father
dialogue.text: Well look I'll phone the bishop and see if we can get the Abbey...

dialogue.speaker: Shabby
dialogue.text: Oh, diarrhoea.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The story so far: Rosamund's father has become ensnared by Mr Shabby's extraordinary personal magnetism. Bob and Janet have eaten Mr Farquar's goldfish during an Oxfam lunch, and Mrs Elsmore's marriage is threatened by Doug's insistence that he is on a different level of consciousness. Louise's hernia has been confirmed, and Jim, Bob's brother, has run over the editor of the 'Lancet' on his way to see Jenny, a freelance Pagoda designer. On the other side of the continent Napoleon still broods over the smouldering remains of a city he had crossed half the earth to conquer...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: ... whilst Mary, Roger's half-sister, settles down to watch television...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: There now follows a Party Political Broadcast on behalf of the Wood Party.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Good evening. We in the Wood Party feel very strongly that the present weak drafting of the Local Government Bill leaves a lot to be desired, and we intend to fight.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Hello Helllllllllloooooooooo! Er I, I'm afraid the minister's fallen through the Earth's crust. Er... excuse me a moment. Helloooo.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Helloooooo.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Are you all right minister?

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: I appear to have landed on this kind of ledge thing.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Shall we lower down one of the BBC ropes?

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: If you'd be so kind.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What length of BBC rope will we be likely to need?

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: I should use the longest BBC rope. That would be a good idea I would imagine.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Okey doke chief. Er, Tex get the longest BBC rope, and bring it here pronto.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: In the meantime, since I am on all channels, perhaps I'd better carry on with this broadcast by shouting about our housing plans from down here as best I can. Could someone throw me down a script. The script would appear to have landed on a different ledge somewhat out of my grasp, don't you know.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Er, well perhaps when the rope reaches you minister you could kind of swing over to the ledge and grab it.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Good idea.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Well I'm going to carry on, if I can read the script.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Good evening. We in the Wood Party feel very strongly about the present weak drafting of the Local Government Bill and no, no - it's no good, it's not working.., I think I'll have to try and make a grab for it. Ah. There we are. Good evening. We in the Wood Party feel very strongly about the present agh, agh. Oh dear. Hello!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Hello.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Look, look, I must look a bit of a chump hanging upside down like this.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Don't worry minister. I think love if we turn the picture upside down we should help the minister, then.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Oh good. Look, er, I'm sorry about this, but there seem to be a few gremlins about... I think I'd better start from the beginning. Er, good evening, we in the Wood Party feel very strongly about, oh ... Bloody heck. Oh, oh dear, er terribly sorry about this, about saying bloody heck on all channels, but, er...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: There's another script on the way down minister.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Oh good, good. Well ... er... er... um... Good evening. Er ... well... er... how are you? Er... Oh yes look, I don't want you to think of the Wood Party as a load of old men that like hanging around on ropes only I ... er ... oh ... oh.

dialogue.speaker: Minister
dialogue.text: Ah. Thank you. Good evening, we in the Wood Party feel very strongly about the present weak drafting... Look. I think we'd better call it a day.

dialogue.speaker: First Robert
dialogue.text: Is this the furthest distance that a minister has fallen? Robert.

dialogue.speaker: Second Robert
dialogue.text: Well surprisingly not.
