The Canadian Minister for External Affairs fell nearly seven miles during a Liberal Conference in Ottawa about six years ago, and then quite recently the Kenyan Minister for Agric. and Fish fell nearly twelve miles during a Nairobi debate in Parliament, although this hasn't been ratified yet.

dialogue.speaker: First Robert
dialogue.text: Er, how far did the Filipino cabinet fall last March?

dialogue.speaker: Second Robert
dialogue.text: Er, well they fell nearly thirty-nine miles but it's not really so remarkable as that was due to their combined weight, of course. Robert.

dialogue.speaker: First Robert
dialogue.text: Thank you, Robert. Well now what's your reaction to all this, Robert?

dialogue.speaker: Third Robert
dialogue.text: Well, well Robert the main thing is that it's terribly exciting. You see the minister is quite clearly lodged between rocks we know terribly little of. Terribly little. Of course the main thing is we're getting colour pictures of an extraordinarily high quality. The important thing is, the really exciting thing is the minister will be bringing back samples of the Earth's core which will give us a tremendous, really tremendous tremendous tremendous clue about the origins of the Earth and what God himself is made of. Oh, oh I needed that.

dialogue.speaker: First Robert
dialogue.text: Thank you Robert. Well that seems to be about all we have time for tonight. Unless anyone has anything else to say. Has anyone anything else to say?

dialogue.speaker: Presenter
dialogue.text: What do we mean by no, what do we mean by yes, what do we mean by no, no, no. Tonight Spectrum looks at the whole question of what is no.

annotations: 'It's' man
Opening animation.
(and CAPTION:)
Studio:
Interior of a signalbox. A signalman (Terry J) stands by the signal levers. He is attacked by a bear. He wrestles it for 3.48 seconds.

Two people seated opposite each other at a desk. Between them there is a large window. It appears that they are quite high up in a large office building. Every so often a body falls past the window. They are both working busily.
After a pause a body drops past the window. First Man talks. Second Man hasn't noticed.
(indicates down)
(flatly)
Second Man returns to his work. First Man looks for a little. As he starts to work again another body goes hurtling past the window.
(another falls)
(another falls past)
(Another falls.)
(shakes; they look at the window)
Cut to letter.
(splat)
Cut to film of man falling out of window.
Cut back to set. First Man has hands in the air jubilantly.
(possibly incorporating falling) which leads us ingeniously into: A presenter at a desk. Urgent current-affairs-type music.
Cut to equally intense pundit in front of a graph with three different coloured columns with percentages at the top. He talks with great authority.
Cut back to presenter.
Pull out to reveal bearded professor sitting next to presenter.
Cut to presenter, he talks even faster now.
(holds up signs saying 'ship' and 'boat')
(holds up signs)
(he holds up signs saying 'so there')
Cut to cricketer.
Cut back to presenter.
Pull out to reveal professor still next to him.
Cut to close-up of presenter.
Mix to stock film of London-Brighton train journey in two minutes. After a few seconds the train goes into a tunnel. Blackness. Loud crash. Cut to signalbox as before.
(calling out of window)
He goes back to wrestling with bear.
Mr and Mrs Johnson, a typical holidaying bourgeois couple walk up to the front door and ring the bell. Inside the boarding house, the landlady goes up to the front door and opens it.
(following her into the lounge)
In the lounge are sitting another bourgeois couple Mr and Mrs Phillips.

Landlady leads Mr and Mrs Johnson over to a table at which Adolf Hitler is sitting poring over a map. He is in full Nazi uniform. Himmler and Von Ribbentrop are also sitting at the table with him, Himmler in Nazi uniform and von Ribbentrop in evening dress, with an Iron Cross.
(to others)
(leaning over map)
(Hitler slaps him)
(they don't see the joke)
(through clenched teeth)
(leaping two feet in the air, then realizing)
(hurriedly corrects himself)
(A telephone rings)
(leaves the room)
(shouting)
(drawing revolver)
Von Ribbentrop og Himmler grab Hitler and calm him.
(laughing it off)
The landlady enters.
(controlling Hitler and getting him towards the door)
(Hitler exits)
(he exits)

Cut to a grotty Italian café. Sign above it read 'Axis Café, Italian Food a Specialty'. A figure clearly belonging to Mussolini is nailing up a sign or poster which reads: 'Vote for Hitler'. He looks around and goes into the café furtively. At this moment past the café come Hitler, Von Ribbentrop and Himmler on bikes. Hitler at the front shouting German through a megaphone. Von Ribbentrop at the back with a large banner 'Hilter for a better Meinhead'. Himmler in the middle with an old grammophone playing 'Deutschland Über Alles'.
Cut to Hitler ranting in German on a balcony with Himmler at his side. Beneath them is a Nazi flag.
(stepping forward)
Shot of a yokel looking disbelievingly at balcony. Von Ribbentrop appears behind.
Meanwhile back on the balcony.
(very exited)
Over this we hear loud applause and 'Sieg Heils'. The yokel, who is not applauding, turns round rather surprised to see whence cometh the applause. He sees Von Ribbentrop operating a grammophone.
Cut to vox pops.
(voice over)
(thinly disguised as yokel)
(he foams at the mouth and falls over backwards)
Cut to 'Spectrum' studio: same presenter as before, sitting at desk.
Cut to police station.
(behind station counter into camera)
Camera pulls back to show a man standing in front of the counter.
(bellowing)
(a little louder than normal)
(in a high-pitched voice)
(gets out pencil and paper)
(louder and more high pitched)
(by now a ridiculously high-pitched squeak)
Another sergeant enters and goes round to back of counter.
(in high-pitched voice)
(in very deep voice)
The second sergeant is taking his coat off, and the first one begins to pack up his papers. The man carries on with his tale of woe, but still in a high-pitched shriek.
He leaves counter. Sergeant Foster comes forward with a helpful smile.
(continues in high-pitched shriek)
(normal voice)
(in a very deep voice)
At that moment, via the miracle of cueing, the detective inspector comes out of his office.
(in very slow deep voice)
(speaking at fantastic speed)
(deep voice)
(turns to man and addresses him in normal voice)
(normal voice)
The detective inspector has been straining to hear but has failed. The second sergeant comes in helpfully.
(fast)
(squeak)
(fast)
(squeak)
(deep)
(very deep)
(normal voice to man)
(he picks up phone and dials, at the same time he shrieks in high voice to the tint sergeant)
(very deep voice to the second sergeant)
(ridiculous sing-song voice into phone)
Meanwhile the second sergeant has a radio-controlled microphone and is singing down it in fine operatic tenor.
(singing)
Cut to vox pops.
(in deep male voice, dubbed on)
(meows)
(barks)
(superimposed sheep bleating)
Cut to Upperclass Twit of the Year sketch. The five competitors run onto the pitch.
(close-up of the competitors)
(the starter fires the gun; nobody moves)
(starter fires gun again; the twits move off erratically)
(the twits make their way erratically along five white lines)
(the twits approach a line of matchboxes piled three high)
(the twits are kicking a beggar with a vending tray)
(Oliver is still trying to jump the matchboxes)
(He is still kicking the beggar)
(the twits approach a table with two attractive girls and a photographer)
(shot of twit in a sports car reversing into cut-out of old woman)
(a man in bed in the middle of the pitch; twit slams car door repeatedly)
(Oliver falls over the table)
(Simon runs past a waiter standing with a tray)
(Oliver lying in front of car)
(the twits each have several goes at getting under a bar of wood five feet off the ground)
(the twits approach five rabbits staked out on the ground; they fire at them with shotguns)
(they approach a line of shopwindow dummies each wearing only a bra)
(the twits are wreaking havoc on the dummies)
(they approach a table with five revolvers laid out on it)
(three coffins on stand with medals)
Letter and voice over.
(coughs)
(off)
(coughs again, his leg falls off)
(coughs again, he completely disintegrates)
A hand picks up the animated bits and we see Terry J. stuffing them into a pipe. He puts the pipe down and various strange beasties climb out of it.

Pull out to reveal that he is addressing a ghastly thing. A grubby, smelly, brown mackintoshed shambles, unshaven with a continuous hacking cough, and an obscene leer. He sits on the sofa in this beautiful elegant lounge.
(sniffing and coughing)
(she gazes at Shabby fondly)
(lasciviously)
(makes obscene gesture involving elbow)
(produces handkerchief and cleans throat horribly into it)
(coughing fit)
Cut to strange PHOTO CAPTION SEQUENCE (to be worked out with Terry 'the sap' Gilliam) (if he can spare the time).
Mix from photo captions to studio.
A girl in bra and pants goes over to television and switches it on.
On the screen comes the start of a Party Political Broadcast.
Cut to a traditional grey-suited man at desk looking straight into camera.

He thumps on the desk and he falls through the floor. (Yes Mr Director you did read that right: he fell through the floor and added a fortune to the budget). As he falls he emits a long scream, fading away slowly. Another man comes and looks down into the pit.
(to camera)
(goes and looks at pit)
(unseen, a long way down)
(still a long way down)
(man drops the script down and Tex appears with enormous coil of rope)
Cut to minister swinging on rope.
He swings over to a ledge opposite with a script on it. As he gets near he peers and starts reading.
(he swings away and then back)
(swings away and back)
(he swings over and grabs the script with one hand; he turns to camera and continues)
(he makes a vigorous gesture and in so doing lets go of rope and slips so that he is now hanging upside down)
(out of vision)
(out of vision)
(cut to man looking off-camera)
Cut to minister. The picture is now the other way up. The minister now appears to be the right way up.
(he drops script)
(out of vision)
Meanwhile a man, the right way up, has been lowered down to the minister. As the picture is reversed, he appears to be moving straight up towards him. The minister sees him.
(taking script; the man on the rope starts to climb back up)
(man falls past with a scream)
Cut to two men at a desk in a discussion set.
Cut to Robert.
Cut to third Robert who is staring intently into camera. He is wearing a fright wig and has a left eyebrow four inches above his right one.
(as he gets more excited he starts to emit smoke)
(he bursts into fire and someone has to throw a buckets of water over him)
Cut back to first Robert.

Various 'noes' plus one 'bloody fairy' and more noes, from a very rapid montage of all the possible characters in this week's show saying 'no'. The last one we come to is the Spectrum presenter. He says more than no.
The sixteen-ton weight falls on him. Cut to 'It's' man running away.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 11

script.description: Have you finished in there yet?

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS'

dialogue.speaker: First Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, I object strongly to the obvious lavatorial turn this show has already taken. Why do we never hear about the good things in Britain, like Mary Bignall's wonderful jump in 1964? Yours etc., Ken Voyeur.

dialogue.speaker: Second Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, I object strongly to the obvious athletic turn this show has now taken. Why can't we hear more about the human body? There is nothing embarrassing or nasty about the human body except for the intestines and bits of the bottom.

dialogue.speaker: Third Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, I object strongly to the letters on your programme. They are clearly not written by the general public and are merely included for a cheap laugh. Yours sincerely etc., William Knickers.

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: 1348. The Black Death, typhus, cholera, consumption, bubonic plague.

dialogue.speaker: First Undertaker
dialogue.text: Ah, those were the days...

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: Now I'm... I'm... Now I'm not prepared to go on with this, unless these interruptions cease. All right? Right. The devastating effect of these, em...

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: No, don't follow me and ... And don't zoom in on me, no I'm off, I'm off. That's it. That's all. I'm off.

dialogue.speaker: Second Undertaker
dialogue.text: Are you nervy, irritable, depressed, tired of life. Keep it up.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector Tiger
dialogue.text: This house is surrounded. I'm afraid I must not ask anyone to leave the room. No, I must ask nobody ... no, I must ask everybody to... I must not ask anyone to leave the room. No one must be asked by me to leave the room. No, no one must ask the room to leave. I ... I ... ask the room shall by someone be left. Not. Ask nobody the room somebody leave shall I. Shall I leave the room? Everyone must leave the room... as it is... with them in it. Phew. Understand?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Pickering
dialogue.text: You don't want anybody to leave the room.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector Tiger
dialogue.text: Now, alduce me to introlow myslef. I'm sorry. Alself me to myduce introlow myslef. Introme -to-lose mlow alself. Alme to you introself mylowduce. Excuse me a moment. Allow me to introduce myself. I'm afraid I must ask that no one leave the room. Allow me to introduce myself. I'm Inspector Tiger.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Tiger?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector Tiger
dialogue.text: Where? Where? What? Ah. Me Tiger. You Jane. Grrr. Beg your pardon, allow me to introduce myself I'm afraid I must ask that no one leave the room.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Velloper
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector Tiger
dialogue.text: Elementary. Since the body was found in this room, and no one has left it. Therefore ... the murderer must be somebody in this room.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Pickering
dialogue.text: What body?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector Tiger
dialogue.text: Somebody. In this room. Must the murderer be. The murderer of the body is somebody in this room, which nobody must leave... leave the body in the room not to be left by anybody. Nobody leaves anybody or the body with somebody. Everybody who is anybody shall leave the body in the room body. Take the tablets Tiger. Anybody with a body but not the body is nobody. Nobody leaves the body in the ... Albody me introbody albodyduce.

dialogue.speaker: Surgeon
dialogue.text: Now for Sir Gerald.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: That's better, now I'm Inspector Tiger and I must ask that nobody leave the room. Now someone has committed a murder here, and that murderer is someone in this room. The question is ... who?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Pickering
dialogue.text: Look, there hasn't been a murder.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector Tiger
dialogue.text: No murder.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector Tiger
dialogue.text: Oh. I don't like it. It's too simple, too clear cut. I'd better wait. No, too simple, too clear cut.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel Pickering
dialogue.text: By jove, he was right.

dialogue.speaker: Lookout
dialogue.text: This house is surrounded. I must ask that no one leave the room. I'm Chief Superintendent Lookout.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Velloper
dialogue.text: Look out?

dialogue.speaker: Lookout
dialogue.text: What, where, oh, me, Lookout. Lookout of the Yard.

dialogue.speaker: Lady Velloper
dialogue.text: Why, what would we see?

dialogue.speaker: Lookout
dialogue.text: I'm sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Lady Velloper
dialogue.text: What would we see if we look out of the yard?

dialogue.speaker: Lookout
dialogue.text: . .. I'm afraid I don't follow that at all. Ah ha. The body. So the murderer must be somebody in this room. Unless he had very long arms. Say thirty or forty feet. I think we can discount that one. Ha, ha, ha, Lookout of the Yard. Very good. Right. Now, we'll reconstruct the crime. I'll sit down here. Constable, you turn off the lights. Good. Now then, there was a scream then just before the lights went up there was a shot.

dialogue.speaker: Theresamanbehindyer
dialogue.text: All right... all right, the house is surrounded and nobody leave the room and all the rest of it. Allow me to introduce myself. I'm Assistant Chief Constable Theresamanbehindyer.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Theresamanbehindyer?

dialogue.speaker: Theresamanbehindyer
dialogue.text: Ah, you're not going to catch me with an old one like that. Right let's reconstruct the crime. Constable you be Inspector Tiger.

dialogue.speaker: Constable
dialogue.text: Right, sir. Nobody leave the room ask shall - somebody I leave nobody in the room body shall, take the tablets Tigerbody. Alself me to my duce introlow left body in the roomself.

dialogue.speaker: Theresamanbehindyer
dialogue.text: Very good. Just sit down there. Right now we'll pretend the lights have gone out. Constable, you scream. Somebody shoots you and the door opens...

dialogue.speaker: Fire
dialogue.text: Nobody move! I'm Chief Constable Fire.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Fire! Where?

dialogue.speaker: Second Undertaker
dialogue.text: We're interrupting this sketch but we'll be bringing you back the moment anything interesting happens. Meanwhile here are some friends of mine.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, I'm sorry this letter is late, it should have come at the beginning of the programme. Yours, Ivor Bigbottie, (age two).

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: From the plastic arts we turn to football. Last night in the Stadium of Light, Jarrow, we witnessed the resuscitation of a great footballing tradition, when Jarrow United came of age, in a European sense, with an almost Proustian display of modern existentialist football. Virtually annihilating by midfield moral argument the now surely obsolescent catennachio defensive philosophy of Signor Alberto Fanffino. Bologna indeed were a side intellectually out argued by a Jarrow team thrusting and bursting with aggressive Kantian positivism and outstanding in this fine Jarrow team was my man of the match, the arch-thinker, free scheming, scarcely ever to be curbed, midfield cognoscento, Jimmy Buzzard.

dialogue.speaker: Buzzard
dialogue.text: Good evening Brian.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Jimmy, at least one ageing football commentator was gladdened last night by the sight of an English footballer breaking free of the limpid tentacles of packed Mediterranean defence.

dialogue.speaker: Buzzard
dialogue.text: Good evening Brian.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Were you surprised at the way the Italians ceded midfield dominance so early on in the game?

dialogue.speaker: Buzzard
dialogue.text: Well Brian... I'm opening a boutique.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: This is of course symptomatic of a new breed of footballer as it is indeed symptomatic of your whole genre of player, is it not?

dialogue.speaker: Buzzard
dialogue.text: Good evening Brian.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: What I'm getting at, Jimmy, is you seem to have discovered a new concept with a mode in which you dissected the Italian defence, last night.

dialogue.speaker: Buzzard
dialogue.text: I hit the ball first time and there it was in the back of the net.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Do you think Jarrow will adopt a more defensive posture for the first leg of the next tie in Turkey?

dialogue.speaker: Buzzard
dialogue.text: I hit the ball first time and there it was in the back of the net.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, yes - but have you any plans for dealing with the free-scoring Turkish forwards?

dialogue.speaker: Buzzard
dialogue.text: Well Brian... I'm opening a boutique.

dialogue.speaker: Second Undertaker
dialogue.text: And now let's take a look at the state of play in the detective sketch.

dialogue.speaker: Constable
dialogue.text: Alself me to introlow mybody...

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Hello, good evening, and welcome to yet another edition of 'Interesting People'. And my first interesting person tonight is the highly interesting Mr Howard Stools from Kendal in Westmorland.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Good evening Mr Stools.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Hello, David.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Mr Stools, what makes you particularly interesting?

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Well, I'm only half an inch long.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Well that's interesting, thank you for coming along on the show tonight Mr Stools.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Stools
dialogue.text: I thought you'd think that was interesting David, in fact...

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Mr Howard Stools from Kendal in Westmorland ... half an inch long. Our next guest tonight has come all the way from Egypt, he's just flown into London today, he's Mr Ali Bayan, he's with us in the studio tonight and he's stark raving mad.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Mr Ali Bayan, stark raving mad. Now it's time for our music spot and we turn the spotlight tonight on the Rachel Toovey Bicycle Choir, with their fantastic arrangement of 'Men of Harlech' for bicycle bells only.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: The Rachel Toovey Bicycle Choir. Really interesting. Remember, if you're interesting and want to appear on this programme, write your name and address and your telephone number and send it to this address: The BBC, c/o E. F. Lutt, 18 Rupee Buildings, West 12. Thank you, thank you. Now here's an interesting person. Apart from being a full-time stapling machine, he can also give a cat influenza.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Well, you can't get much more interesting than that, or can you? With me now is Mr Thomas Walters of West Hartlepool who is totally invisible. Good evening, Mr Walters.

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: Over here, Hughie.

dialogue.stage_direction: Compère turns to find a boringly dressed man sitting by him.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Mr Walters, are you sure you're invisible?

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: Oh yes, most certainly.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Well, Mr Walters, what's it like being invisible?

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: Well, for a start, at the office where I work I can be sitting at my desk all day and the others totally ignore me. At home, even though we are in the same room, my wife does not speak to me for hours, people pass me by in the street without a glance in my direction, and I can walk into a room without...

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Well, whilst we've got interesting people, we met Mr Oliver Cavendish who...

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: ... Even now you yourself, you do hardly notice me...

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Mr Oliver Cavendish of Leicester, who claims to be able to recite the entire Bible in one second, whilst being struck on the head with a large axe. Ha, ha, wow. We've since discovered that he was a fraud, yes a fraud, he did not in fact recite the entire Bible he merely recited the first two words, 'In the...' before his death.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Now it's time for 'Interesting Sport', and this week it's all-in cricket, live from the Municipal Baths, Croydon.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: With me now is Mr Ken Dove, twice voted the most interesting man in Dorking. Ken, I believe you're interested in shouting.

dialogue.speaker: Dove
dialogue.text: Yes, I'm interested in shouting all right, by jove you certainly hit the nail on the head with that particular observation of yours then.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: What does your wife think of this?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: I agree with him.

dialogue.speaker: Dove
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: ... At parties for instance people never come up to me, I just sit there and everybody totally...

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: That is Tiddles, I believe?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, this is, this is Tiddles.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Yes, and what does she do?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: She flies across the studio and lands in a bucket of water.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: By herself?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, I fling her.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Well that's extremely interesting, Ladies and gentlemen - Mr Don Savage and Tiddles.

dialogue.speaker: Dove
dialogue.text: I'm more interesting than a wet pussycat.

dialogue.speaker: Walters
dialogue.text: ... for hour after hour...

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Yes, great, well now for the first lime on television 'Interesting People' brings you a man who claims he can send bricks to sleep by hypnosis. Mr Keith Maniac from Guatemala.

dialogue.speaker: Maniac
dialogue.text: Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Keith, you claim you can send bricks to sleep.

dialogue.speaker: Maniac
dialogue.text: Yes, that is correct, I can...

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Entirely by hypnosis.

dialogue.speaker: Maniac
dialogue.text: Yes ... I use no artificial means, whatsoever.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Aaagh!

dialogue.speaker: Dove
dialogue.text: You've injured Mr Stools!

dialogue.speaker: Maniac
dialogue.text: I simply stare at the brick and it goes to sleep.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Well, we have a brick here, Keith. Perhaps you can send it to sleep for us...

dialogue.speaker: Maniac
dialogue.text: Oh ... Ah, well, I am afraid that is already asleep.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: How do you know?

dialogue.speaker: Maniac
dialogue.text: Well, it's not moving ....

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Oh, I see - have we got a moving brick? Yes, we've got a moving brick, Keith, it's coming over now.

dialogue.speaker: Maniac
dialogue.text: There we are, fast asleep.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Very good, very good indeed.

dialogue.speaker: Maniac
dialogue.text: All done with the eyes.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Yes, Mr Keith Maniac from Guatemala.

dialogue.speaker: Dove
dialogue.text: Mr Stools - speak to me, Howard.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Mr Keith Maniac of Guatemala... and now four tired undertakers.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: We interrupt this very quickly to take you back to the Jimmy Buzzard interview, where we understand something exciting's just happened.

dialogue.speaker: Buzzard
dialogue.text: I've fallen off my chair, Brian.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Good evening. Tonight I want to examine the whole question of eighteenth-century social legislation - its relevance to the hierarchical structure of post-Renaissance society, and its impact on the future of parochial organization in an expanding agrarian economy. But first a bit of fun.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: To put England's social legislation in a European context is Professor Gert Van Der Whoops of the Rijksmuseum in the Hague.

dialogue.speaker: Professor
dialogue.text: In Holland in the early part of the fifteenth century there was three things important to social legislation. One ... rise of merchant classes ... two, urbanization of craft guilds... three, declining moral values in age of increasing social betterment. But first, a bit of fun ...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: And now Professor R.J. Canning.

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: The cat sat on the mat. And now the Battle of Trafalgar... Tonight we examine popular views of this great battle. Was the Battle of Trafalgar fought in the Atlantic off southern Spain? Or was it fought on dry land near Cudworth in Yorkshire? Here is one man who thinks it was...

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: And here is his friend.

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: What makes you think the Battle of Trafalgar was fought near Cudworth?

dialogue.speaker: First Gumby
dialogue.text: Because ... Drake ... was ... too ... clever for... the German ... fleet.

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: First Gumby
dialogue.text: ... Oh I've forgotten what I said now.

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: Mr Gumby's remarkable views have sparked off a wave of controversy amongst his fellow historians.

dialogue.speaker: Second Gumby
dialogue.text: Well I rink ... we ... should ... reappraise ... our concept of the ... Battle of Trafalgar.

dialogue.speaker: Third Gumby
dialogue.text: Well... well... I agree with everything Mr Gumby says.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Gumby
dialogue.text: Well, I think cement is more interesting than people think.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: One subject... four different views ... twelve and six... in a plain wrapper.

dialogue.stage_direction: The stuff of history is indeed woven in the woof. Pearl Harbour. There are pages in history's book which are written on the grand scale. Events so momentous that they dwarf man and time alike. And such is the Battle of Pearl Harbour, re-enacted for us now by the women of Barley Townswomen's Guild.

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: Miss Rita Fairbanks - you organized this reconstruction of the Battle of Pearl Harbour - why?

dialogue.speaker: Rita
dialogue.text: Well we've always been extremely interested in modern drama ... we were of course the first Townswomen's Guild to perform 'Camp On Blood Island', and last year we did our extremely popular re-enactment of 'Nazi War Atrocities'. So this year we thought we would like to do something in a lighter vein...

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: So you chose the Battle of Pearl Harbour?

dialogue.speaker: Rita
dialogue.text: Yes, that's right, we did.

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: Well I can see you're all ready to go. So I'll just wish you good luck in your latest venture.

dialogue.speaker: Rita
dialogue.text: Thank you very much, young man.

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the World of History is proud to present the premiere of the Batley Townswomen's Guild's re-enactment of 'The Battle of Pearl Harbour'.

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: The Battle of Pearl Harbour. Incidentally, I'm sorry if I got a little bit shirty earlier on in the programme, when I kept getting interrupted by all these films and things that kept coming in, but I...

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: So I said if it happened again I'd get very angry and talk to Lord Hill and...

dialogue.speaker: Canning
dialogue.text: Tell Lord Hill.

annotations: Film: The Amazing World of The 'It's' Man
Animated titles.
(and CAPTION:)
Cut to bathroom door, outside. Man knocks on door.
From inside comes a burst of the Tchaikovsky piano concerto. He tuts. Cut to letter and voice over.
Stock film of Mary Bignall's winning jump at the Rome Olympics. Letter and voice over.
We see another letter and another voice over.
Stock film of the whole of an orchestra finishing an orchestral item. When they finish playing we hear the sound of flushing.
a beautiful and not zany introduction, perhaps with photos of famous historical characters, finishing with the words: 'The World of History '. Cut to man at desk.
Cut to five undertakers sitting on a coffin in a country road.
Back to Canning at his desk.
Cut to film of hearses racing. Crashing out of shot. Sign: 'Accident Black Spot', and the undertakers picnicking.
(he is packing up his papers and putting on his mac as he walks away from desk, camera pans with him)
(camera zooms in)
He walks out of shot. Empty frame. A short pause. An undertaker comes into frame.
(to camera)
(winks)

Cut to drawing room of large English country house. Sitting around are various standard Agatha Christie type characters, Colonel Pickering, Lady Amanda Velloper, Kirt, Anona Winn. They drink tea, read etc. Outside there is thunder. Inspector Tiger enters the room.
(clicking fingers to indicate Colonel Pickering has hit the nail on the head)
(bangs himself on the side of the head)
(jumping)
(as he searches for the tablets)
(he takes the tablet)
At this moment a surgeon enters with two nurses and starts to operate on his head with sawing noises.
The surgeon is packing up. Inspector Tiger's head is bandaged.
(he gives thumbs up to the surgeon who is at door)
(he sits on sofa)

The lights go out. There is a scream followed by a shot. The light goes up. Inspector Tiger is dead. He has a bullet hole in his forehead, an arrow through his neck and there is a bottle marked poison on his lap.
Chief Superintendent Lookout enters, with constable.
(jumping)
(he starts really laughing)
(lights go out, we hear Lookout's voice)
(scream)
There is a shot. The lights go up and Chief Superintendent Lookout is sitting dead, bullet hole, arrow and all. In walks Assistant Chief Constable Theresamanbehindyer.
(constable screams)
(pulls gun and shoots constable through head)
The door flies open. Enter policeman.
He jumps. Immediately cut to undertaker as before.
Film of four undertakers carrying a coffin. They surreptitiously tip the body out of the coffin and go skipping lightly up the road.
Letter and voice over.
Two chairs in interview set. Smart interviewer and footballer (who is not over bright) in blazer.
(pauses for thought)
(smiles and looks around)
(confidently)
Cut to undertaker.
Cut to drawing room. There is an enormous pile of dead policemen from the Agatha Christie Sketch on and around the sofa.
Inspector shoots him in the head.

Cut to four undertakers carrying a coffin up a hill. One of them falters and drops. The others lower the coffin to the ground, take out a fresh undertaker, put the fallen one in the coffin, and proceed.
Cut to animated sequence, leadning to big glittering flashing lights saying 'Interesting People'. A compère sits at desk, with guest chairs beside it.
He puts a matchbox on desk in front of him. He presses a button on the desk and we hear applause. Releases button; applause stops abruptly. He opens the box a little and speaks into it.
(from inside box)
(shuts matchbox; applause)
(applause)
Applause. Cut to Ali Bayan who looks at camera in a very mad way. Applause.
(applause)
Cut to six men in oilskins and sou'westers. They sing 'Men of Harlech ', and at the end of each line mournfully ring bells. Applause at end.
(reads caption)
(applause)
Cut to a smart dressed man who coughs into a cat basket. We hear a meow and a feline sneeze. Cut back to compère.
(turns to empty chair)
(off-screen)
(slowly and boringly)
(droning on)
Cut to film montage of sporting clips.
(voice over)
Boxing ring; two fully kitted out cricketers, who as the bell goes, approach each other and start hitting each other with cricket bats. Applause.
(shouting)
(voice off, full-blooded)
Man holding cat enters.
Man whirls the cat round and round. He lets go of the cat, it flies across studio. A hollow splash and a meow. Quick shot of a real cat sitting in a bucket.
(shouting)
(we see only his empty chair)
Maniac is sitting by compère. He wears a top hat and an opera cloak.
(leans and picks matchbox off desk to light pipe, opens it and strikes match)
(from matchbox)
(picks up other box and lights pipe)
(indicates brick on desk)
We see a man in a white coat preparing to throw brick. He throws it gently. It lands on the desk in front of Keith. Keith stares at it as it falls.
(distressed - to matchbox)
Quick cut back to all-in cricket.

Cut to film of four undertakers struggling up a hill carrying a coffin. One staggers and drops. The others lower the coffin, pick him up, and place him inside. Raising the coffin again they stagger off up the hill. Another undertaker collapses; the remaining two place him in the coffin. Exhaustedly they pick up the coffin, but have only gone two or three paces when one of them collapses. The remaining one drags him into the coffin, pushing him in with some difficulty, and forces the lid shut. He debates with himself for a moment on how to pick up the coffin, then disgustedly throws away his hat and climbs into the coffin, shutting the lid behind him. The coffin moves off by itself.
Cut back to the interview studio; Jimmy Buzzard is sitting on the floor.
Cut to a graveyard. The coffin, still moving of its own volition, enters the graveyard. A vicar walks up and motions gravediggers
(who we cannot see)

to get out of the grave. Out of the grave climb two gravediggers. . . then two more... then two more... yet another two... two miners ... two uniformed men... a police dog with handler... and finally an Australian surfboarder. The coffin makes its way into the grave. Then a wonderful piece of animation by the amazing animator Terry Gilliam, wonderboy. Consisting of a very fast collage of extremely sexy stills of half-dressed and naked girls.
Incredibly torchy music, after eight seconds of which:

Cut to fantastically alluring boudoir: a plush four poster bed with silk drapes, silk sheets, a fur pillow etc. We look down on it from above. Stretched out on the bed is a girl (Carol) oozing with sex... a real professional... black net stocking, suspenders, bra and panties or what have you. She moves as if in the throes of orgasm as she mimes to a very masculine voice off.
(very masculine voice to which girl mimes)
Cut to film of eight-second striptease. Cut immediately back to the same set.
Cut to another bed, equally seductive. A little bespectcled professor is lying on it being caressed and undressed by an amorous siren.
(German accent)
(grabs girl)

A curtain and potted palms. Sound effects: angel choirs. A man in dinner jacket with angel's wings on is lowered from above. As he touches the ground the angel choirs fade out. He gets a crumpled piece of paper out of his pocket.
He folds up the paper and puts it away. The angel choirs start again and he slowly rises up and out of frame.
Cut to Professor Canning in straight presentation-type set with BP screen behind him.
(on the screen behind him a contemporary piaure of the Battle of Trafalgar flashes up)
Cut to a man - a Gumby - with gum boots on, rolled up trousers, knotted handkerchief etc., looking very thick and standing in the middle of a field.
(voice over)
Camera pans lightly losing Gumby but revealing identically dressed thick man standing next to him. The camera pans back to original Gumby.
(voice over)
There is a long pause.
(voice over)
(voice over)
Cut to identical Gumby figure in book lined study. He stands.
Cut to another Gumby, this time outside a university.
Cut to yet another Gumby. This time standing in a pig-sty with pigs.
Original sexy girl in seductive boudoir as she mimes to masculine voice over.
(brandishing egg-whisk)
Cut back to Canning.
Cut to a muddy corner of a field. Miss Rita Fairbanks stands talking straight to camera. Behind her lurk five more pepperpots.
(voice over)
She retreats, and joins the other ladies who meanwhile separate into two opposing sides facing each other.
(reverential voice over)
A whistle blows and the two sides set about each other with handbags etc., speeded up 50% just to give it a bit of edge. Cut to Canning in studio.

Cut to vicar in a graveyard He sprinkles dirt and gets mud thrown in his face. Vicar shoots a gun. Cut to undertakers leaving graveyard. They get into a hearse. As they leave it and drive off we see the other side is painted with psychedelic flowers. Cut to Canning.
Cut to 'It's' man.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 10

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS'

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Ooh. Ooh.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh, what is it dear?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: It's from the BBC. They want to know if I want to be in a sketch on telly.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oooh. That's nice.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What? It's acting innit?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well I'm a plumber. I can't act.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh, you never know till you try. Look at Mrs Brando's son next door. He was mending the fridge when they came and asked him to be the Wild One. What do they want you to do?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well, they just want me to stand at a counter, and when the sketch starts I go out.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh, that sounds nice. It's what they call a walk-on.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Walk-on? That's a walk-off, that's what this is.

dialogue.speaker: Robber
dialogue.text: Well, where is he, George?

dialogue.speaker: Floor Manager
dialogue.text: I don't know, he should have been here hours ago.

dialogue.speaker: Robber
dialogue.text: He bloody should have been.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Well what else does it say?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: It just says 'We would like you to be in a sketch. You are standing at a counter. When the sketch starts you go off. Yours faithfully, Lord Hill.'

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh well, you'd better be off then.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yeah, well, what about the cat?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh I'll look after the cat. Goodness me, Mrs Newman's eldest never worried about the cat when he went off to do 'The Sweet Bird of Youth'.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: All right then, all right. Bye. Bye dear.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Bye bye, and mind you don't get seduced.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh, it'll make a change from plumbing. Dad! Frank's got a television part.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: You missed him.

dialogue.speaker: Robber
dialogue.text: Good morning, I am a bank robber. Er, please don't panic, just hand over all your money.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: This is a lingerie shop, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Robber
dialogue.text: Fine, fine, fine. Adopt, adapt and improve. Motto of the round table. Well, um ... what have you got?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Er, we've got corsets, stockings, suspender belts, tights, bras, slips, petticoats, knickers, socks and garters, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Robber
dialogue.text: Fine, fine, fine, fine. No large piles of money in safes?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: No, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Robber
dialogue.text: No deposit accounts?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: No sir.

dialogue.speaker: Robber
dialogue.text: No piles of cash in easy to carry bags?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: None at all sir.

dialogue.speaker: Robber
dialogue.text: No luncheon vouchers?

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: No, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Robber
dialogue.text: Fine, fine. Well, um... adopt, adapt and improve. Just a pair of knickers then please.

dialogue.speaker: Unction
dialogue.text: Well that was a bit of fun wasn't it. Ha, ha, ha. And a special good evening to . Not just an ordinary good evening like you get from all the other announcers, but a special good evening from to . Well, what have we got next? This fun isn't it. Look, I'm sorry if I'm interrupting anything that any of you may be doing at home, but I want you to think of me as an old queen. , ha, ha, ha. Well, let's see what we've got next. In a few moments 'It's A Tree' and in the chair as usual is Arthur Tree, and starring in the show will be a host of star guests as his star guests. And then at 9.30 we've got another rollocking half hour of laughter-packed squalor with 'Yes it's the Sewage Farm Attendants'. And this week Dan falls into a vat of human dung with hilarious consequences. Ha, ha, ha. But now it's the glittering world of show business with Arthur Tree...

dialogue.speaker: Tree
dialogue.text: Hello. Hello people, and welcome to 'It's a Tree'. We have some really exiting guests for you this evening. A fabulous spruce, back from a tour of Holland, three gum trees making their first appearance in this country, scots pine and the conifers, and Elm Tree Bole - there you go, can't be bad - an exiting new American plank, a rainforest and a bucket of sawdust giving their views on teenage violence, and an unusual guest for this programme, a piece of laminated plastic.

dialogue.speaker: Plastic
dialogue.text: Hi there!

dialogue.speaker: Tree
dialogue.text: But first, will you please, please welcome - a block of wood.

dialogue.speaker: Tree
dialogue.text: Well, er, thanks Tree. I've got to pay the rent.

dialogue.speaker: Tree
dialogue.text: Ha, ha, ha, ha, super. Well, what have you been doing, Block?

dialogue.speaker: Block
dialogue.text: Well I've just been starring in several major multi-million dollar international films, and, during breaks on the set, I've been designing a Cathedral, doing wonderful unpublicized work for charity, er, finishing my history of the world, of course, pulling the birds, er, photographing royalty on the loo, averting World War Three - can't be bad - and, er learning to read.

dialogue.speaker: Tree
dialogue.text: The full Renaissance bit, really...super, super. Well I've got to stop you there Block I'm afraid, because we've got someone who's been doing cabaret in the New Forest. From America, will you welcome please a Chippendale writing desk.

dialogue.speaker: Chip
dialogue.text: Thank you Mr Tree. And I'd like to do a few impressions of some of my favourite Englishmen. First off. Long John Silver. Augh, Jim boy. Augh. And now Edward Heath. Hello sailor. Now a short scene from a play by Harold Splinter.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Wasn't that just great, ladies and gentlemen, wait a minute we've got something else I just know you're going to love. Yes sir, coming right up - the Vocational Guidance Counsellor Sketch.

dialogue.speaker: Voices Singing
dialogue.text: Vocational guidance counsellor ... vocational guidance counsellor ... vocational guidance counsellor ... etc.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Ah Mr Anchovy. Do sit down.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Thank you. Take the weight off the feet, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Yes, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Lovely weather for the time of year, I must say.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Enough of this gay banter. And now Mr Anchovy, you asked us to advise you which job in life you were best suited for.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: That is correct, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Well I now have the results here of the interviews and the aptitude tests that you took last week, and from them we've built up a pretty clear picture of the sort of person that you are. And I think I can say, without fear of contradiction, that the ideal job for you is chartered accountancy.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: But I a chartered accountant.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Jolly good. Well back to the office with you then.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: No! No! No! You don't understand. I've been a chartered accountant for the last twenty years. I want a new job. Something that will let me .

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Well chartered accountancy is rather exciting isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Exciting? No it's . It's dull. Dull. . My God it's dull, it's so desperately dull and tedious and stuffy and boring and des-per-ate-ly DULL.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Well, er, yes Mr Anchovy, but you see your report here says that you are an extremely dull person. You see, our experts describe you as an appallingly dull fellow, unimaginative, timid, lacking in initiative, spineless, easily dominated, no sense of humour, tedious company and irrepressibly drab and awful. And whereas in most professions these would be considerable drawbacks, in chartered accountancy they are a positive boon.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: But don't you see, I came here to find a new job, a new life, a new to my existence. Can't you help me?

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Well, do you have any idea of what you want to do?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Yes, yes I have.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Lion taming.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Well yes. Yes. Of course, it's a bit of a jump isn't it? I mean, er, chartered accountancy to lion taming in one go. You don't think it might be better if you worked your way lion taming, say, via banking?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no. No. I don't want to wait. At nine o'clock tomorrow I want to be in there, taming.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Fine, fine. But do you, do you have any qualifications?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Yes, I've got a hat.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: A hat?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Yes, a hat. A lion taming hat. A hat with 'lion tamer' on it. I got it at Harrods. And it lights up saying 'lion tamer' in great big neon letters, so that you can tame them after dark when they're less stroppy.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: I see, I see.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: And you can switch it off during the day time, and claim reasonable wear and tear as allowable professional expenses under paragraph 335C...

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, yes, I do follow, Mr Anchovy, but you see the snag is... if I now call Mr Chipperfield and say to him, 'look here, I've got a forty-five-year-old chartered accountant with me who wants to become a lion tamer', his first question is not going to be 'does he have his own hat?' He's going to ask what sort of experience you've had with lions.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Well I ... I've seen them at the zoo.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Good, good, good.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Lively brown furry things with short stumpy legs and great long noses. I don't know what all the fuss is about, I could tame one of those. They look pretty tame to start with.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: And these, er, these lions ... how high are they?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Well they're about so high, you know. They don't frighten me at all.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Really. And do these lions eat ants?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Yes, that's right.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Er, well, Mr Anchovy ... I'm afraid what you've got hold of there is an anteater.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: A what?

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: An anteater. Not a lion. You see a lion is a huge savage beast, about five feet high, ten feet long, weighing about four hundred pounds, running forty miles per hour, with masses of sharp pointed teeth and nasty long razor-sharp claws that can rip your belly open before you can say 'Eric Robinson', and they look like this.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Time enough I think for a piece of wood.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The larch.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Now, shall I call Mr Chipperfield?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Er, no, no, no. I think your idea of making the transition to lion taming via easy stages, say via insurance...

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Or banking.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Or banking, yes, yes, banking that's a man's life, isn't it? Banking, travel, excitement, adventure, thrills, decisions affecting people's lives.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Jolly good, well, er, shall I put you in touch with a bank?

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: Anchovy
dialogue.text: Er... no, no, no. Look, er, it's a big decision, I'd like a couple of weeks to think about it... er... you know, don't want to jump into it too quickly. Maybe three weeks. I could let you know definitely then, I just don't want to make this definite decision. I'm er...

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Well this is just one of the all too many cases on our books of chartered accountancy. The only way that we can fight this terrible debilitating social disease, is by informing the general public of its consequences, by showing young people that it's just not worth it. So, so please... give generously... to this address: The League for Fighting Chartered Accountancy, 55 Lincoln House, Basil Street, London, SW3.

dialogue.speaker: Unction
dialogue.text: Oh, well that was fun wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: No it wasn't, you fairy.

dialogue.speaker: Unction
dialogue.text: Oh, hello sailor,

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: Here, you wouldn't have got on one of our voyages - they were all dead butch.

dialogue.speaker: Unction
dialogue.text: Oh that's not what I've heard.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: There is an epic quality about the sea which has throughout history stirred the hearts and minds of Englishmen of all nations. Sir Francis Drake, Captain Webb, Nelson of Trafalgar and Scott of the Antartic - all rose to the challenge of the mighty ocean. And today another Englishman may add his name to the golden roll of history: Mr Ron Obvious of Neaps End. For today, Ron Obvious hopes to be the first man to jump the Channel.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Ron, now let's just get this quite clear - you're intending to jump across the English Channel?

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Oh yes, that is correct, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And, er, just how far is that?

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Oh, well it's twenty-six miles from here to Calais.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, that's to the beach at Calais?

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Well, no, no, provided I get a good lift off and maybe a gust of breeze over the French coast, I shall be jumping into the centre of Calais itself.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Ron are you using any special techniques to jump this great distance?

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Oh no, no. I shall be using an ordinary two-footed jump, er, straight up in the air and across the Channel.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: I see. Er, Ron, what is the furthest distance that you've jumped, er, so far?

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Er, oh, eleven foot six inches at Motspur Park on July 22nd. Er, but I have done nearly twelve feet unofficially.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: I see. Er, Ron, Ron, Ron, aren't you worried Ron, aren't you worried jumping twenty-six miles across the sea?

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Oh, well no, no, no, no. It is in fact easier to jump over sea than over dry land.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well how is that?

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Er, well my manager explained it to me. You see if you're five miles out over the English Channel, with nothing but sea underneath you, er, there is a very great impetus to say in the air.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: I see. Well, er, thank you very much Ron and the very best of luck.

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Thank you. Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: The man behind Ron's cross-Channel jump is his manager Mr Luigi Vercotti. Mr Vercotti, er Mr Vercotti ... Mr Vercotti...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: What? I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, no, we're from the BBC, Mr Vercotti.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Who?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: The BBC.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Oh, oh. I see. I thought, I thought you were the er . .. I like the police a lot, I've got a lot of time for them.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Mr, er, Mr Vercotti, what is your chief task as Ron's manager?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Well my main task is, er, to fix a sponsor for the big jump.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And who is the sponsor?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: The Chippenham Brick Company. Ah, they, er, pay all the bills, er, in return for which Ron will be carrying half a hundredweight of their bricks.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: I see. Well, er, it looks as if Ron is ready now. He's got the bricks. He's had his passport checked and he's all set to go. And he's off on the first ever cross-Channel jump. Will Ron be trying the cross-Channel jump again soon?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: No. No. I'm taking him off the jumps. Er, because I've got something lined up for Ron next week that I think is very much more up his street.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, what's that?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Er, Ron is going to eat Chichester Cathedral.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well, there he goes, Ron Obvious of Neaps End, in an attempt which could make him the first man ever to eat an entire Anglican Cathedral.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Well, er, I think, David, this is something which Ron and myself are really keen on. Ron is going to tunnel from Godalming here to Java here.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Java.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Yeah, er, I, I personally think this is going to make Ron a household name overnight.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And how far has he got?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Er, well, he's quite far now, Dave, well on the way. Well on the way, yeah.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well where is he exactly?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Where?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Oh, er, well, er, you know, it's difficult to say exactly. He's er, you know, in the area of er, Ron, how far have you got?

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Oh about two foot six Mr Vercotti.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Yeah well keep digging lad, keep digging.

dialogue.speaker: Ron
dialogue.text: Mr Vercotti are you sure there isn't a spade?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, Mr Verccotti, what do you say to people who accuse you of exploiting Ron for your own purposes?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: Well, it's totally untrue, David. Ever since I left Sicily I've been trying to do the best for Ron. I know what Ron wants to do, I believe in him and I'm just trying to create the opportunities for Ron to do the kind of things he wants to do.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And what's he going to do today?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: He's going to split a railway carriage with his nose.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: The only difficult bit for Ron is getting out of the Earth's atmosphere. Er, once he's in orbit he'll be able to run straight to Mercury.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Vercotti
dialogue.text: I am now extremely hopeful that Ron will break the world record for remaining underground. He's a wonderful boy this, he's got this really enormous talent, this really huge talent.

dialogue.speaker: First Lady
dialogue.text: Oh that was a bit sad, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Second Lady
dialogue.text: Shh. It's satire.

dialogue.speaker: First Lady
dialogue.text: No it isn't. This is zany madcap humour.

dialogue.speaker: Second Lady
dialogue.text: Oh is it?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Good morning, I'd like to buy a cat.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Certainly sir. I've got a lovely terrier.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, I want a cat really.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, how about that?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, that's the terrier.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Well, it's as near as dammit.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well what do you mean? I want a cat.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Listen, tell you what. I'll file its legs down a bit, take its snout out, stick a few wires through its cheeks. There you are, a lovely pussy cat.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Its not a proper cat.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well it wouldn't meow.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Well it would howl a bit.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no. Er, have you got a parrot?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: No, I'm afraid not actually guv, we're fresh out of parrots. I'll tell you what though ... I'll lop its back legs off, make good, strip the fur, stick a couple of wings on and staple on a beak of your own choice. No problem. Lovely parrot.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: How long would that take?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Oh, let me see ... er, stripping the fur off, no legs ... Harry ... can you do a parrot job on this terrier straight away?

dialogue.speaker: Harry
dialogue.text: No, I'm still putting a tuck in the Airedale, and then I got the frogs to let out.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Friday?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No I need it for tomorrow. It's a present.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Oh dear, it's a long job. You see parrot conversion ... Tell you what though, for free, terriers make lovely fish. I mean I could do that for you straight away. Legs off, fins on, stick a little pipe through the back of its neck so it can breathe, bit of gold paint, make good ...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You'd need a very big tank.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: It's a great conversation piece.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, all right, all right ... but, uh, only if I can watch.

dialogue.speaker: Pearson
dialogue.text: Oh, I thought that was a bit predictable.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: It's been done before

dialogue.speaker: Roman Centurion
dialogue.text: Yeah, we did it for Caesar's Christmas Show.

dialogue.speaker: Caesar
dialogue.text: No you didn't, you did Jack and the Beanstalk.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Here what was that picture?

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Ssh! Next! Good morning - Mr Phipps?

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: That's right, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Er, do take a seat.

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: Right sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Now could you tell us roughly why you want to become a librarian?

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: Er, well, I've had a certain amount of experience running a library at school.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. What sort of experience?

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: Er, well for a time I ran the Upper Science Library.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. Now Mr Phipps, you do realize that the post of librarian carries with it certain very important responsibilities. I mean, there's the selection of books, the record library, and the art gallery. Now it seems to me that your greatest disadvantage is your lack of professional experience ... coupled with the fact that, uh, being a gorilla, you would tend to frighten people.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Is he a gorilla?

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Yes he is.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Well why didn't it say on his form that he's a gorilla?

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Well, you see applicants are not required to fill in their species.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: What was that picture?

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Sh! ... Mr Phipps, what is your attitude toward censorship in a public library?

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: How do you mean, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Well I mean for instance, would you for instance stock 'Last Exit to Brooklyn'... or ... 'Groupie'?

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: Yes, I think so.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Good.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Yes, well, that seems to me to be very sensible Mr Phipps. I can't pretend that this library hasn't had its difficulties ... Mr Robertson, your predecessor, an excellent librarian, savaged three people last week and had to be destroyed.

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: I'm sorry sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Oh, no, don't be sorry. You see, I don't believe that libraries should be drab places where people sit in silence, and that's been the main reason for our policy of employing wild animals as librarians.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: And also, they're much more permissive. Pumas keep Hank Janson on open shelves...

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes, yes Mr Phipps. I love seeing the customers when they come in to complain about some book being damaged, and ask to see the chief librarian and then ... you should see their faces when the proud beast leaps from his tiny office, snatches the book from their hands and sinks his fangs into their soft er ... Mr Phipps ... Kong! You can be our next librarian - you're proud, majestic and fierce enough ... will you do it?

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: I ... don't think I can sir.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: I.. I'm not really a gorilla.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Eh?

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: I'm a librarian in a skin.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Why this deception?

dialogue.speaker: Gorilla
dialogue.text: Well, they said it was the best way to get the job.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Get out, Mr Librarian Phipps, seeing as you're not a gorilla, but only dressed up as one, trying to deceive us in order to further your career ... Next. Ah. Mr Pattinson ... Sit!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Mirror View, I would like to be paid five guineas for saying something stupid about a television show. Yours sincerely, Mrs Sybil Agro.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear David Jacobs, East Grinstead, Friday. Why should I have to pay sixty-four guineas each year for my television licence when I can buy one for six. Yours sincerely, Captain R. H. Pretty. PS Support Rhodesia, cut motor taxes, save the Argylls, running-in please pass.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Old Codgers, some friends of mine and I have formed a consortium, and working with sophisticated drilling equipment, we have discovered extensive nickel deposits off Western Scotland. The Cincinnatti Mining Company.

dialogue.speaker: Voices Over
dialogue.text: Good for you, ma'am.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Old Codgers, I am President of the United States of America, Yours truly, R. M. Nixon.

dialogue.speaker: Voices Over
dialogue.text: Phew! Bet that's a job and a half, ma'am.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, I am over three thousand years old and would like to see any scene with two people in bed.

dialogue.speaker: Voices Over
dialogue.text: Bet that's a link ma'am.

dialogue.speaker: Maurice
dialogue.text: Vera ... Vera ... darling! Wake up my little lemon. Come to my arms.

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Maurice! What are you doing here?

dialogue.speaker: Maurice
dialogue.text: I could not keep away from you. I must have you all the time.

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh this is most inconvenient.

dialogue.speaker: Maurice
dialogue.text: Don't talk to me about convenience, love consumes my naughty mind, I'm delirious with desire.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: What's that, Vera?

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh nothing, dear. Just a trick of the light.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Righto.

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Phew! That was close.

dialogue.speaker: Maurice
dialogue.text: Now then my little banana, my little fruit salad, I can wait for you no longer. You must be mine utterly...

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh, Maurice!

dialogue.speaker: Roger
dialogue.text: Vera! How dare you!

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Roger!

dialogue.speaker: Roger
dialogue.text: What's the meaning of this?

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh I can explain everything, my darling!

dialogue.speaker: Roger
dialogue.text: Who is this?

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: This is Maurice Zatapathique ... Roger Thompson ... Roger Thompsnn ... Maurice Zatapathique.

dialogue.speaker: Maurice
dialogue.text: How do you do.

dialogue.speaker: Roger
dialogue.text: How do you do ... How could you do this to me, Vera ... after all we've been through? Dammit, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: Maurice
dialogue.text: Vera! Don't you understand, it's me that loves you.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: What's happening, Vera?

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh, nothing dear. Just a twig brushing against the window.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Righto.

dialogue.speaker: Roger
dialogue.text: Come to me Vera!

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh ... not now, Roger.

dialogue.speaker: Maurice
dialogue.text: Vera, my little hedgehog! Don't turn me away!

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh it cannot be, Maurice.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Hands off, you filthy bally froggie!

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh Ken, Ken Biggles!

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Yes, Algy's here as well.

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Algy Braithwaite?

dialogue.speaker: Algy
dialogue.text: (Ian Davidson) That's right... Vera ... Oh God you know we both still bally love you.

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh Biggles! Algy. Oh, but how wonderful!

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: What's happening, Vera?

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh, er, nothing dear. It's just the toilet filling up.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Righto.

dialogue.speaker: Mexican
dialogue.text: Scusey... you tell me where is ... Mrs Vera Jackson ... please.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Yes ... right and right again.

dialogue.speaker: Mexican
dialogue.text: Muchas gracias...

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Righto.

dialogue.speaker: Mexican
dialogue.text: Oh Vera ... you remember Acapulco in the Springtime ...

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh. The Herman Rodrigues Four!

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Vera! I distinctly heard a Mexican rhythm combo.

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh no, dear... it was just the electric blanket switching off.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Hm. Well I'm going for a tinkle.

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Oh no you can't do that. Here, we haven't finished the sketch yet!

dialogue.speaker: Algy
dialogue.text: Dash it all, there's only another bally page.

dialogue.speaker: Roger
dialogue.text: I say. There's no one to react to.

dialogue.speaker: Maurice
dialogue.text: Don't talk to the camera.

dialogue.speaker: Roger
dialogue.text: Oh sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Vera
dialogue.text: Here it's no good you coming in ... He's gone and left the sketch.

dialogue.speaker: Biggles
dialogue.text: Yes, he went for a tinkle.

dialogue.speaker: Husband
dialogue.text: Sh! I think my wife is beginning to suspect something...

dialogue.speaker: Hartebeeste
dialogue.text: I thought that ending was a bit predictable.

dialogue.speaker: Crocodile
dialogue.text: Yes indeed there was a certain lack of originality.

dialogue.speaker: Ostrich
dialogue.text: However it's not necessarily a good thing just to be different.

dialogue.speaker: A Lady
dialogue.text: No, quite, there is equal humour in the conventional.

dialogue.speaker: Pig
dialogue.text: But on the other hand, is it what the public wants? I mean with the new permissiveness, not to mention the balance of payments. It's an undeniable fact that...

dialogue.speaker: Coelocanth
dialogue.text: I agree with that completely.

dialogue.speaker: Rodent
dialogue.text: That's it... let's get out of this show before it's too late... ('The End' descends on it) Too late!

annotations: Boring old 'It's' man hanging from a meat-hook.
(and CAPTION:)
Animated titles as per usual.
Cut to lingerie shop; assistant and robber still hanging around waiting. A few seconds of this. Floor manager walks on.
(quietly)
Cut back to grotty kitchen.
Man leaves, wife stands for a moment, then...

She turns on the TV set. On the TV comes the picture of the assistant and the robber and floor manager waiting in the lingerie shop. After a second or two a man is brought in and introduced to floor manager, who positions him and cues him. The man walks out.
Cut back to shop, the robber walks in and points gun at the assistant.
(politely)
(slightly nonplussed)
(still politely)
Cut to effeminate announcer sittin at continuity desk. Any resemblance to Mel Oxley should be accidental. His name is David Unction.
(holds up card saying 'David Unction')
Music.

Stock film. Quick cuts. Plane arriving at night. Showbiz lights. Film premières. Audience applauding. Cut to studio: a tree sitting in a middle chair in David Frost type intreview set. Zoom in on tree which has a mouth which moves.
Shot of piece of laminated plastic with mouth.
Shot of large block four feet cube, with a mouth, on the chair next to Tree.
Shot of a forest with the sound of applause over.
They both laugh. Shot of forest laughing.
a Chippendale desk.
(suitable animation)
(a huge hammer smashes it)
Animated compère:
(fanfares)
(more fanfares)
Animation film into Vocational Guidance Counsellor sketch.
Office set. Man sitting at desk. Mr Anchovy is standing waiting. The counsellor looks at his watch then starts the sketch.
(boldly)
(indicating a height of one foot)
The counsellor produces large picture of a lion and shows to Mr Anchovy who screams and passes out.
Picture of a tree.
Cut back to office: Mr Anchovy sits up with a start.
(continues muttering nervously to himsel)
(turning to camera)
gives address.
Cut back to David Unction reading 'Physique' magazine. He puts it into brown paper bag.
Cut to helmeted Viking.
Cut back to Unction.
(sarcastically)
Cut to Viking.
Cut to Unction.
(camply)
Cut to the sea. Pan to show Ron Obvious running along beach.
Ron runs up to group of cheering supporters. An interviewer addresses him.
Brief shot of group of Frenchmen with banner. 'Fin de Cross-Channel jump'.
Ron breaks off to make training-type movements.
(to camera)
(turns to speak to Vercotti, who has a Mafia suit and dark glasses)
(mumbles protestations of innocence)
We see a passport officer checking Ron's passport.
(Ron runs down the beach and jumps; he lands about four feet into the water)
Cut to Chichester Cathedral. Ron walks up to it, brushing his teeth.
Ron takes a hefty bite at a buttress, screams and clutches his mouth. Cut to countryside: a map, and a banner saying 'Tunnelling to Java'. Interviewer and Vercotti walk up to map.
(indicates inaccurately on map)
(emerging from hole)
Cut to interviewer and Vercotti by railway track.
(screams off)
Cut to a hillside; Vercotti, interviewer, and in the background a banner: 'Running to Mercury'.
A heavily bandaged Ron leaps off starting platform: freeze frame. Scream. Cut to a tombstone: 'Ron Obvious 1941-1969 - very talented', Pull back to show Vercotti.
Over the last shot of graveyard and wind whistling, we hear two ladies' voices.
Cut to a pet shop.
Man enters shop and approaches shopkeeper at counter.
(indicates a box on the counter
(glancing in box)
(taking box off counter and then putting it back on counter as if it is a different box)
(looking in box)
(taking small box and rattling it)
(calling)
(off-screen)
Vox pops.

Cut to interview room in town hall: tweedy colonel type chairman; next to him are a vicar and a lady with a pince-nez. The chairman is holding up the picture of Caesar. As the camera pulls out he rather obviously throws it away.
(a gorilla enters)
(sits)
(aside)
(a maniacal look in his eyes)
(collects himself)
(gorilla leaves)
(a dog comes in)
Cut to angry letters.
(reads)

Cut to bedroom of a middle-aged, middle-class wealthy couple. It is dark. They are both lying fast asleep on their backs. The husband is a colonel type with a moustache. The wife has her hair in curlers and face cream on. Someone climbs in through the window and pads across to the wife. He is a dapper little Frenchman in a beret and carrying a fench loaf. He kisses her on the forehead. She wakes.
He kisses her hand repeatedly. The husband wakes up with a start, sits bolt upright and looks straight ahead.
(he goes straight to sleep again)
Suddenly beside them appears a young public-school man in a check suit with a pipe.
(kneeling)
The husband wakes up again.
(he goes back to sleep)
Enter Biggles. He wears flying boots, jacket and helmet as for First World War. He has a notice round his neck: 'Biggles'.
(kneels by the bed)
Into the light comes Algy. Tears streaming down his face. He wears a notice round his neck which reads: Algy's here as well.
(he chokes back the tears)
She starts to cry. Husband wakes up again.
(he goes fast asleep again)

By this stage all the men have pulled up chairs in a circle around Vera's side of the bed. They are all chatting amongst themselves. Biggles is holding her hand. Maurice has produced a bottle of vin ordinaire. At this moment four Mexican musicans appear on the husband's side of the bed. The leader of the band nudges the husband, who wakes.
(reading from a scruffy bit of paper)

He immediately goes back to sleep again. The Mexicans all troop round the bed and enter the group. The leader conducts them and they start up a little conga . . . once they've started he turns and comes over to Vera with a naughty glint in his eye. They play a guitar, a trumpet and maracas.
Suddenly the husband wakes up.
(there is immediate silence)
He gets out of bed and disappears into the gloom.
Enter a huge man dressed as an Aztec god. He stretches arms open wide and is about to speak when owing to lack of money he is cut short by Vera.
Cut to close-up of husband and a dolly bird with a lavatory chain hanging between them. She is about to pull the chain when he stops her.
Cut to animation of various strange and wonderful creatures saying to the effect:
(eating it)
(eating the crocodile)
(emerging from hatch in ostrich)
(eating ostrich)
(eating the pig)
Two men detatch the 'It's' man from his meat-hook and carry him off.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 9

script.description: Large study with maps and photographs on the wall and a large desk at which sits Sir George Head.
