dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS'

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: The llama is a quadruped which lives in the big rivers like the Amazon. It has two ears, a heart, a forehead, and a beak for eating honey. But it is provided with fins for swimming.

dialogue.speaker: Guitarist & Dancer
dialogue.text: Llamas are larger than frogs.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Llamas are dangerous, so if you see one where people are swimming, you shout...

dialogue.speaker: Guitarist & Dancer
dialogue.text: Look out, there are llamas!

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different - a man with a tape recorder up his nose.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different. The office of Sir George Head, OBE.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Next please.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: One at a time please.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: There is only me, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: So there is. Take a . . .

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Seat?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Seat! Take a seat. So! You want to join my mountaineering expedition do you?

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Me, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Yes, I'd very much like to, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Jolly good, jolly good. And how about you?

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: There is only me, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Well bang goes his application then. Now let me fill you in. I'm leading this expedition and we're going to climb both peaks of Mount Kilimanjaro.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: I thought there was only one peak, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Well, that'll save a bit of time. Well done. Now the object of this expedition is to see if we can find any traces of last year's expedition.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Last year's expedition?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Yes, my brother was leading that, they were going to build a bridge between the two peaks, My idea I'm afraid. Now, I ought to tell you that I have practically everyone I need for this expedition ... so what special qualifications do you have?

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Well, sir...

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Yes, you first.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: There is only me, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: I wasn't talking to you. Carry on.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Well I'm a fully qualified mountaineer.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Mountaineer? Mountaineer where the devil are they, mound, mount... mountain... a mountaineer: 'two men skilled in climbing mountains'. Jolly good, well you're in. Congratulations, both of you. Well, er, what are your names?

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Arthur Wilson.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Arthur Wilson, right well look, I'll call you Arthur Wilson one, and you Arthur Wilson two, just to avoid confusion.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Are you actually leading this expedition sir?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Yes, we are leading this expedition to Africa.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: And what routes will you both be taking?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Good questions... shall I? Well we'll be leaving on January 22nd and taking the following routes. The A23s through Purleys down on the main roads near Purbrights avoiding Leatherheads and then taking the A231s entering Rottingdeans from the North. From Rottingdeans we go through Africa to Nairobis. We take the South road out of Nairobis for about twelve miles and then ask.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Does anyone speak Swahili, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Oh, yes I think most of them do down there.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Does anyone in our party speak Swahili sir?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Oh, well Matron's got a smattering.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Apart from the two Matrons ...

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Good God, I'd forgotten about her.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Apart from them, who else is coming on the expedition, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Well we've got the Arthur Brown twins, two botanists called Machin, the William Johnston brothers ...

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Two of them?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: No four of them, a pair of identical twins ... and a couple of the Ken Spinoza quads - the other two pulled out. And of course you two.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: And none of these are mountaineers?

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Well you two are, and we've got a brace of guides called Jimmy Blenkinsop... because Kilimanjaro is a pretty tricky climb you know, most of it's up until you reach the very very top, and then it tends to slope away rather sharply. But Jimmy's put his heads together and worked out a way up. Jimmy? I don't believe you've met. Jimmy Blenkinsop - Arthur Wilson, Arthur Wilson -Jimmy Blenkinsop... Arthur Wilson two -James Blenkinsop one, James Blenkinsop one - Arthur Wilson two. Carry on Jimmies.

dialogue.speaker: Jimmy
dialogue.text: Don't worry about the er ... We'll get him up somehow. Now the approach to Kilimanjaro is quite simply over the foothills, and then we go on after that to ... ohh... to set a base camp, somewhere in the region of the bottom of the glacier when...

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: He'll be leading the first assault.

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Well I'm afraid I shan't be coming on your expedition sir, as I've absolutely no confidence in anyone involved in it.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: Oh dear. Well how about you?

dialogue.speaker: Bob
dialogue.text: Well I'm game, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Sir
dialogue.text: So are we.

dialogue.speaker: Announcers
dialogue.text: And now for aomething completely different - a man with a tape recorder up his brother's nose.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'AND NOW IN STEREO...'

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Morning.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: Ah ... good morning sir, good morning. I'll be with you in a minute.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: How... how would you like it, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Just short back and sides please.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: How do you do that?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Well it's just... ordinary short back and sides.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: It's not a ... razor cut? Razor, razor, cut, cut, blood, spurt, artery, murder... Oh thank God, thank God. It's just a scissors.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Yes...

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: You wouldn't rather just have it combed, would you sir?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: You wouldn't rather forget all about it?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: No, no, no, I want it cut.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: Cut, cut, cut, blood, spurt, artery, murder, Hitchcock, Psycho... right sir ... well ... I'll just get everything ready. In the meanwhile perhaps you could fill in one of these.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: All right, fine, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Excuse me, er...

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Where it says: 'next of kin' shall I put 'mother'?

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: Yes, yes ... yes.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Right there we are.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: Right!

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: Ha, ha, ha ... there, I've finished.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: I've finished cutting... cutting... cutting your hair. It's all done,

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: You haven't started cutting it!

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: I have! I did it very quickly... your honour... ... sir...

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Look here old fellow, I know when a chap's cut my hair and when he hasn't. So will you please stop fooling around and get on with it.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, I will, I'm going to cut your hair, sir. I'm going to start cutting your hair, sir, start cutting now!

dialogue.speaker: Tape Recorder
dialogue.text: Nice day, sir,

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Yes, flowers could do with a drop of rain though, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Tape Recorder
dialogue.text: Did you see the match last night, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Yes. Good game. I thought.

dialogue.speaker: Tape Recorder
dialogue.text: I thought Hurst played well sir.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Tape Recorder
dialogue.text: I thought Hurst played well.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Oh yes ... yes ... he was the only one who did though.

dialogue.speaker: Tape Recorder
dialogue.text: Can you put your head down a little, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Sorry, sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Tape Recorder
dialogue.text: I prefer to watch Palace nowadays. Oh! Sorry! Was that your ear?

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: No no ... I didn't feel a thing.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Look, what's going on?

dialogue.speaker: Tape Recorder
dialogue.text: Yes, it's a nice spot, isn't it.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Look, I came here for a haircut!

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: It looks very nice sir.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: It's exactly the same as when I first came in.

dialogue.speaker: Tape Recorder
dialogue.text: Right, that's the lot then.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: All right ... I confess I haven't cut your hair ... I hate cutting hair. I have this terrible un-un-uncontrollable fear whenever I see hair. When I was a kid I used to hate the sight of hair being cut. My mother said I was a fool. She said the only way to cure it was to become a barber. So I spent five ghastly years at the Hairdressers' Training Centre at Totnes. Can you imagine what it's like cutting the for years? I didn't want to be a barber anyway. I wanted to be a lumberjack. Leaping from tree to tree as they float down the mighty rivers of British Columbia . . . The giant redwood, the larch, the fir, the mighty scots pine. The smell of fresh-cut timber! The crash of mighty trees! With my best girlie by my side ... We'd sing ... sing ... sing.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: I'm a lumberjack and I'm OK, I sleep all night and I work all day

dialogue.speaker: Mounties Choir
dialogue.text: He's a lumberjack, and he's OK, He sleeps all night and he works all day.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: I cut down trees, I eat my lunch, I go to the lavatory. On Wednesdays I go shopping, And have buttered scones for tea.

dialogue.speaker: Mounties Choir
dialogue.text: He cuts down trees, He eats his lunch, He goes to the lavatory. On Wednesdays he goes shopping, And have buttered scones for tea. He's a lumberjack, and he's OK, He sleeps all night and he works all day.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: I cut down trees, I skip and jump, I like to press wild flowers. I put on women's clothing, And hang around in bars.

dialogue.speaker: Mounties Choir
dialogue.text: He cuts down trees, he skips and jumps, He likes to press wild flowers. He puts on women's clothing And hangs around.... In bars???????

dialogue.speaker: Mounties Choir
dialogue.text: He's a lumberjack, and he's OK, He sleeps all night and he works all day.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: I chop down trees, I wear high heels, Suspenders and a bra. I wish I'd been a girlie Just like my dear Mama.

dialogue.speaker: Mounties Choir
dialogue.text: He cuts down trees, he wears high heels Suspenders and a .... a Bra????

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: ...just like my dear Mama.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: (Connie Booth) Oh Bevis! And I thought you were so rugged.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Sir, I wish to complain in the strongest possible terms about the song which you have just broadcast, about the lumberjack who wears women's clothes. Many of my best friends are lumberjacks and only a few of them are transvestites. Yours faithfully, Brigadier Sir Charles Arthur Strong (Mrs.) PS I have never kissed the editor of the Radio Times.

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Well I object to all this sex on the television. I mean I keep falling off.

dialogue.speaker: Gumby
dialogue.text: Well I think television's killed real entertainment. In the old days we used to make our own fun. At Christmas parties I used to strike myself on the head repeatedly with blunt instruments while crooning. 'Only make believe, I love you, Only make believe that you love me, Others find peace of mind...'

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Refreshment Room here at Bletchley. My name is Kenny Lust and I'm your compère for tonight. You know, once in a while it is my pleasure, and my privilege, to welcome here at the Refreshment Room, some of the truly great international artists of our time. And tonight we have one such artist. Ladies and gentlemen, someone whom I've always personally admired, perhaps more deeply, more strongly, more abjectly than ever before. A man, well more than a man, a god , a great god, whose personality is so totally and utterly wonderful my feeble words of welcome sound wretchedly and pathetically inadequate. Someone whose boots I would gladly lick clean until holes wore through my tongue, a man who is so totally and utterly wonderful, that I would rather be sealed in a pit of my own filth, than dare tread on the same stage with him.Ladies and gentlemen, the incomparably superior human being, Harry Fink!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Off
dialogue.text: He can't come!

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Never mind, it's not all it's cracked up to be. Ladies and gentlemen, we give you Ken Buddha and his inflatable knees.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Ken Buddha, a smile, two bangs and a religion. Now ladies and gentlemen, for your further entertainment, Brian Islam and Brucie.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: So anyway, I became a barber.

dialogue.speaker: Customer
dialogue.text: Poor chap.

dialogue.speaker: Barber
dialogue.text: Yes, pity really, I always preferred the outdoor life. Hunting, shooting, fishing. Getting out there with a gun, slaughtering a few of God's creatures - that was the life. Charging about the moorland, blasting their heads off.

dialogue.speaker: Floor Manager
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, we don't need you this week.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Would you mind terribly if I hold your hand?

dialogue.speaker: Iris
dialogue.text: Oh no, no, not at all.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Oh Iris, you're so very beautiful.

dialogue.speaker: Iris
dialogue.text: Oh, do you really mean that?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: I do, I do, I do. I think... I'm beginning to fall in love with you.

dialogue.speaker: Iris
dialogue.text: Oh Victor.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: It's silly isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Iris
dialogue.text: No, no, not at all dear sweet Victor.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: No I didn't mean that. Only just us being so close together for so many months in the soft-toy department and yet never daring to...

dialogue.speaker: Iris
dialogue.text: Oh, oh Victor.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Oh Iris. Who can that be?

dialogue.speaker: Iris
dialogue.text: Oh, well you try and get rid of them.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Yes I will, I will.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Hello!

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Hello.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Remember me?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: No I'm...

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: In the pub. The tall thin one with the moustache, remember? About three years ago?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: No, I don't I'm afraid.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Oh, blimey, it's dark in here, that's better. Only you said we must have a drink together sometime, so I thought I'd take you up on it as the film society meeting was cancelled this evening.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Look, to be frank, it is a little awkward this evening.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Hello, I'm Arthur. Arthur Name. Name by name but not by nature. I always say that, don't I Vicky boy?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Really...

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Is that your wife?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Er, no, actually.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Oh, I get the picture. Eh? Well don't worry about me Vicky boy, I know all about one-night stands.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Mind if I change the record?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Look, look, we put that on.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Here's a good one, I heard it in a pub. What's brown, what's brown and sounds like a bell?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: What's brown and sounds like a bell? Dung! Ha, ha, ha, that's a good one. I like that one, I won't keep you long. That's better, now don't worry about me. I'll wait here till you've finished.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Who the hell...

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: I'll get it. It'll be friends of mine. I took the liberty of inviting them along.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Look, we were hoping to have a quiet evening on our own.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Oh, they won't mind. They're very broad-minded. Hello!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Good evening. My name is Equator, Mr Equator Equator. Like round the middle of the Earth, only with an L. This is my wife Audrey, she smells a bit but she has a heart of gold.

dialogue.speaker: Audrey
dialogue.text: Hello, ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha...

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: There must have been some kind of misunderstanding, because this is not the...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Who's that then?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Who's the bird?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: You got a nice pair there haven't you love. Shut up you silly bitch, it was only a bit of fun.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Now look here ...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Big gin please.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: I'll get it.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Look, leave those drinks alone.

dialogue.speaker: Audrey
dialogue.text: And three tins of beans for me please.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: I told you to lay off the beans, you whore!

dialogue.speaker: Audrey
dialogue.text: I only want three cans.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Button your lip you rat-bag.

dialogue.speaker: Audrey
dialogue.text: Ha, ha, ha, ha...

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: It was rather witty, wasn't it? Where's my gin?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Who the hell's that?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Oh, I took the liberty of inviting an old friend along, as his wife has just passed away, and he's somewhat distraught poor chap. I hope you don't mind.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Come on in.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Freight
dialogue.text: Oh? My God, what a simply ghastly place.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Not too good is it? A pint of crème de menthe for my friend. Well how are you, you great poof? Bit lumpy ...ah, no wonder, I was sitting on the cat.

dialogue.speaker: Iris
dialogue.text: Aaaagh! Boo boo hooo.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Freight
dialogue.text: I've asked along a simply gorgeous little man I picked up outside the Odeon.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Is he sexy?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Cook
dialogue.text: I had to bring the goat, he's not well. I only hope he don't go on the carpet.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Come on then love, drop 'em.

dialogue.speaker: Iris
dialogue.text: Aaaaaaagh!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: Blimey, she don't go much do she.

dialogue.speaker: Audrey
dialogue.text: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, oooooh! I've wet 'em

dialogue.speaker: Mr Cook
dialogue.text: The goat's just done a bundle.

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: Look, get out all of you. Go on. Get out! Get out!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Victor
dialogue.text: I'm turning you all out. I'm not having my house filled with filthy perverts, now look, I'm giving you just half a minute then I'm going to call the police, so get out.

dialogue.speaker: Mr Equator
dialogue.text: I don't much like the tone of your voice. Right let's have a ding dong...

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Ding dong merrily on high, in Heaven the bells are ringing etc...

dialogue.speaker: Spanish Voices
dialogue.text: Look out, there are llamas!

annotations: A forest. From an explosion in the far distance the 'It's' man runs very rapidly up to camera and announces:
(and CAPTION:)
Opening animated titles.
A Spanish guitarist (Eric) and a dancer (Terry J) in traditional spanish costume.
Man enters and walks up to a life-size photo of a llama. He delivers the following lecture in Spanish, with help from the guitarist and dancer, and superimposed subtitles.
(but in Spanish with subtitles in English)

Graham dressed in a spanish frock, enters on a moped; he blows up a paper bag and bursts it. They bow. Cut to exterior Ada's Snack Bar (a small cafe). Hand-held camera moves round the back to where an announcer is seated at desk with an old-fashioned BBC microphone.

We see Michael, in evening dress, on a small stage, with potted plants, etc. He ostentatiously inserts a finger up one nostril. We hear the Marseillaise. He removes the finger; the music stops. He inserts the finger up the other nostril: we hear rewinding noises. Once again he inserts a finger up the first nostril: again we hear the Marseillaise. He bows. Stock film of Women's Institute applauding. He inserts a finger up his nostril again, and we hear:
Arthur walks into the room and up to the desk.
(looking up)
(putting a hand over one eye)
(looking over to Bob's right)
(keeps looking off to right)
(rather uncertain)
(he ticks the sheet and then looks straight at Bob)
(putting hand over eye and looking both at Bob and to Bob's right)
(he tears up form)
(getting up, putting one hand over one eye again and going to large map of Africa on wall and peering at it at point-blank range)
(looks at map with one hand over eye)
(to Bob's right)
(to Bob)
(looks it up in the dictionary)
(to Bob)
(to Bob's right)
(goes over to large map, clearly labelled Surrey)
(opens door)
(Jimmy walks in wearing full climbing gear)
(to Bob, reassuring him)
(puts hand over eye)

Jimmy proceeds to walk round the room clambering over every single piece of available furniture. He doesn't stop talking. Causing a complete wreckage, he clambers over the desk, onto a bookcase and round the room knocking furniture over, meanwhile he is saying..
Jimmy staggers out headlong through the door. There are loud crashing noises
Bob gets up and walks out slamming the door.
(pause - look over at other? Bob)
(sitting in chair at other angle of desk)
Cut back to two sirs, double image, split screen.
Cut to two announcers (Johns) at desks. They put telephones down, turns to camera, and announce:

Cut to Michael on small stage as before, this time also with Graham. Michael puts a finger up Graham's nostril: we hear the Marseillaise. He removes it: the music stops. He puts a finger up Graham's other nostril, and we hear rewinding noises.
(and CAPTION:)
Michael simultaneously puts a finger up his own nostril and a finger (on the other hand) up Graham's; we hear two recordings of the Marseillaise together (out of sync).
(flinching slightly)

Customer sits in barber's chair. Barber carries on washing. He seems to be over-thoroughly washing and rewashing his hands and lower arms. Barber turns and smiles humourlessly, at customer. At last he has finished washing. He dries his hands thoroughly, turns and comes over to the customer. There are very obvious blood stains on his coat and his lapel is torn off. One stain could be the mark of a bloodstained hand which has slipped down the length of it. He picks up a sheet and shakes it out. Sound of iron and heavy objects falling on the floor. He throws it around the customer. As he knots the sheet at the back he is about to pull it tight and strangle the customer. His face sweats, a wild look in his eyes. Then with a supreme effort he controls himself. Customer smiles reassuringly at him.
(suddenly)
(controlling himself)
(sigh of relief)
(laughs, thinking the barber must be having a little joke)
At the word cut barber winces.
(swallows hard)
He hands him a bit of paper; the barber goes to a cupboard and opens it.
On the inside of the door there is a large medical chart headed: 'Main Arteries'. His shaking hand traces the arteries and he looks occasionally back at the customer.
(hands form to barber)
He gets scissors and comb ready and comes up behind the customer and spreads his arms out, opening and shutting scissors as barbers do before cutting.
He can't bring himself to start cutting; after one or two attempts he goes to the cupboard again, gets a whisky bottle out and takes a hard swig. He comes up behind the customer again.
(getting rather testy)
The barber bends down to the floor and drags out a tape recorder which he places behind the barber's chair, talking as he does so.
He switches on tape recorder and then he himself cowers down against the wall as far from the chair as he can get, trembling.
(snip, snip)
(snip, snip, snip; sound of electric razor starting up)
(straining to hear)
(razor stops)
(his head is bowed)
(electric razor starts up again)
The customer rises out from his seat, taking the sheet off himself and looking in the mirror and delving into pocket. He turns round for the first time and sees the cowering barber.
(pathetically)
(angrily)
(he is gradually straightening up with a visionary gleam in his eyes)
(he tears off his barber's jacket, to reveal tartan shirt and lumberjack trousers underneath; as he speaks the lights dim behind him and a choir of Mounties is heard, faintly in the distance)
(moves to stand infront of back-drop of Canadian mountains and forests)
(a frail adoring blonde, the heroine of many a mountains film, or perhaps the rebel maid, rushes to his side and looks adoringly into his eyes)
The choir is loud by now and music as well.
(singing)
Light comes up to his left to reveal a choir of Mounties.
During the last verse the choir has started to look uncomfortable but they brighten up as they go into the chorus.
(spoken rather than sung)
They all mumble. Music runs down. The girl looks horrified and bursts into tears.
Cut to hand-written letter.
Cut to pepperpot.
Shot of battered trophy.
Cut back to Canadian backdrop. In front, a man with a knotted handkerchief on his head, a wooly pullover, and braces.
(sings)
(hits himself on head with bricks)
(hits himself)
Cut to a swish nightclub. Compère enters.
(applause)
(applause)
(grovelling)
(applause)
(applause)
(by now on his knees)
Cut to Ken (Terry J) in evening dress; his knees go 'bang'.
Two animated men dance to jug band music. When they finish we cut back to the barber and customer.
(sympathetically)

Cut to a large country house. A number of sportin' gentlemen dressed in huntin' tweed and carrying shotguns come out, casually firing the guns at random. They climb into a land-rover and drive off. Cut to huntin' country. A line of beater moves towards the camera; as they do so several young couples leap up out of the undergrowth and run away. Shots of hunters stalking their prey and shooting. One of them breaks his gun into two pieces. Another fires into the air. An egg lands on his head. Cut to two duellists (with pistols) and a referee standing between them. They fire; the referee falls dead. A huntin' gentleman fires into the air, falls over backwards; a young couple gets up from close behind him and run away. Another huntin' gentleman is arguing defensively with a pilot who has just landen by parachute. A hunter fires into some bushes; a Red Indian pops up and runs away in alarm. They all return to the house, legs and arms variously in plaster and bandaged. Two of them carry a pole between them from which is slung a very small bird. The picture of the outside of the house freezes and we pull back to reveal that it is a photo on a stand, by which stands the knight in armour, expectantly flexing his raw chicken. The floor manager comes up to him.
Knight looks dejected, droops and slinks off, still holding chicken. He walks past a hen house from wherein we hear a voice.
Cut to a sitting room. Low sexy lighting - ha ha - soft sexy music. On the sofa are Victor and Iris just beginning to make passes at each other.
(they move closer to kiss; just before their lips meet the doorbell rings)
Victor opens the front door. Arthur Name is standing outside the door.
(switches light on)
(stepping in; to Iris)
(to Victor)
(takes the record off)
(the gramophone plays the 'Liberty Bell March' very loud)
The doorbell rings again.
He opens the door; Mr and Mrs Equator walk in and go straight up to Victor.
(wheezing laugh)
(puts hand on Iris's boobs and gives a wet kiss; Iris screams)
(going after Arthur)
(laughs uproariously)
(joins in)
(The doorbell rings again)
(opening door)
In walks Mr Freight in underpants, sequins, eye make-up, white wellies, and necklace.
(sits down)
(throws it into fire)
In walks Mr Cook with a goat. Freight kisses him.
(to Iris)
(runs out)
He sits in chair which collapses.
A group of singers run on, dressed as Welsh miners. All talk at once.
(shoots him)
(singing)
Cut to 'It's' man
(in Spanish)
'It's' man runs away into forest.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 8

dialogue.text: 'MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS'

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Speaking as a public opinion poll, I've had enough of the permissive society.

dialogue.speaker: Man In Dirty Raincoat
dialogue.text: I havn't had enough of the permissive society.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: I would not appear in a frontal nude scene unless it was valid.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: In 1943, a group of British Army Officers working deep behind enemy lines, carried out one of the most dangerous and heroic raids in the history of warfare. But that's as maybe. And now . . .

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Come in, what do you want?

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: I'd like to leave the army please, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Good heavens man, why?

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: It's dangerous.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: There are people with guns out there, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: Real guns, sir. Not toy ones, sir. Proper ones, sir. They've all got 'em. All of 'em, sir. And some of 'em have got tanks.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Watkins, they on our side.

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: And grenades, sir. And machine guns, sir. So I'd like to leave, sir, before I get killed, please.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Watkins, you've only been in the army a day.

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: I know sir but people get killed, properly dead, sir, no barley cross fingers, sir. A bloke was telling me, if you're in the army and there's a war you have to go and fight.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: That's true.

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: Well I mean, blimey, I mean if it was a big war somebody could be hurt.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Watkins why did you the army?

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: For the water-skiing and for the travel, sir. And for the killing, sir. I asked them to put it on my form, sir - no killing.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Watkins are you a pacifist?

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: No sir, I'm not a pacifist, sir. I'm a coward.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: That's a very silly line. Sit down.

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: Yes sir. Silly, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Awfully bad.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Two civilian gentlemen to see you ... sir!

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Show them in please, sergeant.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Mr Dino Vercotti and Mr Luigi Vercotti.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: Good morning, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Good morning gentlemen. Now what can I do for you.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: You've ... you've got a nice army base here, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: We wouldn't want anything to happen to it.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: No, what my brother means is it would be a shame if...

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: Oh sorry, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Well don't worry about that. But please do sit down.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: No, we prefer to stand, thank you, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: All right. All right. But what do you want?

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: What do we want, ha ha ha.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Ha ha ha, very good, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: The colonel's a joker, Luigi.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Explain it to the colonel, Dino.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: How many tanks you got, colonel?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: About five hundred altogether.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Five hundred! Hey!

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: You ought to be careful, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: We are careful, extremely careful.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: 'Cos things , don't they?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Break?

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Well everything breaks, don't it colonel. Oh dear.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: Oh see my brother's clumsy colonel, and when he gets unhappy he breaks things. Like say, he don't feel the army's playing fair by him, he may start breaking things, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: What is all this about?

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: How many men you got here, colonel?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Oh, er ... seven thousand infantry, six hundred artillery, and er, two divisions of paratroops.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Paratroops, Dino.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: Be a shame if someone was to set fire to .

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Set to them?

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Fires happen, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: Things burn.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Look, what is all this about?

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: My brother and I have got a little proposition for you colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Could save you a lot of bother.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: I mean you're doing all right here aren't you, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Well suppose some of your tanks was to get broken and troops started getting lost, er, fights started breaking out during general inspection, like.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: It wouldn't be good for business would it, colonel?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Are you threatening me?

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: Oh, no, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Whatever made you think that, colonel?

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: The colonel doesn't think we're nice people, Luigi.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: We're your buddies, colonel.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: We want to look after you.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Look after me?

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: We can guarantee you that not a single armoured division will get done over for fifteen bob a week.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: No, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Twelve and six.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: No, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: Eight and six ... five bob...

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: No, no this is silly.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: What's silly?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: No, the whole premise is silly and it's very badly written. I'm the senior officer here and I haven't had a funny line yet. So I'm stopping it.

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: You can't do that!

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: I've done it. The sketch is over.

dialogue.speaker: Watkins
dialogue.text: I want to leave the army please sir, it's dangerous.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Look, I stopped sketch five minutes ago. So get out of shot. Right director! Close up. Zoom in on me. That's better.

dialogue.speaker: Luigi
dialogue.text: It's only 'cos you couldn't think of a punch line.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Not true, not true. It's time for the cartoon. Cue telecine, ten, nine, eight...

dialogue.speaker: Dino
dialogue.text: The general public's not going to understand this, are they?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Shut up you eyeties!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Full frontal nudity - never. What do you think, Barbara?

dialogue.speaker: Barbara
dialogue.text: Oh, no, no, no...unless it was artistically valid, of course.

dialogue.speaker: Stockbroker
dialogue.text: Full frontal nudity? Yes I'd do it, if it was valid. Or if the money was valid, and if it were a very small part.

dialogue.speaker: Art Critic
dialogue.text: Good evening. I'd like to talk to you tonight about the place of the nude in my bed ... um ... in the history of my bed ... of art, of , I'm sorry. The place of the nude in the history of tart... call-girl... I'm sorry. I'll start again... Bum ... oh what a giveaway. The place of the nude in art. Oh hello there father, er confessor, professor, your honour, your grace ...

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: (Katya Wyeth) I'm not your Grace, I'm your Elsie.

dialogue.speaker: Art Critic
dialogue.text: What a terrible joke!

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: But it's my only line!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'BUT THERE LET US LEAVE THE ART CRITIC TO STRANGLE HIS WIFE AND MOVE ON TO PASTURES NEW'

dialogue.speaker: Mr Lambert
dialogue.text: Og, certainly, I'll, I'll get someone to help you. Mr Verity!

dialogue.speaker: Mr Verity
dialogue.text: Can I help you, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Er yes. We'd like to buy a bed...a double bed...about fifty pounds?

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: Oh no, I'm afraid not, sir. Our cheapest bed is eight hundred pounds, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Eight hundred pounds!

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Or, er, perhaps I should have explained. Mr Verity does tend to exaggerate, so every figure he gives you will be ten times too high. Otherwise he's perfectly all right, perfectly ha, ha, ha.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Oh I see. I see. So your cheapest bed then is eighty pounds?

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: Eight hundred pounds, yes, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: And how wide is it?

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: Er, the width is, er, sixty feet wide.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Oh... six foot wide, eh. And the length?

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: The length is ... er ... Lambert! What is the length of the Comfydown Majorette?

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Er, two foot long.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Two foot long?

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: Ah yes, you have to remember of course, to multiply everything Mr Lambert says by three. Er, it's nothing he can help, you understand. Apart from that he's perfectly all right.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: I see, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: But it does mean that when he says a bed is two foot wide, it is in fact sixty foot wide.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Oh, yes I see...

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: And that's not counting the mattress.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Oh, how much is that?

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: Er, Mr Lambert will be able to help you there. Lambert! Will you show these twenty good people the, er, dog kennels, please?

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Mm? Certainly.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Dog kennel? No, no, no, mattresses, mattresses!

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: Oh no, no you have to say dog kennel to Mr Lambert because if you say mattress he puts a bag over his head. I should have explained. Apart from that he's really all right.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Ah, hum, er we'd like to see the dog kennels please.

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Dog kennels?

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Yes, we want to see the dog kennels.

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Ah yes, well that's the pets' department. Second floor.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Oh, no, no, we want to see the .

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Yes, pets department second floor.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: No, we don't really want to see dog kennels only your colleague said we ought to...

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Oh dear, what's he been telling you now?

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Well, he said we should say dog kennels instead of mattress.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Oh dear. Hello?

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: Did you say mattress?

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Well, a little yes.

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: I did you not to say mattress, didn't I? Now I've got to stand in the tea chest. 'And did those feet in ancient times, walk upon England's mountains green...'

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: Oh dear, did somebody say mattress to Mr Lambert?

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: He should be all right now, but don't, you know... ! (exits)

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Oh, no, no, no. er,, we'd like to see, see the dog kennels please?

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Yes, second floor.

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: No, no, look these dog kennels here, see?

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Mattresses?

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Oh ...yes.

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Well, if you meant mattress, why dodn't you a mattress? I mean, it's very confusing for me if you go and say dog kennels when you mean mattress. Why not just say mattress?

dialogue.speaker: Groom
dialogue.text: Well, I mean you put a bag over your head last time I said mattress.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Did somebody say mattress to Mr Lambert?

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: Twice.

dialogue.speaker: Assistant
dialogue.text: Hey, everybody, somebody said mattress to Mr Lambert, twice.

dialogue.speaker: Verity
dialogue.text: It's not working. We need more!

dialogue.speaker: Lambert
dialogue.text: Now, er, can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: Bride
dialogue.text: We want a mattress.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Oh. What did you say that for? What did you say that for?

dialogue.speaker: Bride
dialogue.text: But it's my only line!

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Well, you didn't have to say it.

dialogue.speaker: African Native
dialogue.text: Full frontal nudity - not in this part of Esher.

dialogue.speaker: Chartered Accountant
dialogue.text: I would only perform in a scene in which there was full frontal nudity.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Now, I've noticed a tendency for this programme to get rather silly. Now I do my best to keep things moving along, but I'm not having things getting silly. Those two last sketches I did got very silly indeed, and that last one about the bed was even sillier. Now, nobody likes a good laugh more than I do...except perhaps my wife and some of her friends...oh yes and Captain Johnston. Come to think of it most people likes a good laugh more than I do. But that's beside the point. Now, let's have a good clean healthy outdoor sketch. Get some air into your lungs. Ten, nine, eight and all that.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Hello, are you a hermit by any chance?

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Yes that's right. Are you a hermit?

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Yes, I certainly am.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Well I never. What are you getting away from?

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh you know, the usual - people, chat, gossip, you know.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh I certainly do - it was the same with me. I mean there comes a time when you realize there's no good frittering your life away in idleness and trivial chit-chat. Where's your cave?

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh, up the goat track, first on the left.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh they're very nice up there, aren't they?

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Yes they are, I've got a beauty.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: A bit drafty though, aren't they?

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: No, we've had ours insulated.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh yes.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Yes, I used birds' nests, moss and oak leaves round the outside.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh, sounds marvellous.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh it's a treat, it really is, 'cos otherwise those stone caves can be so grim.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Yes they really can be, can't they? They really can.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh yes.

dialogue.speaker: Third Hermit
dialogue.text: Morning Frank.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Morning Norman. Talking of moss, er you know Mr Robinson?

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: With the, er, green loin cloth?

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Er no, that's Mr Seagrave. Mr Robinson's the hermit who lodges with Mr Seagrave.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh I see, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Yes well he's put me onto wattles.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Yes. Swears by them. Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Hermit
dialogue.text: Morning Frank.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Morning Lionel. Well he says that moss tends to fall off the cave walls during cold weather. You know you might get a really bad spell and half the moss drops off the cave wall, leaving you cold.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh well, Mr Robinson's cave's never been exactly nirvana has it?

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Well, quite, that's what I mean. Anyway, Mr Rogers, he's the, er, hermit...

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: ... on the end.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: . .. up at the top, yes. Well he tried wattles and he came out in a rash.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Yes, and there's me with half a wall wattled, I mean what'll I do?

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Well why don't you try birds nests like I've done? Or else, dead bracken.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Hermit
dialogue.text: Frank!

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Yes Han.

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Hermit
dialogue.text: Can I borrow your goat?

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Er, yes that'll be all right. Oh leave me a pint for breakfast will you? ... You see, you know that is the trouble with living half way up a cliff - you feel so cut off. You know it takes me two hours every morning to get out onto the moors, collect my berries, chastise myself, and two hours back in the evening.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Still there's one thing about being a hermit, at least you meet people.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh yes, I wouldn't go back to public relations.

dialogue.speaker: First Hermit
dialogue.text: Oh well, bye for now Frank, must toddle.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Right, you two hermits, stop that sketch. I think it's silly.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: It's silly.

dialogue.speaker: Second Hermit
dialogue.text: What do you mean, you can't stop it - it's on film.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: That doesn't make any difference to the viewer at home, does it? Come on, get out. Out. Come on out, all of you. Get off, go on, all of you. Go on, move, move. Go on, get out. Come on, get out, move, move.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Hello, I wish to register a complaint...Hello? Miss?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: What do you mean, miss?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Oh I'm sorry, I have a cold. I wish to make a complaint!

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Sorry, we're closing for lunch.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Never mind that, my lad. I wish to complain about this parrot what I purchased not half an hour ago from this very boutique.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Oh yes, the, the Norwegian Blue. What's wrong with it?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: I'll tell you what's wrong with it, my lad. It's dead, that's what's wrong with it!

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: No, no, it's resting, look!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Look my lad, I know a dead parrot when I see one, and I'm looking at one right now.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: No no sir. it's not dead. It's resting!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Resting?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Yeah, remarkable bird, the Norwegian Blue, beautiful plumage, innit?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: The plumage don't enter into it - it's stone dead.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: No, no - it's just resting!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: All right then, if it's restin', I'll wake him up! Hello Polly! I've got a nice cuttlefish for you when you wake up, Polly Parrot!

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: There, it moved!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: No, he didn't. That was you pushing the cage!

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: I did not.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Yes, you did! Hello Polly, Polly Polly Parrot, wake up. Polly. Now that's what I call a dead parrot.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: No, no. It's stunned.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Look my lad, I've had just about enough of this. That parrot is definitely deceased. And when I bought it not half an hour ago, you assured me that its lack of movement was due to it being tired and shagged out after a long squawk.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: It's probably pining for the fjords.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Pining for the fjords, what kind of talk is that? Look, why did it fall flat on its back the moment I got it home?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: The Norwegian Blue prefers kipping on it's back! Beautiful bird, lovely plumage!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Look, I took the liberty of examining that parrot, and I discovered the only reason that it had been sitting on its perch in the first place was that it had been nailed there.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Well of course it was nailed there. Otherwise it would muscle up to those bars and voom.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Look matey this parrot wouldn't voom if you put four thousand volts through it! It's bleedin' demised!

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: It's not, it's pining!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: It's not pining, it's passed on. This parrot is no more! It has ceased to be. It's expired and gone to meet its maker.This is a late parrot. It's a stiff. Bereft of life, it rests in peace. If you hadn't nailed it to the perch it would be pushing up the daisies. It's rung down the curtain and joined the choir invisible. This is an ex-parrot.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Well, I'd better replace it, then.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: If you want to get anything done in this country you've got to complain till you're blue in the mouth.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Sorry guv, we're right out of parrots.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: I see. I see. I get the picture.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: I got a slug.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Does it talk?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Not really, no.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Well, it's scarcely a replacement, then is it?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Listen, I'll tell you what, tell you what, if you go to my brother's pet shop in Bolton he'll replace your parrot for you.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Bolton eh?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Er, excuse me. This is Bolton, is it?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: No, no it's, er, Ipswich.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: That's Inter-City Rail for you.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: I wish to make a complaint.

dialogue.speaker: Porter
dialogue.text: I don't have to do this, you know.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogue.speaker: Porter
dialogue.text: I'm a qualified brain surgeon. I only do this because I like being my own boss.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Er, excuse me, this is irrelevant, isn't it.

dialogue.speaker: Porter
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, it's not easy to pad these out to thirty minutes.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Well I wish to make a complaint. I got on the Bolton train and found myself deposited here in Ipswich.

dialogue.speaker: Porter
dialogue.text: No, this is Bolton.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: The pet shop owner's brother was lying.

dialogue.speaker: Porter
dialogue.text: Well you can't blame British Rail for that.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: If this is Bolton, I shall return to the pet shop.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: I understand that this Bolton.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Well, you told me it was Ipswich.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: It was a pun.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: A pun?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: No, no, not a pun, no. What's the other thing which reads the same backwards as forwards?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: A palindrome?

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Yes, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: It's not a palindrome. The palindrome of Bolton would be Notlob. It don't work.

dialogue.speaker: Shopkeeper
dialogue.text: Look, what do you want.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: No I'm sorry, I'm not prepared to pursue my line of enquiry any further as I think this is getting too silly.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Quite agree. Quite agree. Silly. Silly...silly. Right get on with it. Get on with it.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Oh...er...oh...um. Oh!...er... I'm sorry...and now frontal nudity.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Oh, oh I'm sorry. I thought the film was longer. Ah. Now Notlob, er, Bolton.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: This is a frightened city. Over these houses, over these streets hangs a pall of fear. Fear of a new kind of violence which is terrorizing the city. Yes, gangs of old ladies attacking defenseless, fit young men.

dialogue.speaker: First Young Man
dialogue.text: Well they come up to you, like, and push you - shove you off the pavement, like. There's usually four or five of them.

dialogue.speaker: Second Young Man
dialogue.text: Yeah, this used to be a nice neighbourhood before the old ladies started moving in. Nowadays some of us daren't even go down to the shops.

dialogue.speaker: Third Young Man
dialogue.text: Well Mr Johnson's son Kevin, he don't go out any more. He comes back from wrestling and locks himself in his room.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: What are they in it for, these old hoodlums, these layabouts in lace?

dialogue.speaker: First Granny
dialogue.text: Well it's something to do isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Second Granny
dialogue.text: It's good fun.

dialogue.speaker: Third Granny
dialogue.text: It's like you know, well, innit, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Favourite targets for the old ladies are telephone kiosks.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Well come on, come on, off with you. Clear out, come on get out of it. We have a lot of trouble with these oldies. Pension day's the worst - they go mad. As soon as they get their hands on their money they blow it all on milk, bread, tea, tin of meat for the cat.

dialogue.speaker: Cinema Manager
dialogue.text: Yes, well of course they come here for the two o'clock matinee, all the old bags out in there, especially if it's something like 'The Sound of Music'. We get seats ripped up, hearing aids broken, all that sort of thing.

dialogue.speaker: Reporter
dialogue.text: The whole problem of these senile delinquents lies in their complete rejection of the values of contemporary society. They've seen their children grow up and become accountants, stockbrokers and even sociologists, and they begin to wonder if it is all really... arggh!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Young Man
dialogue.text: Oh well we sometimes feel we're to blame in some way for what our gran's become. I mean she used to be happy here until she, she started on the crochet.

dialogue.speaker: Reporter
dialogue.text: Crochet?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Young Man
dialogue.text: Yeah. Now she can't do without it. Twenty balls of wool a day, sometimes. If she can't get the wool she gets violent. What can we do about it?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But this is not just an old ladies' town. There are other equally dangerous gangs - such as the baby snatchers.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: (Rita Davies) I just left my husband out here while I went in to do some shopping and I came back and he was gone. He was only forty-seven.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And on the road too, vicious gangs of keep left signs.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Right, right, stop it. This film's got silly. Started off with a nice little idea about grannies attacking young men, but now it's got silly. This man's hair is too long for a vicar too. These signs are pretty badly made. Right, now for a complete change of mood.

dialogue.speaker: Man In Dirty Raincoat
dialogue.text: I've heard of unisex but I've never had it.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: David Hemmings appeared by permission of the National Forestry Commission.

annotations: We see the 'It's' man sitting in the countryside in a garden lounger chair. A sexy young lady in a bikini hands him a glass of wine and gently helps him up and walks him to the camera. Looking very pleased with himself he sips the wine as she caresses him. Then she hands him a smoking round anarchist's type bomb (with 'Bomb' written on it). He realizes what it is only as he says:
Cartoon credits.
Cut to vox pops.
Cut to policeman.
Stock film of the army. Tanks rolling, troops moving forward etc. Stirring military music.
Cut to colonel's office. Colonel is seated at desk.
Private Watkins enters and salutes.
(sits in corner)
Knock at the door, sergeant enters, and salutes.
The Vercotti brothers enter. They wear Mafia suits and dark glasses.
(looking round office casually)
(he knocks something off mantel)
(he breaks something on desk)
(camera zooms in)
(off screen)
Cut to telecine countdown.
(off screen)
(off screen)
Cartoon rubbish entitled 'Full Frontal Nudity': Written, created and concieved off the back of a lorry by a demented American.
Cut to two naked men.
Cut to a stockbroker.
Cut to art critic examining a nude painting.
He sees the camera and starts guiltily.
(a seductively dressed girl enters slinkily)
(cutely)
(crying)
Cut to an idyllic countryside. Birds sing etc. as the camera starts a lyrical pan across the fields.
(and SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION)

After about ten seconds of mood setting the camera suddenly comes across the art critic strangling his wife in middle foreground. As the camera passes him he hums nervously and tries to look as though he isn't strangling anybody. The camera doesn't stop panning, and just as it goes off him we see him start strangling again. The pan carries on and catches up with a bridegroom carrying his bride across a field and finally arriving in a high street where, breathless and panting, he carries her through traffic and into a large department store. Finally cut to the furniture department of the store. The bridegroom and bride enter, he puts her down and addresses one of the assistants.
(calling off)
(to Verity)
(laughing politely he mutters to wife)
(calls off)
(calls)
They go to Lambert.
Lambert puts bag over head
(looking around)
(he gets in the chest and sings)
The manager enters.
Manager and Verity continue to sing. Lambert takes bag off head, manager exits after pointing a warning finger at bride and groom.
(Getting out of chest)
(pointing)
(jumps)
Bag goes on. Groom looks around guiltily. Verity walks in. Verity heaves a sigh, jumps in box. Manager comes in and joins him, they sing 'And did those feet...'. Another assistant comes in.
Assistant, groom and bride join in the therapy.
Cut to crowd in St. Peter's Square singing 'Jerusalem'.
Cut to department store. Lambert takes the bag off his head and looks at groom and bride.
Lambert immediately puts bag back on head.
(weeping)
They all hop off. She howls. Cut to vox pops.
Cut to colonel.
Cut to two hermits on a hillside.
Third hermit passes by.
Fourth hermit passes by.
(calling from a distance)
(to first hermit)
(coming on)
He shoos them and the film crew off the hillside.
including dancing Botticelli Venus, which links to pet shop: Mr. Praline walks into the shop carrying a dead parrot in a cage. He walks to counter where shopkeeper tries to hide below cash register.
(shouts into cage)
(jogging the cage)
(takes parrot out of cage, shouts)
(bangs it against the counter)
(throws it in the air and lets it fall to the floor)
(picks up the parrot)
(to camera)
(pause)
(handing over a card)
He leaves, holding the parrot.

Close-up of sign on door reading: 'Similar Pet Shops, Ltd.' Pull back from sign to see same pet shop. Shopkeeper now has moustache. Praline walks into shop. He looks around with interest, noticing the empty parrot cage still on the floor.
(to camera)
(leaves)
Man in porter's outfit standing at complaints desk for railways. Praline approaches.
(to camera)
Praline walks into the shop again.
(coming in)
Cut to announcer eating a yoghurt.
(seeing camera)
(shuffles paper)

Cut to tracking or hand-held shot down street, keeping up with extremely shabby man in long overcoat. His back is to the camera. He passes two pepperpots and a girl. As he passes each one he opens his coat wide. They react with shocked horror. He does this three times, after the third time he turns to camera and opens his coat wide. He has a big sign hanging round his neck, covering his chest. It says 'boo'.
Cut back to announcer eating yoghurt. The colonel comes in and nudges him.
(shuffling papers)
Cut to grannies film, which opens with a pan across Bolton. Voice of reporter.
Film of old ladies beating up two young men; then several grannies walking aggressively along street, pushing passers-by aside.
Film of grannies harrassing an attractive girl.
(voice over)
(voice over)
(voice over)
Film of grannies carrying off a telephone kiosk; then painting slogans on a wall.
(coming up to them)
(they clear off, he turns to camera)
Cut to cinema.
A policeman hustles two grannies out of the cinema.
Cut to reporter walking along street.
(disappears downwards rapidly)
Shot of two grannies replacing manhole cover.
Cut to young couple.
(off-screen)
Film of grannies on motorbikes roaring down streets and through a shop. One has 'Hell's Grannies' on her jacket.
Film of five men in baby outfits carrying off a young man from outside a shop. Cut to distraught wife.
Film: two keep-left signs attack a vicar.
(coming up and stopping them)
Cut to man in dirty raincoat.
Cut to 'It's' man still holding smoking bomb.
The 'It's' man realizes that he has a bomb and runs off still carrying it. As the credits end it explodes.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 7

dialogue.speaker: Voice Off
dialogue.text: It's...no...no...it's...it's...it's...

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Good evening. Tonight we're going to take a hard tough abrasive look at camel spotting. Hello.

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Hello Peter.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Now tell me, what exactly are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Er well, I'm camel spotting. I'm spotting to see if there are any camels that I can spot, and put them down in my camel spotting book.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Good. And how many camels have you spotted so far?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Oh, well so far Peter, up to the present moment, I've spotted nearly, ooh, nearly one.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Nearly one?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Er, call it none.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Fine. And er how long have you been here?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Three years.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: So, in, er, three years you've spotted no camels?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Yes in only three years. Er, I tell a lie, four, be fair, five. I've been camel spotting for just the seven years. Before that of course I was a Yeti spotter.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: A Yeti spotter, that must have been extremely interesting.

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Oh, it was extremely interesting, very, very - quite... it was dull; dull, dull, dull, oh God it was dull. Sitting in the Waterloo waiting room. Course once you've seen one Yeti you've seen them all.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And have you seen them all?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Well I've seen one. Well a little one... a picture of a... I've heard about them.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well, now tell me, what do you do when you spot a camel?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Er, I take its number.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Camels don't have numbers.

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Ah, well you've got to know where to look. Er, they're on the side of the engine above the piston box.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Ah - of course you've got to make sure it's not a dromedary. 'Cos if it's a dromedary it goes in the dromedary book.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well how do you tell if it's a dromedary?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Ah well, a dromedary has one hump and a camel has a refreshment car, buffet, and ticket collector.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Mr Sopwith, aren't you in fact a train spotter?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Don't you in fact spot trains?

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Oh, you're no fun anymore.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: (Donna Reading) Oh, you're no fun anymore.

dialogue.speaker: Lasher
dialogue.text: .. thirty-nine... forty. All right, cut him down, Mr Fuller.

dialogue.speaker: Lashee
dialogue.text: Oh you're no fun anymore.

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Now if anybody else pinches my phrase I'll throw them under a camel.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: If you can spot one.

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: Lady Chairman, sir, shareholders, ladies and gentlemen. I have great pleasure in announcing that owing to a cutback on surplus expenditure of twelve million Canadian dollars, plus a refund of seven and a half million Deutschmarks from the Swiss branch, and in addition adding the debenture preference stock of the three and three quarter million to the directors' reserve currency account of seven and a half million, plus an upward expenditure margin of eleven and a half thousand lira, due to a rise in capital investment of ten million pounds, this firm last year made a complete profit of a shilling.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: A shilling Wilkins?

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: Er, roughly, yes sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Wilkins, I am the Chairman of a multi-million pound corporation and you are a very new chartered Accountant. Isn't it possible there may have been some mistake?

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: Well that's very kind of you sir, but I don't think I'm ready to be Chairman yet.

dialogue.speaker: Board Member
dialogue.text: Wilkins, Wilkins. This shilling, is it net or gross?

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: It's British sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Yes, has tax been paid on it?

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: Yes, this is after tax. Owing to the rigorous bite of the income tax five pence of a further sixpence was swallowed up in tax.

dialogue.speaker: Board Member
dialogue.text: Five pence of a sixpence?

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: Yes sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Five pence of a further ?

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: That's right sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Then where is the other penny?

dialogue.speaker: Board Member
dialogue.text: That makes you a penny short Wilkins. Where is it?

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: ... Erm.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Wilkins?

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: I embezzled it sir.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: What all of it?

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: Yes all of it.

dialogue.speaker: Board Member
dialogue.text: You naughty person.

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: It's my first. Please be gentle with me.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: I'm afraid it's my unpleasant duty to inform you that you're fired.

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: Oh please, please.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: No, out!

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: Oh ...

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Yes, there's no place for sentiment in big business.

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: Oh you're no fun anymore.

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: I heard that. Who said that?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: He did! He did!

dialogue.speaker: Bishop
dialogue.text: No I didn't.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Ooh!

dialogue.speaker: Spotter
dialogue.text: Right!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Here is the address to complain to ...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The Royal Frog Trampling Institute, 16 Rayners Lane, London, W.C. Fields. I'll just repeat that...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Tristram and Isolde Phillips, 7.30 Covent Garden Saturday (near Sunday) and afterwards at the Inigo Jones Fish Emporium.

dialogue.speaker: Jewish Figure
dialogue.text: And they want to put the licence fee up?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And now here is a reminder about leaving your radio on during the night. Leave your radio on during the night.

dialogue.speaker: Redcoat
dialogue.text: A little joke, a little jest. Nothing to worry about ladies and gentlemen. Now we've got some science fiction for you, some sci-fi, something to send the shivers up your spine, send the creepy crawlies down your lager and limes. All the lads have contributed to it, it's a little number entitled, Science Fiction Sketch...

dialogue.speaker: American Voice
dialogue.text: The Universe consists of a billion, billion galaxies... 77,000,000,000 miles across, and every galaxy is made up of a billion, zillion stars and around these stars circle a billion planets, and of all of these planets the greenest and the pleasantest is the planet Earth, in the system of Sol, in the Galaxy known as the Milky Way ... And it was to this world that creatures of an alien planet came ... to conquer and destroy the very heart of civilization...

dialogue.speaker: American Voice
dialogue.text: It was a day like any other and Mr and Mrs Samuel Brainsample were a perfectly ordinary couple, leading perfectly ordinary lives - the sort of people to whom nothing extraordinary ever happened, and not the kind of people to be the centre of one of the most astounding incidents in the history of mankind ... So let's forget about them and follow instead the destiny of this man ... ... Harold Potter, gardener, and tax official, first victim of Creatures from another Planet.

dialogue.speaker: Newsvendor's Voice
dialogue.text: Read all abaht it! Read all abaht it! Man turns into Scotsman!

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Mrs Potter - you knew Harold Potter quite well I believe?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Oh yes quite well.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: He was my husband.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Yes. And, er, he never showed any inclination towards being a Scotsman before this happened?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: No, no, not at all. He was not that sort of person...

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: He didn't wear a kilt or play the bagpipes?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: No, no.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: He never got drunk at night or bought home black puddings?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: No, no. Not at all.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: He didn't have an inadequate brain capacity?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: No, no, not at all.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: I see. So by your account Harold Potter was a perfectly ordinary Englishman without any tendency towards being a Scotsman whatsoever?

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Absolutely, yes. Mind you he did always watch Dr Finlay on television.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Ah-hah! ... Well that's it, you see. That's how it starts.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: Well you see Scottishness starts with little things like that, and works up. You see, people don't just turn into a Scotsman for no reason at all... No further questions!

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: (Donna Reading) Charles...

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Darling...

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Charles...

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Darling, darling...

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Charles... there's something I've got to tell you...

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: What is it darling?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: It's daddy ... he's turned into a Scotsman...

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: What! Mr Llewellyn?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Yes, Charles. Help me, please help me.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: But what can I do?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Surely, Charles, you're the Chief Scientist at the Anthropological Research Institute, at Butley Down - an expert in what makes people change from one nationality to another.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: So I am! This is right up my street!

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh good.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Now first of all, why would anyone turn into a Scotsman?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Em, for business reasons?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No, no! Only because he has no control over his own destiny! Look I'll show you...

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: I see.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Yes! So this means that some person or persons unknown is turning all these people into Scotsmen...

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh, what kind of heartless fiend could that to a man?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: I don't know ... I don't know ... all I know is that these people are streaming north of the border at the rate of thousands every hour. If we don't act fast, Scotland will be choked with Scotsmen...

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Ooh!...

dialogue.speaker: American Voice
dialogue.text: Soon Scotland was full of Scotsmen. The over-crowding was pitiful.

dialogue.speaker: American Voice
dialogue.text: Three men to a caber.

dialogue.speaker: American Voice
dialogue.text: For the few who remained, life was increasingly difficult.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Charles! Thank goodness I've found you! It's mummy!

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Hello mummy.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: No, no, mummy's turned into a Scotsman...

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Oh how horrible... Will they stop at nothing?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: I don't know - do you think they will?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: I meant that rhetorically.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: What does rhetorically mean?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: It means, I didn't expect an answer.

dialogue.speaker: She
