dialogue.text: Oh I see. Oh, you're so clever, Charles.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Did mummy say anything as she changed?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Yes! she did, now you come to mention it

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Well, what was it?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh, she said ... 'Them!' Is there someone at the door?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No ... It's just the incidental music for this scene.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh I see...

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: 'Them' ... Wait a minute!

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: A minute?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No, I meant that metaphorically ... 'Them' ... 'Them' ... She was obviously referring to the people who turned her into a Scotsman. If only we knew who 'They' were ... And why 'They' were doing it... Who are 'Them'?

dialogue.speaker: American Voice
dialogue.text: Then suddenly a clue turned up in Scotland. Mr Angus Podgorny, owner of a Dunbar menswear shop, received an order for 48,000,000 kilts from the planet Skyron in the Galaxy of Andromeda.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Angus how are y'going to get 48,000,000 kilts into the van?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: I'll have t'do it in two goes.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: D'you not ken that the Galaxy of Andromeda is two million, two hundred thousand light years away?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Is that so?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Aye ... and you've never been further than Berwick-on-Tweed...

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Aye ... but think o' the money dear ... £18.10.0d a kilt ...that's ... £900,000,000 - and that's without sporrans!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Aye ... I think you ought not to go, Angus.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Aye ... we'd be able to afford writing paper with our names on it... We'd be able to buy that extension to the toilet...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Aye ... but he hasn't signed the order yet, has he?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Who?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Ach ... the man from Andromeda.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Och ... well ... he wasna really a man, d'you ken ...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Not really a man?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: He was as strange a thing as ever I saw, or ever I hope to see, God willing. He was a strange unearthly creature - a quivering, glistening mass...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Angus Podgorny, what y'mean?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: He wasna so much a man as... a blancmange!

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: A blancmange, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Yes, that's right. I was just having a game of doubles with Sandra and Jocasta, Alec and David...

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Hang on!

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: There's five.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Five people . . . how do you play doubles with five people?

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Ah, well ... we were...

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Sounds a bit funny if you ask me ... playing doubles with five people...

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Well we often play like that... Jocasta plays on the side receiving service...

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Oh yes?

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Yes. It helps to speed the game up and make it a lot faster, and it means Jocasta isn't left out.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Look, are you asking me to believe that the five of you was playing doubles, when on the very next court there was a blancmange playing by itself?.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: That's right, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Well answer me this then - why didn't Jocasta play the blancmange at singles, while you and Sandra and Alec and David had a proper game of doubles with four people?

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: Because Jocasta always plays with us. She's a friend of ours.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Call that friendship? Messing up a perfectly good game of doubles?

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: It's not messing it up, officer, we like to play with five.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Look it's affair if you want to play with five people ... but don't go calling it doubles. Look at Wimbledon, right? If Fred Stolle and Tony Roche played Charlie Pasarell and Cliff Drysdale and Peaches Bartcowitz... they wouldn't go calling it doubles.

dialogue.speaker: Girl
dialogue.text: But what about the blancmange?

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: That could play Ann Haydon-Jones and her husband Pip.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Oh, a blancmange gave you an order for 48,000,000 kilts?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Aye!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: And you it?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Aye, I did.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Och, you're a stupid man, Angus Podgorny.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Oh look woman, how many kilts did we sell last year? Nine and a half, that's all. So when I get an order for 48,000,000, I believe it - you I believe it.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Even if it's from a blancmange?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Och, woman, if a blancmange is prepared to come 2,200,000 light years to purchase a kilt, they must be fairly keen on kilts. So cease yer prattling woman and get sewing. This could be the biggest breakthrough in kilts since the Provost of Edinburgh sat on a spike. Mary, we'll be rich! We'll be rich!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Oh, but Angus... he hasna given you an earnest of his good faith!

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Ah mebbe not but he has gi' me this...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: What is it now?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: An entry form for the British Open Tennis Championships at Wimbledon Toon ... signed and seconded.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Och, but Angus, ye ken full well that Scots folk dinna know how to play the tennis to save their lives.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Aye, but I must go though dear, I dinna want to seem ungrateful.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Ach! Angus, I wilna let you make a fool o'yourself.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: But I must.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Och, no you'll not ...

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Oh, Mary... Oh, oh, Mary! Look out! Look out!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs Podgorny
dialogue.text: Urrgh. It's the blancmange.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Oh, now this is where Mr Podgorny could have saved his wife's life. If he'd gone to the police and told them that he'd been approached by unearthly beings from the Galaxy of Andromeda, we'd have sent a man round to investigate. As it was he did a deal with a blancmange, and the blancmange ate his wife. So if you're going out, or going on holiday, or anything strange happens involving other galaxies, just nip round to your local police station, and tell the sergeant on duty - or his wife - of your suspicions. And the same goes for dogs. So I'm sorry to have interrupted your exciting science fiction story ... but, then, crime's our business you know. So carry on viewing, and my thanks to the BBC for allowing me to have this little chat with you. Goodnight. God bless, look after yourselves.

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Do sit down, Mr Podgorny... I... I ... think what's happened is ... terribly ... terribly... funny .... tragic. But you must understand that we have to catch the creature that ate your wife, and if you could help us answer a few questions, we may be able to help save a few lives. I know this is the way your wife would have wanted it.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Aye ... I'll ... do ... my best, sergeant.

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Detective Inspector!

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Er, detective inspector.

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Now then. The facts are these. You received an order for 48,000,000 kilts from a blancmange from the planet Skyron in the Galaxy of Andromeda ... you'd just shown your wife an entry form for Wimbledon, which you'd filled in... when you turned round and saw her legs disappearing into a blancmange. Is that correct?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Yes, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Are you mad?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: No, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Well that's a relief. 'Cos if you were, your story would be less plausible. Now then, do you recognize this?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Oh yes. That's the one that ate my Mary!

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Good. His name's Riley... Jack Riley... He's that most rare of criminals ... a blancmange impersonator and cannibal.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: But what about the 48,000,000 kilts and the Galaxy of Andromeda?

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: I'm afraid that's just one of his stories. You must understand that a blancmange impersonator and cannibal has to use some pretty clever stories to allay suspicion.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Then you mean...

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: But...

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: How?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Well...

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Not?

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: I'm afraid so.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Who knows?

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: Do you think?

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Could be.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: But...

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: Angus
dialogue.text: She was...

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: Good lord what's that? Ah, Riley! Come to give yourself up have you, Riley? Eh Riley? Riley! Riley! It's not Riley!

dialogue.speaker: Detective
dialogue.text: It's an extra-terrestial being! Agggh!

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: So, everyone in England is being turned into Scotsmen, right?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Now, which is the worst tennis-playing nation in the world?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Er ... Australia.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No. Try again.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Australia?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No... try again but say a different place.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh, I thought you meant I'd said it badly.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No, course you didn't say it badly. Now hurry.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Er, Czechoslovakia.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No! Scotland!

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Of course.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text:
Now ... now these blancmanges, apart from the one that killed Mrs Podgorny
have all appeared in which London suburb?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Finchley?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No. Wimbledon ... Now do you begin to see the pattern? With what sport is Wimbledon commonly associated?

dialogue.speaker: Norman Hackforth
dialogue.text: For viewers at home, the answer is coming up on your screens. Those of you who wish to play it the hard way, stand upside down with your head in a bucket of piranha fish. Here is the question once again.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: With what sport is Wimbledon commonly associated?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Cricket.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Pelote?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No. Wimbledon is most commonly associated with tennis.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Of course! Now I see!

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Yes, it all falls into place!

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: The blancmangcs are really Australians trying to get the rights of the pelota rules from the Czech publishers!

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: No ... not quite ... but, er, just look in here.

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: Yes. So these blancmanges, blancmange-shaped creatures come from the planet Skyron in the Galaxy of Andromeda. They order 48,000,000 kilts from a Scottish menswear shop ... turn the population of England into Scotsmen (well known as the worst tennis-playing nation on Earth) thus leaving England empty ! Empty during Wimbledon fortnight ... what's more the papers are full of reports of blancmanges appearing on tennis courts up and down the country - . This can only mean one thing!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'THEY MEAN TO WIN WIMBLEDON'

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: They mean to !

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Well, here at Wimbledon, it's been a most extraordinary week's tennis. The blancmanges have swept the board, winning match after match. Here are just a few of the results: Billie-Jean King eaten in straight sets, Laver smothered whole after winning the first set, and Poncho Gonzales, serving as well as I've never seen him, with some superb volleys and decisive return volleys off the back hand, was sucked through the net at match point and swallowed whole in just under two minutes. And so, here on the final day, there seems to be no players left to challenge the blancmanges. And this could be their undoing, Dan: as the rules of Wimbledon state quite clearly that there must be at least one human being concerned in the final. Well the blancmange is coming out onto the pitch now, and there is a human with it. It's Angus Podgorny! The plucky little Scottish tailor ... upon whom everything depends. And so it's Podgorny versus blancmange in this first ever Intergalactic Wimbledon!

dialogue.speaker: Commentator's Voice
dialogue.text: And it's blancmange to serve and it's a good one.

dialogue.speaker: Blancmange Umpire
dialogue.text: Blurb blurble blurb.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Fifteen love.

dialogue.speaker: BLANCMANGE:
dialogue.text: 40 PODGORNY: 0

dialogue.speaker: Commentator's Voice
dialogue.text: And Podgorny fails to even hit the ball ... but this is no surprise as he hasn't hit the ball once throughout this match. So it's 72 match points to the blancmange now... Podgorny prepares to serve again.

dialogue.speaker: BLANCMANGE:
dialogue.text: 6 6 5 40 PODGORNY: 0 0

dialogue.speaker: Commentator's Voice
dialogue.text: This is indeed a grim day for the human race, Dan.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator's Voice
dialogue.text: But what's this? Two spectators have rushed onto the pitch with spoons and forks... what are they going to do?

dialogue.speaker: Charles
dialogue.text: They mean to eat the blancmange.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator's Voice
dialogue.text: And they're eating the blancmange ... Yes! The blancmange is leaving the court... it's abandoning the game! This is fantastic!

dialogue.speaker: American Voice
dialogue.text: Yes it was Mr and Mrs Samuel Brainsample, who, after only a brief and misleadling appearance in the early part of the film, returned to save the Earth ... but why?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Brainsample
dialogue.text: Oh, well you see we love blancmanges. My wife makes them.

dialogue.speaker: American Voice
dialogue.text: She makes blancmanages size?

dialogue.speaker: Mr Brainsample
dialogue.text: Oh, yes. You see we're from the planet Skyron in the Galaxy of Andromeda, and they're all that size there. We tried to tell you at the beginning of the film but you just panned off us.

dialogue.speaker: American Voice
dialogue.text: So the world was saved! And Angus Podgorny became the first Scotsman to win Wimbledon... fifteen years later.

annotations: A long hilly scar of land; on either side trees. The track comes straight down from the horizon to camera in valley. At the top of the hill we hear running and heavy breathing. The 'It's' man appears. He runs down the valley to camera but fails to say his line:
(prompting)
(finally)
By the miracle of money we swing into a fantastically expensive opening animation sequence, produced by one of America's very own drop-outs.
Then a girl in bed. Count Dracula enters. The girl reveals her neck. The vampire goes to kiss her but his fangs fall out.
A man at the yardarm being lashed.
Back to camel spotter.
(giggling)
Spotter gives him a dirty look. Knight in armour appears beside him. He hits interviewer with chicken.
(eagerly)
(in tears)
(crying)
(he leaves)
He goes over to a wall plaque 'There is no place for sentiment in Big Business'. He turns it over. On the back it says 'He's right you know'.
(to Chairman)
Camel Spotting man comes running in shouting.
(pointing at the bishop)
Shot of the bishop bound and gagged and tied across a railway line.
But he reads:
He reads over it:
Cut to Jewish figure.
Cut to a photo of a man with pipe.
Cut to redcoat.
Zoom through the galaxy to the solar system.
(very resonant)

Mix into close-up of railway station sign: 'New Pudsey'. Pull out to mid-shot of a couple walking towards camera. They are middle-aged. He (Graham) wears a cricket blazer and grey flannels and a carrier bag. She (Eric) wears a fussy print dress.
(gently)
(camera pans off them; they both look disappointed; camera picks up instead a smart little business man, in bowler, briefcase and pinstripes)

Weird electronic music. Sinister atmosphere. Follow him out of station. Cut-away to flying saucer, over day skyline. Back to Potter as he walks up suburban road. Back to flying saucer. It bleeps as if it has seen its prey and changes direction. Cut back to Potter just about to open his front gate. Shot from over the other side of the road. Cut to flying saucer sending down ray. Potter freezes . . . shivers and turns into a Scotsman with kilt, and red beard. His hand jerks out in front of him and he spins round and scuttles up road in fast motion, to the accompaniment of bagpipe music. Cut to close-up of newspaper with banner headline:
'Man turns into a Scotsman'.
Mix through to Potter's front gate. His wife is being interviewed by obvious plainclothes man.
(shocked)
(suddenly remembering)
(goes rigid: with Scots accent:)

The words are hardly out of his mouth when he turns into a Scotsman and spins round and disappears up road in fast motion. Pan with him. Cut to bus queue:
man in a city suit and bowler hat suddenly changes into a Scotsman with beard, twizzles round and speeds out of shot. Cut to street policeman pointing way for woman with a pram. Suddenly he changes into a Scotsman and scuffles out of shot. She looks aghast for a moment and then she too changes into a Scotsman and hurtles off after him. The baby suddenly develops a beard and the pram follows her. Single shot of black jazz musician in cellar blowing a blues sax solo. He changes and whizzes off. Squad of soldiers being drilled. Suddenly they all change into bearded Scotsmen and race off in unison. Pan with them past sign: 'Welsh Guard'.
Quick animated shot of flying saucer disappearing over city skyline.
Cut to big close-up of passionate kiss. It goes on for some moments. Foggy lens... romantic music. Keep on big close-up as they talk. She is none too intelligent.
(pull out to reveal they are in a laboratory; he is in a white coat, she is in something absurdly sexy)
(tentatively)
He presses a button on a control board and a laboratory TV screen lights op with the words 'only because they have no control over their own destinies'.

Zoom in on her face. Cut to as many bearded Scotsmen as possible, hurtling through wood in fast motion. Follow them, ending up with skyline shot as per 'Seventh Seal'. They all still have the arm outstretched in front of them and as always they are accompanied by bagpipe music. Shot of border with large notice: 'Scotland Welcomes You'.
They all dash across harder and then stop abruptly once they're over. They stand around looking lost.

Cut to three Scotsmen tossing one caber. Cut to Scots wife in bed with bearded husband. Pull back to reveal five other Scotsmen in the bed. Short but brilliant piece of animation from T. Gilliam to show England emptying of people and Scotland filling up, ending with a till sound and a till sign coming up out of England reading: 'Empty'. Track into England. Film of a deserted street. Wind, a dog sniffing, newspaper blowing along street. Close-up sign on shop door 'Gone to
Scotland'. Close-up another sign on a shop door.' 'McClosed'. Shop sign: McWoolworths & Co'.

Man suddenly folds up newspaper and runs round corner. Re-emerges driving bus. Drives it halfway to stop and then leaps out with bus still moving. Runs to stop, and puts out hand. Bus stops. He leaps on, rings bell, runs round to front and drives the bus off again. As bus drives out of frame we just see a couple of Scotsmen flashing past camera with arms outstretched. Pan slowly round empty football stadium. Eventually we pick up a solitary spectator, halfway up and halfway along in stand opposite where the players come out. He suddenly leaps to his feet cheering. Cut to players tunnel and one player emerging and a referee with ball. They kick off. Player goes straight down field and scores.
Spectator disapppointed.
A quick shot of flying saucer again.
Studio: the laboratory again. Charles is looking through microscope, when the door flies open and she bursts in.
(with an air of tremendous revelation)
A long pause as he waits expectantly.
(thrilling chord of jangling music and quick zoom into her face)
Crashing chord... cut to a small still of a Scottish crofier's cottage on a lonely moor. Slow zoom in on the cottage.
Mix to interior of highland menswear shop. An elderly Scottish couple are poring over a letter which they have on the counter. Oil lamps etc.
(calculates with abacus)
(with visionary look in his eyes)
Creepy music starts to edge in.
(narrowing eyes)
(sweating as the music rises)
Jarring chord.
Police station: a police sergeant is talking over the counter to a girl dressed in a short frilly tennis dress. She holds a racquet and tennis balls.
Cut back to Podgorny's shop. He and his wife are frozen in the positions in which we left them. They pick up the conversation as if nothing had happened.
(getting a little angry)
(brings out piece of folded paper from sporran)
Close-up on Angus.
(suddenly we hear a strange creaking and a slurping noise; a look of horror comes into his eyes)
Big close-up of Mrs Podgorny's eyes starting out from head.
Blur focus.
Cut to a desk for police spokesman. A peaked-capped policeman sits there, reading 'The Rise and Fall of the Roman Empire' by Googie Withers. He lowers book and talks chattily to camera.
He is hit on the head by knight in suit of armour with raw chicken.
Cut to CID office: a plainclothes detective is sitting in his office. Podgorny is sobbing.
(softly and understandingly)
He is sitting on the desk next to Podgorny. Podgorny with superhuman control makes a great effort to stop sobbing.
(slapping Podgorny)
(getting up and talking sharply and fast)
(detective brings out photograph of blancmange)
(with a squeak of fear)
Suddenly, we hear a strange noise. Angus looks frightened. Detective narrows his eyes and walks over to the door.
(he opens the door and we get a close-up of his staring eyes)
(with sudden fear)
Eating noises. He is dragged out of camera shot. Refocus on Angus ... he averts his eyes as we hear the detective inspector off-screen.
(off-screen)
Jarring chord: Angus shuts his eyes.
Cut back to laboratory: she is sitting suggestively on a stool. He is pacing up and down looking intense.
(testily)
She is thinking really hard.
(off-screen)
(heavily)

He indicates microscope. As she eagerly bends to look into it he picks up a sock filled with sand and without looking strikes her casually over the head with it. She collapses out of sight under desk. He continues to think out loud.
Flash up caption quickly:
(and CAPTION)
Cut to commentator in his box.
(we see a three-foot-high blancmange being shepherded onto a tennis court by a Scotsman)
(suddenly exalted)

Cut to the centre court at Wimbledon or if we can't get it, number one will do. Blancmange and Podgorny on opposite sides net. Another blancmange sitting in umpire's chair. Blancmange serves... a real sizzling ace. Podgorny, who in any case is quivering with fear, doesn't see it.
Blancmange serves again, and again Podgorny misses hopelessly and pathetically. Collage of speeded-up versions of blancmange sewing and Podgorny missing. Cut to scoreboard:
Cut back to the court. Podgorny is serving and each time he fails to hit the ball altogether.
Podgorny fails to serve and we see the scoreboard:
Just as Podgorny is about to serve we see Mr and Mrs Brainsample jump onto the court brandishing forks and spoons and with napkins tucked into their necks.
Cut to laboratory.
The girl pulls herself up from where she was slumped by microscope. He knocks her out again with a sand-filled sock. Cut back to Wimbledon. Mr and Mrs Brainsample chasing blancmange and eating it.
Cut to Mr and Mrs Brainsample covered in bits of blancmange and licking their fingers.
Cut back to Podgorny on court still trying to serve; at last he makes contact and runs backward and forward to receive his own services.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 6

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I thought you did that so well Mr Figgis, could I have your autograph?

dialogue.speaker: Figgis
dialogue.text: You certainly can

dialogue.speaker: Figgis
dialogue.text: Beethoven, Mozart, Chopin, Liszt, Brahms, Panties...I'm sorry...Schumann, Schubert, Mendelssohn and Bach. Names that will live for ever. But there is one composer whose name is never included with the greats. Why is it that the world never remembered the name of Johann Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm? To do justice to this man, thought by many to be the greatest name in German Baroque music, we present a profile of Johann Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm. We start with an interview with his only surviving relative Karl Gambolputty de von Ausfern...

dialogue.speaker: Karl
dialogue.text: Oh ja. When I first met Johann Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm, he was with his wife, Sarah Gambolputty de von...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, if I may just cut in on you there, Herr Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm, and ask you - just quickly - if there's any particular thing that you remember about Johann Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm?

dialogue.speaker: Figgis
dialogue.text: A tribute to Johann Gambolputty...

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: ...de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: ...crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle...

dialogue.speaker: Knight in Armour
dialogue.text: ...dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher...

dialogue.speaker: Mona Lisa
dialogue.text: ...apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic...

dialogue.speaker: Lon Chaney
dialogue.text: ...grander- knotty- spelltinkle...

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: ...grandlich...

dialogue.speaker: Pig
dialogue.text: ...grumblemeyer...

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: ...spelterwasser...

dialogue.speaker: Boar
dialogue.text: ...kurstlich- himbleeisen...

dialogue.speaker: Botticelli Lover
dialogue.text: ...bahnwagen- gutenabend...

dialogue.speaker: Medieval Couple
dialogue.text: ...bitte- ein- nürnburger...

dialogue.speaker: Family Group
dialogue.text: ...bratwustle...

dialogue.speaker: Doctor
dialogue.text: ...gerspurten...

dialogue.speaker: Bishop & Saint
dialogue.text: ...mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut...

dialogue.speaker: Two Dancers
dialogue.text: ...gumberaber- shönedanker...

dialogue.speaker: Three Naked Ladies
dialogue.text: ...kalbsfleisch...

dialogue.speaker: Cricket Team
dialogue.text: ...mittler- aucher...

dialogue.speaker: Policemen
dialogue.text: ...von Hautkopft...

dialogue.speaker: Figgis
dialogue.text: ...of Ulm.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: All clear?

dialogue.speaker: Fifth
dialogue.text: All clear, boss.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Right ... this is the plan then. At 10:45 .. you, Reg, collect me and Ken in the van, and take us round to the British Jewellery Centre in the High Street. We will arrive outside the British Jewellery Centre at 10:50 a of m. I shall then get out of the car, you Reg, take it and park it back here in Denver Street, right? At 10:51, I shall enter the British Jewellery Centre, where you, Vic, disguised as a customer, will meet me and hand me £5.18.3d. At 10:52, I shall approach the counter and purchase a watch costing £5.18.3d. I shall then give the watch to you, Vic. You'll go straight to Norman's Garage in East Street. You lads continue back up here at 10:56 and we rendezvous in the back room at the Cow and Sickle, at 11:15. All right, any questions?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: We don't seem to be doing anything illegal.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Well ... we're paying for the watch.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Yes...

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Well... why are we for the watch?

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: They wouldn't give it to us if we didn't for it, would they... eh?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Look! I don't like this outfit.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Well, we never break the bloody law.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: What d'you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Well, look at that bank job last week.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: What was wrong with that?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Well having to go in there with a mask on and ask for £15 out of my deposit account; that's what was wrong with it.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Listen! What are you trying to say, Larry?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Couldn't we just steal the watch, Boss

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Oh, you dumb cluck! We spent weeks organizing this job. Reg rented a room across the road and filmed the people going in and out every day. Vic spent three weeks looking at watch catalogues...until he knew the price of each one backwards, and now I'm not going to risk the whole raid just for the sake of breaking the law.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Urr... couldn't we park on a double yellow line?

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Couldn't we get a dog to foul the foot...

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: 'Ere, Boss!

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: I just thought... I left the car on a meter... and it's...

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Overdue?

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: Yes, Boss.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: How much?

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: I dunno, Boss... maybe two ... maybe five minutes ...

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Five minutes overdue. You fool! You fool! All right ... we've no time to lose. Ken - shave all your hair off, get your passport and meet me at this address in Rio de Janeiro Tuesday night. Vic - go to East Africa, have plastic surgery and meet me there. Reg - go to Canada and work your way south to Nicaragua by July. Larry - you stay here as front man. Give us fifteen minutes then blow the building up. All right, make it fast.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: I can't blow the building up.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: It's illegal.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Oh bloody hell. Well we'd better give ourselves up then.

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: We can't, Boss.

dialogue.speaker: Boss
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Reg
dialogue.text: We haven't done anything illegal.

dialogue.speaker: Bandit
dialogue.text: No I think being illegal makes it more exciting.

dialogue.speaker: Second Bandit
dialogue.text: Yes, I agree. I mean, if you're going to go straight you might as well be a vicar or something.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Chartered Accountant
dialogue.text: I agree. If there were fewer robbers there wouldn't be so many of them, numerically speaking.

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: I think sexual ecstasy is over-rated.

dialogue.speaker: Scotsman
dialogue.text: Well, how very interesting, because I'm now made entirely of tin.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: After a few more of these remarks, I shall be appearing in a sketch, so stay tuned.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: It's the uniform that puts them off, that and my bad breath.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: We like dressing up, yes...

dialogue.speaker: Inspector Praline
dialogue.text: Hello again. I am at present still on film, but in a few seconds I shall be appearing in the studio. Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Hello. Mr Milton? You are sole proprietor and owner of the Whizzo Chocolate Company?

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: I am.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Superintendent Parrot and I are from the hygiene squad.We want to have a word with you about your box of chocolates entitled the Whizzo Quality Assortment.

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: Ah, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: If I may begin at the beginning. First there is the Cherry Fondue. This is extremely nasty, but we can't prosecute you for that.

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: Agreed.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Next we have number four, 'Crunchy Frog'.

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: An, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Am I right in thinking there's a real frog in here?

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: Yes. A little one.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: What sort of frog?

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: A dead frog.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Is it cooked?

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: What, a raw frog?

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: We use only the finest baby frogs, dew-picked and flown from Iraq, cleansed in the finest quality spring water, lightly killed, and then sealed in a succulent Swiss quintuple smooth treble cream milk chocolate envelope, and lovingly frosted with glucose.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: That's as may be, but it's still a frog!

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: What else?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Well don't you even take the bones out?

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: If we took the bones out it wouldn't be crunchy would it?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Superintendent Parrot ate one of those.

dialogue.speaker: Parrot
dialogue.text: Excuse me a moment.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Well, the Superintendent thought it was an almond whirl. People won't expect there to be a frog in there. They're bound to think it's some sort of mock frog.

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: Mock frog? We use no artificial preservatives or additives of any kind!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Nevertheless, I must warn you that in future you should delete the words 'crunchy frog', and replace them with the legend, 'crunchy raw unboned real dead frog' if you want to avoid prosecution.

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: What about our sales?

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: I'm not interested in your sales! I have to protect the general public! Now what about this one. It was number five, wasn't it? Number five Ram's Bladder Cup. What sort of confection is this?

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: We use choicest juicy chunks of fresh Cornish ram's bladder, emptied, steamed, flavoured with sesame seeds, whipped into a fondue and garnished with lark's vomit.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Larks vomit?

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: Correct.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Well it don't say nothing about that here.

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: Oh yes it does, on the bottom of the box, after monosodium glutamate.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Wel I hardly think this is good enough. I think it's be more appropriate if the box bore a great red label warning lark's vomit.

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: Our sales would plummet!

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text:
Well why don't you move into more conventional areas of confectionary,
like praline or lime cream; a very popular flavor, I'm lead to understand. I mean look at this one 'cockroach cluster', anthrax ripple! What's this one: 'spring surprise'?

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: Ah - now, that's our speciality - covered with darkest creamy chocolate. When you pop it into your mouth steel bolts spring out and plunge straight through both cheeks.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Well where's the pleasure in that? If people place a nice chocky in their mouth, they don't want their cheeks pierced. In any case this is an inadequate description of the sweetmeat. I shall have to ask you to accompany me to the station.

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: It's a fair cop.

dialogue.speaker: Praline
dialogue.text: Stop talking to the camera.

dialogue.speaker: Milton
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Parrot
dialogue.text: If only the general public would take more care when buying its sweeties, it would reduce the number of man-hours lost to the nation and they would spend less time having their stomachs pumped and sitting around in public lavatories.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: The BBC would like to apologize for the extremely poor quality of the next announcement, only he's not at all well.

dialogue.speaker: Parrot
dialogue.text: We present 'The Dull Life of a City Stockbroker',

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: Me heap want see play. Me want play start heap soon.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes well. I think it ... begins in a minute.

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: Me heap big fan Cicely Courtneidge.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes ... she's very good.

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: She fine actress ... she make interpretation heap subtle ... she heap good diction and timing ... she make part really live for Indian brave.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes ... yes ... she's marvelous...

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: My father - Chief Running Stag - leader of mighty Redfoot tribe - him heap keen on Michael Denison and Dulcie Gray.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Do you go to the theatre a lot?

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: When moon high over prairie ... when wolf howl over mountain, when mighty wind roar through Yellow Valley, we go Leatherhead Rep - block booking, upper circle - whole tribe get it on 3/6d each.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: That's very good.

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: Stage Manager, Stan Wilson, heap good friend Redfoot tribe. After show we go pow-wow speakum with director, Sandy Camp, in snug bar of Bell and Compasses. Him mighty fine director. Him heap famous.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh - I don't know him myself.

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: Him say Leatherhead Rep like do play with Redfoot tribe.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh that's good...

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: We do 'Dial M for Murder'. Chief Running Elk - him kill buffalo with bare hands, run thousand paces when the sun is high - him play Chief Inspector Hardy - heap good fine actor.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You do a lot of acting do you?

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: Yes. Redfoot tribe live by acting and hunting.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: You don't fight any more?

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: Yes! Redfoot make war! When Chief Yellow Snake was leader, and Mighty Eagle was in land of forefather, we fight Pawnee at Oxbow Crossing. When Pawnee steal our rehearsal copies of 'Reluctant Debutante' we kill fifty Pawnee - houses heap full every night. Heap good publicity.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I think he's about to start now, thank God for that.

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: Paleface like eat chocolate?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: Indian
dialogue.text: Hmmm - crunchy frog - heap good.

dialogue.speaker: House Manager
dialogue.text: Ladies and gentlemen. Before the play starts, I would like to apologize to you all, but unfortunately Miss Cicely Courtneidge is unable to appear, owing to...

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: (Ian Davidson) What's that dear?

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: There's been another Indian massacre at Dorking Civic Theatre.

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: About time too dear...

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: 'Those who were left alive at the end got their money back'.

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: That's what live theatre needs - a few more massacres...

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: 'The police are anxious to speak to anyone who saw the crime, ladies with large breasts, or just anyone who likes policemen.'

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Yes! Policemen make wonderful friends. So if you are over six feet tall and would like a friend, a pen friend, in the police force, here is the address to write to: 'Mrs Ena Frog, 8 Masonic Apron Street, Cowdenbeath'. Remember - policemen make wonderful friends. So write today and take advantage of our free officer. Thank you. And now for the next sketch.

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: A Scotsman on a horse.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: For Mrs Emma Hamilton of Nelson, a Scotsman on a horse.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Good morning boys.

dialogue.speaker: Writers
dialogue.text: Good morning Mr Saltzberg.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Sit down! Sit down! Sit down! Sit down! Now, boys, I want you to know that I think you are the best six writers in movies today. I want you to know that I've had an idea for the next movie I'm going to produce and I want you boys to write it.

dialogue.speaker: Writers
dialogue.text: Thank you. Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Oh sit down! Sit down! Sit down! There'll be plenty of time for that later on. Now boys, here's my idea...

dialogue.speaker: Third Writer
dialogue.text: It's great!

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: You like it huh?

dialogue.speaker: Writers
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, great! Really great. Fantastic.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Do like it?

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: Yeah! Er ... yeah.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: What do you like about it?

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: Oh well you haven't told us... what it is yet...

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: WHAT!?

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: I like what he likes.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: What do you like?

dialogue.speaker: Second Writer
dialogue.text: I like what he likes.

dialogue.speaker: Third Writer
dialogue.text: I like what he likes.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Writer
dialogue.text: I like what he likes

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Writer
dialogue.text: I just crazy about what he likes

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: What do you like?

dialogue.speaker: Sixth Writer
dialogue.text: (Ian Davidson) I ... I ... I ... agree with them.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Good! Now we're getting somewhere. Now, here's the start of the movie ... I see snow! White snow!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Writer
dialogue.text: Think of the colours!

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: And in the snow, I see ... a tree!

dialogue.speaker: Writers
dialogue.text: Yes! Yes!

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Wait, wait I haven't finished yet.

dialogue.speaker: Third Writer
dialogue.text: There's ?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: And by this tree, gentlemen, I see ... a dog!

dialogue.speaker: Writers
dialogue.text: Olé!

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: And gentlemen, this dog goes up to the tree, and he piddles on it.

dialogue.speaker: Writers
dialogue.text: Hallelujah!

dialogue.speaker: Sixth Writer
dialogue.text: Have we got a movie!

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Writer
dialogue.text: He tells it the way it is!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Writer
dialogue.text: It's where it's at!

dialogue.speaker: Third Writer
dialogue.text: This is something else!

dialogue.speaker: Second Writer
dialogue.text: It's out of sight!

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: I like it, I like it.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Oh yeah?

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, I I like it

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Writer
dialogue.text: Sir, I don't know how to say this but I got to be perfectly frank. I really and truly believe this story of yours is the greatest story in motion-picture history.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Get out!

dialogue.speaker: Fifth Writer
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: If there's one thing I can't stand, it's a yes-man! Get out! I'll see you never work again. What do you think?

dialogue.speaker: Sixth Writer
dialogue.text: Well... I...

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Just because I have an idea it doesn't mean it's great. It could be lousy.

dialogue.speaker: Sixth Writer
dialogue.text: It could?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Yeah! What d'ya think?

dialogue.speaker: Sixth Writer
dialogue.text: It's lousy.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: There you are, you see, he spoke his mind. He said my idea was lousy. It just so happens my idea isn't lousy so get out you goddam pinko subversive, get out! You...

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Writer
dialogue.text: Well ... I think it's an excellent idea.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Are you a yes-man?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Writer
dialogue.text: No, no, no, I mean there may be things against it.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: You think it's lousy, huh?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Writer
dialogue.text: No, no, I mean it takes time.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Are you being indecisive?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Writer
dialogue.text: Yo. Nes. Perhaps.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: I hope you three gentlemen aren't going to be indecisive! What the hell are you doing under that table?

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: We dropped our pencils.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Pencil droppers, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Writers
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no!

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Right. Now I want your opinion of my idea ... You...

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: Oh...

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Has he had a heart attack?

dialogue.speaker: Second and Third Writers
dialogue.text: Er...

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: If there's one thing I can't stand, it's people who have heart attacks.

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: I feel fine now.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Well, what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: Writers
dialogue.text: Oh! Eh! You didn't ask me you asked him. He didn't ask me, he asked him. No, him.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: I've changed my mind. I'm asking you, the one in the middle.

dialogue.speaker: Second Writer
dialogue.text: The one in the middle?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Yes, the one in the middle. Hello, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, Dimitri ... What the hell are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: Second Writer
dialogue.text: I'm thinking.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Get back in those seats immediately. Yes... Right you. The one in the middle, what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: Second Writer
dialogue.text: Er... er...

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Come on!

dialogue.speaker: Second Writer
dialogue.text: Splunge.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Did he say splunge?

dialogue.speaker: First and Third Writers
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: What does splunge mean?

dialogue.speaker: Second Writer
dialogue.text: It means ... it's a great-idea-but-possibly-not-and-I'm-not-being-indecisive!

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Good. Right . .. What do you think?

dialogue.speaker: Third Writer
dialogue.text: Er. Splunge?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: OK...

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: Yeah. Splunge for me too.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: So all three of you think splunge, huh?

dialogue.speaker: Writers
dialogue.text: Yes!

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Well now we're getting somewhere. No, wait. A new angle! In the snow, instead of the tree, I see Rock Hudson, and instead of the dog I see Doris Day and, gentlemen, Doris Day goes up to Rock Hudson and she kisses him. A love story. Intercourse Italian style. David Hemmings as a hippy Gestapo officer. Frontal nudity. A family picture. A comedy. And then when Doris Day's kissed Rock Hudson she says something funny like...

dialogue.speaker: Third Writer
dialogue.text: Er ... Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: Doris Day's a comedienne, not a newsreader. Get out! She says something funny like

dialogue.speaker: Second Writer
dialogue.text: Splunge?

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: That's the stupidest idea I ever heard. Get out! Doris Dog kisses Rock Tree and she says

dialogue.speaker: First Writer
dialogue.text: Er... er... er... I can't take it anymore.

dialogue.speaker: Larry
dialogue.text: I like that! I like that, I can't take it any more, and then Rock Hudson says 'I'm a very rich film producer and I need a lobotomy' and then Doris Dog says 'I think you're very handsome and I'm going to take all my clothes off' and then Doris Dog turns into a yak and goes to the bathroom on David Lemming. No, wait, wait! Hello, hello, hello, who are you? You're an out-of-work writer? Well, you're fired. Roll the credits. Produced by Irving C. Saltzberg Jnr. of Irving C. Saltzberg Productions Ltd. and Saltzberg Art Films, Oil, Real Estate, Banking and Prostitution Inc.

annotations: In the foreground we see a telephone. In the very distant background we see the 'It's' man. The telephone starts to ring. The 'It's' man runs towards the camera and the telephone (speeded up). He arrives at the telephone, picks up the reciever and is about to speak into the mouthpiece when he remembers the camera. He puts his hand over the mouthpiece and says to the camera:
He returns to the reciever.
Animated opening titles.
Cut to presenter in studio.
Lose caption. Pause.
(rushing in)
Presenter sign autograph. Part of his signature gets away (animation) and eventually leads us into the title: 'It's the Arts'. Classical music plays.
(fades out)
Cut to old man sitting blanketed, in wheel-chair, as he speaks, intercut with shot of interviewer nodding and looking interested.
(as he speaks intercut with shots of Karl nodding and trying to look interested)
No response. He shakes the old man, then gets up and listens to his heart. Realizing with exasperation that his interviewee has died, he starts digging a grave. Cut back to presenter.
Cut to Viking.
Cut to weedy man in pullover with National Health specs.
Cut to knight in armour.
Cut to a succession of animated characters.
leading to: A garret room with a bare table. Around it are grouped four desperate-looking robbers. The Boss has a rolled-up map. One of the gang, the fifth, is looking out of the window.
(unfolding big map across table; talking carefuly)
(patiently)
(hesitating)
(heavily)
(at last feeling free to say what's on his mind)
General consternation.
(suddenly going pale)
(quaking)
Cut to film. Exterior of bank. Three bandits rush out with swag etc. One of them stops to talk to camera raising mask off head.
Cut to vicar, wheeling quickly round to reveal he has his hand in the restoration-fund box.
Cut to chartered accountant.
Cut to pepperpot.
Cut to Scotsman.
Cut to Police Inspector Praline.
Cut to policeman.
Cut to judge in full long wig and robes and a QC also wearing wig and robes.
(matter of factly)
Cut to Inspector Praline.
Cut to studio. A door opens. Inspector Praline looks round door.
(to camera)
(he walks in followed by Superintendent Parrot and goes to desk)
(producing box of chocolate)
Superintendent Parrot looks increasingly queasy.
(exits hurriedly)
(insulted)
(superintendent enters)
(superintendent nods)
(exit superintendent)
(looking)
(superintendent enters)
(superintendent exits)
(getting up from the desk and being led away)
Supeintendent Parrot enters the room as Inspector Praline and Milton leave, and addresses the camera.

Cut to a nice suburban street. Inside the house a stockbroker (Michael) is finishing his breakfast. His attractive wife looks on. He picks up his hat, rises, kisses her goodbye, and leaves. As he does so, she takes off her wrap and two men dressed only in briefs (Graham and Terry J) step out of the kitchen cupboard. In the front garden the stockbroker bids his neighbour (Graham) good morning; as he moves off a large African native throws an assegai, killing the neighbour. The stockbroker, not noticing this, moves on. A high street: he walks into a newsagents. Behind the counter a naked young lady gives him his newspaper. Taking his change without apparently noticing her he leaves. A bus queue: the stockbroker is at the head of it; there are four people behind him. As they wait, the Frankenstein monster comes up behind them and works his way along the queue, killing each member as he goes. He has just reached the stockbroker - who has not seen him - when the bus arrives and the stockbroker gets on. On the bus: all the other passengers are uniformed soldiers. The bus drives along a road past explosions and gunfire. A hand grenade comes through the window and lands on the seat next to the stockbroker. The soldiers leave the bus rapidly; the stockbroker calmly leaves the bus and walks down the street, in which the soldiers are engaged in a pitched battle. The stockbroker hails a taxi; it stops. No driver is visible. The stockbroker gets in and it drives off. In the stockbroker's office: a secretary is dead across her typewriter with a knife in her back; at the back of the office a pair of legs swing gently from the ceiling; a couple are snogging at his desk. Unconcerned, the stockbroker sits down. Furtively he looks round, then takes from the desk drawer a comic-book entitled 'Thrills and Adventure'. We see the frames of the comic strip. A Superman-type character and a girl are shrinking from an explosion. She is saying 'My God, his nose just exploded with enough force to destroy his kleenex'. In the next frame, the Superman character is saying 'If only I had a kleenex to lend him - or even a linen handkerchief - but these trousers...!! No back pocket!' In the frame beneath, he flies from side to side attempting to escape; finally he breaks through, bringing the two frames above down on himself. Cut to a picture of a safety curtain. An animated man come in front of it and says:

The front stalls of a theatre. It is a first night - a lot of people in dinner jackets etc. About three rows back there is a spare seat. A general rustle of programmes, chocolates and theatrical murmurs. Suddenly a Sioux Indian enters, clad only in loin cloth, wearing war paint and with a single strip of hair in the middle of his head and feather. He carries a bow and a quiver of arrows. He settles into the empty seat. The man next to him shifts uneasily and looks straight ahead. The Indian looks his neighbour up and down a couple of times.
(always speaking with full gestures)
Man next to him nods.
(highly embarrassed)
(unwillingly drawn in)
The lights start to dim. Auditorium chatter subsides.
(visibly relieved)
They both look towards stage. The overture starts.
(leaning across)
(proffers box)
(helping himself)
Cut to stage, house manager walks out in front of tabs. He is a very nice young man.

He is suddenly struck in the chest by first one arrow and then another. He crumbles to the ground revealing half a dozen in his back. The air is filled with war-whoops and drum beats and screams. Cut to a working-class kitchen.
(reading newspaper)
Suddenly a policeman walks in between the couple and the camera.
(to camera)
The policeman removes his helmet, shakes it, proffers it to mum at the table. She takes out a small folded bit of paper, opens and reads.

A Scotsman (John) rides up to the camera and looks around puzzled. In long-shot we see him riding off. At a wee Scottish kirk another Scotsman (Michael) is waiting at the head of the aisle to be married. Intercut between first Scotsman galloping through the countryside and the wedding procession coming up the aisle. The wedding takes place; just as it finishes the first Scotsman rides up to the kirk and rushes in. The assembled congregation look at him in alarm as he surveys them; then he picks up Michael and carries him off. Cut to film of Women's Institute audience applauding.

which leads us to the 'Twentieth Century Vole' trademark. Cut to film producer's office. Six writers sitting round a table with one very impressive chair empty at the head of the table. They wait reverently. Suddenly the door of the room flies open and Larry Saltzberg, the film producer, walks in. The writers leap to their feet.
They run to help him into his chair.
(sitting)
(the writers are overcome)
The writers run and kiss him.
(he looks round the table)
(catching on fast)
(first writer is the only one not having an orgasm about the idea)
(to first writer)
(thrown)
(still to first writer)
(pointing at second writer)
(pointing at third writer)
(pointing at fourth writer)
(pointing at fifth writer)
(pointing at sixth writer)
(writers applaud)
(applauding)
(finding Larry staring at him)
(suspicious)
(fifth writer leaves very fast, the others go very quiet)
(to sixth writer)
(sixth writer exits)
(looking straight at fourth writer)
(really threatening)
(runs out)
(they try to hide under the table)
(pointing at first writer)
(quaking)
First writer looks around and then faints.
(recovering immediately)
(the phone rings)
(all jockey for position desperately trying to put the others in the middle and finish sitting on one chair)
(back to phone)
(second writer is grabbed by the others and held in the middle chair; Larry finishes with the phone)
(panic)
(to third writer)
(looks at third writer)
(third writer runs)
(looks at second writer)
(second writer leaves)
(looks at first writer)
(runs out)
(picks up phone)
(cut to 'It's' man film with Larry continuing voice over)
(here the credits do start to roll with Larry's voice continuing over)
The credits read:
The technical credits continue in the same style.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 5

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS'

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: Oh good, that'll be the Vet, dear.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: I'd better go and let him in.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: It's the Vet, dear.

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: Oh very glad indeed you could come round, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Vet
dialogue.text: Not at all. Now what seems to be the problem? You can tell me - I'm a Vet, you know.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: See! Tell him, dear.

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: Well...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: It's our cat. He doesn't do anything. He just sits out there on the lawn.

dialogue.speaker: Vet
dialogue.text: Is he ... dead?

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: Oh, no!

dialogue.speaker: Vet
dialogue.text: Thank God for that. For one ghastly moment I thought I was... too late. If only more people would call in the nick of time.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: He just sits there, all day and every day.

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: And at night.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: Sh! Almost motionless. We have to take his food out to him.

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: And his milk.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: Sh! He doesn't do anything. He just sits there.

dialogue.speaker: Vet
dialogue.text: Are you at your wits' end?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: Definitely, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Vet
dialogue.text: Hm. I see. Well I think I may be able to help you. You see ... ... your cat is suffering from what we Vets haven't found a word for. His condition is typified by total physical inertia, absence of interest in its ambience - what we Vets call environment - failure to respond to the conventional external stimuli - a ball of string, a nice juicy mouse, a bird. To be blunt, your cat is in a rut. It's the old stockbroker syndrome, the suburban fin de siecle ennui, angst, weltschmertz, call it what you will.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: Moping.

dialogue.speaker: Vet
dialogue.text: In a way, in a way ... hum ... moping, I must remember that. Now, what's to be done? Tell me sir, have you confused your cat recently?

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: Well we ...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: Sh! No.

dialogue.speaker: Vet
dialogue.text: Yes ... well I think I can definitely say that your cat badly needs to be confused.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: Sh! What?

dialogue.speaker: Vet
dialogue.text: Confused. To shake it out of its state of complacency. I'm afraid I'm not personally qualified to confuse cats, but I can recommend an extremely good service. Here is their card.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: Oooh. 'Confuse-a-Cat Limited'.

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: 'Confuse-a-Cat Limited'.'

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Squad! Eyes front! Stand at ease. Cat confusers ...shun!

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Well men, we've got a pretty difficult cat to confuse today so let's get straight on with it. Jolly good. Thank you sergeant.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Confusers attend to the van and fetch out... wait for it... fetch out the funny things. Move, move, move. One, two, one, two, get those funny things off.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Stage ready for confusing, sir!

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Very good. Carry on, sergeant.

dialogue.speaker: Sergeant
dialogue.text: Left turn, double march!

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: Right men, confuse the ... cat!

dialogue.speaker: Long John Silver
dialogue.text: My lords, ladies and Gedderbong.

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: I hope to God it works. Anyway, we shall know any minute now.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: I can't believe it.

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: Neither can I. It's just like the old days.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs B
dialogue.text: Then he's cured. Oh thank you, general.

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text: What can we ever do to repay you?

dialogue.speaker: General
dialogue.text: No need to, sir. It's all in a day's work for 'Confuse-a-Cat'.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Have you read this, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No! Oh, yes, yes - yes.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Anything to declare?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes ... no! No! No! No! Nothing to declare, no, nothing in my suitcase no...

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: No watches, cameras, radio sets?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh yes ... four watches ... no, no, no. No. One... one watch...No, no. Not even one watch. No, no watches at all. No, no watches at all. No precision watches, no.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Which country have you been visiting, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Switzerland ... er ... no ... no ... not Switzerland ... er ... not Switzerland, it began with S but it wasn't Switzerland... oh what could it be? Terribly bad memory for names. What's the name of that country where they don't make watches at all?

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Spain?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Spain! That's it. Spain, yes, mm.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: The label says 'Zurich', sir.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes well ... it Spain then.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Zurich's in Switzerland, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Switzerland, yes mm ... mm ... yes.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Switzerland - where they make the watches.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, nice shed you've got here.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Have you, er, got any Swiss currency, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No... just the watches... er just my watch, er, my watch on the currency... I've kept a watch on the currency, and I've watched it and I haven't got any.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: That came out a bit glib didn't it? Have you got an alarm clock in there, sir?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, no, heavens no, no... just vests.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Sounded a bit like an alarm going off.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well it can't have been... it must be a vest, er, going off.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Going off?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: All right, I confess, I'm a smuggler ... This whole case is crammed full of Swiss watches and clocks. I've been purposely trying to deceive Her Majesty's Customs and Excise. I've been a bloody fool.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: I don't believe you, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: It's true. I'm, er, guilty of smuggling.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Don't give me that, sir ... you couldn't smuggle a piece of greaseproof paper let alone a case full of watches.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What do you mean! I've smuggled watches before, you know! I've smuggled bombs, cameras, microfilms, aircraft components, you name it - I've smuggled it.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Now come along please, you're wasting our time... move along please.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Look! Look - look at this.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Look, for all I know, sir, you could've bought these in London before you ever went to Switzerland.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What? I wouldn't buy two thousand clocks.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: People do, now close your case move along please come on. Don't waste our time, we're out to catch the real smugglers. Come on.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I am a real smuggler. I'm a smuggler! Don't you understand, I'm a smuggler, a lawbreaker... a smuggler.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: Poor fellow. I think he needs help.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Right, cut the wisecracks, vicar. Get to the search room, and strip.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Well to discuss the implications of that sketch and to consider the moral problems raised by the law-enforcement methods involved we have a duck, a cat and a lizard. Now first of all I'd like to put this question to you please, lizard. How effective do you consider the legal weapons employed by legal customs officers, nowadays? Well while you're thinking about that, I'd like to bring the duck in here, and ask her, if possible, to clarify the whole question of currency restrictions, and customs regulations in the world today. Perhaps the cat would rather answer that? No? Lizard? No. Well, er, let's ask the man in the street what he thinks.

dialogue.speaker: French Au Pair
dialogue.text: I am not a man you silly billy.

dialogue.speaker: Man on Roof
dialogue.text: I'm not in the street you fairy.

dialogue.speaker: Man in Street
dialogue.text: Well, er, speaking a man in the street... Wagh!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What was the question again?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Just how relevant are contemporary customs regulations and currency restrictions in a modern expanding industrial economy? Oh never mind.

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Well I think customs men should be armed, so they can kill people carrying more than two hundred cigarettes.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well I, I think that, er, nobody who has gone abroad should be allowed back in the country. I mean, er, blimey, blimey if they're not keen enough to stay here when they're 'ere, why should we allow them back, er, at the tax-payers' expense? I mean, be fair, I mean, I don't eat squirrels do I? I mean well perhaps I do one or two but there's no law against that, is there? It's a free country. I mean if I want to eat a squirrel now and again, that's me own business, innit? I mean, I'm no racialist. I, oh, oh...

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: I think it's silly to ask a lizard what it thinks, anyway.

dialogue.speaker: Chairman
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: I mean they should have asked Margaret Drabble.

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Well I think, er, customs people are quite necessary, and I think they're doing quite a good job really. Check.

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Door's open.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Oh. Yes. All right. All right, all right, all right. My name's Police Constable Henry Thatcher, and this is a raid. I have reason to believe that there are certain substances on the premises.

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Well what sort of substances, officer?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Er... certain substances.

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Well, what sort of certain substances?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Er, certain substances of an illicit nature.

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Er, could you be more specific?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Could you be 'clearer'.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Oh, oh ... yes, er ... certain substances on the premises. To be removed for clinical tests.

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Have you got anything patiticular in mind?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Well what have you got?

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Nothing, officer.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: You are Sandy Camp the actor?

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: I must warn you, sir, that outside I have police dog Josephine, who is not only armed, and trained to sniff out certain substances, but is also a junkie.

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: What are you after ... ?

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Oo! Oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh! Here is a brown paper bag I have found on the premises. I must confiscate this, sir, and take it with me for clinical examination.

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Wait a minute. You just got that out of your pocket.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Young Man
dialogue.text: Well what's in it anyway? Sandwiches.

dialogue.speaker: Policeman
dialogue.text: Sandwiches? Blimey. Whatever did I give the wife?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear BBC, East Grinstead, Friday. I feel I really must write and protest about that sketch. My husband, in common with a lot of people of his age, is fifty. For how long are we to put up with these things. Yours sincerely, E. B. Debenham (Mrs).

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Dear Freddy Grisewood, Bagshot, Surrey. As a prolific letter-writer, I feel I must protest about the previous letter. I am nearly sixty and am quite mad, but I do enjoy listening to the BBC Home Service. If this continues to go on unabated ...Dunkirk... dark days of the war... backs to the wall... Alvar Liddell ... Berlin air lift ... moral upheaval of Profumo case ... young hippies roaming the streets, raping, looting and killing. Yours etc., Brigadier Arthur Gormanstrop (Mrs).

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Well I think they should attack things, like that - with satire. I mean Ned Sherrin. Fair's fair. I think people should be able to make up their own minds for me.

dialogue.speaker: Woman Journalist
dialogue.text: Well I think they should attack the fuddy-duddy attitudes of the lower middle classes which permit the establishment to survive and keep the mores of the whole country back where they were in the nineteenth century and the ghastly days of the pre-sexual revolution.

dialogue.speaker: Scotsman
dialogue.text: Well that's, er, very interesting, because, er, I am, in fact, made entirely of wood.

dialogue.speaker: Stockbroker
dialogue.text: Well I think they should attack the lower classes, er, first with bombs, and rockets destroying their homes, and then when they run helpless into the streets, er, mowing them down with machine guns. Er, and then of course releasing the vultures. I know these views aren't popular, but I have never courted popularity.

dialogue.speaker: Boy
dialogue.text: I think there should be more race prejudice.

dialogue.speaker: Voice
dialogue.text: Less.

dialogue.speaker: Boy
dialogue.text: Less race prejudice.

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text: ... and several butchers aprons. In Fulham this morning a jeweller's shop was broken into and jewellery to the value of £2,000 stolen. Police have issued this picture of a man they wish to interview. The man is in his late twenties wearing a grey suit, a white shirt and a floral tie. Will anyone who sees this man or can give any information about his whereabouts contact their nearest policestation. Ah! Oh. We've just heard that police have detained the man they wished to interview in connection with the jewel robbery. Ah, but after questioning police have ruled him out of their enquiries and released him. Sport. Ah, they say, however, that acting on his information they now wish to interview a newsreader in the central London area. Ah, police are concentrating their enquiries on the British Broadcasting Corp ... Excuse me a minute...

dialogue.speaker: Other Newsreader
dialogue.text: We understand a man is now helping police with their enquiries. And that is the end of the news. And now, 'Match of the Day'.

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text: Ah, I, Um terribly sorry it's not in fact 'Match of the Day'-, it is in fact edited highlights of tonight's romantic movie. Er. Sorry. Ooh, I'm sorry, on BBC2 Joan Bakewell will be talking to Michael Dean about what makes exciting television. Ah, sorry about all that. And now back to the movie.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh, oh, oh Bevis, should we?

dialogue.speaker: Bevis
dialogue.text: Oh Dora. Why not?

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Be gentle with me.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh Bevis, are you going to anything or are you just going to show me films all evening?

dialogue.speaker: Bevis
dialogue.text: Just one more, dear.

dialogue.speaker: She
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: You know I really enjoy interviewing applicants for this management training course. Come in. Ah. Come and sit down.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Would you mind just standing up again for one moment. Take a seat.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Take a seat. Ah! Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Tell me why did you say 'good morning' when you know perfectly well that it's afternoon?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Well, well, you said 'good morning'. Ha, ha.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Good afternoon.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Ah, good afternoon.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Oh dear. Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: ... Goodbye?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Ha, ha. No. ... Aren't you going to ask me why I rang the bell?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Er why did you ring the bell?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
