dialogue.text: Why do you think I rang the bell? Five, four, three, two, one, zero!

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Well, I, I...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Too late! Goodnight, ding-ding-ding-ding-ding. Goodnight. Ding-ding-ding-ding-ding-ding-ding.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Um. Oh this is, is the interview for the management training course is it?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes. Yes it is. Goodnight. Ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Oh. Oh dear, I don't think I'm doing very well.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Why do you say that?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Well I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Do you say it because you didn't know?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Well. I, I, I, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Five, four, three, two, one, zero! Right!

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, I'm confused.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well why do you think I did that then?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Well I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Aren't you curious?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Well yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well, why didn't you ask me?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Well...I...er...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Name?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Your name man, your name!

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Um, er David.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: David. Sure?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Oh yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: David Shaw.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: No, no Thomas.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Thomas Shaw?

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: No, no, David Thomas.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Goodnight. Ding-ding-ding-ding-ding- ding-ding-ding. Goodnight. Ding-ding-ding-ding-ding-ding-ding-ding-ding.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Oh dear we're back to that again. I don't know what to do when you do that.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well do something. Goodnight. Ding-ding-ding-ding-ding, five, four, three, two, one . . . Good!

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Good?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Very good - do it again. Very good indeed, quite outstanding. Ah right. Ready now. Right, once more. Goodnight, ding-ding-ding-ding-ding-ding.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: What's going on? What's going on?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: You've got very good marks.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Well I don't care, I want to know what's going on! I think you're deliberately trying to humiliate people, and I'm going straight out of here and I'm going to tell the police exactly what you do to people and I'm going to make bloody sure that you never do it again. There, what do you think of that? What do you think of that?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: good marks.

dialogue.speaker: Stig
dialogue.text: Oh, oh well, do I get the job?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, well, I'm afraid not. I'm afraid all the vacancies were filled several weeks ago.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well that was all good fun, and we all had a jolly good laugh, but I would like to assure you that you'd never be treated like that if you had an interview here at the Careers Advisory Board. Perhaps I should introduce myself. I am the Head of the Careers Advisory Board. I wanted to be a doctor, but there we are, I'm Head of the Careers Advisory Board. Or a sculptor, something artistic, or an engineer, with all those dams, but there we are, it's no use crying over split milk, the facts are there and that's that. I'm the Head of this lousy Board. Never mind, now I wonder if you've ever considered what a very profitable line of work this man is in.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Burglar! Burglar!

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Burglar, madam.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I want to come in and steal a few things, madam.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Are you an encydopaedia salesman?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No madam, I'm a burglar, I burgle people.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: I think you're an encyclopaedia salesman.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh I'm not, open the door, let me in please.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: If I let you in you'll sell me encyclopaedias.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I won't, madam. I just want to come in and ransack the flat. Honestly.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: Promise. No encyclopaedias?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: None at all.

dialogue.speaker: Woman
dialogue.text: All right. You'd better come in then.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Mind you I don't know whether you've really considered the advantages of owning a really fine set of modern encyclopaedias... You know, they can really do you wonders.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: That man was a successful encyclopaedia salesman. But not all encyclopaedia salesmen are successful. Here is an unsuccessful encyclopaedia salesman.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Now here are two unsuccessful encyclopaedia salesmen.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: I think there's a lesson there for all of us.

annotations: A river. The 'It's' man rows towards the camera and announces:
(and CAPTION:)
Title animation.
Elderly couple, Mr A and Mrs B are staring through french windows at a cat that is sitting in the middle of their lawn motionless and facing away from them. A car is heard drawing up.
Mrs B goes out and comes back into the room with the Vet.
(stage whisper)
(to camera dramaticaly)
(he goes over to armchair, puts on spectacles, sits, crosses legs and puts finger tips together)
(reading card)

Cut to large van arriving. On one side is a large sign readling 'Confuse-a-Cat Limited:
Europe's leading cat-confusing service. By appointment to...' and a crest. Several people get out of the van, dressed in white coats, with peaked caps and insignia. One of them has a sergeant's stripes.
From a following car a general alights.
(the men unload the van)
The workmen are completing the erection of a proscenium with curtains in front of the still immobile cat. A and B watch with awe. The arrangements are completed. All stand ready.

Drum roll and cymbals. The curtains draw back and an amazing show takes place, using various tricks:
locked camera, fast motion, jerky motion, jump cuts, some pixilated motion etc. Long John Silver walks to front of stage.

Long John Silver disappears. A pause. Two boxers appear. They circle each other. On one's head a bowler hat appears, vanishes. On the other's a sterve-pipe hat appears. On the first's head is a fez. The stove-pipe hat becomes a stetson. The fez becomes a cardinal's hat. The stetson becomes a wimple. Then the cardinal's hat and the wimple vanish. One of the boxers becomes Napoleon and the other boxer is astonished. Napoleon punches the boxer with the hand inside his jacket. The boxer falls, stunned. Horizontally he shoots off stage. Shot of cat, watching unimpressed. Napoleon does one-legged pixilated dance across stage and off, immediately reappearinng on other side of stage doing same dance in same direction. He reaches the other side, but is halted by a traffic policeman. The policeman beckons onto the stage a man in a penguin skin on a pogostick. The penguin gets halfway across and then turns into a dustbin. Napoleon hops off stage. Policeman goes to dustbin, opens it and Napoleon gets out. Shot of cat, still unmoved. A nude man with a towel round his waist gets out of the dustbin. Napoleon points at ground. A chair appears where he points. The nude man gets on to the chair, jumps in the air and vanishes. Then Napoleon points to ground by him and a small cannon appears. Napoleon fires cannon and the policeman disappears. The man with the towel round his waist gets out of the dustbin and is chased off stage by the penguin on the pogostick. A sedan chair is carried on stage by two chefs. The man with the towel gets out and the penguin appears from the dustbin and chases him off. Napoleon points to sedan chair and it changes into dustbin. Man in towel runs back on to stage and jumps in dustbin. He looks out and the penguin appears from the other dustbin and hits him on the head with a raw chicken. Shot of cat still unimpressed. Napoleon, the man with the towel round his waist, the policeman, a boxer, and a chef suddenly appear standing in a line, and take a bow. They immediately change positions and take another bow. The penguin appears at the end of the line with a
puff of smoke. Each one in turn jumps in the air and vanishes. Shot of passive cat.
Cut to Mr A and Mrs B watching with the general.
After a pause, the cat gets up and walks into the house. Mr A and Mrs B are overcome with joy.
Picture freezes and over still of general's face are superimposed the words 'Confuse-a-Cat Limited'. Dramatic music. The words start to roll, like ordinary credits but read:
People's heads appear in frame due to Mr Gilliam's animation on film.
(holds up notice)
(an alarm clock goes off inside his case; the Man thumps it, unsuccessfully)
(he thumps the case and the alarm stops)
Clocks start ticking and chiming in the case. The man desperately thumps the case.
(he opens his case to reveal it stuffed full of watches and clocks)
(shouting)
(he is removed struggling)
A vicar is next.
Cut to chairman of discussion group.
(shot of lizard; silence)
(shot of duck; silence)
(shot of cat; silence)
(shot of lizard again and then back)
Cut to film: vox pops.
(a car runs him over)
(no answer)
(getting up from a deckchair and screaming with indignation and rage: he has a knotted handkerchief on his head and his trousers are rolled up to the knees)
(enter a knight in amour)
The knight is carrying a raw chicken. The man apprehensively covers his head and the knight slams him in the stomach with the chicken.
(off)
(very reasonably)
We now see that he is playing chess with another young man. They are in an ordinary flat. There is a tremendous battering, banging, hammering and clattering at the door.
(he enters)
(pulling a brown paper package from out of his pocket, very badly and obviously)
(takes it)
(opens it)
Cut to viewer's letter in handwriting, read in voice over.
Cut to another letter.
Cut to vox pops film.
A boxer (Eric) runs up and knocks her out.
A boy scout on his knees. Next to him is a scout master, seen only from the knees down.
He is nudged.
Cut to news studio with a large screen behind newsreader.
(as if it's the fourth item))
(on the screen behind, him, there appears an identical picture of him, sitting at his newsreader desk)
(on the screen behind, police come in and remove the newsreader)
(he is handed a piece of paper)
(the other newsreader appears back on the screen and sits down)
(he is handed another piece of paper)
(a policeman comes in, and removes newsreader in the foreground)
The newsreader on the screen behind continues.
(he clips a piece of jewellery on to his ear)

'Match of the Day' music. We see a couple. They are standing at the foot of a largish bed. She is in bra and pants. He is in Y-fronts. They kiss ecstaticaly. After a few seconds there is the sound of a car drawing up. The crunch of footsteps on gravel and the sound of a door opening. The newsreader comes into shot.
(he goes out of shot; the two clinch again; after a second he pops back into shot)
(pops out of shot, then pops in again)
(he goes)
The couple continue to neck.

Cut to film montage. Collapsing factory chimney in reverse motion; pan up tall soaring poplars in the wind; waves crashing; fish in shallow water fountains; exploding fireworks; volcano erupting with lava; rocket taking off, express train going into a tunnel; dam bursting; battleship broadside; lion leaping through flaming hoop; Richard Nixon smiling; milking a cow; planes refuelling in mid-air; Women's Institute applauding; tossing the caber; plane falling in flames; tree crashing to the ground; the lead shot tower collapsing (normal motion).
Cut back to the girl in bed.
(smoking)
We see Bevis, with small projector.
He starts it. A two-minute extravaganza constructed by Mr Terry Gilliam of America you know.
(knock at door)
(Stig enters)
(he sits)
(stares at him and starts writing)
(stands up)
(Stig does so)
(writes again)
(writes)
(shakes head)
(writes again)
(rings small hand-bell)
(rings bell again)
(shouts)
(singing)
(Rings bell)
(makes face and strange noise)
(writing)
(long look, rings bell)
(Stig pulls face and makes noise)
(Stig pulls face and makes noise)
(Interviewer goes to door)
(calls through door)
(four people come in and line up by desk)
(rings bell)
Stig very cautiously pulls face and makes noise. Interviewer rings bell again. Suddenly the four men all hold up points cards like diving or skating judges.
(hysterically)
The judges give him very high marks.
They fall about laughing.
Cut to man sitting at desk.
(emotionally)
(he weeps, then recovers)
Cut to front door of a flat. Man walks up to the door and rings bell. He is dressed smartly.
(longish pause while he waits, he rings again)
(woman appears at other side of door)
(she opens door)
Man enters it through door.
(he pockets valuable)
Cut back to man at desk.
Cut to very tall building; a body flies out of a high window and plummets. Cut back to man at desk.
Cut to a different tall building; two bodies fly out of a high window. Cut back to man at desk.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 4

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS'

dialogue.speaker: Singer
dialogue.text: And did those teeth in ancient time...

dialogue.speaker: Singer
dialogue.text:
... walk upon England's mountains green. Good evening and
welcome ladies and gentlemen. At this time we'd like to up the tempo a little, change the
mood. We've got a number requested by Pip, Pauline, Nigel, Tarquin, and old Spotty -
Tarquin's mother - a little number specially written for the pubescence of ex-King Zog of
Albania, and it's entitled 'Art Gallery'. Hope you like it.

dialogue.speaker: Janet
dialogue.text: 'Allo, Marge!

dialogue.speaker: Marge
dialogue.text: Oh hello, Janet, how are you love?

dialogue.speaker: Janet
dialogue.text: Fancy seeing you! How's little Ralph?

dialogue.speaker: Marge
dialogue.text: Oh, don't ask me! He's been nothing but trouble all morning. Stop it Ralph! Stop it!

dialogue.speaker: Janet
dialogue.text: Same as my Kevin.

dialogue.speaker: Marge
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Janet
dialogue.text:
Nothing but trouble ... leave it alone! He's just been in the Florentine Room and
smeared tomato ketchup all over Raphael's Baby Jesus. Put that
Baroque masterpiece down!

dialogue.speaker: Marge
dialogue.text:
Well, we've just come from the Courtauld and Ralph smashed every exhibit but one
in the Danish Contemporary Sculpture Exhibition.

dialogue.speaker: Janet
dialogue.text:
Just like my Kevin. Show him an exhibition of early eighteenth-century Dresden
Pottery and he goes berserk. No, I said no, and I meant no! This morning we were viewing the early Flemish Masters of the Renaissance and Mannerist
Schools, when he gets out his black aerosol and squirts Vermeer's Lady At A Window!

dialogue.speaker: Marge
dialogue.text: Still it's not as bad as spitting is it?

dialogue.speaker: Janet
dialogue.text: No, well Kevin knows that if he spits at a painting I'll never take him to an exhibition again.

dialogue.speaker: Marge
dialogue.text:
Ralph used to spit - he could hit a Van Gogh at thirty yards. But he knows now it's
wrong - don't you Ralph? Ralph! Stop it! Stop it! Stop chewing that Turner!
You are ... You are a naughty, naughty, vicious little boy. Oh, look at that! The Fighting Temeraire - ruined! What
shall I do?

dialogue.speaker: Janet
dialogue.text: Now don't do a thing with it love, just put it in the bin over there.

dialogue.speaker: Marge
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Janet
dialogue.text:
Yes take my word for it, Marge. Kevin's eaten most of the early nineteenth-century
British landscape artists, and I've learned not to worry. As a matter of fact, I feel a bit peckish
myself. Yes...

dialogue.speaker: Marge
dialogue.text: I never used to like Turner.

dialogue.speaker: Janet
dialogue.text: No ... I don't know much about art, but I know what I like.

dialogue.speaker: Critic
dialogue.text: Mmmm... Well I think Utrillo's brushwork is fantastic... But he doesn't always agree with me ... Not after a Rubens, anyway ... all those cherries ... ooohh ... Urgh! I've got Vermeer all down my shirt...

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text:
(Katya Wyeth) Watteau,
dear?

dialogue.speaker: Critic
dialogue.text: What a terrible joke.

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: But it's my only line.

dialogue.speaker: Critic
dialogue.text: All right! All right! But you didn't have to say it! You could have kept quiet for a change!

dialogue.speaker: Critic
dialogue.text: Oh, that's typical. Talk talk talk. Natter natter natter!

dialogue.speaker: Singer
dialogue.text:
Bring me my arrows of desire ... Bring me my spear oh clouds unfold ...
Bring me my chariot of fire.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Right, cut to me. As Officer Commanding the Regular Army's Advertising Division, I object, in the strongest possible terms to this obvious reference to our own slogan 'It's a dog's life... a life in the modern army' and I warn this programme that any recurrence of this sloppy long-haired civilian plagiarism will be dealt with most severely. Right, now on the command 'cut', the camera will cut to camera two, all right, director... Wait for it! Camera cut.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: This is my only line. Well, it's my only line.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'IT'S A MAN'S LIFE TAKING YOUR CLOTHES OFF IN PUBLIC'

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Quiet. Quiet. Now wait a minute. I have already warned this programme about infringing the Army copyright of our slogan 'It's a pig's life... life in the modern army'. And I'm warning you if it happens again, I shall come down on this programme like a ton of bricks... right. Carry on sergeant major.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Sir! Good evening, class.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Where's all the others, then?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: They're not here.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: I can see that. What's the matter with them?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Don't know.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Perhaps they've got flu.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
Flu...flu? They should eat more fresh fruit. Right. Now,
self-defence. Tonight I shall be carrying on from where we got to last
week when I was showing you how to defend yourselves against anyone who
attacks you with armed with a piece of fresh fruit.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: You promised you wouldn't do fruit this week.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: We've done fruit the last nine weeks.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: What's wrong with fruit? You think you know it all, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: But couldn't we do something else, for a change?

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Man
dialogue.text: Like someone who attacks you with a pointed stick?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
Pointed sticks? Ho, ho, ho. We want to learn how to defend ourselves
against pointed sticks, do we? Getting all high and mighty, eh? Fresh
fruit not good enough for you eh? Well I'll tell you something my lad.
When you're walking home tonight and some great homicidal maniac comes
after you with a bunch of loganberries, don't come crying to me! Now,
the passion fruit. When your assailant lunges at you with a passion
fruit, thus...

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: We've done the passion fruit.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: We've done the passion fruit.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: We done oranges, apples, grapefruits.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: Whole and segments.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Pomegranates, greengages.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Grapes, passion fruit.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Lemons.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: Plums.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Yes, and mangoes in syrup.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: How about cherries?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: We done them.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Red black?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: All right then...bananas!

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: We haven't done them, have we?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
Right! Bananas! How to defend yourself
against a man armed with a banana. Here, you, take this. Now, it's quite simple to defend yourself against the banana fiend. First of all, you force him to drop the banana, next, you eat the banana, thus disarming him. You have now rendered him helpless.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Suppose he's got a bunch.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Shut up!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Man
dialogue.text: Supposing he's got a pointed stick.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Shut up. Right now you, Mr Apricot.

dialogue.speaker: First Man
dialogue.text: Harrison.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Harrison, Mr. Harrison. Come at me with that banana then. Come on attack me with it. As hard as you like. Come on. No no no. Put something into it for God's sake. Hold it, like that. Scream. Now come on, come on...attack me, come on, come on Now...I eat the banana.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: You shot him. He's dead...dead. He's completely dead. You've shot him.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: I have now eaten the banana. The deceased Mr Apricot is now disarmed.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: You shot him. You shot him dead.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Well, he was attacking me with a banana.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: Well, you told him to.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
Look, I'm only doing me job. I have to show you how to defend
yourselves against fresh fruit.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Man
dialogue.text: And pointed sticks.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Supposing someone came at you with a banana and you haven't got a gun?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Run for it.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: You could stand and scream for help.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: You try that with a pineapple down your windpipe.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: A pineapple?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Where? Where?

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: Nowhere. I was just saying pineapple.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Oh blimey. I thought my number was on that one.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: What, on the pineapple?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Where? Where?

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: No I was just repeating it.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
Oh. Oh. Right. That's the banana then. Next... the
raspberry. Harmless looking thing, isn't it? Now you,
Mr Tinned Peach...

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: Thompson.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
Mr Thompson, come at me with that raspberry then. Come on, be as vicious as
you like with it.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: You'll shoot me.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: I won't.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: You shot Mr. Harrison.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: That was self-defence. Come on. I promise I won't shoot you.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Man
dialogue.text: You promised you'd tell us about pointed sticks.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Shut up. Now. Brandish that...brandish that raspberry. Come on, be as vicious as you like with it. Come on.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: No. Throw the gun away.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: I haven't got a gun.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: Oh yes, you have.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: I haven't.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: You have. You shot Mr Harrison with it.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Oh... gun.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: Throw it away.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
All right. How to defend yourself against a raspberry, without a
gun.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: You were going to shoot me!

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: I wasn't.

dialogue.speaker: Third Man
dialogue.text: You were.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
Wasn't. Come on, come on you worm...you miserable little man.
Come at me then...come on, do your worst, you worm. If anyone ever attacks you with a raspberry, simply pull the lever...and a sixteen-ton weight will drop on his head. I learnt that in Malaya.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Suppose you haven't got a sixteen-ton weight?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Well that's planning, isn't it? Forethought.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: How many sixteen-ton weights are there?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
Look...look, smarty pants, the sixteen-ton weight is just one way of
dealing with the raspberry killer. There are millions of others!

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Man
dialogue.text: Like what?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Shoot him.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Well, supposing you haven't got a gun or a sixteen-ton weight?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
All right clever dick, all right clever dick. You two, come at me
with raspberries, there you are, a whole basket each. Come on, come at me with them, then.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: No gun?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: No sixteen-ton weight?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Man
dialogue.text: No pointed stick?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: No rocks up in the ceiling?

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: You won't kill us.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: I won't kill you.

dialogue.speaker: Second Man
dialogue.text: Promise.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text: I promise I won't kill you. Now, are you going to attack me?

dialogue.speaker: Second Man and Fourth Man
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: RSM
dialogue.text:
Right, now don't rush me this time. I'm going to turn me back. So you can stalk me...right. Come up as quietly as you can, right, close up behind me, then, in with the raspberries, right? Start moving Now...the first thing to do when you are being stalked by an ugly mob with raspberries, is to...release the tiger. The great advantage of the tiger in unarmed combat is that it not only eats the raspberry-laden foe but also the raspberries. The tiger, however, do not relish the peach. The peach assailant should be attacked with a
crocodile. Right...I know you're there - lurking under the floorboards with your damsons and your prunes...now, the rest of you - I know you're hiding behind the wall bars with your quinces. Well I'm ready for you.
I've wired myself up to two hundred tons of gelignite, and if any one of you so
much as tries anything we'll all go up together!
I've warned you...I warned you, right. That's it...

dialogue.speaker: Singer
dialogue.text: And did those feet in ancient times, walk upon England's mountains green...we'd like to alter the mood a little, we'd like to bring you something for mum and dad, Annie, and Roger, Mazarin and Louis and all at Versailles, it's a little number calld 'England's Mountains Green'. Hope you like it. And did those feet in ancient time...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, you know it's a man's life in England's Mountain Green.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Right I heard that, I heard that, I'm going to stop this sketch now, and if there's any more of this, I'm going to stop the whole programme. I thought it was supposed to be about teeth anyway. Why don't you do something about your teeth - go on.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: What about my rustic monologue?...I'm not sleeping with producer again.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Excitement, drama, action, violence, fresh fruit. Passion. Thrills. Spills. Romance. Adventure, all the things you can read about in a book.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Er... oh!

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Good morning, I'd like to buy a book please.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Oh, well I'm afraid we don't have any.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: I'm sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: We don't have any books. We're fresh out of them. Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Well what are all these?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: All what? Oh! All these, ah ah ha ha. Your referring to these ... books.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: They're um ... they're all sold. Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: What of them?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Every single man Jack of them. Not a single one of them in an unsold state. Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Who to?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Who are they sold to?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Oh ... various ... good Lord is that the time? Oh my goodness I must close for lunch.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: It's only half past ten.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Ah yes, well I feel rather peckish ... very peckish actually, I don't expect I'll open again today. I think I'll have a really good feed. I say! Look at that lovely bookshop just across the road there, they've got a much better selection than we've got, probably at ridiculously low prices ... just across the road there. Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: But I was told to come here.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Well. Well, I see. Er ... hear the gooseberries are doing well this year... and so are the mangoes.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: I'm sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Er .,. oh . .. I was just saying ... thinking of the weather.. I hear the gooseberries are doing well this year... and so are the mangoes.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Mine aren't

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Go on...

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Go on - mine aren't ... but...

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Aren't you going to say something about 'mine aren't but the Big Cheese gets his at low tide tonight'?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Oh, ah, good morning, Wait. Who sent you?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: The little old lady in the sweet shop.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: She didn't have a duelling scar just here ... and a hook?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Of course not, I was thinking of somebody else. Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, there's something going on here.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: What, where? You didn't see anything did you?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: No, but I think there's something going on here.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: No no, well there's nothing going on here at all and he didn't see anything. Good morning.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: There is something going on.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Look there is nothing going on. Please believe me, there is abso... . . . lutely nothing going on. Is there anything going on?

dialogue.speaker: Van der Berg
dialogue.text: No there's nothing going on.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: See there's nothing going on.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Who was that?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: That was my aunt, look what was this book you wanted then? Quickly! Quickly!

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Oh, well, I'd like to buy a copy of an 'Illustrated History of False Teeth'.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: My God you've got guts.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Just how much do you know?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: What about?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Are you from the British Dental Association?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: No I'm a tobacconist.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Get away from that door.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: I'll just go over the other...

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Stay where you are. You'll never leave this bookshop alive.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: You know too much, my dental friend.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: I don't know anything.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Come clean. You're a dentist aren't you.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: No, I'm a tobacconist.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: A tobacconist who just happens to be buying a book on ...teeth?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Ha ha ha ha...

dialogue.speaker: Lafarge
dialogue.text: Drop that gun, Stapleton.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Lafarge!

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: There is something going on.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: No there isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Lafarge
dialogue.text: OK Stapleton, this is it. Where's Mahoney hidden the fillings?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: What fillings?

dialogue.speaker: Lafarge
dialogue.text: You know which fillings, Stapleton. Upper right two and four, lower right three and two lower left one. Come on. Remember what happened to Nigel.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: What happened to Nigel?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Orthodontic Jake gave him a gelignite mouth wash.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: I knew there was something going on.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Well there isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Lafarge
dialogue.text: Come on Stapleton. The fillings!

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: They're at 22 Wimpole Street.

dialogue.speaker: Lafarge
dialogue.text: Don't play games with me!

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Oh, oh, 22a Wimpole Street.

dialogue.speaker: Lafarge
dialogue.text: That's better.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: But you'll need an appointment.

dialogue.speaker: Lafarge
dialogue.text: OK Brian! Make with the appointment baby. No gas.

dialogue.speaker: Van der Berg
dialogue.text: Not so fast Lafarge!

dialogue.speaker: Lafarge
dialogue.text: Van der Berg!

dialogue.speaker: Van der Berg
dialogue.text: Yes. Now drop the roscoe.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: There something going on.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: No there isn't.

dialogue.speaker: Van der Berg
dialogue.text: Get the guns.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Who's that?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: That's Van der Berg. He's on our side.

dialogue.speaker: Van der Berg
dialogue.text: All right, get up against the wall Lafarge, and you too Stapleton.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: Me?

dialogue.speaker: Van der Berg
dialogue.text: Yes, you!

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: You dirty double-crossing rat.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: What's happened?

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: He's two-timed me.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Bad luck.

dialogue.speaker: Van der Berg
dialogue.text: All right ... where are the fillings? Answer me, where are they?

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: This is quite exciting.

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: Not so fast.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Brian!

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Ooh, what's that?

dialogue.speaker: The Others
dialogue.text: It's a bazooka.

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: All right. Get against the wall Van der Berg ... and you nurse. And the first one to try anything moves to a practice six feet underground ... this is an anti-tank gun ... and it's loaded ...and you've just got five seconds to tell me ... whatever happened to Baby Jane?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: Oh ... I'm sorry ... my mind was wandering ... I've had a terrible day... I really have ... you've got five seconds to tell me... I've forgotten. I've forgotten.

dialogue.speaker: Bookseller
dialogue.text: The five seconds haven't started yet have they?

dialogue.speaker: Van der Berg
dialogue.text: Only we don't know the question.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Was it about Vogler?

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: No, no... no ... you've got five seconds to tell me...

dialogue.speaker: Van der Berg
dialogue.text: About Nigel?

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Lafarge
dialogue.text: Bronski?

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: No. No.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: The fillings!

dialogue.speaker: Brian
dialogue.text: Oh yes, the fillings, of course. How stupid of me. Right, you've got five seconds ... Where are the fillings? Five, four, three, two, one, Zero! Zero! Oh! I've forgotten to fire it. Sorry. Silly day. Very well. Five, four, three, two, one.

dialogue.speaker: Big Cheese
dialogue.text: Drop the bazooka Brian.

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: The Big Cheese!

dialogue.speaker: Big Cheese
dialogue.text: I'm glad you could all come to my little ... party. And Flopsy's glad too, aren't you, Flopsy? Aren't you Flopsy? That'll teach you to play hard to get. There, poor Flopsy's dead. And never called me mother. And soon ... you will all be dead, dead, dead, dead. And because I'm so evil you'll all die the slow way ... under the drill.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: lt's one o'clock.

dialogue.speaker: Big Cheese
dialogue.text: So it is. Lunch break, everyone back here at two.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: Hallo ... give me the British Dental Association ... and fast.

dialogue.speaker: Arthur
dialogue.text: You see, I knew there was something going on. Of course, the Big Cheese made two mistakes. First of all he didn't recognize me: Lemming, Arthur Lemming, Special Investigator, British Dental Association, and second ... spit ... by the time I got back from lunch I had every dental surgeon in SW1 waiting for them all in the broom cupboard. Funny isn't it, how naughty dentists always make that one fatal mistake. Bye for now ... keep your teeth clean.

dialogue.speaker: Song
dialogue.text: Lemming, Lemming ... Lemming of the BDA .. Lemming, Lemming ... Lemming of the BD ...Lemming of the BD ... BD, BDA.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'IT'S A MAN'S LIFE IN THE BRITISH DENTAL ASSOCIATION'

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: Right! No, I warned you, no, I warned you about the slogan, right. That's the end. Stop the programme! Stop it.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Ah! Got you my lad. Still acting eh? Over you go!

annotations: A cliff. Suddenly the 'It's' man is thrown over it, landing on the shale beach beneath. Painfully he crawls towards the camera and announces:
