Singer in sprangly jacket sitting on high stool with guitar.
(singing to the tune of Jerusalem)
CAPTION: 'LIVE FROM THE CARDIFF ROOMS, LIBYA'
(he stops playing)

Interior of art gallery. Two figures enter. They are both middle-aged working mothers.
Each holds the hand of an unseen infant who is beneath the range of the camera.

(she
slaps at unseen infant)
(shouting off sharply)
(smacks unseen infant again)
(firmly)
(slaps the infant)
(she looks down)
(she disappears from shot)

(smack; she comes back into shot holding a copy of Turner's Fighting Temeraire in a
lovely gilt frame but all tattered)
(taking control)
(she breaks a bit off the Turner)
Marge also tastes a bit.
(swallowing)

Cut to a book-lined study. At a desk in front of the shelves sits an art critic with a
mouthful of Utrillo.
SUPERIMPOSED CAPTION: 'AN ART CRITIC'
(taking out stringy bits as he speaks)
(munches)
(stifles burp)
(belches)
(suddenly looks down)
(bringing in a water jug and glass on a tray and laying it on his desk)
(rising vehemently)
Wife cries.
Cut back to singer.
(singing)
A sexy girl (Katya Wyeth) enters and starts fondling him.
Cut to colonel: army recruitment posters on wall behind him.
(correcting himself rapidly)
(cut to a man sitting at desk)
(cut back to colonel)
(cut to man; he has a Viking helmet on)
(catcalls) (defensively)

Cut to a gentleman in striped blazer, boater and cricket flannels walking down to beach clutching towel and bathing trunks. He puts his towel on a breakwater next to another towel and starts to change. He suddenly looks up and we see everyone on the beach has turned to watch him - not with any disapproval - just a blank English stare. He grabs his towel off the breakwater and starts to take his trousers off under that. Girl in a bikini has been sitting on other side of the breakwater, stands up looking for her towel. She sees that the man is using it and she whisks it off him leaving him clutching his half-down trousers. Shot of everyone staring at him again. He pulls them up and makes for a beach hut... embarrassed. He goes into beach hut. Inside he is about to take his trousers off, when he becomes aware of a pair of feet which come up to the back of the beach hut - there is a 6-inch gap along bottom - and stop as if someone was peering through the crack. The man looks slightly outraged and pulls his trousers up, goes outside and edges cautiously round to the back of the beach hut. There he finds a man (Michael) bending close to the side of the beach hut with his hand to his face. The Gentleman kicks him hard in the seat of the pants. The man turns in obvious surprise, to reveal he was merely trying to light his cigarette out of the wind. The gentleman backs away with embarrassed apologies. We cut to the front of the beach hut to see gentleman backing round at the same time as a large matronly woman marches into the hut... the man follows her in. He is promptly thrown out on his ear. In desperation he looks around. On the promenade he suddenly sees an ice-cream van. He walks up to it, looks around, then nips behind to start changing. At the same time a policeman (Graham) strolls up to the ice-cream van and tells it to move on. The van drives off, exposing the gentleman clutching his trousers around his ankles. Close-up policeman's reaction. The man hurriedly pulls trousers up as policeman approaches him pulling out note book. Still covered in confusion he runs away from the policeman. In long shot we see him approach the commissionaire of the Royale Palace De Luxe Hotel. He whispers to the commissionaire, indicates by mime that he wants to take his trousers off. The commissionaire reacts to the gesture. The man nods. The commissionaire starts to take his trousers off. Man backs away once more in confusion - he has been misunderstood. Back on the beach again. He hides behind a pile of deckchairs. At that moment a beach party of jolly trippers arrive and each takes one. The deckchair pile rapidly disappears leaving the gentleman once again exposed. He dashes behind the deckchair attendant's hut which is next to him. Enter two workmen who dismantle it. Desperate by now he goes onto the pier. He goes into the amusement arcade, looking around furtively. Nips behind a 'what the butler saw' machine. Woman comes and puts penny in and starts to look, beckons over husband; he comes, looks in the machine, sees the man changing his trousers. They chase him off. Still pursued he nips into door. Finds himself in blackness. Relieved - at last he has found somewhere to change. He relaxes and starts to take his trousers off. Suddenly hears music and applause... curtains swishes back to reveal he is on stage of the pier pavilion. The audience applauds. Resigned to his fate, he breaks into stiptease routine.
(and CAPTION:)
Cut to colonel
A gym. Four men waiting there, with an ex-RSM type.
(does terrible twitch or tic)
(disappointed)
(scornfully)
(demonstrates)
(to first man)
(throws him a banana)
(Harrison moves towards him rather half-heartedly)
(Harrison runs towards him shouting; RSM draws a revolver and fires it, right in Harrison's face; Harrison dies immediately, falling to the ground; RSM puts gun away and walks to banana)
He does so; the rest of the class gather around Mr Harrison's body
(finishing the banana)
(jumping with fear)
(amazed)
(jumping)
(pulling one out of pocket)
(throws it away)
(third man runs at him; the RSM steps back and pulls a lever; a sixteen-ton weight falls upon the man)
(they start to creep up behind him)
(he presses button and a tiger flashes past him in direction of second and fourth men; cries are heard from them as well as roaring)
(he turns to lok at the scene)
Big explosion.
Ends with cut-out animation of sedan chair; matching shot links into next film.

Cut to deserted beach. Sedan chair arrives at deserted beach. Flunkey opens the door. Gentleman gets out in his eighteenth-century finery. The flunkeys help him to change into a lace-trimmed striped bathing costume. He then gets back into the sedan chair and they all trot off onto the sea.
Cut to singer in bed with woman. Singer reclining with guitar.
Cut to a man standing in the countryside.
(rustic accent)
(walk off)
Cut to film of various sporting activities, wild west stage coach etc.
(with big music, excited)
Cut to bookshop. A bookseller is standing behind the counter. Arthur enters the shot and goes up to the counter. The bookseller jumps and look about furtively.
(trying to hide them)
(he has the door open)
(bundling him back in)
(very, carefully)
(winks)
(nodding keenly, with anticipation)
(starts to bundle him out then stops)
(spinning round.)
(shouts off)
(coming back into shop)
(a hand comes into view behind Arthur's back; Bookseller frantically waves at it to disappear; it does so)
A man appears, fleetingly: he is Van der Berg (Dick Vosburgh)
(disappears)
(pulling gun)
Lafarge enters room with gun. He is swarthy, French, dressed all in black and menacing.
(he drops the gun)
(he threatens with the gun)
(pokes bookseller in eye with the gun)
(shouting out of shop)
Van der Berg appears with machine gun and a nurse (Carol), he is basically dressed as a dentist. But with many rings, chains, wristlets, cravats, buckled shoes and an ear-ring.
The nurse runs forward, picks up the gun and puts it on steel surgeon's tray, and covers it with a white cloth, returning it to Van der Berg.
(going with Bookseller)
Brian enters carrying a bazooka. Brian is dressed in operating-theatre clothes, gown, cap and mask, with rubber gloves and white wellingtons.
(clears throat)
(there is a long pause, Brian has forgotten to fire the bazooka but he can't put his finger on what has gone wrong)
(looks at gun)
(quite rapidly)
A panel slides back and the Big Cheese appears in sight seated in adentist's chair. The Big Cheese is in dentist's gear, wears evil magnifing type glasses and strokes a rabbit lying on his lap.
Brian drops the bazooka.
(he holds rabbit up as it does not reply)
(no reply again so he pulls a big revolver out and fires at rabbit from point-blank range)
(the crowd start to hiss him)
They, all happily relax and walk off. Arthur surreptitiously goes to telephone and, making sure nobody is looking, calls.
Cut to Arthur dressed normally as dentist leaning over patient in chair. He looks up to camera.
(to patient)
Cut to photo of Arthur Lemming
Over this we hear a song which Graham knows the tune of.
(Voice over pre-recorded)
(and CAPTION:)
(knocking the photo aside)
Cut to referee blowing whistle.
The 'It's' man, lying on beach. is poked with a stick from off-screen. He gets up and limps away.
End titles finishes as the 'It's' man reaches the top of the cliff and disappears. As soon as he has disappeared we hear:
'It's' man reappears hurled back over cliff.

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 3

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Monty Python's Flying Circus.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'EPISODE 12B' 'HOW TO RECOGNISE DIFFERENT TREES FROM QUITE A LONG WAY AWAY' 'NO. 1' 'THE LARCH'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The larch. The larch.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text:
Mr Larch, you heard the case for the prosecution. Is there anything you wish to say
before I pass sentence?

dialogue.speaker: Prisoner
dialogue.text:
Well... I'd just like to say, m'lud, I've got a family... a wife and six kids... and I
hope very much you don't have to take away my freedom... because... well, because m'lud
freedom is a state much prized within the realm of civilized society. It is a bond wherewith the savage man may charm the outward hatchments of his
soul, and soothe the troubled breast into a magnitude of quiet. It is most precious as a
blessed balm, the saviour of princes, the harbinger of happiness, yea, the very stuff and pith of
all we hold most dear. What frees the prisoner in his lonely cell, chained within the bondage
of rude walls, far from the owl of Thebes? What fires and stirs the woodcock in his springe or
wakes the drowsy apricot betides? What goddess doth the storm toss'd mariner offer her
most tempestuous prayers to? Freedom! Freedom! Freedom!

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: It's only a bloody parking offence.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
I'm sorry I'm late m'lud I couldn't find a kosher car park. Er... don't bother to
recap m'lud, I'll pick it up as we go along. Call Mrs Fiona Lewis.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk of the Court
dialogue.text: Call Mrs Fiona Lewis.

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text:
I swear to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, so anyway, I said to her, I said, they can't afford that on what he earns, I mean for a start the
feathers get up your nose, I ask you, four and six a pound, and him with a wooden leg, I don't
know how she puts up with it after all the trouble she's had with her you-know-what, anyway
it was a white wedding much to everyone's surprise, of course they bought everything on the
hire purchase, I think they ought to send them back where they came from, I mean you've got
to be cruel to be kind so Mrs Harris said, so she said, she said, she said, the dead crab she
said, she said. Well, her sister's gone to Rhodesia what with her womb and all, and her
youngest, her youngest as thin as a filing cabinet, and the goldfish, the goldfish they've got
whooping cough they keep spitting water all over their Bratbys, well, they do don't they, I
mean you can't, can you, I mean they're not even married or anything, they're not even
divorced, and he's in the KGB if you ask me, he says he's a tree surgeon but I don't like the
sound of his liver, all that squeaking and banging every night till the small hours, his mother's
been much better since she had her head off, yes she has, I said, don't you talk to me about
bladders, I said...

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Mr Bartlett, I fail to see the relevance of your last witness.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: My next witness will explain that if m'ludship will allow. I call the late Arthur Aldridge.

dialogue.speaker: Clerk of the Court
dialogue.text: The late Arthur Aidridge.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: The late Arthur Aldridge?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Yes m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Mr Bartlett, do you think there is any relevance in questioning the deceased?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, your witness is dead.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Yes, m'lud. Er, well, er, virtually, m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: He's not completely dead?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: No he's not completely dead m'lud. No. But he's not at all well.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: But if he's not dead, what's he doing in a coffin?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
Oh, it's purely a precaution m'lud - if I may continue? Mr Aldridge, you were a...
you are a stockbroker of 10 Savundra Close, Wimbledon. Mr Aldridge...

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: What was that knock?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
It means 'yes' m'lud. One knock for 'yes', and two knocks for 'no'. If I may
continue? Mr Aldridge, would it be fair to say that you are not at all well? In fact Mr Aldridge, not to put too fine a point on it, would you be prepared
to say that you are, as it were, what is generally known as, in a manner of speaking, 'dead'? Mr Aldridge I put it to you that you are dead. Ah ha!

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Where is all this leading us?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
That will become apparent in one moment m'lud. Mr
Aldridge are you considering the question or are you just dead? I think I'd better
take a look m'lud. No further questions m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text:
What do you mean, no further questions? You can't just dump a dead body in my
court and say 'no further questions'. I demand an explanation.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: There are no easy answers in this case m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: I think you haven't got the slightest idea what this case is about.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
M'lud the strange, damnable, almost diabolic threads of this extraordinary tangled
web of intrigue will shortly m'lud reveal a plot so fiendish, so infernal, so heinous ...

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Mr Bartlett, your client has already pleaded guilty to the parking offence.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
Parking offence, schmarking offence, m'lud. We must leave no stone unturned. Call
Cardinal Richelieu.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Oh, you're just trying to string this case out. Cardinal Richelieu?

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: A character witness m'lud.

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text:
'Allo everyone, it's wonderful to be 'ere y'know, I just love your country. London
is so beautiful at this time of year.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Er, you are Cardinal Armand du Piessis de Richelieu, First Minister of Louis XIII?

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: Oui.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
Cardinal, would it be fair to say that you not only built up the centralized monarchy
in France but also perpetuated the religious schism in Europe?

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: That's what they say.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Did you persecute the Huguenots?

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: Oui.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
And did you take even sterner measures against the great Catholic nobles who
made common cause with foreign foes in defence of their feudal independence?

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: I sure did that thing.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: Cardinal. Are you acquainted with the defendant, Harold Larch?

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: Since I was so high .

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
Speaking as a Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church, as First Minister of Louis
XIII, and as one of the architects of the modern world already - would you say that Harold
Larch was a man of good character?

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: Listen. Harry is a very wonderful human being.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text:
M'lud. In view of the impeccable nature of this character witness may I plead for
clemency.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: Oh but it's only thirty shillings.

dialogue.speaker: Dim
dialogue.text: Not so fast!

dialogue.speaker: Prisoner
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Dim
dialogue.text:
None of your smart answers ... you think you're so clever.
Well, I'm Dim.

dialogue.speaker: Omnes
dialogue.text: Dim! Consternation! Uproar!

dialogue.speaker: Dim
dialogue.text: Yes, and I've a few questions I'd like to ask Cardinal so-called Richelieu.

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: Bonjour Monsieur Dim.

dialogue.speaker: Dim
dialogue.text: So-called Cardinal, I put it to you that you died in December 1642.

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: That is correct.

dialogue.speaker: Dim
dialogue.text: Ah ha! He fell for my little trap.

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: Curse you Inspector Dim. You are too clever for us naughty people.

dialogue.speaker: Dim
dialogue.text:
And furthermore I suggest that you are none other than Ron Higgins, professional
Cardinal Richelieu impersonator.

dialogue.speaker: Cardinal
dialogue.text: It's a fair cop.

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: My you're clever Dim. He'd certainly taken me in.

dialogue.speaker: Dim
dialogue.text: It's all in a day's work.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: With a brilliant mind like yours, Dim, you could be something other than a policeman.

dialogue.speaker: Dim
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Judge
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Dim
dialogue.text: If I were not in the CID Something else I'd like to be If I were not in the CID A window cleaner, me! With a rub-a-dub-dub and a scrub-a-dub-dub And a rub-a-dub all day long With a rub-a-dub-dub and a scrub-a-dub-dub I'd sing this merry song!

dialogue.speaker: Counsel
dialogue.text: If I were not before the bar Something else I'd like to be If I were not a barr-is-ter An engine driver me! With a chuffchuffchuff etc.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The larch. The larch.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'AND NOW...NO. 1...THE LARCH...AND NOW...'

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text:
This man is no ordinary man. This is Mr. F. G. Superman. To all
appearances, he looks like any other law-abiding citizen.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text:
But Mr F. G. Superman has a secret identity...when trouble strikes at any time...at
any place...he is ready to become... Bicycle Repair Man!

dialogue.speaker: Superboy
dialogue.text: Hey, there's a bicycle broken. Up the road.

dialogue.speaker: Bicycle Repair Man
dialogue.text: Hmmmmm. Thinks - this sounds like a job for... Bicycle Repair Man...but how to change without revealing my secret identity?

dialogue.speaker: First Superman
dialogue.text: If only Bicycle Repair Man were here!

dialogue.speaker: F. G. Superman
dialogue.text: Yes. Wait! I think I know where I can find him - look over !

dialogue.speaker: Supermen
dialogue.text: Bicycle Repair Man! But...how?!

dialogue.speaker: First Superman
dialogue.text: Oh look - is it a Stockbroker?

dialogue.speaker: Second Superman
dialogue.text: Is it a Quantity Surveyor?

dialogue.speaker: Third Superman
dialogue.text: Is it a Church Warden?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: No! It's BICYCLE REPAIR MAN!

dialogue.speaker: Superman
dialogue.text: My! BICYCLE REPAIR MAN! Thank goodness you've come! Look!

dialogue.speaker: Second Superman
dialogue.text: Why! He's mending it with his own hands!

dialogue.speaker: First Superman
dialogue.text: See! How he uses a spanner to tighten that nut!

dialogue.speaker: Superman
dialogue.text: Oh...Oh! Bicycle Repair Man! How can I ever repay you?

dialogue.speaker: Bicycle Repair Man
dialogue.text:
Oh, you don't need to guv, it's all right, it's all in a days work for...
Bicycle Repair Man!

dialogue.speaker: Supermen
dialogue.text: Our Hero!

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Yes! Whenever bicycles are broken, or menaced by International Communism, Bicycle Repair Man is ready!

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Ready to smash the communists, wipe them up, and shove them off the face of the earth... Mash that dirty red scum, kick 'em in the teeth where it hurts. Kill! Kill! Kill! The filthy bastard commies, I hate 'em! I hate 'em! Aaargh! Aaargh!

dialogue.speaker: Wife
dialogue.text: Norman! Tea's ready.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: Coming dear!

dialogue.speaker: Storyteller
dialogue.text: Hello, Children, hello. Here is this morning's story. Are you ready? Then we'll begin. 'One day Ricky the magic Pixie went to visit Daisy Bumble in her tumbledown cottage. He found her in the bedroom. Roughly he gabbed her heavy shoulders pulling her down on to the bed and ripping off her...; 'Old Nick the Sea Captain was a rough tough jolly sort of fellow. He loved the life of the sea and he loved to hang out down by the pier where the men dressed as ladies...' ..... 'Rumpletweezer ran the Dinky Tinky shop in the foot of the magic oak tree by the wobbly dumdum bush in the shade of the magic glade down in Dingly Dell. Here he sold contraceptives and ... discipline?... naked? ... With a !?

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Hello again, now here's a little sketch by two boys from London town. They've been writing for three years and they've called this little number - here it is, it's called - Restaurant sketch.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, very good restaurant, three stars you know.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Mmm...

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: Good evening, sir! Good evening, madam! And may I say what a pleasure it is to see you here again, sir!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh thank you. Well there you are dear. Have a look there, anything you like. The boeuf en croute is fantastic.

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: Oh if I may suggest, sir ... the pheasant à la reine, the sauce is one of the chefs most famous creations.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Em... that sounds good. Anyway just have a look... take your time. Oh, er by the way - got a bit of a dirty fork, could you ... er.. get me another one?

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh it's nothing ... er, I've got a fork a little bit dirty. Could you get me another one? Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: Oh ... sir, I do apologize.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, no need to apologize, it doesn't worry me.

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: Oh no, no, no, I do apologize. I will fetch the head waiter immediatement.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, there's no need to do that!

dialogue.speaker: Waiter
dialogue.text: Oh, no no... I'm sure the head waiter, he will want to apologize to you himself. I will fetch him at once.

dialogue.speaker: Lady
dialogue.text: Well, you certainly get good service here.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: They really look after you... yes.

dialogue.speaker: Head Waiter
dialogue.text: Excuse me monsieur and madame. It's filthy, Gaston ... find out who washed this up, and give them their cards immediately.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: Head Waiter
dialogue.text: Better still, we can't afford to take any chances, sack the entire washing-up staff.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: No, look I don't want to make any trouble.

dialogue.speaker: Head Waiter
dialogue.text: Oh, no please, no trouble. It's quite right that you should point these kind of things out. Gaston, tell the manager what has happened immediately!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh, no I don't want to cause any fuss.

dialogue.speaker: Head Waiter
dialogue.text: Please, it's no fuss. I quite simply wish to ensure that nothing interferes with your complete enjoyment of the meal.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh I'm sure it won't, it was only a dirty fork.

dialogue.speaker: Head Waiter
dialogue.text: I know. And I'm sorry, bitterly sorry, but I know that... no apologies I can make can alter the fact that in our restaurant you have been given a dirty, filthy, smelly piece of cutlery...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: It wasn't smelly.

dialogue.speaker: Head Waiter
dialogue.text: It was smelly, and obscene and disgusting and I hate it, I hate it ,.. nasty, grubby, dirty, mingy, scrubby little fork. Oh ... oh . . . oh . . .

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: Good evening, sir, good evening, madam. I am the manager. I've only just heard . .. may I sit down?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes, of course.

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: I want to apologize, humbly, deeply, and sincerely about the fork.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh please, it's only a tiny bit... I couldn't see it.

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: Ah you're good kind fine people, for saying that, but I can see it.., to me it's like a mountain, a vast bowl of pus.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: It's not as bad as that.

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: It gets me . I can't give you any excuses for it - there are no excuses. I've been meaning to spend more time in the restaurant recently, but I haven't been too well... things aren't going very well back there. The poor cook's son has been put away again, and poor old Mrs Dalrymple who does the washing up can hardly move her poor fingers, and then there's Gilberto's war wound - but they're good people, and they're kind people, and together we were beginning to get over this dark patch ... there was light at the end of the tunnel . .. now this . .. now this...

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Can I get you some water?

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: It's the end of the road!!

dialogue.speaker: Cook
dialogue.text: You bastards! You vicious, heartless bastards! Look what you've done to him! He's worked his fingers to the bone to make this place what it is, and you come in with your petty feeble quibbling and you grind him into the dirt, this fine, honourable man, whose boots you are not worthy to kiss. Oh... it makes me mad... mad!

dialogue.speaker: Head Waiter
dialogue.text: Easy, Mungo, easy... Mungo... the war wound!... the wound... the wound...

dialogue.speaker: Manager
dialogue.text: This is the end! The end! Aaargh!!

dialogue.speaker: Cook
dialogue.text: They've destroyed him! He's dead!! They killed him!!!

dialogue.speaker: Head Waiter
dialogue.text: No Mungo... never kill a customer. Oh . .. the wound! The wound!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Lucky we didn't say anything about the dirty knife.

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Well, there we are then, that was the restaurant sketch, a nice little number...a bit vicious in parts, but a lot of fun...but how about that punch line, eh?...Oh, you know what I mean - oh...oh...really.

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text: Good evening, here is the 6 o'clock News read by Michael Queen. It's been a quite day over most of the country as people went back to work after the warmest July weekend for nearly a year. The only high spot of the weekend was the meeting between officials of the NEDC and the ODCN in Bradford today.

dialogue.speaker: Newsreader
dialogue.text:
In Geneva, officials of the Central Clearing Banks met with Herr Voleschtadt of Poland to discuss non-returnable loans on a twelve-year trust basis for the construction of a new zinc-treating works in the Omsk area of Krakow, near the Bulestan border.
The Board of Trade has ratified a Trade Agreement with the Soviet Union for the sale of 600 low gear electric sewing machines. The President of the Board of Trade said he hoped this would
mark a new area of expansion in world trade and a new spirit of co-operation between East and West. There has been a substantial drop in Gold Reserves during the last twelve months. This follows a statement by the Treasury to the effect that the balance of imports situation had not changed dramatically over the same period. Still no news of the National Savings book lost by Mr Charles Griffiths of Porthcawl during a field expedition to the Nature Reserves of Swansea last July. Mr Griffiths' wife said that her husband was refusing to talk to the Press until the Savings Certificate had been found. In Cornwall the death has been announced today of the former Minister without Portfolio, General Sir Hugh Marksby-Smith. Sir Hugh was vice-president of the Rotarian movement. In the match between Glamorgan and Yorkshire, the Yorkshire bowler Nicholson took eight wickets for three runs. Glareorgan were all out for the thirty-six and therefore won the match by an innings and seven runs. Weather for tomorrow will be cloudy with occasional outbreaks of rain. And that is the end of the news.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'AND NOW' 'NO. 1' 'THE LARCH'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The larch

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'AND NOW' 'NO. 3' 'THE LARCH' 'AND NOW...'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The horse chestnut.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Eric ... do you think you could recognize a larch tree?

dialogue.speaker: Eric
dialogue.text: Don't know.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: What's your name?

dialogue.speaker: Michael
dialogue.text: Michael.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Michael, do you think you know what a larch tree looks like?

dialogue.speaker: Michael
dialogue.text: I want to go home.

dialogue.speaker: Terry
dialogue.text: Bottom!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Are there any other trees that any of you think you could recognize from quite a long way away?

dialogue.speaker: Terry
dialogue.text: I ... want... to see a sketch of Eric's please...

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Terry
dialogue.text: I want to see a sketch of Eric's. Nudge Nudge.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: A sketch?

dialogue.speaker: Terry
dialogue.text: Eric's written...

dialogue.speaker: Eric
dialogue.text: I written a sketch.

dialogue.speaker: Michael
dialogue.text: Nudge nudge, Eric's written ...

dialogue.speaker: Eric
dialogue.text: Nudge nudge...nudge...nudge.

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Is your wife a...goer...eh? Know what I mean? Know what I mean? Nudge nudge. Nudge nudge. Know what I mean? Say no more...know what I mean?

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Your wife...does she, er, does she 'go' - eh? eh? eh? Know what I mean, know what I mean? Nudge nudge. Say no more.

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: Well, she sometimes goes, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: I bet she does. I bet she does. I bet she does. Know what I mean? Nudge nudge.

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, I don't quite follow you.

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Follow me. I like that. That's good. A nod's as good as a wink to a blind bat, eh?

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: Are you trying to sell something?

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text:
Selling, selling. Very good. good. Oh, wicked.
Wicked. You're wicked. Eh? Know what I mean. Know what I mean? Nudge nudge. Know what I mean? Nudge nudge. Nudge nudge. Say...no...more.

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: But...

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Your wife is she, eh... is she a sport. Eh?

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: She sport, yes!

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: I bet she does, I bet she does!

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: She is very fond of cricket, as a matter of fact.

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Who isn't, eh? Know what I mean. Likes games, likes games. Knew she would. Knew she would. Knew she would. Likes games, eh? She's been around, eh? Been around?

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: She's traveled. She's from Purley.

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Oh...oh. Say no more, say no more. Say no more - , say no more. Purley, eh? Know what I mean, know what I mean. Say no more.

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Your wife interested in er... photographs, eh? Know what I mean? Photographs, 'he asked him knowingly'.

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: Photography?

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Yes. Nudge nudge. Snap snap. Grin grin, wink wink, say no more?

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: Holiday snaps?

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Could be, could be taken on holiday. Could be yes - swimming costumes. Know what I mean. Candid photography. Know what I mean, nudge nudge.

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: No, no we don't have a camera.

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Oh. Still Woah! Eh? Wo-oah! Eh?

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: Look, are you insinuating something?

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Oh...no...no... Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: Well?

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Well. I mean. Er, I mean. You're a man of the world, aren't you...I mean, er, you've er... you've been there haven't you...I mean you've been around...eh?

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: What do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: Well I mean like you've er...you've done it...I mean like, you know...you've...er...you've slept...with a lady.

dialogue.speaker: Him
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Norman
dialogue.text: What's it like?

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The Larch.

annotations: Opening as usual - man running through a forest towards camera with clothes tattered; arrives at camera, and says:
Titles sequence as usual. And pretty flowers blooming. This finishes, and a magic lantern slide (done graphically) clicks into vision.
(and CAPTION:)
Photo of a larch tree.
Courtroom: a judge sitting at higher level and a prisoner in the dock.

(slips into Olivier
impression)
The counsel strides into court.
A pepperpot walks into the court and gets up into the witness box.
(taking bible)
During all this counsel has been trying to ask questions. Eventually he gives up and Mrs. Lewis is pushed out of court still talking.
A coffin is brought into the court and laid across the witness box.
(from the coffin comes a bang)

(from the coffin
comes a bang)
(silence, counsel listens;)
(silence)
(walking over to coffin)
(silence)
(he opens the coffin and looks inside for some time; then he closes the coffin)
Fanfare of trumpets. Cardinal Richelieu enters witness box in beautiful robes.
(modestly)
(indicated how high)
Enter Inspector Dim.
(momentarily thrown)
A caption appears on the screen 'DIM OF THE YARD'
(in unison)
Court applauds and the Cardinal looks dismayed.
Piano starts playing introduction.
(singing)

He mimes window cleaning movements and the rest of the
court enthusiastically mimes and sings the chorus again with him. When the chorus verse ends the counsel enthusiastically takes
over but this time the court all sit and watch him as though he has gone completely
mad.
(Singing)

He makes engine miming movements. As before. After a few seconds he sees that the rest of the court are staring at him in amazement and he loses momentum rapidly, almost as rapidly as he loses confidence and dignity. At last he subsides. Our knight in armour walks up to the counsel and hits him with the traditional raw chicken.
(and CAPTION:)
Photo of larch tree.
(and CAPTION:)
Superman film: shot from below of Superman (Michael) striding along against the sky.
(American accent)

Pull back to reveal he is in a modern street full of Supermen walking along shopping, waiting at bus queues etc. F. G. Superman gets onto a bus. The bus is full of Supermen, most of them with shopping baskets on their knees. F. G. Supermen finds a seat...during the commentary the camera slowly tracks in on his face.
The camera is by now in very tight close-up. A country lane. A superman rides into the shot on a bicycle, whistling innocently. Suddenly he veers off to one side and crashes down into a ditch.

Cut to a laundrette. Pan along a row of Supermen, one or two of whom are poring over magazines such as: 'The Adventures of an Insurance Broker', 'Income Tax Comics', and 'The Grocer'. Suddenly the door flies open and a youngish Superboy bursts in dramatically.
(dramatically)
(he points dramatically)
General consternation.
(voice over)
Close-up F. G. Superman. He narrows his eyes.
F. G. Superman points out of window; they turn and look obediently. F. G. Superman whips overall out of case and puts them on.

Fantastically speeded-up for this. His overalls have 'Bicycle Repair Man' written across the chest. He completes the transformation with a pair of little round specs and a bag of tools. He makes for the door and all the Supermen turn and raise their hands in amazement.
Country road. Superman is standing over the mangled bits looking at it and scratching his head. Bicycle Repair Man speeds up to him. Superman stands back in surprise, with arms raised.
(he points stiltedly)
Bicycle Repair Man pushes him to one side and kneels beside the broken bicycle. Speeded-up: he mends the bike with spanners etc. Graphics.
A little group of Supermen has gathered to watch him work. As he does so they point in amazement.
Cut to Bicycle Repair Man presenting the Superman with a glittering drop-handlebarred bike.
(he shuffles away)
(shot of Bicycle Repair Man shuffling, speeded up, into sunset)
Cut to commentator in garden with earphones on, and in front of microphone, which is on a garden table.
(his voice rises hysterically)
(commentator rises from his canvas chair, and flails about wildly, waving script, kicking over table, knocking down sunshade)
(off-screen)
He immediately looks frightened, and goes docile.
(calmly)
He gathers up his script, picks up chair, and walks out of frame. Pause, then the man in the suit of armour crosses frame after him.
Five seconds of Gilliam animation. To gentle children's programme music, we see bunnies jumping up and down.
Cut to children's storyteller in studio.
(sitting with large children's book, at desk)
(opens book; reads)
(reads silently, turns over page quickly, smiles)
(reads on silently; a stick enters vision and pokes him; he starts and turns over page)
(without looking up, reads a bit; then, incredulously to himself)
A hippo squashes the bunnies...and other things happen. Cut to a seaside beach. By a notice, 'Donkey Rides', run two men carrying a donkey. The compère addresses the camera.
Film clip of Women's Institute applauding. A couple are seated at a table in a restaurant.
(examines the fork)
(The Waiter runs off)
(runs off in a passion as the manager comes to the table)
(emotionally)
(in tears)
The cook comes in; he is very big and comes a meat cleaver.
(shouting)
(slams cleaver into the table)
The head waiter comes in and tries to restrain him.
(clutches his head in agony)
(stabs himself with the fork)
(goes completely mad)
(trying to restrain him)
(in pain)
(he and the cook fight furiously and fall over the table)
Boos of disgust from off-screen. Cut back to seaside.
The man from the sketch borrows the knight's chicken and hits commentator with it.

At this point, axes split open the studio door behind him. Through the hole, men with stockings over their heads leap in firing guns in all directions. The newsreader continues, unperturbed. Cut to marauders pushing the newsreader, still at his desk down a passage in the BBC. They rush him out of the TV Centre and onto the back of a lorry.>
(continuing)
(cut to lorry hurtling through London with newsreader still reading news on the back (facing backwards); cut to lorry hurtling through country lane and flashing past camera)
(cut to gang hoisting him on to the back of an open lorry, still in desk etc.)
(a long shot of a jetty; we see the gang still pushing the newsreader still on his desk along the jetty; they reach the end and push him over into the sea)
FX splash. Gurgle gurgle.
(and CAPTIONS:)
Picture of a larch tree.
(and CAPTIONS:)
Picture of a chestnut tree.
Film clip of cheering crowd. Then to inteviewer bending down to speak to children in playground.
(after much deliberation)
Roars of delighted pre-recorded laughter from unseen audience.
Laughter.
(bursting into tears)
Shrieks from unseen audience.
More shrieks.
(elbow gesture; rubs it)
(hand tilting quickly)
(leaning over to him, making eye gesture; speaks slowly)
(leans back as if having imparted a great secret)
(stops him with finger which he lays alongside nose; gives slight tap)
(leans across, looking away)
(about to speak; can't think of anything to say)
(leers, grinning)
(waggles head, leans across)
(slaps hands lightly twice)
Enourmous artificial laugh on sound track. Closing film, starting with referee blowing whistle and then into 'It's' man running away from camera.
ROLLER CAPTION: '"HOW TO RECOGNIZE DIFFERENT TYPES OF TREES FROM QUITE A LONG WAY AWAY" WAS CONCIEVED, WRITTEN AND PERFORMED BY...(CREDITS)'

title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 2

script.description: And now for something completely different. A man with three buttocks!

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Monty Python's Flying Circus.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: Good afternoon.

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text: Afternoon.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: A lovely day isn't it.

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text: Eh, 'tis that.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: You here on holiday or...?

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text: Nope, I live 'ere.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: Oh, jolly good too. I say, those sheep aren't they?

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text: Ar.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: Yes, yes of course, I thought so...only...er why are they up in the trees?

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text:
A fair question and one that in recent weeks has been much on
my mind. It's my considered opinion that they're nesting.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: Nesting?

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text: Ar.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: Like birds?

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text:
Ar. Exactly. Birds is the key to the whole problem. It's my belief that these sheep are laborin' under the misapprehension that they're birds. Observe their behavior. Take for a start the sheeps' tendency to 'op about the field
on their back legs. Now witness their attempts to fly from tree to tree. Notice that they do not so much fly as...plummet. Observe for example that ewe in that oak tree. She is clearly trying to teach her lamb to fly. Talk about the blind leading the blind.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: But why do they think they're birds?

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text: Another fair question. One thing is for sure; a sheep is not a creature of the air. They have enormous difficulty in the comparatively simple act of perchin'. As you see. As for flight, its body is totally unadapted to the problems of aviation. Trouble is, sheep are very dim. Once they get an idea in their heads, there's no shifting it.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: But where did they get the idea from?

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text: From Harold. He's that sheep there over under the elm. He's that most dangerous of animals, a clever sheep. He's the ring-leader. He has realized that a sheep's life consists of standing around for a few months and then being eaten. And that's a depressing prospect for an ambitious sheep. He's patently hit on the idea of escape.

dialogue.speaker: City Gent
dialogue.text: Well why don't you just get rid of Harold?

dialogue.speaker: Rustic
dialogue.text: Because of the enormous commercial possibilities should he succeed.

dialogue.speaker: First Frenchman
dialogue.text: Bonsoir - ici nous avons les diagrammes modernes d'un mouton anglo-français ... maintenant ... baa-aa, baa-aa... nous avons, dans la tête, le cabinc. Ici, on se trouve le petit capitaine Anglais, Monsieur Trubshawe.

dialogue.speaker: Second Frenchman
dialogue.text: Vive Brian, wherever you are.

dialogue.speaker: First Frenchman
dialogue.text: D'accord, d'accord. Maintenant, je vous présente mon collègue, le pouf célèbre, Jean-Brian Zatapathique.

dialogue.speaker: Second Frenchman
dialogue.text: Maintenant, le mouton ... le landing ... les wheels, bon.

dialogue.speaker: First Frenchman
dialogue.text: Bon, les wheels, ici.

dialogue.speaker: Second Frenchman
dialogue.text: C'est formidable, n'est ce pas ...

dialogue.speaker: First Frenchman
dialogue.text: Les voyageurs ... les bagages ... ils sont ... ici!

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oh yes, we get a lot of French people round here.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Ooh Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Third Pepperpot
dialogue.text: All over yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And how do you get on with these French people?

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oh very well.

dialogue.speaker: Fourth Pepperpot
dialogue.text: So do I.

dialogue.speaker: Third Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Me too.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Oh yes I like them. I mean, they think well don't they? I mean, be fair - Pascal.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Blaise Pascal.

dialogue.speaker: Third Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Jean-Paul Sartre.

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Yes, Voltaire.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Ooh! - René Descartes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Good evening, I have with me, Mr Arthur Frampton, who has...Mr. Frampton, I understand that you...er...as it were...have er...well, let me put it another way...I believe Mr. Frampton that whereas most people have - er - two...two...you...you

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Ah yes, yes I see...Um, Are you quite comfortable?

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: Yes fine, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, Mr Frampton... vis-à-vis...your...rump.

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, your rump.

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Your posterior....derriere...sit upon.

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: What's that?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: ...Buttocks.

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: Oh, me bum!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Sshhh! Well Mr. Frampton I understand Mr Frampton, you have a... 50% bonus in the...in the region of what you said.

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: I got three cheeks.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
Yes, yes, Splendid, splendid. Well...we were wondering, Mr Frampton,
if you...could...see your way clear...

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: Here? What's that camera doing?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Er, nothing, nothing at all, sir. We were wondering if you could see your way clear...to giving us...a quick... a quick... visual... Mr Frampton, will you take your trousers down?

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text:
What? 'Ere, get off! I'm not taking me
trousers down on television. Who do you think I am?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Please take them down.

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Just a little bit.

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text:
No, er ahem... Now look here Mr Frampton... It's perfectly easy for somebody just to
come along here to the BBC simply claiming... that they have a bit to spare in the
botty department...but the point is Mr. Frampton... our viewers need proof.

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: I've been on Persian Radio...Get off! Arthur Figgis knows I've got three buttocks.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: How?

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: We go cycling together.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely different. A man with three buttocks.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Good evening, I have with me, Mr Arthur Frampton, who... Mr. Frampton - I understand that you, as it were...well, let me put it another way...I believe Mr. Frampton that whereas most people...didn't we do this just now?

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: Er...yes.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well why didn't you so?

dialogue.speaker: Frampton
dialogue.text: I thought it was the continental version.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And now for something completely the same - a man with three buttocks. Hullo? ...Oh, did we. And now for something completely different. A man with three noses.

dialogue.speaker: Off-screen Voice
dialogue.text: He's not here yet!

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Two noses?

dialogue.speaker: Compère
dialogue.text: Ladies and gentlemen isn't she just great eh, wasn't she just great. Ha, ha, ha, and she can run as fast as she can sing, ha, ha, ha. And I'm telling you - 'cos I know. No, only kidding. Ha, ha, ha. Seriously now, ladies and gentlemen, we have for you one of the most unique acts in the world today. He's...well I'll say no more, just let you see for yourselves...ladies and gentlemen, my very great priviledge to introduve Arthur Ewing, and his musical mice.

dialogue.speaker: Ewing
dialogue.text: Thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you. Ladies and gentlemen. I have in this box twenty-three white mice. Mice which have been painstakingly trained over the past few years, to squeak at a selected pitch. This is E sharp... and this one is G. You get the general idea. Noe these mice are so arranged upon this rack, that when played in the correct order they will squeak 'The Bells of St Mary's'. Ladies and gentlemen, I give you on the mouse organ 'The Bells of St Mary's'. Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Next!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Are you the marriage guidance counsellor?

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Yes. Good morning

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Good morning, sir

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: And good morning to you madam Name?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Mr and Mrs Arthur Pewtey, Pewtey.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text:
And what is the
name of your ravishing wife? Wait. Don't tell me - it's something to do with moonlight - it goes with her eyes - it's soft and gentle, warm and yeilding, deeply lyrical and yet tender and frightened like a tiny whit rabbit

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: It's Deirdre

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text:
Deirdre. What a beautiful name. What a beautiful, beautiful name And what seems to be the trouble
with your marriage Mr Pewtey?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well, it all started about five years ago when we started going on holiday to Brighton together. Deirdre, that's my wife, has always been a jolly good companion to me and I never particularly anticipated any marital strife - indeed the very idea of consulting a professional marital adviser has always been of the greatest repugnance to me although far be it from me to impugn the nature of your trade or profession

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Do go on.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Well, as I say, we've always been good friends, sharing the interests, the gardening
and so on, the model aeroplanes, the sixpenny bottle for the holiday money, and indeed twice a
month settling down in the evenings doing the accounts, something which, er, Deirdre, Deirdre
that's my wife, er, particularly looked forward to on account of her feet I should probably have said at the outset that I'm noted for having something of a sense of humour, although I have kept myself very much to myself over the last two years notwithstanding, as it were, and it's only as comparatively recently that I began to realize - well, er prehaps realize is not the correct word, er, imagine, imagine, that I was not the only thing in her life

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: You suspected your wife?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Well yes - at first, frankly yes Her behaviour did seem at the time to me, who after all was there to see, to be a
little odd.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Odd?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Yes well, I mean to a certain extent yes. I'm not by nature a suspicious person - far
from it - though in fact I have something of a reputation as an after-dinner speaker, if you take
my meaning....

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Yes I certainly do

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Anyway in the area where I'm known people in fact know me extremely well....

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Oh yes. Would you hold this.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Certainly yes Anyway, as I said, I decided to face up to the facts and stop beating about the bush or I'd never
look myself in the bathroom mirror again.

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Er, look would you mind running along for ten minutes? Make it half an hour.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
No, no, right-ho, fine. Yes I'll wait outside shall I?... Yes, well that's p'raps the best things. Yes. You've certainly put my mind
at rest on one or two points, there.

dialogue.speaker: Southener
dialogue.text:
Now wait there stranger. A man can run and run for year after year until he realizes
     that what he's running from...is hisself

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Gosh.

dialogue.speaker: Southener
dialogue.text:
A man's got to do what a man's got to do, and there ain't no sense in runnin'. Now
     you gotta turn, and you gotta fight, and you gotta hold your head up high.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yes!

dialogue.speaker: Southener
dialogue.text: Now you go back in there my son and be a man. Walk tall.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Yes, I will. I will. I've been pushed around long enough. This is it. This is your monent
Arthur Pewtey - this is it Arthur Pewtey. At last you're a man! All right, Dierdre, come out of there

dialogue.speaker: Counsellor
dialogue.text: Go away

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Right. Right.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: So much for pathos.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: These historic pictures of Queen Victoria, taken in 1880 at Osborne show the Queen with Gladstone. This unique film provides a rare glimpse into the private world of a woman who ruled half the earth. The commentary, recorded on the earliest wax cylinders, is spoken by Alfred Lord Tennyson, the Poet Laureate. Well hello, it's the wacky Queen again! And who's the other fella? It's Willie Gladstone! And when these two way-out wacky characters get together there's fun a-plenty. And uh-oh! There's a hosepipe! This means trouble for somebody! Uh-oh, Charlie Gardener's fallen for that old trick. The Queen has put him in a of trouble! Uh-oh that's onein the eye for Willie! Here you have a go! Well, doggone it, where's the water? Uh-oh there it is, all over his face! Well, hello, what's Britain's wacky Queen up to now? Well, she's certainly not on the fence. She's it. Surely nothing can go wrong here? Uh-oh there's th PM coming back for more. And he certainly gets it! Well, that's one way to get the housework done!

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Oh dad... look who's come to see us... it's our Ken.

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: Aye, and about bloody time if you ask me.

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text: Aren't you pleased to see me, father?

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Of course he's pleased to see you, Ken, he...

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: All right, woman, all right I've got a tongue in my head - I'll do 'talkin'. Aye ... I like yer fancy suit. Is that what they're wearing up in Yorkshire now?

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text: It's just an ordinary suit, father... it's all I've got apart from the overalls.

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: How are you liking it down the mine, Ken?

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text:
Oh it's not too bad, mum... we're using some new tungsten carbide drills for the
     preliminary coal-face scouring operations.

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Oh that sounds nice, dear...

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: Tungsten carbide drills! What the bloody hell's tungsten carbide drills?

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text: It's something they use in coal-mining, father.

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: 'It's something they use in coal-mining, father'. You're all bloody fancy talk since you left London.

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text: Oh not that again.

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: He's had a hard day dear... his new play opens at the National Theatre tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text: Oh that's good.

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text:
Good! What do you know about it? What do you know about getting up at five
     o'clock in t'morning to fly to Paris... back at the Old Vic for drinks at twelve, sweating the day
     through press interviews, television interviews and getting back here at ten to wrestle with the
     problem of a homosexual nymphomaniac drug-addict involved in the ritual murder of a well
     known Scottish footballer. That's a full working day, lad, and don't you forget it!

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Oh, don't shout at the boy, father.

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text:
Aye, 'ampstead wasn't good enough for you, was it? ... you had to go poncing off to
     Barnsley, you and yer coal-mining friends.

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text:
Coal-mining is a wonderful thing father, but it's something you'll never understand. Just
     look at you!

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Oh Ken! Be careful! You know what he's like after a few novels.

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: Oh come on lad! Come on, out wi' it! What's wrong wi' me?... yet !

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text:
I'll tell you what's wrong with you. Your head's addled with novels and poems, you come
     home every evening reeling of Chateau La Tour...

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Oh don't, don't.

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text:
And look what you've done to mother! She's worn out with meeting film stars, attending
     premieres and giving gala luncheons...

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text:
There's nowt wrong wi' gala luncheons, lad! I've had more gala luncheons than you've
     had hot dinners!

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Oh please!

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: Aaaaaaagh!

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Oh no!

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Oh, it's his writer's cramp!

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text: You never told me about this...

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: No, we didn't like to, Kenny.

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: I'm all right! I'm all right, woman. Just get him out of here.

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text: Oh Ken! You'd better go ...

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text: All right. I'm going.

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: After all we've done for him...

dialogue.speaker: Ken
dialogue.text: One day you'll realize there's more to life than culture... There's dirt, and smoke, and good honest sweat!

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: Get out! Get out! Get OUT! You ... LABOURER!

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: Hey, you know, mother, I think there's a play there .... get t'agent on t'phone.

dialogue.speaker: Mum
dialogue.text:
Aye I think you're right, Frank, it could express, it could express a vital theme of our
     age...

dialogue.speaker: Dad
dialogue.text: Aye.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh shut up! Shut up! Oh, that's better. And now for something completely different ... a man with three buttocks...

dialogue.speaker: Mum and Dad
dialogue.text: We've done that!

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh all right. All right! A man with nine legs.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Off
dialogue.text: He ran away.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Oh... Bloody Hell! Er ... a Scotsman on a horse!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Harold! Come back, Harold! Harold! Come back, Harold! Oh, blast!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Good evening, and welcome once again to the Epilogue. On the programme this evening we have Monsignor Edward Gay, visiting Pastoral Emissary of the Somerset Theological College and author of a number of books about belief, the most recent of which is the best seller 'My God'. And opposite him we have Dr Tom Jack: humanist, broadcaster, lecturer and author of the book 'Hello Sailor'. Tonight, instead of discussing the existence or non-existence of God, they have decided to fight for it. The existence, or non-existence, to be determined by two falls, two submissions, or a knockout. All right boys, let's get to it. Your master of ceremonies for this evening - Mr Arthur Waring.

dialogue.speaker: MC
dialogue.text: Good evening ladies and gentlemen and welcome to a three-round contest of the Epilogue. Introducing on my right in the blue corner, appearing for Jehovah - the ever popular Monsignor Eddie Gay. And on my left in the red corner - author of the books 'The Problems of Kierkegaard' and 'Hello Sailor' and visiting Professor of Modern Theological Philosophy at the University of East Anglia - from Wigan - Dr Tom Jack!

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Now Dr Jack's got a flying mare there. A flying mare there, and this is going to be a full body slam. A full body slam, and he's laying it in there, and he's standing back. Well .. there we are leaving the Epilogue for the moment, we'll be bringing you the result of this discussion later on in the programme.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Oh my God!

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Yes. The Mouse Problem. This week 'The World Around Us' looks at the growing social phenomenon of Mice and Men. What makes a man want to be a mouse.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well it's not a question of wanting to be a mouse... it just sort of happens to you. All of a sudden you realize... that's what you want to be.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And when did you first notice these... shall we say... tendencies?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Well... I was about seventeen and some mates and me went to a party, and, er...
     we had quite a lot to drink... and then some of the fellows there ... started handing ... cheese
     around ... and well just out of curiosity I tried a bit ... and well that was that.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And what else did these fellows do?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text:
Well some of them started dressing up as mice a bit ... and then when they'd got
     the costumes on they started ... squeaking.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes. And was that all?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: That was all.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: And what was your reaction to this?

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well I was shocked. But, er... gradually I came to feel that I was more at ease ... with other mice.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: A typical case, whom we shall refer to as Mr A, although his real name is this:

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: ARTHUR JACKSON 32A MILTON AVENUE, HOUNSLOW, MIDDLESEX.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: What is it that attracts someone like mr. A to this way of life? I have with me a consultant psychiatrist.

dialogue.speaker: Kargol
dialogue.text: Well, we've just heard a typical case history. I myself have over seven hundred similar histories, all fully documented. Would you care to choose one?

dialogue.speaker: Kargol
dialogue.text: Mr Arthur Aldridge of Leamington.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Well, that's amazing, amazing. Thank you, Janet. Kargol, speaking as a psychiatrist as opposed to a conjuror...

dialogue.speaker: Kargol
dialogue.text: Oh...

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: ...what makes certain men want to be mice?

dialogue.speaker: Kargol
dialogue.text: Well, we psychiatrist have found that over 8% of the population will always be mice, I mean, after all, there's something of the mouse in all of us. I mean, how many of us can honestly say that at one time or another he hasn't felt sexually attracted to mice. I know I have. I mean, most normal adolescents go through a stage of squeaking two or three times a day. Some youngsters on the other hand, are attracted to it by its very illegality. It's like murder - make a thing illegal and it acquires a mystique. Look at arson - I mean, how many of us can honestly say that at one time or another he hasn't set fire to some great public building. I know I have. The only way to bring the crime figures down is to reduce the number of offences - get it out in the open - I know I have.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text:
The Amazing Kargol And Janet.
 What a lot of people don't realize is that a mouse, once accepted, can fulfil a very useful role in society. Indeed there are examples throughout history of famous men now known to have been mice.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: And, of course, Hillaire Belloc. But what is the attitude...

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: ... of the man in the street towards...

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: ... this growing social problem?

dialogue.speaker: Window Cleaner
dialogue.text: Clamp down on them.

dialogue.speaker: Off-screen Voice
dialogue.text: How?

dialogue.speaker: Window Cleaner
dialogue.text: I'd strangle them.

dialogue.speaker: Stockbroker
dialogue.text: Well speaking as a member of the Stock Exchange I would suck their brains out with a straw, sell the widows and orphans and go into South American Zinc.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Yeh I'd, er, stuff sparrows down their throats, er, until the beaks stuck out through the, er, stomach walls.

dialogue.speaker: Accountant
dialogue.text: Oh well I'm a chartered accountant, and consequently too boring to be of interest.

dialogue.speaker: Vicar
dialogue.text: I feel that these poor unfortunate people should be free to live the lives of their own choice.

dialogue.speaker: Porter
dialogue.text: I'd split their nostrils open with a boat hook, I think.

dialogue.speaker: Man
dialogue.text: Well I mean, they can't help it, can they? But, er, there's nothing you can do about it. So er, I'd kill 'em.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Clearly the British public's view is a hostile one.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 'HOSTILE'

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text:
But perhaps this is because so little is generally known of these mice men. We have
     some film now taken of one of the notorious weekend mouse parties, where these disgusting
     little perverts meet.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman's Voice
dialogue.text: Mr A tells us what actually goes on at these mouse parties.

dialogue.speaker: Mr A
dialogue.text:
Well first of all you get shown to your own private hole in the skirting board... then you
     put the mouse skin on... then you scurry into the main room, and perhaps take a run in the
     wheel.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text:
The remainder of this film was taken secretly at one of these mouse parties by a
     BBC cameraman posing as a vole. As usual we apologize for the poor quality of the film.

dialogue.speaker: Mr A's Voice
dialogue.text:
Well, er, then you steal some cheese, Brie or Camembert, or Cheddar or
     Gouda, if you're on the harder stuff. You might go and see one of the blue cheese films...
     there's a big clock in the middle of the room, and about 12:50 you climb up it and then
     ...eventually, it strikes one... and you all run down.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman's Voice
dialogue.text: And what's that?

dialogue.speaker: Mr A's Voice
dialogue.text: That's the farmer's wife.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text:
Perhaps we need to know more of these mice men before we can really judge
     them. Perhaps not. Anyway, our thirty minutes are up.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Goodnight.

script.description: CAPTION: 'SEX AND VIOLENCE' WAS CONCIEVED, WRITTEN AND PERFORMED BY:... (CREDITS)'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: And here is the result of the Epilogue: God exists by two falls to a submission

annotations: A man appears on the top of a sand dune some way away. He loks in direction of camera and runs towards it. He disappears on top of a closer dune and continues towards camera disappearing again into a dip. This time while he is out of sight, the sound of him running is the sound of someone running along a prison corridor, followed by a big door opening and closing.He appears again only two sand dunes away. Still running towards camera he disappears again from sight. This time there is a loud metallic series of sounds followed by a pig squealing. He appears over the nearest dune and runs up to camera.

These words are followed by various strange images, possibly connected with the stretching of owls, and proceeding from a bizarre Amerian immigrant's feveral brain. At the end of this expensive therapy:

A small set of a gate in the country overlooking a field. A real rustic in smock and floppy hat is leaning on the gate. A city gent on holiday appears behind him. Off-screen baa-ing noises throughout.
(surveys field; he looks puzzled)
(off-screen baa-ing)

(baaaaaa...thump)

Two Frenchmen stand in front of a diagram of a sheep adapted for flying. They speak rapidly in French, much of it pseudo.
Transfers his moustache to Second Frenchman
Opens diagram to show wheels on sheep's legs.
(unintelligibly indicates motor at rear of sheep)
Triumphantly opens the rest of the diagram to reveal the whole brilliant arrangement. They run round flapping their arms and baa-ing. Cut to pepperpots in supermarket with off-screen interviewer.

René Descartes is sitting thinking. Bubbles come from his head with 'thinks'. Suddenly he looks happy. In thought bubble appears 'I THINK THEREFORE I AM'. A large hand comes into the picture with a pin and pricks the thought bubble. It deflates and disappears. After a second René disappears too.
Studio: Smart looking and confident announcer sitting at desk.
Interviewer and Arthur Frampton, in interview studio.

(whispers)
(seeing a camera moving round behind him)
(slapping away a hand from off-screen)
(firmly)
Cut to shot of two men riding tandem. The one behind (Graham) looks down, looks up and exclaims 'strewth'.
Announcer's desk: confident announcer again.
Interview studio again.
Announcer's desk: confident announcer.
(phone on desk rings - he answers it)
(puts phone down; to camera)

Stock shot of audience of Woman's Institute type, applauding. A man flourishing a handferchief blows his nose. Then he puts his handkerchief inside his shirt and blows again. Stock shot of women applauding again.
Cut to Ewing
(he raises a mouse by its tail)

He produces two mallets. He starts striking the mice while singing quietly 'The Bells of St Mary's'. Each downward stroke of the mallet brings a terribly squashing sound and the expiring squeak. It is quite clear that he is slaughtering the mice. The musical effect is poor. After the first few notes people are shouting 'Stop it, stop him someone, Oh my God'. He cheerfully takes a bow. He is hauled off by the floor manager.
A little man enters, with a beautiful blond buxom wench, in the full bloom of her young womanhood (Carol Cleveland)
(stares at the wife, fascinated)

(pauses,
he shrugs himself out of it, says to man...)
(writes without looking down, just stares at the wife)
(holds up hand)

and lightly brushes his hand accross the wife's cheek)
The counsellor and wife are not listening, fascinated by each other.
(realizing Pewtey has stopped)

(the counsellor has his
face fantastically close to the wife's, as close that they could get without kissing)
(who is practically in a clinch with her)

behind it)
A piece of his wife's clothing comes over the top of the screen.
The wife's bra and panties come over the screen.
(taking his jacket off)
(helps him with it; the counsellor continues to undress)
(down to his shorts)

(the cousellor has already gone
behind the screen)
Exits through door. He is stopped by a deep southern American voice.
(he exits)
(open the door very determinedly)
He is hit on the head with a chicken by a man in a suit of armour.

Queen Victoria Film: the texture of the film reproduces as accurately as possible an animated Victorian photograph. Queen Victoria (Terry J) and Gladstone (Graham) are walking on the lawn in front of Osborne.
(Michael continues with jolly Amarican accent)
(the Queen repeatedly nudges Gladstone in the ribs and chucks him under the ribs)
(they come up to a gardener with a hose pipe)
(the Queen takes the hose and kicks the gardener; he falls over)
(the Queen turns the hose on Gladstone)
(the Queen hands Gladstone the hose)
(she goes back to the tab and turns off the water)
(Gladstone examines the end of the hose; the water flow returns, spraying him)
(she lifts her skirts and runs as he chases her across the lawn; next we see the Queen painting a fence; Gladstone approaches from the other side)
(Gladstone walks into line with the end of the fence; the Queen daubs paint on him)
(he takes the bucket from her and empties it over her head; she kicks him; he falls through the fence)

Cut to the Queen and Gladstone having tea on the lawn. She pushes a custard pie into his face. As he retaliates the picture freezes; the camera pulls back to reveal that it is a photo on the mantelpiece of a working-class sitting room.
(without looking up)

(looks at Ken
distastefully)
Dad turns away with an expression of scornful disgust.
(mimicking)
(spits)

(at the door)
Ken goes. Shocked silence. Dad goes to table and takes the cover off the typewriter.

In the room beneath a man is standing on a chair banging on the ceiling with a

(bang bang)
(they stop talking upstairs)

The man looks up slightly disconcerted.
Cut to film of a Scotsman (John) riding up on a horse. He looks around, puzzled.
Cut to stock film of Women's Institute audience applauding.
Cut to the man with two noses (Graham); he puts a handkerchief to his elbow and we hear the sound of a nose being blown.

Interview studio; interviewer in the middle. There is a monsignor in full clerical garb with skull-cap, and opposite him a tweed-suite, old Don figure.
The partialpants move into a wrestling ring.

They are real wrestlers. They throw each other about.

We see a cowboy just having been shot. This leads into cartoon film, which include a carnivorous pram and music from Rodin's statue 'The Kiss'. Then a protest march appears carrying banners. Close in on banners which read: End Discrimination:Mice Is Nice; Ho Ho Ho Traps Must Go; Hands Off Mice; Repeal Anti-Mouse Laws Now; Kidderminster Young Methodists Resent Oppression: A Fair Deal For Mice Men.
Photo of newspaper headlines: Pop Stars In Mouse Scandal; Peer Faces Rodent Charges. A man in a mouse skin running into police station with bag over head.
Cut to a policeman leading a man in mouse costume into a police station. Photo of headline: Mouse Clubs On Increase.
Cut to: photos of neon signs of clubs: Eek Eek Club; The Little White Rodent Room; Caerphilly A Go-Go.

Interviewer, Harold Voice, sitting facing a confessor. The confessor is badly lit and is

The camera pulls back to reveal the psychiatrist who places in front og himself a notice saying 'The Amazing Kargol And Janet'.
Janet (Carol), dressed in a showgirl's outfit, enters and offers linkman the case histories fanned out like cards, with one more prominent than the others; he picks it out.

Cut to julius Caesar on beach. He shouts 'Veni Vidi, Vici'. Then he adds a furtive

Cut to Linkman
Cut to man in a Viking helmet.
(Eric Idle)
Vox pops films.

Cut to exterior house (night). The blinds are drawn so that only shadows of enormous

Cut to Mr A.
Very, poor quality film, shadowy shapes, the odd mouse glimpsed.
