title: Monty Python's Flying Circus: Just the Words - Episode 1

dialogue.speaker: It's Man
dialogue.text: It's...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Monty Python's Flying Circus.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Mozart
dialogue.text:
Hello again, and welcome to the show. Tonight we continue to look at some famous
deaths. Tonight we start with the wonderful death of Genghis Khan, conqueror of India. Take
it away Genghis.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: 9.1, 9.3, 9.7, that's 28.1 for Genghis Khan.

dialogue.speaker: Mozart
dialogue.text: Bad luck Genghis. Nice to have you on the show. And now here are the scores.

dialogue.speaker: St Stephan
dialogue.text: 29.9 Richard III 29.3 Jean D'arc 29.1 Marat 29.0 A. Lincoln (U.S of A) 28.2 G. Khan 28.1 King Edward VII 3.1

dialogue.speaker: Eddie
dialogue.text:
Well there you can see the scores now. St Stephen in the lead there with his stoning,
then comes King Richard the Third at Bosworth Field, a grand death that, then the very lovely
Jean d'Arc, then Marat in his bath - best of friends with Charlotte in the showers afterwards -
then A. Lincoln of the U.S of A, a grand little chap that, and number six Genghis Khan, and
the back marker King Edward the Seventh. Back to you, Wolfgang.

dialogue.speaker: Mozart
dialogue.text: Thank you, Eddie. And now time for this week's request death. For Mr and Mrs Violet Stebbings of 23 Wolverston Road, Hull, the death of Mr Bruce Foster of Guildford.

dialogue.speaker: Foster
dialogue.text: Strewth!

dialogue.speaker: Mozart
dialogue.text: Oh blimey, how time flies. Sadly we are reaching the end of yet another programme and so it is finale time. We are proud to be bringing to you one of the evergreen bucket kickers. Yes, the wonderful death of the famous English Admiral Nelson.

dialogue.speaker: Nelson
dialogue.text: Kiss me Hardy!

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Ah - good evening everyone, and welcome to the second of our Italian language classes, in which we'll be helping you brush up your Italian. Last week we started at the beginning, and we learnt the Italian for a 'spoon'. Now, I wonder how many of you can remember what it was?

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Not all at once ... sit down Mario. Giuseppe!

dialogue.speaker: Giuseppe
dialogue.text: Il cucchiaio.

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Well done Giuseppe, or, as the Italians would say: 'Molto bene, Giuseppe'.

dialogue.speaker: Giuseppe
dialogue.text: Grazie signor ... grazie di tutta la sua gentilezza.

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Well, now, this week we're going to learn some useful phrases to help us open a conversation with an Italian. Now first of all try telling him where you come from. For example, I would say: 'Sono Inglese di Gerrard's Cross', I am an Englishman from Gerrard's Cross. Shall we all try that together?

dialogue.speaker: All
dialogue.text: Sono Inglese di Gerrard's Cross.

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Not too bad, now let's try it with somebody else. Er... Mr... ?

dialogue.speaker: Mariolini
dialogue.text: Mariolini.

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Ah, Mr Mariolini, and where are you from?

dialogue.speaker: Mariolini
dialogue.text: Napoli, signor.

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Ah ... you're an Italian.

dialogue.speaker: Mariolini
dialogue.text: Si, si signor!

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Well in that case you would say: 'Sono Italiano di Napoli'.

dialogue.speaker: Mariolini
dialogue.text: Ah, capisco, mile grazie signor...

dialogue.speaker: Francesco
dialogue.text: Per favore, signor!

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Yes?

dialogue.speaker: Francesco
dialogue.text: Non conosgeve parliamente, signor devo me parlo sono Italiano di Napoli quando il habitare de Milano.

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: I'm sorry ... I don't understand!

dialogue.speaker: Giuseppe
dialogue.text: My friend say 'Why must he say...'

dialogue.speaker: German
dialogue.text: Bitte mein Herr. Was ist das Won für Mittelschmerz?

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Ah! Helmut - you want the German classes.

dialogue.speaker: German
dialogue.text: Oh ja! Danke schön. Ah das deutsche Klassenzimmer... Ach!

dialogue.speaker: Giuseppe
dialogue.text: My friend he say, 'Why must I say I am Italian from Napoli when he lives in Milan?'

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Ah, I... well, tell your friend ... if he lives in Milan he must say 'Sono Italiano di Milano...'

dialogue.speaker: Francesco
dialogue.text: Eeeeeee! Milano è tanto meglio di Napoli. Milano è la citta la più bella di tutti ... nel mondo...

dialogue.speaker: Giuseppe
dialogue.text: He say 'Milan is better than Napoli'.

dialogue.speaker: Teacher
dialogue.text: Oh, he shouldn't be saying that, we haven't done comparatives yet.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Yes, mothers, new improved Whizzo butter containing 10% more or less is absolutely indistinguishable from a dead crab. Remember, buy Whizzo butter and go to HEAVEN!

dialogue.speaker: First Pepperpot
dialogue.text: I can't tell the difference between Whizzo butter and this dead crab.

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, you know, we find that nine out of ten British housewives can't tell the difference between Whizzo butter and a dead crab.

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpots
dialogue.text: It's true, we can't. No.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: Here. Here! You're on television, aren't you?

dialogue.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Second Pepperpot
dialogue.text: He does the thing with one of those silly women who can't tell Whizzo butter from a dead crab.

dialogue.speaker: Third Pepperpot
dialogue.text: You try that around here, young man, and we'll slit your face.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Good evening and welcome to another edition of 'It's the Arts'. And we kick off this evening with the cinema.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Good evening. One of the most prolific film directors of this age, or indeed of any age, is Sir Edward Ross, back in his native country for the first time for five years to open a season of his works at the National Film Theatre, and we are very fortunate to have him with us in this studio this evening.

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Edward... you don't mind if I call you Edward?

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: No, not at all.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Only it does worry some people - I don't know why...but they are a little sensitive so I take the precaution of asking on these occasions.

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: No, no, no that's fine.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: So Edward's all right. Splendid. Splendid. I'm sorry to have brought it up, only eh...

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: No, no, please. Edward it is.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well thank you very much for being so helpful...only it's more than my job's worth to...er...

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: Quite, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Makes it rather difficult to establish a rapport ... to put the other person at his ease...

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: Quite.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, silly little point but it does seem to matter. Still - less said the better. Uh...Ted...when you first started in...you don't mind if I call you Ted?

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: No, no, no everyone calls me Ted.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Well it's shorter, isn't it.

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, and much less formal!

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: Yes, Ted, Edward, anything!

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Splendid, splendid. Incidentally, do call me Tom, I don't want you playing around with any of this 'Thomas' nonsense! Ha ha ha ha! Now where were we? Ah yes. Eddie-baby, when you first started in the...

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, but I don't like being called 'Eddie-baby'.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: I'm sorry?

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: I don't like being called 'Eddie-baby'.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Did I call you 'Eddie-baby'?

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: Yes, you did! Now get on with it.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: I don't think I did call you Eddie-baby.

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: You did call me Eddie-baby.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: ( ) Did I call him Eddie-baby?

dialogue.speaker: Voices
dialogue.text: Yes. No. Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: I didn't really call you Eddie-baby, did I, sweetie?

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: Don't call me sweetie!!

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Can I call you sugar plum?

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Pussy cat?

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Angel-drawers?

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: No you may not! Now get on with it!

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Can I call you 'Frank'?

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: Why Frank?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: It's a nice name. Robin Day's got a hedgehog called Frank.

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: What is going on?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Frannie, little Frannie, Frannie Knickers...

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: ( ) No. I'm leaving. I'm leaving. I'm off...

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Tell us about your latest film, Sir Edward.

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: ( ) What?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Tell us about your latest film, if you'd be so very kind, Sir Edward.

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: None of this 'pussy cat' nonsense?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Promise. Please, Sir Edward.

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: My latest film?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, Sir Edward.

dialogue.speaker: Ross
dialogue.text: Well the idea, funnily enough, came from an idea I had when I first joined the industry in 1919. Of course, in those days I was only the tea boy.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Oh, up.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Sir Edward...Ross. Now, later in the programme we will be bringing you a unique event in the world of modern art. Pablo Picasso will be doing a special painting for us, on this programme, live, on a bicycle. But right now it's time to look at a man whose meteoric rise to fame...

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Last week the Royal Festival Hall saw the first performance of a new symphony by one of the world's leading modern composers, Arthur 'Two Sheds' Jackson. Mr Jackson.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: Good evening.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text:
May I just sidetrack for one moment. Mr. Jackson, this, what shall I call it,
nickname of yours.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: Ah yes.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: 'Two sheds'. How did you come by it?

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: Well, I don't use it myself, it's just a few of my friends call me 'Two Sheds'.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: I see, and do you in fact have two sheds?

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: No. No, I've only one shed. I've had one for some time, but a few years ago I said I was thinking of getting another one, and since then some people have called me 'Two Sheds'.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: In spite of the fact that you only have one.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: I see, and are you thinking of purchasing a second shed?

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: To bring you in line with your epithet?

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: I see, I see. Well let's return to your symphony. Ah, now then, did you write this symphony... the shed?

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: No!

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Have you written any of your recent works in this shed of yours?

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: No it's just a perfectly ordinary garden shed.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: I see. And you're thinking of buying this second shed to write in.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: No, no. Look. This shed business, it doesn't really matter at all, the sheds aren't important. It's just a few friends call me Two Sheds and that's all there is to it. I wish you'd ask me about my music. I'm a composer. People always ask me about the sheds, they've got it out of proportion, I'm fed up with the shed, I wish I'd never got it in the first place.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: I expect you are probably thinking of selling one.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: I will sell one.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Then you'll be Arthur 'No Sheds' Jackson?

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: Look, forget about the sheds. They don't matter.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Mr. Jackson, I think, with respect, we ought to talk about your symphony.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Apparently your symphony was written for organ and tympani.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: What's that?

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: What's what?

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: It's a shed. Get it off.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Now then Mr. Jackson...your symphony.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: I understand that you used to be interested in train-spotting.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: I understand that, about thirty years ago, you were extremely interested in train-spotting.

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: What's that got to do with my bloody music?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Are you having any trouble from him?

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, a little.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Exactly. Well we interviewers are more than a match for the likes of you, 'Two Sheds'.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Yes, make yourself scarce, 'Two Sheds'. This studio isn't big enough for the three of us!

dialogue.speaker: Jackson
dialogue.text: What are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Get your own Arts programme, you fairy!

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Arthur 'Two Sheds' Jackson.

dialogue.speaker: Third Interviewer
dialogue.text: Never mind, Timmy.

dialogue.speaker: Second Interviewer
dialogue.text: Oh, Michael, you are such a comfort.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Arthur 'Two Sheds'...

dialogue.speaker: Viking
dialogue.text: ...Jackson.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text:
And now for more news of the momentous artistic event in which Pablo Picasso is doing a specially commissioned painting for us whilst riding a bicycle. Pablo Picasso - the founder of modern art - without doubt the greatest abstract painter ever... for
the first time painting in motion. But first of all let's have a look at the route he'll be taking.

dialogue.speaker: Baxter
dialogue.text: Well Picasso will be starting, David, at Chichester here, he'll then cycle on the A29 to Fontwell, he'll then take the A272 which will bring him on to the A3 just north of Hindhead here. From then on Pablo has a straight run on the A3 until he meets the South Circular at Battersea here. Well, this is a truly remarkable occasion as it is the first time that a modern artist of such stature has taken the A272, and it'll be very interesting to see how he copes with the heavy traffic round Wisborough Green. Vicky.

dialogue.speaker: Vicky
dialogue.text: Well Picasso will be riding his Viking Super Roadster with the drop handlebars and the dual-thread wheel-rims and with his Wiley-Prat 20-1 synchro-mesh he should experience difficulties on the sort of road surfaces they just don't get abroad. Mitzie.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: And now for the latest report on Picasso's progress over to Reg Moss on the Guildford by-pass.

dialogue.speaker: Reg Moss
dialogue.text: Well there's no sign of Picasso at the moment, David. But he should be through here at any moment. However I do have with me Mr Ron Geppo, British Cycling Sprint Champion and this year's winner of the Derby-Doncaster rally.

dialogue.speaker: Geppo
dialogue.text: Well Reg, I think Pablo should be all right provided he doesn't attempt anything on the monumental scale of some of his earlier paintings, like Guernica or Mademoiselles d'Avignon or even his later War and Peace murals for the Temple of Peace chapel at Vallauris, because with this strong head wind I don't think even Doug Timpson of Manchester Harriers could paint anything on that kind of scale.

dialogue.speaker: Reg Moss
dialogue.text: Well, thank you Ron. Well, there still seems to be no sign of Picasso, so I'll hand you back to the studio.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Well, we've just heard that Picasso is approaching the Tolworth roundabout on the A3 so come in Sam Trench at Tolworth.

dialogue.speaker: Trench
dialogue.text: Well something certainly is happening here at Tolworth roundabout, David. I can now see Picasso, he's cycling down very hard towards the roundabout, he's about 75-50 yards away and I can now see his painting... it's an abstract... I can see some blue some purple and some little black oval shapes... I think I can see...

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: That's not Picasso - that's Kandinsky.

dialogue.speaker: Trench
dialogue.text: Good lord, you're right. It's Kandinsky. Wassily Kandinsky, and who's this here with him? It's Braque. Georges Braque, the Cubist, painting a bird in flight over a cornfield and going very fast down the hill towards Kingston and... Piet Mondrian - just behind, Piet Mondrian the Neo-Plasticist, and then a gap, then the main bunch, here they come, Chagall, Max Ernst, Miro, Dufy, Ben Nicholson, Jackson Pollock and Bernard Buffet making a break on the outside here, Brancusi's going with him, so is Gericault, Ferdinand Leger, Delaunay, De Kooning, Kokoschka's dropping back here by the look of it, and so's Paul Klee dropping back a bit and, right at the back of this group, our very own Kurt Schwitters..

dialogue.speaker: Pepperpot
dialogue.text: He's German!

dialogue.speaker: Trench
dialogue.text: But as yet absolutely no sign of Pablo Picasso, and so from Tolworth roundabout back to the studio.

dialogue.speaker: Linkman
dialogue.text: Well I think I can help you there Sam, we're getting reports in from the AA that Picasso, Picasso has fallen off...he's fallen off his bicycle on the B2127 just outside Ewhurst, trying to get a short cut through to Dorking via Gomslake and Peashall. Well, Picasso is reported to be unhurt, but the pig has a slight headache. And on that note we must say goodnight to you. Picasso has failed in his first bid for international cycling fame. So from all of us here at the 'It's the Arts' studio, it's goodnight. Goodnight.

dialogue.speaker: Private
dialogue.text: Dobson's bought it, sir.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Porker, eh? Swine.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: This man is Ernest Scribbler... writer of jokes. In a few moments, he will have written the funniest joke in the world... and, as a consequence, he will die ... laughing.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: It was obvious that this joke was lethal... no one could read it and live ...

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: This morning, shortly after eleven o'clock, comedy struck this little house in Dibley Road. Sudden ...violent ... comedy. Police have sealed off the area, and Scotland Yard's crack inspector is with me now.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: I shall enter the house and attempt to remove the joke.

dialogue.speaker: Inspector
dialogue.text: I shall be aided by the sound of sombre music, played on gramophone records, and also by the chanting of laments by the men of Q Division ... The atmosphere thus created should protect me in the eventuality of me reading the joke.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: There goes a brave man. Whether he comes out alive or not, this will surely be remembered as one of the most courageous and gallant acts in police history.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: It was not long before the Army became interested in the military potential of the Killer Joke. Under top security, the joke was hurried to a meeting of Allied Commanders at the Ministry of War.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: Top brass were impressed. Tests on Salisbury Plain confirmed the joke's devastating effectiveness at a range of up to fifty yards.

dialogue.speaker: Generals
dialogue.text: Fantastic.

dialogue.speaker: Colonel
dialogue.text: All through the winter of '43 we had translators working, in joke-proof conditions, to try and produce a German version of the joke. They worked on one word each for greater safety. One of them saw two words of the joke and spent several weeks in hospital. But apart from that things went pretty quickly, and we soon had the joke by January, in a form which our troops couldn't understand but which the Germans could.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: So, on July 8th, 1944, the joke was first told to the enemy in the Ardennes...

dialogue.speaker: Commanding NCO
dialogue.text: Tell the ... joke.

dialogue.speaker: Joke Brigade
dialogue.text:
Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! ...
     Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput!

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text:
It was a fantastic success. Over sixty thousand times as powerful as
     Britain's great pre-war joke ...

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: ...and one which Hitler just couldn't match.

script.description: SUBTITLE 'MY DOG'S GOT NO NOSE' SUBTITLE: HOW DOES HE SMELL? SUBTITLE: AWFUL'

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: In action it was deadly.

dialogue.speaker: Joke Corporal
dialogue.text: Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! .. Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput!

dialogue.speaker: Joke Brigade
dialogue.text: Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! ... Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: The German casualties were appalling.

dialogue.speaker: Nazi
dialogue.text: Vott is the big joke?

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: I can only give you name, rank, and why did the chicken cross the road?

dialogue.speaker: Nazi
dialogue.text: That's not funny! I vant to know the joke.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: All right. How do you make a Nazi cross?

dialogue.speaker: Nazi
dialogue.text: I don't know ... how do you make a Nazi cross?

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Tread on his corns.

dialogue.speaker: Nazi
dialogue.text: Gott in Himmel! That's not funny! Now if you don't tell me the joke, I shall hit you properly.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: I can stand physical pain, you know.

dialogue.speaker: Nazi
dialogue.text: Ah ... you're no fun. All right, Otto.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Oh no - anything but that please no, all right I'll tell you.

dialogue.speaker: Nazi
dialogue.text: Quick Otto. The typewriter.

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! ... Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput.

dialogue.speaker: Nazi
dialogue.text: Ach! Zat iss not funny!

dialogue.speaker: Officer
dialogue.text: Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! ... Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But at Peenemunde in the Autumn of '44, the Germans were working on a joke of their own.

dialogue.speaker: German Joker
dialogue.text: Die ist ein Kinnerhunder und zwei Mackel über und der bitte schön ist den Wunderhaus sprechensie. 'Nein' sprecht der Herren 'Ist aufern borger mit zveitingen'.

dialogue.speaker: Otto
dialogue.text: We let you know.

dialogue.speaker: Voice Over
dialogue.text: But by December their joke was ready, and Hitler gave the order for the German V-Joke to be broadcast in English.

dialogue.speaker: Radio
dialogue.text:
Der ver zwei peanuts, valking down der strasse, and von
     vas... assaulted! peanut. Ho-ho-ho-ho.

dialogue.speaker: Commentator
dialogue.text: In 1945 Peace broke out. It was the end of the Joke. Joke warfare was banned at a special session of the Geneva Convention, and in 1950 the last remaining copy of the joke was laid to rest here in the Berkshire countryside, never to be told again.

dialogue.speaker: Announcer
dialogue.text: And here is the final score: Pigs 9 - British Bipeds 4. The Pigs go on to meet Vicki Carr in the final.

annotations:
A seashore. Some way out to sea a ragged man is struggling his way to shore. Slowly and with
difficulty he makes his way up onto the beach, flops down exhausted and announces:
Titles beginning with words "Monty Python's Flying Circus". Various bizarre things happen. When titles end:
Ordinary grey-suited announcer standing by desk. He smiles confidently.
The announcer confidently moves to chair and sits down. There is a squeal as of a pig being sat upon.
Cut to a blackboard with several lines of pigs drawn on it in colour. A man steps into view and with a piece of chalk crosses out one of the pigs
Mozart sitting at piano tinkling with the keys. He finishes tinkling.

Cut to Genghis Khan's tent. Genghis strides about purposefully. Indian-style
background music. Suddenly the music cuts out and Genghis Khan with a squawk
throws himself in the air and lands on his back. This happens very suddenly. Judges
hold up cards with points on, in the manner of ice skating judges.
Mozart still at piano.
Scoreboard with Eddie Waring figure standing by it. The scoreboard looks a little like this:
Mozart still at piano.
(taking card off piano)
Cut to a lounge setting. Mr Foster sitting in chair.
(he dies)
Mozart still there. He looks at watch.
Cut to a modern office block, as high as possible. After a pause a body flies out of the top window looking as much like Nelson as possible. As it plummets there is a strangled scream.
The body hits the ground. There is the loud noise of a pig squealing.
Shout of 'Si! Si! Si!' from the class whom we see are all Italians.
(pointing to Francesco)
Hand goes up at back of room and a Lederhosen Teutonic figure stands up.
(he starts to leave)
(he leaves)
(agitatedly, leaping to his feet)

In the background everyone has started talking in agitated Italian. At this point a genuine mandolin-playing Italian secreted amongst the cast strikes up: 'Quando Caliente Del Sol...' or similar. The class is out of control by this time. The teacher helplessly tries to control then but eventually gives up and retreats to his desk and sits down. There is a loud pig squeal and he leaps up.

The Blackboard with the coloured pigs drawn on it, is reproduced on the first few frames of the animation film. A real hand comes into the picture and crosses off a third pig. Thereafter action follows the dictates of Señor Gilliam's wonderfully visual mind.
(on animation)
Cut to a group middle-aged lower-middle-class women (hereinafter referred to as 'Pepperpots') being interviewed.
(modestly)
Linkman sitting at desk
Cut to second interviewer an Ross.
looking off-screen
Getting up
Off-screen
(Pats seat)
Cut to linkman, as before
A pig squeals. Interviewer leaps up, grabs a revolver from his desk drawer and fires off-screen.
Third Interviewer and Arthur 'Two Sheds' Jackson. Musical score blow-up behind.
A picture of a shed appears on the screen behind them.
(catches sight of the picture of the shed behind hin)
He points to BP screen shed. The picture of the shed disappears and is replaced by a picture of Jackson. Jackson looks at it carefully.
Cut back to studio: the picture of him is replaced by a picture of two sheds, one with a question mark over it.
Enter Second Interviewer from Edward Ross sketch (John)
They push him away and propel him out.
(he is pushed out of vision with a crash)
(to camera)
Cut to linkman. He is about to speak when:
(off-screen)
(off-screen)
Cut to a man in Viking helmet at desk.
Cut back to linkman.
Cut to Raymond Baxter type standing in front of map. A small cardboard cut-out of Picasso's face is on map and is moved around to illustrate route.
Cut to Vicky, holding a bicycle.
Cut to linkman at desk with Viking on one side and a knight in armour on the other.
Reg Moss standing with hand mike by fairly busy road.
Geppo is in full cyclist's kit.
Cut to Sam Trench at roadside.
A Pepperpot comes up and nudges him.
(excited)
(cylists pass in front of him)
Toulouse-Lautrec pedals past on a child's tricycle.
Cut back to studio.
(pigs head appears over edge of desk; linkman gently pushes it back)
Cartoon sequence of animated Victorian photos, at the end of which a large pig descends, fatally, on a portrait of a man.
Cut to wartime planning room. Two officers are pushing model pigs across the map. A private enters and salutes.

Cut to a suburban house in a rather drab street. Zoom into upstairs window. Seriuos documentary music. Interior of a small room. A bent figure (Michael) huddles over a table, writing. He is surrounded by bits of paper. The camera is situated facing the man as he writes with immense concentration lining his unshaven face.

Ernest stops writing, pauses to look at what he has written... a smile slowly spreads across his face, turning very, very slowly to uncontrolled hysterical laughter... he staggers to his feet and reels across room helpless with mounting mirth and eventually collapses and dies on the floor.

The scribbler's mother (Eric) enters. She sees him dead, she gives a little cry of horror and bends over his body, weeping. Brokenly she notices the piece of paper in his hand and (thinking it is a suicide note - for he has not been doing well for the last thirteen years) picks it up and reads it between her sobs. Immediately she breaks out into hysterical laughter, leaps three feet into the air, and falls down dead without more ado. Cut to news type shot of commentator standing in front of the house.
(reverentially)

At this point an upstairs window in the house is flung open and a doctor, with stetoscope, rears his head out, hysterical with laughter, and dies hanging over the window sill. The commentator and the inspector look up briefly and sadly, and then continue as if they are used to such sights this morning.
(he indicates a little knot of dour-looking policemen standing nearby)
He gives a signal. The group of policemen start groaning and chanting biblical laments. The Dead March is heard. The inspector squares his shoulders and bravely starts walking into the house.
The inspector suddenly appears at the door, helpless with laughter, holding the joke aloft. He collapses and dies.
Cut to film of army vans driving along dark roads.
Cut to door at Ham House: Soldier on guard comes to attention as dispatch rider hurries in carrying armoured box.
(Notice on door: 'Conference. No Admittance'.)

Dispatch nider rushes in. A door opens for him and closes behind him. We hear a mighty roar of laughter... . series of doomphs as the commanders hit the floor or table. Soldier outside does not move a muscle.
Cut to a pillbox on the Salisbury Plain. Track in to slit to see moustachioed top brass peering anxiously out.
Cut to shot looking out of slit in pillbox. Zoom through slit to distance where a solitary figure is standing on the windswept plain. He is a bespectacled, weedy lance-corporal
(Terry Jones)
looking cold and miserable. Pan across to fifty yards away where two helmeted soldiers are at their positions beside a blackboard on an easel covered with a cloth.

Cut in to corporal's face - registening complete lack of comprehension as well as stupidity. Man on top of pillbox waves flag. The soldiers reveal the joke to the corporal. He peers at it, thinks about its meaning, sniggers, and dies. Two watching generals are very impressed.
Cut to a Colonel talking to camera.
Cut to a trench in the Ardennes. Members of the joke brigade are crouched holding pieces of paper with the joke on them.
(together)

Pan out of the British trench across war-torn landscape and come to rest where
     presumably the German trench is. There is a pause and then a group of Germans
     rear up in hysterics.

Cut to a film of Chamberlain brandishing the 'Peace in
our time' bit of paper.
Film of Hitler rally. Hitler speaks; subtitles are superimposed.
A young soldier responds:
Hitler speaks:

Cut to a small squad with rifles making their way through forest. Suddenly one of
     them (a member of the joke squad) sees something and gives signal at which they all dive for cover. From the cover of a tree he reads out joke.
Sniper falls laughing out of tree.
(charging)
They chant the joke. Germans are put to flight laughing, some dropping to ground.
Cut to a German hospital and a ward full of casualties still laughing hysterically.

Cut to Nazi interrogation room. An officer from the joke brigade has a light shining in his face. A Gestapo officer is interrogating him; another (clearly labelled 'A Gestapo Officer') stands behind him.
(slaps him)
(momentarily fooled)
(does so; the Nazi hops in pain)
(mimes cuffing him while the other Nazi claps his hands to provide the sound effct)
Otto (Graham) starts tickling the officer who starts laughing.
They stop.

Otto goes to the typewriter and they wait expectantly. The officer produces piece of
     paper out of his breast pocket and reads.
Otto at the typewriter explodes with laughter and dies.

Bursts into laughter and dies. A guard (Terry G) bursts in with machine gun, The
     British officer leaps on the table.
(lightning speed)
The guard reels back and collapses laughing. British officer makes his escape.
Cut to stock film of German scientists working in laboratories.

Cut to interior. A German general (Terry J) is seated at an imposing desk. Behind him stands Otto, labelled 'A Different Gestapo Officer'. Bespectacled German scientist/joke writer enters room. He clean his throat and reads from card.
He finishes and looks hopeful.
He shoots him.
More stock film of German scientists.
Cut to 1940's wartime radio set with couple anxiously listening to it.
(crackly German voice)
Radio bursts into 'Deutschland Über Alles'. The couple look at each other and then in blank amazement at the radio.
Cut to modern BBC 2 interview. The commentator in a woodland glade.
He walks away revealing a monument on which is written: 'To the unknown Joke'. Camera pulls away slowly through idyllic setting. Patriotic music reaches cresendo.
Cut to football referee who blows whistle. Silence. Blank screen.
The seashore again, with the 'It's' man lying on the beach. A stick from off-screen prods him. Exhausted, he rises and staggers back into the sea.
